name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the European Agenda for Migration (2015/2648(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Commissioners, honourable Members, there is a time for words and there is a time for deeds. I am very proud that today I can speak about concrete actions the European Council and the Council have taken recently in response to the dramatic loss of lives of those seeking shelter in Europe, and I am sure that the Commission will complement that by presenting its view. Let me recall that, at its special meeting of 23 April 2015, the European Council tasked the Presidency and the Commission with ensuring appropriate follow-up to the orientations for tackling this issue and with reporting back to the European Council in June. The Presidency and the Council indeed ensured a swift follow-up. Already by the end of April we prepared, together with the Commission and the European External Action Service, a comprehensive document – a roadmap for the orientations given by the European Council. The Commission, too, did not hesitate. Last week, it presented the expected European Agenda on Migration, earlier than initially planned. I would like to thank the Commission for the comprehensive and immediate action. The roadmap and the agenda contain a number of proposals with a view to strengthening the European presence at sea, fighting traffickers, preventing illegal migration flows and reinforcing internal solidarity and responsibility. As an immediate action, in order to prevent further loss of lives at sea, a tripling of the resources allocated to Frontex has been recognised as a matter of priority. Hence, tomorrow, in the Committee on Budgets, the Presidency will start its first examination of the Commission’s proposal for budgetary amendments. In order to disrupt trafficking networks, special attention in the Council is devoted to stepping up EU efforts in this field.   Let me recall that this Monday at the joint meeting of Foreign Affairs and Defence Ministers, the Council decided to establish an EU military operation – EUNAVFOR Med – as a part of a comprehensive approach to solving the migration crisis in the Mediterranean. The operation aims at breaking the ‘business model’ of human smugglers and traffickers in the Mediterranean. In the medium and long term, we will focus on measures aimed at stopping illegal migration flows. Preventive and comprehensive cooperation with countries of origin and transit, development cooperation, and strengthening of EU delegations in third countries, are matters of particular importance. The necessity to deal with the root causes of the migration flows was emphasised at the joint meeting of Foreign Affairs and Defence Ministers this Monday.  Efficient response to the migration-related challenges is an issue of highest priority for the Council. Yesterday, the General Affairs Council held a thorough discussion on the follow-up to the special meeting of the European Council, and a first exchange of views on the European Agenda for Migration. The issue of broadening the development-migration linkage will be addressed during the meeting of EU Development Ministers on 26 May. The Justice and Home Affairs Council will continue this debate and examine the Migration Agenda on 16 June.  The policy debate covering both immediate and mid-term measures would serve as a contribution to the debate of the Heads of State or Government in the June European Council. The Presidency takes this task very seriously and stands ready to facilitate work in the Council. I can only underline that both the roadmap and the European Agenda on Migration serve as a very important contribution to the current discussion on the EU migratory policy launched by the European Council. Before concluding, let me assure you that the Council and the European Parliament share the same objectives: fair and robust migration policy, assuming responsibilities and showing solidarity. A European solution is necessary, based on solidarity and responsibility, and combining internal and external policies. All contributions are therefore welcome and deserve thorough examination. This is what we will do in the coming weeks.  I would like to conclude by noting that this is at least the fifth time under our Presidency that we have had a migration-related debate at the plenary. This is clear evidence of the prominent place this issue occupies in our agenda.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, following the terrible loss of life in the Mediterranean last month, the European Council stood for a minute’s silence. Leaders made a firm commitment to solidarity among Member States to address the common migratory challenges Europe faces.  The European Agenda on Migration is about turning words into action. It provides for the measures that are urgently needed to deal with a crisis in the Mediterranean and to build a structured response that can be used in cases of extreme pressure on other parts of our shared external border.  The input and support this House gave us in your resolution last month was very important to us in finalising the agenda. We have reacted with more funding and resources for Triton to help it manage borders and save lives. We are taking measures to disrupt the brutal people-smuggling trade and we are proposing hotspot teams to give support on the ground in Member States where the pressure is worse, to help identify, register and fingerprint incoming migrants. The Commission agrees with this House that we must do more to make a reality of the commitment to solidarity and to open up legal channels for those who are most in need of international protection.  Next week, the Commission will propose a temporary relocation mechanism by triggering the emergency clause in Article 78 of the Treaty to help relieve the immediate and exceptional pressure on frontline countries. This Parliament will be formally consulted and we count on your support, and later on we will come back to you to co-decide a standing mechanism for relocation that is automatically triggered whenever there are these extreme crisis situations. Let me underline that this is not about migration in general; it is about extreme crisis situations that demand a clear response. Under the relocation scheme, people of identified nationalities who are most desperately in need of sanctuary will be distributed to other Member States who will then take care of their reception and asylum processing.  The Commission has tabled a distribution key showing what this intra-EU solidarity means in concrete terms for each Member State and the Union as a whole. In parallel, we want to create safe and legal channels for those who really need protection to get to Europe without risking abuse, exploitation and their very lives in the hands of smugglers. We are therefore proposing a humanitarian resettlement scheme working with UNHCR. We are putting an extra EUR 50 million into the scheme, which should result in resettling an additional 20 000 people into the EU over two years.  Beyond the immediate crisis we are setting out a longer-term strategy to address the more fundamental issues of migration in a comprehensive way. These are complex matters and we need to act on all aspects if we want to be effective. That means tackling irregular migration at its source and all along the routes. It means securing our borders and saving lives, but it also has to mean applying our common asylum rules properly. Solidarity can be asked if responsibility is at the same time also taken by all Member States.  Everyone who needs sanctuary should find it in Europe, but those who have no justified claim should be quickly identified and quickly returned to their home country. Effective action on return and limiting the scope for abuse are crucial for the credibility and societal acceptance of migration policy. All too often in our countries people who deserve asylum because they flee war or prosecution are seen as profiteers because we have not been effective enough in having people who do not deserve asylum return to their countries of origin and this needs to change.  Getting these rules working correctly is also a necessary precondition for the serious debate we need to have on the legal migration Europe will need in the future. We will only get citizen support for legal migration if we get all the aspects of a comprehensive migration policy working together. If our people do not trust our asylum policy they will not trust a policy of legal migration. If they do trust our asylum policy because it is effective, they will be more relaxed about the necessity and possibilities of legal migration.  This European Agenda on Migration mobilises all the tools at the EU’s disposal. Our internal policies and our various European agencies should work together. But also, development policy needs to be put in place to address the root causes of migration, as well as a coherent and united foreign policy to bring migration management onto the agenda in our relations with key third countries. Third countries sometimes do not do what they need to do in taking back their nationals who do not have the right to asylum. It is a holistic agenda; an example of the benefits of the new working methods under the Juncker Commission.  These are bold proposals and they are already attracting debate, including among the Member States. But in our view, it is not acceptable for people to say ‘yes, we want you to stop people from drowning’, but at the same time stay silent on where these people should go once they have been rescued.  What the Commission is doing today is putting into practice the commitment the European Council made last month: more responsibility and effective application of our common rules to prevent abuses, going hand—in—hand with more solidarity. I know these are challenging proposals; I know they will prompt debate and controversy in Member States, but it is really not acceptable for people around the EU to say ‘stop the drowning’, and at the same time, to say ‘but do not bring the people here’.  We are setting out today a set of targeted and balanced measures and we will work closely with this Parliament and each of our Member States to match words with action.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, after years in which we have seen migrants dying on our doorstep and in which we have seen the trust of our citizens in the European institutions diminish, it was time to be visionary, to be bold. It was time for the Commission to fulfil its fundamental role as the engine of European integration, taking action on the big challenges of our times. Migration is one of these big challenges. Last year, as Members know, over 620 000 people asked for protection in Europe. The numbers for 2015 show that even that peak may be mild in comparison to the one we will record this year. Seventy thousand asylum applications have already been lodged every month in the European Union since the beginning of 2015. More than 80 000 migrants have reached our shores. Let me be clear: this is not due to any ‘pull factor’. This is because our immediate neighbourhood is on fire. It is because we are living in a time of instability and Europe is seen as a refuge in times of crisis. It is time we started being responsible about it, recognising that we need to start acting together in Europe. The Agenda we have adopted is more ambitious than that. We are proposing to act together on the global stage because managing migration is a shared responsibility across the world. The approval of a common security and defence policy mission in the Mediterranean on Monday by the Council and the efforts of Federica Mogherini to get the United Nations to pass a resolution that will allow Europe to take decisive actions against the criminal networks is a perfect example of this global approach, of this global vision. This effort is part of the immediate response that the European Agenda on Migration suggests in order to deal with the pressure in the Mediterranean and to give an immediate and solid follow-up to the deliberations of this Parliament and of the Heads of State and Government. We are doing so by expanding our capacity to save lives through the tripling of Frontex–led joint operations Triton and Poseidon and by adopting an action plan to fight migrant smuggling in order to respond to two fundamental, understandable and simple questions that we felt remained open. The first question is: ‘What do we do with those we rescue?’ We thought it was time to give a true European response to such fundamental questions, one where every Member State would do its fair share in order to promote the fundamental values of humanity and solidarity on which the European Union is built. This is why, next week, the Commission will propose the triggering of Article 78(3) of the Treaty, an emergency mechanism that was conceived precisely for situations such as those we are facing today: ‘a sudden inflow of nationals of third countries’. The mechanism will allow the transfer of those who are in clear need of protection from the frontline states towards the other Member States. In the past few days, since the adoption of the Agenda, I have heard many complaining that this system is far too oriented to the Mediterranean. Let me be very clear: what we are building today is not only an emergency response to the current pressure, but it is also an emergency mechanism to be applied in the future wherever pressure emerges. Those who help today will be those who may need help tomorrow. I think that this is what solidarity truly means in practice. The second question is: ‘What do we do with those that today use smugglers in order to seek the protection they deserve?’ If we are really serious about the fight against the smugglers, to the point of going to the United Nations Security Council, we need to be equally serious in opening alternative and legal avenues to come to Europe. Again, this is an effort where Europe needs to act as one, with a common and consistent approach. This is why the Commission has proposed a resettlement scheme to transfer 20 000 refugees to Europe from third countries, showing much needed solidarity with our neighbours which are already bearing the brunt of the crisis in Syria and Libya. The Commission will make available EUR 50 million in order to support the Member States. These two mechanisms will be based on a distribution key developed according to objective and clear criteria. I am ready to discuss the criteria retained but, let us be clear, we should not hide behind this discussion to do nothing. Beyond the immediate actions, the European Agenda on Migration also responds to the more fundamental challenges that European society faces. It is an agenda that looks at the medium to long term, in order to lead the way towards a truly common European migration policy in the European Union. In line with the priorities identified by President Juncker in his political guidelines we have built around four key pillars. Firstly, strengthening our capacity to fight irregular migration: in order to do that the Commission will adopt an action plan on smuggling next week and will reinforce the role of Frontex in return operations.  Secondly, protecting migrants in need of international protection: the Commission will promote and monitor the full implementation of the Common European Asylum System and will take action to fight abuses.  Thirdly, strengthening the shared management of our external borders: Frontex will be reinforced and more coherent standards will be developed.  Fourthly, the European Union’s demographic and skill needs mean that legal migration will be a necessary part of our future. So the Commission intends to develop a new policy on legal migration starting with revision of the Blue Card Directive. The principle is very simple. Europe will extend a helping hand to those in need and will strive to attract those we need, but this will be balanced by strong and targeted action for those who try to abuse our system. As I said, our objective is to give a comprehensive response and one that also encompasses the enormous demographic challenges Europe faces. While the working age population in the European Union will decline by 17.5 million, foreign skilled workers who can complement our own will be important to support Europe’s economic development. The Agenda is about concrete actions and initiatives, which are realistic and can be implemented if we all take part consistently in this shared effort. To do this, I need the support of this House, which has always been in the forefront in advocating true and effective solidarity. More than ensuring that the current system delivers its full potential, the Agenda finally launches parallel reflections for deepening our future European cooperation in the field of migration. This includes ideas such as the establishment of a European single asylum decision-making process or a European border guards system. I look forward to hearing your reactions.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioners, commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Before Going into the matter, I would like to sacrifice one minute of my speaking time and take a quick look back at the British elections. I am pleased that David Cameron has achieved good electoral success with his approach to fiscal consolidation and also with his approach to reform. Above all, however, I would like to welcome the election loser, our colleague Mr Farage. I would like to welcome the great election loser of Great Britain back here. I would like to emphasise that he has now found something positive about Europe, namely the fact that Europe obviously has a much better electoral system than The United Kingdom. Because if Europe did not have a proportional electoral system, it would no longer have a job today – let us say it – because its British voters did not vote for him. And I note that Mr Farage has lost all credibility. He has announced that if British voters do not elect him, he will resign as party leader. He has said he will resign and will not continue in office. You don't need to justify it by the fact that your great party executive has kneeled you to keep going. The fact is that you, Mr Farage, are not keeping their election promises. You are still here, you are further here as party leader and have broken an important election promise. Welcome back, and it's good that you're the big election loser. It was worth sacrificing one minute of speaking time, ladies and gentlemen. But now we are talking about the migration debate, and Here I would like to thank the Commission – Frans Timmermans, Mr Avramopoulos and our Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker – because the proposals on the table provide an overall proposal on how we can tackle the great challenge of migration. First of all, even if we look at the debates in the Council, the central question is: how do the citizens see this question? When citizens watch pictures from the Mediterranean on tv every night – in Great Britain, Poland, Germany, Spain: how do citizens see this? When people see the television pictures, there is a feeling that they say: as a British, as a Pole, as an Austrian, something is at stake for me? And I am convinced that most people in Europe say: yes, these pictures do not leave me cold, that concerns me. And if you are aware of this, it is also clear that we need European responses to the fact that we Europeans are jointly called upon to tackle this challenge. We welcome the solidarity mechanism, especially with regard to the UNHCR, and we welcome the criteria that have been considered. In my group too, I would like to say that there are still tough debates on the issue of the design of the solidarity mechanism, and there are still many discussions. But the basic approach is welcomed. We must put a stop to the smugglers. There are concrete proposals for this. The military option must also remain on the table. We welcome the partnership with the countries of origin: it is good that we are meeting in Malta to talk to the partner countries at the joint summit. We also welcome the fact that it is clear that we must also enforce the law. I would like to express my thanks to the two Commissioners for saying that we must also repate those who have just been rejected in the procedure under the rule of law, and that we must also enforce law in the European Union. Otherwise, we may lose citizens' confidence in our rule of law in the long term. I would also like to add that in some Countries of the European Union refugees from the Balkans – that is, from Europe – are a relevant group of refugees. This, too, must be addressed. It is difficult to explain that refugees who apply for asylum come from countries with which we are in accession talks to the European Union. That is why we must also address these issues, which are more difficult. Thank you to the Commission. Many of the European Parliament's issues have been included. The close partnership also shows this, and I am grateful for that. And now to the Council: there we have a plethora of 'no' sayers, of people who are already aware of what is not working. It is petty what we are experiencing there, namely only looking at one's own figures, at one's own personal situation, and, unfortunately, god does not look at the common task that is before us. I hope that the European Council in June will be able to overcome this, that we in the European Council really get a European view that the European Council will have a view of the Commission proposals are referred to and that the will to give the answers together will then also be apparent. I would like to appeal to the media not to always say – when these statements come from the Council – that Europe has failed because there is a clear will here in the European Parliament, because there is a clear will in the Commission. That is why it is the Member States that do not support joint European initiatives if it fails here. We are ready to continue the good job that the Commission has now put forward, and I would ask the Commission to make ambitious further proposals ... (Unrest) Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I would simply like to send my backing to the Commission, because the proposal is a good one. If you are now discussing with the Member States, you can point to my view, to the view of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, that we are jointly supporting these initiatives that have now been presented. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! I would ask you to moderate a little. I am also very generous in your speaking time. If you exceed the speaking times, mrs Ferrara, for example, I am not shouting at you either. I didn't do that yesterday. I also gave you more speaking time yesterday. That is why you should be a little fairer on this issue.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Mr Weber, my question is this: do you not realise that the kind of intervention you made at the start of your speech is exactly why UKIP’s vote trebled in the elections in the UK. Four million people do not want this kind of intervention from people from the outside, like you, talking about our domestic issues, telling us – and I will be more pertinent to this discussion than you were – about what kind of immigration we can have, what we can do with our own borders, and then intervening in our own domestic politics and spending a minute and a half of your own time poking fun at us. They do not want that. Four million people said: Sorry, Mr Weber, go away!

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I can understand the emotion, as I said. I have pointed out that you, personally and also Mr Farage, should finally say thank you that Europe has such a great electoral system. Compared to the British one, you have a job here, you are paid by the European taxpayer. You should say thank you, before you say loudly here that Europe is so good. And the second is that I am simply concerned with the fact that Mr Farage has announced that he will resign as party leader if he loses. That was the thesis that stood in the room. And he sits here as party leader. In this respect, Mr Farage's credibility has been destroyed.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, this is a point of order. Irrespective of the emotions and the response across the Chamber with regards to these comments from Mr Weber, he started his speech saying: I am prepared to sacrifice a minute of my speaking time to speak on the British domestic general election. And yet, Mr President, with respect, you allowed him to speak for a minute over his allocated speaking time. So how did he sacrifice any speaking time?

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we can say without rhetoric that the immigration package presented by the European Commission represents a turning point for this parliamentary term and I would like to acknowledge that this College, and in particular President Juncker, Vice-President Timmermans, Commissioner Avramopoulos and Federica Mogherini, have acted courageously.  If a word were to sum up this strategy, I would say 'solidarity': solidarity with the men and women crossing the Mediterranean, solidarity with the peoples and Member States most exposed to migratory phenomena.  The Commission's strategy contains all the answers to the challenge of immigration. In the short term, the establishment of a quota system for asylum seekers will ensure more supportive and responsible management of flows, the strengthening of Poseidon and Triton will help to prevent further tragedies in the sea, and the mobilisation of the European Union alongside the United Nations must instead aim to defeat human traffickers and smugglers.  Let me be clear on this point: for us Socialists, there is no military intervention in Libya. The aim of our action must be to destroy the supply chains of traffickers, and to this end we must equip ourselves with all possible instruments. No pietism, no shyness with the merchants of death who profit on migrants.  In the text presented there is also a long-term vision, built around three pillars. First of all, we need to strengthen the common asylum system by reforming Dublin. The second pillar is the creation of a shared system of border management that controls our borders, without falling into the illusion that they can or should be hermetically sealed. There is, in fact, no direct relationship between terrorism and immigration. And then, finally, a European policy on legal immigration. These are the stages in front of us. A path begins, a path that is finally holistic, unified.  I would like to end with an appeal to the Member States. I appeal to all the Heads of Government, especially the most reluctant ones: do not throw this opportunity away, do not bow to blackmail by those who foment fear. Europe has often been accused of speaking, of speaking, of speaking but of not acting. With these measures we are finally demonstrating that Europe can work. Let us not miss this opportunity. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: João FERREIRA
text: according to the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, Mr Pittella has spoken to us here in a sympathetic response. I wanted to ask you whether in your concept of solidarity it is up to sending warships to the Mediterranean, in addition to air and land means, violating the sovereignty and territorial integrity of sovereign states and international law to sink boats aimed at transporting immigrants.  And by the way, what do you have to say about what the European Council of Refugees and Exiles said, which warned of the risk of more victims with these solutions, either by sinking boats with immigrants or because they are forced to look for other riskier solutions to reach Europe? Is this your concept of solidarity? Is this your group's concept of solving the problem at source?

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Mr Ferreira, you have probably missed a passage in my speech, in which I made it clear that a military mission is not at stake for us Socialists. So no force or violence against this situation, but only the use of other tools to fight and defeat the smugglers.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, in saving lives, addressing the criminality of human trafficking and stabilising the EUʼs external borders through cooperation are vital factors. We have a moral duty to assist one another, but I do not believe that this assistance should undermine the key international principle of humanitarian and asylum law: that an individual should be able to seek sanctuary in the first safe country reached.  True solidarity is offering assistance because it is the right thing to do – not through compulsion. I do not believe that quotas and forced relocation are sustainable, democratic or fair to the individuals in question. It is a mistake to have a strategy which addresses all kinds of migration in one document. Economic migration and asylum are two very different issues, with separate challenges, and this joint strategy blurs lines which should be clear.  We do agree on the important role of Frontex, EASO, returns and Eurodac, and the need for increased funding in tackling the issue at source, and we look forward to working with the Commission on this important issue. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Vicky FORD
text: blue-card question. – We are very lucky to have Mr Kirkhope here because he has been a minister with responsibility for immigration in a British Conservative government. Mr Kirkhope, could you explain, for the benefit of others, the difference between having a Conservative immigration minister back in the Council and one from some of the other parties that might perhaps have been there?

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, I wonder whether that is a hostile question; I think perhaps it is not. My reaction to it is that I am very proud of what I did when I was Immigration Minister; I am proud of the fact that we have a Conservative Government. I am also proud of the fact that it is a government which deals with immigration issues by mixing humanitarian approaches with responsibility and security.  Were we to have seen a different outcome in our elections recently, with any need to concur with some of the more extreme views that certain parties have expressed, I would be a very disappointed man, and it would not help those who sought sanctuary or those who wish to deal with immigration rules for their benefit.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! The process we have just experienced is interesting. The ECR Group is using the instrument of intermediate questions to continue a piece of the British election campaign and, at the same time, to extend its own speaking times a little. We did not introduce the instrument for this. So assume that I cannot accept every blue card, not every intermediate question here. You simply have to realise that this is not the instrument by which we wanted to make the debates more lively, by giving individual groups the opportunity, as in this case, representatives of the United Kingdom to play internal games. I shall therefore think carefully about the way in which we will continue to deal with this instrument.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, firstly I have to tell Mr Weber that he does not understand how this works. He is a man of his word, Nigel Farage. He has sent a letter to Nigel Farage saying ‘I resign’. Nigel Farage has responded to Nigel Farage saying ‘I refuse your resignation.’ That is the way it works! So, that said, let us come to the topic of today. Mr Timmermans, I strongly support the Commission’s proposal of last week on migration, because I think the Commission has assumed your responsibility, and that is not the case with the Council. The Commission has, in fact, taken a stance that is absolutely necessary because it promotes the interest of all, rather than focusing on single Member States, and that is what we have to do to tackle this problem. We cannot continue to say it is only the Italians who have to do their job; we cannot say it is the European Union which is at the source of this problem. What we need is a European solution to a European problem. I want to condemn very strongly those Member States who say officially that they are in solidarity but are already stating, as we have heard, that they will object to the use of the temporary protection procedure. With regard to the temporary protection procedure, I think, Commissioner, that Article 78(3) of the Treaty was especially created for that purpose. So let us use it now: it is only right that the Commission should exploit it. What I do not understand is those – like the Prime Minister of France, Mr Valls, last Sunday I think – who say ‘I am against quotas but I am for solidarity in this field.’ I do not understand this. It is either one thing or the other. Secondly, I agree with the Commission that the right approach is to start first with temporary protection and only then, at a later stage, to work on a permanent procedure to replace the Dublin rules. However, I think it shall be necessary to replace Dublin, and to do so not by recommendations, Commissioner, but through real legislation.  Let us also be clear in this debate that we cannot go down the road of what we are currently hearing: anti-European, xenophobic talk in which people are mixing everything up – asylum seekers, refugees, economic migrants. It is simply not acceptable to do as some people are doing and equate migrants with terrorists. So, colleagues, we have a responsibility as the European Union because – and let us be honest among ourselves – if we have such flows coming to Europe it is in part because of European Union inaction in our neighbourhood. We did nothing, after all, in Libya, and we did nothing in Syria, and that is one of the reasons why so many refugees are now seeking to enter the Union. We have to learn from that, which means we need to assume our responsibilities in our neighbourhood. Our Group supports the Commission proposals as a first step. Action is needed, Commissioner – joint action, common action, and that means European action. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" question. I regret that I am only addressing you. I have long asked everyone who has spoken so far from the factions the following question which also has to do with the suggestions: on the causes of immigrants, economic migrants, and on the causes of refugees, I have not heard a word so far. Please, once again, because it seems that the bureau's left eye doesn't see me, take a little care this way. Thanks!

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for his You can reply on behalf of all Members, because the question was addressed to all Members. Take advantage of this unique opportunity!

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, it is a little difficult for me to speak on behalf of the whole Parliament. I would have to sit in your seat to do that!

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Well. But I am grateful, Mr Glezos, for criticising me for being blind in my left eye. Otherwise I will always be criticized, I would be blind in my right eye. So that has now been balanced.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Let me begin with George Orwell's vision. Winston Smith, Orwell's hero, begins his secret diary on April 4, 1984: "Last Night in the Cinema," reads the first entry, "loud war movies; a very good one about a ship of refugees being bombed somewhere in the Mediterranean; viewers very amused." Now I do not assume that anyone here in this room has been amused by this tragedy in the Mediterranean. But fiction can become a reality. The shelling or sinking of refugee boats as part of the overall package at least – and this must be made clear here – at least accepts so-called collateral damage, namely the deaths of people – refugees, boatmen and also members of the armed forces involved. In principle, however, I would also like to mention the criticism of the behaviour of the Member States here. The basis for what we are discussing today and the framework laid by the Summit of Heads of Government. And when the Commission talks about realistic, enforceable measures, its realism is shaped by and geared to the behaviour of the Member States. And therein lies the crux at the same time. With all due will, the package presented does not change the perspective of the suffering of the refugees. It still deals with the refugee issue, above all from a security point of view and from an economic point of view. The fundamental question arises here: What do we actually mean by security? Can security really only be achieved if we close our own borders and close Europe down? The package and the agreement of the foreign and defence ministers are primarily aimed at repressive measures against stakeholders. But repression, which destroys the conditions of existence of human beings, does not contribute to greater security, but to less. They continue to drive people into the clutches of terrorists and do not protect them from them. We do not deprive the business basis of organised smuggling with military intervention. The refugee problem remains. And so the question arises: why do we not cry out when it comes to cutting the World Food Programme, for example.B? Why do we not cry out when we see how many refugee camps outside the European Union people live in the most unworthy conditions? The refugee problem, as I said, remains. We are simply pushing it from our point of view and from our point of view from the Mediterranean to the Libyan border. And anyone who has seen that 190 dead people have been found behind the Libyan border in the last few weeks alone, and anyone who has seen the images of the refugee reception camps must simply ask themselves the question: what are we really doing, and are we prepared to approach the refugee problem in a very different way, mainly on humanitarian grounds? Are we prepared to accept that we must change ourselves, our lives, our standards, in order to really offer people the help they need? I can't see that yet! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Zimmer, do you not think it is highly frivolous to make the claim here, which is definitely just the untruth that we intend to shell and bomb refugee boats and, with intent, to accept, so to speak, the death, the collateral damage of refugees and boaters? The fight is human traffickers, and you know that. I call on you to stick to the truth and not to talk about something that neither the European Commission's external envoy nor a single Member State intends.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Hohlmeier, I have not spoken of the fact that somewhere in the text it says that people themselves will be targeted. But you know very well that as soon as armed forces are deployed, as soon as weapons and military are deployed and fired, and as soon as boats are destroyed, the risk is huge that people will also perishe in the process. Nowhere in the world will they find a form of military intervention in which there is no so-called collateral damage in which people die. And I would ask you to take note of this at last: there will be no clean intervention in this sense, as you say about it!

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – It is grate for the European Commission to fight with the Council to distribute refugees fairly across Europe, and I am therefore saddened to see Member State after Member State report that it does not want to do so. The only approach that seems to be shared with the Council is to tackle military action, increase border controls and send more people back.  I heard you yesterday, Commissioner Timmermans, stories about the Hungarian refugees who were welcomed with open arms in other European countries in 1956. Those open arms, where are they now? They are not with the Council, but they are not with you, Commissioner, nor the Commission. The Dublin review is not in the proposals, and that is what you wanted so badly, Mr Avramopoulos? I thought we were going to see what we were going to do about Dublin. I can't find it. I think there is a difference of opinion in the Commission and that you are therefore not coming up with your proposals.  You write in your own agenda that Europe will see a demographic deficit in the near future. But you leave it at that. Do I have to fill it out myself? An ancient continent surrounded by countries with young populations cannot limit itself to combating illegal migration through tighter controls. A rich continent surrounded by countries at war or in poverty cannot afford to do so. If there is work for low-skilled or low-paid workers, then you will have to facilitate it, because otherwise you will see illegality and illegal work increase. In the previous period, we saw the directive on seasonal work. We should have built on that now. Where are the proposals for facilitating the Palestinian nannies, ladies who are doing illegal work with us, which no one else wants to do? Where are the proposals for circular migration?  Mr. President, you can create an agenda for a week. You can create a calendar for a few months. You can make an agenda until the sea is rough again and the refugees stay on the other side for a while. But I expect the European Commission to set an agenda for the next few years, for the next generation. Unfortunately, it is not there, Mr President. (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mrs Sargentini, why, before you give a fiery speech on the admission of refugees from the time of communism, you will not find out anything about how today, for example, the Czech Republic accepts refugees from Ukraine. Are you concerned that the Czech Republic is the country with the third largest number of refugees from Ukraine? Have you ever been collecting this information? Have you ever been to refugee camps in the Czech Republic? Did you see the situation? Please correct your information before you start criticizing anyone here.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: "blue card" answer. – I would like to accept the invitation to visit a refugee camp in the Czech Republic. I really appreciate any country's inclusion of refugees. I do think that we are still not doing enough. Resettling 20 000 people from refugee camps is a good endeavour that the Member States do not want. But it's only a tiny bit. I would also like to say, and that is the latter, that there is quite a difference between the different countries when people are admitted, after granting a status and giving a real new life to these people.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to extend huge thanks all of those who have welcomed me back to this institution so warmly. I do detect, however, in some of the smiles and laughter directed at me, a slight hint of nervousness – and so there jolly well should be because there is going to be a British referendum on whether we stay in or whether we leave this European Union. For the first time in many decades there will be a fundamental debate on the existence of this Union and the need for it in the modern world. I have to say that this referendum would not have happened without UKIP and its people’s army of millions of supporters.  It is pretty clear that, actually, when it comes to renegotiation, nothing substantial can be achieved, because already all the big bosses in Europe have said that the freedom-of-movement rules are not up for negotiation and that there will be no treaty change on this point. That, for us, is simply not good enough, and it goes to the heart of the debate this morning. What we want in Britain is an Australian-style points system so that we can choose who comes to live, work and settle in our countries. I would bet that, if such a proposal were put to all of your electorates in your Member States, they too would opt for that policy. A month ago I warned Mr Timmermans that the common EU asylum policy had absolutely no security checks whatsoever and that there was a genuine threat of ISIS using this policy to infiltrate our countries and to pose great threats to our society. I was laughed at out loud here. People said I had no evidence for it. Well, now even the Libyan intelligence agencies are saying that ISIS are not only making money from trafficking people but are also beginning to send us their terrorists directly. We need to have another think. We must not allow our compassion to imperil our security. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, listening to Mr Farage, and thinking more about it, I now have a second thought. If I put a question to Mr Farage, he is probably going to reply in his personal, populist, demagogical way and, if anything, that is going to threaten his political career even further. I really do not want to do that. At the same time, his presence here, his interventions and those of his Group represent for us a huge incentive to continue European integration as much as possible... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: – Today we discuss the migration agenda. A flut piece first class.  We need to redistribute the thousands of illegal immigrants. Each country will soon receive a proportionate share of the number of illegal immigrants and terrorists. Those who believe that they will be attracted to quotas have not understood it. They will move freely, because our borders are gone. And with the increasing flow of illegal immigrants, the dangers are only increasing. Not for these fortune seekers, because for them we are expanding the rescue missions, but for the inhabitants of the European Union.   If you think it couldn't be more idiotic, then there's always Ms Mogherini: "No refugees or migrants intercepted at sea will be sent back against their will." she said yesterday.  Smiling third parties are the people smugglers, because they make one rich. Not to mention the terrorists of the Islamic State who are travelling among the illegal immigrants, who will cause death and destruction in the European Union. The losers are the inhabitants of the European countries. Our borders must be secure, watertight. Real border security, like in Australia. They send back the illegal immigrants and there are no people drowning off the coast. That's where we need to go.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! Before I give the floor to Mrs Hohlmeier, I would like to make it clear once again that we have introduced this instrument of the blue card in order to be able to be a little more animated in the debate, but also in a matter-of-fact manner. If, firstly, these blue cards mean that our debates are usually extended by half an hour and that the Presidents-in-Office then have to be slammed for not keeping to the times, and secondly, if they are used to extend speaking times or for any personal explanations, then they do not make sense. I therefore am sure that I will reflect with the Bureau on how we can prevent this misuse of this instrument.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioners for their excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I welcome the Commission's agenda on migration. Firstly, it makes sense to have a crisis mechanism that takes place in times of crisis. Dublin makes sense when we have peaceful times, when there are few migrants and when a Member State is not overwhelmed. From the moment a Member State is confronted with a mass influx, there must be a functioning crisis mechanism and therefore also a correspondingly meaningful distribution mechanism. Secondly, I welcome the fact that there is also greater thought on the legal channels in terms of resettlement, humanitarian visas, temporary status options, but also in an attempt to strengthen these instruments. Because if the fight against the traffickers of human beings is taken seriously – and I believe that everyone in this House should be in favour of combating traffickers, because they are not friends of the refugees, but often criminals who accept their deaths, who torture them, who kill them, who use them for organ trafficking, who use them for all the evils that no human being can advocate – if we are to fight the fight against traffickers. , which I very much support, just as a military action of a targeted and targeted nature is taking serious action seriously, but then it also means that we, as the European Union, must make a contribution to facilitating and improving the refugee situation. However, an efficient return programme is also needed in the event that someone abuses our right to asylum or is in the countries illegally and a Member State alone may not have the strength to repate these people, but needs the support of the European Union to do so.  However, I would like to make one criticism very clear, and that concerns the staff, the personnel wishes. The fact that Europol is strengthened with three people and eASO with four people cannot be seen as a serious contribution to a European programme in the field of asylum and as a solution to the refugee situation. Sorry, dear Commission: these two posts are simply a joke!

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, after the last great tragedy of the Mediterranean the convening of the meeting of Heads of State and Government was as urgent as so, so scarce in content and compromise. Parliament has been much more ambitious the five times it has dealt with this issue in plenary and in the resolution it has recently adopted. The Commission has been ambitious and concrete and the Member States should have reacted by supporting the Commission, noting: we want joint action, we want to be in solidarity to respond to this humanitarian crisis; we are ready to put more means to deal with it and are prepared for a long-term strategy that addresses the causes behind these tragedies.  However, they have reacted in a regulatory manner: we agree or disagree with this principle, with this criterion, with this indicator. That is not the way to react to this problem: the way to react is with political will and with commitment. It has been said before that now is the time for sanctions and not just words; I go back to the Ecclesiastes: "It is time to sow and then the time will come to collect". If we don't sow now, we'll collect many more tragedies.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The vast majority of my previous previous spokes represent countries – let us be clear – which for centuries owed a great deal to colonies whose economic position was stronger than other European countries because they had colonies. Today, these immigrants are the interest on those profits that these countries, the states of the old Union, had from the colonies. I say as a historian, and agree with the truth that these interest must be paid. That's the first thing. Secondly, my country has welcomed many thousands of Chechens after Russia's attack. As recently as last year alone, six thousand and eighty-four Chechen citizens applied for asylum in Poland. This shows that my country is open to refugees, but that does not mean that all decisions of the European Union are in this regard.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to thank the Commission for the European Agenda on Migration. I particularly appreciate the holistic view expressed. It is also very gratifying that the European Parliament and the Commission speak the same language. In this context, the Member States leave a great deal to be desired. What is lacking in this document remains a more far-reaching vision for migration policy in Europe, such as what a common European handling of asylum cases in order to ensure the same treatment and participation could look like. It is together that we can make a joint effort, that is, when all countries, in solidarity, take their share of responsibility for those who have to flee when the world is on fire. Because if all 28 countries share responsibility, we can together provide protection to more people and at the same time guarantee legal certainty in the asylum system.  Like the Commission, I too believe that this distribution should be based on quantitative data. It is also important to take into account qualitative data such as language, culture and family ties in order to facilitate integration as well. It is impossible to legislate for solidarity. Solidarity must be built when trust is built. I now call on the Presidency of the Council to take political responsibility for the Member States to stop shoveling responsibility over to someone else. It is not okay for six countries in the EU to take the greatest responsibility for more than 80% of asylum seekers, while 22 countries do almost nothing at all. I also believe that, in evaluating the Dublin Regulation in 2016, the Commission should benefit from the experience of redistribution of resettlement. I hope it can be the beginning of the end of the Dublin Regulation and the first-country of arrival principle. It is a failed relic of the legal situation and legal instruments of the 20th century. Asylum policy in europe in our time can and should be so much better when we share responsibility with each other. It is now time for us to move from words to deeds. I welcome what the Commission has done in this document, and it is wonderful that the European Parliament and the Commission speak the same language. Now the Member States must deliver!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before giving the floor to Mr Beazley, i.e. the Committee on The Vergiat, I wanted to inform the House that, given the time, given the very high number of speakers and also given the very high number of requests for catch the eye, except in exceptional cases or for personal reasons I will not authorize "blue card" questions.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Mr President, the European migration programme is not up to the task of preventing deaths in the Mediterranean and in dealing with the humanitarian crisis that is actually playing out on our borders. We stick to the same logic with the four pillars. But when we hear the reaction of the Member States, we are appalled: not a shadow of hesitation to embark on a high-risk military operation, including for migrants. Here we have the financial and human resources. But to save human lives, it's ridiculous. Just compare the numbers.  Governments respond by amalgamating migrants, asylum seekers and refugees. With regard to resettlement, the Spanish government tells us that the unemployment rate and the effort should be integrated. Commissioner, I wonder if they have read your proposals. France argues that this calls into question the principle of subsidiarity in the field of asylum. I pass on the reactions of Great Britain, Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and the Baltic countries which do not make much effort in this area. We're in a state of delirium.  Member States play with fear. They're chasing the far right. When will they finally become aware of the challenges that will arise in the European Union in the coming years, in terms of demographics and economics? All human lives have the same value. Where is the solidarity of the Member States?  Yes, the Union must act, and Member States must respect the law, international law, starting with the right of asylum.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, I would just like to remind us of what we are actually talking about here. Approximately 2 000 people have died this year alone in the Mediterranean, and to single out just one example of a conflict, Syria has already produced more than four million refugees living outside Syria in camps for four years in unbearable conditions. That is the situation we are talking about.  And what do we do? We argue about 20 000 resettlement places with a ‘yes or no’ and about quotas with a ‘yes or no’. The only thing governments seem to be agreeing on is that they want to send their armies out against smugglers – as if that would help. The only thing that helps against smugglers is to open safe and legal ways of entry for refugees.  Mr Avramopoulos, you were rightly calling for that. But are we then going to stop at 20 000 resettlement places? Is that really all? I think we need to go far beyond that.  Regarding relocation: yes, it is absolutely right to have now a short-term crisis mechanism, but we should not stop there. We need to thoroughly reform the Dublin Regulation, because if a system does not work when it is really needed then it is high time to think about something else.  Solidarity should not remain an empty word here. We need solidarity amongst Member States, but also with those people who are really in need of protection. Mr Timmermans also rightly said that we need to increase acceptance; but for that I think we need governments to really work for that acceptance and to argue for that acceptance, and not claim that people fleeing from war and persecution are a problem that you can send the army against and that this is going to be the solution to it all.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, good morning, Mr Avramopoulos, good morning, Commissioner Timmermans. We have heard the Commission say that the European agenda on immigration wants to change words into action and that the contribution of the European Parliament resolution has been very important.  Well, I would now really like to see what impact the proposals presented by the European Commission will have on the facts, first ly the temporary and then permanent resettlement mechanism: Article 78 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union is invoked, which therefore provides for a temporary mechanism to deal with emergency situations of mass influx; no mention of the revision of the Dublin Regulation, no mention of the new legal avenues for access to the European Union. What does it actually change? When will certain situations be identified as emergency and when, say, everything will return to normal activity?  It seems to me once again to be the celebration of hypocrisy. In fact, Italy, like so many other Mediterranean countries, will continue to receive hundreds and hundreds of migrants who will continue to risk their lives aboard the dinghies. So I would like to understand, in fact, what is new about this Eu ropean Union agenda. Furthermore, with regard to the distribution between the Member States, there has been no mention of the refusal announced by France, the United Kingdom and Hungary. How do solidarity and cooperation apply here? Do they impose themselves? It seems to me that this is a real failure of those principles on which the European Union is founded. In conclusion, I would like to address the Council: I would have liked to have heard a few more news about this EUNAVFOR MED military operation. What is it, in fact? Is this the famous barges bombing? Is this really how we think we are solving the problem of organised crime for human traffickers? Can we have some further clarification, rather than reading it in the newspapers?

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Earlier this week, we read in the renowned German daily die Welt: "Uncontrolled immigration is not a human right, but leads to an unexplained civil war." I ask the Commissioners present: what are you doing with your policy, with your agenda on migration? You should be protecting Europe, you should defend Europe, you should defend the social achievements of this continent. Instead, I have the impression that cruises to hell are being organized here. Because it is only because you tolerate migration via Lampedusa, which is organised by criminals, that people have made their way to hell in the first place. Mr Timmermans, if you want a humanitarian resettlement programme, if Mr Avramopoulos says that the comprehensive answer is legal migration, then I wonder what do you want to achieve with it? Do you want to bring even more cheap human slaves to Europe, instead of helping people where they come from, so that they also have a future and a perspective in their own homeland?

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Nixtieq li nibda llum billi nirringrazzja flower-gumsjoni għall-kuraġġ tagħha meta ressqet politika ġdida dwar l-immigrazzjoni. Din hi l-aktar policy ambizzjuża li qatt kellna u pass kbir 'il quddiem. Finalment għandna quddiemna rikonoxximent li l-immigrazzjoni hi sfida Ewropea li teħġtie risposta komuni Ewropea, fejn hawk Stat Membru jimxi b'solidarjetà. Nilqa' b'mod partikolari l-proposta dwar ir-rilokazzjoni u t-tqassim ġust bejn l-Istati Membri ta' individwi li jgawdu protezzjoni internazzjonali. Nistenna b'ħerqa l-leġiżlazzjoni dwar dan. L-isfida issa hi li jiġi żgurat li l-proposti jgħaddu minn fuq il-karta għall-azzjoni konkreta mill-Istati Membri. Nifhem li hawn Stati li għadhom mhumiex konvinti, però hawnekk m'aħniex qed nitkellmu dwar il-karità. Ebda Stat Membru ma jista' jeżonera lilu nnifsu mir-responsabbiltà li għandu bl-iskuża li ma jinsabx ġeografikament fil-Mediterran.  Il-ftehim mill-Istati Membri li sar nhar it-Tnejn dwar l-operazzjoni navali biex tattakka t-traffikanti huwa wkoll pass. B'hedge se jitnaqqas it-traffikar tan-nies u jfisser ukoll aktar assi fil-baħar li jwassal biex aktarħajjiet jiu salvati. Fl-istess ħin i nistgħux nippermettu li din il-missjoni tnaqqas mill-focus minn fuq il-kriżi umanitarja fil-Mediterran. Kwalunkwe operazzjoni trid timxi id f'id ma' inizjattivi oħra sabiex jiġi żgurat li jkun hemm azzjoni li tolqot hawk aspett ta' din il-kwistjoni. Jekk l-Istati Membri huma kapa大i jaqblu dwar azzjoni militari ma hemm ebda skuża biex ma jaqblux li kulħadd għandu jerfa' parti mill-piż biex ikun hemm tqassim ġust tar-responsabbiltà. L-immigrazzjoni hi realtà. Għandna bżonn nimplimentaw miżuri permanenti u fit-tul. Irridu nħarsu lil hinn mill-mandat politiku tagħna bl-iskadenza li dan għandu. Jeħtieġ, u nagħlaq, li nieħdu d-deħiżjonijiet li jistgħu jkunu iebsa imma li jkunu meħtieġa u li nispera li l-Prim Minister jkollhom il-kuraġ liġ jagħmlu l-istess.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the How are we going to deal with the refugees in the Mediterranean? The Response of the Member States so far: to combat smugglers, including by military means. I reject military action. The fight against criminal smugglers remains the right one. But without safe routes to Europe for people fleeing war and persecution, the message is: stay away from Europe! It is cynical, for example, for our states to warn, on the one hand, that ISIS terrorists could also commit brutal crimes in our country and, on the other, not to accept people fleeing precisely these crimes. It is now necessary for all Member States to show solidarity so that we can welcome people and integrate them into our societies. No, we cannot accept all those who come to Europe and want to work here. We must therefore also address the causes of flight. For example, 0.7% of gross domestic product is to be used for development aid. However, only five of our Member States have achieved this objective. Other policy areas are also being put to the test. I would like to see more international cooperation here. Finally, in future, all our Member States will need immigration into labour markets, into all areas of qualification. It is therefore high time that we designed a European immigration policy. The Commission's proposal is a first step in the right direction. But now the Member States must act.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: I have thoroughly reviewed the migration agenda, which is a good start to debate. However, I cannot allow it to be repeated that the existing European framework on asylum, including the Dublin rules and fingerprinting, is a good basis. This must first be done fully and correctly. Practice shows that the Dublin system is not working as it should. Moreover, economic migrants, i.e. people who are not entitled to asylum, are not sent back. The Commission will therefore have to be very careful about the evaluation of the Dublin system and also examine thoroughly why it does not work. Otherwise, we risk drawing the wrong conclusions, with the result that the whole asylum system will be even more shaken. Only then can we possibly talk about relocation, resettlement and legal migration routes. First things first.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Mr President, allow me, in a minute, to send congratulations and a cry of anger. Congratulations because, in my turn, I want to welcome the European Commission's programme proposal. Finally, it is an awareness of the scale of the migration phenomenon in Europe. Finally! Thousands of years after terrible shipwrecks in the Mediterranean. Finally! While we have been strongly denouncing the failure of the Dublin system for a long time. Finally! Because we have been advocating for years for a revision of the blue card directive. This awareness, which comes late, is an awareness that has the merit of existing and, above all, of proposing actions, of formulating innovative pragmatic proposals and - I want to stress here - courageous. A cry of anger also because I, in turn, want to denounce the scandalous reactions of some Member States which are a bit like the Janus bifront, the Roman god with two profiles, who, on the one hand, recognise in their states, through compassionate speeches, the need for solidarity and who, on the other hand, with the other profile, as soon as a courageous solution such as that is put on the table , oppose it head-on, as do some heads of government whom I will not appoint. This strategic document is a real step forward. I call on the Council to encourage Member States to take action, to act and to translate these proposals into action. At the same time, it is appropriate for all of us to also express this European solidarity, with long-term measures on the causes, as was pointed out very effectively this morning.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, civil war, deprivation and astounding levels of poverty have driven thousands of migrants to risk their lives crossing the Mediterranean to the EU. Traffickers and smugglers have willingly exploited the desperation of those fleeing their homes. As a result, many have perished. Some argue that military action targeting and destroying smugglers’ boats, despite the threat to migrants’ lives, will solve the problem. Bonkers! It is clear that military intervention in the Middle East and North Africa has only exacerbated social, economic and ethnic tensions in the region.  Military intervention in Iraq and Libya have created both the conditions for further conflict from which people flee and the instability that allows smugglers and traffickers to operate with relative impunity. We need, without doubt, a humanitarian approach to deal with the horror of the floating cemetery that the Mediterranean has become. We do not need the ‘search and destroy’ operation that is being advocated. We need EU governments to increase the number of resettlement places, humanitarian admissions and visas for people in need of international protection.   Finally, I want to distance myself and our Group from the shameful behaviour of some of the MEPs in this Chamber this morning who play political football with this issue which is, without doubt, one of the most disturbing issues that we have had to deal with. Shame on each and every one of you.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: – Mr President, I can agree with much of what has just been said. I would also like to remind people that, over the years, this Parliament has called for solidarity between Member States. We have called for the implementation, in a consistent and high-quality way, of a common asylum system and we have called for a common migration policy. I think we are still waiting for a lot of our Member States to actually catch up with those realities.  I also want to stress that, when we are looking at putting in place hotspot teams from the European Asylum Support Office (EASO), and when we are looking at a number of those things, the resources need to follow those commitments. I also welcome the temporary relocation plans and the settlement places. I am really, really upset that my own country is not willing to participate and not willing to step up on this occasion. If we are talking about a holistic system, can we please recognise that measures can be simultaneous, not sequential, and that migration is part of development, not a substitute for it.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I don't want to build walls. I want to build refugee camps, field hospitals and schools for the children. I want us to work for peace in Syria and Iraq. I am convinced that people feel best about staying in the immediate area and knowing that they can return home when possible.  I support the principle that every Member State of the European Union should have an absolute right to decide who stays on its territory, an unrestricted right to protect its people from terror and an unrestricted right to protect its social system, democracy and welfare system. I would like to stress that every nation state should be respected and that supranational decisions should not be contrary to the rights, freedoms and legislation of each nation state. The forced transfer of refugees into the Member States is contrary to the right of nations to self-determination. I want to protect Sweden as a nation and its citizens. I am a Swedish politician and i am in the EU on a Swedish mandate. My first priority will always be Sweden.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. What, in my view, is completely neglected in this debate is that you do not distinguish between illegal immigration, asylum and legal immigration. Not everyone who travels from Africa to Europe is automatically a refugee. On the contrary, the figures for asylum procedures show that around 70% have no grounds for fleeing, but are in fact migrants pushing into Europe. If you – and I am addressing the left-wing groups here, and in my view the PPE - say' 'yes, we are all bringing in', please also answer the question of how many you want to let in for Europe. The African continent has 1.2 billion people. You owe it to the Europeans to tell them how many you want to bring into Europe. The only solution can be to help these people on their continent to set up their own first reception centre on African soil, in order to determine who has any reasons to flee in order to be able to take care of the people on their continent, and not to bring everyone into Europe. The peoples of Europe also have a right: the right to the protection of their cultural identities, which you must not rob them of.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: Commissioner, you have presented a European migration programme and this proposal has at least one merit, that is to exist. The programme also contains good proposals, namely the tripling of Triton and Poseidon's financial resources, the financing of the EU Navfor Med operation, the strengthening of partnerships, and a more robust return policy. All this is going in the right direction, but I am very reserved about your proposal to relocate asylum seekers.  My country, France, is one of the five countries that already take in 75% of asylum seekers. Every year, in fact, we take in almost 300,000 more migrants. In addition, we provide significant resources within the framework of the Frontex agency. Therefore, can we really decide on a distribution mechanism based on accounting terms without taking into account our traditions? Commissioner, I would like clarification. When do you plan to trigger this mechanism? Under what conditions will the distribution, for example, be decided when fingerprinting in boats? And by whom? Under what authority? Commissioner, I believe, as you do, that solidarity should not just be a word but must be translated into action. But the solution is not found in a distribution system which would, by definition, be fixed and which would instead encourage or encourage migratory pressure and further strip States of an essential part of their sovereignty.

name: Jörg LEICHTFRIED
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Vice-President of the Commission spoke of a special situation; I would rather say an emergency situation. We must be aware of this: people are fleeing extreme violence, fleeing their lives, fleeing because their freedom is massively threatened. I believe that there is only one answer, a short-term answer, which is solidarity. That means, firstly, saving if you can save, and secondly, solidarity within the European Union. I do not understand the debate– I say it openly now – where some people think that no, we do not need to include anyone at all. This is not possible in an emergency situation. I would also like to return to something that the Greek colleague said earlier, namely that there must of course also be a longer-term solution. And one of the possibilities we have is foreign trade policy. We are strong here. I only have the feeling that if we no longer discuss refugee policy, but foreign trade policy, then the hypocritical shopkeepers' souls will come back to us, for which short-term profits of European corporations are more important than helping refugees. I am curious to see how colleagues on the right will vote today on conflict minerals, where armed gangs benefit and, on the other hand, again harass people in Africa. I'm curious to see how it's voted. I am also curious to see how the external trade agreements are coordinated when it comes to social clauses, human rights clauses. Then we will see whether there is solidarity in this House too, or whether there is always only the hypocritical chatter.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Mr President, a growing proportion of those who cross the Mediterranean are not, by definition, refugees fleeing from persecution, but rather economic migrants from Western Africa and elsewhere. They are encouraged by European maritime activities and our inefficient return policies.  The population of Africa is expected to reach four billion by the end of this century, so the pressure will not go away. The question is: can Europe indefinitely afford, economically or socially, a massive influx of people for whom the European labour market has very little to offer? Already today we can witness the failed integration in most Western European countries. One may predict that the situation will not improve if the numbers increase dramatically. I think we should pay close attention to how Australia is dealing with this situation and look for a model there.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Mr President, I would like to welcome the plan proposed by the Commission because I find it structured, voluntary and courageous, and I say to the Commission that it has done a good job overall and that we will support it. We will support it to deal with the humanitarian emergency in the Mediterranean, to wage a ruthless fight against the trafficking rings, to organise a genuine strengthening of solidarity between Member States in terms of reception and to intensify the coordination of the action of the specialist agencies Frontex, Europol and the European Asylum Support Office, whose role and means need to be greatly increased in the future. Of course, much remains to be done, and I regret the almost non-existent progress towards a common structural management of external borders, the too timid progress in creating legal channels of immigration on European territory and the inconsistencies in the asylum policy, which does not give equal opportunities in terms of reception to genuine refugees according to the countries in which they enter. If the Commission tackles these problems, it will benefit from our determined support.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: We started the day very badly. We have seen that the Council welcomed a decision which amounts to the deployment of military personnel, whereas the deployment of military forces in Libya was part of the problem underlying the flow of refugees. We have seen a Commission that welcomes an agenda for migration, while there is nothing in it about the broken Dublin system. It provides for the resettlement of 20 000 people in two years' time. The UN is asking for 130,000 resettlement sites. Overall, you can say that European asylum policy, including Dublin, is a mess. We should have started to establish that early this morning and then we should have looked at the proposals of the UN refugee agency. No one has mentioned the UN action plan here, which does offer solutions: mass resettlement, good humanitarian visas and other safe routes for asylum and reception in the region, for which Europe is also responsible. We must help those countries in the region. I would have liked to hear that. The current policy is quite a disgrace.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The Commissioners said that we are in an acute crisis situation that needs to be dealt with now. However, I believe that we cannot just put out fires, but we must also avoid their spread. Sending military to stop people smugglers is in the short term thought and only leads to smugglers finding other routes and people dying elsewhere along the way. As long as the market exists for the smugglers, they will find new and more dangerous routes. I hope that the UN will be wiser than the Council of Ministers is in this case. In principle, all the proposals put forward by the Commission are about keeping people out of Europe. What I lack in the proposals is the long-term work. You spoke of root causes when you talked about the long-term, but you linked to it how the migrants should be stopped from coming here.
