You did not say anything about the reasons why they are leaving their home countries and that we must focus on, for example, climate impacts, poverty reduction, conflict resolution, etc. People don't come here because they want to, they come because they have no other options. In this respect, the Commission has not made any proposals whatsoever.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: – Mr President, colleagues, I am categorically opposed to the application of quotas to European Union countries in the so-called Resettlement Programme for African Immigrants. The wrong path is chosen. It will not solve the problems, but exacerbate it. What does quotas mean for 20,000 migrants, when the Mediterranean sea alone reaches Europe by 150,000 refugees? Once again, we are being offered to fight not the causes, but the consequences. Unreasonable, illogical, inefficient. Quotas for refugees are non-milk production quotas for European Union countries, which are mechanically much easier to regulate. The quota policy will, in principle, be null and void, but it will only encourage migration to Europe more, because it will send a signal: 'You are welcome here, you will be taken care of here'. However, african states, their governments should be sent a completely different signal. Only stable peace in the region, only proper control of its borders must henceforth be the only and non-negotiable condition in the negotiations of the European Union institutions on financial, technological and humanitarian aid and trade agreements for donors.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the disaster of its immigration policy and its inability to prevent migration, the European Union proposes a plan that it alone could invent: to distribute illegal immigrants among the various European countries and to apply for a common asylum system. It is out of the question for the commissioners to decide instead of the French the number of illegal immigrants they must accept on their soil. On the other hand, it is clear that this organized management of illegal immigration will have a standardization effect and will create an additional call for air. As a result, there will unfortunately be more illegals, more shipwrecks and more deaths at sea. The European Union has also invented a justification to legitimise its position in favour of greater immigration: immigration would be good for growth! Mind boggling! You admit, shamelessly, that your objective is to provide low-cost labour in order to weigh down the wages of all workers in Europe, against the advice of the people. It is therefore a further attack on the sovereignty of our country, an affront to the French people, who are overwhelmingly opposed to immigration, and a way of increasing the problem rather than solving it. As usual, the European Union's desire to extend its powers will lead to disastrous results.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr As usual, the extreme right criticises everything and everyone without making any concrete and feasible proposals. I'm sorry about that.  No one should die in the Mediterranean on their way to Europe. We're going to save everyone, but we're not going to take them all. I wholeheartedly support the Commission's agenda and particularly welcome the fact that they are strengthening Frontex and the Triton effort to try to save people in the Mediterranean in a wider area. However, more countries must contribute and provide resources, equipment, logistics and staff to Frontex, the asylum office and the Refugee Fund. We have common rules, an asylum package to be fully applied by all Member States for a humane and legally secure asylum policy. The motorway into Europe on a legal and safe road is resettlement from the High Commissioner for Refugees. It is time we move from a voluntary to a binding system, and the Council must agree on a distribution mechanism. It's time! But that's not enough. If we do not take action against smugglers and serious organised crime, it will not be possible to reduce irregular migration. If military means are to be used, it must be done under international law, with a clear UN mandate. There is no quick fix. A holistic approach is needed, but what is lacking is not ships, but what is lacking is the will of the Member States. It is time for you to take greater and shared responsibility.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission has shown great courage in ushering in what I hope will be a radical change in European migration policy. I can now say that the Commission's work has live up to our expectations, with forward-looking proposals consistent with what has been adopted by this House.  At this point, all we have to do is ensure that the emergency measures are implemented as soon as possible and, above all, that the alliance between the Commission and Parliament is not break. We will ensure that the search and rescue operation in the Mediterranean is conducted with the same courage and foresight as Operation Mare Nostrum. Let us recognize ourselves in those people who are fleeing conflict and poverty. We too, in their place, in the choice between a certain death and a probable death would not hesitate to climb the first boat; at least I would have known what to choose: life, save me, not to land in Eldorado but in the hope of a better future. The fact that the patrol operation in the Mediterranean has been entrusted to Italy and our Navy is a source of great pride and a source of guarantee for us.  Finally, we will ensure that the Member States do not call into question, with a view to electoral consensus, the objectives of solidarity to which they are bound under the Treaties and the International Convention. I would add that the phenomenon of migration is not managed with slogans, but by investing in concrete, courageous and far-sighted actions, with a holistic approach. To those who say 'let us help them at home', I would remind you that they have the opportunity to do so now by returning the natural riches robbed – conflict mineral – to their rightful owners: the local populations.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, it appears to me that the discussion about the European Agenda on Migration is filled with fear and negative emotions. I would like to stress that migrants are not a problem. Migrants are people. For many citizens, it was narrowed just to quotas for Member States. Also, measures against smugglers have a short-term impact. Therefore, I find it more effective to solve causes rather than consequences and I stress and suggest this one:    Last week I accepted an invitation from the democratic self-administration of Rojava in North-East Syria and I visited Jazira/Gozarto Canton. I saw the severe conditions under which Syrian Christians and other minorities like Kurds and Arabs live. We Europeans know little about their bravery when facing ISIS aggression, the Assad regime and other Islamic militants.  I would urge the Commission to use diplomatic, political and economic means for a solution that will focus mainly on regions from where the migration springs, with a special focus on democratic regional initiatives for self-administration.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán said 'no' yesterday to the European Agenda on Migration. He did so in an obtuse and cheating way, saying that he would protect Hungarians from migrants. It's not the only case, but it's the most brazen. The hornet-outs of the wars from which men, women and children flee have been stirred, in large part, by Western Allied powers. We now face these dramas with more responsibility and solidarity, and we need to turn tragedy into an opportunity for the future. Fleeing children are part of our best future, if we can welcome them. Commissioners, above all, it should not happen again that EUR 173 million for asylum and humanitarian aid is not used, as happened in 2014, by unenforceable bureaucracy.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: – Mr President, this migration policy fosters a strong Europe, and migration policy is understood by you as part of security policy. We are systematically violating human rights on both sides of borders, but this is not what we are talking about here. No more inconsistencies and cynicism. We take our hands to our heads when a tragedy occurs in the Mediterranean, but it is our policies, the outside and especially the commercial, that lead the people of the south to despair and force them to emigrate. Ladies and gentlemen, have you stopped to think about the consequences of TCI on southern migration? It will further impoverish these people and force them to emigrate, but this big corporations don't care.  Let us be consequential and root the problem, promoting the development and well-being of the people of the southern countries, no longer impoverishing them. Migration and trade policy are absolutely inseparable. Today we will vote on minerals from conflict zones and there we will all be portrayed, and we will see which side we are on.

name: Eva JOLY
text: Mr President, when the Commission proposes refugee quotas, bringing the crisis to a European response, it is the Member States that, driven by their selfishness, are torpedoing this solution. Therefore, is it still useful to discuss this European migration programme, when the Member States have already agreed on a military operation? By targeting boats, will the flow of migrants fleeing wars and misery be dried up? No! Will the traffickers be defeated? No! Will the matter have been resolved, even temporarily? No! We will add chaos to chaos and suffering to suffering. Have we lost and head and heart?  By refusing the minimum of European solidarity, the Member States are betraying Europe. When François Hollande and Manuel Valls oppose solidarity in Europe, I feel an irrepressible sense of shame and I am angry to see Europe and its values trampled on.

name: Petr MACH
text: – Mr President, the Commission has decided to apply Article 78(1) of the Ec Treaty. 3 to propose quotas and redistribution of refugees. But the article doesn't mention quotas at all. You just made up a new authority. The article talks about the possibility of helping a Member State in need, that may mean, for example, financial assistance, but there is certainly nothing about quotas. I really consider this a violation of the principle of subsidiarity, I consider it an interference with the sovereignty of a Member State, and I ask myself: how could you even think of talking again in Europe about human transport? You're talking about a temporary redistribution of refugees. We have a bad experience with the term temporaryity in the Czech Republic. The Soviet army's fraternial temporary assistance in 1968 stretched to 20 years.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). – The European Union's new strategy on migration was made from the same materials as the previous ones: strengthening FRONTEX, shielding the Schengen Treaty, maintaining the Dublin Treaty, and returning to last year's funds during which three and a half thousand migrants drowned in the Mediterranean. And the European Union's lionisms for soul traffickers are the pretext for new military interventions to treasure monopolies. The Greek government is satisfied and co-signing this policy, implementing this ongoing barbarism. As for the so-called sharing of twenty thousand refugees in the other Member States, this is nothing more than the sharing of just a sample of the huge waves of migrant-victims of the imperialist wars of the United States, the European Union and NATO in the wretched concentration camps maintained by the European Union and its governments. There is one way out for the people: fighting here and now in conflict with the European Union and monopolies for immediate relief of migrants, supporting them with human reception centres, abolishing the European Union's reactionary regulations.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Mr President, I would like to focus my speech on the most immediate and spectacular response to this difficult issue of migration, the recently launched naval military operation in the Mediterranean. This is very unusual on my part, but I will express the greatest reservations and doubts about this operation. I fear that the ambitions displayed are exceedingly difficult to achieve. At best, it seems to me, this device may have a deterrent effect. And again... It will be extremely difficult, legally and operationally, to really tackle the trafficking and smuggling networks. The martial language that we have been drinking for weeks is quite understandable in this difficult situation, but I think it is difficult to really cover the reality of the operational and legal constraints that we will encounter. Beyond the major martial declarations, much more in-depth work must be undertaken with and towards the African countries from which these waves of migration come and go. We have interlocutors in those countries, we have points of support, including on the security front, and I think that is the first thing that needs to be worked on, because when we tackle the problem on the shores of the Mediterranean, it is already too late.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, in a very interesting development last week, one member of the College of Commissioners said that one member of the Council perhaps should have read the press statement in its entirety before commenting. I can say this, but perhaps the Commissioner cannot. What he was saying was that before making any pronouncements we should understand the Commission is in very difficult circumstances. While people are dying in the Mediterranean and while we are asking for action, we must understand also that the Commission talked about the causes. Many people are asking: why do we not talk about the causes? In fact they mention the causes. It is for us as politicians to convince our citizens that we will talk about the causes; we will talk about all of our citizens and we will do something in the Mediterranean and not let people die.  But we will also talk about many of the mechanisms, which we have talked about before. Jean Lambert said that we had created an asylum system; all of us here have legislated on this, but we have not implemented it. Therefore, let us turn our fire to where it should be: on the Council.  Here we have a Commission proposal which is comprehensive. But we have a choice. There is a low political priority of the tough choices, a resettlement. Let us have some perspective. Many of our colleagues on the other side of the house talk about Australia, a country which last year resettled 200 000 migrants and 14 000 refugees. We are talking about 20 000. So, perspective. Regarding humanity, thousands of people are dying in the Mediterranean, let us rescue them. Regarding the long-term: let us try to ensure that the Council has a high priority on the tough decisions and perhaps a little lower priority on the more easy media shots.  That is what we need to do in this Parliament. Let us get on with it and work in partnership.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! Often in this house you get the impression that you are very far from reality. This is also true in this case, where the warnings given by even Frontex in the case of a major search and rescue operation in the Mediterranean are not included in the considerations.  Unfortunately, when the Italians introduced Mare Nostrum, we saw that it had a much greater appeal to people smugglers and to people trying to flee to Europe in desperation and poverty. Already this year, Frontex expects that more than half a million will seek the way across the Mediterranean. Some will certainly drown in tragic accidents, but many will get over. We will only increase the number of people who will try to come to Europe in this way as we increase our efforts in the coastal areas.  You like it or not, but the only humane immediate reaction that can be to the situation in the Mediterranean at the moment is to go down the Australian route and take the bread out of the mouths of the people smugglers and help the refugees where they are most, namely in their neighbourhoods.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, the Golden Dawn People's Association, in its one year of parliamentary presence here, has highlighted the problem of illegal immigration and has proposed feasible solutions. I am particularly pleased that while some have described us as graphic and racist, now they not only understand the scale of the problem -- but adopt and embrace solutions that we first proposed. Racism, gentlemen, is when Member States do not care about the enormous burden that countries of entry of migration flows endure, to ask for solidarity and democracy from others but not to accept to be part of the solution, to fortify yourself behind the despicable Dublin II Treaty, because that is how you keep immigrants out of your country and voters happy. Fortunately, however, Mr. Younger, in his new migration action plan, adopting part of the Golden Dawn programme, talks about quota allocation among the countries of those seeking asylum, the repatriation of those who do not qualify for asylum, the prevention and boarding, and the fight against trafficking networks. Finally, I call on you, in view of Turkey's progress report, to condemn it on the grounds of its criminal negligence, if not refusal, to combat smugglers.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcomed with moderate satisfaction the European immigration agenda that has been drawn up, because at last there has been an awareness that immigration is not just an Italian, Maltese, Greek or Spanish problem, but an absolute European emergency that requires a comprehensive response from the whole of Europe. I welcome the commission's efforts to reverse this trend through, for example, the tripling of appropriations for Frontex and the identification of compulsory, non-optional quotas for the allocation of asylum seekers among all Member States.  More could certainly be done. Above all, we must act upstream, not downstream, through bilateral agreements with the North African States in an attempt to accompany their economic development process and for the return of illegal migrants, because we must show complete solidarity with asylum seekers but equally intransigent towards illegal immigrants. This is, however, an important first step forward, which is to be welcomed. What puzzles me is the attitude of some Member States, which in recent days have expressed some doubts and critical issues with regard to the solidarity mechanisms identified. The selfishness of states cannot and must not prevail. Now it must be the Council that is doing its part, but there is absolutely no turning back.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr President, the least we can say is that the European Commission has left no one indifferent with its migration programme: some deplore its lack of ambition, others shout, on the contrary. However, everyone agrees on one thing: the task was not easy. How, in fact, can we propose an ambitious and innovative programme when the current context seems to call more to minimalist recipes and calculations by the small end of the electoral lens? The European Council gave us an unfortunate example last April. That is why I would like to welcome the Commission's position, which has acted, and I congratulate it on that. There is no discourse on migration without the term "solidarity" but its application remained in the field of the virtual. The emergency allocation mechanisms proposed by the Commission aim to break this taboo by giving shape to solidarity between member states as well as with third countries. Of course, the operational arrangements have yet to be defined, but this is a step in the right direction, which Parliament has been calling for for many years. Parliament also called for a comprehensive approach to migration, and this is also what is proposed to us: the marking of the entire migration route from the country of origin to the host country, via the transit country. This is consistent with our analysis, which is that migration is viewed from a short-, medium- and long-term perspective. Finally, I would have, if I may say so, two suggestions to make to the Commission: first, continue your work of pedagogy and explanation of the proposals, to avoid sterile confusions which have more to do with the sensational speeches of fear than with reason and, secondly, hold on!

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by First of all, I am pleased that Minister Kalniņa-Lukaševica is with us. I congratulate the Latvian Presidency on its achievements, and thank you for saying: we want to stop the influx of immigrants.  But I hoped that we would see President Donald Tusk here, who, as President of the Council, should be here and defend the findings of the Council, which opposed the adoption of quotas for the sending of migrants around Europe. This is contrary to the arrangements of European countries and the European Commission is committing an abuse to which President Tusk should react. Unfortunately, he is probably busy conducting an election campaign in Poland, because he probably forgot that it is the job of the President of the European Council to defend its arrangements, to defend the agreements of European countries, not to watch the citizens of European countries vote. Thank you very much.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this deserted Chamber is the best proof of Europe's great interest in the 5 000 dead and the fate of Italy: look at how many people are worrying about the ongoing invasion!  Australia with the "No Way" campaign says anyone who sets foot in Australia without a document does so for a quarter of an hour and then is turned away. France has turned down a thousand illegal immigrants in the last week to Italy. Austria rejects. Hungary does not want them. Britain doesn't want them.  Some geniuses in Brussels have decided that we must sink the boats before they leave to harm the smugglers: better late than never. An adviser to the Libyan government has warned us that Isis terrorists are arriving in the boats. This morning, a Moroccan terrorist involved in the massacre at the Tunis museum was arrested on the outskirts of my Milan. Since Europe does not exist, over and above the chatter and minutes of silence, I appeal to the national governments and the Italian Government to defend the borders, block departures and suspend Schengen before it is too late.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE). – The Commission really deserves congratulations because the ambitious programme it is carrying out today shows that it is addressing the problem of migration holistically and globally. And the Commissioner, Mr Avramopoulos, is very consistent in his initial position months ago, when he spoke of 'shielding' legal immigration as the only way to combat illegal immigration. It is very important that we look forward to and aim for a common European asylum policy, it is very important that we aim to control traffickers and, indeed, in an original and meaningful way, not the one who is criticised but the one who really did not read those who are criticised, namely the establishment of information centres in third countries, starting in Niger, something very innovative and essential because , let us not forget that the traffickers who exploit people, exploit situations and essentially 'bet' on human life, are those who, with misinformation, incite people to artificial paradises. The Commission's programme is certainly workable and European citizens look forward with ambition to us implementing it, always in accordance with the basic principles of the European Union and the European culture of mutual trust and solidarity. Otherwise, neither fair distribution can find ground for implementation, nor, otherwise, we can easily say that we belong to a European family that has common rules.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, last week in Lisbon I had the honour of representing the European Parliament in the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean, where 33 Presidents of Parliament spoke of the need to share the reception of asylum seekers from the 28 European countries, economic participation in relief, identification and transfer activities and to make Operation Triton similar to Mare Nostrum. Migration, Commissioner, changes geographical references and imposes new responsibilities, and we know that Europe, when it speaks with one voice, is a strong Europe.  Commissioner, we support the Commission's idea of moving towards a common immigration policy, just as we share Mr Juncker's position of working on a European defence policy.  This approach strengthens the alliance between Parliament and the Commission; we know that we are at the beginning of this parliamentary term and we have major challenges, for example to transfer immigration policy and European defence policy from states to Europe because a strong Europe is a Europe that has more Europe and not less ......  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, I think that states should decide for themselves how many asylum seekers they can receive because e.g. Croatia does not have adequate accommodation for asylum seekers whose number has increased drastically in recent years. It is now being asked to further take care of 1.73% of asylum seekers arriving on the shores of Italy, Malta or Greece. Today it's one figure, relatively small, tomorrow we're going to have to take care of so much more, maybe a little more in the coming months, and so on and on and on indefinitely. This kind of migration policy leads exclusively to social catastrophe because the state, which has entered its seventh year of crisis, whose own population is increasingly moving out and where more and more people are poor due to lack of work, cannot be expected to take advantage of African emigrants. Unfortunately, Croatia has nothing to offer these people – only misery while they wait for their process to be completed.  Therefore, I believe that we need to deal with the problem much more decisively at its source, in Africa, because this influx of migrants will lead to the collapse of the social and security system in several Member States.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, indeed, the tragic loss of human life in the Mediterranean has shocked all the citizens of the world, and especially Europeans, by unacceptable human suffering. Citizens expect Europe to give an immediate response, not to be cross-armsed. European solutions are therefore needed, because we cannot get used to anyone's suffering. It is undoubtedly a global problem. There are immediate challenges. The Commission has raised them well: ending human tragedies, strengthening mechanisms to deal with emergencies and, of course, combating this phenomenon and dismantling all the networks that organise these journeys and taking advantage of human lives, through a resolution, as has been said, of the United Nations. But there are also longer-term challenges: developing a new policy on legal immigration, also developing a new asylum policy, saving lives, protecting our borders and, of course, eliminating all incentives for irregular immigration through the implementation of the Return Directive. But it's important to distinguish between asylum and immigration. Asylum seekers are those who are persecuted on the basis of race, religion, or political reasons. This is not the case in emigration: they flee poverty, they want to eat. But it is true that when they reach a territory, the territory that hosts them will not distinguish them, because everyone will need education, health and services. That is why quota weighting is very important; to weigh unemployment more strongly, because, in order to give employment opportunity and a better opportunity, unemployment needs to be much more weighted than the Commission has now established.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the proposal you are making is a huge step forward, particularly on binding refugee quotas for all Member States. This is only the beginning and we are waiting for a specific programme for the implementation of these measures. It is not enough to save and receive refugees on European soil, but also to respond to their integration into our societies to allay the fears of our citizens.  However, some Member States want to block the measures proposed by the Commission even before this first debate. These reactions cause a great concern. The Council's responsibility is enormous. We can't run away from problems when they're outside our door. Rather, we must show solidarity.  If we do not take urgent action, we risk deepening the humanitarian crisis at our external borders and encouraging traffickers. The Dublin Regulation should be revised to take into account the interests of all countries in Europe. The Commission should use all the levers to ensure that the Council accepts the urgent implementation of the proposed measures.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am speaking out in favour of solidarity, but against centralism, against the placement of immigrants on the basis of predetermined quotas. This is a completely wrong policy. Immigration policy must take into account the health of individual societies. The peoples of Central and Eastern Europe are under immigration pressure from the East. This is a problem no less important than the pressure that goes from North Africa. Mr Zdechovský from the European People's Party spoke of the efforts of the Czech State. I, too, could say a lot about the efforts of the Polish State. The last thing that can be done is to condemn the Member States, as Mr Verhofstadt has done. If we are to condemn someone, it is those countries that first had corrupt relations with dictatorships in North Africa and then inseignly destabilised the situation there. These are the real perpetrators of misfortune. Let us act in solidarity, but without the mistakes of centralism.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Mr President, I would say that we have four fundamental plans here. The first plan, which is essential, is the humanitarian plan and then I do not think that the European Union should spare any effort to rescue lives and to treat with dignity all those who reach its borders. That's the foreground. The second plan is the asylum plan and then I must say that this common asylum plan and even the idea of a common migration policy and even a common demographic policy in the European Union are good ideas. And it is important that the effort is allocated to everyone, even if european funds need to be allocated to do so. But I think that countries, such as mine, that receive fewer refugees have to be open to receiving more and sharing this effort with others who have more.  Then, finally, we have the problem of migration, migration for economic reasons, and then, although I think there should be openness, common criteria and a common policy, there must also be reasonableness in the criteria. We cannot, of course, open the borders from pair to par, with all the ease. It would be impossible, it would be catastrophic, it would be bad for those who come, it would be bad for those who are!  And finally, a reaction against the traffickers, which has to be a military reaction and that there, yes, the Council, for once, was fine.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – L-aġenda ppreżentata mill-Rubber Ewropea hija pass 'il quddiem, meta tqis li sal-lum i teżistix politika komuni Ewropea għal realtà daqshekk importanti. Imma rridu naraw li dak li hemm fuq il-karta jibda jitwettaq fir-realtà.  U hawnhekk indur fuq il-gvernijiet tal-Istati Membri tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Għaliex l-aħħar stqarrijiet li rajna minn ighertu mexxejja li m'humiex lesti jilqgħu kwoti ta' rilokazzjoni u resettlement juru biss li għandna pajjiżi komdi jħallu pajjiżi bħal Malta, l-Italja u l-Greija jġorru l-pi ważhomed. Id-diskussjoni m'għandhiex tkun jekk dan il-pro大ess isirx jew le, iżda fuq kif se jinqasam il-piż, l-hedge imsejħa distribution key. Din l-attitudni turi li m'hemmx impenn biex is-sitwazzjoni tkun indirizzata. Għandna gvernijiet li komdi jħallu lil ħaddiehor iġorr il-piż waħdu. U appell tal-aħħar anki flower-Rubber Ewropea. Jekk mhux se jkollna reviżjoni tar-regolamenti ta' Dublin se nkunu qegħdin inħallu lil min jabdika mir-responsabilità jibqa' jagħmel dan.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: – Mr President, the situation is very serious throughout Europe as far as illegal immigration and asylum are concerned. It is serious not only in southern countries where tragedies reach the media stimulus threshold, but also in states where the population has not yet encountered this presence on this scale, such as Hungary. Today, sweden has the highest number of immigrants relative to the population, according to Frontex data. It has grown 20-thirds in a few months, and most of them are not eligible for refugee protection, but are clearly economic migrants. A distinction should therefore be made between illegal immigrants and refugees entitled to asylum and illegal economic migrants. Europe will not be able to deal with the worsening migration crisis if it does not make this distinction with clear consequences at the level of policy and the regulation that expands it. With regard to refugee policy, it is clear that moral considerations, international treaties and obligations are the starting point. And tackling illegal economic migration should remain a competence of the Member States.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S&D). – I would like to congratulate the Commission and especially those responsible on this issue because, for the first time, the sharing of responsibilities in all Member States is so clearly placed on the basis of solidarity. It is time to look behind the veil of hypocrisy and each Member State to take a stand on the question: "Can Europe be trampling on international treaties? Can he deny asylum to people from death zones? Can it deny solidarity with the other Member States?"  But if the answer is yes, we should prepare for a new era where laws and obligations apply at the choice of those who concern them. But let us not just dwell on the issue of refugees. The four pillars that approach migration respond to our demands for a holistic approach and references to the legal paths for economic migrants, to the strengthening of developing regions, to our obligations but also to the needs of an old Continent, along with the right to feel a little optimistic. If the Commission gives even greater importance to aspects such as relocation from war zones and ensures transparency, efficiency and respect for human rights, we will be on the right track.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: – With regard to what Mr Jurek of the ECR has maliciously suggested, I would like to declare that The President of the Council, Donald Tusk, is currently preparing an Eastern Partnership summit to be held tomorrow in Riga, and is not running any campaign, Mr President.  On the other hand, I am pleased that Manfred Weber has said that the solidarity mechanism for the relocation of resettlement has yet to be discussed. The essence of solidarity is the voluntary cooperation of partners when we want it to be truly effective. So for this tango you always need two. Solidarity must go hand in hand with the economic and logistical capacity of individual countries. Therefore, Poland will be ready to participate in such a program, but under conditions defined by itself. The very announcement of the programme by the Commission, Commissioner, has triggered a wave of anti-immigrant, populist behaviour in the countries concerned by the migration. On social media, thousands of people join anti-immigration movements.  So what prevention measures does the Commission propose to prevent the spread of a wave of xenophobic and anti-immigrant behaviour? What resources does the Commission propose to create programmes that integrate refugees and those that educate local communities? What specific criteria has the Commission used, in addition to those listed on the agenda, to assess the efficiency of ... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, the European Agenda on Migration is a start to address a problem that is European and requires solidarity. The naval operation for the Mediterranean must be given priority to saving lives and then destroying the networks of traffickers. And destroying the nets is not destroying the boats, it's destroying their profit. This requires immediate measures to open up safe and legal avenues for those in need of protection and immigration, and in the long run coherent external action against the causes that cause people to flee their countries. We need to share the welcome effort immediately across all Member States. Mine, Portugal, can and must do more. It is therefore deplorable that some Member States have rejected the Commission's proposal for a reception distribution scheme. They shouldn't be able to stop this scheme. Turning our backs on those fleeing war, oppression and persecution is more than violating international law and the Treaties is immoral and unworthy.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that the biggest mistake of this debate is that we will equate solidarity with quotas. The Czech Republic has long been in solidarity with both the European Union and other countries. We really systematically work and allow Ukrainian students to study at Czech universities, for example. The immigration system, Commissioner, needs to be more sophisticated. It must not be clearly aimed at southern states. I know that the situation between the southern states is very urgent, but the situation in eastern Europe may also be as urgent. Let's keep an eye on the situation in Ukraine, there's really another war going on. There are 850,000 homeless people, and this too needs to be addressed.  Commissioner, I call on you to really focus your attention on Eastern Europe, which the Czech Republic or Poland is intensively addressing.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I welcome the Commission's proposals because they are a step in the right direction, but the problem is very complex and it will take a great deal of effort to resolve it. I would like to highlight one aspect: the situation in the regions of origin. I myself have been to Iraq and Lebanon in recent months, and when you have these experiences, you also understand why people want to go to Europe. There are 500 000 children in Lebanon, and only 100 000 of these children have the opportunity to go to school. So far, only 8% of the funds pledged to Iraq have actually arrived. From June, there will be food cuts in the refugee camps in northern Iraq. If we do not solve these problems, ladies and gentlemen, it will be too late – then our work will be the same as that of Sisyphos.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, more border control and faster returns for those who do not want to and for those who do not qualify as refugees seem to me to be the central points on which the Commission has focused, and this seems to me to be very important in order to finally clarify a slippery and too often ambiguous issue. This is the central point that frightens our fellow citizens. And then there is the fight against the criminals who torture, who kill, who exploit: they are the new slave holders of the contemporary world.  The left, again, is always ambiguous: it is ambiguous, it plays on words, because by saying asylum seekers, instead of having the right to asylum, it opens up to illegal immigration.  Italy is full of people who have been refused asylum, but because they appeal, they remain in Italy and delinqueous because they do not have a job, how do they support themselves? Last month, in March, in Terni, a boy was killed by a person who had been refused refugee status because he did not qualify for it and it was a terrible tragedy.  I thank the Commission: it is laboriously clarifying all this dangerous, guilty and irresponsible molasses.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Last Monday, EU defence and foreign ministers decided to set up a European mission in the Mediterranean to tackle the criminal networks of people smugglers. The Member States have therefore shown that, when the political will is present, they can act decisively and in unison. However, the willingness to implement the other aspects of this same refugee problem, such as creating safe, legal routes for people in need and organising solidarity within the EU, is unfortunately many times less significant.  At the beginning of this debate, the Council did not even dare to use the term 'refugee' and spoke only of the need to stop illegal migration. In its new agenda on migration, the Commission rightly states that the response to this humanitarian crisis lies in an integrated approach. It is therefore time for the Council to come to that conclusion and to start providing a safe haven for those who need it most.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I am sometimes frightened in this debate. One says: "The quotas alone do not help, so they must not come." The other says: "To act against the smugglers, that alone does not help, so we prefer to leave it." Everyone excuses it by saying that one thing alone does not work, that the other is not to be done. I think everything has to be done. There must be a fair distribution, action must be taken against the smugglers, the state of Libya must be rebuilt, and help must be provided in sub-Saharan Africa. Everything must be done together, and one must not excuse one with the other. The British say: "We want to shell boats, so we don't need a quota." I am against Le Pen and others and in favour of the quota, because it must finally be clear to our own people that we are making a fair distribution. Those who do not want quotas do not want a fair distribution, and those who do not want a fair distribution want to make populism strong. That is the crucial point. Let us make this clear here.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Mr President, with regard to the four million people or more who need Europe to take refuge from war and violence, we have heard many governments say that a thousand people are too many. Shame on you, what a shame!  After insistently demanding a common migration policy, the governments of the Member States are halting the European Commission's initiative - which I greet from here. And citizens should know that with this policy of ostrich and the most selfish short-termism, governments are holding back a common policy of migration and solidarity.  I believe that human solidarity is prepolitical and reflects the best of humanity's values. I don't understand that politics can be done with solidarity. But we are also in breach of international conventions that force us to stand in solidarity, and even our own Treaty. We are responsible for the diplomatic, political and economic paralysis of the south and east of the Mediterranean, and we also refuse to save our compatriots.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission has given a good sign: in addition to Europe as guardian of constraints, there is a Europe that, if it wants to, is alive and capable. But the next day, here again is the ballet of the States, between selfishness and myopia. That is unacceptable! I wonder, by the way, whether the geography was different and the landings had been in Brighton, what Cameron would tell us today. Ladies and gentlemen, Heads of State or Government, you must make it clear to the citizens: this is not an episode, it does not last a season, that of good weather, and it is not by chance: migration has causes and consequences that must be addressed and sometimes solutions have costs. Of course, there is a frightened and sometimes even hostile public opinion, but the task of leadership is to guide towards the most far-sighted goals. Europe would not even have been born if the leaders of that time had stopped in the face of a public opinion marked by the grudges of war. What is at stake today is the very essence of Europe, respect for values and human rights. It is not an exercise in vanity and it is not even a molasses, as I have heard. It is the foundation of our coexistence. If we start losing it, today it is up to the refugees, tomorrow who knows.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: With regard to the catch-the-eye procedure that is now being followed, I inform you that 25 Colleagues have already come forward. It will be impossible to call everyone. I will try to be as balanced as possible, but I would ask for your understanding from those who do not make the move today. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I very much welcome the Commission's European agenda on migration. It is a first step in the right direction, europe can work here. But Europe must also show solidarity: everyone must do what they are able to do, including the Member States. A package of measures is needed. Elmar Brok was right to say that everything must be done, not everyone can do what they want. Only in this way can we solve European problems at European level, only in this way can we make progress in this crisis situation.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Elf u tmien mitt ruħ mietu dis-sena biss. Elf qasmu l-Mediterran, eluf illegalment u aktar minn mitejn elf jinsabu l-Libja jistennew biex jaqsmu u xorta qed naraw oppożizzjoni minn ħerti Stati Membri għall-introduzzjoni he' sistema' kwota usta.  Nilqa' l-aġenda tal-Kummisjoni li tippreżenta punti perfettament immirati u miżuri konkreti li jagħtu ħajja għall-ewwel darba għal kliem bħal mobilizzazz u għajnuna finanzjarja. Iżda għad hemm nieqes soluzzjoni Ewropea bbażata fuq is-solidarjetà.  Nilqa' b'mod partikolari l-proposta tal-Gumsjoni biex tintrodu大i kwoti li jorbtu l-pajjiżi Membri jgħinu biex jittaffa l-piż fuq pajjiżi fuq il-periferija tal-Ewropa ballħ-Italja u Malta. Iżda nemmen li l-Gumsjoni jeħtieġ li tagħmel pass ieħor u timpenja ruħha li jiġi rivedut ir-Regolament ta' Dublin li mingħajru mhux se jkun possibbli li jinbukis riżultati konkreti.  Dawn huma biss short term solutions. Is-soluzzjoni fit-tul hija li jingħata futur lil dawn l-immigranti f'pajjiżhom. F'sens permezz tal-investiment fl-ekonomija, is-saħħa u l-edukazzjoni. Irridu nibdew illum qabel għada. Hedge biss tista' tissolva l-emoraġġija ta' nies li (id-diskors ġie interrott mill-President peress li kien skada l-ħin).

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – The problem of refugees from North Africa and the Middle East is currently the most pressing issue in the European Union. The European Commission has proposed that EU countries accept a certain number of refugees depending on m.in size of GDP and population of the country concerned. My country Poland would accept five percent of all refugees under this proposal. Recently, The President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, said at a meeting in Gdansk that Europe is to receive seventy million migrants over the next twenty years. This means that Poland would accept three and a half million refugees. This is therefore a very serious problem and I do not know whether there is agreement among the citizens of the European Union on such a solution.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). – I have listened with interest to Commissioner Avramopoulos to note that Europe needs a number of migrants per year, organised and legal. Because, indeed, we need labour because of the under-birth that exists in Europe. But under-birth, like migratory flows, are not natural phenomena. Under-birth is caused by incorrect tax, wage and social-insurance policies, which do not reward the birth of children and do not protect motherhood, while migratory flows are caused by unequal conditions of exchange with the countries of the region, and imperialist interventions, in violation of international law, which cause chaos in those same countries. So if we really want to tackle the problem of migration, we need to change our thinking and promote the balance and prosperity of human societies, not the profits of capital.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, I would like to express my support clearly to the Commission, which has come out with concrete proposals, and together with the Council. I am definitely convinced that we are finally standing before a serious solution and we hope all together in our joint success.  What I want to emphasize here – because I hear these thesis all the time that we need an Australian model – ladies and gentlemen, we are Europe, not Australia. Therefore, we need a European model, created together with member states in the way it is presented here.  I am really convinced that we should also act in the countries where the migrants come from, that we should act in terms of the cause of this accident that is happening in the Mediterranean, and unfortunately also on the eastern borders of the European Union. That's why I think we should extend a hand to anyone who has a need for our hand, but of course we should also be very careful of those who want to abuse our hand.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. We are currently seeing an increasing number of refugees fleeing war, conflict situations, and I hope that today, in the subsequent vote, you will vote in favour of a strong resolution, a strong legislative proposal against conflict minerals, which will actually ensure that there is no longer any war in these areas for the resources we need for our mobile phones and the other. But now it is also a question of seeing what we are doing here. I am very glad that many in this House are also in favour of a quota system. I can tell you that in Austria it is currently the case that more than 70% of the population is in favour. And I really do not see why other states do not also declare this solidarity. We need common solidarity here. We need to change the Dublin system, but at least as a first step we have to say: everyone must join in, including those who are now saying no to it. And one last thing: setting up tent cities, as is now the one in Austria, for three hundred refugees, really seems to me to be a panic reaction. This is not the direction to be taken.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the forces driving people away from their homes and pushing them to take on deadly perils to arrive on the shores of Europe – war, persecution, poverty, famine – are huge and will not go away any time soon. The Commission deserves credit for acknowledging the magnitude of the problem and for identifying both short and long-term solutions to address the refugee crisis.  The Agenda rightly identifies the fact that a determined fight against irregular migration and human traffickers should be coupled to a fairer and stronger asylum policy and integrated development action that is capable of addressing, in the long term, the root causes of migration in the countries of origin. We should be hopeful that this paper will fuel the right debates among Member States and eventually bring more solidarity, coherence and efficiency to our asylum and immigration policy.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – I would like to say that I am quite disappointed with the many speeches that have been made in this room. I am disappointed with the arrogance that has been in these speeches towards people who come here to the European Union as people who seek support, support perhaps before death, perhaps from hunger. And I am particularly frightened to hear this from colleagues from countries where our citizens go to work in other economically stronger countries. They are hundreds of thousands of citizens from our countries who are looking for work elsewhere, and we are here to talk insultingly about people who come here also for economic reasons. I would therefore ask my colleagues to really look for the right words and the right means of expression to speak out about migrants. And on the Commission's point: Commissioner, I am very much keeping my fingers crossed that all that you have presented to us will succeed. I believe that this will also be done for the benefit of those who are looking for a new life in Europe.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Mr President, I would like to commend the Commission and congratulate it on its commitment. This action is truly European action, which commits our governments to work together. Having said that, Frontex will play a very important role, and I would like to ask you, Commissioner, and also you, Madam President, why Poland has still not signed the siege agreement, while Frontex has been based in Warsaw since 2004. If we want to be fully operational and welcome employees who are not necessarily Poles at Frontex, it seems to me that there is a need to finally get this siege agreement signed. Thank you for your answers and for your diligence on this issue.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Avramopoulos, I am pleased that, after two years, at least this proposal has arrived from the Commission, this agenda on migration.  I believe that first of all we should try to inform the citizens, because I come from a country where citizens often and willingly ask what Europe is doing, they say that Europe leaves us alone in the face of this problem of immigration – I am Italian and I am Sicilian, so I live first-hand the problem of landings, the problem of deaths in the Mediterranean. So we have to explain how the European Union works: the European Parliament has spoken, the Commission has now expressed itself, but the third part, which is the Council, which is the States, is missing. And here we are faced with yet another case in which the States are selfish in the face of what is a global emergency, in the face of what is a great moment when Europe should show solidarity. So what do I hear? I hear France saying it doesn't agree. I hear Britain with Cameron, who has just won, saying he's not interested in splitting quotas. And so we take a thousand steps back on the European Union.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, please allow me to start by expressing my thanks to the Members of this House for their mainly positive reactions, encouragement and support of the overall agenda. I have taken note of all their remarks and concerns. We all know that addressing migratory challenges means making some bold decisions. Starting from the very beginning of the life of this Commission, commitment on this issue has been shown by the Commission itself, President Juncker and myself – you will remember my commitment before the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) during the hearing – and we have delivered results in a very short period. In the beginning some of you might have believed that we would not be in a position to do so. Well, here we are before you today after the public announcement of the new European Agenda on Migration. The time for decisions has come. Do we want to honour our responsibilities? Do we want to face the new reality throughout Europe? The European Agenda on Migration is not only an emergency response, it is a strategy that will lead Europe – that will lead us – forward in the next five, or even ten, years. During this period a lot of things will change but we have to strive towards our destination: to adopt and implement a comprehensive European policy on migration. This is why the agenda outlines a broader set of initiatives in the medium term in order to manage migration better. But we all know that any action alone will not be enough to solve the situation. This agenda requires political will and commitment, and this Commission has both. Solidarity shall not only be a slogan, as many of you have said. We need Member States to participate. We need their support. The important thing is to make a difference and to show that we are able to address the situation together. This agenda is based on the conviction that the European Union migration policy is not about opening or closing borders. Both of those options are unrealistic. The European Agenda on Migration is about managing migration better so that migration can take place in an orderly, safe and regular manner.  The Commission is already mobilising all its resources to implement these actions and will adopt a package implementing measures next week. Triggering this emergency mechanism means that more needs to be done together for those who are in need of protection. Let me say here that it is not a free ticket to another European country. It has become indispensable.  This package will include, among other things: firstly, a proposal for a decision, based on Article 78(3) of the Treaty, establishing an emergency relocation scheme. This proposal will also give details on how the regulation will work, including necessary safeguards. Secondly, we will present a recommendation on the establishment of a European resettlement scheme. Thirdly, an action plan on smuggling. Fourthly, guidance on fingerprinting. Finally, a public consultation on the future of the Blue Card.  The Commission’s European Agenda on Migration completes and deepens the commitments of the European Council and it is a response to the call by Parliament. Migration is a critical issue for the future of our societies and for the future of Europe. We need to regain people’s trust by proving that Europe is able to manage migration in an effective way. That means going beyond words and putting good intentions into practice. The European Agenda on Migration offers a comprehensive approach to address the migratory challenges. As I said before, it must be seen as a package, and all the measures proposed have to be implemented in parallel. No Member State can address this challenge alone. Thank you for this very fruitful debate. As I said earlier, I count on your support more than ever, knowing that Parliament shares our ambition finally to prevent and plan instead of only reacting to dramatic events. I hope that you can also help me to get support from Member States and citizens. We need this European Agenda on Migration. I am even more convinced of this after today’s debate.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank you very much for this very important debate today. Parliament’s contribution is instrumental in finding the most appropriate answers to the challenges we have. This is one more step in the continued dialogue between our two institutions on the very important issue of migration, which we intend to pursue.  Given the seriousness of the migratory pressure on the EU, all contributions to this debate are welcome, in particular if they can contribute to finding a solution to the challenges we are facing. I can therefore promise you that we will take duly into account Parliament’s views on the different aspects of the European Agenda on Migration. In any case, this is just the first phase of a long debate. I am sure that the next Presidencies will also pursue this cooperation with Parliament on this very complex issue of migration.  As I have already said, at the beginning of this debate, as a result of swift action and cooperation between institutions we can already talk about substantial steps taken in the direction of addressing the humanitarian challenge the EU is facing due to migration flows.  I started my speech today by underlining that it is no longer time for words. It is time for deeds. This is the approach of the Council. The Council has already delivered concrete results and decisions. We have prepared the roadmap and have welcomed the presentation of the Agenda by the Commission. We also took the decision to prioritise the tripling of the resources allocated for Frontex and we have decided to establish an EU naval operation. More steps will follow when preparing for the June European Council. Some of you, in your comments, criticised the Council for its lack of support for the emergency mechanisms under Article 78(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Such criticism is premature as the Commission’s communication was adopted just one week ago. Even if some Member States have already expressed their preliminary views concerning the emergency relocation mechanism, the Council has not yet defined its position.  We are still waiting for the Commission’s concrete proposals. Once tabled, the Council will immediately activate its preparatory bodies. We will certainly have another opportunity to discuss the mechanism as decisions on provisional measures may be taken only after consulting Parliament.  I will be honest. It will not be easy to find an agreement in the Council on such a major and sensitive issue as migration policies, just as it is also not easy to find an agreement in this House. What is important at this moment is that the Presidency and the Council stand ready to respond to the Commission’s proposal. This House has today also shown a lot of interest in knowing more about the EU naval operation. EUNAVFOR Med will be conducted in sequential phases and in accordance with the requirements of international law. It will start by surveilling and assessing human smuggling and trafficking networks in the southern-central Mediterranean and will be conducted as soon as possible. The second and third phases of the operation will work to search, seize and disrupt the assets of smugglers, based on international law and in partnership with the Libyan authorities.  The EU CSDP operation is part of a set of comprehensive measures aimed at responding to the immediate need to save lives, address emergency situations and tackle the root causes of irregular migration, as requested by the European Council on 23 April.  The Council agrees with the need to have a European solution. It is important to have a comprehensive approach with a view to providing asylum for those in genuine need, as well as at the same time ensuring the effective return of those who do not have a right to stay. But the most urgent priority is to stop further loss of life.  We look forward to working together with you to find the best and most effective solutions to the crisis we are facing.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you very much for that. I would remind the Council and the Commission once again of the question put by the chairman of the Committee on Budgets on the question of the Frontex Headquarters Agreement. We are still waiting for an answer here. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – With the new European Agenda on Migration, the EU is reacting to migration pressure on Europe and in general in the right direction. Priorities are identified, due to the urgency of action in the face of the humanitarian emergency posed by the relentless and unacceptable deaths in the Mediterranean. It is intended to improve the European Asylum System, by activating the emergency mechanism provided for in the EU Treaty, in order to distribute refugees in solidarity among the Member States. It is intended to strengthen the FRONTEX agency to carry out rescue and rescue work at sea. New legal and secure avenues for legal immigration will be explored. And it strengthens the fight against irregular immigration by cooperating with the issuing and transit countries, and the fight against organized human trafficking networks. The agenda is positive, but government reactions are not. The agenda will not be effective if States begin to resist welcoming the rescued. The EU must achieve a common migration and asylum policy. Member States must be aware that we are facing a serious emergency and have a responsibility to act with "internal solidarity".

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. – The European Union’s agenda on migration is that it should continue unabated under the open borders policy. On 7 May the British people voted into power a Conservative Government. What that guarantees is that unlimited and uncontrolled immigration will continue – as indeed it would if they had elected a Labour Government. The Conservative and Labour parties are committed to keeping the open borders policy, and for more countries to join the EU, such as Turkey with a population of 75 million people. It is totally dishonest of the Tories to talk about controlling immigration and at the same time to support more countries joining the EU. It will not be long before the voters regret their decision.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – We welcome the action plan put on the table by the European Commission to tackle the influx of refugees, asylum seekers and migrants effectively. Mandatory quotas for the Member States: it is clearly not obvious in some capitals, but it is much needed. Just continuing as we are doing now is not an option at all.  Five Member States account for three quarters of asylum applications. We all know this has to change. We are counting on the Commission to come forward next week with a good and feasible proposal, which can be adopted quickly, including in the Council. But today all our attention must be primarily on the rescue of boat people, towards a stepped-up, effective action against the people smugglers and at the same time to much more intense cooperation to guard our external borders. It is a strategy and a strategy. This is the only way to gain broad popular support for this action plan.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. The immigration policy presented by the European Commission is demagogic and completely inefficient. This type of distribution of immigrants into the EU, which has not yet been accepted by all Member States, is certainly not in itself a measure that halts migratory flows, nor is it such as to counter the now obvious phenomenon of terrorist infiltration into irregular migratory flows. The Commission persists in not restoring Schengen and not helping these desperate people in their own country, which are the only solutions to this problem. Too drastic? So let's follow Australia: stop the boats and send them back to the ports of departure. The results are zero illegals and zero victims in the sea. The policy of good will does not work: what is the point of this Europe at last being aware of this?

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – With the new European Agenda on Migration, the EU is reacting to migration pressure on Europe and in general in the right direction. Priorities are identified, due to the urgency of action in the face of the humanitarian emergency posed by the relentless and unacceptable deaths in the Mediterranean. It is intended to improve the European Asylum System, by activating the emergency mechanism provided for in the EU Treaty, in order to distribute refugees in solidarity among the Member States. It is intended to strengthen the FRONTEX agency to carry out rescue and rescue work at sea. New legal and secure avenues for legal immigration will be explored. And it strengthens the fight against irregular immigration by cooperating with the issuing and transit countries, and the fight against organized human trafficking networks. The agenda is positive, but government reactions are not. The agenda will not be effective if States begin to resist welcoming the rescued. The EU must achieve a common migration and asylum policy. Member States must be aware that we are facing a serious emergency and have a responsibility to act with "internal solidarity".

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. I can only agree with the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini: there can never be a real solution to the problem of immigration until we have eradicated its root causes, the poverty of the countries from which the boats come and the instability caused by the wars in Libya and Syria.  I welcome the news that the resources available for Frontex's Triton and Poseidon joint operations have tripled. It is clear that without adequate funding we cannot go far. However, the problem must be felt by the whole of Europe, all countries must commit themselves to receiving migrants arriving, according to a quota allocation. It has been said to destroy the boats with which passers-by transport hundreds of people, often causing them to sink and die: it can be a solution at the moment, but it is only a palliative. What is more, we need a common asylum policy which will make it possible to identify and distinguish refugees fleeing from the horrors of war, from criminals trying to escape justice. The Commission's agenda on migration is acceptable, and we must now all work together to make it a reality.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. – The Commission got off to a bad start with the 10-point Action Programme, but has corrected its approach and the Migration Agenda is a workable, multifaceted document that strengthens European solidarity. It includes measures addressing the root of the problems and the need to articulate responses in the countries of origin. No less important are the much needed measures to respond to the humanitarian emergency, solidarity at sea and solidarity on land! The activation of the Article 78 clause and the strengthening, which I have long advocated, of the Poseidon and Triton operations are positive!  Unfortunately, we depend on the will of the Member States, the same ones that have so far failed. I therefore call on you to provide means to save lives, to allow you to go beyond 30 nautical miles, to help the Member States that, on the front line, welcome people who are fleeing. And if fighting traffickers is necessary, I have a lot of doubt that slaughtering the boats, preemptively, on Libyan territory is effective and safe for refugees. The unwillingness of the Member States prevents us from acting effectively and projects the image that we do nothing because the Member States want to do nothing.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. – The loss of life in the Mediterranean has shocked Europe, European citizens are waiting for the Member States and the European institutions to act to prevent a recurrence of these tragedies. We have a duty to identify European solutions based on real solidarity and awareness that we have a shared responsibility, including that of establishing an effective migration policy. By presenting this migration agenda, the EU shows that it is ready to identify solutions to the dramatic challenges that people fleeing wars, persecution and poverty are going through. Migration is the common responsibility of all Member States, so we must help address this challenge, which is not only European but also a global one. This agenda also represents an extension of our cooperation with countries of origin and transit to save lives, to combat illegal migrant networks. Given that the loss of life in the Mediterranean is mainly caused by traffickers exploiting the desperation of migrants, the Commission has a duty to propose initiatives to stimulate the identification and prosecution of those involved in trafficking networks.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. In front of the terrifying Mediterranean cemetery, the masters of the European Union have removed their masks. We knew of the incompetence of these institutions in immigration because they were unable to control and contain ever-increasing flows. The treachery of the Commission and the Council now appears to be the perfisis of the Commission and the Council, which wish to speed up the migration submersion in defiance of the lives of millions of men, women and children to whom you make believe that Europe is an eldorado open to all. Instead of adopting the Australian method of refoulement of migrants which has proven its effectiveness and humanity, you are getting caught up in a quota policy that will only affect a tiny fraction of the migration flows and fill the pockets of smugglers and mafias proliferating on this new human trafficking system. What a paradox that of a European Union which prides itself on being at the forefront of risk assessment but which does not measure the dramatic and irreversible consequences of an air call for mass immigration to Europe: insecurity, misery, overcrowding, uncontrolled social spending and destruction of the national cohesion and cultural unity of European nations. Your irresponsibility is violence against people.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – Illegal immigration is a central problem for the Union and there is hardly a Member State where this topic is not on the agenda.  I have repeatedly raised here the question of what to do with this wave of illegal immigrants. I will say again that as long as The Islamic State exists as long as al-Shabaab exists, while the Middle East and Africa are shaking up conflict, this wave will not diminish. That is why all talk of quotas for illegal immigrants, and their follow-up distribution in Europe, are palliative measures. The solution to the problem is not quotas. I believe that their introduction is a mistake. We're treating the symptom, not the disease. We are talking about quotas – how we will allocate 20 thousand euro. between 28 Member States. And when that quota runs out? Then what? Bulgaria, Italy, Spain, Greece will suffer again. More than 50,000 people will enter Italy alone. people, 30,000 people will enter Bulgaria this year alone. People. What are we going to do with them?!? The problem must be solved by the peace of mind of the areas from which the illegals come.  Every economic immigrant – to be sent to their homeland. We are offered another liberal model that will only redistribute the wave. No thank you. I will not support such a policy. It is against the interests of my Bulgaria.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. The foreign and defence ministers' proposals on the future treatment of refugees crossing the Mediterranean are naive and dangerous. I will also tell you why: it is naive to believe that Libya, where there are currently two completely divided governments, will have a European force patrolling the coast. And if this does happen, it can also be quite dangerous. Not only Libyan militias could oppose it, but also fighters of the so-called Islamic State would have a perfect target for their actions. I also wonder how to distinguish fishing boats from smugglers' boats. How do you know if a few dozen refugees are not hidden in the lower deck when you attack the boat to sink it? All this is planned. And the Austrian Foreign Minister has also unearthed the idea with the refugee camps in North Africa: there will be a lot of talk that only a few people will be allowed through, so they will again look for and find other ways to get to Europe. I think it is only a distraction, because once again we have not been able to agree on quotas whereby the refugees are distributed evenly in Europe. But they are urgently needed now!

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The European Agenda on Migration is the EU's response in the right direction in the face of migration pressure on Europe. It identifies the urgent priorities for action in the face of the humanitarian emergency posed by relentless and unacceptable deaths in the Mediterranean. It is intended to improve the European Asylum System, by activating the emergency mechanism provided for in the EU Treaty, in order to distribute refugees in solidarity among the Member States. It is intended to strengthen the FRONTEX agency to carry out rescue and rescue work at sea. New legal and secure avenues for legal immigration will be explored. It strengthens the fight against irregular immigration by cooperating with issuing and transit countries, and the fight against organized human trafficking networks. I think the agenda is positive, but this is not the reactions of governments. The agenda will not be effective if States start refusing to welcome those rescued. The EU must adopt a common immigration and asylum policy. Member States must be aware that we are facing a serious emergency and have a responsibility to act with "internal solidarity".

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. – Finally the European Union assumes its responsibility for a phenomenon, immigration, which particularly affects certain States but which must be managed by all. Welcome to the comprehensive and holistic approach presented by the Commission, which addresses both immediate measures – such as tripling the capacity of Frontex's joint operations and the activation of the emergency mechanism to help Member States face a sudden influx of immigrants – as well as longer-term measures combining respect for the rule of law with the protection of human rights.  In order to implement this plan as soon as possible, Member States need to agree to overcome discrepancies in quotas for the distribution of asylum seekers as soon as possible.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. They were all standing in this Parliament a month ago for yet another massacre. They were also standing last October. And then two years ago, for the lampedusa massacre. Standing, and silently. Since then thousands of men, women and children have died again. They came here to Europe to demand that they be given a right. This is the fifth time this year that immigration has been discussed in this House. And this morning many people spent their time, our time, on populism and demagoguery for electoral purposes. To gain consent or, it is the case of most, not to lose it.  The European Commission has finally given us a bold agenda on immigration and there are those who still want to take time, and they have doubts, they say no. Just as the distinctions of countries rejecting a sharing plan that affects only 20 000 people in greater Europe are now emerging. Instead, it must demonstrate that it is able to govern migratory flows and a phenomenon that is the child of a profound and very rapid geopolitical change that sees us unprepared.  In June, the Council followed up the battle we fought in Parliament and the agenda that the European Commission has written. So that solidarity and sharing are not just empty words.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – Firstly, we need to clarify the concepts in order to avoid political demagogy. Immigration and the refugee issue are not directly related. Refugees shall be recognised as refugees who are persecuted or feared in their home country or in the country of habitual residence because of their race, nationality, belonging to a specific social group, religious or political beliefs. Regardless of the economic situation of the refugee. This is a question of solidarity.
