Neither the EU nor the Member States have a choice on this issue: we must remain in solidarity with refugees and against Member States facing disproportionate refugee pressures in relation to their size. This solidarity also does not allow the criminalisation of refugees. Throughout history, hundreds of thousands of Hungarians have been accepted all over the world because they have had to flee different regimes. They were not treated as criminals either. The issue of immigration is different in that the European Union and its Member States can decide whether or not to allow legal immigration from third countries to the EU. This issue, including Europe's demographic challenges, is indeed one of the most important issues of our time. But we must find solutions to this issue in Europe jointly, responsibly, on the basis of facts and not on the fears and prejudices of citizens. The so-called national consultation in Hungary, which connects immigration to terrorism and which asks politically directed, spurred questions. It's the result of all but responsible politics.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The numbers are alarming. In the first months of this year 35,000 people managed to reach the European Union by sea, but unfortunately more than 2,000 lost their lives. According to data from the World Organization for Migration, since 2000, we are facing the loss of 22,000 people. This is a real humanitarian catastrophe. We have to move from words and intentions to action. We need a stronger Common Asylum Policy, which includes a European refugee resettlement scheme and a relocation system for emergencies. We have to fight criminal networks and traffickers. We have to improve the policy on legal migration. We certainly need more Europe and an even more solidary Europe. I applaud the european commission's efforts, in particular on the naval military mission, to combat traffickers operating in Libya. Member States should now act and participate through the provision of resources and staff. I believe that this initiative should also be discussed within multilateral institutions, because it is a global problem. The issue of thousands of migrants adrift in the seas of Southeast Asia should not be forgotten

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. – The Commission's proposal is an important step forward in the common European asylum and immigration policy. It proposes effective and rapid measures to save lives and to humanely resolve the crisis caused by the refugee wave affecting the Mediterranean. It initiates the distribution of refugees between Member States and provides financial and professional assistance to the countries where the refugees arrive. The solutions developed can be expected at a later time by all the Member States concerned, Hungary the member states concerned. It is crucial that the Commission proposes to strengthen the common European asylum policy, address the possibility of legal migration, take advantage of its economic benefits and integrate immigrants effectively.  One of the crucial issues for the future of Europe is to give migrants a real opportunity to live their lives as equal European citizens. We need to create adequate educational opportunities, employment programmes, childcare and community opportunities. This kind of integration is in the common interest of all of us. This makes it possible for newcomers to Europe to play a useful economic role, to be equal members of communities, to help prevent radicalisation and alien an enemy. Integration also has public conditions. Any declaration or action that creates a mood against migrants, especially if it comes from responsible leaders, only poisons the atmosphere, harms Europe and all Member States. Instead of tempers, we need sensible dialogue, solidarity and cooperation instead of shut-in.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. - I welcome this document, as this is a good step forward for the Member States of the European Union to share responsibility on migration in a solidarity manner. Obligations on paper must now be honoured in practice. Member States must demonstrate that they are capable of finding common solutions to the mass influx of migrants, but this solution cannot focus solely on the EU. It is therefore important to level the way people in transition and their home countries to prevent traffickers from transporting migrants to the EU. It is also important to carry out an information campaign in the home countries from which migrants come to discourage potential migrants from their journey, as nearly 2/3 of the asylum applications have been shown to be rejected and that migrants, having made the extremely difficult and expensive journey, are eventually overwhelmingly returned to the countries from which they arrived. It has also been shown that development aid coming from the EU to third countries is certainly not well targeted, as it does not affect the improvement of the quality of life of the local population, to whom it then literally challenges its life in order to find a better life. The document is a significant step forward in responding to the tragedies in the Mediterranean and if adopted, it will reflect solidarity among Member States.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. - The crisis is a reality for many citizens of the Member States. However, millions of people live in much more brutal conditions in our immediate neighborhood. To them, a troubled EU is a promised land compared to the desperation from which they must flee. Refugees are triple victims; devastation in their home countries, the greed of people smugglers, but also the front of refusal in countries where they want to continue living. Refugees must not remain a problem only a member on whose borders and shores they arrive. The Commission acted swiftly. The council with a certain hesitation. Differences are looming insofar as the Commission defends common European and the Council represents the interests of the Member States. The EU has accepted one million of the world's 12 million refugees. Lebanon country of 6 million has 1.2 million refugees. If the Union is to be judged by how it treats the neediest in society, and migrants certainly are, then we need to seriously rethink current migration policies and reform them thoroughly. That is why I support the Commission's proposals.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - Migration has become the EU's main concern, following a huge wave of refugees and many migrants arriving in Europe by land or by boat across the Mediterranean Sea. In the first two months of 2015, 26,600 irregular border crossings were recorded, as well as 1,829 casualties at sea border crossings. To this end, the Commission has set out a new European Agenda on Migration setting out the common policy objectives of the 28 Member States in order to adopt criteria and make legislation on migration. The current system cannot cope with the growing influx of migrants further strengthened and accelerated by the profits made by people smugglers from the many war-affected areas that encourage people to flee and where basic human rights that migrants should have are not taken into account. Therefore, the Commission is proposing mandatory quotas for Member States to move many migrants who have managed to reach the EU, so as not to bring all the burden on asylum first, namely Italy, Greece and Malta. The new mechanism is based on member state size, G.D.P., unemployment rate and number of existing asylum applications.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. The European migration programme is an undeniable first step towards a comprehensive EU migration policy. This strategy emphasizes cooperation with countries of origin and transit as well as strengthening the common European asylum system. The EU and its Member States can no longer allow people to risk their lives in order to apply for asylum. In order to avoid shipwrecks, it was necessary to propose a military naval operation under the aegis of the United Nations in the Mediterranean to dismantle smuggling networks and combat migrant trafficking. At the same time, there is also a need to develop legal and secure channels of access to the Union for applicants. Embassies, consulates, the establishment of a European system of humanitarian visas, and the processing of asylum applications directly in third countries are all possible solutions. The EU could also charter its own boats to bring refugees and asylum seekers to our continent safely. I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal to achieve a fairer distribution of refugees and asylum seekers among Member States, although the proposals on legal migration lack ambition.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – With the new European Agenda on Migration, the EU is reacting to migration pressure on Europe and in general in the right direction. Priorities are identified, due to the urgency of action in the face of the humanitarian emergency posed by the relentless and unacceptable deaths in the Mediterranean. It is intended to improve the European Asylum System, by activating the emergency mechanism provided for in the EU Treaty, in order to distribute refugees in solidarity among the Member States. It is intended to strengthen the FRONTEX agency to carry out rescue and rescue work at sea. New legal and secure avenues for legal immigration will be explored. And it strengthens the fight against irregular immigration by cooperating with the issuing and transit countries, and the fight against organized human trafficking networks. The agenda is positive, but government reactions are not. The agenda will not be effective if States begin to resist welcoming the rescued. The EU must achieve a common migration and asylum policy. Member States must be aware that we are facing a serious emergency and have a responsibility to act with "internal solidarity".

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – Globalisation is the way to greater prosperity, but any fundamental process has negative consequences. When we talk about the movement of goods, we can be neutral, but when people migrate massively because of economic difficulties, we must first talk about human dignity, ethics, human rights. It is clear that solidarity on migration needs to be promoted in a europe without borders, but it must not be a matter for border states alone. If Europe was in solidarity with us, the Baltic States, when we were under the consequences of the Russian embargo, today we must be in solidarity with Italy. Solidarity cannot be partial or one-sided. It must be welcomed that the Member States have come together to address this important issue. However, the distribution of migrants across different countries is not a long-term solution. I believe that we can invest more in preventing the influx of migrants and crises. It is equally important to ensure adequate public awareness of the implementation of the Common Agenda on Migration. There are now many stereotypes, fears that politicians in this Chamber are raising. We need to ensure that the people of the European Union are aware of the validity of our actions.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – Europe is finally proposing to deal with resettlement issues for irregular migrants, with proper search-and-rescue arrangements, and with the containment of smuggler gangs. It is to be hoped that European political actors will place solidarity on their political agenda and embrace a fairer allocation system. Other priorities need to be kept in mind. Some migrants are asylum-seekers. A resolution of the problem that caused them to leave home frequently requires military action by the international community which is most often outside the EUʼs remit.  Irregular migrants are also people who aspire to improve their economic situation as they have limited to zero opportunities back home. Past development aid failed to improve sufficiently the economic conditions in sub-Saharan Africa. We need to understand why this has happened and to convert that understanding into an action programme committed to generating economic growth and jobs. We urgently need a European policy on legal migration. For while the inflows of irregular migrants cause concern, some Member States actually need migrants to replenish their labour force. It is a truism that problems caused by irregular mass migration can only be solved conclusively by improvements that give grounds for hope, in the countries from which migrants originate.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – The causes of migration need to be addressed, not just its consequences. It is essential to better address development aid and to try to raise living standards in the countries where most migrants arrive in the EU. It is also important to streamline development aid, to prepare trade agreements with third countries, to tighten the granting of immigration quotas and to take account of the competences of the Member States. The current migration situation is critical and therefore the challenges of EU migration and asylum policy need to be tackled systemically.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. We must finally stop perceiving migration to Europe as a threat. As long as we align our policy with this, we will not achieve a modern immigration policy. We must finally apply our values and fundamental rights to refugees. That is why the Commission's proposals to extend the mandate for rescue at sea, to distribute refugees among the Member States and to a European programme for the resettlement of refugees are to be welcomed in principle. However, many of the proposals come too late, we are calling for a full sea rescue programme since the end of the Mare Nostrum mission, so why are proposals coming to this only now? Why are the Member States still reluctant to distribute refugees fairly in Europe? For many years, we have been calling for safe and legal routes for refugees to reach Europe, so that they do not have to risk their lives through smuggling gangs into Europe. Why does the proposed agenda on migration not provide for this either? We must make it our duty for the Member States to finally see migration as an opportunity here and not to continue to pursue a policy of inhumane and shameful foreclosure.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. – Solidarity lays at the foundation of the European Union, including with those people who have been brought to Europe with the recent influx of refugees. I believe the proposals tabled by the Commission to deal with the issue duly reflect this solidarity, consequently I fully support the set of measures for resettlement and relocation drafted in the Agenda on Migration.  Efficient execution of the Agenda requires full backing by all Member States. One particular Member State government, however, is challenging its bases, those of European values, solidarity and humanity. As we heard in this very part-session of Parliament from Hungarian Prime Minister Mr Orbán himself, his government insists on undermining current EU efforts by dealing with all migration and refugee issues under exclusive national competence, rejecting current and future migrants, thereby using arguments that smack of nationalist and populism.  The most appalling aspect of his attack against the Commission’s proposals is the fact that Mr Orbán launched this provocation purely to serve his internal political goals, to cover up recent corruption scandals his proxies were involved in. In response to such challenges from the Council I urge Parliament to use its full political weight to back the Commission in this important effort.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. Finally, Europe. Politics won. After parliament's strong requests, the European Commission has had the courage to tackle decisively an issue which is unfortunately often underestimated by countries that do not border the Mediterranean, but which is vital for the European Union, for what we have been, for who we are today and for what we represent in the world.  The reception of migrants, of those fleeing war situations, of human lives that see Europe as a hope, is not the usual emergency: we cannot back down from living in a world that is now globalised, but we can decide how to be part of it; that is our task. And if we really want to create a 'European Union' that is not just so in name, we must be united in our approach to this challenge; We therefore welcome the 'compulsory quotas' for all Member States and the fact that the Dublin agreements have been successfully exceeded, and we also welcome the reflection on how to get to the root of the problem by intervening in Africa with investments that will promote the development of local communities in the first place. An "intelligent solidarity" that does not de-responsible but that makes everyone protagonists of their future.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. – Two weeks ago, the European Commission, in the wake of the inconvenience of being accused of the responsibility of letting thousands of people die in the Mediterranean, launched the so-called 'European Agenda for Migration 2015'. This programme proposes to triple the funds of Operation Triton and the Frontex Programme, aimed at controlling the EU's external borders and not at the rescue and integration of migrants and refugees. It proposes strengthening the cooperation of police institutions – such as Eurojust and Europol – with EU asylum policy, in particular for fingerprintidentification of migrants' DNA and to repatriate all those who are not considered to need special protection. Rather than solving the problem by creating channels for safe and regular migration, particularly for workers and unqualified migrants and for people seeking family reunification, as advocated by the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, numerous social organisations and all those who have common sense and a spat esda of humanity, it intends to review the Blue Card Directive , designed to 'regulate' the immigration of skilled labour, exclusively depending on the needs of businesses in the EU, i.e. by selecting 'desirable' migrants from the 'undesirable'.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: I have received requests from the ECR Group for nominations and amendments to committees and delegations. The list of these designations and amendments shall be published in the minutes of this session. These designations shall be deemed to be confirmed if no opposition is received until the approval of this Protocol.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to use Article 164 of the Rules of Procedure on the possibility of referring at the end of the debate on the item of the agenda in question to statements which concerned me personally. Mr Lambsdorff did not accept this notification. I would like to answer, at the end of the last point, the statements made by Mrs Kudrycka, which have been made here. Thank you very much, and you, Ladies and Gentlemen, Mrs Kudrycka was surprised by my expectation that President Donald Tusk, as President of the Council, will be at our meeting and will defend the Position of the European Council on immigration, a voluntary principle which is opposed to the establishment in the Position of the European Commission, which announced the quota for the sending of migrants around the countries of Europe. I do not know where Mr Tusk is at the moment. I know that this week he was at the election campaign in Poland, and I know one thing that he should be here today and present the Council's position, defending the position of the Countries of the European Union, because this is his first duty! Thank you very much.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Since Mr Jurek mentioned my name, I would like to make a clear statement about what he said. The Council was represented by a Minister from Latvia, from the Presidency, which is currently underway. The Head of the European Council, Donald Tusk, is currently preparing and preparing the Eastern Partnership Council, which will take place in Riga tomorrow and the day after tomorrow. As a result, mr Jurek's malicious insinuations have nothing to do because he has accused him of running any campaign. This is not true. President Donald Tusk prepares the Council for tomorrow's Riga Summit.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Perhaps for the time being, Mr Jurek, the Council is represented by the Presidency-in-Office. In other words, the presence of the Minister this morning is the normal procedure. For your better guidance, Mr Tusk is the President of the European Council. This is a different institution from the Council of the European Union. You have to keep that apart. (Applause) The President of the European Council reports here after the Summit of Heads of State or Government. Then comes Mr Tusk. However, we are all aware that the speeches have nothing to do with the presidential campaign in Poland. We all know that.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We shall now proceed to the election of a Vice-President in accordance with Rule 15, 17 and 20 of our Rules of Procedure. I have received the following nominations: – First of all, his candidacy was declared by his agreement: Mr Fabio Massimo Castaldo. – It has also been proposed with her agreement: Mrs Anneli Jäätteenmäki. The candidate and the candidate have informed me that they have each been proposed with their agreement. The election shall be conducted by secret electronic ballot. (The President explained the voting procedure. This is followed by a technical test tuning with two fictitious names.) Mr Lucke, you have asked for the floor. Do you want to run?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the No, I don't want to run. But I would ask that the two candidates introduce themselves very briefly, because I do not know the second candidate at all.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Lucke, that is not provided for in our Rules of Procedure. Elections take place without debate. But I have taken note of your request. Nevertheless, we are now going to the vote.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We are now going to the vote. (The vote was taken) (The President announced the result of the vote) – For Mr. Fabio Massimo Castaldo 285 votes – For Mrs Anneli Jäätteenmäki 301 votes. Madam President, congratulations on your election and welcome to the Bureau. Good cooperation!

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! No amendments have been tabled to the proposal of the Conference of Presidents for the calendar of meetings for 2016, which was announced to the plenary on Monday 18 May. I therefore declare the calendar of meetings approved.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: (Chairman of the INTA Committee). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which On the basis of this vote, which has changed significantly from the outcome of the committee's vote, I would request a brief interruption in accordance with Rule 61(2) of the Rules of Procedure, so that I can weigh this result with the rapporteur and the coordinators. I request a five-minute interruption in accordance with Article 61(2).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Chairman of the INTA Committee). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is Having discussed the discussion with the shadow rapporteurs, the rapporteur and the coordinators, there are differences of opinion as to the way forward the discussions. But I believe that we should decide on this in plenary. That is why, under Rule 61(2), I request that the final vote be suspended and that the trialogue be started.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission would like to highlight the reasons for the Commission Delegated Regulation repealing Regulation No 2336/2003 on the ethanol market. The Commission adopted this delegated regulation in the framework of its Better Regulation and simplification agenda. This Commission delegated act will remove administrative burdens for operators and administrators without affecting our border protection, allowing the Commission to continue monitoring the ethanol market in the European Union more efficiently.  At its meeting of 20 April 2015, the Council confirmed it had no objection to the Commission delegated regulation and the Commission made a statement to confirm that it will continue to collect the necessary data for monitoring the ethanol market, with particular attention to imports at zero duty.  The Commission invites the European Parliament to reject the motion of objection to the Commission delegated regulation. This will allow the publication of the regulation in the Official Journal of the European Union and its entry into force. This is an opportunity for the European Parliament to align itself with the objective of reducing red tape for European citizens and business and of simplifying European legislation, a shared responsibility to which the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission have committed together. The Commission confirms its commitment to a Better Regulation agenda as illustrated by the Better Regulation package adopted by the College.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, on a point of order, I was under the impression that political posters were not allowed in the Chamber but, when consulting the rule book, I could not actually find it. I notice that the other side of the Chamber is festooned with signs. My eyesight is not good enough to read them from here, but I presume they are of a political nature and therefore I assume that it is OK to display posters of a political nature. So I have therefore written my own hasty poster – ‘Vote UKIP’– which I will put here. If it is OK to display political posters I will bring a proper one next time and display it permanently in order to elicit votes from the electorate... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, we are all familiar with the arguments against this monthly peregrination between Brussels and Strasbourg. I am not planning to rehearse them again. I would rather hold up this meeting here as a symbol of the immobilism – the resistance to change – that all bureaucracies evolve over time. In fact, if you want a perfect physical symbol of what Milton Friedman calls the tyranny of the status quo, think of the trunks outside our offices. They date from a pre—e—mail age when it was necessary to move paperwork back and forth. Why do we still have them? Because an industry has grown up around their transportation: the lorry drivers, the removal men, and so on. What we see is that the European Union exists primarily for the benefit of its own employees, and that is why it is, in practice, impossible for a government fundamentally to reform the deal in Brussels. This is the classic tyranny of the status quo: it is why the British Government is making such paltry and unambitious demands. We know that, whatever we say, whatever our citizens believe, the system will continue to exist for the benefit of those lucky enough to be employed by it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to place on record that I oppose the monthly journeys from Brussels to Strasbourg and back, at a massive cost to the taxpayer.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this new working timetable for the European Parliament.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposed calendar for the 2016 plenary sessions.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. It was a procedural vote to determine the outcome of the plenary sessions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. 2016 will include 58 days of plenary sessions, including 12 sessions in Strasbourg and 5 mini-sessions in Brussels. This timetable does not call for comments since it is the same as in 2015 and does not tend to call into question the siege of Strasbourg. So I decided to vote for it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the European Parliament's timetable for 2016, in accordance with the proposal drawn up by the political groups and chamber bodies.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The next timetable includes changes to the minimum plenary sessions. Indeed, instead of standing on one day, they will be spread over two, with debates scheduled for Wednesday afternoon and votes on Thursday morning. I abstained on the vote on the calendar.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's timetable for 2016. I would like to point out, however, that, according to the treaties, the European Parliament sits in a plenary session in Strasbourg. The number of mini-plenary sessions in Brussels should therefore be reduced.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament spends more than EUR 200 million per year on the maintenance of the three offices (Brussels, Luxembourg and Strasbourg). Unfortunately, the new calendar of part-sessions confirms the status quo: every month around 5 000 people will continue to move to the French. This economic waste is compounded by travel pollution, with 19,000 tonnes of CO2 produced per year, when the European Union pledged to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 40% by 2030. I therefore voted against this timetable.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this change in the timetable, which will allow a return to normality, i.e. at a pace that allows for the optimal and more efficient work of parliamentarians during plenary sessions in Brussels; these will again take place over two days, which will allow the Wednesday to be devoted to real substantive debates since the votes will take place on Thursday.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, as provided for in Rule 145 of its Rules of Procedure, has been asked to give its opinion on the dates of the part-sessions for 2016. As I have not encountered any problems with the method, I voted in favour.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This decision aims to adopt the timetable for the work of the European Parliament and its plenary session periods for 2016. I note that twelve plenary sessions taking place in Strasbourg are planned in the same way as five "mini-sessions" taking place in Brussels. In the context of a reduction in European legislative activity, in accordance with the campaign commitments of the EPP and Jean-Claude Juncker to better legislate, the merits of these mini-sessions should be questioned and such a practice should not eventually be called into question by the Strasbourg plenary sessions, which are envisaged in the treaties. Nevertheless, considering that this proposal for a timetable respects the letter of the treaties in this regard, I voted in favour of this timetable but I will remain attentive and vigilant on this issue.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the timetable for Meetings of the European Parliament because we must have a programme!

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The calendar for 2016 is in line with the EP's working methodology. However, we also use this space to underline our opposition to the dual seat of Parliament for the obvious reasons that we have repeatedly pointed out.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Following an audit, the timetable for Parliament's part-sessions for 2016 was established.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to approve Parliament’s calendar of part-sessions for 2016.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I would like to thank President Schulz and parliament's Bureau for presenting us with the calendar of part-sessions scheduled for 2016 and I voted in favour of the proposal.  I would like to remind you once again of the importance of giving a concrete sign to the citizens of Europe by reducing bureaucratic costs and obstacles and by using our working time more efficiently: the double seat between Strasbourg and Brussels – although historically and symbolically understandable – is no longer functional to the proper conduct of parliamentary work; I therefore hope that Parliament, by a large majority, will be able to express itself once again in order to overcome this unnecessary waste.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 In the vote, I supported the proposal of the Conference of Presidents of the European Parliament on the dates of the 2016 short plenary sessions.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted to approve parliament's 2016 session schedule, as I consider the proposal presented by the Conference of Presidents to be well thought out, balanced and in line with Parliament's rules of procedure. I found no deficiency or deficiency in the proposed proposal.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Conference of Presidents' proposal on the 2016 plenary calendar. This timetable respects the European treaties and the 12 plenary sessions scheduled per year in Strasbourg. This timetable for the sessions was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposal of the Conference of Presidents setting out the timetable for plenary sessions for 2016.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The vote on parliament's calendar of part-sessions is one of the internal organisation decisions, which is the prerogative of us Members. By voting in favour, I voted in favour of organising it for 2016.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted for the European Parliament's 2016 calendar, and I am pleased that this year we have been spared the traditional manoeuvres to challenge Strasbourg's position as the seat of the European Parliament.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted with reservations in favour of the proposed timetable for Parliament's 2016 part-sessions, because this timetable, although it adequately and comprehensively promotes the legislative and other parliamentary activities of the European Parliament, nevertheless operates solely on the basis of the religious holidays of the Catholic Church and does not take into account the religious holidays of the Orthodox Churches even though a significant number of MEPs and MEPs are Orthodox Christians and , therefore, they are discriminated against in this regard in the exercise of their religious beliefs, in particular in relation to the Easter holiday.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual calendar of the European Parliament's work is set annually by Parliament on a proposal from the Conference of Presidents and is divided into part-sessions and meetings. I consider this to be a fundamental instrument for ensuring the management and organisation of parliamentary work. That is why I voted in favour of parliament's calendar of part-sessions for the year 2016.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Determining the timetable for its sessions is one of Parliament's responsibilities.  Unusually, in the proposed 2016 calendar, important national commemorations are respected. It does not offer sessions on May 8, July 14 or November 11. I vote for and strongly encourage this new attitude that respects history.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the Calendar of Parliament's sitting periods for the year 2016, hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support the proposed dates for part-sessions and finalise the days set for plenary duties next year.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to approve Parliament’s calendar for 2016.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This calendar of the plenary sessions of Parliament 2016 does not call for any particular remarks since it includes the same number of plenary sessions as in 2015, when there were fears of a decrease in these sessions given the european Parliament's stated desire to increase the time spent by Members in constituencies to preach the good European word.  Thus, 2016 will include 58 days of plenary sessions, including 12 sessions in Strasbourg and 5 mini-sessions in Brussels.  So I voted for it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the calendar of Parliament's 2016 part-sessions set by the Bureau of the European Parliament and the political groups.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The adoption of Parliament's 2016 session schedule has opened up a frequently asked question about the European Parliament's total costs for two-seat sessions. Respecting the historical connotations of the city of Strasbourg in the historical memory of Western Europe, and in terms of reconciliation among European nations after two great wars in the 20th century, and bearing in mind that the bulk of the EU institutions are based in Brussels, I think that after 70 years it is necessary to turn this page and look to the future. At a time when the southeastern part of the EU is in debt, while citizens are getting poorer and politicians, governments and all levels of state administration are being called out every day for unnecessary spending of taxpayers' funds, I consider it necessary to react again and ask that a decision be taken on one seat of the European Parliament as soon as possible.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒I support the proposal for a schedule of sessions for the following calendar year as it fulfils the obligations on the regular number of plenary sessions in Brussels and Strasbourg and is fully complementary to the existing Regulations on the Functioning of the European Parliament.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the adoption of the European Parliament's schedule of meetings, as I believe it regulates the dynamics of European Parliament meetings in an efficient and in line with past practice. Parliament's adopted calendar for 2016 retains twelve plenary sessions of the European Parliament in Strasbourg for four days, and introduces two-day plenary sessions in Brussels. Bearing in mind parliament's increasing workload and powers following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, I believe that the efficiencies of the work will also contribute to the two-day planned mini-plenary sessions in Brussels.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with the Conference of Presidents' proposal for the calendar of part-sessions for 2016, and I voted for approval.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, the timetable of the European Parliament's part-time periods for the year 2016 has been presented. I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the European Parliament's timetable for 2016, in accordance with the proposal agreed by the political groups and the chamber bodies.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. MEPs voted yesterday on the dates of the next plenary sessions of the European Parliament for 2016 in Strasbourg and Brussels. I will point out here, however, that I still prefer, for the reasons we know, a single seat for the European Chamber in Brussels. So, on this, at work!

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ We voted to approve Parliament’s calendar of part-sessions for 2016.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 As part of the Single Seat campaign, I would like to draw attention to the excessive waste of public funds, thus appealing to the inclusion of fewer days in plenary sessions in Strasbourg and the atteming of more days for plenary sessions in Brussels. By meeting the European Parliament in only one city, we will save taxpayers EUR 114 million.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support the 2016 session schedule, which is important for the quality preparation of European Parliament debates.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Following an audit, the timetable for Parliament's part-sessions for 2016 was established.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I take advantage of this explanation of vote to protest that this potential timetable was not yet online at the time of the votes, which indicates a lack of transparency on something that did not deserve the secrecy or at least any mention on the EP website.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2016 calendar of plenary sittings in Strasbourg and Brussels, adapting Parliament’s calendar to the legislative agenda.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the timetable for 2016, as it was a purely technical vote.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We have nothing to owe.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This recommendation gives the European Parliament's consent to add Croatia to the European Union's trade and cooperation agreement with South Africa, as Croatia acceded to the EU in July 2013 and the agreement concerned was signed in 1999 and entered into force in 2004. Thus, although it is a technical change which does not affect the substance of the trade and cooperation agreement, I abstained since I am in principle opposed to such agreements because it is in the best interest of multinationals and political-financial elites to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. The Council's proposed decision concerns the approval of the additional protocol to the CDC agreement between the EU and South Africa to take account of Croatia's accession to the Union. It therefore aims exclusively to make to the CDC agreement the few technical and linguistic changes made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Union. I am expressing opposition as a matter of principle to further enlargement of the EU and to all that follows. However, I abstained on this text because the initial agreement signed in Pretoria in 1999 aims to strengthen cooperation. I cannot therefore object to the development of ties between the EU and South Africa at a time when the new CDI has been halved to EUR 241 million for the period 2014-2020.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This additional protocol was made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Union. The agreement includes technical and linguistic changes. The aid package to South Africa will help the poorest, who have suffered the most from the deterioration of the economic and political situation in south Africa over the past two decades. This amounted to EUR 241 million over the period 2014-2020. A regular political dialogue is in place to make financial endowment more effective and effective. The agreement, signed in 1999, aimed to strengthen cooperation and support the process of economic and social transition. Nevertheless, I do not support the policy of enlargement of the Union, and therefore, for the sake of political coherence, I preferred not to vote for this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Believing that the UK should negotiate its own trade deals, UKIP MEPs customarily vote against such matters.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is only intended to make to the CDC agreement the few technical and linguistic changes made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Union. Its signature is required to allow the Republic of Croatia to become a party to the agreement.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal. The new Protocol takes into account Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with South Africa to conclude an additional protocol to the agreement on trade, development and cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and South Africa, on the other, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. This negotiation process was completed on 19 May 2014. The additional protocol is only intended to bring to the agreement on trade, development and cooperation the few technical and linguistic changes made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Union.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The report proposes approval for the conclusion of the additional protocol to make technical and linguistic changes to the CDC agreement. These changes follow Croatia's accession to the European Union, which on 1 July 2013 became the 28th Member State of the Union. The agreement in question, which dates from 1999 and was signed in Pretoria, was intended to support South Africa economically and socially and to establish a regular political dialogue with south Africa. If this cooperation seems necessary to me, I have indeed always promoted more dialogue on the international scene, the approval of the report in question would be tantamount to thinking that I am in favour of an ever-increasing enlargement of the borders of the European Union. This is obviously not the case, being firmly opposed to any enlargement process and wishing for a full recovery of our national sovereignty. Therefore, I abstain.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report itself is acceptable: it is a question of updating with an additional protocol the existing agreement between the EU and South Africa following Croatia's accession to the Union. What made me abstain is that I believe that these kinds of agreements should only be kept active with those countries that really need aid and cooperation in order to emerge from a situation of underdevelopment, while South Africa, despite going through a period of crisis, has shown in the recent past that it has an extremely flexible economy that has allowed it in a few years to move to a very important level of development and wealth compared to the previous phase of Poverty.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. On 11 October 1999, the EU and South Africa signed an Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation which entered into force on 1 May 2004 and aimed to strengthen bilateral dialogue, support South Africa in its economic and social transition process, promote regional cooperation and economic integration of the country in Southern Africa and the world economy , and expand and liberalize bilateral trade in goods, services and capital. The Agreement also established regular political dialogue on matters of common interest, both bilaterally and regionally. The agreement was revised in 2009 to introduce in development the demand for respect for democratic principles, human rights and the rule of law, cooperation on disarmament and non-proliferation issues of weapons of mass destruction and cooperation in new areas such as counter-terrorism and money laundering. Croatia's participation in the Agreement with South Africa is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and therefore approval should be given to the conclusion of this Additional Protocol to the Agreement with South Africa.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation, in which the European Parliament approves the conclusion of an additional protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Union and South Africa. The Additional Protocol was adopted by the Council on 9 October 2014 and by South Africa in December 2014. End. The Additional Protocol merely aims to include in the South African Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (TDS) a number of technical and linguistic amendments necessary following Croatia's accession to the European Union. The signature of the Additional Protocol is necessary in order for the Republic of Croatia to become a Contracting Party to the TDS. The Additional Protocol shall be added to the list of languages in the TDDS in Which the text is authentic in Croatian. The Government of the Republic of South Africa is currently deciding which representative to sign the Additional Protocol. The Council shall await the adoption of that decision before the signature is organised. Once the Protocol has been signed, the Council will formally ask the European Parliament to approve the conclusion of the Protocol.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report. Given that Croatia joined the EU in 2013, the harmonisation and completion of negotiations on trade, development and cooperation with South Africa should be accepted in faith in good cooperation in the future.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is important that Croatia, as a new Member State, is included in all treaties and agreements concluded by the European Union.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Allowing the new Member State of Croatia today to be an integral part of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of South Africa is not only an act due to the Republic of Croatia but is also an opportunity to reaffirm the value of the partnership between the EU and South Africa, which is not only a commercial aspect but is also a good example of cooperation and development. At present about 4 out of 10 South Africans live below the poverty line, the country suffers from serious inequality (Gini coefficient 0.7/1) and 25% of the population is out of work. The fact that, in addition to economic cooperation, the Agreement contains other provisions relating to important areas of cooperation and development (such as: social cooperation, on the basis of an organised dialogue focusing on freedom of association; workers' and children's rights; equality between men and women; combating violence against women; environmental cooperation, particularly with regard to climate change; cultural cooperation; cooperation in the fight against drugs and money laundering; cooperation in health matters, in particular in the fight against AIDS) make it a good example to take into account for other future agreements.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The additional protocol is intended only to make a few technical and linguistic changes made necessary by Croatia's accession to the European Union to the agreement on trade, development and cooperation. The initial agreement signed in Pretoria in 1999 aims to strengthen cooperation and support South Africa in its economic and social transition process, as well as to extend and liberalize bilateral trade in goods, services and capital. As this text has only a technical and legal scope, I abstained.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The original agreement signed in Pretoia in 1999 aims to strengthen bilateral cooperation in a number of areas aimed at objectives such as: strengthening bilateral dialogue, supporting South Africa in the process of economic and social transition, promoting regional cooperation and the country's economic integration within Southern Africa and the world economy. Furthermore, important provisions of the agreement concern, in addition to economic cooperation, social cooperation, on the basis of an organised dialogue on, in particular, freedom of association, workers' rights, children's rights, equality between women and men, combating violence against women, cooperation in the field of the environment, in particular with regard to climate change, cultural cooperation, cooperation in the field of combating drugs and money laundering , cooperation in the field of health, in particular the fight against AIDS. I voted in favour of this report because it welcomes the new development provisions, which were inserted at Kleinmond in 2009, in particular those on combating poverty, aid effectiveness, the MDGs and the link between migration and development.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. The vote, in itself, would be absolutely peaceful. It is a question of updating the trade, development and cooperation agreement with South Africa with an additional protocol, since today the EU has one more Member State. What makes me doubt the choice of a positive vote is precisely the need for such an agreement to be in force with a dynamically economy country such as South Africa. South Africa is one of the so-called 'BRICS', that is, those countries that in a few years have moved to very important levels of development and wealth compared to an earlier phase of poverty. Of course, the crisis is hitting South Africa hard, with very high unemployment rates, but that does not alter the fact that agreements of this kind must remain in force only with countries that really need aid and cooperation in order to get out of underdevelopment.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Since Croatia's accession to the European Union in July 2013, the EU's international treaties with third countries must take this new accession into account. This report takes into account Croatia's accession to the agreement on trade, development and cooperation between the European Community and its Member States and the Republic of South Africa. I voted in favour of this text which approves this protocol change.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement ("TDCA") between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other, was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. Considering that the Republic of Croatia has joined the EU as the twenty-eighth Member State, the proposal for a Council decision aims to approve the Additional Protocol to the TDCA between the EU and South Africa, taking into account croatia's accession to the European Union, on behalf of the Union itself and its Member States. I consider this proposal to be logical and have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the document does not present any particular critical issues for which I should have voted against.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report, which provides for the approval of an additional protocol to the agreement on trade and development and cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other, in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. Of course, the protocol is only intended to make the necessary changes to this trade agreement to take into account Croatia's accession to the EU; there is therefore, in itself, no substantive change to the agreement signed in Pretoria in 1999, which aims to strengthen cooperation and development policies with regard to South Africa. Furthermore, I am in favour of the aspect of regular political dialogue with that country in the agreement, especially since it does not provide for any specific financial allocation but provisions on the fight against drugs and money laundering. However, I could not be totally in favour of an agreement which is part of a logic of endless enlargement of the EU. I therefore abstained: while I am in favour of cooperation with South Africa, I oppose the principle of unlimited enlargement.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 This measure concerns the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of South Africa, of the other part, to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, as the 28th Member State , which took place on 1 July 2013. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The trade, development and cooperation agreement with South Africa aims not only to strengthen trade relations with the Pretoria government, but also to deepen development cooperation issues.  In this context, the signing of an additional protocol would enable Croatia, as a new Member State, to become a contracting party to this agreement. Therefore, in view of the important implications that this agreement could have for the European Union, especially in terms of development and cooperation, I intend to vote in favour of this draft resolution.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament must give its approval for new Member States to be recognised as signatories of the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (TDCA) between the European Community and its Member States and the Republic of South Africa. I have thus voted in favour of this technical measure to take into account Croatia’s accession to the EU.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement ("TDCA") between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other, was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004.  On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia joined the EU and became the 28th Member State. The draft Council decision aims to approve the Additional Protocol to the TDCA between the EU and South Africa, which takes account of Croatia's accession to the European Union, on behalf of the Union and its Member States. The purpose of the Additional Protocol is only to make the abovementioned agreement the few technical and linguistic adjustments required by Croatia's accession to the EU. The signing of the Additional Protocol is necessary to enable the Republic of Croatia to become a contracting party to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – This recommendation grants the European Parliament's consent to add Croatia to the European Union's trade and cooperation agreement with South Africa, as Croatia acceded to the EU in July 2013 and the agreement concerned was signed in 1999 and entered into force in 2004. Thus, although it is a technical change which does not affect the substance of the trade and cooperation agreement, I abstained since I am in principle opposed to such agreements because it is in the best interest of multinationals and political-financial elites to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed Council decision aims to approve the Additional Protocol to the EU South Africa TDCA taking into account Croatia’s accession to the EU. I voted in favour of this technical adjustment to take note of Croatia’s accession.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to give the European Parliament the agreement to ratify an additional protocol approved by the Council in October 2014 to allow Croatia to join the agreement on trade, development and cooperation with the Republic of South Africa. Considering that it is normal for Croatia, as a full member of the European Union, to become a party to the agreement on trade, development and cooperation with the Republic of South Africa, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement ("TDCA") between the European Union and the Republic of South Africa was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia joined the EU and became the twenty-eighth Member State. I voted in favour of this protocol, which aims to make the technical and linguistic adjustments required by Croatia's accession to the European Union to the TDCA Agreement.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Parliament has given its approval for the Council to conclude on behalf of the EU and its Member States the additional agreement taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU in the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (CDC) between the European Community and the Republic of South Africa, from 11 October 1999. Simple technical and linguistic changes will be made to reflect this development, and to update the existing agreement.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the recommendation on the trade, development and cooperation agreement with South Africa (protocol to take into account Croatia's accession). This recommendation leads to support for EU enlargement projects. They threaten both the cultural identity and the economy of our states. Croatia's entry into the EU is an open door for Western Balkan migrants to reach Central Europe. While increased cooperation with South Africa is desirable, a green light given to supranational enlargement institutions is unthinkable. My abstention was therefore necessary in order to protect our states from European gigantism.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (TDCA) between the EU and South Africa was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and revised in Kleinmond in South Africa on 11 September 2009. The revised agreement from 2009 inserted the new provisions on development, in particular as regards combating poverty, aid effectiveness, the Millennium Development Goals and the link between migration and development. On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia acceded to the EU. The proposed Council decision aims to approve, on behalf of the EU and its Member States, the additional protocol to the EU-South Africa TDCA taking account of Croatia’s accession to the EU.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported Mr Stieer's report on the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (TSD) with South Africa, as it gives the Council the right to conclude an additional protocol with South Africa with a view to Croatia's accession to the EU.  The Additional Protocol is only intended to make small technical and linguistic adaptations to the TDC that are necessary with Croatia's accession to the EU. However, this Protocol is necessary, in particular, to enable the Republic of Croatia to become a Contracting Party to the TDC.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Croatia has always pursued a stable Anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of extending the scope of the Protocol to the EU-South Africa Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement to Croatia. Croatia is a member of the European Union, so all international treaty treaty treaty contracts concluded by the EU also apply to Croatia. To do this, you need to take the necessary legal action, this is the current one.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The new development cooperation financing instrument for the period 2014-2020 has a budget of EUR 241 million for South Africa. In addition to economic cooperation, the agreement contains other provisions covering a number of areas of cooperation very relevant to development, such as social cooperation, environmental cooperation, in particular on climate change, cultural cooperation, cooperation in the fight against drugs and money laundering, cooperation in the area of health and in particular on climate change, cultural cooperation, cooperation in the fight against drugs and money laundering, cooperation in the area of health and in particular on , in the fight against ISD. The revised agreement introduces a number of significant development changes into the initial agreement. Democratic principles, human rights and the rule of law, cooperation on disarmament and the non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction have become essential elements in the agreement. Factors that I consider positive and deserve my approval.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution because I am opposed to any further enlargement, but there is no possibility here of opposing the EU-South Africa bilateral agreements.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (TITA), signed by the EU and South Africa in 1999, aims to strengthen their cooperation in several areas. The Objectives of the ACDC is to strengthen dialogue between the parties, support for South Africa in its economic and social transition process, the promotion of regional cooperation, the country's economic integration in Southern Africa and the world economy, as well as the expansion and liberalisation of trade in goods, services and capital between the parties. Since its signature, this agreement has been revised several times to extend its scope. This report intends to adopt an Additional Protocol in order to introduce into the ACDC some necessary language adaptations due to croatia's accession. Although this revision is of an eminently technical nature, we cannot go away from one of the general objectives of this agreement: the progressive establishment of a free trade area (FTAs) on the free movement of goods. We are well known the consequences of these trade agreements. Our position on free trade and trade deregulation is also well known.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council Decision aims, in this case, at approving an Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of South Africa, of the other part, in order to take account of croatia's accession to the European Union. It is currently waiting to see who the Government in South Africa will entrust with signing the additional protocol in question.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, if not carefully considered, would seem absolutely peaceful. It is a question of updating the trade, development and cooperation agreement with South Africa with an additional protocol, since the EU now has one more Member State. The issue that is not detected is how over time the economies of the world with which the EU maintains relations change and this, especially in the case of the so-called BRICS, should be evaluated much more carefully. That is why I shall abstain.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation with South Africa (Protocol to take account of Croatia's accession). Croatia has always pursued a stable Anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ South Africa is a strategic partner for the EU, especially given its influential role in the Southern African region and the continent as a whole. The TDCA is working very well and enables the trade and development perspectives to be combined. I welcome the accession of Croatia, as a new member of the EU, to this important trade and development cooperation relationship.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the EU and South Africa, which needed to be updated after Croatia's accession as a Member State.  I would particularly like to highlight a number of new areas on which the agreement has been particularly improved: the fight against weapons of mass destruction; the fight against terrorist financing and organised crime; combating the production, trade and accumulation of so-called 'small arms' weapons; the prevention of mercenary activities; unconditional support for the International Criminal Court and its work to end impunity and enforce international justice.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Stier report, given that it simply concerns a codification to take into account the accession of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, which is not about the agreement between the European Union and the South African Republic, but on an additional protocol that simply takes into account the Republic of Croatia's access to the EU, because we consider it logical that Croatia, as the new EU Member State, should also be included in the agreement. The Agreement on Trade and Cooperation between the EU and its Member States on the one hand, and the South African Republic on the other, was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. In July 2013 the Republic of Croatia joined the EU.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed Council decision aims to approve the Additional Protocol to the EU South Africa TDCA taking into account Croatia’s accession to the EU. I voted in favour of this technical adjustment to take note of Croatia’s accession.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal. It is a procedural solution that includes a number of technical and linguistic amendments that are necessary following Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, which is not about the agreement between the European Union and the South African Republic, but on an additional protocol that simply takes into account the Republic of Croatia's access to the EU, because we consider it logical that Croatia, as the new EU Member State, should also be included in the agreement. The Agreement on Trade and Cooperation between the EU and its Member States on the one hand, and the South African Republic on the other, was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. In July 2013 the Republic of Croatia joined the EU.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. With Croatia's entry into the EU, it is important to underline the importance of agreement that emphasizes the fight against poverty, aid effectiveness, the MDGs and the link between migration and development.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other hand, in order to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union, as technical and linguistic adjustments are necessary for Croatia to become a full-fledged Contracting Party. Thus, Croatia, as a member of the European Union, becomes part of bilateral and regional cooperation that was established in 1999 with the Republic of South Africa. This Agreement supports the country concerned in the economic and social transition, and I believe that at the same time political dialogue is being improved in areas of common interest

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I have decided to abstain on this vote. This is an additional protocol made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Union. The agreement includes technical and linguistic changes. The aid package to South Africa will help the poorest for whom the last 20 years have been particularly difficult. This amounted to EUR 241 million over the period 2014-2020. In addition, a regular political dialogue is put in place to make financial endowment more effective and effective. The agreement, signed in 1999, aimed to strengthen cooperation and support the process of economic and social transition. Nevertheless, I cannot endorse the policy of enlargement of the Union, and therefore, for the sake of political coherence, I preferred not to vote for this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Davor Ivo Stier's report on the agreement on trade, development and cooperation with South Africa. An additional Memorandum of Understanding is currently under discussion with South Africa to ensure that Croatia is included in this agreement; as the last Member State to join the Union, it was not a party to the agreement until now. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the additional protocol to the agreement on trade, development and cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other, in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report on the agreement with South Africa does not change the current legal situation, i.e. it does not add value. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it is of a technical, not a political, nature that takes into account the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Stier's report on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement with South Africa to take account of Croatia's accession. I welcome the new development provisions introduced in the agreement on trade, development and cooperation, particularly as regards the fight against poverty, the effectiveness of aid and the link between migration and development, always bearing in mind the importance of compliance with security rules and reciprocity clauses.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the agreement on trade, development and cooperation with South Africa (protocol to take into account Croatia's accession). On the one hand, this is an opposition in principle to any further enlargement of the European Union. On the other hand, I am obviously not opposed to bilateral ties between the European Union and South Africa.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I abstained on this proposal to approve the conclusion of this additional protocol. Croatia has been a member since 1 July 2013. Although I can support the development of relations between the European Union and South Africa, this proposal is part of the enlargement of this Union. In addition, the bulk of cooperation aid to South Africa is funded from the EU budget.  Provisions are thus in place for the fight against drugs and money laundering. In addition to my opposition to the policy of enlargement of the European Union, I believe that, as is often the case, the European Union is pursuing a policy of interference. That's why I abstained.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation (ACDC) between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other hand, was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. It was revised in Kleinmond, South Africa, on 11 September 2009. The signing of this Additional Protocol is necessary to enable the Republic of Croatia to become a Contracting Party to the ACDC, as on 1 July 2013 the Republic of Croatia joined the EU.  The objective of the Additional Protocol merely formulates in the ACDC the few technical and linguistic adaptations required by Croatia's accession to the EU, so vote in favour of this project.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because it is only an amendment taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union and does not imply a change in the substance of the documents.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support the recommendation of Representative Davor Ivo Stier, who gives his consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States and the Republic of South Africa, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The agreement was signed in 1999 and entered into force in 2004. The purpose of the Agreement is to enhance bilateral cooperation by increasing dialogue between signed parties, assisting South Africa in the process of economic and social transition, and promoting regional cooperation and integration. The revised text of the 2009 Agreement included cooperation in the areas of democracy and human rights, the fight against poverty, terrorism and organised crime, which is South Africa's big problem. Since the Republic of Croatia has become a member of the European Union, it is necessary to sign an additional Protocol in order for Croatia to join the Agreement and have the same conditions as other Member States and to participate in the development of South Africa. Changes to the additional protocol are technical. Croatian-South African relations are very good and there have never been any disputes between these two countries. Along with political relations, trade and economic relations have been developing more and more recently. By helping South Africa, we also help Croats who live there, most of whom are in humanitarian missions.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Republic of Croatia has become the 28th Member State of the European Union since 1 July 2013. The signing of the Additional Protocol is necessary in order to allow the Republic of Croatia to become a Contracting Party to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation which strengthens cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and the Republic of South Africa.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of South Africa, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union , because Title IV-other provisions cover a number of very important areas of development-related cooperation, such as social cooperation on the basis of an organised dialogue on freedom of association, workers' rights, children's rights, equality between women and men, the fight against violence against women, etc.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of this report on the decision incorporating Croatia into the EU trade agreement with South Africa.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. The purpose of this vote was to make changes to the agreement between the EU and South Africa, following Croatia's accession. These were only technical and linguistic changes. Although we are not opposed to dialogue between the EU and South Africa, we are against EU enlargement and we were against Croatia's accession. Also, we abstained.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the trade, development and cooperation agreement with South Africa.
