The basis of this agreement is an agreement to strengthen bilateral cooperation in a number of areas, seeking to achieve a number of objectives: strengthening bilateral dialogue, supporting South Africa in its economic and social transition process, promoting regional cooperation and working on the liberalisation of bilateral trade in goods, services and capital.  It is essentially an agreement which strengthens relations between the two realities and is working to improve the political and economic dialogue.  These are the main reasons why I am in favour of the agreement.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support this Parliament's draft legislative resolution in view of the Council's decision to conclude an Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other hand, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I also abstained from voting on an agreement on trade, development and cooperation with the Republic of South Africa. The general cooperation with the Republic of South Africa is to be welcomed, but I believe that the planned further allocation of EUR 241 million for the period 2014-2020 is not appropriate, given the current financial situation of the Union.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. An agreement on trade, development and cooperation (the CDC agreement) between the EU and South Africa has been under way since 2004. To take account of Croatia's accession, the Memorandum of Understanding should be amended to include Croatia. Opposed to both free trade agreements and any new EU membership, I can only oppose this amendment, even if it remains purely technical. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This is an additional protocol made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Union. The agreement includes technical and linguistic changes. The aid package to South Africa will help the poorest for whom the last 20 years have been particularly difficult. This amounted to EUR 241 million over the period 2014-2020. In addition, a regular political dialogue is put in place to make financial endowment more effective and effective. The agreement, signed in 1999, aimed to strengthen cooperation and support the process of economic and social transition. Nevertheless, it is not possible to endorse the union's enlargement policy, and therefore, for the sake of political coherence, I preferred not to vote for this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The ACDC between the EU and its Member States—on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, of the other part, was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. It was revised in Kleinmond (South Africa) on September 11, 2009.  This proposal aims only to ratify the Protocol in the light of Croatia's recent accession to the EU.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this technical measure, as Parliament must give its consent before new Member States can be recognised by signatories of the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement. In this case, Parliament had to give its consent on the agreement being amended to take into account the Treaty of Accession of Croatia.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposed Council decision which aims to approve the Additional Protocol to the EU South Africa TDCA taking account of Croatia’s accession to the EU, on behalf of the Union and its Member States, and I welcome the accession of Croatia, as a new member of the EU, to this important trade and development cooperation relationship.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, of the other part, was signed in Pretoria in 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004 and was revised in Kleinmond, South Africa, on 11 September 2009. I am voting in favour of the proposal for a Council Decision to adopt the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the EU and South Africa, taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU on behalf of the Union and its Member States. The Additional Protocol was adopted by the Council on 9 October 2014 and by South Africa at the end of December 2014.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. After Croatia's accession to the EU on 1 July 2013, becoming the 29th Member State, this report aims to approve the conclusion of the additional protocol amending the CDC agreement through technical and linguistic changes.  The agreement, signed in Pretoria in 1999, was intended to support South Africa economically and socially by establishing a political dialogue with state leaders. However, if this exchange and cooperation with sovereign states seems to me to be essential to the proper functioning of international relations, the acceptance of this report would suggest that I am in favour of an infinite enlargement of the EU's borders. However, being opposed to the fact that the EU can play any role in the foreign policy of the Member States, I have decided to abstain.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as the changes to the agreement are minor and technical – for example to include Croatian as one of the languages into which documents should be translated. The agreement also establishes a regular political dialogue on issues of mutual interest at both bilateral and regional level (as part of the EU’s dialogue with the countries of Southern Africa and the ACP group of countries).

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the extension of the Additional Protocol on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States and the Republic of South Africa to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. We take this opportunity to note that the agreement on trade, development and cooperation is bearing fruit, both as regards trade and as regards the prospects linked to the development of South Africa. The Republic of South Africa is a strategic partner of the EU, especially in view of its leading role in southern Africa and on the continent as a whole.  On the other hand, Croatia's accession to the European Union is a very positive development, which in our view makes it automatic that the agreement with the Republic of South Africa should be extended. Croatia and South Africa are two countries with a dramatic recent past, albeit in a different way, which, also thanks to their relationship with the European Union, want to look to the future with confidence and hope.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of South Africa, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. This project solves a technical aspect generated by Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Although the agreement or protocol is a purely technical measure, I have some substantive concerns which ultimately led me to abstain.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The signing of the Additional Protocol is necessary to enable the Republic of Croatia to become a party to this Agreement as a new member of the EU. In addition, some linguistic and technical changes will be introduced.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Whereas the additional protocol is intended solely to make to the Agreement on trade, development and cooperation between the European Community and the Republic of South Africa the few technical and linguistic adjustments required by Croatia's accession to the EU; that the signature of the Additional Protocol is necessary to enable the Republic of Croatia to become a Contracting Party to that Agreement; that, in addition to economic cooperation, other provisions refer to a number of very important and development-related areas of cooperation, such as social cooperation, on the basis of an organised dialogue concerning, in particular, freedom of association, workers' and children's rights, equality between men and women, the fight against violence against women, environmental cooperation and the protection of the environment. , in particular with regard to climate change, cultural cooperation, cooperation in the fight against drugs and money laundering and cooperation in the field of health, in particular in the fight against AIDS. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒The Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (TDCA) between the EU and its Member States with the Republic of South Africa is a bilateral agreement aimed at the process of economic and social transition, promoting regional cooperation and economic integration of the country, the global economy, and extending the liberalisation of bilateral trade in goods, services and capital. The agreement also establishes a regular political dialogue on issues of common interest at bilateral and regional level.  I supported the Additional Protocol to this Agreement because it regulates relations between the Republic of Croatia as a Member State of the European Union and the Republic of South Africa and represents the possibility of establishing more efficient partnerships and more profitable trade links with this part of the world. In particular, I would like to point out the prescribed retroactive application of the provisions of the Agreement of 1 July 2013, which will result in Croatian businessmen, following the entry into force of the Additional Protocol, to request from the customs authorities the reimbursement of paid duties for goods imported from 1 July 2013 on the basis of subsequently issued evidence of the origin of the goods.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. To the extent that I am opposed to any enlargement of the European Union, I can only be opposed to the measures that go in this direction. Nevertheless, it is a technical text to take into account Croatia's entry into the EU. The initial agreement signed in Pretoria in 1999 aims to strengthen cooperation and support South Africa in its economic and social transition process, as well as to extend and liberalize bilateral trade in goods, services and capital. The agreement also establishes a regular political dialogue. It would not be very relevant to vote against it, but I would like to disagree with the EU's enlargement policy and I therefore prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒The proposed Council Decision aims to approve the Additional Protocol to the TDCA EU-South Africa Agreement taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU, on behalf of the Union and its Member States. On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with South Africa in order to conclude the Additional Protocol. These negotiations were successfully concluded on 19 May 2014. The additional protocol was approved by the Council on 9 October 2014 and South Africa at the end of December 2014. The additional protocol aims, among other things, at bringing into the TDCA several technical and linguistic adjustments that required Croatia's accession to the European Union, which is also necessary to enable the Republic of Croatia to become a contracting party to the TDCA. The additional protocol (Article 2) adds The Croatian language to the list of the original languages of the TDCA.  The revised 2009 Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the EU and its Member States brings a number of interesting changes to the guidelines for combating money laundering, terrorist financing and organised crime, combating the production and trade of small arms and light weapons and their accumulation, and the prevention of mercenary activities. The revised Agreement is also an unwavering basis for action by the ICJ to put an end to impunity and contribute to the enforcement of international justice. Due to these items, I support colleague Stier's report on the conclusion of the Additional Protocol.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒As a Croatian MEP, I strongly support this Recommendation on the Draft Decision of the Council on the Conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa (TDCA), on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Croatia became a full member of the European Union in 2013 and as such has assumed all the rights and obligations required by the Accession Treaty, including the application of this Agreement. As the Act on accession act of the European Union acts on behalf of the States, in this case the Council carried out all necessary negotiations on the additional procedures set out in the Additional Protocol. The additional protocol provides for only certain technical and linguistic adjustments and its adoption makes Croatia one of the Contracting Parties to the TDCA.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Following Croatia's accession to the European Union, it was necessary to start negotiations with South Africa for the approval of the additional protocol to the agreement between the EU and South Africa to take account of Croatia's accession. It is a due procedure when there is the accession of a new Member State, so I voted in favour.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Parliament on Wednesday approved the conclusion of the additional protocol to the agreement on trade, development and cooperation with South Africa, which came into force in 2004. I voted in favour of this text, which mainly brings to the original agreement technical and linguistic changes after Croatia joined the Union in July 2013.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Additional Protocol to the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (TCDC) between the EU and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of South Africa, of the other part, was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. It was revised in Kleinmond (South Africa) on 11 September 2009. This agreement aims to strengthen bilateral cooperation in a number of areas and pursues several objectives, including: strengthening bilateral dialogue; support South Africa in its process of economic and social transition; promote regional cooperation and economic integration of the country in Southern Africa and the world economy; and expand and liberalize bilateral trade in goods, services and capital. Since the Republic of Croatia joined the EU on 1 July 2013, it was necessary to ensure that the Member State fully participates in bilateral relations with South Africa.  I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the conclusion of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation with South Africa, in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 It is an Additional Protocol which aims to introduce into the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (TCDC) some technical and linguistic adaptations, necessary due to Croatia's accession to the EU and for croatia to become a contracting party alongside the other Member States.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. On 11 October 1999, the EU and South Africa signed an Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation which entered into force on 1 May 2004 and aimed to strengthen bilateral dialogue, support South Africa in its economic and social transition process, promote regional cooperation and economic integration of the country in Southern Africa and the world economy , and expand and liberalize bilateral trade in goods, services and capital. The Agreement also established regular political dialogue on issues of common interest, both bilaterally and regionally. The agreement was revised in 2009 to introduce in development the demand for respect for democratic principles, human rights and the rule of law, cooperation on disarmament and non-proliferation issues of weapons of mass destruction and cooperation in new areas such as counter-terrorism and money laundering. Croatia's participation in the Agreement with South Africa is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and therefore approval should be given to the conclusion of this Additional Protocol to the Agreement with South Africa.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia joined the European Union and became its 28th Member State. The Council's proposal for a decision put to a vote today concerns the approval, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the additional protocol to the CDC agreement between the UNION and South Africa to take account of Croatia's accession to the Union (on 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with the Republic of South Africa for the conclusion of the additional protocol. These negotiations were concluded on 19 May 2014). The additional protocol was approved by the Council on 9 October 2014, and by South Africa at the end of December 2014. The vote in the European Parliament was logically followed.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation presented, which provides for the approval of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other.  In this way, the Republic of Croatia, the last country in chronological order to have obtained European membership, will also be able to participate in the agreement in question.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report, which is not about the agreement between the European Union and the South African Republic, but on an additional protocol which simply takes into account the Republic of Croatia's access to the EU, because we consider it logical that Croatia, as a new EU Member State, should also be included in the agreement. The Agreement on Trade and Cooperation between the EU and its Member States on the one hand, and the South African Republic on the other, was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. In July 2013 the Republic of Croatia joined the EU.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This recommendation gives the European Parliament's consent to add Croatia to the European Union's trade and cooperation agreement with South Africa, as Croatia acceded to the EU in July 2013 and the agreement concerned was signed in 1999 and entered into force in 2004. Thus, although it is a technical change which does not affect the substance of the trade and cooperation agreement, I abstained since I am in principle opposed to such agreements because it is in the best interest of multinationals and political-financial elites to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament consented to the Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of South Africa, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting the motion for a resolution of the Council decision on the conclusion of an Additional Protocol to the AGREEMENT on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the EU and the Republic of South Africa to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU, as the aim of this resolution was to introduce a number of technical and linguistic adaptations to this Agreement, and the signing of the Additional Protocol was necessary in order for the Republic of Croatia to become a Party to the TDCA.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the amendment of the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement with South Africa to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union. The treaty needs ratification in order to apply the same rules, as the EU has with South Africa on trade, development and cooperation, on croatia's relationship with South Africa after Croatia's accession to the EU. The additional Protocol aims to adapt several technical and linguistic parts, such as Croatia's entry into the EU. The signing of the Additional Protocol is necessary to enable the Republic of Croatia to achieve the status of a Contracting Party in the Agreement. It adds Croatian terms used in traffic certificates. This raises the possibility of temporary crossing of goods in the route or temporary storage in Croatia or South Africa.  The agreement, first signed in Pretoria in 1999, establishes a regular political dialogue on issues of common interest at bilateral and European level. In addition to economic cooperation, other treaty provisions cover many other areas of cooperation, such as social cooperation relating to freedom of association, labour rights, the rights of the child, equality between women and men, the fight against violence against women, the environment, climate change, cultural cooperation and the fight against AIDS.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 As the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other hand, entered into force on 1 May 2004, it was necessary to conclude an Additional Protocol in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU.  It is important to emphasize that the agreement of the Additional Protocol is necessary in order for the Republic of Croatia to become a contracting party in the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation. This would enhance bilateral dialogue between the European Community and its Member States and the Republic of South Africa, expand bilateral trade in goods, services and capital, and also establish a political dialogue on problems of common interest at bilateral and regional level. For all of the above, I support this report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to give consent on this report, which includes the accession of Croatia in the EU’s Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement with South Africa.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒I supported the Recommendation on the Draft Decision of the Council on the Conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Additional Protocol to the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (TDCA) between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of South Africa, on the other, in order to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union. The TDCA was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and was intended to enhance bilateral cooperation in a number of areas. It pursues several objectives: strengthening bilateral dialogue, supporting South Africa in its economic and social transition process, promoting regional cooperation and economic integration of the country within South Africa and the global economy, and expanding and liberalising bilateral trade in goods, services and capital.  The aim of the proposed Council decision is to approve the Additional Protocol with the TDCA between the EU and South Africa taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU, on behalf of the Union and its Member States. The additional protocol only seeks to make in the TDCA several technical and linguistic adjustments that require Croatia's entry into the EU. The signing of the Additional Protocol is necessary in order to enable the Republic of Croatia to become a contracting party to the TDCA. The additional protocol adds Croatian to the list of native TDCA languages, and sets transitional provisions for goods on the road or on temporary storage in Croatia or South Africa, or between both countries.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ as it only aims to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Croatia has always pursued a stable Anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. I would like to take this opportunity to welcome the new development provisions included in the CDC agreement in Kleinmond in 2009, including the fight against poverty, aid effectiveness, the MDGs and the links between migration and development.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of an additional Protocol to the Agreement on Trade, Development and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Although the Protocol is of a technical nature, it enables the Republic of Croatia to become a contracting party to the Agreement and continue to represent the interests of the Croatian economy in South Africa. Membership in the European Union has opened up numerous opportunities for Croatia to access markets in view of trade agreements concluded or concluded by the European Union with third countries.  With good political relations, trade between the Republic of Croatia and South Africa is increasingly developing as is economic relations. Therefore, I consider changes of technical nature such as the introduction of the Croatian language on the list of official languages in the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement extremely important so that as a Contracting Party it can adopt and be properly informed about the texts related to the Agreement.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, which is not about the agreement between the European Union and the South African Republic, but on an additional protocol that simply takes into account the Republic of Croatia's access to the EU, because we consider it logical that Croatia, as the new EU Member State, should also be included in the agreement. The Agreement on Trade and Cooperation between the EU and its Member States on the one hand, and the South African Republic on the other, was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. In July 2013 the Republic of Croatia joined the EU.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia acceded to the EU and became its 28th  Member State. The proposed Council decision aims to approve the Additional Protocol to the EU-South Africa TDCA taking account of Croatia’s accession to the EU, on behalf of the Union and its Member States. (On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with South Africa in order to conclude the Additional Protocol. Those negotiations were successfully completed on 19 May 2014).  I support and give consent to the conclusion of the Additional Protocol.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report, which is not about the agreement between the European Union and the South African Republic, but on an additional protocol which simply takes into account the Republic of Croatia's access to the EU, because we consider it logical that Croatia, as a new EU Member State, should also be included in the agreement. The Agreement on Trade and Cooperation between the EU and its Member States on the one hand, and the South African Republic on the other, was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. In July 2013 the Republic of Croatia joined the EU.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This recommendation gives the European Parliament's consent to add Croatia to the European Union's trade and cooperation agreement with South Africa, as Croatia acceded to the EU in July 2013 and the agreement concerned was signed in 1999 and entered into force in 2004. Thus, although it is a technical change which does not affect the substance of the trade and cooperation agreement, I abstained since I am in principle opposed to such agreements because it is in the best interest of multinationals and political-financial elites to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The Objectives of the ACDC is to strengthen dialogue between the parties, support for South Africa in its economic and social transition process, promote regional cooperation, the country's economic integration in Southern Africa and the world economy, as well as the expansion and liberalisation of trade in goods, services and capital between the parties. Since its signature, this agreement has been revised several times to extend its scope. This report intends to adopt an Additional Protocol in order to introduce into the ACDC some necessary language adaptations due to croatia's accession. This revision is technical in nature, but we cannot be abstracted from one of the general objectives of this agreement: the progressive establishment of a free trade area (FTAs) on the free movement of goods

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I also abstained from voting on an agreement on trade, development and cooperation with the Republic of South Africa. The general cooperation with the Republic of South Africa is to be welcomed, but I believe that the planned further allocation of EUR 241 million for the period 2014-2020 is not appropriate, given the current financial situation of the Union.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I voted in favour of approving, on behalf of the Union and its Member States, the Additional Protocol to the EU-South Africa Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement, which takes into account Croatia's accession to the EU.  The Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement between EU Member States and South Africa was signed in Pretoria on 11 October 1999 and entered into force on 1 May 2004. On 24 September 2012 The Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with South Africa with a view to concluding an Additional Protocol. Negotiations on this issue were successfully concluded on 19 May 2014. The purpose of the Additional Protocol is solely to introduce into the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement the few technical and linguistic changes necessary for Croatia's accession to the EU. The signing of the Additional Protocol is necessary in order for the Republic of Croatia to become a party to the Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement with South Africa.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text which makes Croatia a party to the trade, development and cooperation agreement between the EU and its Member States with the Republic of South Africa. The report adjusts the necessary details to the text of the agreement in order to allow Croatia to join.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement (TITA), signed by the EU and South Africa in 1999, aims to strengthen their cooperation in several areas. The Objectives of the ACDC is to strengthen dialogue between the parties, support for South Africa in its economic and social transition process, the promotion of regional cooperation, the country's economic integration in Southern Africa and the world economy, as well as the expansion and liberalisation of trade in goods, services and capital between the parties. Since its signature, this agreement has been revised several times to extend its scope. This report intends to adopt an Additional Protocol in order to introduce into the ACDC some necessary language adaptations due to croatia's accession. Although this revision is of an eminently technical nature, we cannot go away from one of the general objectives of this agreement: the progressive establishment of a free trade area (FTAs) on the free movement of goods. We are well known the consequences of these trade agreements.  Our position on free trade and trade deregulation is also well known.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this proposal to amend the directive governing the fight against dirty money. This is also a very strong topic at the national level, e.g. in the Czech Republic. I am very glad that this proposal for a directive addresses the issue of further sanctioning anonymous shares and informing them who is the beneficial owner of individual companies. We have also addressed this issue in the Czech Republic, we have put forward a proposal that essentially abolishes anonymous shares, and I believe that this is the right way to go. I am also very happy that the European Union is moving in this direction, because anonymous shares offer a great deal of scope for legalising money derived from crime or money that does not have a clear origin. I therefore consider this decision by the European Parliament today to be a step in the right direction and a way to go and fight organised crime.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the report on the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, given that it provides a crucial tool in the fight against tax avoidance and fraud, and can play a vital role in cutting off a funding stream to terrorists. Therefore, the more transparency we can have, the better. By setting up public registers we increase transparency on the financial flux. However, as the recent tax scandals show, we remain heavily dependent on the action of whistleblowers working in the business, so we need to convince these whistleblowers to reveal cases of tax avoidance and tax fraud, because Member States are often not willing to do so. We need to have a follow-up step of having a European framework to protect them.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I have noticed something in this Chamber. Whenever people want to expand the powers of EU bodies – whether it is Europol or Eurojust or any of the quangos attached to the European Union – they always have the last-ditch argument of security, and we are all supposed to say ‘Oh security, we will not argue about it then’. There is a parallel with what happened to the FBI in North America: it began acting – exactly as in this report – against money launderers and terrorists and, of course, it eventually became a kind of federal police force for the entire United States. I have to say, quite apart from feeling less free, I do not feel any more secure handing powers of this kind to the same dolts who gave us the common agricultural policy, the common fisheries policy, the overregulation of small business and the rest of it. I would rather we had intelligence and security services collaborating voluntarily and globally than placing such collaboration under the jurisdiction of the European Union. As my countryman, William Pitt the Younger, put it: ‘necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves.’

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, given Ireland’s experience of both terrorism and the abuse of the financial system, prevention of the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing is something that should be close to the heart of every Irish person.  I do not have to elaborate on how physical terrorism affected Ireland for decades – and there are those who still have not been weaned off it just yet – but there is also another kind of terrorism that is far more widespread and far more endemic. I am talking about financial terrorism, the terror inflicted on peoples all over the world by small, but disproportionately powerful, moneyed interests whose actions are facilitated by captured governments.  Our own government in Ireland has long been captured and is now held prisoner by the IFSC, dancing to its every tune. This is the same financial centre which is so low down on the scale – or so high depending on your perspective – that it was described by no less an outlet than the New York Times as the ‘Wild West’ of finance! It is good to see something being done about it, but the idea that the European Union can do anything about it given that it is a type of financial terrorist itself, well, that is a joke, is it not?

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, I am in favour of the adoption of the fourth EU Anti—Money Laundering Directive. As criminal and terrorist networks constantly evolve their tactics and methods, we must also adapt to the new threats posed by them. It was high time to address – and even to go beyond – the recommendations issued by the Financial Action Task Force in 2012 to tackle money laundering and terrorist financing and to have a European legal protection framework built around the highest international standards. The misuse of the financial system to channel illicit money or to finance terrorist activities threatens the good functioning, reputation and stability of the whole international financial system. This is why we needed the current Europe-wide response to address such risks.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the A philosopher once said, "In the stream of truth, lies float along." Unfortunately, this is also the case here. Of course, we want a single internal market, and of course we also want to ensure that the people of Europe can move freely. Of course, we also want to simplify financial flows, and that is right. Unfortunately, evil also seeks space in this freedom. We must, of course, deal intensively with money laundering and, as the previous speaker said, financial terrorism. It was therefore right that the Commission had made further proposals in addition to the current proposal. I think this is extremely important, which is why I was able to vote in favour of the directive. I would just like to ask for one thing: we will also have to monitor this fourth money laundering directive critically, because it is the case that evil and the bad sometimes have too much imagination, and they will develop further. We simply have to stick to the problem.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, I have supported the adoption of a recommendation for a second reading of the revision of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive in order to continue working in this important area, which will further ensure the prevention, research and detection of money laundering cases and the inadmissible financing of terrorism.  Given the reality of the armed conflicts to which the European Union is surrounded, I support the introduction of additional measures that will ensure more transparent financial transfers in order to strengthen the internal market and further secure the Union's financial system.  In this regard, I support the securing of transparent information through the publication of the register of beneficial owners, where Member States will need to ensure that central registers, commercial registers or registers of undertakings in their countries contain information on the beneficial owners available to the competent authorities, while ensuring full responsibility for the proper application of data protection.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, fight money laundering and, therefore, organised crime and terrorism, yes! But do you seriously believe for a moment that organized crime and terrorism go through the ordinary channels of banks? The perverse effect of this system is that in my own country, France, under the influence of state regulations, every banker has been turned into a spy, by supervising, as a whistleblower for his clients. For example, having repaid a personal debt of 10,000 euros, which was perfectly in credit in my bank account, some time ago, I had to justify myself to my banker, who called me, finding this transaction abnormal and asking me what I was doing with my money. I replied that, at my age, young mistresses were more expensive than they used to be. It was inaccurate, I'm a husband loyal to his wife. This response did not seem to satisfy. From then on, the circuit starts: Tracfin is informed, the financial brigade investigates... These are absolutely perverse effects of this legislation. The same is true at the Kredietbank in Brussels, in the European Parliament's agency, where even your European passport is not enough to justify your home! It's financial terrorism.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Mr. President, the issue of anti-money laundering and terrorism is of uprooted at the level of all Member States, as non-stopping seriously undermines the stability of the Union financial system and in the case of terrorism the stability of the whole society. That is why we are obliged to fight and take all actions against these activities. I therefore supported both the proposed recommendations and amendments to the directive that make special efforts to prevent these phenomena. It is proposed to define the data that must be contained in the public register of companies for the purpose of quality exchange of information, and it is also proposed that every 6 months a risk assessment be carried out by which money laundering and terrorist financing affect the market with a particular focus on cross-border activities. The goal of all of us is to prevent and strengthen legislation - this is a step towards that.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive because the soundness, integrity and stability of financial and credit institutions, as well as confidence in the financial system as a whole, could be seriously jeopardized by the efforts of criminals and their accomplices, whether to cover up the origin of the products of crime, or to channel the product of legitimate or illegitimate activities for terrorist purposes.  Money launderers and terror financiers could take advantage of the free movement of capital and the freedom to provide financial services which provides an integrated financial space to facilitate their criminal activities, and coordination measures at Union level are therefore necessary.  In addition, I welcome the success of the Socialist and Democratic Group in the future rule of establishing a public register of beneficiary owners of financial assets, at the level of the Member States, and whose access can be allowed to anyone with a "legitimate interest". It is necessary to identify any natural person who holds ownership or control of a legal entity. This is a fundamental tool for fighting interposed societies.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The European Council has repeatedly refused to lift secrecy about many of the tax practices that facilitate money laundering. However, the revelation of scandals such as LuxLeaks has allowed pressure to open such records, even partially, to the scrutiny of public authorities and those organizations and members of civil society with a legitimate interest, including the prosecution of tax crimes. Although insufficient, the final commitment represents a breakthrough respect for previous negotiating positions. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I welcome the new rules on better traceability of money transfers and a more effective fight against money laundering. This directive provides the competent authorities with new tools to combat illegal activities – tax evasion, corruption, but also the financing of terrorism – more effectively. The transparency registers with the economic beneficiaries of companies, trusts or similar legal entities, as requested by Parliament for this purpose, are progress in this sense.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This draft resolution aims to update the third anti-money laundering directive. This directive applies a risk-based approach and aims to strengthen the European Union's defences against money laundering and terrorist financing. To this end, the Council and Parliament have introduced various amendments to preserve the integrity and stability of the financial system. The Commission would be responsible for coordinating the risk assessment of money laundering and terrorist financing. In particular, the directive provides for the provision of information on actual beneficiaries with regard to companies. Each Member State could view this information. In particular, the text provides for the introduction of maximum administrative monetary penalties. These measures seem to me to be necessary to combat this fiercely current problem. So I voted in favour of the text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not approve of the procedure for approval without a vote, and would like to place my views on this subject on record.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. I supported the Anti-Money Laundering Directive because it is necessary to adapt the European legal framework for monitoring financial circuits and to ensure greater transparency in their operation. The aim is to force Member States to keep central registers accessible to the relevant authorities (financial intelligence cells, banks) or to organisations and persons with a legitimate interest (investigative journalists). In addition, the text broadens the scope of the individuals and legal entities concerned by lowering the threshold to 10,000 euros for cash payments that will need to be monitored in particular. The directive also provides for financial penalties of a minimum threshold of one million euros or five million euros if the infringement involves banks or financial entities. The Commission will be responsible for coordinating the assessment of money laundering and the risk of terrorist financing affecting the internal market. I voted for this directive because we need to adopt clear rules to strengthen our control over illegal money laundering activities that benefit organised crime and terrorism.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing aimed at strengthening the fight against money laundering. Money laundering accounts for between 2% and 5% of global GDP each year. Under the new rules, the eu's central registers will have to be published by the beneficial business owners, which will have to be made available to public authorities and persons with legitimate interests, such as journalists. New rules on transfers of funds are also introduced, which should facilitate the traceability of money. In negotiations with the Council of the EU, the European Parliament succeeded in ensuring that the updated Anti-Money Laundering Directive obliges EU countries to publish beneficial owners of companies, foundations and other legal entities in their central registers. In addition, banks, auditors, lawyers, real estate agents and casinos will have to monitor suspicious customer transfers more closely.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The proposal aims to protect the financial system from money laundering and terrorist financing through the adoption of prevention, investigation and detection measures. Money laundering and terrorist financing create a significant risk to the integrity, functioning and stability of the financial system. The changing nature of money laundering and terrorist financing requires a permanent adaptation of European legislation on the subject. At present and in the wake of the various scandals, I believe it is essential to combat these forms of fraud.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. With the approaching end of the football season, many will probably be tempted to take a gamble and bet on who will become champions now. Unfortunately, we have known for some time that sports betting is also easy prey for mafiosi who want to abuse the sport to launder money.  That is why it is important that we have extended the money laundering legislation today by including the gambling operators. As soon as transactions are detected for 2000 euros or more, a "customer survey" will have to be carried out.  The exception provided for for Member States to ise off bets with small risks will need to be closely monitored by the Commission. This should not be free-to-do for Member States to maintain a lax attitude towards gambling operators.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This text aims to prevent the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing. It seems to me to be a good thing, in that money laundering and terrorist financing are consensual and common-sense objectives against which we must fight extremely firmly. The developments proposed in this text, made necessary by the changing nature of the financing of terrorism and money laundering, seem to me to be appropriate and it is for these reasons that I vote for this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure which passes at second reading. I support this text, which provides for new, more stringent methods of financial control to intercept movements of money for the purpose of money laundering or terrorist financing.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive because the soundness, integrity and stability of financial and credit institutions, as well as confidence in the financial system as a whole, could be seriously jeopardized by the efforts of criminals and their accomplices, whether to cover up the origin of the products of crime, or to channel the product of legitimate or illegitimate activities for terrorist purposes.  Money launderers and terror financiers could take advantage of the free movement of capital and the freedom to provide financial services which provides an integrated financial space to facilitate their criminal activities, and coordination measures at Union level are therefore necessary.  In addition, I welcome the success of the Socialist and Democratic Group in the future rule of establishing a public register of beneficiary owners of financial assets, at the level of the Member States, and whose access can be allowed to anyone with a "legitimate interest". It is necessary to identify any natural person who holds ownership or control of a legal entity. This is a fundamental tool for fighting interposed societies.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation, which endorses the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering or terrorist financing. This Directive proposes to strengthen the internal market and, in particular, to reduce the complexity of cross-border movements, to protect the public from crime and terrorist acts, to protect the economic well-being of the European Union by ensuring an efficient business environment and enhancing financial stability. The disappearance of barriers in the internal market makes it easier not only to create or develop legitimate businesses across the EU, but also to increase opportunities for money laundering and terrorist financing. Therefore, criminals involved in money laundering may attempt to conceal or disguise the true nature, source or ownership of the property in question. European legislation has been adopted to safeguard the proper functioning of the financial system and the internal market. However, due to the changing nature of money laundering and terrorist financing threats, which are supported by the constant development of technology and the methods used by criminals, the legal framework needs to be continuously adapted to prevent such threats.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of a new anti-money laundering regulation already agreed with the Council, which for the first time obliges Member States to list the beneficial owners of companies, other legal persons and trustees in a central database. The new directive aims to combat money laundering, tax-related crime and terrorist financing.  Money laundering has now become one of the most profitable and high-end businesses in the world. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for between 2% and 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth.  The initiatives now proposed will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. I believe that Member States should be able to require foreign entities in their territory to report any suspicious activity to the financial intelligence unit in the Member State concerned. In turn, foreign entities must comply with the requirements for the transparency of information in that country.  The interconnectability of registers is unfortunately essential for the usability of this information because of the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnectability of the internal market. It is therefore necessary to link the registers as a matter of urgency and to make them available to public authorities and obliged entities.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. Back in 2013, the European Commission presented two proposals to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The Social Democrats' GROUP in the EP has proposed an amendment demanding public disclosure of beneficiaries of benefits in corporations for legitimate public interest. I believe that the voted text will contribute to a transparent funding system within the EU.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has shown over time that it is concerned about initiating and implementing measures to combat money laundering from crime. However, these efforts have proved insufficient amid terrorist acts that are increasingly shaking the society in which we live. The use of the financial system to finance terrorism such as hostage-taking, drawing up false administrative documents and leading a terrorist group, are realities of contemporary society, which must be combated with the utmost urgency by European and international for a. The use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing is serious lymsing on a daily basis with regard to the stability of the European financial sector.  However, with sustained efforts to increase the vigilance of banks, other financial actors, implicitly the clientele as a whole, a substantial contribution will be made to the end of these types of crimes and a faster process of examination of suspicious transactions will be established. I voted in favour of the report because taking further measures to prevent the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing strengthens stability and transparency, thus helping to protect and encourage the legal economy.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The report sets the objective of greater financial control to intercept movements of money for money laundering or terrorist financing.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive because the soundness, integrity and stability of financial and credit institutions, as well as confidence in the financial system as a whole, could be seriously jeopardized by the efforts of criminals and their accomplices, whether to cover up the origin of the products of crime, or to channel the product of legitimate or illegitimate activities for terrorist purposes.  Money launderers and terror financiers could take advantage of the free movement of capital and the freedom to provide financial services which provides an integrated financial space to facilitate their criminal activities, and coordination measures at Union level are therefore necessary.  In addition, I welcome the success of the Socialist and Democratic Group in the future rule of establishing a public register of beneficiary owners of financial assets, at the level of the Member States, and whose access can be allowed to anyone with a "legitimate interest". It is necessary to identify any natural person who holds ownership or control of a legal entity. This is a fundamental tool for fighting interposed societies.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. We need strong European anti-money laundering legislation. This will enable us, among other things, to combat the financing of terrorism. This legislation is the result of a compromise linking security and protection of private data. In the fight against terrorism and money laundering, we must provide a European response. More transparency in this area will be used to achieve this objective. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing, amending Regulation (EU) No 648/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Directive 2005/60/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and Commission Directive 2006/70/EC. I believe that both money laundering and terrorist financing hinder the proper functioning and stability of the European system and put society and its interests at risk. The adoption of the anti-money laundering directive is a significant step towards greater effectiveness in the fight against these issues, and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I acknowledge that significant progress has been made in relation to the current situation, I am not satisfied with the compromise reached on access to public registers. I see this as a missed opportunity for better transparency and for the introduction of effective instruments in the European anti-money laundering framework. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the recommendations of Krisjanis Karins and Judith Sargentini and Timothy Kirkhope and Peter Simon on preventing the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing. By providing for member states to hold information on the actual beneficiaries of corporations and trusts in a centralised register, but also a cross-border harmonisation of powers within the Union, both between Member States and between their financial intelligence cells, as well as a European analysis of terrorist financing conducted by the Commission, the European Union is developing an ambitious project which constitutes a major step forward in terms of transparency of access to information on actual beneficiaries.  The Union will undoubtedly be at the forefront of the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing in the coming years.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I have positioned myself in favour of this directive to combat money laundering, which is used in particular to finance terrorism. The text is indeed the result of a compromise between Parliament and the Council and is in the direction of strengthening the integrity and soundness of the European financial system. For example, gambling is supervised and providers must exercise due diligence for transactions of 2,000 euros or more; the text is, however, realistic since it leaves room for Member States, which would be allowed to exempt these services, excluding casinos, from certain obligations, in limited and justified circumstances. Furthermore, I am in favour of the approach developed by the directive which is based on a risk assessment, which would be assessed by the Commission for those who could affect the internal market. I would, however, put a damper on the Council's position that does not distinguish between persons who hold or have held important positions at home or abroad.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The text voted on represents an important step forward in the European anti-money laundering framework: it not only brings EU countries into line with the most advanced international standards, but goes far beyond these standards.  The directive contains a number of ambitious provisions, which will allow Europe to make considerable progress in the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism. In particular, in order to increase transparency regarding the ownership of companies and trusts, the approved text introduces a centralised register of effective ownership information in all European countries. In addition, the directive recognises the importance of a supranational approach to combating the risks of money laundering and terrorist financing in the Union and moves in this direction, entrusting the European Commission with the task of carrying out a supranational assessment of these risks and making recommendations to the Member States so that they can cope effectively with them. For these reasons, I voted in favour of

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure aims to strengthen the internal market by reducing cross-border complexity, protecting the interests of society from crime and terrorist acts and contributing to financial stability by protecting the soundness, smooth functioning and integrity of the financial system.  Breaking down barriers in the internal market not only facilitates the creation or development of legitimate activities in the EU, but can also offer greater opportunities for money laundering and terrorist financing. Criminals carrying out money laundering activities could therefore try to conceal or disguise the true nature, origin or ownership of the goods in question and turn them into apparently law-making proceeds.  Money laundering and terrorist financing pose a serious risk to the integrity, smooth functioning, reputation and stability of the financial system. To this end, European legislation has been adopted which needs to be constantly updated, due to the changing nature of the threats posed by money laundering and terrorist financing, facilitated by the continuous evolution of technology and the means available to criminals.  In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The fight against terrorism is unfortunately back on the media agenda. This initiative, however, is an expression of the continued and structured work that the European Union has been developing in combating this phenomenon. Indeed, and although it has been a long and technically complex process, this report adopts the fourth revision of Directive 2005/60/EC. It aims to adapt the legislative framework to the increasing complexity of the financial system by increasing transparency and transaction control. In the fight against terrorism, funding is unavoidable and is therefore essential to change. Within the Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs Committee, we paid particular attention to the balance - always necessary - between the security and the right to data protection of European citizens.  It is my understanding that both rights are guaranteed and the Union will therefore be safer and therefore have given my positive vote to this report.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the new anti-money laundering directive, which aims to strengthen the fight against tax crimes and the financing of terrorism, and which introduces an amendment to the previous framework in order to strengthen the internal market and promote greater transparency of financial movements. The growing complexity of the financial sector requires stricter rules to guarantee the security of both the European economy and its citizens, given the well-founded suspicions of money laundering and terrorist financing.  I therefore welcome the proposal, introduced by Parliament, to oblige Member States to keep central registers on which to report the names and information of the actual owners of companies and other legal entities. These registers will then be made accessible only to persons capable of demonstrating a 'legitimate interest' in relation to money laundering, terrorist financing and associated alleged offences that could help fund them, such as corruption, tax crimes and fraud. This will make it possible to exercise a better level of control over financial movements, increasing transparency without having any ful rights to privacy and data protection for European citizens.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The revision of directive 2005/60/EC was necessary to strengthen the internal market and to support the fight against terrorism. The main points of the second reading agreement concern the beneficial ownership registers: Member States will have to ensure that central registers, commercial registers or company registers within their territory contain information about beneficial owners that is accessible by competent authorities, obliged entities and the wider public, provided that they can demonstrate a legitimate interest. Further provisions have been agreed to ensure that EU data protection requirements are applied. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the fourth anti-money laundering directive, proposed by the Commission in 2013 to bring the European framework into line with international standards developed by the Financial Action Task Force.  The aim of the directive is to combat money laundering, tax evasion and terrorist financing, increasing transparency and improving the traceability of financial flows within the EU. The directive, which was voted on in Parliament during the last parliamentary term, was substantially watered down by negotiations with the Council during the Italian Presidency. In order to close the file, a watered-down compromise has been accepted, which raises important challenges with regard to transparency and effective implementation, which will depend above all on how it is transposed in the various Member States. Wide discretion at national level also risks leading to uneven implementation between Member States, creating new loopholes and the possibility of regulatory arbitrage. Although this new directive is heading in the right direction, the many shortcomings do not allow us to support the final text. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – The European Council has repeatedly refused to raise secrecy about many of the tax practices that facilitate money laundering. However, the revelation of scandals such as LuxLeaks has allowed pressure to open such records, even partially, to the scrutiny of public authorities and those organizations and members of civil society with a legitimate interest, including the prosecution of tax crimes. Although insufficient, the final commitment represents a breakthrough respect for previous negotiating positions. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's objective is to strengthen existing rules on anti-money laundering and the transfer of funds, bringing them into line with international standards and fatf recommendations. The establishment of a public register of beneficiaries is a key step forward in the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing cases.  This is a sensitive issue with important implications. International terrorist groups, which increasingly need to circulate money to keep their terror networks alive, are using money laundering to conceal the true nature, origin or ownership of assets, turning them into seemingly lawless proceeds. Money laundering and terrorist financing are a serious risk, with potentially devastating consequences for society as a whole.  We must keep up with the changing forms that international criminals take in their mechanisms, and we must do so quickly and courageously, without fear of displeaseing some large financial group that uses the shortcomings of the system for its own gain. Otherwise, we will have an obsolete and useless weapon against one of the most serious threats of this beginning of the millennium.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to revise the 2005/60/EC Directive with a view to strengthening the rules applicable in the internal market and preventing the misuse of the European financial system for criminal purposes. Considering that it is necessary, in the current context of the terrorist threat, to make financial transfers more transparent and to better control them, in order to avoid money laundering for the financing of terrorist networks and activities, I also voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this report, Parliament validates at second reading the Commission's proposal to revise the Anti-Money Laundering Directive. As criminal organizations always find new ways to circumvent the rules, it is necessary to change our legislation. This is all the more important because laundered capital is a source of financing for terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. For a long time, I have repeatedly called for increased means to prevent the financing of terrorist activities. The adoption of this directive is one of those means, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 EUR 330 billion is the recycling figure in Europe. There is no doubt that this is an area in which we must act forcefully and decisively. The proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing is a step in this direction. It is a question of building an appropriate and balanced legislative framework that includes all those measures against money laundering by criminal organisations including those operating in the collection of funds linked to terrorist activities. For this reason, the European commitment must be coordinated at international level within the International Financial Action Group.  A great deal of attention has been paid to preventive measures through the establishment of rules relating to financial institutions and individuals. In particular, those measures for the recognition of its customers were encouraged. Therefore, The Member States must be able to oblige third-country entities active in their territory to comply with the requirements relating to transparency in the European Union.   I therefore consider the progress made in this direction to ensure a tough fight against money laundering and terrorism in Europe to be significant.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Total money laundered accounts for 5% of global GDP each year. The European Parliament has called for stricter rules on money laundering to combat tax evasion and terrorist financing. Fraudsters will no longer be able to use the anonymity of offshore companies and accounts to hide their financial transactions. Business owners will now have to be registered in central registers maintained by Member States. These registers will be accessible to the relevant authorities and their financial intelligence cells, as well as to persons with a "legitimate interest" such as journalists. These provisions thus place the European Union at the forefront of the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of a new anti-money laundering regulation already agreed with the Council, which for the first time obliges Member States to list the beneficial owners of companies, other legal persons and trustees in a central database. The new directive aims to combat money laundering, tax-related crime and terrorist financing. Money laundering has now become one of the most profitable and high-end businesses in the world. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for between 2% and 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. The initiatives now proposed will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. I believe that Member States should be able to require foreign entities in their territory to report any suspicious activity to the financial intelligence unit in the Member State concerned. In turn, foreign entities must comply with the requirements of the transparency of information in a given country. The interconnectability of registers is unfortunately essential for the usability of this information because of the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnectability of the internal market. It is therefore necessary to link the registers as a matter of urgency and make them available to public authorities and obliged entities.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the new directive to step up the fight against tax offences, money laundering and terrorist financing. I also supported the new Remittance Regulation, which aims to improve the traceability of payers and beneficiaries and their assets. Financial crime is a cross-border phenomenon. To counter this, it is necessary for the EU to have harmonised rules. That is why I am pleased that Members have wished to go further than the Commission's proposal. Asking Member States to keep central registers containing information related to the actual owners of companies and trusts is a major step forward in the direction of greater transparency. These new rules are an important step in the fight against money laundering, corruption and the financing of terrorism. They ensure consistency with the international approach. It is now time for Member States to implement these new rules quickly.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of a new regulation on money laundering already agreed with the Council, which for the first time obliges Member States to include the beneficial owners of companies, other legal persons and trustees in a central database. The new directive aims to combat money laundering, tax-related crime and terrorist financing.  Money laundering has now become one of the most profitable and high-end businesses in the world. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for between 2% and 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth.  The initiatives now proposed will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. I believe that Member States should be able to require foreign entities in their territory to report any suspicious activity to the financial intelligence unit in the Member State concerned. In turn, foreign entities must comply with the requirements of the transparency of information in a given country.  The interconnectability of registers is unfortunately essential for the usability of this information because of the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnectability of the internal market. It is therefore necessary to link the registers as a matter of urgency and make them available to public authorities and obliged entities.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to amend the Money Laundering Directive to finance international terrorism, as I believe it is of utmost importance. The current European legislation in this field is outdated and not in line with international standards, which instantly puts us on the losing side in the fight against international terrorism. We all know very well that terrorist organisations are always one step ahead, both in using new technologies and in finding holes in our laws. A major countermeasure to the threat posed by terrorist organisations is the cessation or partial reduction of the cash flows funding terrorist activities. This is also directly related to the money from the production and illegal trafficking of drugs, trafficking in human beings and other activities inherent in organised crime. The link between organised crime and terrorism is direct. Limiting financial flows to terrorist organisations and groups will lead to a reduction in terrorist activity. Terrorism operates internationally, and that is why we need to take decisive common action and constantly adapt the legal framework so that we can at least partially limit the threat posed by illegal organisations, such as traffickers and terrorists.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Since the main source of terrorist financing and money laundering are mainly electronic transactions through the labyrinthine banking system, the provision of exceptions to the application of rules and restrictions is incorrect (such as the provision of exceptions to individual transactions, the raising of the threshold for natural or legal persons, the low level of administrative fines, etc.).

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a very important subject, as all means must be taken to counter the financing of criminal organisations and terrorist organisations. The proposal for legislation in question is therefore intended to ensure better transparency of financial flows. At second reading, the agreement reached with the Council meets the objectives set, and I therefore voted in favour of approving the text of the agreement.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 I certainly very much welcome the willingness of this Parliament to work on a directive that combats the evasion, money laundering and financing of terrorism and which aspires to introduce greater transparency and traceability of financial flows into the European system.  However, it cannot be disturbed that the text voted on for the first time in Parliament during the last parliamentary term has now returned to the Chamber, for the second reading, which was seriously lightened after the negotiations in the Council during the Italian Presidency.
