In particular, it is concerned that the central register of beneficial owners is only accessible to those who prove to have a legitimate, unspecified interest, and to the authorities, contrary to parliament's request. It is also important that the Member States should be left with very wide discretion, which could lead not only to a further relaxation of the rules at national level, but also to a considerably uneven implementation of the directive.  For these reasons, by not wanting to vote against a text which, in any case, seems to be heading in the right direction, we have decided to abstain from judgment.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 EU countries should maintain a central register with information on the beneficial owners of companies, foundations and other structures, so that it is possible to identify the persons who are actually behind these entities. This directive aims to tighten the fight against tax crimes and the financing of terrorism.  The new European rules require central registers to be established and maintained in all EU countries on beneficial owners of companies, foundations, trusts and other entities. Member States should ensure that such information is stored in a register outside companies and may use a central database collecting information on beneficial owners, the commercial register or other central register. Over the next four years, the Commission should assess the technical conditions and procedures to ensure the safety and effectiveness of the interconnection of central registers through a Central European Platform. I voted in favour.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive because the soundness, integrity and stability of financial and credit institutions, as well as confidence in the financial system as a whole, could be seriously jeopardized by the efforts of criminals and their accomplices, whether to cover up the origin of the products of crime, or to channel the product of legitimate or illegitimate activities for terrorist purposes. Money launderers and terror financiers could take advantage of the free movement of capital and the freedom to provide financial services which provides an integrated financial space to facilitate their criminal activities, and coordination measures at Union level are therefore necessary.  In addition, I welcome the success of the Socialist and Democratic Group in the future rule of establishing a public register of beneficiary owners of financial assets, at the level of the Member States, and whose access can be allowed to anyone with a "legitimate interest". It is necessary to identify any natural person who holds ownership or control of a legal entity. This is a fundamental tool for fighting interposed societies.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because I am in principle in favour of any repressive progress in the fight against terrorism.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ Given our own experience of both terrorism and the abuse of the financial system, ‘prevention of the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing’ is something that should be close to the heart of every Irish person. I do not have to elaborate on how physical terrorism affected Ireland for decades, and there are still those who have not been weaned off it just yet. But there is also another kind of terrorism, terrorism that is far more widespread and far more endemic. I am talking about financial terrorism, the terror inflicted on peoples all over the world by the small but disproportionately powerful moneyed interests, whose actions are facilitated by captured governments. Our own government in Ireland has long been captured and is now held prisoner by the IFSC, dancing to its every tune, the same financial centre which is so low down the scale – or so high, depending on your perspective – that it was described by no less an outlet than the New York Times as the ‘Wild West’ of high finance. Consequently, I had no hesitation voting for this.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ as between €615 billion and €1.54 billion are spent globally each year, and various organised crime groups continue to use traditional methods of money laundering, Such as fictitious companies and accounts run in foreign jurisdictions, and, moreover, people who launder dirty money are also increasingly using the Internet and other technological innovations, with the emergence of illicit financial service providers in the form of unmonitored payment platforms and banks, it is absolutely essential that the outdated Money Laundering Directive 2005/60/EC be updated. Especially in the current deteriorated security situation in the European Union, we cannot allow the perpetrators of large-scale crime to continue to legalise and transform their means. Terrorist groups seek to legalise their revenues, which they can then use and threaten society as a whole. European society must respond more flexibly to threats, also in view of the changing nature of the threat and technological changes. The new European Union legislation in this area will enable us to respond more effectively.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the text which sets out the objective of greater financial control to intercept movements of money for the purpose of money laundering or terrorist financing.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is against, since the main source of terrorist financing and money laundering are mainly electronic transactions through the labyrinthine banking system, the provision of exceptions to the application of rules and restrictions is incorrect (such as the provision of exceptions to individual transactions, the raising of the threshold for natural or legal persons, the low level of administrative fines, etc.)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the inclusion in this report of our Group’s perspective regarding the setting up of a public register on beneficial owners. Access to the public register on beneficial ownership is subject to a ‘legitimate interest’: this formulation will allow those Member States which wish to be more transparent to adopt a broad definition of legitimate interest. Member States may provide for an exemption to access to all or part of the beneficial ownership information on a case-by-case basis in exceptional circumstances, if this would expose a beneficial owner to the risk of fraud, kidnapping, blackmail, violence or intimidation or if the beneficial owner is a minor or otherwise incapable. The fourth Anti-Money-Laundering Directive will provide a sound basis for providing maximum transparency in respect of beneficial ownership of corporate structures across the EU.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of a new anti-money laundering regulation already agreed with the Council, which for the first time obliges Member States to list the beneficial owners of companies, other legal persons and trustees in a central database. The new directive aims to combat money laundering, tax-related crime and terrorist financing.  Money laundering has now become one of the most profitable and high-end businesses in the world. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for between 2% and 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. The initiatives now proposed will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. I believe that Member States should be able to require foreign entities in their territory to report any suspicious activity to the financial intelligence unit in the Member State concerned. In turn, foreign entities must comply with the requirements for the transparency of information in that country.  The interconnectability of registers is unfortunately essential for the usability of this information because of the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnectability of the internal market. It is therefore necessary to link the registers as a matter of urgency and make them available to the authorities and to the obliged entities.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of a new anti-money laundering regulation already agreed with the Council, which for the first time obliges Member States to list the beneficial owners of companies, other legal persons and trustees in a central database. The new directive aims to combat money laundering, tax-related crime and terrorist financing. Money laundering has now become one of the most profitable and high-end businesses in the world. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for between 2% and 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. The initiatives now proposed will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. I believe that Member States should be able to require foreign entities in their territory to report any suspicious activity to the financial intelligence unit in the Member State concerned. In turn, foreign entities must comply with the requirements of the transparency of information in a given country. The interconnectability of registers is unfortunately essential for the usability of this information because of the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnectability of the internal market. It is therefore necessary to link the registers as a matter of urgency and make them available to public authorities and obliged entities.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive because the soundness, integrity and stability of financial and credit institutions, as well as confidence in the financial system as a whole, could be seriously jeopardized by the efforts of criminals and their accomplices, whether to cover up the origin of the products of crime, or to channel the product of legitimate or illegitimate activities for terrorist purposes.  Money launderers and terror financiers could take advantage of the free movement of capital and the freedom to provide financial services, which brings with them an integrated financial space, to facilitate their criminal activities, so coordination measures at Union level are necessary.  In addition, the Socialist and Democratic Group has succeeded in including in the future rule a very important demand, the establishment of a public register of beneficiary owners of financial assets, at the level of the Member States, which allows access to anyone with a "legitimate interest". It is necessary to identify any natural person who holds ownership or control of a legal entity. This is a fundamental tool for fighting interposed societies.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. U2012 Money launderers and terror financiers could take advantage of the free movement of capital and the freedom to provide financial services provided by an integrated financial space to facilitate their criminal activities, and coordination measures at Union level are therefore necessary.  I therefore voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive because the soundness, integrity and stability of financial and credit institutions, as well as confidence in the financial system as a whole, could be seriously jeopardized by the efforts of criminals and their accomplices, or to cover up the origin of the products of crime , and for channeling the product of legitimate or illegitimate activities for terrorist purposes.  In addition, the Socialist and Democratic Group has succeeded in including in the future rule the establishment of a public register of beneficiary owners of financial assets, at the level of the Member States, and whose access can be allowed to anyone with a "legitimate interest". It is necessary to identify any natural person who holds ownership or control of a legal entity. This is a fundamental tool for fighting interposed societies.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation, which instructs the publication in the Official Journal of an important directive opposing the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing.  We need a 360-degree EU strategy against crime and terrorism. Today we have completed an important piece of our tax strategy: we now need to move forward quickly in all other areas as well, and I will ensure that this happens, making the protection of citizens' security and the fight against crime a priority for the European Parliament.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I welcome the important legislative proposal to strengthen and extend the measures of Directive 2005/60/EC (Third Anti-Money Laundering Directive) and the international recommendations of the FATF (International Financial Action Group) on which it is based. I agree with the need for more information on money transfers, with stricter investigations into transactions, beneficiaries and orderers, the lowering of the maximum cash payment threshold, and I also believe that it is essential to strengthen the fight against money laundering and to reduce the risk of financing terrorist actions through the financial system, and up-to-date and precise information on the beneficial owners of institutions and companies in the Member States in a register accessible to the main systems of comparison and control.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the directive that created new European instruments to combat money laundering, because I believe it is essential to strengthen the regulatory framework and the instruments to combat a global phenomenon, in line with internationally applicable rules, which are often non-binding. The new legislation, consisting of a directive and a regulation, took two years of work and it was not until December 2014 that political agreement was reached in the Council under the Italian PRESIDENCY of the EU, which made it a qualifying battle. The "Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive" enriches the existing framework by introducing new and very important elements such as the creation of central registers, requested by the EP, which bring together information on the actual beneficiaries of the funds, accessible to the competent authorities, financial information units, banks or financial institutions. Other parties other than the latter can also access central registers if they prove that they have a 'legitimate interest'. In addition, the obligation to take other precautions in dealing with politically exposed persons is introduced and clarified. Finally, the directive aims to increase the clarity and accessibility of information of the person carrying out the transfer of money. Personal data is fully protected.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. The directive introduces a number of requirements and rules to make money laundering difficult. That's why we would have been in favour of voting.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Anti-Money-Laundering Regulation as I believe it is essential that we have the most rigorous possible protections in place to stop people from either laundering money or financing terrorism. I am delighted that the final directive calls for central registers of beneficial ownership, which will also help with the ongoing fight against tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance, and I would call on all Member States to take advantage of the option given in the directive to make those registers publicly accessible.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. On Wednesday 20 May, I voted in favour of a new directive to strengthen EU rules against money laundering and terrorist financing. The actual owners of companies will now have to be registered in the central registers of EU countries, open to both the authorities and those with a "legitimate interest", such as investigative journalists.  This is the first time that a directive will force Member States to keep such central registers. MEPs also approved a regulation on "remittances" which aims to improve the traceability of payers and beneficiaries and their assets. This vote is a strong signal from the European Parliament against tax evasion and the financing of terrorism. The eradication of such illegal practices requires strong political will and cooperation at all levels. Both money laundering and terrorist financing are obstacles to the harmonious functioning, stability of the financial system and the well-being of society.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. Each year, laundered capital accounts for 2 to 5% of global GDP. Money laundering, terrorist financing and organised crime are major problems that need to be addressed in Europe. In this context, it is therefore crucial to defend the adoption of clear rules that strengthen the vigilance of all professionals concerned and allow for greater financial transparency. Financial transparency is an indispensable tool in the effective fight against money laundering. That is why I supported this anti-money laundering directive. In particular, for the first time, it obliges Member States to keep central registers containing information relating to the actual owners of companies, as well as trusts. These registers had not been considered by the Commission, it was Parliament that pleaded for their establishment to end the anonymity of offshore companies and accounts exploited by fraudsters to conceal their financial transactions. While the conditions for access to this register are not as ambitious as we had defended it, it is a first step that should be encouraged. Parliament will remain vigilant to continue to defend the widest possible access to information.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering or terrorist financing. The world is not standing still. The EU's internal market, financial systems, economic conditions, technology are changing. Criminals involved in money laundering or contributing to the financing of terrorism are also adapting to a changing world. For this reason, it is constantly necessary to update and modernise the legal framework in order to adequately prevent these threats.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive because the soundness, integrity and stability of financial and credit institutions, as well as confidence in the financial system as a whole, could be seriously jeopardized by the efforts of criminals and their accomplices, whether to cover up the origin of the products of crime, or to channel the product of legitimate or illegitimate activities for terrorist purposes.  Money launderers and terror financiers could take advantage of the free movement of capital and the freedom to provide financial services which provides an integrated financial space to facilitate their criminal activities, and coordination measures at Union level are therefore necessary.  In addition, I welcome the success of the Socialist and Democratic Group in the future rule of establishing a public register of beneficiary owners of financial assets, at the level of the Member States, and whose access can be allowed to anyone with a "legitimate interest". It is necessary to identify any natural person who holds ownership or control of a legal entity. This is a fundamental tool for fighting interposed societies.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is an important milestone towards ensuring that the veil of secrecy is lifted from certain sectors where criminals can launder money. I believe it is up to Member States now to use the two-year implementation period to ensure that the directive is transposed into national law in an efficient manner.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of a new anti-money laundering regulation already agreed with the Council, which for the first time obliges Member States to list the beneficial owners of companies, other legal persons and trustees in a central database. The new directive aims to combat money laundering, tax-related crime and terrorist financing. Money laundering has now become one of the most profitable and high-end businesses in the world. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2-5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. The initiatives now proposed will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. I believe that Member States should be able to require foreign entities in their territory to report any suspicious activity to the financial intelligence unit in the Member State concerned. In turn, foreign entities must comply with the requirements of the transparency of information in a given country. The interconnectability of registers is unfortunately essential for the usability of this information because of the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnectability of the internal market. It is therefore necessary to link the registers as a matter of urgency and make them available to public authorities and obliged entities.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the revised directive on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing. The fight against terrorist threats must be a priority. Cutting the floodgates of funding is therefore an essential weapon in this fight that our democracies must wage against criminal organizations and terrorist groups. This directive stipulates that information on actual beneficiaries must be kept in a central register maintained by each Member State. Access to information is not only reserved for the relevant authorities but for any person or organisation capable of demonstrating a legitimate interest in accessing this information. In my view, this decision responds to two demands by citizens: greater transparency and security.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ This legislation will be an important tool in preventing serious criminal activity and I was happy to vote in favour.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council.  The directive introduces a number of requirements and rules to make money laundering difficult. That's why we would have been in favour of voting.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of recommending the second reading of a document implementing the regulations of the European Parliament and of the Council for a more effective fight against money laundering and financing it from terrorism.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on preventing the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering or terrorist financing, amending Regulation (EU) No 2013/2013; 648/2012 of the European Parliament and the Council and on the repeal of Directive 2005/60/EC of the European Parliament and the Council and the Commission Directive 2006/70/EC, as this seeks to strengthen the EU anti-money laundering regime. Removing barriers to the creation of the internal market facilitates legal business in the EU but also creates opportunities for money transfer from illegal activities, money laundering, terrorist financing. Money laundering and terrorist financing, with potentially major consequences for society, also create risks to the functioning, reputation, integrity and stability of the financial system. This regulation also aims to protect the current financial system and prevent illegal financial activities. In line with changes that are happening more rapidly through further liberalisation and the development of technology at the disposal of crime, a legal framework should be adapted to prevent such threats.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This draft resolution aims to update the third anti-money laundering directive. The approach of this directive is based on risks and seeks to strengthen the European Union's defences against money laundering and the financing of terrorism The Council and Parliament have therefore added amendments to preserve the independence and stability of the financial system. The text also provides for the Commission to coordinate the risk assessment of money laundering and terrorist financing. In particular, the directive provides for the provision of information on actual beneficiaries with regard to companies, and all Member States could consult this information. These measures seem to me to be necessary to combat this fiercely current problem. So I voted in favour of the text.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ Following the recent terrorist attacks in Paris, Brussels and Copenhagen, it was crucial that the European Union took decisive action against anti money laundering and terrorist financing. I believe this new directive is part of the answer. It will facilitate the work of Financial Intelligence Units from different Member States to identify and follow suspicious transfers of money, facilitate the exchange of information and ensure full traceability of funds transfers within, to, and from the EU. Moreover, these new rules reflect the legitimate public demand for increased transparency in this field. It will for the first time oblige EU Member States to keep central registers of information on the ultimate ‘beneficial’ owners of corporate and other legal entities, as well as trusts, a strong demand from the European Parliament. There is still room for improvement when it comes to the accessibility of the public register, but the directive leaves the door open to those Member States which are ready, to move forward. I strongly encourage them to use the available flexibility to provide unrestricted public registers with access to beneficial ownership information for companies and trusts.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Karins and Sagentini on money laundering and terrorist financing. The aim of this report is to strengthen the EU's legislative framework in order to combat money laundering more effectively and to better monitor money laundered in order to prevent the financing of terrorism. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism. This fight includes greater transparency in financial transfers and stronger internal market rules. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I voted negatively on this report in committee, as the development initiated here amounts to a gradual abolition of cash. Although this is an approval without a vote, I would like to make it clear that I continue to oppose this proposal. However, I support sensible and sustainable measures to combat money laundering.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this very important legislation that has now passed the last needed step to be adopted.  Corruption is of main concerns for the EU citizens and it costs EU economy about EUR 120 billion annually. It serves as vital help for terrorists, criminal gangs and makes it much easier to bypass sanctions that have been applied to certain third states.  Control on money laundering has been notoriously weak and insufficiently coordinated. Non-transparent money flows stemming from suspicious sources have found their way to the EU, where they benefit criminal groupings, shadow economy and terrorists.  The legislation foresees public registers of beneficial ownership. Member States have to ensure that these central registers, commercial registers or company registers within their territory contain information about the beneficial owners and will be made accessible by competent authorities. It has to be highlighted that the legislation is very firm on exceptions and did not surrender to the pressure by the banking, gambling and credit card industries which advocated for more exceptions and ambiguous rules.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Anti-Money Laundering Regulation because I believe it is essential that we have the most rigorous possible protections in place to stop people from either laundering money or financing terrorism. I am delighted that the final directive calls for central registers of beneficial ownership, which will also help with the ongoing fight against tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance, and I would call on all Member States to take advantage of the option given in the directive to make those registers publicly accessible

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the positions of the Fidesz-KDNP and EPP Groups, I voted in favour of the adoption of a new anti-money laundering regulation already agreed with the Council, which for the first time obliges Member States to include the beneficial owners of companies, other legal persons and trustees in a central database. The new directive aims to combat money laundering, tax-related crime and terrorist financing.  Money laundering has now become one of the most profitable and high-end businesses in the world. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for between 2% and 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth.  The initiatives now proposed will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. I believe that Member States should be able to require foreign entities in their territory to report any suspicious activity to the financial intelligence unit in the Member State concerned. In turn, foreign entities must comply with the requirements for the transparency of information in that country.  The interconnectability of registers is unfortunately essential for the usability of this information because of the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnectability of the internal market. It is therefore necessary to link the registers as a matter of urgency and to make them available to public authorities and obliged entities.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – It is no more natural to fight money laundering and terrorist financing. However, this proposal is a Trojan horse, primarily centralising in nature, rehabiating nation-state competences. Moreover, it does not address the problem at its root, the current path is impassable, this speculative financial system is not sustainable. It is timely to return to the system before incorrect deregulation and to replace the free flow of capital causing the economic crisis with controlled capital flows. Thus, the proposal in this form is unacceptable because the current financial system, together with the above reforms, does not serve the interests of the wider social strata of the Member States.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation by Mr Kariš and Mr Sargentini on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing, following the Commission's proposal, which is a revision of Directive 2005/60/EC.  I fully agree with the need for new regulations to ensure greater transparency. All this is useful in order to strongly support the fight against terrorism and organised crime, while at the same time strengthening the European Union's internal market.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. These new anti-money laundering rules make it possible to make progress in disclosing the actual owners of businesses and entities. According to the new directive, central registers will have to exist in all EU states, listing the final owners of businesses. The idea is that administrations, especially tax authorities, can have reliable information that allows them to see who owns what and thus be able to estimate the wealth of certain individuals or see precisely between whom suspicious transactions are made. These registers should also be accessible to people with a "legitimate interest", such as investigative journalists. This is therefore a real step forward, especially since some European countries, including France, have announced that they want to make these registers public. I have therefore supported this text and call for rapid implementation and greater transparency. I regret, however, that trusts (complex structures of ownership of companies or entities) will benefit from a specific regime exempting them from these rules: the fight against money laundering and tax evasion must apply to all and even more to those who try to hide their assets and transactions by these opaque structures.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to prevent the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing. The fight against money laundering linked to terrorism is a priority for the National Front. In the face of increasing terrorist acts and money laundering mechanisms, it is essential to respond quickly and firmly with appropriate legal tools. This report covers only one side of the issue of terrorism, the essential point of the restoration of national borders is still obscured by the EU.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report includes the establishment of a public register of beneficiary owners of financial assets, at the level of the Member States, and whose access can be allowed to anyone with a 'legitimate interest', which is within the definition of the Member States. Agreeing with this inclusion and in the spirit of the report, I voted in favour.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 There was no vote in plenary because the document was accepted by jurisdiction. This Karyn and Sargentini report plump from the previous legumes, there was also a trialogue with the European Commission.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing, the amendment of Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 648/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council, and the repeal of Directive 2005/60/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and Commission Directive 2006/70/EC, because all interested parties are improving their understanding of the legislative framework for combating money laundering, but also of the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament of 19/05/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that we were able to get a first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation on the revision of Directive 2005/60/EC on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing reaches a final agreement after 2 years of negotiations. We finally have a revision of the directive that can effectively help the fight against money laundering, tax evasion and tax fraud, with more transparent financial transfers to support the fight against terrorism and organised crime.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. U2012 We must prevent our financial system from being used for money laundering or the financing of terrorism at all costs. That is why my clear and forceful support for the new directive, which we are about to finally adopt, to take the necessary measures to stop these criminal activities.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I was, of course, supported by the vote on preventing the use of the financial system for money laundering. Reducing terrorist financing is one of the union's priority objectives in times of ISIS and Europe-wide attacks.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. According to the International Monetary Fund's calculations, money laundering is on a considerable scale and amounts to almost 5% of global GDP. The aim of the new directive is to improve the current framework to prevent the use of the financial system for the conversion of the proceeds of criminal activity into lawful funds. This includes improving the functioning of business registers by mandating the identification of the actual beneficiary of the business or the business transaction. Guarantees have been given for the protection of personal data in accordance with European regulations. But since the text focuses on the financing of terrorism, it avoids the issue of the savage liberalisation of capital flows and the opaque financial rules that allow this fraud. I would gladly abstain from denouncing this "forgottenness" but I am voting for, which remains a small step forward.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This new Money Laundering Directive requires EU countries to maintain a central register with information on beneficial owners of companies, foundations and other structures in order to identify the persons behind them. The Directive also strengthens the duty of surveillance and the obligation of banks, among others, to report suspicious transactions of customers.  This Money Laundering Directive aims to tighten the fight against tax crimes and terrorist financing. The new European rules require central registers to be established and maintained in all EU countries on beneficial owners of companies, foundations, trusts and other entities. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support the Commission’s more robust anti-money laundering measures as it is important that the Union support intelligence forces and investigative task forces in their efforts to combat illicit financial transactions. The new measures will respect the EU data protection requirements but increase the level of transparency amongst companies and the business community.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I approved the new anti-money laundering directive which aims to step up the fight against tax crimes and terrorist financing. The new rules include the obligation for Member States to keep a central register of information on who owns companies and other legal entities. New anti-money laundering rules will help fight tax crime and terrorist financing by making it easier to trace transfers of funds and sources of wealth.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to facilitate criminal activities, money whiters and terrorist financiers are trying to take advantage of the free movement of capital associated with the integrated financial area, and it is essential that certain coordination measures be adopted at European Union and international level. In this regard, I vote in favour of the adoption of this act at first reading in accordance with the Council's position..

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to prevent the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing.  The fight against money laundering linked to terrorism is a compelling public interest. Moreover, the content of this text seems to me to be appropriate to the situation and therefore goes in the right direction. In the face of rapidly evolving terrorism and money laundering mechanisms, it is essential to respond quickly and firmly with an appropriate legal arsenal. If the EU can be blamed for casting a modest veil on key issues, such as the restoration of borders and some form of capital controls, which would kill money laundering in the bud, I still voted for this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the fourth EU anti-money laundering directive; it is a key piece of legislation which marks a positive step in the fight against tax crimes and the financing of terrorism and serious crime. It also aligns EU legislation with international standards in that field, guaranteeing at the same time EU fundamental rights standards for citizens.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the Council's position at first reading on a particularly sensitive issue such as the necessary prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing. We are particularly pleased to vote for the adoption of an act which saw the conclusion of the negotiations during the trialogue during the Six-Monthly Italian Presidency. The establishment of a register of the actual beneficiaries of funding is certainly a step in the direction of greater transparency, which at the same time may be in the interests of the Member States when determining the definition of legitimate interest. The Directive lays down a minimum list of information provided for, which are the name, date of birth, nationality, country of residence of the beneficiaries and information on the use of the funds.   The text is fully compliant and offers Community adaptation to the new international anti-money laundering standards set in 2013.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 There are two requirements for the effectiveness of our fight against terrorism. We must act quickly, but at the same time be extremely judicious. In today's complex world, when the transparency of the financial environment is becoming more complex, we must find a solution to ensure transparency of transactions. I therefore welcome this report. I, too, am calling for tough and consistent regulation against money laundering and tax evasion, which can finance terrorism, and a hotbed of corruption. We need maximum cooperation between our law enforcement agencies. We must act with a cool head, consistently, with the most effective weapon – the cutting of channels of money. We have to face the fact that this is a power struggle, where the fanatical, corrupt madness is trying to extend its power over a world based on values and rights. In the meantime, we must make it clear that we have a responsibility to curb fear and radicalisation in relation to citizens and minorities among us.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on preventing the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering and terrorist financing, amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 648/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Directive 2005/60/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and of Commission Directive 2006/70/EC. This project allows, inter alia, greater control over the financial activity of publicly exposed persons, the interconnection of the corporate tax system or the creation of transparency registers.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report with my vote today, because it endorses the Council's position on halting the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing. Money laundering is a major issue in all the economies of the world, and the EU is no exception in this respect. Unfortunately, in addition to the harm it brings to economies, money laundering is used to finance a wide range of illegal and cross-border activities, such as drug trafficking, human trafficking, and, last but not least, terrorism. It is very clear that the sources of financing of terrorism at global level are very diverse and it is equally clear that all the financial resources needed by it are going through a money laundering process at some point. In this respect, setting limits on the amounts that can be used to make cash payments, a method that is very difficult for the authorities to follow, is necessary.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I appreciate the resulting form of the directive, which is a compromise between the EP and the Council retaining most of the elements promoted by the EP at first reading. All companies registered in EU Member States will therefore now be required to provide information on their owners, up to the level of natural persons. This information will be collected in a mandatory central register of beneficial owners, which will be publicly available. I consider this to be an important step towards greater transparency in financial flows and reducing tax evasion. I believe that this will also be an impetus for the Government of the Czech Republic to adopt legislation leading to the declassification of the owners of all anonymous joint-stock companies.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The motion has already been voted on in committee and has therefore been approved in plenary without further voting. Nevertheless, I see the proposal as good approaches to preventing and combating money laundering as a result of organised crime, although the measures can only be a first step. Nevertheless, I would have voted in favour of the motion.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Money laundering and its involvement in terrorism and terrorist financing are a threat to any society. Methods of money laundering are constantly changing, with the need to develop new countermeasures to ensure security and the credibility of the financial system.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. This directive will require Member States for the first time to record the data of corporate entity owners, i.e. to require banks, auditors, lawyers or casinos to monitor their clients' suspicious transactions more closely.   The financing of terrorism must be tackled globally. We need more transparency. Control and attack the impunity with which large sums of money move freely. This allows us to fight organizations in a direct way and disrupt system corruption.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the position presented. We need to step up our efforts to protect the public from crime and terrorist acts, as well as the economic well-being of the European Union, ensuring an efficient business environment. Financial stability needs to be strengthened by ensuring the soundness, proper functioning and integrity of the financial system. It is therefore essential to ensure that the EU has an effective system to prevent the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing.  In order to achieve the objectives set, it is appropriate to extend the scope of the Directive to not only casinos but also the gambling sector as a whole. In addition, tax offences must be included in the scope of the Directive. It is very important to strengthen the sanctions regimes. In particular, minimum rules of principle need to be laid down in order to strengthen administrative sanctions. In addition, it is appropriate to carry out a threat assessment and to take risk mitigation measures in a timely manner.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Having regard to the Council's position at first reading and the opinions of the Economic and Social Committee and the European Central Bank; Having regard to the joint deliberations of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and their joint recommendation; I voted in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Attacking the financing of terrorism is undoubtedly one of the most effective methods of combating this phenomenon which is destroying entire countries in the Middle East and also directly threatening the Member States, as we unfortunately saw in Paris last January. All measures to better control financial flows should be encouraged. That is why I support this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Recommendation for a second reading on 11 May 2015 at the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and the Council on preventing the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing, amendments to Regulation (EU) No 100/2013; 648/2012 of the European Parliament and the Council, and on the abolition of Directive 2005/60/EC of the European Parliament and the Council and the Commission 2006/70/EC. With this report, the European Parliament adopts the first reading and approves the recommendation for the second reading, in view of the Council's position at first reading (05933/4/2015-C8-0109/2015), and taking into account the opinion of the European Central Bank as of 17 May 2013 and the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee of 23 May 2013, bearing in mind Article 294, paragraph 7 of the Regulation. treaty on the functioning of the European Union and is in line with joint discussions between the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (A8-0153/2015). It is also in accordance with Article 294, paragraph 7. treaty on the functioning of the European Union.  Due to all the above items, I support this recommendation from colleagues Kariėš and Sargentini.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support the Karniš and Sergetini Members' reports because I believe that large flows of illicit money can completely lead to the destabilisation of the financial sector and jeopardise the single market and international development. Factors conducite to illicit activities and flows are secret corporate structures or tax havens that are almost undetectable. I welcome the Work of the Commission, which will carry out a risk assessment covering areas of the internal market that are at higher risk and the possibility of obtaining information on suspected parties from Member States and non-member states in order to prevent further abuse of the financial system. I also welcome the European Parliament's report proposing the introduction of a register of owners whose Member States will have to provide all information on companies and their 'beneficial owners' located in the EU, and to take into account branches and branches located outside EU jurisdiction. It is also important to stress that there are cases where strict identification procedures need to be carried out, namely individuals performing public functions in countries where corruption is widespread, and I also welcome the request of members to verify the identity of the parties and the actual owners before establishing a business relationship and committing transactions.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the latest statistics, money laundering covers up to 2-3% of the world's gross domestic product per year. These percentages clearly indicate that this is a global problem that needs to be addressed urgently. Especially at a time when europe is not only plagued by the aftersteps of the economic crisis. I therefore supported the Anti-Money Laundering Directive. I am very glad that my political group has succeeded in the proposal to create central registers at Member State level that will enable the public to find out who the real owners of large companies and other corporate entities are. The directive is therefore a further step both to increase transparency and public scrutiny and to further win the fight against tax evasion. I firmly believe that the directive will not only be an effective obstacle to the financing of terrorism, but also a solution to the problem of conflicts of interest for politically active persons.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The relevant committees – the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs – had jointly voted and adopted the recommendation at second reading of the report on preventing the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing, recommending by a very large majority that the Council's position be followed in plenary. As we have seen, the position expressed by the two committees has been followed.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Money laundering threatens not only our economy but also the safety of our citizens. This illegal activity can help finance certain terrorist movements. The EU is trying to put in place legislative tools to combat money laundering effectively and in the long term.  The European Parliament has adopted the fourth directive against money laundering. I have spoken in favour of this text which, for the first time, will force EU Member States to keep central registers containing information relating to the actual owners of companies.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This legislative resolution adopts the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and the Council on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing. The purpose of the Directive is for Member States to ensure, in their territories, that central registers, trade registers or registers of undertakings have data on the enjoyment of financial products.  Such information should be accessible to the competent authorities as well as to the general public, so that it can be demonstrated whether the usufructors have a legitimate interest in financial investments. The aim is to strengthen the internal market, make financial transfers more transparent, support the fight against terrorism and organised crime and strengthen the EU financial system. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The European Parliament has completed new strategic legislation to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The tools introduced by this directive, particularly the register of actual beneficiaries, will strengthen the capacity of national authorities to detect and identify billions of euros from criminal activities.  The new rules are more flexible: they focus on high-risk activities and include simplified measures for low-risk activities. This new legislation will make the European market more functioning, while strengthening the stability of our economies. We will also be better equipped to track the financial flows that support terrorist groups and thus we will be able to better combat this scourge. It is therefore crucial that these rules are operational as soon as possible.  By adopting this text, we have not only aligned our rules with the latest international recommendations in this area, including those of the Financial Action Task Force, but we are also creating an example for the rest of the world. In order for our efforts to have a greater impact, we will need to strengthen our cooperation with third countries in the same direction.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Money laundering and terrorist financing are too often linked, jeopardising the integrity of the functioning, reputation and stability of the financial system. A permanent adaptation of the legal framework is needed in an attempt to contain this threat and protect the financial system. This objective will be to ensure the consistency of national laws and flexibility in their implementation, ensuring that they are adapted to new forms of threat and in line with the measures taken at international level.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive because the soundness, integrity and stability of financial and credit institutions, as well as confidence in the financial system as a whole, could be seriously jeopardized by the efforts of criminals and their accomplices, whether to cover up the origin of the products of crime, or to channel the product of legitimate or illegitimate activities for terrorist purposes.  Money launderers and terror financiers could take advantage of the free movement of capital and the freedom to provide financial services which provides an integrated financial space to facilitate their criminal activities, and coordination measures at Union level are therefore necessary.  In addition, I welcome the success of the Socialist and Democratic Group in the future rule of establishing a public register of beneficiary owners of financial assets, at the level of the Member States, and whose access can be allowed to anyone with a "legitimate interest". It is necessary to identify any natural person who holds ownership or control of a legal entity. This is a fundamental tool for fighting interposed societies.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which includes stricter rules on money laundering to combat tax evasion and terrorist financing. From now on, company owners will have to be registered in the central registers of EU countries, open to both the authorities and people with a "legitimate interest", such as journalists. I also welcome the adoption of new rules to facilitate the tracing of remittances.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this report, which aims to strengthen the European Union's defences against money laundering and terrorist financing and to ensure the soundness, integrity and stability of the financial system. In order to prevent the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing, Member States will need to keep central registers containing information on the owners of companies and other legal entities.  At the same time, banks, auditors, real estate agents or casinos should be more vigilant about transactions deemed suspicious by their clients.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the text for presentation at second reading. In the text presented, which examines the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing, the rapporteurs agree with the Commission's desire to amend the 2005 directive in order to make financial transfers increasingly transparent. Specifically, the LIBE and ECON committees are calling for a register of the benefits received, which can be consulted by the State to verify the goodness of such donations.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council.  The directive introduces a number of requirements and rules to make money laundering difficult. That's why we would have been in favour of voting.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The European Council has repeatedly refused to lift secrecy about many of the tax practices that facilitate money laundering. However, the revelation of scandals such as LuxLeaks has allowed pressure to open such records, even partially, to the scrutiny of public authorities and those organizations and members of civil society with a legitimate interest, including the prosecution of tax crimes. Although insufficient, the final commitment represents a breakthrough respect for previous negotiating positions. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the current international context, organised crime and terrorists enjoy an increasingly significant financial force, often fuelled by money laundering and illicit funds. In order to combat these phenomena, it is necessary to introduce new and complex instruments to increase the transparency of capital transfers within the single market. I believe that the obligation for Member States to keep central registers and to ensure that commercial registers or business registers in their territory contain information on the actual beneficiaries immediately accessible to the competent authorities, financial information units and obliged entities such as banks can contribute to this.  That is why I have today chosen to vote in favour of the revision of the anti-money laundering rules. Finally, I hope that greater accessibility and availability of this data will really serve to prevent the financing of terrorism.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the anti-money laundering regulation because I believe it is essential that we have the most rigorous possible protections in place to stop people from either laundering money or financing terrorism. I am delighted that the final directive calls for central registers of beneficial ownership, which will also help with the ongoing fight against tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance, and I would call on all Member States to take advantage of the option given in the directive to make those registers publicly accessible.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as I consider that money laundering has to be fought decisively as an unacceptable financial crime. This proposal combats it, and Member States will be obliged to hold central registers of beneficial ownership, accessible to competent authorities under certain conditions.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I think it is extremely important to prevent the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing purposes. Necessity and proportionality should be the guiding principles for European legislation in money laundering issues.  While the EU has a developed framework to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, over the years the rules have evolved and the scope has been expanded, with each change going towards the goal of eliminating opportunities that criminals and terrorists could exploit.  I am committed to strengthening the internal market by reducing cross-border complexity, protecting societal interests from crime and acts of terrorism, supporting financial stability by protecting the good functioning and integrity of the financial system, and protecting the economic prosperity of the European Union by ensuring an efficient business environment.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – According to the International Monetary Fund, the extent of dirty money is huge, reaching 5% of world GDP. Such criminal activity weakens the financial sector, leads to loss of revenue in individual Member States, hinders competition and adversely affects the functioning of markets. Money laundering and illegal activity pose a real threat in the existing economy. From this point of view, every measure is welcome and needs to be supported. The establishment and functioning of business registers shall enable the identification of the beneficial owner of the undertaking or business transaction in the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing. Business registers should also help to identify the actual profits of companies, in particular in cross-border commercial transactions. In preventing the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering, the most important is a preventive approach, which should be targeted and proportionate in full respect of the EU legal order.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The issue of organised crime in connection with money laundering is a constant presence. However, the financial crisis has further increased this phenomenon in recent years. In addition, various illegal methods and forms of terrorist financing are increasingly emerging, which poses an increasing threat in the EU. As it was already established that this issue goes beyond the scope of national action and is becoming a broader, global challenge, Member States have committed themselves to stepping up their activities in this area.  These activities are addressed in Directive 2005/60/EC on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing. In view of the increasing activity in these areas, I believe that the revision of the directive was necessary and a good one.  I think it is right that the protection of persons who report suspected money laundering or the financing of possible terrorist acts has been increased, so that persons/organisations working in this area can be better detected.  I also think it is important that countries that deal with these jobs and help with money laundering are more easily and quickly identified. For this reason, I supported the adoption of amendments to the directive, which will further underpin the fight against money laundering.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour today on the directive that is part of the new anti-money laundering package, aimed at strengthening the fight against tax crimes and the financing of terrorism. With the adoption of the fourth anti-money laundering directive, the European Union is adopting stricter standards of transparency than those in force at international level and is therefore at the forefront of prosecuting tax crimes.  The text approved today by Parliament improves the Commission's proposal on one point in particular: for the first time, Member States will be obliged to keep central registers containing information from the actual owners of companies and other legal entities, as well as trusts. In addition, central registers will be accessible to authorities, so-called 'obliged entities' (such as banks carrying out their duty to adequate customer verification) and, subject to certain conditions, to persons demonstrating a 'legitimate interest' (e.g. investigative journalists or NGOs) in relation to money laundering, terrorist financing and crimes that could help their financing, such as corruption , tax cimini and fraud.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. I welcome this vote, which is making significant progress in the fight against money laundering, corruption and tax evasion.  The European Parliament agreed to a register of final stakeholders so that public authorities, citizens and organisations can see which natural person is behind a tangle of business structures. Transparency is the biggest enemy of money launderers and tax evaders. Thanks to this legislation, everyone will soon be able to see with a substantiated application what shadowy constructions are behind companies. Criminals try to launder the money they earn black, including corruption, fraud and drug trafficking, through a network of companies with opaque structures. In doing so, they are trying to fool the government and citizens. Every year, two to five percent of our economy is laundered worldwide. You can count on what it costs the taxpayer. The register of final stakeholders also makes it clear through which constructions multinationals evade tax. Tax evasion is legally legal, but morally unacceptable. With this register in hand, researchers can fine-find which multinationals are not able to do so. The countries of the European Union now have two years to convert the directive into national legislation and to establish a register of final stakeholders.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 We must take all steps to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing. It is a joint task of the security and financial authorities to cooperate closely and to exchange data in a timely manner.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the Council's position at first reading (05933/4/2015 - C8-0109/2015), the Opinion of the European Central Bank of 17 October 2015 On 23 May 2013, the Opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee of 23 May 2013, and the discussions of the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and in accordance with Article 55 of the Regulation. Rules of Procedure, I support this Recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on preventing the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering or terrorist financing.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ It is vital that we have rigorous protection in place to prevent money laundering or terrorist financing, and therefore I voted in favour of this regulation. I am delighted that the final directive calls for central registers of beneficial ownership which will also help with the ongoing fight against tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. I would call on all Member States to take advantage of the option to make these registers publicly accessible.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the Commission's revision of Directive 2005/60/EC, as it has become necessary to strengthen the internal market, make financial transactions more transparent in a financial environment that is becoming more complex, support the fight against terrorism and organised crime, and strengthen the EU financial system.   Member States should ensure that companies and other entities with legal personality, established or incorporated on their territory, or managed under their law, must obtain, keep and transfer to the public central register, commercial register or register of companies on their territory adequate, accurate, valid and up-to-date information on them and their ownership, at the time of incorporation, as well as any changes theret. Registers should be interconnected and accessible by the authorities and obliged entities. Member States may grant access to information and other parties and lay down rules on the basis of which the register can be accessed.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because it leads in several ways to increase the regulatory burden on the institutions concerned, and the results of these measures are questionable. I am convinced that the new regulatory burden will particularly affect persons who carry out legitimate activities in accordance with the law and not persons who engage in terrorist activities or money laundering.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing.  The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime estimates that between €615 billion and €1.54 billion is laundered worldwide each year. These are unimaginable sums. Money laundering is often linked to organised crime, which threatens security in our society, undermines the legal foundations of a democratic state and undermines the values on which the European Union was founded.  Moreover, money laundering poses a serious threat to the stability of the financial sector and weakens market power, which ultimately results in large losses in member states' budgets and the EU budget. In addition to traditional money laundering methods, organised criminal groups are increasingly using advanced means, enabling them to be enabled by the Internet and other technological innovations. For this reason, we must continue and intensify the fight against those who abuse freedom of movement and the European Union's internal market, and ensure the highest standards of anti-money laundering.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The need to prevent the use of the financial system for money laundering as well as in general to combat dirty money laundering and terrorist financing confirms our position on the need for state control over the market. Neoliberal ideas of a free and competitive market reinforce and maintain the unbridled need for large capital for enrichment at all costs, and thus lead to phenomena such as money laundering and terrorist financing. Therefore, the directive, although it will not solve the problem as long as neoliberal policies remain in force, is nevertheless a step in the right direction. Ensuring that the public register for the beneficial owners of a business is broad and as accessible as possible and contains information enabling the identification of actual ownership/property can help. For the above reasons we have decided to vote in favour.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the main source of terrorist financing and money laundering are mainly electronic transactions through the labyrinthine banking system, the provision of exceptions to the application of rules and restrictions is incorrect (such as the provision of exceptions to individual transactions, the raising of the threshold for natural or legal persons, the low level of administrative fines, etc.)

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 Money laundering has become one of the most profitable and high-end businesses in the world today. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of a new money laundering regulation already agreed with the Council, which for the first time obliges Member States to list the beneficial owners of companies, other legal persons and trustees in a central database. The new directive aims to combat money laundering, tax-related crime and terrorist financing. The interconnectability of registers is unfortunately essential for the usability of this information because of the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnectability of the internal market. Foreign entities must comply with the requirements of the transparency of information in a given country.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of a recommendation to prevent the use of financial systems for money laundering or terrorist financing. I agree that, in addition to criminal law measures, there is a need for further targeted measures to reduce the problem. I would also like to point out that, according to the Group of Socialists and Democrats, much more effective measures need to be taken to eradicate tax havens in third countries, but I am also firm that the existence of 'quasi-tax havens', secret and opaque tax agreements, cannot be accepted within the borders of the Union. The fight must also be strengthened in this area. I would also like to underline that this problem is also closely linked to the issue of government corruption in some Member States, which is also intended to be legalised in some cases by legislation. Although the recommendation does not address this issue in detail, I believe that we should pay more attention to this in the future, as this could also negatively affect the resources provided by the Union.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: in writing. ‒ Along with the report concerning ‘information accompanying transfers of funds’, this legislation is vital in the fight against terrorism and transnational crime. Crime networks spanning Europe and across the globe benefit from authorities lack of co-operation and profit from being able to exploit the opportunities provided by borders to carry out their illicit activities and evade capture. By working to tackle this at a European level, Member States of the EU will be able to implement a coordinated approach that will help to remove such opportunities, and is a good example of where the European Union is able to offer value added in the fight against crime. It is estimated that money laundering costs the global economy nearly GBP 1 trillion per year and provides the capital to fund human-trafficking, terrorism and corruption. I am also pleased that this legislation finds the right balance between targeting criminals whilst allowing legitimate businesses and individuals to conduct their affairs without unnecessary impediment – the legislation will work on the basis of risk-assessments, only targeting transactions that appear suspicious. As the EU works towards a commitment of ‘better regulation’, this is a good example and I am pleased to have voted in favour.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The actual owners of companies will have to be registered in the central registers of EU countries, open to both the authorities and those with a "legitimate interest", such as investigative journalists, according to the new rules agreed with the Council and adopted in plenary on Wednesday. The new directive aims to step up the fight against tax offences and the financing of terrorism. That's a good thing!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive, which introduces the idea of a public register of ultimate ownership. This new directive, if correctly implemented, will increase and improve the fight against money laundering.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Laundered capital accounts for 2 to 5% of global GDP per year. This dirty money undermines the stability of the financial sector while benefiting organized crime and terrorism. It interferes through loopholes in legislation and knows no boundaries. It requires us to adapt the legal framework. That is why I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this directive, which provides for increased supervision of financial channels and greater transparency in their operation. This fourth anti-money laundering directive will, for the first time, force EU Member States to keep central registers. These registers should list any information related to the "effective" owners of the companies. They will be open to the authorities and people with a "legitimate interest", such as investigative journalists. New rules to facilitate the tracking of remittances have also been approved. I welcome this progress, which has met with many resistances Some Member States have tried to preserve unsavotive interests. I stress that this vote illustrates that a determined political impulse cannot be buried by a few national interests.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Money laundering and the closely related development of organised crime pose a risk to the stability of individual economies, but they also have a major impact on global economic flows. The main goal in transactions of illicitly acquired money is to insert it into financial flows or transfer it outside the country. I therefore consider that closer cooperation between Member States and better coherence between national justice systems is very much needed.   I find proposals aimed at facilitating the investigation and prosecution of illegal activities related to the exchange of money for crimes such as terrorism, corruption and illegal trafficking very useful. We must be aware that this is a complex process in which new techniques are constantly being applied, and criminals engaged in illicit activities are increasingly being perfected.
