I therefore support provisions that focus on transparency and the availability of information on bank and wireless money transactions so that loopholes are not exploited for illegal activities. Risk assessment-based rules protect individuals who transfer money or open up businesses, and also indicate a reduction in regulatory burdens compared to previous legislation. So I voted in favor.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council.  The directive introduces a number of requirements and rules to make money laundering difficult. That's why we would have been in favour of voting.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council.  The directive introduces a number of requirements and rules to make money laundering difficult. That's why we would have been in favour of voting.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as it puts Parliament in a stronger position in the face of the Commission's proposal. Many provisions have been clarified especially in the field of data protection. In general, the possibility of research and detection of possible money laundering and terrorist financing is strengthened.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution concerning the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing. Terrorist groups and attacks are on the rise globally and it has been proven that they finance their activities through money laundering channels.  I strongly believe that this resolution and the existence of clear rules within the EU will contribute to the European Parliament’s constant battle against terrorist groups that threaten our cohesion and security.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The European Council has repeatedly refused to lift secrecy about many of the tax practices that facilitate money laundering. However, the revelation of scandals such as LuxLeaks has allowed pressure to open such records, even partially, to the scrutiny of public authorities and those organizations and members of civil society with a legitimate interest, including the prosecution of tax crimes. Although insufficient, the final commitment represents a breakthrough respect for previous negotiating positions. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. In the face of public-related scandals over tax evasion and money laundering, the EU is obliged to do anything to respond to public outrage. What we say is that these scandals are not mere abuses or misadjustments of the system. They are the concrete expression of the contradictions of a system that represents at this moment the greatest obstacle to the development of humanity.  Creating the illusion that it is possible to create a control mechanism that allows moralising the system and aligning it with humanity's aspirations is to lead European citizens to deception. As we questioned.  Take this example. The European Commission has declared war on tax havens. What is surprising is that the same European Commission approved last March the IV Tax Benefit Scheme of the International Business Centre of Madeira, thus extending the existence of the Madeira Free Trade Zone until 2027.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I had to abstain from voting on the amendment of the delegated regulation on the obligation to present an import licence for ethyl alcohol. The current licensing and accounting of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin is quite sufficient and is also consistently enforced and reviewed. Furthermore, a further expansion of biofuel areas would put the fight against hunger at great risk.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this proposal in the same way as the previous proposal. This proposal to change European legislation extends the information to be collected on individual transfers of funds. On the one hand, of course, this collection of information will lead to customers feeling that information that is their private environment is being collected about them, on the other hand, it should be remembered that today international terrorism is being financed by money flowing into the European Union from third countries. Therefore, it is necessary to collect this information and use it in case suspicions of possible terrorist financing become revealed.  I am in support of the proposal, but it must be said that it is necessary to ensure that this information is used only when a suspect is being investigated and that there is a suspicion of committing, say, a serious form of crime.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I gave my support to the regulation on information accompanying transfers of funds, given that we need stronger measures to tackle tax avoidance and fraud. This means establishing public registers to increase transparency on the financial flux and have better protection at EU level for whistleblowers, given that we are almost completely dependent on them to alert us on the cases of fraud or where taxpayers’ money is abused. We also need a coordinated response from the law enforcement bodies in the Member States and a standardised procedure for financial institutions and payment service providers to combat money laundering. It is simply unacceptable that billions and billions of euros simply continue to fall through the cracks every year.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Mr. President, in the context of the prevention and detection of money laundering and terrorist financing, this Regulation aims to improve the supervision of money transfers by determining the data to be attached to the financial transaction and aims to strengthen legislation and competent authorities at Union level, in the part of imposing sanctions.  The Regulation addresses the extremely sensitive data issues needed to monitor the transfer of funds and identify payers and recipients. Significant changes are being made in this part, as the constant advancement of technology leads to the facilitation of criminal activities that need to be prevented by safeguards further proposed. In order to ensure the correctness, integrity and stability of the financial system, I supported this recommendation for a second reading of the Information Regulation accompanying the transfer of funds.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I have supported this regulation which amends and updates a 2006 rule, which sets out the information to be included on the payer and recipient of bank and financial transfers in order to prevent money laundering.  It is particularly important that, thanks to the action of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, all transactions relating to the EU's externality have been achieved in the same way as those of an intra-Community nature, with the exception of those with an amount of less than EUR 1000, so as not to prejudice remittances from immigrants. Penalties for non-compliance and control mechanisms have also been strengthened. European harmonisation of bank transfer information is essential to combat laundering from illicit transactions such as drug trafficking, terrorism or organised crime, but also to fill the processes of the Banking Union and the so-called Capital Markets Union, so that users of financial services do not have to deal with a disparity in conditions depending on the Member State in which they fix their residence.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The objective of this report (which has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process) is to implement measures to control transfers of funds in the context of combating financial fraud and money laundering. While clearly insufficient, the existence of this regulatory framework is a small step in the international fight against financial crime and tax evasion.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not approve of the procedure for approval without a vote, and would like to place my views on this subject on record.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on information provided through transfers of funds aimed at strengthening the fight against money laundering. Money laundering accounts for between 2% and 5% of global GDP each year. Under the new rules, the eu's central registers will have to be published by the beneficial business owners, which will have to be made available to public authorities and persons with legitimate interests, such as journalists. New rules on transfers of funds are also introduced, which should facilitate the traceability of money. In negotiations with the Council of the EU, the European Parliament succeeded in ensuring that the updated Anti-Money Laundering Directive obliges EU countries to publish beneficial owners of companies, foundations and other legal entities in their central registers. In addition, banks, auditors, lawyers, real estate agents and casinos will have to monitor suspicious customer transfers more closely.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The proposal aims to revise the regulation on the information on the client accompanying the transfer of funds in order to increase the traceability of payments and to ensure that the EU framework remains in line with international standards in this area.  The Transfer Regulation sets rules requiring payment service providers to transmit information about contractors throughout the payment chain for the prevention and detection of money laundering and terrorist financing and investigations.  The aim of the proposal is to increase transparency by including the following changes: information on the client; Bring credit cards, debit cards and telephones into the scope of the regulation if they are used for money transfer; obligation to establish a risk-based procedure to determine when a payment should be blocked, suspended, executed...; Align with FATF traceability rules Strengthen the sanctioning power of the relevant authorities; make it mandatory to publish sanctions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The purpose of this vote is to adopt the recommendation for second reading on the regulation on information accompanying remittances and repealing Regulation (EC) No. 1781/2006. This regulation should allow for the amendment and updating of the existing anti-money laundering regulation to improve the traceability of payments and bring EU standards in this area into line with international law. This regulation is a step in the right direction and proposes strong measures such as on the traceability of money transfers. In addition, there is an arsenal of administrative sanctions, so I have decided to vote for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While it is partly acceptable, there are still unclear passages in this text. I therefore abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I have supported this regulation which amends and updates a 2006 rule, which sets out the information to be included on the payer and recipient of bank and financial transfers in order to prevent money laundering.  It is particularly important that, thanks to the action of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, all transactions relating to the EU's externality have been achieved in the same way as those of an intra-Community nature, with the exception of those with an amount of less than EUR 1000, so as not to prejudice remittances from immigrants. Penalties for non-compliance and control mechanisms have also been strengthened. European harmonisation of bank transfer information is essential to combat laundering from illicit transactions such as drug trafficking, terrorism or organised crime, but also to fill the processes of the Banking Union and the so-called Capital Markets Union, so that users of financial services do not have to deal with a disparity in conditions depending on the Member State in which they fix their residence.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation, which endorses the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on information accompanying transfers of funds and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006. In view of the changing nature of money laundering and terrorist financing threats and the increasing threat profile due to the constant development of the technologies and tools available to criminals, the Commission has proposed to revise Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006 on payer information accompanying transfers of funds in order to increase the traceability of payments and to ensure that the EU framework is fully compliant with international standards. This proposal is consistent with and complements the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing. These two legal instruments pursue the general objective of reviewing the existing European Union framework for preventing money laundering and terrorist financing in order to improve its effectiveness while ensuring its consistency with international standards. The proposal is also in line with the EU's internal security strategy, which identifies the EU's most urgent security challenges in the coming years and proposes five strategic objectives and specific actions for the 2011-2014 creation of a safer EU. These include addressing money laundering and preventing terrorism, in particular updating the EU framework in order to increase the transparency of information on the beneficial ownership of legal persons.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this Report, which contributes to strengthening the EU institutions in the fight against money laundering, and almost unanimous support on the Committees also makes it clear that this is indeed a quality document. The main concern remains transfers outside EU countries. The sanctions and monitoring chapter has been improved and the data protection provision is better harmonised within the rules.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The purpose of the draft regulation is to revise Regulation (EC) 1781/2006 relating to the information relating to the client accompanying the transfer of funds in order to improve the traceability of payments. In particular, strengthening legislation helps to better combat money laundering. However, improving payment traceability should not have the effect of infringing on the privacy of users of banking services. Since the European Commission has taken into account MEPs' demands on this matter, I have given a favourable opinion to the text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Coordinated action by Member States in the field of electronic bank transfers contributes to combating fraud and actions that may have serious repercussions on the security and credibility of the Union's financial sector. Firstly, financial institutions and payment service providers must ensure that they have all the truthful information on the initiators and beneficiaries of transactions and that the data registration requirements comply with THE SAFEF standards. Encrypted virtual currencies and payment methods through them have led to the emergence of new illicit activities online. It is worrying that since the new payment methods were made public since 2008, illegal activities have been recorded aimed at money laundering, child pornography, drug trafficking, electronic fraud, identity theft using encrypted coins. Therefore, authorisation of payment via virtual currencies should only be allowed if there is clear information on those involved and on the subject matter of the transaction. In order to prevent transfers of funds pursuing fraudulent money laundering and terrorist financing actions, it is necessary to establish principles of cooperation with third country authorities in order to allow mutual access to complete information and the follow-up of suspicious transactions.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. The text did not bring the desired changes and there is still too much 'heavy' traceability on money transfers.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I have supported this regulation which amends and updates a 2006 rule, which sets out the information to be included on the payer and recipient of bank and financial transfers in order to prevent money laundering.  It is particularly important that, thanks to the action of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, all transactions relating to the EU's externality have been achieved in the same way as those of an intra-Community nature, with the exception of those with an amount of less than EUR 1000, so as not to prejudice remittances from immigrants. Penalties for non-compliance and control mechanisms have also been strengthened. European harmonisation of bank transfer information is essential to combat laundering from illicit transactions such as drug trafficking, terrorism or organised crime, but also to fill the processes of the Banking Union and the so-called Capital Markets Union, so that users of financial services do not have to deal with a disparity in conditions depending on the Member State in which they fix their residence.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. A European regulation on information accompanying remittances is a necessary step in the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. We must at all costs provide a European response in this area. A balance must be struck between the security of citizens and the protection of private data. I voted in favour of such a regulation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the information data accompanying transfers of funds and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006. This recommendation endorses the Council's position at first reading, which stressed that illicit money flows from transfers of funds and the efforts made by criminals to disguise the origin of their proceeds of criminal activity can undermine the integrity, stability and reputation of the financial sector and pose a threat to the Union's internal market as well as to international development.  The measures concerning the information data accompanying transfers of funds are therefore to be considered fundamental: without certain coordination measures at Union level, money launderers and financiers of terrorism would benefit from the free movement of capital within the Union's integrated financial area to support their criminal activities.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The anti-money laundering package presented by the Commission in 2013 contains two legislative proposals aimed at updating the Eu ropean Union legal framework on money laundering and terrorist financing. We have today voted on the European Parliament's recommendation on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the information data accompanying transfers of funds and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006. The M5S delegation decided to abstain in order to be consistent with the vote on the anti-money laundering directive and to underline its concerns about exemptions for certain payment instruments and entities, the derogations provided for and the wide discretion left to The Member States with regard to sanctions.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, endorsing the Council's position on the information accompanying the transfer of funds. This is indeed an important issue since the traceability of funds touches on the issues of money laundering, the financing of illicit and criminal activities, and even the financing of terrorism, an issue that, as everyone knows, is close to my heart. We know that the principle of free movement of capital, imposed by the European Union, facilitates financial malfeasance by destroying barriers, allowing cross-border flow flows with reduced controls. In order to prevent the risks inherent in such a principle, and if it is necessary to remain within the framework of an integrated financial zone, the regulation proposed by the Commission and amended by parliamentarians provides that financial institutions communicate up-to-date, appropriate and accurate information on transfers of funds made on behalf of their clients, so as to enable the competent authorities to respond more effectively to money laundering and terrorist financing. Control that will allow for greater transparency and slightly improve the probity of financial institutions.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the revision of Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006 on information data relating to the payer accompanying transfers of funds in order to improve the traceability of payments and to ensure that the EU regulatory framework continues to be in line with international standards. The Fund Transfer Regulation lays down rules requiring payment service providers to disclose information about the payer throughout the payment chain in order to prevent, investigate and detect cases of money laundering and terrorist financing.  The proposed changes are aimed at filling some gaps in transparency by imposing certain requirements such as information on the beneficiary, extension of the credit flow to cards, telephones and IT devices, verification of the identity of the beneficiary, strengthening the sanctioning powers of the competent authorities and the publication of sanctions.  In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that the illicit money flows created by transfers of funds can undermine the stability and reputation of the financial sector and pose a threat to the internal market. The current Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006, while ensuring that the EU regulatory framework continues to be in line with international standards, still has some legal shortcomings. Therefore, due to the changing threats posed by money laundering and the need to review the EU regulatory framework, I have decided to vote in favour of this recommendation.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of the proposal is to prevent and detect money laundering and terrorist financing when transferring funds, and it strengthens certain aspects of traceability of payments. The proposal is rather technical in its nature but I support the Council’s position for the second reading which is identical to the agreed text in the trilogues.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulation on the transfer of funds is part of the anti-money laundering package presented by the Commission in 2013, was negotiated in Parliament during the last legislature and approved at second reading by the Council during the Italian Presidency.  The aim of the regulation is to prevent, investigate and detect cases of money laundering and terrorist financing, improving the transparency and traceability of transfers of funds by authorities and law enforcement agencies. In particular, payment service providers are required to disclose data relating to the payer and the payee of a payment order.  In committee, the text passed by a large majority. However, we have chosen to abstain not only in order to be consistent with the vote on the anti-money laundering directive, to which the regulation is closely linked, but also to highlight our concerns about exemptions for certain payment instruments and subjects, derogations and the wide discretion left to the Member States also with regard to sanctions.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – The objective of this report (which has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process) is to implement measures to control transfers of funds in the context of combating financial fraud and money laundering. While clearly insufficient, the existence of this regulatory framework is a small step in the international fight against financial crime and tax evasion.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to strengthen the traceability of payments and remittances within the internal market in order to avoid and detect all money laundering and terrorist financing activities. This relatively technical text is the counterpart of the report aimed at preventing the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This report is part of the latest legislative package proposed by the European Commission to change our anti-money laundering measures. Its adoption enshrines the upgrading of European standards with the recommendations of the Financial Action Task Force, an intergovernmental body in which the European Union is very active. When it comes to electronic transfers of funds, it is important to ensure accurate traceability of contractors and beneficiaries throughout the payment chain. One of the roles of the committee in which I sit, the committee responsible for civil liberties, justice and home affairs, was to ensure that adequate data protection was ensured.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. To combat the financing of terrorism, the new European regulation on the regulation of remittances strengthens the control by financial institutions, of money transfer operations, especially international ones, by enriching the information provided, and by substantially limiting the anonymity of these transactions. The proposed measures will more accurately trace the origin of the funds, using debit and credit card information, as well as data contained in mobile phones or other digital and computer devices. The sanctions power of the competent authorities will also be strengthened. This legislation will better monitor and prevent fraud. At the same time, the use of data must be done with respect for the privacy and privacy of European citizens.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006 on information accompanying remittances, because I believe that the European Union legal framework needs to adapt to the present moment because terrorist organisations benefit from gaps in our legislation. Currently, huge cash flows from the Union flow into the accounts of the terrorist organisation Islamic State – this can only be stopped or restricted by introducing stricter legislation on information accompanying remittances.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the main source of terrorist financing and money laundering are mainly electronic transactions through the labyrinthine banking system, the provision of exceptions to the application of rules and restrictions is incorrect (such as where the nature of the sanctions provided for is purely 'administrative' there may be a question of challenging the severity of the proposed administrative sanctions, no harmonised recommendations and interpretative provisions are put in place at European level in order to achieve a more uniform application of the rules , there is no guarantee of cases (such as criminal proceedings, bankruptcy or succession) where documents and information are deleted after 5 or 10 years from the end of the business relationship, etc.)

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 This draft legislation aims to make it more difficult to finance criminal organisations and terrorist organisations . By providing new information, it makes money laundering more difficult. At second reading, the agreement reached with the Council satisfies the objectives set, which is why I voted in favour of approving the text of the agreement.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I have supported this regulation which amends and updates a 2006 rule, which sets out the information to be included on the payer and recipient of bank and financial transfers in order to prevent money laundering.  It is particularly important that, thanks to the action of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, all transactions relating to the EU's externality have been achieved in the same way as those of an intra-Community nature, with the exception of those with an amount of less than EUR 1000, so as not to prejudice remittances from immigrants. Penalties for non-compliance and control mechanisms have also been strengthened. European harmonisation of bank transfer information is essential to combat laundering from illicit transactions such as drug trafficking, terrorism or organised crime, but also to fill the processes of the Banking Union and the so-called Capital Markets Union, so that users of financial services do not have to deal with a disparity in conditions depending on the Member State in which they fix their residence.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because I am in favour of stricter control over any transfer of funds.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 2013, the European Commission has been seeking to amend existing European regulations responding to the acute need for change and the fight against money laundering and the transfer of funds of terrorist organisations. That Regulation should establish clear and precise rules for financial service providers and clarify the flow of money along the way through the financial chain between the payer and the payee for the purpose of clarifying, preventing and protecting against money laundering.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I shall abstain because the text did not bring about the changes we would have liked after the passage at first reading at second reading. Changes so as not to have such unjustified traceability on all money transfers.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is against, since the main source of terrorist financing and money laundering are mainly electronic transactions through the labyrinthine banking system, the provision of exceptions to the application of rules and restrictions is incorrect (such as where the nature of the sanctions provided for is purely 'administrative') there may be a question of challenging the severity of the proposed administrative sanctions, no harmonised recommendations and interpretative provisions are put in place at European level in order to achieve a more uniform application of the rules , there is no guarantee of cases - such as criminal proceedings, bankruptcy or succession - where documents and information are deleted after 5 or 10 years from the end of the business relationship, etc.)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation lays down rules for payment service providers to send information on the payer and the payee throughout the payment chain for the purposes of prevention, investigation and detection of money laundering and terrorist financing. A coordinated response from law enforcement bodies in the MS and a standardised procedure for financial institutions and payment service providers is essential to combat money-laundering, which costs many billions annually. The main points of interest of the first reading negotiations concern transfers outside the Union, where all information should be recorded, with the exception of a de minimis EUR 1000 threshold, which should make remittances slightly easier. Furthermore, the chapter on sanctions and monitoring has been enforced, and the provisions on data protection have been better aligned within the regulation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the new money laundering legislation already agreed with the Council, which for the first time obliges Member States to list the beneficial owners of companies, other legal persons and trustees in a central database. The new directive aims to combat money laundering, tax-related crime and terrorist financing. Money laundering has now become one of the most profitable and high-end businesses in the world. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for between 2% and 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. The initiatives now proposed will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I have supported this regulation amending and updating a 2006 rule, which sets out the information to be included on the payer and recipient of bank and financial transfers in order to prevent money laundering.  It is particularly important that it has been achieved, thanks to the action of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, that all transactions relating to the EU's externality be referenced in the same way as those of an intra-Community nature, with the exception of those with an amount of less than EUR 1000, so as not to prejudice remittances from migrants. Penalties for non-compliance and control mechanisms have also been strengthened. European harmonisation of bank transfer information is essential to combat laundering from illicit transactions such as drug trafficking, terrorism or organised crime, but also to complement the processes of the Banking Union and the so-called Capital Markets Union, so that financial service users do not have to deal with a disparity in conditions depending on the Member State in which they set their residence.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this regulation amending and updating a 2006 rule setting out the information to be included on the payer and recipient of bank and financial transfers in order to prevent money laundering.  It is particularly important that it has been achieved, thanks to the action of the Socialist Group, that all transactions relating to the EU's externality be referred to in the same way as those of an intra-Community nature, with the exception of those with an amount of less than EUR 1000, so as not to harm remittances from migrants. Penalties for non-compliance and control mechanisms have also been strengthened. European harmonisation of bank transfer information is essential to combat laundering from illicit transactions such as drug trafficking, terrorism or organised crime, but also to fill the processes of the Banking Union and the so-called Capital Markets Union, so that users of financial services do not have to deal with a disparity in conditions depending on the Member State in which they fix their residence.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to complementarity with the vote on preventing the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing, I voted yes to this recommendation accompanying the previous one, repealing the previous Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the fund transfer regulation primarily because it enriches and complements a pre-existing and very important overall regulatory framework concerning EU instruments to combat money laundering. Secondly, because I believe that it is essential to strengthen the regulatory framework and the instruments to combat a phenomenon of global scope, in line with the rules in force at international level, which are very important but often non-binding. The new legislation, consisting of a directive and a regulation, took two years of work and it was not until December last year that political agreement was reached in the Council, thanks to the efforts of the Italian PRESIDENCY of the EU, which considered it a priority of the six-month period. The regulation on the transfer of funds concerns payment service providers, and therefore banks, and in this case information on the person ordering the transfer. It introduces an obligation on financial institutions to include accurate information on both the payer and the beneficiary of the transfer, and thus the obligation to follow the transfer throughout the payment chain. The complex and hard work carried out by the EP, and in particular by the two rapporteurs, has led to a more ambitious final result.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. The directive seeks to increase the demands for information in international bank transfers to make tax evasion difficult. That's why we would have been in favour of voting.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ This legislation ensures that transfers of funds are fully traceable, by making competent authorities and payment service providers responsible for making sure that information on the payee is included with any transfer of funds.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council position adopted at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on information accompanying transfers of funds and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006. The Commission has proposed to complement the relevant legislation with provisions to facilitate the traceability of payments and to ensure that the Legal Framework of the European Union is complied with with international standards.  This and other relevant legal instruments pursue the common objective of a safer European Union. This is particularly important in view of the changing circumstances and technologies used by criminals involved in money laundering or terrorist financing.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I have supported this regulation which amends and updates a 2006 rule, which sets out the information to be included on the payer and recipient of bank and financial transfers in order to prevent money laundering.  It is particularly important that, thanks to the action of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, all transactions relating to the EU's externality have been achieved in the same way as those of an intra-Community nature, with the exception of those with an amount of less than EUR 1000, so as not to prejudice remittances from immigrants. Penalties for non-compliance and control mechanisms have also been strengthened. European harmonisation of bank transfer information is essential to combat laundering from illicit transactions such as drug trafficking, terrorism or organised crime, but also to fill the processes of the Banking Union and the so-called Capital Markets Union, so that users of financial services do not have to deal with a disparity in conditions depending on the Member State in which they fix their residence.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is an important proposal that will increase the traceability of payments which are used for money laundering or terrorist financing operations. The proposed changes to the report address gaps where transparency may have been otherwise weaker.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ This report strikes the right balance between the need to prevent money laundering and tax evasion on the one hand and data protection on the other. I was able to support the trilogue agreement.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council.  The directive seeks to increase the demands for information in international bank transfers to make tax evasion difficult. That's why we would have been in favour of voting.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the information accompanying the transfer of funds and the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 100/2013; 1781/2006 on the basis that it is of utmost importance to increase the level of transparency in financial transactions. In my view, it is necessary to provide complete information on the recipient, to define what are the monetary amounts above which, when it comes to foreign payments, additional checks and controls are needed, and to strengthen the possibility of sanctions and to improve the coordination between institutions and relevant authorities. In addition, it is necessary to specify what procedures are when the recipient/payer information is missing or incomplete when transferring transaction funds. This strengthens the fight against organised crime and money laundering.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Kirkhope and Simon on the information accompanying the remittances. The aim of this report is to remove Regulation (EC) 1781/2006 in order to create an up-to-date new regulation and to be able to best monitor funds that can be used to finance terrorism and money laundering. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on information accompanying remittances and repealing Regulation (EC) 1781/2006, in order to improve the traceability of transfers, prevent money laundering and combat terrorist financing.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I voted negatively on this report in committee, because the development that has been initiated here is making citizens more and more 'glassy' and there are more and more obstacles to simple money transfers that are not justified. Although this is an approval without a vote, I would like to make it clear that I continue to oppose this proposal.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. The proposal that Mrs Cora van Nieuwenhuizen has presented to us on the regulation on indices used as reference values in financial instruments and financial contracts deserves attention. This is an extremely important measure, which aims to resolve those serious cases of manipulation of benchmarks for the determination of interest rates, such as LIBOR and EURIBOR, and currency reference values, which in recent years have caused considerable losses to consumers and investors as well as destroying public confidence in the financial sector.  I therefore wholeheartedly voted in favour of the proposal, which forms part of the many efforts that Europe is trying to make to restore confidence and rules to the economy.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – I already consider this proposal acceptable in order to combat money laundering and criminal financing. Indeed, this can be supported by the complex monitoring of international transfers through the introduction of a system obliging banks and other payment service providers to pass on the data of the payer and the payee in a way that is linked to the transfer. However, care will have to be taken to ensure that personal rights are respected and that no additional fees can be charged to customers under this title.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Voting in favour of mr Kirkhope and Mr Simon's report on the information data accompanying transfers of funds has meant supporting a proposal aimed at improving the traceability of payments and at preventing and detecting money laundering and terrorist financing, especially in certain areas where serious doubts remain about the transparency and traceability of financial funds.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to adopt the recommendation on the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of the European Parliament and Council regulation on information accompanying remittances and repealing Regulation (EC) No. 1781/2006. It aims to amend and update the existing anti-money laundering regulation to improve the traceability of payments and bring EU standards in this area into line with international law. This recommendation is therefore based on the recommendations of the International Financial Action Task Force (FATF) but sometimes goes further, particularly on the traceability of remittances; the various European banking and financial authorities could issue guidance to the relevant authorities and payment service providers on the measures to be taken. There is also an arsenal of administrative sanctions.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This Regulation provides for the information to be included on the payer and recipient of transfers in order to prevent money laundering. All transactions relating to outside the EU have been made to refer in the same way, except those below EUR 1 000. Sanctions and control have also been strengthened. Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 There was no vote in plenary because the document was accepted by jurisdiction.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the information accompanying transfers of funds and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In order to improve the understanding by all interested parties of the legislative framework for combating money laundering and of the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 19/05/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased we got agreement on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on information accompanying transfers of funds.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the text on the information data accompanying the transfers of funds because, after lengthy negotiations with the Council, a conclusion was finally reached. The text adopted at second reading is capable of improving the traceability of payments and of combating money laundering and terrorist financing through the transfer of funds. The proposed changes refer to areas where European regulations are still unable to take precise action.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The EU will soon have a new regulation that will regulate everything related to the information accompanying transfers of funds, replacing the regulation that until now regulated this matter. My support, therefore, for the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament which we have already adopted at second reading.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I also received my agreement to vote on the transmission of information on transfers of funds. Since this proposal can also make a significant contribution to curbing terrorist financing, as it exposes the money laundering routes of the terrorist cells and thus makes them vulnerable, it can only be supported.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The lack of effective information requirements in the financial sector allows for massive fraud and the flow of illicit money into the financial sector. The proposal introduces the requirement for payment service providers to record information about the client and the recipient of the funds when carrying out a transfer of more than 1,000 euros. While some improvements were made to this text at second reading, notably on the means of monitoring the information accompanying the transfer of funds, this attempt to introduce control of the financial sector concerns only the tip of the iceberg. Indeed, neither the savage liberalisation of capital flows nor the transfer prices that allow large groups to pay taxes are mentioned, nor the austerity that decimates tax control. I'm still voting for this little step forward.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to revise Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006 on the information on the payer accompanying transfers of funds (hereinafter referred to as the 'Regulation on transfers of funds') in order to improve the traceability of payments and to ensure that the EU framework remains fully in line with international standards.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation as it is important that the Union support intelligence forces and investigative task forces in their efforts to track illicit financial transactions. These measures are intended to strengthen the internal market through an increased level of transparency and increase the traceability of payments to curb money laundering and track terrorist networks.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I approved a ‘transfers of funds’ regulation, which aims to improve the traceability of payers and payees and their assets. The regulation lays down rules for payment service providers to send information on the payer and the payee throughout the payment chain for the purposes of prevention, investigation and detection of money laundering and terrorist financing. A coordinated response from law enforcement bodies in the Member States and a standardised procedure for financial institutions and payment service providers is essential to combat money-laundering, which costs many billions annually.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Massive flows of illicit money can damage the stability and reputation of the financial sector, threaten the single market and international development. Tax evasion and non-disclosure and concealment mechanisms can be used as strategies applied in money laundering, and it is important that measures are taken at European level to combat illicit activities. I am voting in favour of the measures put forward to achieve full traceability of transfers of funds, to investigate money laundering and to detect terrorist financing.  It is also important to ensure the transmission of information throughout the payment chain and to provide for the establishment of a system imposing on payment service providers the obligation to ensure that transfers of funds are accompanied by information on the payer and the payee.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The purpose of this vote is to adopt the recommendation on the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of the European Parliament and Council regulation on information accompanying remittances and repealing Regulation (EC) 1781/2006. It aims to amend and update the existing anti-money laundering regulation to improve the traceability of payments and bring EU standards in this area into line with international law. This recommendation is therefore based on the recommendations of the International Financial Action Task Force (FATF) but sometimes goes further, particularly on the traceability of remittances; the various European banking and financial authorities could issue guidance to the relevant authorities and payment service providers on the measures to be taken. There is also an arsenal of administrative sanctions. So I decided to vote for this text.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the resolution regulating information data accompanying transfers of funds, which brings EU rules into line with international standards set in 2013, specifically by the Recommendation of the Financial Action Group. The text is at second reading and follows an agreement reached in the trialogue under the Italian Presidency. We are particularly pleased that, with one exception concerning transfers of less than EUR 1 000, it will be obligatory to provide the specifications for foreign currency transfers. We also welcome the strengthening of the sanctions and monitoring chapter, and the fact that the rules on the protection and publication of sensitive data have been brought into line with existing EU regulations.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the information accompanying transfers of funds and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. This document strengthens transparency and control over the provenance of funds and financial transfers.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the document negotiated with the Council, which brings a number of regulations on the information to be provided and collected when it comes to transfers of funds. The purpose of these regulations is not to make it difficult for those involved in transfers of funds to work and bureaucracy, but to ensure a certain traceability of these funds in order to stop the financing of illegal and terrorist activities.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the COMPROMISE AGREEMENT between the EP and the Council, on the basis of which FIUs and law enforcement authorities will have more information at their disposal to make payments more traceable. The resulting form also ensures that the EU legal framework remains in full compliance with international standards. The benefit is to establish the obligation for payment service providers to send information throughout the payment chain not only on the payer, but also on the payee for the purpose of preventing, investigating and detecting money laundering and terrorist financing. Uniform implementation of the new rules across the European Union should ensure that there is no distinction between cases involving national payments within a Member State and cross-border payments between Member States. At the same time, all such mechanisms needed today must be quite clear and clear in terms of how information is used and defended against misuse.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The proposal has already been voted on in committee, so that it was no longer put to the vote in plenary. However, I would have abstained because, although the proposal contains some positive approaches to combating money laundering, for example, it does not take sufficient account of my ideas on the protection of private data.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported.  The aim of the bill is to prevent money laundering and to detect and prevent terrorist financing.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the position presented.  I believe that the time has come to review the existing EU framework for preventing money laundering and terrorist financing in order to improve its effectiveness. It should be noted that the nature of money laundering and terrorist financing threats is constantly changing and threats to the constant change in technology and tools available to criminals are increasing. It is therefore important to ensure that the EU system fully complies with international standards. In particular, the EU must be subject to common and sufficiently strict rules on information provided by the payer and the payee when transferring funds. This will increase the traceability of payments. In order to prevent discrimination in relation to national payments in a Member State and cross-border payments between Member States, the international standard must be transposed uniformly throughout the Union.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Having regard to the Council's position at first reading and the opinions of the Economic and Social Committee and the European Central Bank; Having regard to the joint deliberations of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and their joint recommendation; I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒The proposed regulation revising the Appropriations Transfer Regulation is necessary to improve the traceability of payments and ensure that the Union legislative framework remains fully compliant with international standards. The main objective is to set out such a legislative framework that will effectively prevent and detect money laundering and terrorist financing during the transfer of funds. I therefore support the prescribed rules for payment service providers on sending information on financial payers through the payment chain. In the conditions of changes in the nature of money laundering and terrorist financing threats facilitated by the continuous development of technology and resources available to criminals, it is of utmost importance to adapt quickly. This is precisely what the new regulation aims to achieve by harmonising the legislative framework in line with revised international standards, ensuring consistency between national rules and addressing shortcomings concerning emerging threats, and I therefore support the adoption of this Regulation.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Anything that allows more transparency in financial movements is positive. Efforts are still very limited and reform of financial practices is unfortunately not a real priority. I support this text, of course.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. \u2012 Recommendation for second reading 11. May 2015 at the Council's first reading position with a view to adopting european parliament and Council regulations on the issue of data protection that monitor the transfer of funds by referring to the first reading 1781/2006 (05932/2/2015-C8-0108/2015-2013/0024(COD)). With this report, the European Parliament adopts the first reading and approves the recommendation for the second reading, given the Council's position at first reading 1781/2006 (05932/2/2015-C8-0108/2015-2013/0024(COD)), and taking into account the opinion of the European Central Bank as of 17 May 2013. and the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee of 23 May 2013, bearing in mind Article 294(7) of the agreement on the functioning of the European Union and is in line with the joint discussions between the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (A8-0154/2015). It is also in accordance with Article 294(7) of the Regulation. treaty on the functioning of the European Union. Due to these items, I support this recommendation from my colleagues Kirkhope and Simon.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒Money laundering, terrorist financing and organised crime pose major problems that should be addressed at Union level, as illicit money flows through the transfer of funds can harm the security, integrity, stability, reputation of the financial sector and, as a result, jeopardise the Union's internal market and international development. The amendments to the Regulation aim to strengthen the EU's protection against money laundering and terrorist financing while ensuring consistency with the approach applied at international level, in particular with fatf recommendations (Financial Action Task Force).  It is also important to point out that this Regulation does not intend to impose unnecessary burdens or costs on payment service providers on persons using their services. Consequently, as well as the fact that the implementation and application of the Regulation as well as the FATF Recommendations No 2013/2013, 16 constitute relevant and effective means of preventing and combating money laundering and terrorist financing, I supported this recommendation for a second reading of the Information Regulation accompanying the transfer of funds.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Also in the case of the information accompanying the transfers of funds there were joint meetings of the two competent committees, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, which voted almost plebiscitely for Parliament to approve the Council's position at first reading. That was the case, and I welcome that.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Faced with a lack of transparency and irregularities in remittances, the EU is trying to legislate to increase the transparency of these financial movements. MEPs adopted a regulation on "remittances" on Wednesday. I have spoken in favour of this text, which aims to improve the traceability of payers, beneficiaries and their assets.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This legislative resolution adopts the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on information accompanying transfers of funds and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1781/2006. The regulation aims to improve the traceability of payments and the prevention and detection of money laundering and terrorist financing when funds are transferred.  To this end, it is intended to eliminate areas where transparency gaps still persist, in particular by ensuring: access to payer information; extending the field of action to credit and debit cards and mobile phones and digital devices; verification of the identity of the beneficiary; and the strengthening of the sanctioning powers of the competent authorities and the publication of sanctions. I voted in favour

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The adoption of this new regulation is part of the European Parliament's efforts to establish a legislative framework that provides the necessary tools to prevent and detect money laundering and terrorist financing. More specifically, the rules adopted today improve the traceability of remitting funds, in line with the recent revision of international standards in this area. Today we have made the choice of greater transparency in an increasingly complex financial system that is therefore more vulnerable to fraud. To act for greater transparency is therefore to act in the interests of citizens by combating money laundering operations. It is a huge amount of money , every year and internationally, between 2% and 5% of GDP - sums that do not benefit our economies.  And the losses are even higher because the terrorism financed by these laundered funds affects the lives of millions of people around the world. This new regulation is important because it enhances transparency while ensuring that the storage and exchange of information meets the criteria for protecting personal data and privacy.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The reason for this proposal is the revision of the regulation on the transfer of funds in order to ensure compliance with legality by detecting possible attempts at money laundering and terrorist financing. Due to the constant technological developments available to criminals, which allows or facilitates new forms of money laundering, a permanent review of the forms of action at international level is necessary.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I have supported this regulation which amends and updates a 2006 rule, which sets out the information to be included on the payer and recipient of bank and financial transfers in order to prevent money laundering.  It is particularly important that, thanks to the action of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, all transactions relating to the EU's externality have been achieved in the same way as those of an intra-Community nature, with the exception of those with an amount of less than EUR 1000, so as not to prejudice remittances from immigrants. Penalties for non-compliance and control mechanisms have also been strengthened. European harmonisation of bank transfer information is essential to combat laundering from illicit transactions such as drug trafficking, terrorism or organised crime, but also to fill the processes of the Banking Union and the so-called Capital Markets Union, so that users of financial services do not have to deal with a disparity in conditions depending on the Member State in which they fix their residence.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Noting that the act was adopted in accordance with the Council's position, in voting this report, we instructed the President of Parliament to sign the act with the President of the Council, in accordance with Article 297, paragraph 1, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the text for presentation at second reading. This recommendation is also the result of the work carried out by the LIBE and ECON Committees and aims to identify money laundering and terrorist financing through the transfer of funds.  The approach of the committees is clear: one way to fight with the same weapons as terrorists is to control them economically as well. In order for this action to be effective, each Member State must impose requirements on its territory in terms of the transfer of money, such as requesting information from the beneficiary and strengthening the powers of penalties for the competent authorities.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council.  The directive seeks to increase the demands for information in international bank transfers to make tax evasion difficult. That's why we would have been in favour of voting.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The objective of this report (which has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process) is to implement measures to control transfers of funds in the context of combating financial fraud and money laundering. While clearly insufficient, the existence of this regulatory framework is a small step in the international fight against financial crime and tax evasion.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This legislation ensures that transfers of funds are fully traceable, by making competent authorities and payment service providers responsible for making sure that information on the payee is included with any transfer of funds.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this proposal since it also clarifies the rules on politically—exposed persons and adds several important provisions on data protection.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the approval of the anti-money laundering package, I also voted in favour of the fund transfer regulation, which aims to increase the traceability of payers and beneficiaries and their assets. The agreement thus reached between the Council and Parliament makes it possible to modernise and revise the existing regulation on information accompanying transfers of funds, in order to improve the traceability of payments and bring the EU legal framework into line with international standards, such as the recommendations of the Financial Action Task Force (FATF).

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the Council's position at first reading (05932/2/2015 - C8-0108/2015), the Opinion of the European Central Bank of 17 October 2015 On 1 May 2013, and a recommendation for a second reading of the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (A8-0154/2015), I accept this recommendation for a second reading.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which was a recommendation for a second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on information accompanying transfers of funds.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the report because the flow of illicit money is a major problem for the Union, undermines the structure, stability and reputation of the financial sector and threatens the internal market as well as international development, and directly or indirectly undermines citizens' trust in the rule of law.  Furthermore, the main point of the agreement (report) is to improve payment monitoring to prevent and detect money laundering and terrorist financing in the transfer of funds.   We need to focus on areas where transparency gaps continue to remain, by imposing some of the main requirements such as recipient data, extending the scope to credit/debit cards and mobile phones, on digital/IT devices, by requiring verification of users' identities, strengthening the powers of sanctioning authorities and disclosing sanctions. Thus, before transferring funds, the payment service provider shall apply customer due diligence measures and shall verify the accuracy and completeness of the information.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because it brings new administrative obligations to financial institutions that will increase their regulatory burden, and the new regulations will also lead to a reduction in the privacy of data subjects. Like the proposal on the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing, this proposal will particularly affect innocent persons.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Since the main source of terrorist financing and money laundering are mainly electronic transactions through the labyrinthine banking system, the provision of exceptions to the application of rules and restrictions is incorrect (such as where the nature of the sanctions provided for is purely 'administrative' there may be a question of challenging the severity of the proposed administrative sanctions, no harmonised recommendations and interpretative provisions are put in place at European level in order to achieve a more uniform application of the rules , there is no guarantee of cases - such as criminal proceedings, bankruptcy or succession - where documents and information are deleted after 5 or 10 years from the end of the business relationship, etc.)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the recommendation on data accompanying money transfers, because I believe that the abusive exploitation of the principle of free movement of capital is a significant violation of our common interests and harms the European Union. Coordinated action at EU level is needed to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing. Making money transfers much more transparent is an important step towards this goal.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's position measure at first reading for the adoption of the European Parliament and Council regulation on information accompanying remittances and repealing the regulation.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council.  The directive seeks to increase the demands for information in international bank transfers to make tax evasion difficult. That's why we would have been in favour of voting.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council.  The directive seeks to increase the demands for information in international bank transfers to make tax evasion difficult. That's why we would have been in favour of voting.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The objective of this report (which has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process) is to implement measures to control transfers of funds in the context of combating financial fraud and money laundering. While clearly insufficient, the existence of this regulatory framework is a small step in the international fight against financial crime and tax evasion.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Directive proposes to raise the level of customer due veto duties to be exercised in relation to 'politically exposed persons', in particular by requiring that such persons, as well as their immediate family members and employees, be subject to enhanced customer due vein procedures. Ppes will now include not only 'foreign' individuals, but also 'internal' individuals to whom prominent public functions have been performed. The proposed Directive provides for more stringent rules and more specific rules and procedures for the identification of beneficial owners of companies or other legal entities or trusts, although the definition of beneficial owner remains unchanged. In addition, companies or other legal entities or trusts will be required to keep records regarding the identification of their beneficial owners.  These are positive measures that do not convince and create the illusion that it is possible to reform an unreformable system that will surely find ways to turn these regulations into the next scandal. .

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I also received my agreement to vote on the transmission of information on transfers of funds. Since this proposal can also make a significant contribution to curbing terrorist financing, as it exposes the money laundering routes of the terrorist cells and thus makes them vulnerable, it can only be supported.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. The resolution on the transmission of information on transfers of funds ensures that it will be more difficult to make anonymous transfers in the future. I voted in favour of this with regard to the group line, because I believe that cash is, and should remain, the means suitable for anonymous money transactions. However, anonymous cashless money transactions must not be misused for money laundering. In this case, banks will have a greater role to play in this area, which will then have to assess the risk of whether a transaction is objectionable.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this amendment to the regulation governing insolvency law. I was also present at the debate yesterday, but unfortunately I did not have time to say one of the essential reasons. That's why I signed up for this explanation today. Personally, I consider the greatest benefit of the amendment of insolvency law conflict-of-law rules to be the fact that it is now imposed on the States of the European Union to establish insolvency registers. As a person who has dealt with insolvency law in the Czech Republic and prepared a new insolvency law as Minister of Justice, I know that insolvency law can only work if the information is public for creditors and debtors and if the information is not only for individual states, but is interconnected. This will allow any firm to know how their potential debtor is doing in another part of Europe and whether insolvency proceedings are initiated against him.  I think that this change is revolutionary and will significantly improve the functioning of insolvency not only in individual states, but also throughout Europe.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the Zwiefka report, as I believe we reached a balanced outcome. It is very positive that we updated this legislation after 10 years of its being in force. The regulation covers 50 000 companies which are yearly involved in cross-border insolvency procedures. It is important for them that we clarified the rules on jurisdiction of the courts, the recognition of judgments and the applicable law in these cases, and I consider the extension of the scope of the rules to hybrid procedures and company restructuring as an important step forward. I also welcome the introduction of the additional criterion of a three-month cooling-off period in order to avoid forum shopping.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, up to two years ago Ireland had one of the most draconian personal insolvency regimes in the civilised world, legislation that belonged in the era of Charles Dickens. At the time I was a Member of the Irish Parliament and, given the huge mortgage crisis that was unfolding, the government of the day, which is still the government of this day, was forced to introduce new, more modern, more fitting legislation – so they said. As with so much else that they have done, however, rather than enact the new legislation for the benefit of the people, they allowed themselves to be entirely influenced by the banking sector.  Despite clear warnings from those who were trying to assist people in mortgage distress in their dealings at the time with the banks, the government, in the legislation, gave the banks the final veto over whether or not a deal could be made, whether insolvency could be declared. It has been a disaster, so much so that now the government has been forced to move again. They will remove that veto but in the meantime, what of the damage they have done over the last two years, all the unnecessary added stress they have caused? But it is ironic that the European Union, that actually led to the financial crisis in Ireland, is now going to create rules to solve it. Well, hopefully it will, but its past history is not good.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, I supported the report and hope that the proposed reform will make bankruptcy procedures faster and more efficient and have a less stressful and detrimental impact on employees of companies that find themselves in liquidity problems. Namely, the bankruptcy of a company in any country presents its workers with the worst nightmare. A company usually goes bankrupt when there is no more help, and bankruptcy proceedings take years. Workers' rights are in last place. In the circumstances of the economic crisis, Croatia has introduced pre-bankruptcy settlements. In the Croatian examples of the procedures carried out, there were at least strange things, the strangest of which is the one in which the court had no jurisdiction to determine the veracity of bankruptcy claims and the debtor himself determined the claim. This has since been changed, but only after several procedures have been carried out.  That is why I think this report is important, I welcome its adoption and hope that it will be reflected as an incentive to change these bad situations that we have witnessed in Croatia.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, insolvency and pre-bankruptcy proceedings in the Member States vary significantly, thus affecting both differences in the functioning of the single market and member states' resilience to the economic crisis.  These procedures must be swift and effective, and the aim is to throw out of the market bad entities that, through their default, endanger those of good quality who do well. There is no single solution at EU level, but the country-specific recommendations within the European Semester are clear - legislation must be defined and procedures as simple, fast, clear and open as possible.  Croatia's legislative framework in this area has been rated as one of the weakest in Europe and the government is being asked for significant improvements and changes. Due to the importance this Regulation has for the quality functioning of the single market, I was happy to support the proposed amendments and the extension of coverage today.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing.
