We voted in favour of the revision of this regulation which lays down common rules as regards the court competent to bring insolvency proceedings, applicable law and recognition of judgments in the event that a debtor – whether a company or a trade company or an individual – is in a situation of insolvency , because after ten years of its entry into force it was improveable in the application of some of its provisions. The main novelty it includes is to prevent the debtor from moving his assets or judicial proceedings from one country to another in order to improve his situation from the legal point of view forum of convenience, thus preventing some companies or debtors from suddenly changing their headquarters before the start of insolvency proceedings. It introduces greater legal certainty and allows consideration of whether the change of venue meets objective reasons or not. It has also been possible to include a recital concerning workers' rights in relation to the establishment of a preferential right for workers, taking into account that they are the weakest when insolvency proceedings are initiated.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to revise existing European regulation on transnational insolvency proceedings. From the perspective of workers, the final outcome of the negotiations is still insufficient: insolvency proceedings continue to over-protect debtors' interests with respect for the preservation of employment or in choosing the national framework in which the procedure should be opened. However, positive aspects such as better judicial and administrative control of insolvency proceedings should be recognized and that the maintenance of the activity is facilitated while the company restructures its activities and accounts. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. As insolvency proceedings are increasingly cross-border, the Commission proposed a reform of the Insolvency Regulation in 2012. This was adopted by the outgoing Parliament at first reading in February 2014. Subsequently, the Council of Ministers adopted its position in March 2015, which has now been submitted to Parliament. I welcome the resolution on this issue, as it obliges courts and insolvency administrators from different Member States, among others, to work more closely together to better coordinate cross-border insolvencies.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The aim of this amendment to the EU regulation of 29 May 2000 is to protect creditors in the case of cross-border enterprises. This text assigns jurisdiction to the State in which the company has "the centre of its main interests" and thus provides that creditors seek the most favourable national jurisdiction, which I welcome. However, the creditor's ability to use the jurisdiction of his own state, as long as he owns property there, is ruled out. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not approve of the procedure for approval without a vote, and would like to place my views on this subject on record.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to increase the effectiveness of the European system for cross-border insolvency proceedings, thereby ensuring the smooth functioning of the internal market and its resilience to economic crises. The Insolvency Regulation establishes a European system for the handling of cross-border insolvency proceedings. The Regulation applies where the debtor's assets or creditors are located in more than one Member State. The Regulation determines which court is competent to open insolvency proceedings, the main proceedings must be opened in the Member State where the debtor has the principal interests and the effects of the case are recognised throughout the EU. The Insolvency Regulation applies to all Member States except Denmark, which are not involved in judicial cooperation.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. One of the objectives of the proposed regulation is to give a "second chance" to companies experiencing financial difficulties as a result of cross-border insolvency proceedings. In the context of the economic crisis, I believe it is essential to stimulate businesses in order to stimulate jobs and growth.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation for the second reading presented by Tadeusz Zwiefka aims to amend the Community regulation of 29 May 2000 on insolvency procedures to improve the protection of creditors in the event of a company's insolvency being cross-border.  Hundreds of thousands of jobs are linked to cross-border corporate insolvency proceedings and it is proposed to save companies deemed strong but facing temporary financial difficulties.  While these provisions are laudable, I can only note that they undermine the sovereignty of the Member States but also that these failures are the result of European policies that have been pursued for years. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Zwiefka report on insolvency proceedings is acceptable and balanced. I believe that the proposed update of the legislation will ensure improvements, especially in cases of financial difficulties in the management of transnational insolvency proceedings, and for these reasons I supported the text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the revision of this regulation which lays down common rules as regards the court competent to bring insolvency proceedings, applicable law and recognition of judgments in the event that a debtor – whether a company or a trade company or an individual – is in a situation of insolvency , because after ten years of its entry into force it was improveable in the application of some of its provisions. The main novelty it includes is to prevent the debtor from moving his assets or judicial proceedings from one country to another in order to improve his situation from the legal point of view forum of convenience, thus preventing some companies or debtors from suddenly changing their headquarters before the start of insolvency proceedings. It introduces greater legal certainty and allows consideration of whether the change of venue meets objective reasons or not. It has also been possible to include a recital concerning workers' rights in relation to the establishment of a preferential right for workers, taking into account that they are the weakest when insolvency proceedings are initiated.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation, which endorses the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings. This new proposal amends Council Regulation (EC) No 1346/2000 on insolvency proceedings. The Insolvency Regulation establishes a European system for the handling of cross-border insolvency proceedings. The Regulation applies where the debtor's assets or creditors are located in more than one Member State. The Regulation determines which court is competent to open insolvency proceedings, the main proceedings must be opened in the Member State where the debtor has the principal interests and the effects of the case are recognised throughout the EU. Secondary proceedings may be brought at the place where the debtor is established; secondary proceedings are limited to the assets of the debtor in that State. The Regulation also lays down rules on the determination of applicable law and certain basic and secondary rules for the coordination of insolvency proceedings. The Insolvency Regulation applies to all Member States except Denmark, which do not participate in judicial cooperation under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  The purpose of the revision of the Insolvency Regulation is to increase the effectiveness of the European system of cross-border insolvency proceedings, thereby ensuring the smooth functioning of the internal market and its resilience to economic crises. This objective is in line with the EU's current policy priorities to promote economic recovery and sustainable growth, investment and job retention, as set out in the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Bankruptcy Report, as it improves the application of certain provisions. These are technical things related to improving its application itself, and certainly in the future will have to think about improving the preferential rights of workers at European level.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The draft regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amends the EU regulation of 29 May 2000 on insolvency proceedings. Its purpose is to protect creditors from insolvency in the case of cross-border trade. This text assigns jurisdiction to the Member State in which the debtor company has the centre of its main interests in order to combat the abusive search of the most favourable national jurisdiction. On the other hand, the text removes the creditor's ability to initiate secondary proceedings before the courts of his own state if the debtor owns property there. As a defender of legal sovereignty, I finally voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context that cross-border insolvency proceedings are no longer an exception, but a common phenomenon affecting not only large businesses or groups of companies, but also SMEs, this Commission's proposal is welcome because it is an important initiative aimed at European Union company law. It is noted that there are certain areas of insolvency law where harmonisation is desirable and achievable, which is fully valid at present. Moreover, it should not be neglected that disparities between national insolvency laws lead to competitive advantages or disadvantages and difficulties for undertakings with cross-border activities and could become obstacles to the successful restructuring of insolvent undertakings. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the conduct of insolvency proceedings in a coordinated manner can play an important role in avoiding the liquidation of groups and can contribute to a better recovery of assets and the maintenance of jobs.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Zwiefka report is on a very important issue, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, that of insolvency proceedings. The legislative proposal amends Regulation (EC) No 1346/2000. The process has been very long, not least because it has not been easy to reach agreement in the Council. At first reading, the text received a very large majority in Parliament (589 for, 69 against).  The updating of the insolvency proceedings legislation should ensure some improvements in the business world, especially in cases of financial difficulties in cross-border insolvency proceedings. The text contains rules against phenomena such as so-called forum shopping also thanks to more precise definitions regarding the concept of "centre of main interest" of a company and that of "establishment". National insolvency registers should cooperate better with each other in the exchange of information, including through the European e-Justice portal. I am in favour of this report.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the revision of this regulation which lays down common rules as regards the court competent to bring insolvency proceedings, applicable law and recognition of judgments in the event that a debtor – whether a company or a trade company or an individual – is in a situation of insolvency , because after ten years of its entry into force it was improveable in the application of some of its provisions. The main novelty it includes is to prevent the debtor from moving his assets or judicial proceedings from one country to another in order to improve his situation from the legal point of view forum of convenience, thus preventing some companies or debtors from suddenly changing their headquarters before the start of insolvency proceedings. It introduces greater legal certainty and allows consideration of whether the change of venue meets objective reasons or not. It has also been possible to include a recital concerning workers' rights in relation to the establishment of a preferential right for workers, taking into account that they are the weakest when insolvency proceedings are initiated.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of this resolution in order to make cross-border insolvency proceedings more efficient and effective, with benefits for debtors and creditors, facilitating the survival of companies and giving entrepreneurs a second chance. Every year, insolvency proceedings affect some 200 000 companies across the EU, putting 1.7 million jobs at risk. A quarter of these insolvency proceedings have a cross-border dimension. The new legislation, through the protection of creditors and the survival of companies, will contribute to the maintenance of jobs during this particularly difficult period.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mr Tadeusz Zwiefka's report because the text aims to improve the efficiency of the European framework for resolving cross-border insolvency cases. The European Commission's figures show that every year the procedure affects some 200 000 companies throughout the Union, or almost 600 companies a day, putting 1.7 million jobs at risk. A quarter of these insolvency proceedings have a cross-border dimension. In the light of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Zwiefka's recommendations, which validate the compromise text from the trilogue as adopted at first reading by the Council. The new rules on cross-border insolvency procedures approved today by the European Parliament will facilitate the restructuring of companies whose insolvency has a cross-border dimension.  They will also clarify the process of appointing the competent courts and thus avoid the so-called forum shopping practice aimed at choosing the jurisdiction likely to provide the most favourable judgment.  I also welcome the creation of an electronic register to improve the monitoring of cross-border insolvency procedures in the Union.  Together, these measures should provide a more effective framework for both debtors and creditors while giving honest entrepreneurs the chance to restructure their businesses in order to operate better in the future.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which amends the Community regulation of 29 May 2000 on insolvency proceedings. Of course, I recognise the merit of the report in assigning jurisdiction to the courts of the Member State in which the debtor company has 'the centre of its main interests', which places the principle of reality at the centre of the procedure.  However, the possibility for the creditor to initiate a second proceeding before the courts of his own state is all too limited. While I welcome the desire of this text to protect creditors in cases of insolvency of a cross-border undertaking, I consider the effort too small, especially since the proposed measures constitute an infringement of national sovereignty, and have therefore opposed this text.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 By Regulation (EC) No 1346/2000, the EU has established a European framework on cross-border insolvency proceedings, which applies to cases where the debtor, a natural or legal person, has assets or creditors in more than one Member State and determines the court responsible for opening insolvency proceedings: the main proceedings must be initiated in the Member State where the debtor has the centre of the main interests, and produces recognised effects throughout the European Union; the secondary procedure may be initiated in the place where the debtor is dependent, and has effects limited to the goods in that State.  The regulation, which entered into force in 2002, needs to be updated. The overall objective of amending the Regulation is to improve the efficiency of the European framework for resolving insolvency cases, so as to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and its resilience in times of economic crisis. In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 As you know, the common framework for insolvency proceedings aims to avoid the transfer of assets or legal proceedings from one Member State to another, in order to benefit from more favourable conditions and to the detriment of creditors. However, the current regulation does not harmonise insolvency laws but only regulates legislative conflicts in the different Member States.  On the basis of these considerations, I have decided to vote in favour of this proposal. Indeed, I believe that this proposal for a regulation, aimed at making transnational insolvency procedures more effective and efficient, is more in line with the legislative developments of the Member States and favours a better and more efficient functioning of the internal market.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The EP adopted the report at first reading in February 2014. The proposed regulation was aimed at making cross-border insolvency proceedings more efficient and effective with a view to ensuring smooth functioning of the internal market and its resilience in economic crises. The EP proposed a more flexible approach with the main focus of the negotiations on jurisdiction and preferential rights of the employees. An early second reading agreement was reached after the trilogues. The main goals of the counteracting of forum shopping has been achieved, and thus I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – The objective of this report is to review the existing European regulation on transnational insolvency proceedings. From the perspective of workers, the final outcome of the negotiations is still insufficient: insolvency proceedings continue to over-protect debtors' interests with respect for the preservation of employment or in choosing the national framework in which the procedure should be opened. However, positive aspects such as better judicial and administrative control of insolvency proceedings should be recognized and that the maintenance of the activity is facilitated while the company restructures its activities and accounts. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to revise the current legislation on insolvency procedures to include cross-border insolvency cases, which regularly cause legal and jurisdictional conflicts. Considering that it is not a question of unifying national insolvency laws but of resolving the legal and jurisdictional disputes of the Member States, in order to ensure the efficient functioning of the internal market, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament validates the updating of EU legislation on cross-border corporate insolvency. In 2014, I had already supported this text at first reading. Indeed, the harmonization of national standards for insolvency procedures strengthens the internal market. Clarifying the areas of competence of Member States is a guarantee of legal certainty for companies operating in the European Union. In this regard, I reiterate my support for the proposal to establish a European insolvency register to check whether proceedings have already been initiated in a Member State.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation because it sets out more efficient and effective rules on cross-border insolvency proceedings, which will help to achieve one of the European Union's current priorities: stimulating economic growth. These rules will make it easier for businesses to survive and give insolvent entrepreneurs a second chance.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The main elements of the Council’s position are as follows: – moving away from a traditional liquidation approach to insolvency to a ‘second-chance approach’ for businesses and entrepreneurs in financial difficulties when cross-border insolvency proceedings are involved; – the scope of the proposed Insolvency Regulation is therefore broader than the scope of the current Insolvency Regulation and extends to hybrid and pre-insolvency proceedings; – the new rules contain a set of safeguards aimed at preventing abusive forum shopping; – the regulation would impose on Member States an obligation to establish insolvency registers (that contain certain information on the debtor and the insolvency practitioner); these national insolvency registers are to be interconnected and accessible via the European e-Justice portal.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against. This position gives too many possibilities to companies that could take advantage of the law to avoid paying their obligations. However, we recognise that there should also be some kind of protection for small and medium-sized enterprises, contrary to the specific text that protects very large companies.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the agreement at second reading with the Council. The new legislation will contribute to a more efficient and simpler management of cross-border insolvency proceedings, while respecting the national competence of legal institutions.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. The figures provided by the European Commission indicate that cross-border insolvency proceedings affect some 200 000 companies each year in the European Union, meaning that 1.7 million jobs are at stake. A quarter of these insolvency proceedings have a cross-border element This proposal for a regulation aims to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of these procedures, for the benefit of debtors and creditors, thus facilitating the survival of undertakings and offering entrepreneurs a second chance. It also adapts the current Insolvency Regulation to the evolution of national insolvency laws since the entry into force of the Regulation in 2002.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the revision of this regulation which lays down common rules as regards the court competent to bring insolvency proceedings, applicable law and recognition of judgments in the event that a debtor – whether a company or a trade company or an individual – is in a situation of insolvency , because after ten years of its entry into force it was necessary to update it. The main novelty it includes is to prevent the debtor from moving his assets or judicial proceedings from one country to another in order to improve his situation from a legal point of view, thus preventing some undertakings or debtors from suddenly changing their seats before the start of insolvency proceedings. It introduces greater legal certainty and allows consideration of whether the change of venue meets objective reasons or not. It has also been possible to include a recital concerning workers' rights in relation to the establishment of a preferential right for workers in insolvency proceedings.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Although there are many positive elements to this resolution, I voted against it because I believe that such measures must be the responsibility of states.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation contains some improvements to pre-existing legislation that should be highlighted. In it, however, workers are neglected and reduced to the mere quality of creditors who do not recognise credit privileges and whose claims are not granted any specific guarantees. Likewise, the Regulation does not unequivocally have the identification, choice and attributions of workers' representatives in the cases in which it applies and thus puts at risk the exercise of their rights to be informed, to be consulted and, more generally, to actively participate in such proceedings. Furthermore, the way in which the Regulation defines the centre of the debtor undertaking's main interests, on whose location the choice of the State—Member State in which the main insolvency proceedings may be opened, does not preclude such a location from being purposely chosen because it has a legislative environment favourable to the interests of shareholders and thus unfavorable to those of workers which provides incentives to Member States to use their company law as an instrument of legislative competition in damage to workers' rights.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 2000, the European Union has been paying particular attention to this issue, as demonstrated by Directive 1346/2000, which clearly defined the European framework for cross-border insolvency proceedings. It has clearly and comprehensiblely determined which Member State has jurisdiction to open and open insolvency proceedings and laid down uniform rules of applicable law. It entered into force in 2002 and, after years of its use, the European Commission concluded that there was a need to improve the application of certain provisions, which are very complex and technical aspects.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation has my support. It deals with insolvency proceedings, which is a very important and sensitive issue, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. The legislative proposal amends Regulation (EC) No 1346/2000 in a positive way and we support it.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on insolvency proceedings, as this position gives too many possibilities to companies that could take advantage of the law to avoid paying their obligations. However, I recognise that there should also be some kind of protection for small and medium-sized enterprises, contrary to the specific text that protects very large companies.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Council Regulation establishing a European framework for cross-border insolvency proceedings. This would determine which Member State has jurisdiction for opening insolvency proceedings and establish uniform rules on applicable law, and provides for recognition and enforcing of insolvency-related decisions as well as for the coordination of main and secondary insolvency. Our S&D Group amendment managed to avert forum shopping by introducing the additional criteria of a three months cool—off period. The regulation now also allows for the coordination of the proceeding for corporate groups, and calls for a future introduction of preferential rights of employees. I thank the rapporteur and the shadows for the very good job done.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the revision of this regulation which lays down common rules as regards the court competent to bring insolvency proceedings, applicable law and recognition of judgments in the event that a debtor, whether a company or a trade company or an individual, is in a situation of insolvency , because after ten years of its entry into force, it was necessary to improve the application of some of its provisions. The main novelty it includes is to prevent the debtor from moving his assets or judicial proceedings from one country to another in order to improve his situation from the legal point of view forum of convenience, thus preventing some companies or debtors from suddenly changing their headquarters before the start of insolvency proceedings. It introduces greater legal certainty and allows consideration of whether the change of venue meets objective reasons or not. It has also been possible to include a recital concerning workers' rights in relation to the establishment of a preferential right for workers, taking into account that they are the weakest when insolvency proceedings are initiated.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I am in favour of the revision of this regulation which lays down common rules as regards the court having jurisdiction to bring insolvency proceedings, applicable law and the recognition of judgments in the event that a debtor – whether a company or a trade company or an individual – is insolist, because after ten years of its entry into force it was improveable in the application of some of its provisions. The main novelty it includes is to prevent the debtor from moving his assets or judicial proceedings from one country to another in order to improve his situation from the legal point of view forum of convenience, thus preventing some companies or debtors from suddenly changing their headquarters before the start of insolvency proceedings. It introduces greater legal certainty and allows consideration of whether the change of venue meets objective reasons or not. It has also been possible to include a recital concerning workers' rights in relation to the establishment of a preferential right for workers, taking into account that they are the weakest when insolvency proceedings are initiated.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote marks the start of a new phase for thousands of businesses. The new regulation on cross-border bankruptcy procedures puts an end to the traditional hostile prospect of liquidation, providing greater guarantees and protections for creditors and a second chance for companies and entrepreneurs in difficulty. Other measures include concrete solutions to so-called forum shopping, thus making it more difficult to circumvent the sacrosanct rights of creditors, and insolvency electronic registers are introduced that can provide relevant information in a timely manner to creditors and courts, also in order to avoid parallel insolvency proceedings. For these reasons, I have firmly voted in favour of this measure, in the hope that a new phase will really be opening up in which the institutions are at the side of companies and entrepreneurs in difficulty, not to punish and liquidate but to help and restructure.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I congratulate Mr Zwiefka on concluding the agreement with the Council on a long-awaited measure by consumers and businesses in Europe.  I voted in favour of the regulation: the insolvency system at European level was in fact in a state of uncertainty, especially for cross-border situations, and the Commission was right, more than two years ago now, to propose an overall reform of the sector.  I would particularly like to highlight an important aspect introduced after reading by the Council and Parliament, namely the safeguards put in place against the so-called phenomenon of forum shopping. In too many well-known cases, companies and debtors moved their headquarters abruptly before insolvency or bankruptcy proceedings were initiated: the regulation now introduces a legal framework of greater protections as well as the ability of courts to assess whether the move is genuine or not.  The agreement that we are about to ratify takes a step forward to protect the European economy; I hope that this will be an important sign of the new policy direction of growth and attention to citizens, consumers and businesses launched with the new Commission.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of recasting Regulation (EC) No 1346/2000 on cross-border insolvency proceedings, firstly because insolvency proceedings at European level affect more than 200 000 companies each year, a quarter of which are cross-border. The new legislation took about three years of work and the Italian Presidency of the EU was particularly committed to the final success of the negotiations, which succeeded in finding the right political synthesis between the Council and the European Parliament. The aim is to ensure a second chance for entrepreneurs, including not only bankruptcy proceedings, but also hybrid and pre-insolvency proceedings, and also the remission and restructuring of the debt of natural persons (consumers and independent professionals), and to initiate an electronic register useful both for creditors, in order to identify assets and obtain information, and to avoid parallel proceedings. The registry will be available in the e-Justice portal.  In order to prevent abusive practices, the concept of centre of principal interests (COMI), which is important for cross-border corporate groups, particularly interested in specific discipline, has been clarified. Group insolvency rules are supplemented by rules allowing the coordination of corporate group procedures.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. The result is a recast of the directive governing insolvency proceedings. The interest of workers is to hinder insolvency proceedings because they often mean that a company can close without facing its wage obligations. The directive is insufficient in this regard. That is why we would have abstained from voting.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of Council Regulation No 1346/2000 which determines which Member State has jurisdiction for opening insolvency proceedings, establishes uniform rules on applicable law and provides for the recognition and enforcement of insolvency—related decisions, as well as for the coordination of main and secondary insolvency.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings. The Insolvency Regulation establishes a European system for the handling of cross-border insolvency proceedings. This Regulation shall be established where the debtor's assets or creditors are located in more than one Member State. There are also other rules for the conduct of insolvency proceedings of this kind. The Regulation is being reviewed in order to improve the functioning of the European system of cross-border insolvency proceedings.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the revision of this regulation which lays down common rules as regards the court competent to bring insolvency proceedings, applicable law and recognition of judgments in the event that a debtor – whether a company or a trade company or an individual – is in a situation of insolvency , because after ten years of the entry into force of the original regulation, it was improveable in the application of some of its provisions. The main novelty it includes is to prevent the debtor from moving his assets or judicial proceedings from one country to another in order to improve his situation from the legal point of view forum of convenience, thus preventing some companies or debtors from suddenly changing their headquarters before the start of insolvency proceedings. It introduces greater legal certainty and allows consideration of whether the change of venue meets objective reasons or not. It has also been possible to include a recital concerning workers' rights in relation to the establishment of a preferential right for workers, taking into account that they are the weakest when insolvency proceedings are initiated.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that cross-border insolvency proceedings need to be more efficient and handled in a quicker way. This regulation can work towards the smooth functioning of the internal market and help the resilience of the internal market to economic crises.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ A large proportion of insolvencies involve cross-border issues and this agreement will help resolve possible legal conflicts. I was accordingly happy to support the text.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. The result is a recast of the directive governing insolvency proceedings. The interest of workers is to hinder insolvency proceedings because they often mean that a company can close without facing its wage obligations. The directive is insufficient in this regard. That is why we would have abstained from voting.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on insolvency proceedings, as the phenomenon of insolvency has become a cross-border problem, which, in addition to large companies, also engages SMEs across Europe. I support the proposal to modernise the current European bankruptcy law through public consultations, and to devote particular importance to the needs of SMEs in order to increase legal certainty. I also believe that there are positive proposals on the creation of a European register, which would allow creditors to have information on possible insolvency proceedings initiated, and to address the bankruptcy of a group of companies. This further strengthens European integration and supports cross-border business activities.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text aims to amend the EU regulation of 29 May 2000. The purpose of this amendment is to protect creditors in the case of investment in cross-border companies. This text, it should be noted, assigns jurisdiction to the State in which the company has "the centre of its main interests". The creditor is therefore invited to seek the most favourable national jurisdiction. But the creditor cannot still resort to the jurisdiction of his own state, even if he owns property there. It is a violation of the principle of sovereignty and citizenship. Therefore, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Tadeusz Zwiefka's report on insolvency proceedings. This report approves at second reading the Council's position on the harmonisation of the various insolvency procedures within the European Union through the amendment of Regulation (EC) No. 1346/2000. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on insolvency proceedings. In order to respond to cross-border insolvency cases, this recommendation calls for the creation of a unified European framework that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. An important report that has already been voted on in committee. The proposals must be supported, which is why I would like to reiterate my support.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. This legislative act regulates insolvency rules if more than one Country of the European Union is involved in the proceedings. The new regulation clarifies the rules for cooperation between courts and insolvency administrators and establishes a register for the accounting of cross-border insolvency cases, which is publicly available. I believe that this legislation will facilitate a faster handling of cross-border insolvency cases and improve the business environment as a whole. This is another area where uneeding of rules can improve the functioning of the single market.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it largely seeks to improve functioning of the regulation, and I am also pleased the S&D Group has managed to get some amendments in aimed at improving the situation of employees and small creditors.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 19. 5. 2015, at the strasbourg plenary session, we discussed an important revision of the insolvency regulation. To begin with, I welcome the Commission's efforts to modernise insolvency law, not only in the light of the scandalous abuse of this right in the Czech Republic. I believe that the proposal put forward may lead to a reduction in the infamous 'insolvency tourism' and to the now necessary modernisation of the solution to so-called cross-border insolvency cases. However, despite my support for this document, I continue to see a number of shortcomings in it. In my opinion, the planned revision should, above all, increase the protection of those who are most at risk, namely employees affected by the eventual bankruptcy of their company. Nowadays, in the Czech Republic, company insolvencies are on a daily basis, in the last six years only the number of proceedings initiated has increased almost 7x. We need not only a broader discussion on how to protect companies from possible bankruptcy, but especially in the context of the situation in the Czech Republic, also a discussion on how to prevent their frequent and unregulated abuses in the context of competitive struggle between entrepreneurs. As one of the real avenues, I would see, for example, to strip creditors across the board of the possibility of filing so-called creditor insolvency proposals. The situation where, according to the available data, almost one in ten companies in the Czech Republic has encountered similar practices remains absolutely unacceptable.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Many small hungarian enterprises have been destroyed by the inancy of being able to get their income after the work they have done with integrity. A number of troubled subcontracting chains included companies with interests in several countries. This regulation regulates multi-country insolvency proceedings very well and clearly serves legal certainty, so I supported it with good heart. It can be of great help to companies in the SME sector, for which the costly and complicated legal path to date has been impassable.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. After several technical meetings and trialogues, we reached agreement at second reading. This is a very topical issue and concerns business failure and insolvency. The report proposes, among other points, a more ambitious solution on the insolvency of business groups by proposing a compromise for a more flexible approach. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. This recommendation is intended to amend the Community Regulation of 29 May 2000 on insolvency procedures to improve the protection of creditors in the event of a company's insolvency being cross-border. In fact, 400,000 job losses in the EU are linked to cross-border business insolvency proceedings.  The idea is to create a "European culture" of "rescue and recovery" by giving a second chance to companies deemed robust but facing financial difficulties. However, it can be argued that corporate failures are also linked to the budgetary austerity introduced by Brussels. Moreover, while the intentions are laudable, these provisions still represent an attack on the national sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1346/2000 on insolvency proceedings is a technical report. The scope of the Regulation has extended to hybrid procedures and restructuring of undertakings. In order to avoid a forum of convenience, the additional three-month criterion of reflection period has been introduced by an amendment by the S&D Group. The Regulation also now allows the coordination of procedures for corporate groups.  The S&D Group also succeeded in including a recital on workers' rights: "Additional harmonisation measures must also introduce privileges for workers". Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 There was no vote because the document was accepted by jurisdiction.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings because it is complete and adequate but also for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech of 19/05/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that we got agreement on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. This text aims to protect creditors in the event of cross-border insolvency of a company. This text contains a positive point in that it assigns jurisdiction to the jurisdiction of the Member State in which the debtor company is based. However, it also undermines the sovereignty of States because it prevents creditors from opening secondary proceedings before the courts of its own State of origin, as long as the debtor owns property there. So I voted against that recommendation.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings. Efficient and effective procedures are needed for the proper functioning of the internal market, and to achieve this the provisions on jurisdiction, recognition and applicable law in this area should form part of a Union measure that is binding and directly applicable in the Member States.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the revision of the Regulation governing insolvency proceedings to be an important step towards modernising insolvency law. In particular, I believe that there is a need to increase the protection of employees who are most affected by the possible bankruptcy of their employer. Unfortunately, the risk of company bankruptcies is high nowadays, e.g. in the Czech Republic, the number of insolvency proposals has increased from 5,300 to more than 35,000 cases per year over the past 6 years. We therefore need a broader debate on how to protect companies from possible bankruptcy. I see another problem in the so-called insolvency tourism and the submission of bullying insolvency proposals in order to eliminate competition. As a result, companies that do not actually owe anyone anything can also enter the insolvency register. According to statistics, one in ten companies in the Czech Republic has encountered such a bullying insolvency proposal. Need not add that such a situation will seriously damage the company concerned. Although I support the attempt to modernise insolvency law, because I believe that this document does not guarantee sufficient protection for workers, I abstained in the vote.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support Parliament's position on the establishment of new rules on cross-border insolvency proceedings. It is important to adopt rules that give more scope to companies operating in several countries and going through problems, because that's how we're going to avoid bankruptcy. We are talking about some 50,000 companies facing cross-border insolvency proceedings each year, and up to 40,000 people who lose their jobs for this cause, which makes it urgent to act to bring this initiative forward.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The amendment to the European Union regulation on insolvency proceedings has already been voted on in committee and the text has been submitted to Parliament for first reading. However, I would like to point out that I would have voted in favour of the regulation, as the papers submitted by MEP Zwiefka would mean some important changes to insolvency proceedings.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Insolvency Regulation establishes a European framework for cross-border insolvency proceedings. It applies if a debtor, whether a natural or legal person, has assets or creditors in more than one Member State.  The regulation aims to put in place procedures to help debtors in serious financial difficulty, in order to help healthy businesses survive and to give entrepreneurs a second chance. It also helps to combat organized insolvency. The scope of this regulation was extended at second reading to secondary procedures (where liquidation is not necessary).  I vote for this text, regretting, however, that the definition of the actual headquarters of companies is not established in a precise way.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The aim of this amendment to the EU regulation dated 29 May 2000 is to protect creditors in the case of cross-border enterprises. The positive side of this text is that it assigns jurisdiction to the State in which the company has "the centre of its main interests" and thus provides that creditors seek the most favourable national jurisdiction. However, the creditor's ability to use the jurisdiction of his own state, as long as he owns property there, is ruled out. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal amends Council Regulation (EC) No 1346/2000 of 29 May 2000 on insolvency proceedings ('insolvency regulation' or 'Regulation'). The general objective of the revision of the Insolvency Regulation is to strengthen the efficiency of the European regulatory framework in resolving cross-border insolvency cases in order to ensure the smooth functioning of the internal market and its resilience during economic crises.  This objective is linked to current EU policies to promote economic recovery and sustainable growth, a higher investment rate and job preservation, as foreseen in the Europe 2020 strategy. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report on the updated regulation on insolvency as it will streamline cross-border insolvency proceedings amongst Member States. It is important to stress that it will not change national legislation but takes into account the changes that have occurred at the national level since 2002.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Council Regulation (EC) No 1346/2000 establishing a European framework for cross-border insolvency proceedings, which determines which Member State has jurisdiction for opening insolvency proceedings, establishes uniform rules on applicable law and provides for the recognition and enforcement of insolvency-related decisions as well as for the coordination of main and secondary insolvency.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This is about the wording of Council Regulation (EC) No 1346/2000 of 29 May 2000 on insolvency proceedings. The proper functioning of the internal market requires insolvency proceedings which produce cross-border effects to be carried out efficiently and effectively. These cases occur where the properties, lideities, among others, of the insolvent are located in more than one Member State, or even where the insolvent is subject to legal systems of several Member States.  Insolvency laws differ significantly between Member States. The existing Regulation does not standardise, harmonises on insolvency situations, but regulates conflicts between the legal systems of different Member States. I am voting in favour of this Recommendation, as I advocate the establishment of a cross-border insolvency proceedings procedure

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This recommendation aims to amend the EU regulation of 29 May 2000 on insolvency procedures to improve the protection of creditors in the event of a company's insolvency being cross-border. In fact, 400,000 job losses in the EU are linked to cross-border business insolvency proceedings. The idea is to create a "European culture" of "rescue and recovery" by giving a second chance to companies deemed robust but facing financial difficulties. However, it can be argued that corporate failures are also linked to the budgetary austerity introduced by Brussels. Moreover, while the intentions are laudable, these provisions still represent an attack on the national sovereignty of the Member States. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as the proposal largely seeks to improve functioning of the regulation. I am also proud that my S&D colleagues managed to get some amendments in aimed at improving the situation of employees and small creditors.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this purely technical report and welcome some political data. Firstly, the scope of insolvency proceedings has been broadened to include hybrid procedures and corporate restructuring. Furthermore, we believe it is important to emphasise that the current regulation introduces the possibility for business groups to proceed in a coordinated manner between companies by reducing costs and time for both the private and public sectors. We also recognise the efforts of the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs to insert a recital introducing for the future a clause protecting the interests and preferences of employees in cases of corporate insolvency.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the insolvency proceedings regulations must be clear. As it also appears in the text that this report supports, a number of EU-wide insolvency procedures are needed, especially when we are talking about the free market. In this context, the old regulations have been amended and amended to keep up with the latest contexts, leading to their vagueness and misinterpretation. In these circumstances, the text adopted today, which puts all these amendments into the agreement and makes improvements to the old procedures, was necessary in order to create clarity and predictability in the legislation.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. If the report had been a vote, I would have abstained, as it contains some positive aspects, such as encouraging the start of economic activities. At the same time, however, it expresses a certain laisser-faire in terms of financial responsibility, which I cannot support.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the pre-ōu. This is essentially the harmonisation of insolvency law in a situation where cross-border insolvency proceedings are a common occurrence. A common European framework is needed for the functioning of the EU internal market and to cope with economic crises.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. We consider that this Regulation does not sufficiently reflect EU priorities or current national practices in insolvency law. The current crisis and the high levels of unemployment, which affect more than 25% of the working population in Spain, have meant that hundreds of thousands of families have reached limit situations that, in many cases, do not allow them to meet their most basic needs. The consequences have been that many families have lost their home because they cannot cope with their debts. In this Regulation, moreover, we have tried to emphasize improving the deteriorating rescue mechanisms of struggling companies, which are often the only economic livelihood for thousands of people.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the position put forward, the non-planned changes will create better conditions for the protection of companies in financial difficulties and on the verge of bankruptcy. In particular, the new Regulation will help to address the problems in practice with regard to the conduct of insolvency proceedings involving persons from several Member States of the European Union. In addition, the abuse of the right in the search for a more favourable legal position will be prevented. Issues of the opening of main and secondary insolvency proceedings and the relationship between these cases, as well as questions on the publicity of information on insolvency proceedings and the exchange of information between courts and administrators will be dealt with more efficiently and expeditiously. The entry into force of the provisions of the proposal on mandatory cooperation between professionals in judicial and insolvency proceedings in main and secondary proceedings and in insolvency proceedings of group members of companies may increase the duration of insolvency proceedings, as well as increase the administrative costs of insolvency proceedings, but this is likely to lead to a better outcome of the insolvency proceedings.  It should be noted that the provisions of the proposal will improve economic, business and competitive conditions by enabling more efficient insolvency proceedings involving entities from several Member States of the European Union.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Council's position at first reading and the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee; I voted in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This text amends the Community Regulation of 29 May 2000 on insolvency proceedings. It aims to protect creditors in cases where a company's insolvency is cross-border. It has the merit of assigning jurisdiction to the courts of the Member State in which the debtor company has the centre of its main interests. The reality of the company's place of activity is thus used as a criterion for the attribution of jurisdiction, which allows the shopping forum to be excluded, i.e. the abusive search by cross-border debtors of the most favourable national jurisdiction. This text, however, fails to over-marginalize the creditor's ability to initiate secondary proceedings before the courts of his own state, as long as the debtor owns property there. Thus, it clearly undermines national sovereignty and it is therefore out of the question for me to support it. Despite the positive elements it contains, I therefore vote against defending the sovereignty of States.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. \u2012 I support colleague Zwiefka's report on the recasting of the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on insolvency proceedings accepting the Council's position at first reading, as it is in accordance with Article 294(7) of the EIA. Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, Article 76 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament and recommendations for the second reading of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 For the proper functioning of the internal market, cross-border insolvency procedures should take place efficiently and effectively. The activities of entrepreneurs are increasingly having cross-border effects and are increasingly governed by Union law for the same reason. At the same time, the insolvency of such undertakings affects the proper functioning of the internal market and there is a need for a Union act which would require the coordination of measures taken in relation to the assets of an insolvent debtor.  Therefore, bearing in mind that the proposed Insolvency Regulation aims to increase the efficiency of cross-border insolvency procedures in order to ensure the smooth functioning of the internal market and its resilience in economic crises, and that this objective is also in line with the European Union's current political priorities on promoting economic recovery and sustainable growth as well as higher investment rates and preserving employment , as stated in the Europe 2020 strategy, and on the protection of the development and survival of businesses, as set out in the Small Business Act, I supported this recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on insolvency proceedings.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to revamp the insolvency regulations. It is necessary to clarify European legislation and to have a common position on this issue.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This legislative resolution adopts the Council's first reading position with a view to adopting the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on insolvency proceedings. Cross-border insolvency occurs where the assets or liabilities of a debtor are situated in more than one State or where the debtor is subject to the jurisdiction of more than one Member State. The proposal for a Regulation at issue here amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1346/2000 of 29 May 2000 on insolvency proceedings aims to make insolvency proceedings more effective and effective in order to ensure the smooth functioning of the internal market and its resilience in situations of economic crisis.  To this end, it proposes, inter alia, the extension of the scope to debt adjustments and reorganisations; clarification of jurisdictional rules and the improvement of the procedural framework for determining jurisdiction; and the establishment of detailed rules on cooperation between courts and liquidators. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation aims to establish a set of procedures in order to improve efficiency in solving cross-border insolvency cases, while ensuring the fluidity of the internal market and resilience to economic crises. With increasing globalization and internationalization of enterprises, clarification of procedures is a priority.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the revision of this regulation which lays down common rules as regards the court competent to bring insolvency proceedings, applicable law and recognition of judgments in the event that a debtor – whether a company or a trade company or an individual – is in a situation of insolvency , because after ten years of its entry into force it was improveable in the application of some of its provisions. The main novelty it includes is to prevent the debtor from moving his assets or judicial proceedings from one country to another in order to improve his situation from the legal point of view forum of convenience, thus preventing some companies or debtors from suddenly changing their headquarters before the start of insolvency proceedings. It introduces greater legal certainty and allows consideration of whether the change of venue meets objective reasons or not. It has also been possible to include a recital concerning workers' rights in relation to the establishment of a preferential right for workers, taking into account that they are the weakest when insolvency proceedings are initiated.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Noting that the act was adopted in accordance with the Council's position, in voting this report, we instructed the President of Parliament to sign the act with the President of the Council, in accordance with Article 297, paragraph 1 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the presentation at second reading of the following text, which is concerned with insolvency proceedings. As early as December 2012, the Commission proposed a revision of the rules on cross-border insolvency, which are very different from one State to another, in order to make cross-border insolvency proceedings more effective and to improve the current regulation, which is limited to regulating conflicts between Member States, without unifying or harmonising insolvency laws.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. The result is a recast of the directive governing insolvency proceedings. The interest of workers is to hinder insolvency proceedings because they often mean that a company can close without facing its wage obligations. The directive is insufficient in this regard. That is why we would have abstained from voting.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to revise existing European regulation on transnational insolvency proceedings. From the perspective of workers, the final outcome of the negotiations is still insufficient: insolvency proceedings continue to over-protect debtors' interests with respect for the preservation of employment or in choosing the national framework in which the procedure should be opened. However, positive aspects such as better judicial and administrative control of insolvency proceedings should be recognized and that the maintenance of the activity is facilitated while the company restructures its activities and accounts. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the reform of the rules on cross-border insolvency, which broadens the scope of the bankruptcy proceedings regulation and clarifies the legal concept of the Centre of Main Interests (COMI).  These measures will serve to prevent abusive and opportunistic practices of law such as recourse to the courts and legislation of a milder country rather than to the one most competent to adjudicate on the dispute. In addition, the new framework specifies the relationship between main and secondary procedures and provides for all States to create public insolvency registers containing information relating to the procedure of insolvency proceedings, as well as to the creditor and the insolvent debtor.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ S&D MEPs voted in support of Council Regulation No 1346/2000 which determines which Member State has jurisdiction for opening insolvency proceedings, establishes uniform rules on applicable law and provides for the recognition and enforcement of insolvency—related decisions as well as for the coordination of main and secondary insolvency.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting a resolution at second reading on the Council's position with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings, taking into account the positive opinion of the ECR.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the rapporteur's legislative resolution approving the position of the Council for the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings. One of the key objectives of the proposed insolvency regulation is to move away from the traditional liquidation approach to access to a second chance for businesses and entrepreneurs in financial difficulties with regard to cross-border insolvency proceedings. The Council's position also contains new rules aimed at preventing the abuse of bargaining in the competent court. Also, in order to improve the provision of relevant and timely information to creditors and participating courts and to prevent the opening of parallel insolvency proceedings, the Regulation obliges Member States to set up insolvency registers. National registers will have to be linked and accessible through the European e-Justice portal in full compliance with European data protection legislation. The Regulation should also contain specific provisions on cooperation and communication between courts and insolvency practitioners involved in the insolvency of members of company groups.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour today on the revision of the regulation introducing new rules on insolvency proceedings at EU level and extending its scope. The aim of the review is to make cross-border insolvency proceedings more efficient and effective, to the benefit of debtors and creditors, to facilitate the survival of businesses and to give entrepreneurs a second chance. The new provisions will also ensure the consistency of the current insolvency regulation with the evolution of national insolvency legislation introduced after its entry into force in 2002. The data provided by the European Commission show that, in the European Union, these procedures affect some 200 000 companies every year; This means that 1.7 million jobs are at stake. As around a quarter of these insolvency proceedings have a cross-border element, it is clear that legislative action is needed at European level to improve the procedural framework in these cases.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the Council's position at first reading (16636/5/2014 - C8-0090/2015), the Opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee of 22 May 2013 and the recommendation for a second reading of the Committee on Legal Affairs (A8-0155/2015), I accept this recommendation for a second reading.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which improves the functioning of the European framework for cross-border insolvency proceedings.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I voted for this Council position at first reading to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on insolvency proceedings.  This Regulation aims to continue promoting a 'rescue culture' in the EU. The basic elements of this Regulation are the extension of the scope of the Regulation in order to cover "preventive" insolvency proceedings that are to save companies, but also to cover a wider range of personal insolvency proceedings. It also clarifies the criteria of legal jurisdiction and improves the procedural framework for assessing legal jurisdiction. The establishment of a system of tax insolvency registers will increase transparency for debtors. This Regulation increases the chances of saving companies by avoiding secondary proceedings if the interests of local creditors are guaranteed in another way, and provides a legal framework for coordinating the procedures of members of groups of companies. It is necessary to include an additional measure to combat the phenomenon in which consumers abuse the possibility of achieving a more favourable legal position by changing the legal jurisdiction.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because while it brings some minor changes that may increase the effectiveness of insolvency proceedings, the proposal also brings one significant change that can fundamentally reduce the responsible behaviour of debtors. This is a change in approach to insolvency proceedings, under which entrepreneurs may, under certain conditions, be given a 'second chance' to survive 'healthy firms'. However, this approach greatly increases moral hazard, as borrowers will be aware that they will not be fully responsible for their eventual default. Since such a 'second chance' must necessarily be granted to the detriment of the interests of creditors, it can be assumed that this will increase the prices of the loans, since the creditors will have to take into account the higher risk of losing money.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for a second reading on insolvency proceedings. In some insolvency cases, national insolvency legislation poses a major problem when it comes to cross-border activity and the related successful restructuring of insolvent companies.  Our concern must go towards the survival of healthy businesses, so we must look for solutions to effectively restructure over-indebtoring and insolvent companies. In this respect, we must bear in mind at all times the employees of such companies, who are not to blame for the insolvency of the company, but usually the latter pulls the shortest end when there is not enough money in the bankruptcy mass to pay down debts to employees. I welcome the court's ability to establish the centre of the debtor's main interests and that the place of the debtor's ordinary business is determined in such a way that it is the place where the debtor operates at least three months before the opening of insolvency proceedings or interim proceedings. The place will also be able to be verified by third parties.  Lengthy insolvency proceedings, which have been dragging on for years, are often unsuccessful, so it is very important to have the effective work of the insolvency administrators as well as to supervise the work of them.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for new rules on insolvency proceedings because I believe that this is a good example of useful EU legislation that helps to deal with cross-border situations, the number of which is increasing. First of all, I welcome the fact that the new rules have also focused on eliminating forum shopping and introducing an online database of ongoing cross-border procedures.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This position gives too many possibilities to companies that could take advantage of the law to avoid paying their obligations. However, we recognise that there should also be some kind of protection for small and medium-sized enterprises, contrary to the specific text that protects very large companies.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. This is an administrative measure orchestrated by MP Simon. So of course I voted in favour.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I voted to amend the Insolvency Procedure Regulation, which focuses attention on cross-border proceedings. The Regulation lays down new rules with a set of measures aimed at preventing abuse of office so that debtors who have become over-indebted, insolvent or illiquid for certain reasons provide themselves with a more favourable legal position. I therefore agree with the decision that Member States are required to present relevant data through the electronic register in cases of cross-border insolvency proceedings, which will improve transparency but also facilitate their implementation. However, as an MP from a country where there is a sad story with more than 19 000 companies that have achieved the conditions for initiating bankruptcy, I think we need to focus on measures that allow debtors to be restructured even at the stage where entities are indebted because of their inability to meet their overdue monetary obligations. The expediency of insolvency proceedings should be in the fair distribution of goods, but unfortunately we are witnessing different examples. Therefore, when creating measures, I believe that when creating measures, we need to find the best ways to enable companies to become solvent again and continue to operate, which is the ultimate goal of the insolvency proceedings themses.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. This regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. The result is a recast of the directive governing insolvency proceedings. The interest of workers is to hinder insolvency proceedings because they often mean that a company can close without facing its wage obligations. The directive is insufficient in this regard. That is why we would have abstained from voting.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of unifies the criterion to be used in the case of companies resulting from the crisis starting an insolvency process such as the creditor contest. But I have taken the opportunity to denounce that this second opportunity given to companies is not given to families and individuals who cannot take care of their mortgages and are forced to pay off all the debt and lose their home, which results in clear discrimination of treatment between companies and individuals.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to revise existing European regulation on transnational insolvency proceedings. From the perspective of workers, the final outcome of the negotiations is still insufficient: insolvency proceedings continue to over-protect debtors' interests with respect for the preservation of employment or in choosing the national framework in which the procedure should be opened. However, positive aspects such as better judicial and administrative control of insolvency proceedings should be recognized and that the maintenance of the activity is facilitated while the company restructures its activities and accounts. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the trilogue process.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report recasts the Insolvency Proceedings Regulation. The main objective is to revise Regulation 1346/2000 on transnational insolvencies. The Regulation under consideration applies to collective public insolvency proceedings, including interim proceedings, based on insolvency law and in which, for the purposes of recovery, debt adjustment, reorganisation or liquidation.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The amendment to the European Union regulation on insolvency proceedings has already been voted on in committee and the text has been submitted to Parliament for first reading. However, I would like to point out that I would have voted in favour of the regulation, as the papers submitted by MEP Zwiefka would mean some important changes to insolvency proceedings.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is to recast the Insolvency Proceedings Regulation. The main objective is to revise Regulation 1346/2000 on transnational insolvencies. This text is the result of negotiations with the Council. Since there has been no change of rejection, the President declared it approved. The Regulation under consideration applies to collective public insolvency proceedings, including interim proceedings, based on insolvency law and in which, for the purposes of recovery, debt adjustment, reorganisation or liquidation: the debtor is all or partly deprived of his assets; an insolvency practitioner is appointed; business shall be under the control and supervision of a court or a temporary suspension of enforcement proceedings is ordered. In cases where there is only a likelihood of insolvency, it has been decided in the negotiation that the purpose should be to prevent the debtor's bankruptcy or the cessation of his activity, which seems to us to be positive. As far as workers' claims are, nothing is changed and they are not recognised as credit privileges, which we consider to be negative.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I very much welcome the fact that we did actually postpone the final vote on conflict minerals and that it is going to trilogue. But I am deeply disappointed by the position adopted by the EPP and ECR groups on blocking mandatory due diligence across the supply chain for conflict minerals. They know as well as we do that we will be able to make sure the minerals in our smartphones, tablets and computers are not mined by men, women and children who are exploited like slaves in Third World mines only if all the operators involved, from A to Z, are covered by mandatory rules requiring them to check on the presence of conflict minerals in their supply chains.
