Otherwise, given that there are hardly any smelters or refiners in the EU, conflict minerals could continue to be sold to suppliers and manufacturers by smelters primarily based in China. The position of these groups is all the more difficult to understand knowing that the proposed rules do not entail a high price to be paid by companies. Due diligence obligations are tailored to the company’s individual circumstances, size, leverage and position in the supply chain. They do not entail bureaucracy, and our group, the S&D Group, has proposed that micro—enterprises be excluded from this regulation.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Mr President, Europe has a unique opportunity and a moral obligation to end trade in minerals obtained under conditions that violate human rights. We have to get rid of prejudice and ask companies. The good ones, the responsible ones, those who respect the rules are more than willing to join this chain of cleanliness, traceability and corporate social responsibility. It is essential to involve them in this joint effort so that they can make their best efforts of transparency and commitment. As representatives elected by European citizens, it is our obligation to act unequivocally and bluntly, not only on the treatment of minerals such as coltan, but on the entire production, distribution and supply chain. Dr. Mukwege, our Sakharov Prize, has not stopped claiming it. We owe him. If we do not act forcefully, Europe will be complicit in genuine barbarism.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, last year we gave several standing ovations to Dr Mukwege, our Sakharov Prize winner, for his tireless work to treat women and children. They are the real victims of the trade in conflict minerals. Dr Mukwege called for comprehensive and mandatory rules and from across this House we applauded his appeal. Today, we have followed through in our votes.  Voluntary due diligence has been shown to be inadequate, and a narrow focus only on smelters and refineries would only serve to undermine our EU foundation industries in the long term. We have voted for effective and mandatory rules that apply to all the key actors involved in the trade of minerals across the supply chain. I voted for the report today to show that we are willing to follow through on our applause in this Chamber with real action to improve human rights in conflict regions around the world.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Mr President, we all want to curtail opportunities for armed groups and break links between minerals and conflicts, but we have to do it sensibly. Unfortunately I cannot support this report because of the last-minute amendment that was pushed in to impose a mandatory – as opposed to voluntary – system. I support a voluntary system with mandatory due diligence, as the Committee on International Trade had proposed. A mandatory approach will fundamentally damage the economy of conflict-affected areas around the world – for example, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where mining is almost the only source of income in many areas. The Dodd-Frank Act in the USA showed the folly of a mandatory approach. It showed that it is virtually impossible to comply with such regulations, and companies in the US now avoid most of these areas completely. The end result is that very poor regions cannot sell their minerals at all or sell them to countries with no responsible sourcing schemes – completely undermining the whole idea of the legislation. This is bad legislation: it will not deal with the real issue and all it will do is penalise the poorest people in the world.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report concerning due diligence for conflict minerals as important amendments, such as amendments 154 and 155, were passed, supporting a meaningful obligatory system. The responsible sourcing by industry and business of minerals from conflict areas is of great importance given that the EU is one of the biggest markets for such minerals. The exports of these minerals by armed groups often finance continuing violence with terrible implications for human rights, as well as arresting development in the countries concerned. The Commission’s proposals did nothing meaningful to address and inform or to avoid importation of conflict minerals into the EU. Unfortunately, the committee proposals were not very ambitious, so I supported progressive, meaningful amendments for the obligatory system of due diligence that would apply to all levels of the supply chain, and that would include all conflict minerals.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. The Sakharov Prize winner of the year, Denis Mukwege, has reminded us of the enormous impact that the export of conflict minerals has on the people of his country. Since the problem is greatest in the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Great Lake region in particular, I, as shadow rapporteur for the EPP Group in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, have acted in favour of legislation that focuses on this area. The EPP line imposes mandatory legislation on refineries and importers. Virtually all the minerals purchased by EU companies go through these channels, and focusing on these links in the supply chain is an accurate measure that lays the foundation for companies to be able to exercise due diligence while safeguarding jobs and growth.  This, together with active EU support for regional initiatives for conflict-free mineral extraction, strengthens the conditions for legitimate activities and for breaking the link between mineral extraction and the financing of armed groups.  The fact that I am in favour of this approach is also due to the fact that there are several legislative proposals that have been shelved because of disagreementbetween Parliament and the Council. Almost all Member States support the Commission's line on voluntary self-certification. The fact that the European Parliament is taking a tougher stance than the Commission is a good thing, but constructive negotiations with the Member States are crucial for the legislation on conflict minerals to become a reality.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of establishing a mandatory system of traceability of minerals extracted in conflict-affected areas, because it is the only way to effectively combat the link between their marketing and the financing of violent armed organizations. To date, only 4% of the affected companies have opted for a voluntary certification system to ensure that the minerals they trade with and that we carry on our mobiles, computers and many other products that we use on a daily basis are not stained with blood. The European Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege, who has served nearly 40,000 women and girls in Congo, who have had to "recompose" for the atrocities to which they had been subjected by violent groups, and advocates for the mandatory certification system. Even so, the rapporteur, of the People's Group, has advocated voluntary regulation because he "respects and guarantees the functioning of markets and creates a viable framework for businesses". In the face of this, the Socialists defend "respect and guarantee of human rights and a viable framework for the dignity of people".

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The objective of this regulation should be to gain greater control of certain minerals or metals originating in conflict and high-risk areas, in order to prevent them from financing destabilization and violence in areas where, on the contrary, the presence of these materials should serve the sustainable and peaceful development of the local economy. Regulation has enormous shortcomings that call into question its usefulness: the number of materials to be accredited is unjustifiably restricted; import control is left to the companies themselves, who cannot be expected to declare their activities in conflict zones; it is not taken into account that most of these materials are processed before entering the European market, so most traffic is excluded from this legislation. That's why I voted against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amended proposal on conflict minerals. The proposal concerned minerals whose export profits are often used as a means of funding armed groups in the developing world, which fuels human rights violations, etc. The EU is one of the biggest markets for these materials. I voted in favour of a number of strong amendments from my political group GUE/NGL and other groups which aimed at getting the system of due diligence made mandatory and expanding the list of minerals included beyond the four proposed by the Commission. While not all of the amendments I supported were passed, amendments calling for the due diligence system to be made mandatory and applying it throughout the supply chain were adopted. For this reason I voted in favour of the amended proposal.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I welcome the Commission's proposal, which allows EU importers to further deepen their ongoing efforts to ensure clean supply chains in lawful trade with market participants in conflict zones, ultimately helping to curb the financing of armed groups and security forces through revenues from the minerals business in conflict zones. At the same time, however, I believe that this should go a step further, and I have therefore supported amendments that would oblige at least upstream companies to apply the OECD guidelines and to publish information on their due diligence in relation to responsible procurement.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This text aims to restrict and provide a precise framework for trade in minerals in areas of current or future war or violent conflicts. Many factual groups, terrorists or radical Islamists manage to obtain weapons and ammunition through the exploitation of these so-called "blood" minerals. This is particularly the case in the Great Lakes region of Africa. The Commission's proposal is not, in this case, satisfactory as it retains a self-certification mechanism for companies that would import metals into Europe. Parliament has required companies to verify that their supply chain is not corrupted by blood ores. This text, although animated by a laudable intention, is not satisfactory enough for me to vote for it. So I abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Too many amendments were passed on this issue which sought to impose an unacceptable regulatory burden on businesses. Insufficient account was taken of the ability for small businesses to comply with this legislation. For that reason, I felt that I had little choice but to vote against. I believe that there should indeed be tough legislation against the import of conflict minerals, but that legislation should be a) proportionate and b) determined by national parliaments.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this amended proposal because, with the adoption of this report, any European smelter and refinery and importer will now have to certify that their imported ores are clean and not from conflict zones. At the same time, European SMEs will receive financial assistance to establish traceability on these minerals and then be granted a conflict-free label.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is one of the biggest importers of minerals and metals originating in conflict areas. This means that trade of such minerals cannot be treated as an isolated issue but should be considered in the broader EU foreign and security policy context. Taking this fact into account, the EU should establish regulatory mechanisms in order to make sure that trade in such minerals will not result in financing of military groups or indirectly contribute to human rights violations in the countries of extraction. In the absence of such regulation, such trade subsequently undermines EU peacekeeping efforts and results in ineffectiveness of EU aid. Therefore, I am convinced that in order for ores and minerals to be sourced responsibly, the supply chain needs to be made more transparent. For this reason, I voted in favour of the EP resolution calling for mandatory compliance on implementing the OECD due diligence guidance on responsible sourcing of gold, tin, tantalum and tungsten originating in conflict—affected and high—risk areas.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to make trade in minerals from conflict zones more responsible. The EU is one of the largest markets for tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold, with more than 400 importers of these ores and metals. The new regulation establishes an EU framework for the approval of these importers who have chosen to import these metals into the EU responsibly. The claim requires eu importers of these metals to apply the due diligence principle by monitoring and managing their purchases and sales in accordance with the five phases of the OECD Due Diligence Guidance. The aim is to limit the ability of armed groups in conflict zones to finance their activities from tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold mining and trade. I agree with the need to oblige EU smelters and refiners to carry out independent audits assessing whether they are responsibly purchasing minerals. In order to increase the public ownership of smelters and refiners and the transparency of the supply chain and facilitate responsible mineral purchases, the EU should publish an annual list of responsible smelters and refiners in the EU and the world.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because it provides for the EU to certify European importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold; this will ensure that they do not fuel conflict and human rights violations in conflict zones. We also call on the Commission to provide micro and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) who wish to provide financial assistance for certification through the Commission's COSME programme (EU Programme for Business and SME Competitiveness). It is essential to guarantee all citizens decent working rights!

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation on conflict minerals was sent directly to the trialogue because a decisive majority was reached on some key amendments proposed by the Five Star Movement and the other groups. Amendments essential to make the proposal effective. The rapporteur's proposal was flawed, useless, ineffective and harmful to jobs in Europe, as well as detrimental to SMEs. It was a proposal born of that watered-down compromise which destroys rather than creates, it was a proposal written by the Commission for the use and consumption of multinationals and for the benefit of merchants of death. I have a message for the Commission: you have lost the battle! Parliament will now have to express a new position with the Council, and the rapporteur will have to understand that he does not have a majority for his proposal.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Written. 'Conflict minerals must be excluded from the European market. At the same time, it is necessary to prevent the local population from bearing the brunt of European legislation. That is why I support a self-certification system.  I would also like to stress that such legislation is not the solution, but merely a tool. The EU must work on the world stage to resolve conflicts and support governments in implementing the necessary reforms.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report concerns the European self-certification mechanism for importers of certain minerals and metals originating in conflict or high-risk areas. This text attempts to address the problem of minerals mined in conflict zones, illegally. Importers of these metals or minerals can obtain a responsible importer's certificate based on an OECD guide to the subject. The companies concerned must keep all traceability evidence that they do not buy from illegal mines. Checks are carried out by Member States each year and rules relating to infringements are made by states which can decide to withdraw the certificate of responsible importer. I abstained on this report to avoid the resale of minerals extracted in illegal areas while expressing reservations about the willingness of some to impose our European values in all countries of the world. I believe that the scope of the legislation should be broadened to include other metals and that much more coercive measures should be taken, particularly for marketing companies.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of establishing a mandatory system of traceability of minerals extracted in conflict-affected areas, because it is the only way to effectively combat the link between their marketing and the financing of violent armed organizations. To date, only 4% of the affected companies have opted for a voluntary certification system to ensure that the minerals they trade with and that we carry on our mobiles, computers and many other products that we use on a daily basis are not stained with blood. The European Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege, who has served nearly 40,000 women and girls in Congo, who have had to "recompose" for the atrocities to which they had been subjected by violent groups, and advocates for the mandatory certification system. Even so, the rapporteur, of the People's Group, has advocated voluntary regulation because he "respects and guarantees the functioning of markets and creates a viable framework for businesses". In the face of this, the Socialists defend "respect and guarantee of human rights and a viable framework for the dignity of people".

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which states that on 5 March 2014 the European Commission presented a legislative proposal aimed at limiting the ability of armed groups in conflict and high-risk areas to finance their activities through mineral mining and trade. The main objective of the proposal is to facilitate the acquisition of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold in a responsible way and to promote channels of legitimate trade. The Commission proposes a draft regulation (also in response to Parliament's resolutions) establishing an EU framework for the approval of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold importers who have chosen to import these metals into the Union responsibly. The EU importers are given the opportunity to carry out more in-depth current activities aimed at ensuring the cleanliness of supply chains for legitimate trade with economic operators in conflict-affected countries. In order to increase the public ownership of smelters and refiners and the transparency of the supply chain and facilitate responsible mineral purchases, the EU aims to publish an annual list of responsible smelters and refiners in the EU and the world.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. Regulation of the trade in minerals, which represent the greatest natural wealth of poor African countries, is essential. It is disappointing that the people of these countries have very little of this wealth, at most even more suffering from the consequences of its unfair exploitation. On the one hand, we have such appalling exploitation of children, women and men, on the other hand, the millions of profits of traffickers and smugglers with minerals that pass into the hands of corrupt groups and paramilitary militias. Denis Mukwege also drew attention to these atrocities.  Given that the EU is one of the largest importers of minerals, taking measures to limit unfair trade and divert profits from this trade is the first step towards recovering one of the most dangerous diseases that is in the African continent. The consequences of this disease are armed conflict and terrorism, poverty, famine and, last but not least, millions of refugees.  I believe that the regulation of the area of trade in minerals is by far the largest development aid that can be offered to African countries. This is the basis for the profits of this trade to remain in the country and to devote themselves to development, education, etc. I was pleased to support the proposed regulation introducing certification schemes in the mineral supply chain to improve their traceability.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Marie Arena's proposal to introduce control throughout the process of sourcing and importing raw materials from war zones. Consumers need to know that when buying, for example, a mobile phone, they do not finance a war conflict.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amended proposal on conflict minerals. The proposal concerned minerals whose export profits are often used as a means of funding armed groups in the developing world, which fuels human rights violations, etc. The EU is one of the biggest markets for these materials. I voted in favour of a number of strong amendments from my political group GUE/NGL and other groups which aimed at getting the system of due diligence made mandatory and expanding the list of minerals included beyond the four proposed by the Commission. While not all of the amendments I supported were passed, amendments calling for the due diligence system to be made mandatory and applying it throughout the supply chain were adopted. For this reason I voted in favour of the amended proposal.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Zimbabwe, the Central African Republic, Colombia, Burma and other countries, minerals are mined under the control of warlords who exploit local populations and place them in conditions of slavery to finance themselves with their trade. In the last 40 years, 60% of the conflicts in the so-called 'developing' countries have been linked to the trade in natural resources, allowing the financing of armed groups guilty of violence against the local population. In the Democratic Republic of Congo alone, conflicts linked to the mineral trade have caused 3.5 million deaths, more than half a million rapes and an unspecified number of violence of all kinds since 1995. More deaths, more violence, more rapes will follow if we don't do something. We Europeans account for 35% of world trade and we are major importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold, which is why we have a responsibility not to look the other way. We can and must vote in favour of a binding regulation that requires the public traceability of minerals imported into Europe from the point of purchase: the fate of millions of men, women and children depends on our decisions. Let's all vote on it together.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The financial crisis that hit the economic sectors of developed countries to the full has exposed the vulnerability of financial mechanisms and brought mineral resources back to the attention as a potential development factor. Whether it's precious metals or minerals and rare metals, essential in the technological process, they arouse heated debate and lead to conflict. The technological momentum recorded in recent times and the horizontal expansion of the use of technology has, by implication, increased demand for mineral resources. There are very large interests behind the companies involved in the extraction of ores, and the vulnerability of the authorities in resource-rich areas creates premises for escalating conflicts and flagrantly violates human rights. Perhaps it should not be ignored that, if in the past communication channels were limited, we are facing a novel phenomenon today due to the increasing access to the virtual environment, which, through the rapidity and avalanche of information, contributes significantly to the intensification and perpetuation of conflicts. I believe that we need a regulated and transparent framework on responsible mineral supply in the EU that ensures both the traceability of ores and the fact that financial resources do not pursue risk-factor destinations in escalating conflicts.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Writing. – A binding system of control of origin of minerals and metals from conflict zones is urgently needed for reasons of human rights and the prevention of violence, war, persecution and corruption. I believe that the PPE-DE Group's approach of finding a realistic and feasible start to this is the right one.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained. While we understand the reasons behind the measure, it is not with regulations such as these that we can hope to eradicate violence, illicit trafficking or the financing of terrorist groups in conflict areas such as congo, for example. There is no doubt that any mandatory limits or certifications for European companies will not stop Chinese companies which, on the contrary, will only enter the African mineral resources market further.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of establishing a mandatory system of traceability of minerals extracted in conflict-affected areas, because it is the only way to effectively combat the link between their marketing and the financing of violent armed organizations. To date, only 4% of the affected companies have opted for a voluntary certification system to ensure that the minerals they trade with and that we carry on our mobiles, computers and many other products that we use on a daily basis are not stained with blood. The European Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege, who has served nearly 40,000 women and girls in Congo, who have had to "recompose" for the atrocities to which they had been subjected by violent groups, and advocates for the mandatory certification system. Even so, the rapporteur, of the People's Group, has advocated voluntary regulation because he "respects and guarantees the functioning of markets and creates a viable framework for businesses". In the face of this, the Socialists defend "respect and guarantee of human rights and a viable framework for the dignity of people".

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report to call for importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold for the production of consumer goods to be obliged to receive EU certification in order to ensure that they do not fuel conflicts and human rights violations in war zones.  I also voted in favour of an amendment to the European Commission's proposal introducing compulsory traceability for the 800 000 EU companies using tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold, which are present in many consumer products in Europe, particularly in the automotive, electronics, aerospace, packaging, construction, lighting, industrial machinery, as well as in jewellery. Finally, since metal sme foundries and gold refineries are the last stage in which the origin of minerals can actually be traced, they must be subject to a mandatory audit, carried out by third parties and independent parties, to check whether they apply the 'duty of care' rules designed to help companies in the sector not to fuel conflicts and human rights violations in war zones.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal from the Commission was concerned with the responsible sourcing of certain minerals by companies in the EU from conflict areas. However, there were a number of problematic provisions in the proposal. A primary concern being that due diligence should be applied throughout the complete supply chain and not just to smelters and refiners. However, as amendments which were tabled in order to strengthen this proposal were passed in the vote, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 In plenary, we were able to vote on an important amendment which aims to make it compulsory for every person in the precious metal and mineral processing chain to ensure that they are not tainted by human rights violations that often occur in the relevant supply chain. Given the importance of the amendment, it was decided to refer the text back to the trialogue, but I am delighted to have contributed to Parliament's position in defence of human rights.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of a report which, in my view, lays the foundations for an effective and realistic system and puts an end to the financing of conflicts by the exploitation of conflict minerals by the belligerents.  By making the traceability of minerals mandatory for key players in the sector, we ensure the cleanliness of imported minerals. The support that will be provided to European SMEs in the implementation of this traceability makes this gradual approach operational. The granting of the conflict-free label must be the consecration of a transparent and peaceful system. In three years' time, it will be time to assess the functioning of this system and, why not, to increase the obligations and the number of minerals affected by this legislation if the applicability of the process is demonstrated.  For the time being, we can be congratulated for having opted for an ambitious line that is a great step forward in the prevention of armed conflicts related to minerals.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ We must have stronger mechanisms that support the respect of human rights and business transparency in the areas where minerals are extracted. To truly change things on the ground, we need a system that will work in practice. This is why I supported a mandatory due diligence system for all smelters, refiners and importers of minerals, because it can realistically be implemented and hit hard where it matters. It is, however, simply not feasible to include a mandatory approach to all downstream companies in the supply chain. These companies would struggle to obtain the information from all their different suppliers, and it will be the SMEs that will mostly be penalised. If this mandatory system for all actually could work in practice, then it would have my full support. But as we have seen with the US example of Dodd-Frank, going further in legislation does not always mean we get the desired results.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report, which provides for the establishment of a mechanism for self-certification of importers of certain minerals and metals originating in conflict zones or high risk.  Of course, this procedure will limit as much as possible what is commonly called the trafficking of blood diamonds, or other precious metals acquired illegally or violently. The European mechanism would be based on OECD standards for metal importers to obtain a responsible importer certificate, particularly if they meet due diligence obligations in relation to their supply chain. The traceability of imported metals should thereby be guaranteed and the activities of the importer verified by a third-party importing body, and Member States will be responsible for verifying the application of the regulations and, if necessary, taking corrective action to a found infringement. However, the measures as envisaged in the text will lead to unilateral sanctions against European companies by increasing the costs of processing certain metals, even though competing companies, particularly in Asia, will certainly not have to submit to such constraints.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Today the European Parliament has shown that promotion and protection of human rights sits at the top of the agenda. Thanks to the approval of the proposed legislation on conflict minerals, the EU will endeavour to break the links between the trade and extraction of minerals, and the financing of armed conflicts. Moreover, this proposed legislation will not just be about banning imports from conflict-affected areas, but also about creating a European market for responsibly—traded minerals sourced from conflict regions. We believe that the entire supply chain should be covered and follow internationally agreed ‘due diligence’. In other words: a system of checks and reporting. Lastly, we believe that every citizen in Europe should be sure that what they buy is not financing conflicts and human rights abuses.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Breaking the link between mineral extraction and trade and the financing of armed conflicts is the aim of a European Parliament report drafted by Iuliu Winkler MEP on self-certification of importers of minerals and metals originating in conflict-affected and high-risk areas.  We need a regulation which can be put in place soon and helps the people in the relevant conflict regions. We must prevent jeopardising small mines because of unrealistic legislation and that the local people are then unintentionally pushed into unemployment, smuggling or illegal activities.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the labelling of conflict substances. With a binding system of origin control and mandatory transparency rules for conflict minerals, we want to end the link between mineral extraction and trade and the financing of armed conflicts. We also want to focus on the people in the conflict regions. I am sure that the existing mineral resources represent significant development potential for Africa. New European legislation must not lead to further conflicts and violence in Africa.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The need to break the link between trade in certain minerals and the financing of armed conflicts is linked to the need to preserve and develop a responsible European market. From this point of view, I believe it is important to establish a system of self-certification for importers, thanks to which due diligence obligations can be fully respected. At the same time, I believe that we should not underestimate the impact of the burden of transparency and self-certification, which could lead operators to abandon areas of conflict and weaken their objectives of socio-economic development.  Therefore, in the hope of reaching broad political agreement, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The main objective of this proposal is to help reduce the financing of armed groups and security forces through mineral proceeds in conflict-affected and high-risk areas by supporting and further promoting responsible sourcing practices of EU companies in relation to tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold originating from such areas. The proposal builds on existing international due diligence frameworks and principles. The EU is a major importer of these minerals and metals, and thus this regulation is likely to have an important impact on trade flows. As some important elements of the proposal which could have guaranteed the system being voluntary and concentrate on the upstream process have been rejected, I abstained.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 On 5 March 2014, the Commission presented a legislative proposal aimed at making it more difficult for armed groups in conflict and high-risk areas to finance their activities through the extraction and trade of minerals. Central to this approach is to make it easier for companies to obtain tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold responsibly and to encourage the use of legal commercial channels. I could only vote in favour of this report, as we must make those involved in one way or another responsible for the use of conflict minerals. To this end, it is necessary that all those involved in the processing and marketing of these products ensure the traceability of these minerals (tin, tantalum, tungsten, gold). By voting in favour, I intend to make my contribution in order to make accountable not only all the actors involved in the import, but also the natural or legal persons involved in consumption and sale.  The mandatory nature of these transparency and certification measures throughout the production chain is essential for our battle for the protection of social and environmental rights/obligations.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – The objective of this regulation should be to gain greater control of certain minerals or metals originating in conflict and high-risk areas, in order to prevent them from financing destabilization and violence in areas where, on the contrary, the presence of these materials should serve the sustainable and peaceful development of the local economy. Regulation has enormous shortcomings that call into question its usefulness: the number of materials to be accredited is unjustifiably restricted; import control is left to the companies themselves, who cannot be expected to declare their activities in conflict zones; it is not taken into account that most of these materials are processed before entering the European market, so most traffic is excluded from this legislation. That's why I voted against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 In conflict-torn parts of the world, the exploitation and trade in natural resources allows armed groups, often guilty of human rights violations against populations, to finance themselves. To remain helpy or pretend not to see is a crime that Europe cannot allow or tolerate. Just as a stump and limited initiative, almost a testimony, was not tolerable in the face of a huge problem with multiple implications.  That is why, in accepting the invitation that has been forwarded to us from different worlds, as Socialists&Democrats we have strongly supported the need to broaden the spectrum of enforcement, introducing a mandatory regulation that applies to companies at all levels of the mineral and metal supply chain. This is not our victory: such a dramatic subject cannot count winners or losers. However, we are pleased that our obstinacy has opened the eyes of many and, by subverting the committee's vote, has made it possible to introduce a criterion which we believe can reduce the livelihoods and funding of the warlords who have been scientifically bloodied large parts of the world for years, in order to make them unstable and to be able to build their criminal empires more easily.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I think it is important to make progress in establishing an EU system of self-attrusion for minerals from conflict-affected areas, while making originalisation mandatory in the more advanced stages of the production chain would impose an excessive economic and administrative burden on European medium and small enterprises. I support the idea of strengthening control mechanisms in the countries of origin of minerals that contribute to a fair distribution of the system's resources. The aim of the European system should be to create a balanced regulation that promotes sustainable development in the countries of origin surrounded by armed conflicts, without having economic effects similar to embargoes.  In view of the fact that the Plenum of the European Parliament did not fully share the principles represented by the PP group in judging the key issues, I abstained on the final vote in order to ensure that the dialogue could continue in interinstitutional consultation.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of excluding conflict minerals from the EU market, both as raw materials and as manufactured products. I am in favour of a legally binding scheme to ensure traceability of tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold and to make sure that products sold in the EU should never fuel armed militias or foster human rights violations in conflict areas. This vote proves that the European Union cares about human rights and human dignity beyond empty declarations.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted strongly in favour of the proposal for a regulation establishing a European system of self-certification of the exercise of due diligence in the supply chain for importers responsible for tin, tungsten, tantalum, their minerals and gold, originating in conflict and high-risk areas.  With today's vote, we have, in fact, achieved the great objective of significantly increasing the traceability of these minerals and metals. We must, however, continue to fight for this Parliament to adopt an ambitious and effective proposal which will help, on the one hand, to break the unacceptable link between the extraction and trade in these resources and the financing of armed groups and, on the other hand, to take account of the effective ability of the various operators to monitor and assess possible risks along their supply chain, avoiding excessive bureaucratic burdens. , in particular for SMEs and micro-enterprises.  I also believe that we will only be able to achieve significant results from this proposal for a regulation if we are able to place it within the broader framework of a coherent European cooperation policy.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to set up a European self-certification mechanism for importers of certain minerals in order to break the link between mineral extraction and trade on the one hand and the financing of armed conflicts on the other. The report also aims to support the development of a European market for responsiblely mined minerals from conflict zones and improve the ability of operators throughout the supply chain to comply with due diligence. Considering that in such a complex case it was necessary to propose a fair and realistic system to achieve the intended objectives, I decided to support the establishment of a mandatory system upstream of the chain concerning importers of minerals and smelters and refineries, and a voluntary system downstream for small and medium-sized enterprises. Supporting the objectives of this report but considering that the plenary vote in favour of a binding system of traceability and certification on the entire supply chain, i.e. more than 880,000 companies, will be difficult to implement, I have decided not to block the forthesty discussions with the Council and I have therefore abstained on this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. By voting on this text, we have taken an important step in the European Parliament on the importation of minerals from areas of armed conflict. I voted for a binding approach for all companies that produce, import and process tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold. This obligation of transparency must enable the European Union to stop financing, in spite of itself, through the purchase of minerals, conflicts and human rights violations, particularly in Africa. Parliament can now negotiate with the Council with a strong and ambitious position. Despite the administrative burden that may weigh on European businesses as a result of our vote, I remain convinced that only an ambitious regulation lives up to our values. The European Union now has the opportunity to be a global pioneer in terms of transparency and social responsibility in its trade relations with conflict zones.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that a stricter approach to conflict minerals is needed. It must not be the case that the minerals that end up in our household appliances are used to finance conflicts, resulting in immeasurable human suffering. At the same time, I am pleased that we have been able to do this in a way that is effective and at the same time feasible for our – often smaller – companies, without losing ourselves in a tangle of rules and administration.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation aims to establish a European system of self-certification of the exercise of due diligence for European importers of tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold. I voted in favour of this proposal because it aims to help break the link between the extraction and trade in minerals from conflict or high-risk areas and the financing of armed groups that control the extraction areas.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. We all have a common goal: to break the link between mining and armed conflict. For us, traceability must be mandatory for all key players in the sector. With the vote of the European Parliament, any smelter, european refinery and importer will now have to certify that their imported ores are clean and not from conflict zones. At the same time, European SMEs will receive financial assistance to establish traceability on these minerals and then be granted a conflict-free label. After three years, we have an appointment clause. We will be able to take stock of this regulation, assess very concretely what has worked and what has not worked. The Commission will then be able to increase obligations, and we will also be able to expand the number of minerals that are affected by this legislation. This European legislation can then serve as a model to create positive momentum in other parts of the world. Parliament must now negotiate with the Council in a trilogue on the basis of the amendments adopted for a compromise at first reading.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I abstained on the final vote because the text adopted in plenary does not seem realistic to me, but I did not want to block it by a negative vote since I fully share the main objective, which is to break the financing of armed groups through the trade of these four minerals originating in conflict zones or high risk. I fear that what has been voted is difficult to apply because more than 800,000 companies (multinationals as SMEs) are being asked to set up a binding system involving, among other things, the conduct of audits. I therefore wished, through my votes on the amendments, to support a realistic and progressive approach that went beyond the Commission's proposal. I wanted to set up a mandatory system upstream of the chain (importers of minerals and foundries/refineries) and voluntary downstream (companies) with the establishment of a label. This approach allowed first the accountability of the actors and, secondly, through the revision of the regulation, a strengthening of the prepared and therefore applicable measures.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that the plenum did not fully share the principles of the Hungarian People's Party Group and the EPP in the assessment of key issues, I had no choice but to abstain in the final vote in order to ensure that the dialogue could continue in interinstitutional consultation. Making originalification mandatory in the more advanced stages of the production chain would impose an excessive economic and administrative burden on European medium and small enterprises, while strengthening control mechanisms in the countries of origin of minerals that contribute to a fair allocation of system resources. My aim is therefore to create a balanced regulation that promotes sustainable development in the countries of origin surrounded by armed conflicts, without having economic effects similar to embargoes.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I am particularly pleased with the European Parliament's ambitious vote in favour of an obligation to trace the supply chain and processing of minerals and metals, whose exploitation is a major issue in conflict zones. All European companies involved in the import, processing and marketing of these minerals and metals, including those upstream, will need to be transparent and provide information on the measures they are taking to identify and address risks in their supply chains. Those downstream will have to disclose the source of their supply. This decisive step was made thanks to the vote of the amendments tabled by Louis Michel, myself and a few other Members. This vote will, I hope, stop the financing of wars and rebellions through the exploitation of blood ores. I am now waiting for the Council to take its responsibilities during the trilogue that will begin in the coming days.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – In view of the fact that the plenum did not fully share the principles represented by the Hungarian PpE group and the EPP in judging the key issues, I had no choice but to abstain in the final vote in order to ensure that the dialogue could continue in the interinstitutional consultation.  Making originalification mandatory in the more advanced stages of the production chain would impose an excessive economic and administrative burden on European medium and small enterprises, while strengthening control mechanisms in the countries of origin of minerals that contribute to a fair allocation of system resources. My aim is therefore to create a balanced regulation that promotes sustainable development in the countries of origin surrounded by armed conflicts, without having economic effects similar to embargoes.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ It is absolutely right that action be taken to ensure that the EU supply chain is both protected and regulated in terms of the trade of conflict minerals – which has been proven to fuel criminality and which devastates local communities in war-torn parts of Africa and South America. As with all legislation, however, there is a balance to be struck. Despite supporting the overarching premise of transparency, I believe it is vital to ensure that reputable firms with long-standing economic benefits are treated fairly and not put under undue regulatory burdens in order to fulfil these requirements. This I feel was the most consistent and proportionate basis upon which to approach this report. What is needed now is a rigorous review process, in order to safeguard businesses from disproportionate burdens, as well as clear and tangible efforts to ensure that smaller enterprises that stand to be affected have access to funding through relevant EU programmes to tackle the cost of gaining certification.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The main objective of this proposal is to help reduce the financing of armed groups and security forces through mineral proceeds in conflict-affected and high-risk areas by supporting and further promoting responsible sourcing practices of EU companies in relation to tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold originating from such areas. Such importers of minerals or metals within the scope of the regulation may self-certify as responsible importers by declaring to a Member State competent authority that they adhere to the supply chain due diligence obligations set out in the regulation. The declaration shall contain documentation in which the importer confirms its adherence to the obligations, including results of the independent third-party audits carried out. Following the vote in the INTA Committee, the proposal was amended to make such efforts at due diligence a mandatory legal obligation for smelters and refiners which import such minerals into the EU.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 It is very important that we as the European Parliament send a strong message to armed terrorist groups.  Most of their financial sources are related to mines or mineral commercial activities. If we want to stop them, we must make it impossible for them to finance through these highly profitable markets. Let's not forget that we are more than ever directly affected by this problem.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against this proposal because we consider it unrealistic and unworkable. It is out of the question that the Commission is calling for these metals to be identified at all times and in their constantly changing forms in order to enforce 'social justice'. If the EU wants to stop supporting mines and businesses that are not "politically correct" or because they are in war zones it can do so with economic measures as it did, wrongly, in the case of Russia. Billions will be spent without predictable results and in the end the only result that will be certain is that we will take another step towards globalisation.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the aim of a more effective way for the EU to counter the financing of armed groups in conflict zones, one of the forms of which is to finance their activities through mineral mining and trade. Therefore, let us offer alternative solutions for the purchase of significant minerals, such as mainly gold, but also tin, tantalam and tungsten, which can be obtained easily and legally. The proposed voluntary self-self-management system could be a good tool for importers who choose to carry out this activity responsibly. With this legislation, the UNION contributes to international efforts to address the problems of resource-rich but armed conflict-prone countries, such as the Great Lakes region of Africa. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the legislative proposal.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of the proposal by the Greens/EFA Group to make the legislation stronger, and welcome the support of Parliament for this. A strong and comprehensive legislative response was needed. My constituents in Wales demanded no less.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 Conflict minerals are minerals extracted in conflict zones and whose trade subsidises armed groups, murders and abominations of all kinds. There are four elements considered: gold, tungsten, tantalum and tin, all of which are essential for the manufacture of technological products. The report defines the conditions necessary to be certified as "responsible importers" of the minerals and metals covered. It is based on a due diligence regime that allows EU importers to apply the principles and measures defined by the OECD and, therefore, to counter the risk of funding armed groups and security forces and to reduce any other negative effects, including any serious violations associated with the extraction, transport or trade of the minerals in question.  The M5S believes that there is a balance in order not to burden SMEs, already battered by the economic crisis, while protecting human rights. In the votes in plenary, the mandatory nature proposed by the M5S prevailed, both in the upstream and in the downstream, and this led to my vote in favour of the entire Commission proposal as amended in plenary.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 It is important that importers are forced to report that the mining of minerals does not finance armed conflicts, but this control must be carried out in a practicable way. My line in this vote was therefore to support tough demands while avoiding placing a heavy administrative burden on every single entrepreneur in Europe who sells goods with minerals.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft resolution establishes a system of self-certification, within the framework of the duty of diligence in the supply chains of importers of tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold from conflict and high-risk areas, thereby reducing the illegal financing of armies and other armed groups in conflict areas. The draft Regulation gives European importers the possibility to strengthen their efforts to ensure transparent supply chains when they legitimately trade with companies and other actors in conflict countries. To increase accountability, improve the transparency of its supply chains and facilitate responsible procurement, the EU intends to publish annual lists of responsible companies. With more than 400 importers, the EU is among the largest markets for tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of establishing a mandatory system of traceability of minerals extracted in conflict-affected areas, because it is the only way to effectively combat the link between their marketing and the financing of violent armed organizations. To date, only 4% of the affected companies have opted for a voluntary certification system to ensure that the minerals they trade with and that we carry on our mobiles, computers and many other products that we use on a daily basis are not stained with blood. The European Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege, who has served nearly 40,000 women and girls in Congo, who have had to "recompose" for the atrocities to which they had been subjected by violent groups, and advocates for the mandatory certification system. Even so, the rapporteur, of the People's Group, has advocated voluntary regulation because he "respects and guarantees the functioning of markets and creates a viable framework for businesses". In the face of this, the Socialists defend "respect and guarantee of human rights and a viable framework for the dignity of people".

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The persistent scarcity of raw materials globally is at the root of many internal, regional conflicts, crimes against humanity, interference, permanent violations of their sovereignty and territorial integrity of states, almost always with the complicity of international organizations and foreign powers – interested in maintaining control of resources.  Despite the obvious limits of such mechanisms, we accept that it is appropriate to discuss mechanisms for certifying importers of minerals from conflict and high-risk areas, creating traceability mechanisms to identify raw materials originating in these areas. The original proposal only covered a part of the minerals marketed and did not go beyond the first link in the value chain, deliberately forgetting the myriad of final and intermediate products where these raw materials are incorporated. A proposed amendment adopted during the vote (against the position of the right of parliament and the European Commission) has opposed these limitations, extending the range of raw materials contemplated and covering other links in the value chain, which are also subject to traceability rules, thus eliminating an ineffective and perverse nature of the original proposal. Although other limitations remain, we voted in favour, valuing these changes.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important that the European Union, by all means available, attempt to limit the financing of armed groups through the extraction and sale of mineral resources in conflict areas. Since this proposal, the European Commission is promising that importers of specific metals into the European Union will prevent damage at the bottom of the chain by monitoring and managing their purchases and sales in line with OECD guidelines. It is very important that the European Union targets all societies around the world and not just a small group in a certain area. The European Union must cooperate with responsible businesses and promote legitimate trade.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report as I consider it unrealistic and unworkable. It is out of the question that the Commission is calling for these metals to be identified at all times and in their constantly changing forms in order to enforce 'social justice'. If the EU wants to stop supporting mines and businesses that are not "politically correct" or because they are in war zones, it can do so with economic measures as it did, wrongly, in the case of Russia. Billions will be spent without predictable results and in the end the only sure result will be that we will take another step towards globalisation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe voluntary provisions, concerning only a simple link on the supply chain, are not enough to prevent the spread of conflicts. Mandatory transparency requirements for the entire chain would make the real difference.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that the plenum did not fully share the principles of the Hungarian People's Party Group and the EPP in the assessment of key issues, I had no choice but to abstain in the final vote in order to ensure that the dialogue could continue in interinstitutional consultation.  Making originalification mandatory in the more advanced stages of the production chain would impose an excessive economic and administrative burden on European medium and small enterprises, while strengthening control mechanisms in the countries of origin of minerals that contribute to a fair allocation of system resources. My aim is therefore to create a balanced regulation that promotes sustainable development in the countries of origin surrounded by armed conflicts, without having economic effects similar to embargoes.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that the plenum did not fully share the principles of the Hungarian People's Party Group and the EPP in the assessment of key issues, I had no choice but to abstain in the final vote in order to ensure that the dialogue could continue in interinstitutional consultation. Making originalification mandatory in the more advanced stages of the production chain would impose an excessive economic and administrative burden on European medium and small enterprises, while strengthening control mechanisms in the countries of origin of minerals that contribute to a fair allocation of system resources. My aim is therefore to create a balanced regulation that promotes sustainable development in the countries of origin surrounded by armed conflicts, without having economic effects similar to embargoes.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. One of our foreign policy priorities at European level should be to prevent armed groups in conflict and high-risk areas from accessing funding for their activities through mineral mining and trade. It is our obligation to promote legitimate trade channels and prevent illegal and immoral trade in these minerals. Considerable progress has been made in this area in recent years, but action must still be taken at the international level to address problems in resource-rich countries, but vulnerable to armed conflict. Without belittling the importance these minerals have in the economy of exporting countries, we must regulate in the most precise and rigorous way to ensure that any material reached in the EU comes from trade in line with European values. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of establishing a mandatory system of traceability of minerals extracted in conflict-affected areas, because it is the only way to effectively combat the link between their marketing and the financing of violent armed organizations. To date, only 4% of the affected companies have opted for a voluntary certification system to ensure that the minerals they trade with and that we carry on our mobiles, computers and many other products that we use on a daily basis are not stained with blood. The European Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege, who has served nearly 40,000 women and girls in Congo, who have had to "recompose" for the atrocities to which they had been subjected by violent groups, and advocates for the mandatory certification system. Even so, the rapporteur, of the People's Group, has advocated voluntary regulation because he "respects and guarantees the functioning of markets and creates a viable framework for businesses". In the face of this, the Socialists defend "respect and guarantee of human rights and a viable framework for the dignity of people".

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of establishing a mandatory system of traceability of minerals extracted in conflict-affected areas, because it is the only way to effectively combat the link between their marketing and the financing of violent armed organizations. To date, only 4% of affected companies have embraced a "voluntary" certification system to ensure that the minerals they trade with and that we carry on our mobiles, computers and many other products that we use on a daily basis are not stained with blood. The European Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege, who has served nearly 40,000 women and girls in Congo, who have had to "recompose" for the atrocities to which they had been subjected by violent groups, and advocates for the mandatory certification system. Even so, the rapporteur, of the People's Group, has advocated voluntary regulation because he "respects and guarantees the functioning of markets and creates a viable framework for businesses". In the face of this, the Socialists defend "respect and guarantee of human rights and a viable framework for the dignity of people".

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ Armed conflict, particularly over natural resources, has practically condemned much of Sub-Saharan Africa to poverty and violence. By reducing EU demand for conflict minerals, the incidents of armed militants fighting over natural resources should be diminished. I believe in taking the strictest possible measures to limit funding to armed groups in conflict zones. These proposals will ensure that corporations incorporate due diligence in provenance in the future.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I abstained on the European mechanism for self-certification of importers of certain minerals and metals from conflict zones. I am of course in favour of the non-use of minerals mined in conflict zones in order to finance the belligerents. This is particularly the case in the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Great Lakes region. Europe accounts for 35% of the world's trade in the minerals concerned (gold, tin, tantalum, tungsten). Nearly 900,000 companies, including many SMEs, are involved in this trade. Under the mechanism presented by the European Commission, importers of these metals themselves create certificates from responsible importers, i.e. self-certifications.  However, the mechanism, as amended by the European Parliament, should require European companies to get involved to ensure that their supply chain is not corrupted by "blood minerals". This is therefore good news, but it is not yet the final agreement on legislation and it remains clear that this mechanism is essentially based on the goodwill of importers.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour colleagues, voted in favour of this resolution as I believe that a fully mandatory system covering all operators upstream and downstream needs to be put in place when it comes to conflict minerals. Human rights abuses are common within the extractive industry and may include child labour, sexual violence, enforced disappearance, forced resettlement and the destruction of ritually or culturally significant sites.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of establishing a mandatory system of traceability of minerals extracted in conflict-affected areas, because it is the only way to effectively combat the link between their marketing and the financing of violent armed organizations. To date, only 4% of the affected companies have opted for a voluntary certification system to ensure that the minerals they trade with and that we carry on our mobiles, computers and many other products that we use on a daily basis are not stained with blood. The European Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege, who has served nearly 40,000 women and girls in Congo, who have had to "recompose" for the atrocities to which they had been subjected by violent groups, and advocates for the mandatory certification system. Even so, the rapporteur, of the People's Group, has advocated voluntary regulation because he "respects and guarantees the functioning of markets and creates a viable framework for businesses". In the face of this, the Socialists defend "respect and guarantee of human rights and a viable framework for the dignity of people".

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. "Conflict minerals" such as tin, tantalum, tungsten or gold are found in most electronic devices that we use daily. The financial windfall that comes from it feeds into criminal networks, warlords and militias, responsible for abuses of all kinds. Every day, this trafficking is organised by companies operating in Europe, unscrupulous and unconcerned with respect for fundamental rights. The text submitted to Parliament and amended by the group imposes a duty of "diligence" on the entire supply chain, from the extraction of the ore to the sale of the consumer product. This binding measure will have the effect of forcing companies operating in Europe to comply with respect for fundamental rights. I voted for this text because it is a major step forward in the fight against trade that fuels the destruction of human lives. By adopting this text, Parliament demonstrates that the values at the heart of the European project still animate its actors and that the best interests of the peoples are better than the unbridled pursuit of profit.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which presents proposals put forward by the Commission to limit the ability of armed groups in conflict and high-risk areas to finance their activities through mineral mining and trade. We must take all possible measures to break the link between the world's worst military conflicts and trade-friendly fossils. The Commission has proposed to facilitate the acquisition of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold in a responsible and transparent manner. This would reduce the availability of illicit trade channels. The Commission has also proposed a draft regulation establishing an EU framework for the approval of these beneficial importers of minerals who have chosen to import these metals responsibly into the Union. We need to do even more in this area. The Commission must ensure that the provisions contained in the document are implemented. It is also essential that, by legally promoting legitimate trade, we do not forget the wider spectrum of measures to prevent bloody conflicts around the world.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of establishing a mandatory system of traceability of minerals extracted in conflict-affected areas, because it is the only way to effectively combat the link between their marketing and the financing of violent armed organizations. To date, only 4% of the affected companies have opted for a voluntary certification system to ensure that the minerals they trade with and that we carry on our mobiles, computers and many other products that we use on a daily basis are not stained with blood. The European Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege, who has served nearly 40,000 women and girls in Congo, who have had to "recompose" for the atrocities to which they had been subjected by violent groups, and advocates for the mandatory certification system. Even so, the rapporteur, of the People's Group, has advocated voluntary regulation because he "respects and guarantees the functioning of markets and creates a viable framework for businesses". In the face of this, the Socialists defend "respect and guarantee of human rights and a viable framework for the dignity of people".

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mandatory certification from all EU importers who source these minerals in conflict zones. The trade of conflict minerals that are mined in areas where there is either armed conflict or weak or non-existent governance or security continues to perpetuate a cycle of conflict and human rights abuses in many fragile areas of the world. When we in the EU buy products containing these minerals we are unwittingly helping to fuel conflict and displace indigenous peoples in many failed or failing states.  This proposal will require all importers to certify that the minerals they import do not originate in conflict areas and demand mandatory compliance from all downstream companies. These companies will now be obliged to provide information on the steps they take to identify and address risks in their supply chains for the minerals and metals concerned.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Report on Self-certification of importers of minerals and metals originating in conflict-affected and high-risk areas. The EU is behind the USA in finally dealing with this issue and at last we have arrived at a position where we can now make progress. The legislative outcome will now mean that negotiations will now take place with the Council. I voted in favour of mandatory conditions as against a voluntary code that some wanted. I voted for a proper due diligence regime that would apply and I voted to include all minerals, rather than just four as was originally proposed. While negotiations will now proceed, I believe that a strong position has been reached which will send a clear message that EU businesses must respect developing countries and the materials they import and make.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. \u2012 The extraction of minerals that EU countries import often causes violent conflicts, human rights violations and environmental damage. The package of measures adopted today shows the ambition to keep minerals out of conflict zones. That's a clear signal. For example, European companies should report on the origin of minerals they use, so that electronics and mobile phones made from raw materials from conflict zones can be banned. This prevents violent groups in conflict zones from funding their weapons by selling raw materials extracted in their region. There will also be a mandatory certification for tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold, to ensure that these do not come from conflict zones.  However, the Party for Animals believes that we should go further, with mandatory due diligence (due dilligence) for all types of raw materials and not just these four. I also believe that all companies processing metals and minerals, not just importers, both upstream and downstream in the distribution chain, must demonstrate that their products are conflict-free. That is why I abstained in the final vote on the Commission's proposal and I hope that Parliament will get these matters settled in the negotiations with the Council. Only then will I fully agree.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. Parliament voted in favour of a European mechanism for self-certification of importers of minerals and metals from conflict or high-risk areas. Beyond the unanimously shared objective of cutting off the sources of funding for armed groups, there is a duty of realism that we owe to European citizens. It is impossible to offer a mandatory self-certification system to the entire production line. How can an SME be sure that the ore it uses to make its product does not come from a conflict zone? Like the consumer who is not responsible for the manufacturing process of the garment he wears, I consider that companies that use minerals cannot be fully informed of their origin. That is why I support a gradual but more effective approach: a mandatory system that is imposed on the first players in the chain (foundries/refineries and importers) and the creation of a label for other players in the chain in order to create a responsible supply system. Unfortunately, Parliament's position is unrealistic. I fear that the effects will be neutralized by an excess of control, which will be contrary to the interests of the local people.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that a voluntary approach for companies involved in mineral extraction does not prevent conflict minerals from entering the European supply chain. Binding rules are an absolute necessity and I am pleased that Parliament has voted to strengthen the Commission’s original proposal.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted against delaying the adoption of the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a Union system for self-targeting responsible importers of tin, tantains and tungsten, their ores and gold, originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas through due diligence in the supply chain. On the eve of the vote, a pause was requested by the Chairman of the INTA Committee. After several consultations, the same president proposed delaying the adoption of this report. As there was a huge division within the ALDE group, I decided to follow the party's proposals (although I was personally inclined to many other proposals) because I expected the report to be adopted and a good Regulation would finally come on the scene. However, a very narrow majority of practically "disobedied" ALDE lawmakers postponed this vote.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text aims to restrict and provide a precise framework for trade in minerals in areas of war or violent or future conflict. Many factual groups, bandits, and perhaps, tomorrow, Islamists, manage to obtain weapons and ammunition through the exploitation of these minerals, so-called "blood". This is particularly the case in the Great Lakes region of Africa. However, if one can only be appalled by this situation, the Commission's proposal is not, in this case, satisfactory since it retains a self-certification mechanism for companies that would import metals into Europe. Fortunately, Parliament has succeeded in amending this text: companies must therefore verify that their supply chain is not corrupted by blood ores. This text, even if it starts with a laudable intention, is not satisfactory enough for me to vote for: I abstained.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of establishing a mandatory system of traceability of minerals extracted in conflict-affected areas because I believe that the voluntary nature of the Commission's proposal was insufficient and would have no effect on the ground. To date, only 4% of the affected companies have opted for a voluntary certification system to ensure that the minerals they trade with and that we carry on our mobiles, computers and many other products that we use on a daily basis are not stained with blood. Mandatory measures need to be adopted to prevent the indirect purchase of minerals mined in conflict-affected areas and to effectively combat the link between their marketing and the financing of violent organizations.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I abstained on the final vote of my colleague Iuliu Winkler's report following a proposal by the European Commission to establish a voluntary European self-certification mechanism for importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten, minerals and gold from conflict zones or high risk. It is essential to put an end to all financing of armed groups obtained through the trade in these four minerals, to fight corruption and to ensure effective development assistance; that is why I have defended an approach that goes beyond the original proposal of the European Commission. For example, I supported the proposal to make the duty of care mandatory for the first players in the chain. It is regrettable, however, that the final text is not operational because of the demagoguery shown by the left. It sets out objectives and instruments that are not applicable in fact and contains a number of contradictions which will contribute to putting Parliament in a bad position in the forthness of the forthness with the Council and the Commission. I regret that the sensationalist and media temptations of some are at the expense of an effective fight against the financing of armed groups.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I was surprised that Mr Winkler wanted to send his well-done report, which is basically worthy of support, directly to the trialogue after the vote on the Commission proposal.
