I rejected the Commission's proposal because it contains significant gaps in definitions, means more effort for SMEs and leaves important issues relating to conformity assessment unresolved.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, at its plenary session in Strasbourg, voted on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Union framework for the self-certification of tin, tantalum, tungsten, tungsten, their ores and gold responsible importers for the proper functioning of the supply chain, the so-called conflict mineral regulation, in support of the European Commission's offer to enable importers and processors of these metals to introduce a verification system on a voluntary basis. The Regulation applies to metals used in the production of high-tech products such as mobile phones, computers. Importers of these metals must carry out checks to determine where the metals in question are supplied and to prevent them from being imported from military conflict zones.  A voluntary verification system would not increase prices or destroy individual companies, as in many cases it is not possible to find out the starting supplier because of the length and complexity of global trade chains. It would also save many jobs, as these metals have to reach Europe so that the production of countless products can take place at all. Even tougher controls will seriously increase the cost to businesses, which will be reflected in prices, reducing the competitiveness of European producers in the global market and in bringing higher costs to local consumers.  In the final vote, the majority of the European Parliament voted in favour of introducing mandatory and stricter checks, so I abstained because I believe that the text proposed by the European Commission is proportionate to all the parties involved and will achieve the objectives of the regulation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ This is a historical victory that puts the respect of human rights above the profit of companies. After a long and hard campaign, the S&D Group convinced the rest of the European Parliament to secure a legally binding scheme to ensure the traceability of minerals, to make sure that products sold in the EU do not fuel armed militias or foster human rights violations in conflict areas. There have been voluntary guidelines in place for five years and more than 80% of companies have chosen not to publish any information on their supply chain due diligence. These mandatory requirements, while not burdensome on any one link in the supply chain, will make a huge difference to those on the ground in conflict areas. We now need the support of EU Member State governments to reach an agreement on this legislation.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Great Lakes area in Africa is a place where conflicts often occur in which minerals and metals play a crucial role. Just a glimpse of the history of the countries in the summer of the region (i.e. Burundi, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania and Uganda) shows that this land is seecped with blood from civil wars and genocides. The European Parliament has decided to help at least a little to ease the difficult situation in which the region is located. Left-wing forces in the European Parliament have made it clear that they want a certificate system in place to make it clear that minerals or metals do not come from conflict zones and are therefore not, for example, so-called blood diamonds. At present, consumers are often indirectly linked to conflicts that have serious implications for the peaceful development of the region. Human rights violations commonly occur in the extractive industries, which may include child labour, sexual violence, enforced disappearances, forced removals and the destruction of ritually or culturally important sites. In the Great Lakes area, democracy and education should be developed, not inhumane practices to increase profits, which will then end up in the accounts of self-proclaimed leaders or arms and drug traffickers. Whatever it may help to stop it, I will be happy to support it, as will this proposal.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that the plenum did not fully share the principles of the Hungarian People's Party Group and the EPP in the assessment of key issues, I had no choice but to abstain in the final vote in order to ensure that the dialogue could continue in interinstitutional consultation.  Making originalification mandatory in the more advanced stages of the production chain would impose an excessive economic and administrative burden on European medium and small enterprises, while strengthening control mechanisms in the countries of origin of minerals that contribute to a fair allocation of system resources. My aim is therefore to create a balanced regulation that promotes sustainable development in the countries of origin surrounded by armed conflicts, without having economic effects similar to embargoes.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote, conscience and responsibility prevailed, beyond political affiliation. A conscience and responsibility that have been stronger than external pressures and the interests at stake. This House has chosen to go beyond indifference by calling for mandatory certification for European importers of tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold originating in conflict and high-risk areas. A demand strongly supported, achieving the ambitious goal of tying the entire production chain to this obligation.  A great step forward has been taken, with Europe taking full responsibility for the 'minerals of conflict'. We can no longer tolerate our tablets, mobile phones and computers being stained with the blood of thousands of innocent people. We can no longer tolerate indifference. The citizens of Europe, who have the right to buy responsible minerals, are asking us to do so.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted against the final text of Mr Winkler's proposal on self-certification for importers of certain minerals and metals originating in conflict and high-risk areas, mainly because some of the fundamental prerogatives I support have not been approved. Although we are aware of the importance of a system of self-certification by companies, which is of fundamental importance for the ethical functioning of the entire production chain, we must also recognise the negative impact of compulsory self-certification, with bureaucratic costs and burdens that will be likely to seriously damage the sector, being able to effectively protect human prerogatives and rights in another way, less incisive than the one then approved.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council establishing a European self-certification mechanism, within the framework of the duty of care on supply chains, for importers of minerals from conflict zones.  With this vote, we demanded that binding legislation be adopted on the traceability of the use of four minerals: tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold, extracted in countries affected for several years by the war. Future legislation should thus allow for systematic certification of these minerals by the European Union to ensure that they do not in any way fuel conflicts and human rights violations in conflict zones, such as rape, which is regularly used in some countries as a weapon of war.  We are well aware that this binding legislation could place a weight, particularly financially, on certain European companies, but the moral and human stakes are too high for the European Union and the European Parliament to remain passive on this issue.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. This text is a significant step forward in framing imports of minerals from conflict zones, particularly from the Great Lakes area. These rare minerals, tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold, must no longer feed the funds of the many guerrillas and paramilitary groups of this region guilty of violent abuses, acting with impunity, and often forcing the local populations to participate in the extraction. Europe, which is one of the main markets for the consumption of electronic products (particularly mobile phones and plasma screens) using these minerals, could not stand idly by and lag behind. The United States took up the problem as early as 2010. That is why I have supported this text, which goes much further than the Commission's proposals by imposing a mandatory system for certifying minerals. It is therefore the 880,000 European companies using these metals that will have to participate in a traceability system throughout the supply chain, whereas previously it was limited to 19. Thus, we will ensure that these conflict minerals do not end up in our products and do not finance the criminal and heinous abuses of these armed groups.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a naïve effort to prevent human rights violations in the extraction of precious minerals and minerals. But making regulations won't help people. At most, it will take smaller firms out of the market and strengthen large corporations. I have nothing against voluntary certification of companies. However, there is no need for an EU directive for this.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported Representative Iuliu Winkler's report establishing a Union self-certification system for responsible importers of tin, tantains and tungsten, their ores and gold originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas through due diligence in the supply chain.  The aim is to establish a Union self-certification system in accordance with due diligence in the supply chain in order to limit the opportunities for armed groups and security forces to trade in tin, tantalum and tungsten, their ores and gold, and aims to ensure transparency and security of the supply process for importers, stalions and refineries procuring from conflict-affected and high-risk areas. Natural mineral resources in conflict-affected and high-risk areas, despite their great development potential, can be the cause of a dispute in which the revenue generated from them incides an outbreak or the permeation of violent conflict, undermining states' efforts on the path of development, good governance and the rule of law. In these areas, breaking the links between conflict and the illegal exploitation of minerals is essential for peace and stability.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 In its previous mandate, the Commission proposed a voluntary certification regime for European companies dealing with imports of the so-called "conflict minerals". Today, I supported the proposal for more ambitious measures and the mandatory certification of all eu 'conflict minerals' importers to ensure that trade in minerals does not fuel conflict and does not contribute to human rights violations. I believe that mandatory certification will help to break the link between the trade in minerals and the financing of the activities of terrorist organizations in the conflict zones concerned.  Concerns about the effect of the compulsory certification scheme on small and medium-sized businesses are well founded, but let me remind you that Parliament has called on the Commission to provide support to SMEs to obtain this certificate, covering their costs under the procedure in the so-called 'SME'. competitiveness of enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises (COSME).  The adoption of the bill in a more binding version is in itself a historic step forward, but it is important to note that the text will only be finalised once informal negotiations with the other European institutions have been completed. I am convinced that the economic interest should not be placed above values.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the postponement, and the majority was only 343 to 331. Next, the Committee on International Trade will ask for a vote on this legislative resolution at a later date, at another plenary session. It is an excellent victory for the Socialist Group, because the people seemed defeated today. In key votes, we achieved what we wanted, but the People's Party group was divided.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Revenues from mining and trade in mineral wealth are a source of financing for armed conflicts in several countries around the world. Many business entities thus indirectly support this funding through their activities. At the same time, the European Union is one of the leading importers and processors of mineral resources, with 400 importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold and their ores, which ranks it among the largest markets for these metals and ores. I consider it important that, in order to increase the transparency and information of all economic operators involved in the extraction, trade and processing of minerals from these countries, measures should be taken by the European Union and the Member States leading to the responsible and lawful action of all the operators concerned.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of postponing the adoption of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing an EU system of self-certification of due diligence with regard to the supply chain of responsible importers of tin, tantalin and tungsten, their minerals, as well as gold, coming from conflict and high risk areas following the proposal of the rapporteur of the report.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am delighted that we got a majority in Parliament for due diligence from the start to the end of the supply chain for conflict minerals.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulation establishing a European system of self-certification for importers of certain minerals and metals from conflict zones aims at a balance between a system of self-certification and mandatory indication of the quantities of minerals imported. Precise rules must be laid down for responsible trade in the four materials indicated by the OECD (tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold), without damaging the European entrepreneurial fabric that revolves around trade in these materials but above all by making sure that the proceeds do not feed the conflicts.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Contrary to the proposal of the Commission and the Council, the final report enshrines a system of mandatory traceability of the origin of mining from conflict or high-risk areas, so I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. We must ensure from the European Parliament that there is a trade in minerals, especially in the areas of the world where there are the greatest conflicts, under certain conditions and that, above all, they prevent armed groups from being financed through this activity. That is why my support for the bill establishing a mandatory certification for all participants in the supply chain of metals and minerals from conflict and high-risk zones, because we cannot allow the extraction of minerals so necessary to manufacture many of the goods that we use so much in our day-to-day life to serve the maintenance of illegal and terrorist activities.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I have rejected the proposal for self-certification by importers of certain minerals and metals from high-risk areas. Admittedly, the introduction of such raw materials requires regulation in order to deprive rebels, etc., of the funding base. However, the proposal put forward for this purpose is not strict enough and self-certification is an inappropriate means of ensuring this.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This legislation aims to regulate the extraction by European companies of certain minerals and gold which play a key role in financing certain armed groups or security forces in conflict zones such as the Great Lakes region. Certification is therefore proposed. Of course, multinationals did not want it to be mandatory, but only optional. They were helped in this direction by Marielle de Sarnez, MEP for Modem, who stepped up to the plate to defend them. Even the US version of this legislation, on which the Commission and the rapporteur rely, is binding. Finally, my group's amendments passed. The text is ambitious, I vote for it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This text aims to restrict and provide a precise framework for trade in minerals in areas of war or violent or future conflict. Many factual groups, bandits, and perhaps, tomorrow, Islamists, manage to obtain weapons and ammunition through the exploitation of these minerals, so-called "blood". This is particularly the case in the Great Lakes region of Africa. However, if one can only be appalled by this situation, the Commission's proposal is not, in this case, satisfactory since it retains a self-certification mechanism for companies that would import metals into Europe. Fortunately, Parliament has succeeded in amending this text: companies must therefore verify that their supply chain is not corrupted by blood ores. This text, even if it starts with a laudable intention, is not satisfactory enough for me to vote on it. So I abstained.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to make it difficult to finance the activities of armed groups in conflict and high-risk areas through the exploitation and trade of minerals.  The main objectives of the proposed Regulation are to prevent the profits from trade in minerals from being used to finance armed conflicts, to promote responsible supply of these minerals by companies and to promote legitimate trade channels. The minerals concerned - tin, tantalum, tungsten, their ores and gold - are used, for example, in the automotive, construction, electrical and electronic industries, being present in consumer products used by many Europeans, such as computers, printers, washing machines and refrigerators. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ While I voted not to postpone the decision, I am pleased that the European Parliament has agreed on robust measures that seek to prevent the trading of commodities that finance armed conflict.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I support strengthening the rules on companies importing minerals such as tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold, which must be certified by the EU to help ensure the income flowing to the producers does not fuel conflicts and human rights abuses. Mineral importers, smelters and refineries, but also manufacturers of consumer products (mobile phones, tablets, washing machines) should ensure that revenues from the minerals they use are not funding conflicts. We must stay true to our goals of solidarity and development.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This European self-certification mechanism for importers responsible for tin, tungsten, minerals and gold originating in high-risk conflict zones is an example of a binding administrative standard for industrialists and probably useless in effects. This mechanism does not seem to be appropriate at all to address the problems outlined in this report. How can we think that self-certification, i.e. the awarding of a label by the company itself and with a very hypothetical control of the administrative authorities, may have any interest? This is one of many issues of the EU institutions to raise awareness of the tragic events taking place in conflict zones, and which highlights their total impotence. Although the intention of this report to avoid the resale of these minerals is commendable, it shows once again a willingness of the European institutions to impose their "values" on the whole earth. It is up to the Member States to take responsibility and take real enforcement action. I have therefore decided to abstain on this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I am proud to have voted for compulsory checks on the sources of minerals imported from conflict zones. The vote signals intent to not put business interests ahead of fundamental human rights. The proposals ensure a legally binding scheme to ensure traceability of products sold in the EU. This will help safeguard EU industry and ensure that companies will be responsible for ensuring that their suppliers are not fuelling human rights abuse and conflicts across the world.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament had a great responsibility on the subject of so-called 'conflict minerals': to adopt an effective and coherent text on trade in minerals from war zones, which would protect victims of violence and exploitation. Unfortunately, this has only been done in part. The text resulting from the adoption of the amendments is contradictory in some respects; It is therefore welcome to refer it back to the trialogue process in order to arrive at targeted solutions for real respect for human rights.   It will be up to Parliament's representatives to obtain mandatory procedures, with clear mechanisms for certification and traceability of the mineral supply chain, with particular regard to entities importing raw materials in Europe. At the same time, these procedures will have to limit the impact on small and micro-enterprises, avoiding onerous bureaucratic burdens, not resolutions of human rights violations.  All this, within the framework of a cooperation and development policy which, I repeat, is really concerned about the protection of human rights and the economic growth of third countries, which effectively opposes the positions of the pension of armed groups that violate these rights and which is a source of pride for this Parliament and this Europe.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe must have the courage of those who know that they are moving in the right direction: we cannot afford to adopt a rule that serves only to appease our consciences. We must adopt a rule that really helps to eliminate the problem, which is why the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D) is fighting to have not only compulsory, but also the extension of the latter to the entire production chain. Our group has worked for a long time to ensure a balance between the need to combat this phenomenon and the need not to burden small businesses with obligations that exceed their possibilities. We have overcome this point in a number of ways, from the exemption of micro-enterprises (with fewer than 9 employees) to the inclusion of strong flexibility, where according to which the obligations for operators vary according to their size and position in the production chain. We've always said we want to set standards in the world. We have always said that the European Union is not limited to managing the economy but is based on powerful values and ideals, such as peace, attention to others, solidarity. This proposal is a very important test to show that these are not just words, that Europe really wants to lead in the area of the protection of human rights.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amended proposal on conflict minerals. The proposal concerned minerals whose export profits are often used as a means of funding armed groups in the developing world, which fuels human rights violations, etc. The EU is one of the biggest markets for these materials. I voted in favour of a number of strong amendments from my political group GUE/NGL and other groups which aimed at getting the system of due diligence made mandatory and expanding the list of minerals included beyond the four proposed by the Commission. While not all of the amendments I supported were passed, amendments calling for the due diligence system to be made mandatory and applying it throughout the supply chain were adopted. For this reason I voted in favour of the amended proposal.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report proposed by the Committee on International Trade, because it has as its theme an issue that we also discussed in the previous mandate, when I worked in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, namely control on the extraction of minerals in conflict zones. The money from the exploitation and marketing of ores from conflict zones raises a problem that affects us indirectly. In many of these cases, we have clear situations of exploitation of people, impoverishment of the population and, last but not least, financial support of terrorist groups, paramilitary and local mafias. It is essential to have clearer control of the provenance of ores and thus ensure that we do not end up sponsoring a modern form of slavery, paramilitary troops or even terrorist groups.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the most important sources of financing for war and civil war-type conflicts in the world is the extraction and sale of various ores and metals. They are usually mineed in inhumane conditions, with slave, forced and child labour, a violation of liberties and workers' rights, and the destruction of the environment. The resources generated in this way are used in a opaque manner in a significant number of cases, to maintain the repressive machinery of dictatorial regimes, to purchase weapons, to finance crimes and terrorist activities.  In my view, the fundamental values on which the European Union is based require us to do everything we can to reduce this practice, to create strict regulations that promote the ethical and responsible behaviour of European economic operators on this issue while respecting the requirements of a market economy.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report has some positive aspects to actually curbing the financing of civil wars and armed conflicts. At the same time, however, it also entails the risk that our Austrian small and medium-sized enterprises in particular will be slain by a certification bureaucracy. I would therefore have probably abstained from voting.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The European Commission's initial proposal was to establish a European self-certification mechanism for importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten, their ore and gold from conflict or high-risk areas.  But the importation of these minerals from many of our everyday objects has dramatic consequences in the importing countries that are too often ignored here. Self-certification is far from sufficient because it will leave industrialists too comfortable in the face of the massacres perpetuated daily in the world for the extraction of these minerals. That is why I have co-signed amendments to significantly strengthen this proposal by creating a binding monitoring mechanism for supply chains, from producers to importers of these minerals.  Thanks to these amendments, the resolution now proposes a strict system of control of minerals marketed on its territory. Since these amendments were adopted in plenary, I have decided to vote in favour of this very ambitious report, which will still have to be agreed with the Council.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. I supported the proposal. It aims to break the link between conflicts and the illegal extraction of minerals and thereby make it more difficult to finance the activities of armed groups operating in conflict zones by extracting and selling mineral resources.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Whereas the Commission proposes a proposal for a regulation establishing a European system of self-certification for importers of tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold who choose to import responsibly into the Union; whereas self-certification requires EU importers of these metals and minerals to exercise 'due diligence', i.e. avoid causing damage to the territory; I voted against.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I consider it unacceptable that the European Union should participate and encourage the continuation of the conflict in these areas through an unregulated ore and metals market, trading in these activities, financing armed groups. Many serious forms of disregard for human rights, especially women and children, are linked to the actions of these armed groups. Since the foundation on which the European Union is based is precisely this principle - respect for human rights, it stands to reason that this community of ours must not be a stakeholders in supporting something that disagrees with these principles of itss. I believe that the process of self-certifying importers, with the involvement of supervisory authorities that will control the correctness of the procedure itself, will contribute to reducing criminal activities in these areas and that it is necessary to reach an agreement on outstanding issues as soon as possible.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This text attempts to address the problem of rare minerals exploited in conflict zones illegally and thus contributing to the conflict. The successful project is a self-certification mechanism for companies, based on an OECD guide. Importers self-identify by fulfilling due diligence on their supply chain. They must keep in their possession traceability evidence that they are not buying from illegal mines. The importer's procedures and activities are verified by an independent third party. Member States will be responsible for auditing and enforcing the regulation. In principle, taking steps to avoid conflict financing is a good idea. Unfortunately, the mechanism chosen, that of self-certification, is ineffective on the ground and will only penalise European companies. It is clear that minerals will leave conflict zones to be processed by companies from countries less looking than those of the EU and will therefore return to EU states as finished products. Refusing to agree to this mechanism, which I strongly doubt, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Natural mineral resources in conflict-affected and high-risk areas, despite their great development potential, may be the cause of a dispute in which the revenue generated from them incides the outbreak or prevention of violent conflict, undermining efforts on the path of development, good governance and the rule of law. In these areas, breaking the links between conflict and the illicit exploitation of minerals is a key element in ensuring peace, development and stability. Human rights violations are common in the extractive industry and can include child labour, sexual violence, enforced disappearance, forced transfer and destruction of places of ritual and cultural importance.  I therefore support the report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a Union system for self-targeting responsible importers of tin, tantains and tungsten, their ores and gold originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas through due diligence in the supply chain and the adoption of commission proposals at first reading.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support the Report on the proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a Union system for self-certifying responsible importers of tin, tantains and tungsten, their ores and gold originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas through due diligence in the supply chain. Conflict-affected mineral-rich countries are in a vicious circle where rebels are funded by precisely valuable digs. To end this, international organisations and the EP have called for the establishment of due dilligence systems between companies that perform excavations and importers. The proposal applies to excavations 3t and g - tin, tantamoun, tungsten and gold, the participation of companies is voluntary, refers to any conflict affected area and to companies that carry out melting and processing as well as importers. Importers wishing to participate may be declared as responsible importers of a Member State and must comply with the proposed measures. It is accepted that it is strictly defined which are conflict zones and that voluntary participation for importers and for producers is mandatory.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ I am glad at the result achieved by Parliament on the S&D proposals of establishing a EU system for supply chain due diligence self-certification of responsible importers of metal in conflict areas. Regarding continuing conflicts and suffering around the world, it is important that we ensure a disconnection between conflict financing and mineral extraction to promote economic transparency and, most importantly, human rights. It is therefore equally crucial when it comes to making solid changes of situations in high-risk areas to introduce a mandatory scheme of due diligence for the entire supply chain to guarantee the traceability of not only imported metals, but also of all natural resources from such areas. Meanwhile, I am also convinced that special attention and flexibility should be designated to the SMEs along with the requirement of a mandatory self—declaration as a responsible importer. With the voice of Parliament demanding an exclusion of conflict metals in the EU market, I look forward to a final resolution, in accord with the Commission and Council, being adopted to put the approach of achieving human rights into practice.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission had decided to adopt a voluntary system in its proposal. The GROUP of the European People's Party ( CHRISTIAN Democrats) and European Democrats, out of a clear desire to protect those operating in the supply chain, had called for, and I agree, that it should be compulsory to indicate the quantities of minerals imported from conflict zones only for those importers upstream of the supply chain (refineries and foundries), while maintaining an optional system for everyone else.  I agree with the theory that if there were obligations of transparency and self-certification for all, there would be too heavy a burden on the importers themselves, with the result that operators would be forced to abandon those areas for others where the obligation is not laid down, not achieving the development objective that is intended to be pursued in these territories. In addition, the creation of a 'responsible companies' label requires the European Commission to produce a list of companies responsible for self-certification of the origin of minerals.  This issue is certainly complex and involves many profiles, from foreign policy aspects to respect for human rights, from the promotion of democracy to development cooperation. Since the pursuit of general objectives with the need to protect the production system has been disrupted by a number of amendments, I have preferred to abstain.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. MEPs voted on the report on the creation of a European self-certification mechanism for importers of minerals (tin, tantalum, tungsten, gold) in order to break the link between mineral extraction and trade on the one hand and the financing of armed conflicts on the other. The aim of the report is to support the development of a market in the EU for minerals from conflict zones exploited responsibly, and to improve the ability of supply chain players to respect the duty of care. This vote is a mess. Some might welcome the few amendments passed by a narrow majority, but they are not strengthened by a structure that allows them to be implemented. As the Commission and the Council are closed to any progress on the Commission's proposal, Parliament could have been in a position of strength.  It would have taken a comprehensive approach with means to fight corruption, manage development aid and combine it with an instrument whose constraint could have been spread over time for the 880,000 European companies. The European Parliament could have launched a major action; with this vote he made only an inaudible appeal.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft regulation under this procedure aims to break the vicious circle between the extraction, trade in minerals and the financing of armed conflicts by establishing a European system of self-certification for importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold. Self-certification requires EU importers of these metals and their ores to fulfil their duty of diligence - i.e. do not cause adverse effects on the ground - by controlling and managing their purchases and sales, in line with the five steps prescribed in the OECD Guide on Duty of Diligence. The Regulation also allows EU importers to deepen their current efforts to ensure fair supply chains by establishing legitimate trade relationships with operators from conflict-affected countries. I voted in favour.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. I welcome today's vote to end the sale of minerals (gold, diamonds, tantalum, tin, copper) for the benefit of armed groups and to establish a duty of care to all importing companies in the European Union. These raw materials are used every day for the construction of various technologies (portable, tablets, etc.). However, their extraction has consequences for the lives of hundreds of thousands of people. The Commission's initial draft was limited to the establishment of a non-binding European self-certification mechanism for only companies that directly imported raw materials upstream of the supply chain. The scope of this mechanism would then have been very limited. With the support of civil society and citizens, left-wing parliamentarians and especially socialists and democrats, we have succeeded in putting in place mandatory legislation for all companies in the supply chain. This is a victory against the European right, which wanted a cheap mechanism. Above all, it is a victory against the trafficking of "blood minerals", against armed groups and for the establishment of a real European development policy.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. At noon, MEPs voted in favour of an ambitious settlement to end the financing of armed conflicts through the exploitation of a series of minerals (tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold), commonly used in European industry. For decades, eastern Congo has been ravaged by violence caused by the proliferation of armed groups that feed on income generated by illegal mines, often to the detriment of local populations.  The aim of this regulation is to break the link between the financing of these groups and mining in conflict zones, specifically in Africa where 30% of the world's mineral resources are concentrated, where mining production weighs on average 24% of GDP and where 27 conflicts are known to be linked to these resources.  The text adopted this afternoon by the European Parliament is realistic and humanistic, and provides an excellent basis for the future of the negotiations. It provides, thanks to the adoption of the two amendments tabled by Louis Michel and which I have co-signed, a mechanism of transparency for all the players of the channel. It remains to convince the Council to take its responsibilities in the face of this trafficking in death.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. "As Gianni Pittella, President of S&D, said, "all those who fight for respect for human rights have always won over any multinational interests." With this proposal, it increases the guarantee that the import into the EU of certain minerals from conflict zones will not finance armed militias that act against human rights. Importers will be certified and obliged to comply with certain rules under penalty of penalty.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of establishing a mandatory system of traceability of minerals extracted in conflict-affected areas, because it is the only way to effectively combat the link between their marketing and the financing of violent armed organizations. To date, only 4% of the affected companies have opted for a voluntary certification system to ensure that the minerals they trade with and that we carry on our mobiles, computers and many other products that we use on a daily basis are not stained with blood. The European Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege, who has served nearly 40,000 women and girls in Congo, who have had to "recompose" for the atrocities to which they had been subjected by violent groups, and advocates for the mandatory certification system. Even so, the rapporteur, of the People's Group, has advocated voluntary regulation because he "respects and guarantees the functioning of markets and creates a viable framework for businesses". In the face of this, the Socialists defend respect and guarantee of human rights and a viable framework for the dignity of people.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of an ambitious settlement on the issue of conflict minerals, because I am convinced that it is necessary to compel companies to ensure that the minerals they buy are not used to finance deadly conflicts in Central Africa.  I call for this traceability to be made mandatory and transparent so that the exploitation and trade of these minerals that end up in our mobile phones, tablets, fridges and televisions no longer lead, as is the case at present, to serious human rights violations. It is essential that Belgium has the same voice heard in the Council of the European Union, where the discussions will continue.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The financing of armed groups obtained by the trade in tin, tantalum, tungsten, their minerals and gold must cease. With my votes on this text, I wanted to support a realistic and progressive approach that would have made the duty of care for the upstream supply chain, i.e. smelters, refineries and importers, mandatory, and voluntary for the rest of the companies in the chain. That is why I abstained on the final vote because a mandatory approach across the whole chain, more than 800,000 European companies, whether multinationals or small or medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), seems difficult to apply and implement. A progressive approach, thanks in particular to the revision clause, which would gradually broaden the scope of the regulation, would have been preferable. By abstaining, I also wanted the discussions and negotiations on this text to continue.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the amendments that have been made, I abstained because I believe that the aim of this report, which establishes a European system of self-certification of the exercise of due diligence in the supply chain for importers responsible for tin, tungsten, tantalum, their minerals and gold, originating in conflict zones and at high risk, is entirely acceptable, but I do not believe that the text makes an incisive contribution to combating this problem.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The objective of this regulation should be to gain greater control of certain minerals or metals originating in conflict and high-risk areas, in order to prevent them from financing destabilization and violence in areas where, on the contrary, the presence of these materials should serve the sustainable and peaceful development of the local economy. Regulation has enormous shortcomings that call into question its usefulness: the number of materials to be accredited is unjustifiably restricted; import control is left to the companies themselves, who cannot be expected to declare their activities in conflict zones; it is not taken into account that most of these materials are processed before entering the European market, so most traffic is excluded from this legislation. That's why I voted against it.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the creation of a European market free of complicity in bloody conflicts. I believe that if producers and consumers unite for a responsible mineral market in Europe, we will come closer to breaking the link between mineral extraction and trade and conflict financing on a global scale. I believe, however, that the winkler report's proposals still fall short of contributing to truly ambitious legislation needed to remove the presence of 'conflict minerals' in the European Union. Legislation that instills the duty of diligence only to refiners and smelters has too little impact. Effective mechanisms are needed throughout the production chain, from raw material importers to the final consumer. A chain-to-chain certification system should be implemented, with all actors responsible for the reliability of the information given to the final consumer. I therefore voted in favour of extending the duty of diligence to all companies operating in the minerals market, including companies downstream of the supply chain.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted today for compulsory checks on the sources of minerals imported from conflict zones. Under the proposals, companies must make reasonable checks to ensure the step behind them in the supply chain can verify where the product came from, which will help break the link between armed conflict and the minerals trade. Companies will be responsible for ensuring that their suppliers are not fuelling human rights abuse and conflicts across the world, benefiting both consumers and business.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. Human rights are being violated in the extractive industries in developing countries. We normally encounter child labour, sexual violence or forced evictions there. Only organised and armed groups benefit from the mineral trade. We must therefore set up this system so that people are not abused. Human rights are worth more than a few euros cheaper mobile or other electronics.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The Green Party is particularly committed to binding transparency of companies involved in the mineral manufacturing and sales chain, and above all we want the sale of conflict minerals in Europe to be banned.  The vote by the EP has voted on binding transparency when GE is to sell minerals coming from conflicted or high-risk areas, but in any case the Greens will continue to fight to ensure that this requirement is included in the binding legislation.  Above all, it was important to cover the entire supply chain in the field of conflict minerals. This means that the review has been taken since the extraction phase of mineral resources from conflict and high-risk areas and then the use of them for computers, mobile phones and any other electronic equipment.  We want the legislation to cover as wide as possible the widest possible scope of minerals in everyday consumer products and to prohibit the import of conflict minerals into the European Union market. For this reason, I supported the report and voted in favour of its adoption by the European Parliament.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the text amending the European Commission's proposal for the introduction of a compulsory traceability system for EU importers using tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold in the manufacture of consumer products, such as smartphones, tablets and computers. According to the scheme strongly desired by the Group of Socialists and Democrats and despite opposition from the conservative bloc, the 800 000 EU companies that use these 4 minerals for the production of everyday goods should be obliged to receive EU certification to ensure that they do not feed bloody conflicts and human rights violations in war zones, such as those that have plagued Congo and the Great Lakes region for many years. The obligation of transparency concerns the entire supply chain of companies importing minerals and metals from areas of armed conflict, from the site of origin to the final product, passing also from metal foundries and gold refineries, which represent the last stage in which the origin of minerals can actually be traced. In order to support micro and small and medium-sized enterprises wishing to obtain certification, the text voted also calls on the Commission to grant financial support, through the COSME programme.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. We voted today in favour of an ambitious package of measures to combat trade in conflict minerals. All European companies must report bindingly on the origin of the minerals they use This is a victory of human rights over economic interests! Unwittingly, European consumers are funding death and death. Voluntary rules on conflict minerals have been in place for years and do not bring solace. Human suffering is a global political responsibility. With binding legislation, we ensure that the entire European consumer market only imports conflict-free products, so that rebels in areas such as eastern Congo no longer pay for their weapons through clandestine mineral trade. Binding legislation on conflict minerals was introduced in the United States as early as 2012. If the world's two largest consumer markets work together to end conflict mineral trading, we will also clean up the Asian market. For example, if the manufacturers of smartphones in China still want to supply us, they also need to see if their minerals are fairly extracted. The European Parliament will now negotiate the final legislation with the Member States. I call on the Belgian Finance Minister to subordinate business interests to the many human rights violations that conflict minerals entail and to ensure that Belgium has a truly humane face.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the resolution on the labelling of conflict substances. With binding European legislation on the labelling of conflict minerals, we want to put an end to the abuse of mineral sources and child labour. With this vote, we have sent out a clear signal against conflict financing through commodity trading. It must also be said that mining can in principle be a source of economic development, but it also leads to negative economic development, child labour and armed conflict when workers are exploited. That is why we want the regulation of the use of conflict minerals not only to be a voluntary additional option, but to become mandatory for all companies. Products that we take for granted are often produced for us for us at the expense of vulnerable people from another part of the world. We want to curb this exploitation with this measure. Consumers can thus be prevented from indirectly co-financing the suffering of others.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I think it's important to remove the link between minerals and conflict. I would also like to stress that we need a regulation that will be applicable and appropriate. We need mandatory certifications for smelters and mineral processors, and we need to encourage non-EU smelters and processors to operate responsibly by including importers in the compulsory certification system. However, if we go beyond certification, this could be counterproductive, as this will not only be a burden on industry in the EU, but also for developing countries. We must not restrict access to the EU market for them, as this could result in job losses in underdeveloped countries. This must by no means be the objective of the European Union regulation. By introducing applicable and appropriate certification rules for smelters and processors, and mineral and metal importers, we will create a system that is applicable and effective in our efforts to break the link between minerals and conflict.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported this report, which calls for compulsory checks on the source of minerals from conflict zones. Millions of people have been killed or displaced due to the trade of conflict minerals, and the real victims of the trade in conflict minerals are children and women. This mandatory system is vital in improving human rights in areas where conflict minerals are mined.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ because I agree with the voluntary approach to certification and, like the rapporteur, I believe that market pressures in the small and transparent markets concerned by the proposal will lead to a high level of involvement. Even if some businesses choose not to join, a better punishment than a legal penalty is to punish customers in the market.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ The main objective of this proposal is to help reduce the financing of armed groups and security forces through mineral proceeds in conflict-affected and high-risk areas by supporting and further promoting responsible sourcing practices by EU companies in relation to tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold originating from such areas. I am confident that my Conservative colleagues are fighting for sound legislation and a measured approach that will deliver this very important objective. I will continue to support their efforts to build a functioning system from the ground up, while allowing for genuine trade in these metals and minerals to continue.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The regulation of the production and processing processes of the various minerals of European refineries and metallurgical industries, in order to break the link between mineral extraction and conflict financing in areas affected by them, is a very important step. Developing a supply policy is a positive step.   However, we consider the choice of voluntary approach and labelling system to be wrong. It would be more effective to establish a mandatory registration system and develop a policy that approaches the whole issue and not just the supply chain. The aim should be to create a mandatory system, to avoid trafficking in human beings and not to discriminate, to register the use of recycled products and to extend the scope of the Regulation to other products. Unfortunately, these issues are absent from the text.  For the above reasons we have decided to abstain.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is out of reality for the Commission to request that these metals be identified at all times and in their constantly changing forms in order to enforce 'social justice'. If the EU wants to stop supporting mines and businesses that are not "politically correct" or because they are in war zones it can do so with economic measures as it did, wrongly, in the case of Russia. Billions will be spent without predictable results and in the end the only sure result is that we will take another step towards globalisation.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on self-at-self-attification among importers of minerals and metals from conflict-affected and high-risk areas. I agree that mineral resources in these regions, although a huge opportunity for development, can be contradictory if the proceeds from them are used to start or sustain violent conflicts that undermine development, good governance and the rule of law efforts. The disconnect between conflict and the illegal extraction of minerals in these areas is a critical element in guaranteeing peace, development and stability. The proposal highlights the sad fact that human rights abuses are common in the extractive industry, including child labour, sexual violence, forced disappearances, forced displacements and the destruction of areas of ritual or cultural importance. I therefore think it is important that Parliament has today given a strong signal to the European Commission and the Council calling for the eradication of this phenomenon. The Socialists and Democrats group was united in their support for the report, thus taking a step towards showing that respect for human rights is more important than multinational economic interests.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Most mobile phones, tablets and computers are currently producing valuable mineral resources, the extraction, conversion and even marketing of which is sometimes very objectionable. It turns out that the minerals used are very often obtained in violation of fundamental human rights, which can be safely described as 21st century slavery. Moreover, profits from the marketing or processing of such minerals are often used for other illegal activities, including, worst of all, they can be used to finance armed conflicts that have consumed tens or even hundreds of thousands of lives, particularly in Africa and Latin America. This problem also has a real economic dimension. Indeed, we cannot allow honest companies, which comply with international standards for the extraction and marketing of mineral resources, to be harmed by competition with entities that break the basic rules. That is why I am in favour of a regulation that will ensure that all companies in the mineral supply chain comply with the relevant standards as much as possible.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is very important because it deals with the establishment at EU level of responsible practices for the supply by companies of minerals and metals from conflict and risk zones, so as to reduce the funding of armed groups in those areas and any serious violations associated with the extraction, transport or trade of the minerals in question, and therefore their environmental consequences. The amendments tabled were voted on in this House, but not the report as a whole, because it was decided to proceed directly to the negotiations with the Council on the basis of the only amendments adopted.  However, the negotiations will be opened with an important amendment which we have strongly supported and which also establishes that downstream companies must take all measures to identify and address the risks in the supply of minerals and metals; the obligation to provide information on their reasonable due diligence practices for responsible sourcing is also established. The mandatory nature of these transparency and certification measures throughout the production chain is essential for our battle for the protection of social and environmental rights/duties.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: in writing. ‒ At the core of this report is the very noble aim to help prevent armed militias in some of the poorest parts of the world profiting from the commercial extraction of natural resources (in this case, three specific resources). The Commission presented a very sensible proposal that would have implemented a voluntary scheme, establishing a compromise between the aims of increasing transparency but weighed against the backdrop of international competition that is beyond the reach of the EU/international mandate. Unfortunately, the majority in this Parliament have sought to row against this compromise, opting instead for a mandatory, more proscriptive scheme. The effects of this will be quite simple. European—based companies seeking to conduct business with a corporate-social responsibility agenda will lose business to purely profit-minded rivals from around the world without any such restrictions. This will result in the loss of business, and thus jobs, for companies in the EU and, ironically, to an increase in the exact patterns of behaviour that this legislation is aimed at eradicating.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I am delighted with the result. Today's regulation is a historic victory that puts respect for human rights ahead of corporate profits. Europe, with our position in Parliament, has a chance to become a pioneer in economic ethics. The Council must now take Parliament's signal into account and work towards binding regulation that guarantees the traceability of the products we consume in Europe.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the text calling for a European certification system for smelters and refiners of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold, in order to stop the exploitative and deadly trade in conflict minerals. This EU legislation should serve as a model to create a positive dynamic in other parts of the world to put an end to the exploitation of minerals that are funding conflicts.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Trade in minerals such as gold, diamonds, tantalum, tin and copper fuels armed conflicts, particularly in Africa. To appropriate the land on which the minerals are located, armed gangs sow terror through crime and rape. The European Commission's initial draft on the trade in these "blood minerals", published in March 2014, was limited to an optional mechanism for self-certification of importers, which was derisory in view of the tragedies generated. Thanks to a left gathered in Parliament, we were able to find a majority to put in place legislation that obliges European companies or not to indicate the origin of minerals on the whole supply chain. An important step has been taken in the fight against the financing of conflicts in mining regions. This victory was achieved despite the protests of a large part of the right and the extreme right more concerned with serving the interests of a few firms than saving populations victims of armed gang violence. The same people who refuse to take in migrants in danger even though they have refused to address the causes of their exile.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Earnings from trade in minerals that have great development potential are often used to finance armed conflicts and I agree that we must not allow this harmful practice to continue. It is also of utmost importance to prevent the link between conflict and illegal exploitation of minerals in countries affected by conflict or high-risk areas. Many Member States really depend on the import of these ores and metals found in electrical appliances, which we use in everyday life . However, I cannot agree with the basic intention of the Regulation, which seeks to establish a self-targeting system by acting with due diligence in the supply chain in order to limit the opportunities for armed groups and security forces to trade in tin, tantalum, tungsten, their ores and gold. I do not believe that this way the desired effect can be achieved because the measures are based on a voluntary self-certation procedure by importers. I believe that such a requirement would lead to the imposition of costs and unnecessary administrative consequences, which would ultimately affect the competitiveness of SMEs who do not need the additional burden and therefore voted against it.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I have analysed the different elements of this proposal and in the end I also have to listen to my conscience. I believe the right thing to do is to have a mandatory certification for those who purchase metals or minerals for the production of goods such as our mobile phones, washing machines and fridges. This is a just thing to do when we know that, for example, the proceeds of conflict minerals and metals has been linked to the funding of militias in the ongoing Congolese conflict which has claimed the lives of 5.4 million people and displaced two million people. Of course we must make a clear distinction between legitimate mining and trading in blood-stained minerals globally. As I see it, the Commission proposals, which were mostly voluntary measures, did not go far enough.  I supported the amendments with mandatory schemes for smelters and refiners, which are the key players in this market and cover most of the global market.  I think that this is the right way forward as other sectors such as the diamond industry already have a mandatory labelling system and the United States has also passed mandatory legislation in this field.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This draft regulation sets out a laudable principle: that of not encouraging the financing of armed groups that participate in guerrilla and terrorist actions and aggravate civil and inter-ethnic wars, especially on the African continent. These conflicts are also fuelling the migratory flows of refugees seeking to flee the massacres. Therefore, we cannot turn a blind eye to this issue. However, this text will result in the economic and unilateral sanctioning of European companies importing minerals originating in conflict zones. Indeed, this new regulation will increase the processing costs of certain metals, which will weigh on the European steel industry. Finally, before regulating in the name of morality, the European Union would be wise to first control the use of its funds in certain areas. So I choose abstention.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which makes the regulations controlling the marketing and manufacture of minerals extracted in conflict zones mandatory. The struggle for the exploitation of these precious minerals involves massive human resources violations and in some cases wars. In plenary session, fundamental amendments have been introduced to ensure mandatory legislation linking the manufacture of products containing such minerals (Tablets, smartphones, light bulbs...) and not just foundries.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution concerning the self-certification of importers of minerals and metals originating in conflict-affected and high-risk areas, as I believe that this is a very significant step that Parliament should take in order to guarantee and secure the human rights of people living in the conflict minerals zones. With this resolution, it is also very important that European consumers will be able to avoid buying certain products that might consist of conflict minerals, and therefore stop indirectly financing conflicts and illegal armed groups. I strongly believe that this resolution and the creation of a European certification system for smelters and refiners will be the starting point for the further establishment of a transparency mechanism for the entire supply chain and for all key players in the minerals industry.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I supported the proposal because the text contained clear and clear indications on compulsory traceability and compliance with OECD rules throughout the supply chain, from extraction to distribution. It is important to combat all the proceeds from the exploitation of minerals in conflict and high-risk areas, thus pursuing responsible practices for supplying materials such as tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold. Importers must, in fact, recognise their capital role and follow a responsible path with regard to minerals and metals, relying on clean supply chains. Finally, it should be stressed that the approved system will not affect small and medium-sized enterprises and that opposition to a compulsory traceability system comes mainly from multinationals.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The objective of this regulation should be to gain greater control of certain minerals or metals originating in conflict and high-risk areas, in order to prevent them from financing destabilization and violence in areas where, on the contrary, the presence of these materials should serve the sustainable and peaceful development of the local economy. Regulation has enormous shortcomings that call into question its usefulness: the number of materials to be accredited is unjustifiably restricted; import control is left to the companies themselves, who cannot be expected to declare their activities in conflict zones; it is not taken into account that most of these materials are processed before entering the European market, so most traffic is excluded from this legislation. That's why I voted against it.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with S&D colleagues in favour of this resolution because I truly believe that a fully mandatory system covering all operators upstream and downstream needs to be put in place when it comes to conflict-minerals. Human rights abuses are common within the extractive industry and may include child labour, sexual violence, enforced disappearance, forced resettlement and the destruction of ritually or culturally significant sites.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. The conflict minerals dossier was high on the agenda this week. I have seen with my own eyes the conditions in which children and women had to mine these minerals in mines in conflict zones. Many of them took their lives. I am satisfied that, together with Louis Michel, I have been given the obligation to provide a minimum amount of origin information at every step of mining and production. This will in the long run prevent criminal and terrorist organisations from enriching themselves by exploiting the weak in extracting these minerals and from selling them on the European market.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The exploitation of minerals in conflict zones has been denounced for many years and has been the subject of large citizen mobilizations. The European Union imports a significant amount of these minerals (tin, tantalum, tungsten, gold...). Their trade is often the root cause of these conflicts. It is the source of massive corruption and fuels the financing of armed militias in these areas. These European companies are therefore largely complicit directly or indirectly in the crimes committed in these regions. At the time of the plenary vote, an alternative majority was established to expand the original legislative proposal in order to impose an obligation of transparency and, therefore, information on all companies on the supply chain. This may seem insufficient, but it is a first step.  The European Parliament has taken a position which will be submitted to the Council. Let us hope that this position will be maintained. Enabling mining wealth to be exploited for the benefit of the people is essential in many of the poorest countries. I hope that we can make some first steps in this area. To follow...

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 It is obvious the current and growing persistent shortage of raw materials globally. Important mineral resources with limited distribution on a planetary scale are in supply deficit. And it is no accident that some of the greatest reserves are in countries devastated by internal, regional conflicts, crimes against humanity, interference, permanent violations of their sovereignty and territorial integrity, almost always with the complicity of international organizations and foreign powers – interested in maintaining control of resources. This is the case of the Great Lakes region. It is appropriate to discuss mechanisms for the certification of importers of minerals from conflict and high-risk areas, creating traceability mechanisms to identify the raw materials originating in these areas. However, this proposal, which only covers a part of the minerals marketed and does not go beyond the first link in the value chain, deliberately forgetting the myriad of final and intermediate products where these raw materials are incorporated. You don't deserve our credit.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I have rejected the proposal for self-certification by importers of certain minerals and metals from high-risk areas. Admittedly, the introduction of such raw materials requires regulation in order to deprive rebels, etc., of the financing basis. However, the proposal put forward for this purpose is not strict enough and self-certification is an inappropriate means of ensuring this.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote was a great victory for progressives and in particular for the S&D Group.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. On 20 May 2015, Parliament voted on the resolution on "Self-certification by importers of certain minerals and metals from conflict and high-risk areas".  I rejected this resolution because it goes far beyond the self-imposed objective. It is true that there is indeed a problem with the use of raw material yields to finance civil wars. They keep the conflicts in these regions alive. I think it is a good welcome to establish self-certification of importers in order to resolve this issue. I therefore support the voluntary approach of the European Commission. However, the majority of Parliament has extended the proposal from voluntary self-certification to compulsory regulatory certification. I reject this wider proposal, supported by the majority of Parliament, to include all minerals and all companies that use these materials. The extent of the verification requirements overwhelms the economy and is not well related to the chance of achieving peace in the affected regions. Small and medium-sized enterprises in particular now have to make an enormous effort to prove the origin of the installed substances. It would have been better to confine ourselves first to the moderate voluntary scheme and then to review its successes later.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This vote is for action to exclude conflict minerals from EU markets, and make sure that products sold in the EU do not fuel armed militias or foster human rights violations in conflict areas. Under the proposals, companies must make reasonable checks to ensure the step behind them in the supply chain can verify where the product came from, which will help break the link between armed conflict and the minerals trade. Voluntary requirements have been in place for many years, but very few businesses have taken them up. These new mandatory requirements, while not burdensome on any one link in the supply chain, would make a huge difference to those on the ground in conflict areas. Labour MEPs voted in favour of these new requirements.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted for a voluntary certification system on the supply chain of importers of tin, tantalum and tungsten, their ores and gold - 3TG from conflict zones and high-risk areas. I believe that we need an integrated EU approach to these areas, and the report on minerals coming from conflict zones was a proposal that also involves empowering all actors involved in this sector and is an important pillar of the EU's integrated response. We need to strengthen European capacity in these areas, we need to educate and empower all actors involved, including EU industry, but also the governments of states facing local armed conflicts.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote we have achieved an extraordinary result: to exclude conflict minerals from European markets throughout the supply chain. I voted in favour of compulsory traceability of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold in order to sever the links between trade, the extraction of these minerals and the financing of armed conflicts.  We all know that negotiations with the Council and the Commission will be difficult, but the fact that Parliament has come out in favour of a compulsory traceability mechanism is an historic victory for the Socialist Group and an ethical turning point in the European Union's trade policy.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, by introducing the principle of traceability of metals from conflict zones, thanks to the decisive commitment of the Socialists and Democrats, wanted to point out that there can be no real development without respect for the dignity and life of people.  Europe is often identified only as a source of obligations, rules and sanctions; Today's vote has shown that we can and must continue to hope for a common future that favours the value of life over mere profit.   Now the Council and the Commission, which have to reformulate a legislative proposal, are taking account of Parliament's wishes.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Iuliu Winkler Report on the self-certification of importers of certain materials from the conflict and high-risk zone, in the belief that my vote contributed to protecting people's rights and to defending the european union industry.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The persistent scarcity of raw materials globally is at the root of many internal, regional conflicts, crimes against humanity, interference, permanent violations of their sovereignty and territorial integrity of states, almost always with the complicity of international organizations and foreign powers – interested in maintaining control of resources.  Despite the obvious limits of such mechanisms, we accept that it is appropriate to discuss mechanisms for certifying importers of minerals from conflict and high-risk areas, creating traceability mechanisms to identify raw materials originating in these areas.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on a proposal to reject a Commission delegated act, which conditionally allows the use of cadmium in illumination and display lighting applications. We believe it should only be our elected and accountable national governments that decide these things, not unelected EU Commissioners using the undemocratic method of delegated acts to pass wide-reaching rules. We totally oppose the EU deciding what can and cannot be sold on the British market. However, blocking this delegated act will potentially have a far reaching effect on a certain section of British industry. However, of course we recognise the consequences of allowing cadmium to continue to be used, especially when there is new technology in its infancy that does not use cadmium-based dot technology in display screens. UKIP fully supports the development of alternative technology to these hazardous substances.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on a proposal to reject a Commission delegated act, which conditionally allows the use of cadmium in illumination and display lighting applications. We believe it should only be our elected and accountable national governments that decide these things, not unelected EU Commissioners using the undemocratic method of delegated acts to pass wide-reaching rules. We totally oppose the EU deciding what can and cannot be sold on the British market. However blocking this delegated act will potentially have a far reaching effect on a certain section of British industry. However, of course we recognise the consequences of allowing cadmium to continue to be used, especially when there is new technology in its infancy that does not use cadmium-based dot technology in display screens. UKIP fully supports the development of alternative technology to these hazardous substances.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because Parliament exercises its power of scrutiny over the rules with which the European Commission seeks to impose exceptions to the rule by conferring on itself a political power which it does not have. Delegated acts allow parliament to oppose technical legislation developed by the Commission and in this particular case the Commission has introduced derogations from the requirements laid down in Directive 2011/65/EU on hazardous substances in electrical appliances. The Commission has sought to introduce these exceptions to benefit producers against the safety of European citizens. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution which rejects the delegated act.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ Cadmium is a carcinogenic substance  which, under the Restrictions of Hazardous Substances Directive has been banned in electronic products in the EU since June 2014, so there are no more products on the EU market which contain this substance.
