The Commission, in January this year, introduced a delegated act which would see cadmium quantum dots being allowed again in LCD TVs by allowing an exemption for its use.  There are already cadmium-free quantum dot TVs on the market so there is no need to reintroduce toxic cadmium to electronic products. It is vital that the protection of consumers’ and workers’ health is the priority and for this reason I voted in favour of this resolution to reject any reintroduction of cadmium electronic products into the market.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the objection of 30 January 2015. Commission Directive amending, in adapting to technical progress, provisions concerning the exemption from the use of cadmia in lighting installations and display lighting installations. I support the calls for the Commission to submit a new delegated act that takes into account Parliament's position.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Parliament rejects the European Commission's proposal for a delegated act because it considers that the exemption granted for the use of cadmium in screen lighting is based on an outdated situation since cadmium can already be replaced by quantum boxes. Given the danger of cadmium to human health and the damage it causes to the environment and technological developments, the use of cadmium for screen lighting should be banned as soon as possible.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This text relates to an amendment to Schedule III of the 2011/65/EU Directive of the European Parliament and the Council with regard to an exemption for cadmium in general lighting and screen lighting applications. It provides for a rejection of the delegated act and an update according to the technologies available in Europe. I also consider that the Commission's key justification for granting the new specific exemption is that "[i]t there are no quantum boxes without cadmium yet" and therefore that this justification is manifestly unfounded. So I voted for that point.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote this resolution opposing a delegated Directive of the Commission amending the current legislation on the restriction of the use of certain dangerous substances in electrical and electronic equipment. This directive does not fulfil the conditions for granting the derogations it wishes to introduce, nor has the technical deadlines for submitting applications for exemption been respected.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. When the revisions to the directives on waste electrical and electronic equipment were adopted in 2012, Parliament and the Council agreed to allow a transitional exemption from the use of cadmium for certain luminaires and quantum television screens. That exception expired last year, so the European Commission submitted a delegated act to extend the period until 2018 to which the Green Group has objected in view of the high toxicity of cadmium as a substance and the existence of alternatives whereas they consider that a postponement of the exemption is not justified. We Socialists agree that there is no reason to extend the deadline further and believe that industry must make an effort to enhance existing alternatives.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which addresses the issue of the exemption from the use of cadmium in lighting installations and display devices. The Commission has made it clear that there are not yet lighting LEDs with quantum dots ,whether with or without cadmia, and agrees that the positive environmental impact of their use could not be demonstrated. However, the Commission extended the general exemption for the use of cadmia quantum dots in lighting installations until 30 June 2017, thus allowing industry to apply for a specific exemption if such installations were already in the pre-production phase. In recent times, significant new developments have taken place with regard to the trading of devices using quantum dots without cadmia technology, which require a new assessment. The European Parliament therefore objected to the decision of 30 January 2015. Commission Delegated Directive amending, in adapting to technical progress, the provisions of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the exemption for the use of cadmime in lighting installations and display lighting installations.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ Cadmium is a carcinogenic substance  which, under the Restrictions of Hazardous Substances Directive has been banned in electronic products in the EU since June 2014 so there are no more products on the EU market which contain this substance. The Commission, in January this year, introduced a delegated act which would see cadmium quantum dots being allowed again in LCD TVs by allowing an exemption for its use.  There are already cadmium-free quantum dot TVs on the market so there is no need to reintroduce toxic cadmium to electronic products. It is vital that the protection of consumers’ and workers’ health is the priority and for this reason I voted in favour of this resolution to reject any reintroduction of cadmium electronic products into the market.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that a further assessment is needed regarding the exemption for cadmium in general lighting and lighting applications of display systems and that, therefore, the Commission should present a new proposal in this regard.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution deals with the ban on cadmium, a heavy metal that is harmful to the health of consumers as well as the environment. This metal is still used for the manufacture of LED screens as well as for lighting, thanks to an exemption valid until June 30, 2017. Given the technological advances made, cadmium is no longer essential for the manufacture of certain LED screens. In addition, this motion for a resolution opposes a delegated act so that the exemption planned until 2017 takes into account technological advances and that the Commission incorporates the position of the European Parliament. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 This directive aims to improve environmental performance at all stages of a product's life cycle. Some materials used in electronic products may lead to environmental and health hazards during their production or at the end of their life cycle. It is precisely for these reasons that the EU has restricted the use of these materials. The elimination of cadmium is an essential factor in achieving these objectives, and the delegated directive aims to eliminate the prohibition on the use of cadmium in lighting and lighting applications of display systems. Arguments such as the unavailability of cadmium-free quantum points at the technical level, bearing in mind that there is a wide range of TVs on the EU market based on this technology, although the energy-saving properties of cadmium-free quantum dots are similar to those with cadmium, are not convincing enough. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because such a derogation can only be addressed in the context of a prior assessment, which has so far not been carried out.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. This is the objection to a delegated Commission directive amending, adapting it to technical progress, Annex III to the RoHS Directive (restriction of the use of certain dangerous substances in electrical and electronic equipment). (a) extend until 30 June 2017 exemption 39, which becomes exemption 39 a) "II-VI LED cadmium with colour conversion (< 10 μg Cd per mm2 of light emitter surface) for use in lighting systems or solid state display"; b) introduces a new and more specific exemption 39 b) "cadmium at cadmium-based quantum dots (semiconductor nanocrystals) for downshift intended for use in display system lighting applications (< 0.2 μg Cd per mm2 display screen surface)", expiring on 30 June 2018. The delegated Directive does not comply with the conditions for granting an exemption laid down in Article 5(1)(a) of the RoHS Directive for both exemptions. In particular, the reasons given for exemption 39 (b) are based on an obsolete situation as regards the feasibility of replacing cadmium in quantum dots. In addition, the Commission received the application for renewal of the exemption 5 months behind the deadlines laid down in the RoHS Directive. Nevertheless, the Commission has accepted it.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of Parliament's resolution on cadmium in general lighting and lighting applications of display systems. The resolution raised objections to the Commission Delegated Directive of 30 January 2015 amending, adapting it to technical progress, Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards the exemption for cadmium in general lighting and lighting applications of display systems.  Given that cadmium is a highly dangerous toxic substance, I believe that extending an existing derogation, while granting a new derogation for cadmium, should be avoided in order to guarantee the protection of the environment and public health. Furthermore, the derogation could also give the industry the wrong signal by discourating it from investing in innovation and research in order to find alternatives to cadmium. Finally, the derogation could lead to market distortions due to the import of electrical and electronic equipment containing cadmium from third countries to the detriment of innovative and environmentally sensitive companies operating in Europe. For all these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of Parliament's objection.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the final resolution and against the two separates (technical correction after clarification with the Commission).  Cadmium is a carcinogenic substance (the by-product of zinc and copper production) which, under the Restrictions of Hazardous Substances Directive has been banned in electronic products in the EU since June 2014, so there are no more products on the EU market which contain this substance. The Commission, in January this year, introduced a delegated act which would see cadmium quantum dots being allowed again in LCD TVs by allowing an exemption for its use.  There are already cadmium-free quantum dot TVs on the market and the claim from cadmium quantum dot lobbyists that there are not is untrue. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on a proposal to reject a Commission delegated act, which conditionally allows the use of cadmium in illumination and display lighting applications. We believe it should only be our elected and accountable national governments that decide these things, not unelected EU Commissioners using the undemocratic method of delegated acts to pass wide-reaching rules. We totally oppose the EU deciding what can and cannot be sold on the British market. However, blocking this delegated act will potentially have a far reaching effect on a certain section of British industry. However, of course we recognise the consequences of allowing cadmium to continue to be used, especially when there is new technology in its infancy that does not use cadmium-based dot technology in display screens. UKIP fully supports the development of alternative technology to these hazardous substances.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Cadmium is a carcinogenic chemical element. The so-called RoHS (Restriction of Hazardous Substances) directive severely restricts its use in electrical and electronic equipment placed on the European Union market. On 1 July 2014, the exemption for its use in general lighting and lighting applications of display systems (e.g. LEDs) expired. The European Commission would like to renew this exemption and our M5S delegation, together with a very large majority of the European Parliament, opposed this choice, in order to protect the health of European citizens.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to ban this heavy and dangerous metal, cadmium. The text also calls on the Commission to integrate the position of parliamentarians on the subject. The parliamentarians of the ENVI committee wanted to draw the Commission's attention to a problem already anticipated by industrialists in the field. Cadmium, which has known harmful effects on health and the environment, is already excluded from the manufacture of screens by two of the largest distributors on the market, Samsung and Nanoco, which have replaced it with "quantum boxes", nanostructures of semiconductors without cadmium; only large U.S. companies continue to endanger consumers by continuing to use cadmium. I welcome Parliament's desire to ban this product while asking the Commission to respect the views of parliamentarians on this issue.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 On 30 January 2015, the Commission Delegated Directive amended Annex III to Directive 2001/65/EU on the restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment (RoHS Directive), annex II of which limits, among other things, the use of cadmium in such equipment. In paragraph 39, Annex III provided for a derogation for LED cadmium expiring on 1 July 2014.  The Commission, after receiving an application to extend this exemption until 30 June 2017, approved the delegated directive. However, it was found that: (1) the Commission's statement that led products (with or without cadmium) referred to in paragraph 39 did not exist and that, as a result, an impact assessment could not be carried out, was incorrect and (2) the request for exemption went beyond the deadline and was judged by the experts appointed by the Commission to be excessive. The European Commission is therefore invited to take account of the position and objections raised by the EP and to carry out a re-evaluation in order to present a new delegated act.  In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution objecting to the Commission delegated directive of 30 January 2015 amending Annex III to Parliament and Council Directive 2011/65/EU as regards the exemption for cadmium in general lighting and lighting applications of display systems. Indeed, as recent technological developments have led to the introduction into the Union market of new equipment, in particular a new complete line of models of television sets based on cadmium-free quantum dots, I share the concerns about extending the exemption for the ban on the use of cadmium. In addition, according to the information available and the expert reports of some independent consultants, given two televisionsets of the same size, the one equipped with a display system with cadmium-free quantum dots seems to show lower energy consumption than the model with quantum dots containing cadmium, and the color rendering tests, compared to the relevant standard, have shown that display systems based on quantum dots without cadmium allow equivalent if not higher results.  I therefore support the call in the text of the resolution voted for a rapid re-evaluation of the exemption in force with a view to lifting it.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Annex III of the proposal lists a derogation for ‘Cadmium in colour converting for use in solid state illumination or display systems’, which is an application for a new exemption with a different formulation and not a renewal of an existing exemption as delegated act.  For this reason, the application was acceptable for the Parliament and I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution as it calls on the Commission to revise its delegated act, which provides in point 39 of Annex III for the extension of the exemption until 2017 of LED cadmium and one until 2018 for cadmium in quantum dots.  The Commission's delegated act is not justified, as the market is absolutely ready to produce general lighting applications and display systems without any presence of cadmium, which is dangerous to human health. The same independent consultants responsible for assessing the application on behalf of the Commission came to the same conclusion and openly recommended that the extension should not be granted.  I voted against recital F and paragraph 5 because, of the exemption applications submitted by lighting application manufacturers, one was submitted beyond the deadline, and despite this infringement of the regulation it was also accepted by the Commission.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because Parliament exercises its scrutiny power over the rules with which the European Commission seeks to impose exceptions to the rule by conferring on itself a political power which it does not have. Delegated acts allow parliament to oppose technical legislation developed by the Commission and in this particular case the Commission has introduced derogations from the requirements laid down in Directive 2011/65/EU on hazardous substances in electrical appliances. The Commission has sought to introduce these exceptions to benefit producers against the safety of European citizens. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution which rejects the delegated act.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that extending an existing derogation granted to cadmium is bad for the environment and for public health. In my opinion it could also send a wrong signal to industry which may, as a consequence, consider discontinuing investment in innovation and research into cadmium-free alternatives. The motion for a resolution objects to the proposed delegated act that extends the life of cadmium in television displays until June 2018 and thus I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This motion seeks to object to the adoption by the European Commission of a Commission delegated directive amending, for its adaptation to technical progress, Annex III of the 2011/65/EU Directive on an exemption for cadmium in general lighting and screen lighting applications. Point 39 of the said annex of the legislation on limiting the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment provides for a derogation for cadmium intended for use in lighting or display systems, whose expiration date is 1 July 2014, with the possibility of being extended if the progress of scientific and technical progress does not allow the replacement of this substance in electrical and electronic equipment by another product. The delegated directive adopted by the European Commission extends the exemption prescribed in point 39 until 30 June 2017, which, according to expert assessments and the progress of scientific and technical progress, is not justified, as considerable changes have been observed regarding the availability on the market of products using cadmium-free quantum box technology. Considering, therefore, that such an exemption no longer needs to be, I voted in favour of the objection.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European Union has standards to limit the use of harmful substances in electrical and electronic equipment. However, limitations may be exempted where warranted. This is the case with cadmium, which is used for lighting and ignition of television screens, tablets or computers.  In a delegated act, the Commission extended the exemptions for cadmium. However, it did not have sufficient support for this extension. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Commission to carry out a new assessment.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Various scientific studies have shown that cadmium, a heavy metal used in the screens of some LCD televisions and other electronic devices, poses high risks to human health. However, there is now a whole range of new models of televisions on the EU market using cadmium-free quantum boxes available from leading outlets in the Member States. That is why the European Parliament has refused to extend the exemption that cadmium has previously enjoyed in lighting and illumination applications, for lack of any other solution.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on an exemption for cadmium in general lighting and screen lighting applications. Cadmium is an environmental and health risk. That is why in May 2015 I sent a written question to the European Commission in which I asked him about his intentions. There are already other, much safer and more environmentally friendly solutions. This means that we must not wait until 2017 in order to outlaw the cadmium of the above elements, as understood by the Commission's delegated act. Indeed, we must encourage the approach of scientists and companies who have developed these new technologies and who consider cadmium to be a risk that can no longer be taken.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ Directive 2011/65/EU (RoHS Directive) restricts the use of cadmium in electrical and electronic equipment placed on the market in the EU. Cadmium is carcinogenic, and can also cause acute flu-like symptoms, bronchitis and pneumonia.  The proposed delegated act will delay the restriction on cadmium for equipment where it is believed there is currently no safer alternative on the market. It proposes that the restriction on using cadmium in colour converting LEDs such as lamps be delayed until 30 June 2017, and for use in solid state illumination or display systems such as in televisions, until 30 June 2018. The ECR Group supports the objection resolution and believes that better regulation and innovation should be championed in this area.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I absolutely support this proposal as the EC has failed to shed light on whether such a petition was adopted after the deadline. There have also been many important new developments regarding the commercial availability of cadmium-based quantum point products and this delegated act needs to be reviewed and, in any event, to prevent legal uncertainty and illegal action.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to object to a delegated act which would have extended the derogation for cadmium in colour converting LEDs (e.g. lamps) until 30 June 2017, and use in solid state illumination/display systems (e.g. televisions) until 30 June 2017. As the rapporteur on the RoHS legislation in 2009 I know how important this decision was and that it was indeed in the interests of my constituents in Wales.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Directive on the restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment limits, inter alia, the use of cadmium in electrical and electronic equipment. The extension of exemption 39 concerns two different applications of quantum dots with cadmium: one concerns the use in solid state lighting and the other concerns visualization systems. The Commission explicitly states that quantum dot LEDs (with and without cadmium) for lighting are not yet available and recognises that their positive environmental impact has therefore not been demonstrated. This delegated Directive does not comply with the conditions laid down and the justification given for exemption 39 b) is based on an outdated situation in relation to the feasibility of replacing cadmium in quantum dots.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution objects to the Directive amending, for the purpose of adapting to technical progress, Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU with regard to an exemption for cadmium in lighting and lighting applications for monitors. In January 2015, the European Commission proposed a delegated act extending cadmium life on televisions until June 2018. The Commission thus reintroduces cadmium into the EU market, as manufacturers had already removed it from lighting and backlighting applications of cadmium monitors in light of the end of this exemption in July 2014. The Commission's justification is that "cadmium-free quantum dots are not yet technically available". However, according to the Commission's explanamis, for one of the applications, there are no products on the market using quantum dots (Cd and Cd—free), so it is difficult to understand why such an exemption would still be necessary. And, in fact, the Commission consultants who assessed this request for exemption do not consider it justified at this stage. In addition, according to industry information, there are at least two companies that offer Cd-free quantum dots, and there are products with this technology already on the market. As such, the Commission's justification seems to be incorrect.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution bearing in mind the objection to the Commission delegated directive amending, adapting it to technical progress, Annex III to the RoHS Directive (restriction of the use of certain dangerous substances in electrical and electronic equipment).

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of amending the directive on the exemption for the use of cedium in general lighting and display lighting applications, since the text condemns a Commission action (to extend the exemption for the use of cedium in display lighting and lighting applications), which is unjustified, irregular and dangerous to the environment and European citizens.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of objecting to Commission Delegated Directive of 30 January 2015 amending, for the purposes of adapting to technical progress, Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards an exemption for cadmium in illumination and display lighting applications, considering the fact that rejection of the delegated directive therefore does not ban cadmium quantum dots, but only triggers a new assessment and that therefore there will be no market distortions, as the current exemption stays valid until revocation, with an additional grace period to be granted thereafter.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. Directive 2011/65/EU on restrictions on the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment currently restricts, inter alia, the use of cadmium in these appliances. The RUSP Directive provides for exemptions from the restrictions laid down, provided that the inclusion of these substances does not weaken the degree of protection of health and the environment. On the other hand, there do not appear to already be televisions with quantum points of cadmium on the Union market. Quantum points without cadmium are not only technically available, but a whole line of televisions based on this technology is already widely available on the Union market. That's why I voted for it.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Given the rapid technological progress of the market and the re-evaluation required by new products and found based on cadmium-free quantum dot technology and considering the request for exemption 39b as obsolete, I welcome the motion for a resolution on the Commission directive amending Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU on the exemption of cadmium in display system lighting applications.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed delegated act will not only permit the use of a carcinogenic substance in the European market but will also stifle innovation in cadmium-free technology. European regulation should be designed not only to restrict materials that pose an unacceptable public health risk but should also favour innovation. The proposals are out of date and are a symptom of bad regulation. Regulations in areas of technology need to react quickly to constant change, not only for public health but so that European technology firms are not placed at a competitive disadvantage within international markets. For these reasons I support this objection to the proposed delegated act.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this amendment because the restriction of hazardous substances directive (RoHS) adopted in 2011 exempted the use of cadmium in LEDs and screen applications until 1 July 2014. In January 2015, the Commission proposed a Delegated Act extending the life of cadmium on television until June 2018. In this way, the Commission effectively reintroduces cadmium to the European market once cadmium televisions have already been withdrawn from the market in view of the end of that exemption provided for in the regulation for the past July 2014.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I  voted in support of the report as the justification given for exemption 39(b) is based on an outdated situation with regard to the practicability of the replacement of cadmium in quantum dots. It therefore calls for a swift reassessment of the existing exemption 39 with a view to its revocation.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on Commission Delegated Directive .../.../EU, amending Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards the exemption from the use of cadmi terms in lighting installations and display lighting installations, as the European Commission has clarified that there are not yet lighting LEDs with quantum dots , whether with cadmia or without it, and agrees that the positive effects of their use on the environment could not be demonstrated. I therefore support the EP's position that the justification for the exemption is not updated and therefore the resolution calls for an urgent reassessment of the existing exception.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution objecting to an exemption for cadmium in illumination and display lighting applications. The Restriction of Hazardous Substances Directive exemptions from the cadmium ban for certain LED lamps and displays were only supposed to last until 2014; however, the Commission wish to prolong this as to as far as 2018.  I feel a future exemption by the Commission cannot be justified as the current one is already outdated and doesn’t recognise new developments in alternative, cadmium-free technologies which have already reached the EU market. Cadmium is a highly toxic and carcinogenic metal and this objection is in line with the aims of the Restriction of Hazardous Substances Directive to minimise the dangers to human health and to the environment. I hope following the vote in favour of the Resolution the Commission will act quickly to reassess the exemption in light of the latest evidence and come to a new decision.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. Cadmium is a heavy metal that is dangerous to health and the environment; it is banned in many applications. However, the European Commission has granted an exemption for TV screens, including LED screens and lighting. This exemption is valid until June 30, 2017. However, the technology has, as often, anticipated legislation and there are now "quantum boxes", semiconductor nanostructures, available on the market that can be cadmium-free. The new technology is proposed by two companies, Samsung in Korea and Nanoco in England. Quantum boxes with cadmium are made by three American companies. Cadmium is a concern and my colleague Mireille d'Ornano's office has also questioned the Commission on the possibility of a ban.  This resolution therefore objects to a delegated act so that the exemption takes into account the technical progress and that the Commission incorporates Parliament's position on the subject.  This motion for a resolution therefore calls for the rejection of a delegated act. It calls for the opinion of elected officials to be taken into account and is aimed at banning a dangerous product. So I voted for it.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this amendment because the restriction of hazardous substances directive (RoHS) adopted in 2011 exempted the use of cadmium in LEDs and screen applications until 1 July 2014. In January 2015, the Commission proposed a Delegated Act extending the life of cadmium on television until June 2018. In this way, the Commission effectively reintroduces cadmium to the European market once cadmium televisions have already been withdrawn from the market in view of the end of that exemption provided for in the regulation for the past July 2014.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour by emphasizing the importance of the exemption for cadmium in lighting applications. The manufacture of televisions without quantum cadmium points on the Union market should be used as a model to allow these technologies to be installed in other lighting products with quantum points of cadmium.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's Delegated Directive amending, with a purpose of adapting to technical progress, Annex III. Directive 2011/65EU of the European Parliament and the Council as regards the exemption for the use of kadmi in screen lighting and illumination refusing a delegated Act of the European Commission on the ground that the exception of the ban on kadmi for individual LED lamps and displays is inadmissible. Kadmium is a highly toxic substance that should have been completely banned by 2014, especially since alternatives have developed in the meantime that do not involve the use of kadmi. In my view, the exception of the use of kadmi, which stretched to mid-2017 for light bulbs and by mid-2018 for displays, would encourage unnecessary entry into the EU market of products containing the substance. Therefore, I oppose such a solution.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The European Commission has granted an exemption from a ban on cadmium for TELEVISION screens and lighting. Cadmium is a heavy metal that is particularly harmful to public health and the environment. However, some companies have anticipated legislation by creating quantum boxes, semiconductor nanostructures, and cadmium-free. These cadmium-free quantum boxes have been put on the market by three U.S. companies. The cadmium is of particular concern to National Front MPs and we are trying to get it banned by all means. The resolution presented here provides that the exemption takes into account the technical advance, which allows to free itself from the use of cadmium and thus to prohibit it in all areas. So I decided to vote for this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on a proposal to reject a Commission delegated act, which conditionally allows the use of cadmium in illumination and display lighting applications. We believe it should only be our elected and accountable national governments that decide these things, not unelected EU Commissioners using the undemocratic method of delegated acts to pass wide reaching rules. We totally oppose the EU deciding what can and can’t be sold on the British market.  However, blocking this delegated act will potentially have a far reaching effect on a certain section of British industry. However, of course we recognise the consequences of allowing cadmium to continue to be used, especially when there is new technology in its infancy that doesn’t use cadmium-based dot technology in display screens. UKIP fully supports the development of alternative technology to these hazardous substances.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution objecting to the Commission's proposal to keep cadmium in certain electronic and lighting products. Despite its harmfulness, cadmium was exempt from use in some European electronics and lighting products. The Commission wanted to maintain this exemption at a time when new processes for making these cadmium-free objects are possible. Therefore, the exemption is expired and deserves to be withdrawn. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of objection to the delegated directive amending the provisions for a cadmium exemption in general lighting and screen lighting applications.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Cadmium, a toxic material found in numerous LED lamps and televisions, should be banned. Not only because of its toxicity, but also because of formal criteria – the request for an extension of the transitional period for the abolition of cadmium has been tabled well after the official deadline – the request should be approved. However, I am abstaining because the text makes a similar argument to what was once the case with the abolition of the light bulb.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. \u2012 The Directive on the restriction of dangerous substances adopted in 2011 temporarily removed from its scope until July 2014 the use of cadmium in LEDs for lighting and display components. However, in January this year, the Commission surprisingly proposed, using a delegated act, a further extension of the use of cadmium in televisions until June 2018. From my point of view, the Commission thus essentially wanted to reintroduce cadmium to the EU market, because, with a view to ending the original exemption in July 2014, some producers have already fully proceeded to withdraw cadmium from the products produced by them. The Commission's reasoning is that quantum dots without cadmium are not yet technically available. From my point of view, however, this is merely a trade conflict between two groups of producers, where some have already developed and successfully implemented the technology, others have not yet, so they are asking the Commission for more time. In view of this and on the basis of the analysis provided by the Legal Department of the European Parliament, which assured us that the refusal of this delegated act does not imply a ban on cadmium in quantum dots, as the original exception remains in force, I have decided to support a resolution that will not allow the use of cadmium in diodes to be extended. This is also because the resolution supported by me calls for a re-assessment of the extension of the exemption.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Taking note that the RoHS Directive restricts, among other things, the use of cadmium in electrical and electronic equipment (restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment), it can be seen that the market has developed important developments since then, especially from the point of view of available techniques. In fact, the properties of cadmium-free quantum dots in terms of energy saving can be expected to be similar to those of quantum dots containing cadmium.  In the light of this, and with a view to protecting the right to health, I voted in favour.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. This proposal aims to amend Schedule III of the European Parliament and Council's 2011/65/EU Directive on an exemption on cadmium in general lighting and screen lighting applications. In particular, it requires updating according to the technologies known in the EU and therefore rejecting the delegated act.  Moreover, the commission's reason for renewing the exemption, namely that there would not yet be a quantum box without cadmium, seems to me to be perfectly illegitimate and inoperative. So I voted in favour of that point.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted for it. The aim of this resolution is to ban cadmium, a heavy metal that is harmful to health and the environment. There is an exemption valid until June 30, 2017 for TV screens and lighting. Cadmium is an important subject on which it is indeed useful to legislate, especially since technology allows the manufacture of devices without cadmium. This resolution takes this possibility into account and wishes to object to a delegated act so that the exemption is no longer possible, since it calls for the rejection of the delegated act with the expected consequence of banning a dangerous product; I support this resolution.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against it because I believe that the Commission's proposal in this case exceptionally means fewer regulations and unnecessary bans.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Kadmium (Cd) is a silver-white, soft and plastic metal that can be cut with a knife, dragged into wires and forged into leaves, and used to cover other metals, especially iron and steel. Due to the toxicity of the chemical and its compounds and the development of awareness for the care of the environment, the chemical begins to be decomptioned and is substituted with replacement material. Directive 2011/65/EU restricting the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment limits, inter alia, the use of kadmi in electrical and electronic equipment, but also states exemptions from restrictions. I supported the objection to the Commission's Delegated Directive amending annexes to adapt to technical progress, with regard to the exemption for the use of kadmi in screen lighting and illumination. The Commission argues that the kadmium is used in screens and that such displays will have a beneficial effect due to their low energy consumption and that quantum dots without kadmi are not yet technically available. The resolution calls for the exemption to be repealed and for the Commission to submit a new delegated act that will take parliament's position into account, as the development of technology today produces screens that do not contain toxic kadmium.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I was among the 618 Members who voted in favour. 33 were against, 28 abstained. Lighting, as well as other EU-like areas, are all strictly regulated.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the delegated directive .. /.../EU of the Commission amending, with a view to adapting to technical progress, Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards an exception for the use of cedium in general and screen lighting applications, since it calls on the Commission to submit a new delegated act taking into account Parliament's position and, on the other hand, asks the Commission to explain why it accepted an application submitted five months after the deadline.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal because I share the concerns that lead to the objection to Commission Delegated Directive of 30 January 2015 amending, for the purposes of adapting to technical progress, Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards an exemption for cadmium in illumination and display lighting applications.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the ban on cadmium. This heavy metal is dangerous to health and the environment and is prohibited in most products except for a few TV screens, including LED screens, and for lighting. Another solution to this metal currently exists on the market. This motion for a resolution calls for the rejection of a delegated act, calls for the opinion of elected representatives on this subject to be taken into account and aims, in the long run, to ban this dangerous product, so I am in force.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the delegated directive on the exemption of cadmium in general lighting and lighting applications. Given the important developments that the market has seen, regulation allows a useful and systemically managed development of technologies. This document initiates a new assessment which does not result in market distortions, since the current exemption remains in force until the withdrawal plus a subsequent grace period.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the Commission's delegated directive. On the one hand, since the deadlines for submissions were not met and, on the other hand, such a regulation would be perfectly sensible and effective, abstention was the only logical consequence.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In 2011, the EU adopted a directive on limiting the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment, mainly cadmium. However, a waiver was provided until 2014 for "cadmium in light-emitting diodes (LEDs) for use in solid-state lighting or source display systems."  In a delegated act the Commission extended this exemption to 2017 considering that technological advances do not allow the absence of cadmium: "There are no quantum boxes without cadmium yet". This assertion is unfounded, for example there are "ranges of new models of televisions using quantum boxes without cadmium". The resolution opposes the entry into force of the delegated act which serves industrialists with little concern for the environment. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have expressed my vote in favour of the European Parliament's objection to the delegated act on the matter in question.  The Commission's Delegated Directive extends an exemption for a longer period, an exemption which may be relevant in the future but which can only be granted on the basis of a careful and appropriate assessment.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution and object to the Commission’s delegated regulation as I support the conclusions of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Commission Delegated Directive ../…/EU amending, for the purposes of adapting to technical progress, Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards an exemption for cadmium in illumination and display lighting applications.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2011/65/EU on the restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment, in Article 4(1), limits, inter alia, the use of cadmium in electrical and electronic equipment. Annex III to that Directive provides for exemptions from the restrictions provided for in Article 4(1). Point 39 of Annex III contains a derogation for 'Cadmium present in colour conversion LEDs II-VI (content less than 10 μg Cd per mm2 of light emission surface) for use in solid state or display lighting systems' which expires on 1 July 2014. The Commission indicated that it received an application for renewal of exemption 39 in December 2012 and a related application for a more restricted and specific exemption for the use of cadmium in quantum dots on monitors in May 2013. Applications for renewal of an exemption must be submitted up to 18 months before the exemption expires; application for the specific exemption was submitted after that deadline. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This proposal aims to amend Schedule III of the European Parliament and Council's 2011/65/EU Directive on an exemption on cadmium in general lighting and screen lighting applications. In particular, it requires updating according to the technologies known in the EU and therefore rejecting the delegated act.  Moreover, the commission's reason for renewing the exemption, namely that there would not yet be a quantum box without cadmium, seems to me to be perfectly illegitimate and inoperative. So I voted in favour of that point.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We support the resolution on the exemption of cadmium from lighting applications of display systems because we believe that the Commission's delegated directive of 30 January 2015 does not comply with the conditions relating to the exemption of cadmium contained in Article 5(l)(a) of the Directive on the restriction of the use of certain dangerous substances in electrical and electronic equipment. That is why we agree with the request made to the Commission to present a new version of the delegated act which takes account of the position of the rapporteur and Parliament as a whole.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ Cadmium is a carcinogenic substance  which, under the Restrictions of Hazardous Substances Directive has been banned in electronic products in the EU since June 2014, so there are no more products on the EU market which contain this substance. The Commission, in January this year, introduced a delegated act which would see cadmium quantum dots being allowed again in LCD TVs by allowing an exemption for its use.  There are already cadmium-free quantum dot TVs on the market so there is no need to reintroduce toxic cadmium to electronic products. It is vital that the protection of consumers’ and workers’ health is the priority and for this reason I voted in favour of this resolution to reject any reintroduction of cadmium electronic products into the market.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution objecting to the Commission's delegated directive amending Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of cadmium in lighting and visualisation systems for the purpose of adapting to technical progress. I am of the opinion that the exemption for the use of cadmium, which concerns a wider range of lighting and visual technology (typically mobile phones, monitors, televisions, tablets), is now justified. Generally speaking, while I support reducing health risks, cadmium-free technologies do not seem ready to meet market requirements today, for example due to low energy efficiency and low-life problems. According to my knowledge, there are not enough technologies on the global market without the presence of cadmium. I am afraid that invalidating the exemption will mean thwarting investments made by the lighting industry in particular in order to improve energy efficiency, which is why I think it may be premature.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The protection of our health by curbing cadmium when used in lighting fixtures is to be highlighted positively. It is unacceptable for the Commission to accept proposals for exemptions for the use of cadmium in LED months after a set 'deadline'. However, the proposal also links aspects that have the tinge of over-regulation and impracticality. That is why I abstained.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This resolution, which concerns an exemption for cadmium in general screen lighting, invites the Commission to present a new delegated act taking parliament's position into account. Indeed, in a 2011 directive restricting hazardous substances, an exemption was made for the use of cadmium in the colour lighting of screens. With this exemption expiring by 1 July 2014, the Commission has proposed a delegated act extending this deadline to June 2018, while the majority of manufacturers have already withdrawn cadmium from televisions, rendering the extension unfounded. I supported that resolution.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because the subject needs further analysis.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the Commission's delegated directive of 30 January 2015 amending, for the purposes of adaptation to technical progress, Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards the exemption for cadmium in lighting and display applications, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 The toxic properties of the chemical are the reason for its inclusion in the list of Directive 2011/65/EU on the restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment. This Delegated Commission Directive is surprising, and even more days of justification in the introductory text in addition to the act. In my view, the reasons for the exemption for restricting the use of kadmi in screen lighting and illumination are neither valid nor justified. Even more surprising is the acceptance of the waiver application submitted outside the deadline for equipment that is not yet available on the market or is yet to come on the EU market. In my home country, we would rightly call this procedure a bargain, which is at the very limit of legality or even illegal if inaccurate data is given or incorrectly argued reasons to push through a legislative act. That is why I support the adoption of this resolution and am indeed asking the Commission to explain the reasons why this Delegated Directive was adopted.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This resolution, submitted by the Green/S-D/GUE groups, deals with the ban on cadmium, a heavy metal that is dangerous to health and the environment. There is an exemption from this ban for TV screens, including LED screens and lighting. The exemption is valid until June 30, 2017. However, the technology has, as often, anticipated legislation and there are now "quantum boxes", nanostructures of semiconductors available on the market that can be cadmium-free. The new technology is proposed by two companies, Samsung in Korea and Nanoco in England. Quantum boxes with cadmium are made by three American companies. This resolution therefore objects to a delegated act so that the exemption takes into account the technical progress and that the Commission incorporates Parliament's position on the subject. Considering that the text calls for the rejection of a delegated act, calls for the opinion of elected officials to be taken into account and aims to ban a dangerous product, I vote for it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. \u2012 I support the proposal for a resolution on amending, for the purpose of adapting to technical progress, Annex III. Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and the Council as regards the exemption for kadmium in applications in screen lighting and lighting, which asks the Commission to submit a new delegated act that will take into account Parliament's position.  In accordance with Article 5 (a) (a) of paragraph 1, exemptions shall be made in Annex III, provided that this does not impair the environmental and health protection prescribed by Regulation (EC) No 100/2013. 1907/2006 and if any of the following conditions are met: if their elimination or replacement by modifications in design or materials and components that do not require any of the materials or substances listed in Annex II is not feasible for scientific or technical reasons; where it is not possible to guarantee the reliability of substitutes; or if the overall adverse effects on the environment, health and consumer safety caused by the replacement are likely to be greater than the overall benefit of that environmental, health and consumer safety substitute.  Also, independent consultants assessed the requirements on behalf of the Commission and concluded that it was not possible to justify the illumination exemption at that time, and therefore explicitly opposed it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I supported the proposal for a resolution on the Commission's delegated directive on amending, in order to adapt to technical progress, Annex III. Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and the Council on exemptions for kadmium in applications in screen lighting and illumination. The Commission clearly states that LEDs for illumination with (from or without kandi) are not yet technically available and it is clear on this basis that their beneficial environmental impact cannot be demonstrated. However, despite this, the Commission extended the general exemption for kamadi quantum point lighting devices until 30 June 2017, allowing lighting industries to submit a specific requirement for them, as these devices were already in the pre-production phase.  In my view, the rejection of the Delegated Directive does not mean that the kadmium in quantum dots will be prohibited, but that a new impact assessment will be made and that competition is not distorted for the same reason, as the current exemption is valid until it is repealed, with an additional grace period to be applied thereafter.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I shared the objections to the Commission's delegated directive. A re-evaluation is needed as a result of developments in the commercial availability of products based on cadmium-free quantum dot technology. I am in favour of the resolution: as it is, the delegated directive cannot enter into force. Even if the directive does not enter into force, and it is important to emphasise this, there will be no market distortions, as the current exemption remains in force until it is lifted plus a subsequent grace period.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted in favour of the objection to the Commission's EU Delegate Directive, amending Annex III of the European Parliament and Council's 2011/65/EU Directive for an exemption for cadmium in general lighting and screen lighting applications for its adaptation to technical progress. I voted for this text and I stress that the original delegated act requires some modifications and improvements to be fully implemented and applicable.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on a proposal to reject a Commission delegated act, which conditionally allows the use of cadmium in illumination and display lighting applications. We believe it should only be our elected and accountable national governments that decide these things, not unelected EU Commissioners using the undemocratic method of delegated acts to pass wide-reaching rules. We totally oppose the EU deciding what can and can’t be sold on the British market.  However, blocking this delegated act will potentially have a far-reaching effect on a certain section of British industry. However, of course we recognise the consequences of allowing cadmium to continue to be used, especially when there is new technology in its infancy that doesn’t use cadmium-based dot technology in display screens. UKIP fully supports the development of alternative technology to these hazardous substances.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Cadmium has been classified as a human carcinogen by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) since 1993, which means its dangerousness. This heavy metal is found in products as varied as batteries, welds, paint pigments, fertilizers and pesticides, but also in general lighting and screen lighting applications.  It is this latter case that justifies the objection adopted this afternoon, almost unanimously by MEPs, to the Commission's proposal to extend the exemption for this substance in the RoHS (Restriction of Hazardous Substances) directive. I agree with the objections of the European Parliament, for at least two reasons: The first is linked to the very principle of this legislation which since July 2006 prohibits the use of dangerous substances such as lead, mercury, cadmium, hexavalent chromium or polybromodyphenylethers (PBDEs). The second reason is the cadmium exemption on lighting applications, such as LED lamps, which normally expired on July 1, 2014. There is therefore no justification for extending the exemption as the European Commission wants, which must not compromise with the health of European consumers.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Directive submitted by the Commission does not prohibit the use of cadmium-comed quantum dots in the application of lighting and backlighting of monitors. It requires only a new evaluation, since the resolution does not meet some of the conditions laid down. I believe that the Commission should put forward a new proposal which complies with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and, above all, guarantees consumer safety.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. When the revisions to the directives on waste electrical and electronic equipment were adopted in 2012, Parliament and the Council agreed to allow a transitional exemption from the use of cadmium for certain luminaires and quantum television screens. That exception expired last year, so the European Commission submitted a delegated act to extend the period until 2018 to which the Green Group has objected in view of the high toxicity of cadmium as a substance and the existence of alternatives whereas they consider that a postponement of the exemption is not justified. We Socialists agree that there is no reason to extend the deadline further and believe that industry must make an effort to enhance existing alternatives.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Yesterday, by a very large majority (618 votes in support, 33 against and 28 abstentions), the European Parliament vetoed the Commission's plan to authorise, by delegated act and as a derogation, the prolonged use of cadmium in the applications of illumination or lighting of television screens using quantum dot technology.  Cadmium, a carcinogenic heavy metal, is one of the substances whose use is limited in the European Union under the Directive on the Limitation of Dangerous Substances in Electrical and Electronic Equipment (Eu directive 2011/65/EU). Although the Commission has invoked the need to adapt this legislation to technical progress and has argued that quantum dots without cadmium are not yet technically available to justify its proposal to exempt cadmium from the provisions of the directive until July 2017, its argument has not convinced us. Other solutions exist and a range of televisions using cadmium-free quantum dot technology is widely available on the European market. In other words, the draft legislation was not justified.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission delegated directive amending Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU. Although cadmium has been classified as a dangerous substance to be banned in electrical and electronic equipment placed on the market, as set out in Directive 2011/65/EU, this material has been exempted, as provided for in Annex III to that Directive. The exemption of cadmium, supported here, depends on the fact that this material is the basis of quantum dots, a cutting-point technology that offers considerable advantages in terms of energy efficiency and color rendering. The vote in favour of the delegated directive therefore makes it possible not to hinder scientific progress in this area.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this amendment because the restriction of hazardous substances directive (RoHS) adopted in 2011 exempted the use of cadmium in LEDs and display applications until 1 July 2014. In January 2015, the Commission proposed a Delegated Act extending the life of cadmium on television until June 2018. In this way, the Commission effectively reintroduces cadmium to the European market once cadmium televisions have already been withdrawn from the market in view of the end of that exemption provided for in the regulation for the past July 2014.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because Parliament exercises its power of scrutiny over the rules with which the European Commission seeks to impose exceptions to the rule by conferring on itself a political power which it does not have. Delegated acts allow parliament to oppose technical legislation developed by the Commission and in this particular case the Commission has introduced derogations from the requirements laid down in Directive 2011/65/EU on hazardous substances in electrical appliances. The Commission has sought to introduce these exceptions to benefit producers against the safety of European citizens. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution which rejects the delegated act.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulatory role of the European Union promoting sustainable development and often opening legislative paths to international standards is recognised. At the same time, through funding programmes such as Horizon 2020, the Union has catalyzed scientific and technological research where much of the innovations that reduce polluting effects and offer citizens in general a better quality of life are based. Cadmium is an abundant natural element with no relevant role in living systems. Even in small concentrations, Cadmium is harmful to human and animal health in general. In technological terms, cadmium has numerous uses that are not yet capable of substitution. However, the proposed Delegated Directive allowed the continued use of Cadmium on monitors, from a perspective that is no longer justified. I believe that we must continue to promote sustainable solutions and inhibit the use of techniques and methods that are obsolete or have more appropriate environmentally friendly alternatives. For this reason, I voted to derail this Delegated Directive and to impose the best available environmental and technological practices.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ We voted in support of the report as the justification given for exemption 39(b) is based on an outdated situation with regard to the practicability of the replacement of cadmium in quantum dots. It therefore calls for a swift reassessment of the existing exemption 39 with a view to its revocation.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. After a ban on F-gases, the European Parliament is now fighting against cadmium. Cadmium is harmful to health while equivalent alternatives are available. That is precisely why the European Parliament objects to a proposal by the Commission to allow the use of cadmium in televisions and lamps.  By nature, cadmium is present in very low concentrations in the Earth's crust. As a result, our body cannot cope well with prolonged increased exposure. This leads to adverse effects, from high blood pressure to disturbances in bone formation. The Commission therefore imposed a ban on the use of cadmium, but with one exception: televisions. By placing so-called cadmium quantum dots in TVs, they become more energy efficient. The Commission considers that this benefit outweighs the adverse health effect of use. The Commission wishes to extend this exception. This while cadmium free quantum dots are available on the market. The Commission also succumbed to an intensive lobby by lamp manufacturers, which extended the use of cadmium to lamps. This is despite the fact that research carried out on behalf of the Commission recommends this extension. It is therefore a good thing that the European Parliament, as a whole, is now opposed to this.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 The use of dangerous substances such as kadmium should be kept to a minimum or completely expelled with the development of technology. In this particular case, there are alternatives to the use of this element in electronics and lighting, and they do not inducies large costs or are less effective than whenmium.  I support this motion for a resolution, as there will be no negative impacts on the market by increasing the use of kadmi in the electronic industry, thus working on the development of technology and put harmful substances out of service.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution which upholds the exemption of the use for cadmium, a toxic and carcinogenic substance, in illumination and display lighting applications.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒I voted for this proposal for a resolution on the Commission's Delegated Directive amending, for the purpose of adapting to technical progress, Annex III. Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and the Council as regards exemptions for the use of kadmi in screen lighting and illumination.  Namely, in Article 4(1) of the Directive 2011/65/EU restricting the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment also limits the use of kadmi in electrical and electronic equipment. In the Commission's Delegated Directive, Exemption 39(b) calls for an extension of the use of lighting devices with quantum dots from kadmi to 30 June 2017, in order to allow the lighting industry to submit a specific application for them, as those devices were already in the pre-production phase.  The Commission's main justification for granting a new special exemption is that quantum dots without kadmi are not yet technically available, while on the other hand, the leading manufacturer of TVs in 2015  In 2014, the Commission launched a new line of TVs using quantum dots without kadmi, which are available in major retail centres in several Member States. That justification is incorrect, since quantum dots without kadmi are not only available, but a wide range of TVs in which this technology is used are available on the Union market in the offer of large well-known retail stores.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ because I share the criticism in the report on the proposal. In view of today's situation with regard to the products concerned by the proposal, the derogation granted for the use of cadmium is already unjustified.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament objects to a Directive of the European Commission granting an exception for the use of cadmium in lighting and visualisation systems. In this sector, quantum point technology based on cadmium, a toxic element, is used. That exemption may be granted where technical progress does not allow the dangerous element to be replaced by another or if it would be an economically intolerable method of production. However, since these cadmium-free technologies are already on the market and are performance-comparable to or even outstrip cadmium-based technologies, I do not think it is necessary or desirable to allow an exception to prolong the production of technologies based on an element that is demonstrably harmful to the human body. I therefore supported the resolution against granting an exemption.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The text condemns an action by the Commission (to extend the exemption for the use of cedium in lighting and display lighting applications), an action which is unjustified, irregular and dangerous for the environment and European citizens.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution exempting cadmium used in lighting and display lighting applications and amending it to adapt it to technical progress. The motion states that a new specific exemption for cadmium has been granted in a Commission directive. They argue that it is already used for displays due to low energy consumption, highlighting its positive effects and the fact that cadmium-free quantum dots are not technically feasible yet. On the contrary, I agree that significant market developments have taken place and it can therefore be expected that the energy saving properties of cadmium-free quantum dots are similar to those of cadmium quantum dots.  Moreover, on the basis of eco-labelling information, displays using cadmium-free quantum dots compared to cadmium-free quantum dot models compared to televisions of the same size showed lower energy consumption compared to cadmium quantum dot models. Therefore, the Commission's reasoning for exemption is based on an outdated situation as regards the feasibility of replacing quantum dots containing cadmium. In order to resolve the contradictory situation, I support the request to the Commission to repeal this Delegated Commission Directive without delay.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it calls on the Commission to review its delegated act, which provides in point 39 of Annex III for the extension of the exemption until 2017 of cadmium in LEDs and one until 2018 for cadmium in quantum dots.  The Commission's delegated act is not justified at all because, contrary to what the Commission has decided, the market is absolutely ready to produce general lighting applications and display systems without any presence of cadmium, which is dangerous to human health. The same independent consultants responsible for assessing the application on behalf of the Commission came to the same conclusion and openly recommended that the extension should not be granted.  I voted against recital F and paragraph 5 because, of the exemption applications submitted by lighting application manufacturers, one was submitted beyond the deadline, and despite this infringement of the regulation it was also accepted by the Commission.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's Delegated Directive amending Schedule III of the European Parliament and Council's 2011/65/EU Directive for an exemption for cadmium in general lighting and screen lighting applications for its adaptation to technical progress. This is a readjustment text.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support the objection to the delegated act on exemption for cadmium in illumination and display lighting applications. Cadmium is a highly toxic metal the use of which is restricted to cases where there is no substitute: illuminations and display lightings fall under this exception. The exemption came to an end in 2014 and the Commission is asking, through a delegated act, to renew it. I am opposing it because the exception is based on outdated information and may no longer be justified. Opposing the delegated act does not mean immediate banning of cadmium as the exemption will remain until a decision is taken. What I want is to send the decision back to the Commission for a thorough technical assessment, in line with an objective of better regulation.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I voted for a Resolution on the Commission's delegated directive amending Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and the Council on the exemption for the use of kadmi in screen lighting and illumination. Technological advances indicate that there are much better and less harmful alternatives on the market that do not use technology that contains quantum dots than kadmi.  We understand that this is a dangerous substance used in electrical and electronic equipment on the European Union market, and it is also carcinogenic. The use of such harmful substances can, to the smallest extent, have major impacts on the environment, climate and population. I therefore consider it necessary to support innovation and achieve better regulation in this area.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this amendment because the restriction of hazardous substances directive (RoHS) adopted in 2011 exempted the use of cadmium in LEDs and screen applications until 1 July 2014. In January 2015, the Commission proposed a Delegated Act extending the life of cadmium on television until June 2018. In this way, the Commission effectively reintroduces cadmium to the European market once cadmium televisions have already been withdrawn from the market in view of the end of that exemption provided for in the regulation for the past July 2014.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this amendment because the restriction of hazardous substances directive (RoHS) adopted in 2011 exempted the use of cadmium in LEDs and display applications until 1 July 2014. In January 2015, the Commission proposed a Delegated Act extending the life of cadmium on television until June 2018. In this way, the Commission effectively reintroduces cadmium to the European market once cadmium televisions have already been withdrawn from the market in view of the end of that exemption provided for in the regulation for the past July 2014.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because Parliament exercises its power of scrutiny over the rules with which the European Commission seeks to impose exceptions to the rule by conferring on itself a political power which it does not have. Delegated acts allow parliament to oppose technical legislation developed by the Commission and in this particular case the Commission has introduced derogations from the requirements laid down in Directive 2011/65/EU on hazardous substances in electrical appliances. The Commission has sought to introduce these exceptions to benefit producers against the safety of European citizens. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution which rejects the delegated act.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. In January 2015, the European Commission proposed to the European Parliament and the Council to maintain the exemption from the use of cadmium in television sets until June 2018.  Cadmium is a hazardous metal used in the composition of various electrical and electronic equipment and, in particular, in television screens for lighting applications. The toxicity of this metal is known and manufacturers are gradually removing the equipment containing this alloy. The exemption from its use was due to expire in 2014, but the Commission requested an extension of this exemption on the grounds that there would be no substitutes for the substance. However, according to information from the industrial sector, there are at least two companies that offer cadmium-free products.  This request comes late, five months after the end of the exemption, without justification. With this resolution, proposed by the GUE/NGL, the Greens and the Socialist Group, the European Parliament asks the Commission to explain itself and withdraw its proposal.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. In January 2015, the European Commission proposed a delegated act extending the life of cadmium on televisions until June 2018. The Commission thus reintroduces cadmium into the EU market, as manufacturers had already removed it from lighting and backlighting applications of cadmium monitors in light of the end of this exemption in July 2014. The Commission's justification is that "cadmium-free quantum dots are not yet technically available". However, according to the Commission's explanamis, for one of the applications, there are no products on the market using quantum dots (Cd and Cd-free), so it is difficult to understand why such an exemption would still be necessary. And, in fact, the Commission consultants who assessed this request for exemption do not consider it justified at this stage. In addition, according to industry information, there are at least two companies that offer Cd-free quantum dots, and there are products with this technology already on the market. As such, the Commission's justification seems to be incorrect.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
