text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the Commission's delegated directive. On the one hand, since the deadlines for submissions were not met and, on the other hand, such a regulation would be perfectly sensible and effective, abstention was the only logical consequence.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. This motion for a resolution takes account of new, mainly commercial developments in related products, while at the same time calling for the position of the European Parliament to be taken into account.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution objects to the Delegated Directive of 30 January 2015, which amends, for the purpose of adapting to technical progress, Annex III to Directive 2011/65/EU of the European Parliament and the Council with regard to an exemption for cadmium in lighting and lighting applications for monitors, requesting the Commission to present a new delegated act taking into account Parliament's position. In January 2015, the European Commission proposed a delegated act extending cadmium life on televisions until June 2018. The Commission thus reintroduces cadmium into the EU market, as manufacturers had already removed it from lighting and backlighting applications of cadmium monitors in light of the end of this exemption in July 2014. However, according to the Commission's explanamis, for one of the applications, there are no products on the market using quantum dots (Cd and Cd—free), so it is difficult to understand why such an exemption would still be necessary. And, in fact, the Commission consultants who assessed this request for exemption do not consider it justified at this stage. As the replies provided by the Commission have not been satisfactory, this resolution opposes the delegated act proposed by the Commission. We agreed.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This was an objection to a delegated act concerning the importation of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the establishment of specific measures in relation to the market for this product. We have proposed three amendments to the text as we understand that it is important that the problem of access to land and its use for food purposes be reflected in it. However, I voted in favour of the objection to the delegated act, since the current monitoring of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and its commercialization ensures greater transparency and knowledge as to market developments than the commission's proposal that this data be collected by Eurostat. This would not give such accurate information and data on a controversial market against which I am highly critical would be lost.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. In the name of simplification, and in view of the negligible share of ethanol production in Europe, the Commission plans to remove ethyl alcohol from the list of products required to submit an import certificate and to stop producing annual ethyl alcohol balances within the Union. On the contrary, I consider it essential to maintain monitoring of the ethyl alcohol market, and for this, transparency and market knowledge are necessary for both the players and the Member States. The European sector, mainly fuelled by the cereal and wine sectors, is very competitive with Brazilian ethanol (often derived from sugar cane), mainly because of trade agreements concluded by the European Union. This product has also been imported several times in bypasses. However, maintaining a balance sheet can detect these commercial abuses. I would add that these would be extremely useful for all the trade negotiations under way. Finally, this act of simplification on ethyl alcohol should not set a precedent tomorrow for other productions that are also exposed to international competition. For all these reasons, I oppose the delegated act proposed by the Commission.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on measures for the market in ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. Further examination of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge of market developments. The market is still unstable and is facing strong competition, in particular imports from third countries. Such information is also particularly useful in the context of the negotiations on an international agreement and anti-dumping investigations. Eurostat does not provide such accurate information, which means that operators, Member States and EU institutions have no other access to detailed information on the market situation. I agree with the objection expressed to the Commission delegated regulation.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Parliament opposes the Commission's regulation because it considers that monitoring data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures transparency and ensures the dissemination of information on market developments. This information on the state of the agricultural ethyl alcohol market is extremely useful in international negotiations and anti-dumping investigations.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This point calls for a vote on the amendment of the Regulation (EC) No. 376/2008 with respect to the requirement to present a certificate for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and repealing Regulation (EC) No. 2336/2003. The report states that monitoring data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures transparency and ensures the dissemination of information about the changing market, which is unstable. This information is useful in international negotiations, especially since Eurostat does not provide such precise information. Parliament's resolution asks us to object to the Commission's delegated regulation and I have therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. I believe that the monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin guarantees transparency and knowledge of market developments, which in any case has to cope with competition from imports from third countries. I believe it is imperative to keep active all the systems that allow us to control and combat dumping and support the production realities of our territories.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge as regards developments in a market which remains unstable and is subject to strong competition, in particular in the face of imports from third countries considering. This information is also extremely useful for negotiating international agreements and anti-dumping investigations. Moreover, Eurostat does not provide such precise information, so there is no alternative for economic operators, Member States and EU institutions to become fully aware of the market situation; I considered it necessary to vote in favour of objecting to this Commission Delegated Regulation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which addresses the question of the requirement to present an import licence for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. The examination of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge relating to market developments. The market is still unstable and is facing strong competition, in particular imports from third countries. Such information is particularly useful in the context of the negotiations on an international agreement and anti-dumping investigations. Unfortunately, Eurostat does not provide such accurate information, which means that operators, Member States and EU institutions do not have any other access to detailed information on the market situation.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The delegated act in question would have provided significant relief for undertakings importing bioetanol. It would have removed the quarterly reporting obligation and most of the procedural obligations relating to ethyl alcohol import licences, under the cover of simplification. Consequently, there would be a huge increase in ethanol imports on the EU market, which would result in the ruins of Hungarian bioethanol producers. We must prevent this, since the production of bioetanol, on the one hand, provides a stable income for maize growers and, on the other hand, produces a significant amount of GMO-free and healthy feed, which is needed now more than ever in the EU and Hungary. This legislation would have benefited the most important bioetanol exporting countries over union producers. The EU is negotiating free trade with many of these countries today, I can only refer to TTIP.  In addition to the above, I have also raised environmental concerns. The major ethanol exporter produces bioet ethanol from GMO crops in third countries. On the other hand, rainforests are cut down in these places and farmers are driven from the land in order to establish huge monoculture maize, rapeseed or palm plantations for bioetanol production. If we allowed in large quantities of foreign bioetanol, the EU would also contribute to the negative effects mentioned above. For these reasons, I voted in favour of challenging the delegated act, a move that also complied with the direction of the European People's Party.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because, in my opinion, the measures proposed by the European Commission with regard to the monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin are not satisfactory and, therefore, I hope that the Commission will put forward another proposal that takes due account of Parliament's position.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution follows a proposal by the Commission to amend the regulation on imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. In particular, the Commission called for the abolished import certificate, which nevertheless guaranteed transparency in data tracking. The motion for a resolution aims to reject this abolition in order to combat the free trade drifts of the Brussels Commission. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. According to the Commission's delegated act, the obligation to issue import licences no longer appears justified for the management of agricultural markets; COMAGRI considers, on the contrary, that the monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin (which derives from the securities system) guarantees both transparency and knowledge relating to market developments, which is still unstable and faces strong competition, in particular because of imports from third countries. Finally, it is useful in terms of international agreements and in combating dumping.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Commission delegated regulation of 20 February 2015 amending Regulation (EC) No. Regulation (EC) No 376/2008 as regards the obligation to submit a licence for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2336/2003 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 670/2003 laying down specific market measures in the field of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. The Commission's delegated act provided for the elimination of the Union's obligation to draw up and publish an EU budget for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the quarterly obligation for Member States to provide information on production, disposal and stocks. It also provided for the elimination of the obligation to present an import licence for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin into the Union. In view of the fact that the monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin guarantees both transparency and knowledge of market developments, which is still unstable and faces strong competition, in particular due to imports from third countries, I voted in favour of objecting to the Commission's delegated regulation.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the text because I believe that the monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin guarantees the transparency of data relating to market developments. Unfortunately, our market is facing vigorous competition, particularly as a result of imports from third countries. These data collected are key elements in international negotiations and anti-dumping investigations.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I have chosen to support this resolution, which is in line with the will and interests of our farmers, while preserving biodiversity. The resolution provides for the existence of the import certificate concerning imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin; this certificate allows the traceability of the product and a certain transparency favorable to the protection of consumers and our food industry. Despite the proposal put forward by some Members of the European Parliament's AGRI Committee, I therefore welcome the work of MePs Michel Dantin, Eric Andrieu, José Bové and Martin Hasling who, taking into account the opinion of professionals in the sector, have tabled this resolution to maintain the certificate; imports of ethyl alcohol from agricultural origin will thus be promoted and this will also help to combat the dumping of certain third countries in the area which poses a threat to the European internal market, in particular France, a major agricultural power.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 Monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge of market developments, which is still unstable and faces strong competition, in particular due to imports from third countries. In addition, this information is also extremely useful in the context of the negotiations for international agreements and anti-dumping investigations. However, Eurostat does not provide such precise information, which means that operators, Member States and EU institutions have no alternative but to be fully informed of the market situation. Parliament therefore raises objections to the delegated regulation and declares that this cannot enter into force. In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution tabled by the European Parliament on the Commission's delegated regulation of 20 February 2015 amending the existing rules on the obligation to submit a licence for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin.  In the light of the changes that have taken place over the last decade on the ethyl alcohol market, the Commission, committed to the objectives of reducing red tape and simplifying administration, considered it appropriate to take action by considering the monitoring of the ethyl alcohol market to be no longer necessary and therefore regulation (EC) No 2336/2003 obsolete. Whereas, however, the collection of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin is a guarantee of transparency and makes it possible to know and monitor market developments, which in this case are still unstable and subject to strong external competition; Whereas, moreover, the usefulness of this information also extends to international negotiations and anti-dumping investigations and that no entity, not even Eurostat, carries out data collection work in this area, I have decided to associate myself with the objections raised by my parliamentary colleagues to the Commission's delegated regulation and I have expressed my opposition to its entry into force.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – This was an objection to a delegated act concerning the importation of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the establishment of specific measures in relation to the market for this product. We have proposed three amendments to the text as we understand that it is important that the problem of access to land and its use for food purposes be reflected in it. However, I voted in favour of the objection to the delegated act, since the current monitoring of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and its commercialization ensures greater transparency and knowledge as to market developments than the commission's proposal that this data be collected by Eurostat. This would not give such accurate information and data on a controversial market against which I am highly critical would be lost.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I am opposed to the Commissionʼs proposed delegated act due to the fact that the following-up of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin should ensure both transparency and knowledge as regards the evolution of the market, while information on the matter is also extremely useful when it comes to anti-dumping investigations.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This delegated act aims to remove, on the one hand, market balance sheets for ethyl alcohol imported into the EU and, on the other hand, the licensing requirement for third countries wishing to import products into the EU. I have personally called for rejecting this delegated act because no longer having comprehensive and precise data on the importation of this very fragile product would be a mistake, especially in the context of trade negotiations with our international partners. Moreover, the abolition of licences seems to me to be a source of imbalance between our European companies and their foreign competitors. I support the European Commission's comprehensive approach to simplification, but simplifying does not mean abolishing, and in this case the deletion does not seem to me to be relevant. For these reasons, I voted to object to the delegated act.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this resolution, Parliament objected to a commission delegated act concerning certificates of import of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. The removal of such certificates is not desirable. Indeed, it is one of the ways we have to obtain accurate data on the ethanol market, which is still very competitive. Monitoring this market is useful for our trade policy. On the other hand, while the use of ethanol reduces carbon dioxide emissions, its production requires agricultural resources that can be used for livestock and human food. This is one more reason to remain vigilant about the ethanol market.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. It is important to maintain rules on tracking ethyl alcohol data. These allow stakeholders, namely the professional sector and institutional players, to be informed of developments in a highly fluctuating market subject to strong competition from third countries. This information is also very useful for gathering evidence in anti-dumping proceedings. That is why the European Parliament has chosen to maintain this obligation of transparency and information.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of rejecting this delegated act, which aims to abolish market balance sheets for ethyl alcohol imported into the union as well as the licensing requirement for third countries wishing to export ethyl alcohol to the Eu.C. Indeed, it is important for this sensitive market to have accurate data on imports, especially in the context of negotiating international trade agreements. Import licences are also part of the negotiations that are not wise to anticipate.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The delegated act in question would have provided significant relief for undertakings importing bioetanol. It would have removed the quarterly reporting obligation and most of the procedural obligations relating to ethyl alcohol import licences, under the cover of simplification. Consequently, there would be a huge increase in ethanol imports on the EU market, which would result in the ruins of Hungarian bioethanol producers. We must prevent this, since the production of bioetanol, on the one hand, provides a stable income for maize growers and, on the other hand, produces a significant amount of GMO-free and healthy feed, which is needed now more than ever in the EU and Hungary. This legislation would have benefited the most important bioetanol exporting countries over union producers. Many of these countries are now in free trade negotiations with the EU. The dismantling of customs duties and market access should be negotiated in free trade negotiations and not decided in a Commission legislation. In addition to the above, environmental concerns are also raised. The major ethanol exporter produces bioet ethanol from GMO crops in third countries. On the other hand, rainforests are cut down in these places and farmers are driven from the land in order to establish huge monoculture maize, rapeseed or palm plantations for bioetanol production. If we allowed in large quantities of foreign bioetanol, the EU would also contribute to the negative effects mentioned above. For these reasons, and in line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I supported the challenge to the delegated act.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The delegated act in question would have provided significant relief to undertakings importing bioetanol. It would have removed the quarterly reporting obligation and most of the procedural obligations relating to ethyl alcohol import licences, under the cover of simplification. Consequently, there would be a huge increase in ethanol imports on the EU market, which would result in the loss of Hungarian bioethanol producers. We must prevent this, since the production of bioetanol, on the one hand, provides a stable income for maize growers and, on the other hand, produces a significant amount of GMO-free and healthy feed, which is needed now more than ever in the EU and Hungary. This legislation would have benefited the most important bioetanol exporting countries over union producers. The EU is negotiating free trade with many of these countries today, I can only refer to TTIP. The dismantling of customs duties and market access should be negotiated in free trade negotiations and not decided in a Commission legislation. In addition to the above, I have also raised environmental concerns. The major ethanol exporter produces bioet ethanol from GMOs in third countries. On the other hand, rainforests are being cut down in these places and farmers are being driven from the land in order to establish huge monoculture maize, rapeseed or palm plantations for bioetanol production. If we allowed in large quantities of foreign bioetanol, the EU would also contribute to the negative effects mentioned above. For these reasons, I voted in favour of challenging the delegated act, a move that also complied with the direction of the European People's Party.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The Delegated Act aims to remove obligations for Member States to communicate detailed information on ethanol production, for the Commission to publish an annual balance sheet, and for importers to present an import licence.  As a result the Delegated text will lead to a reduction of the administrative burden for the Commission and Member States. The ECR Shadow was opposed to this objection on the grounds that the Delegated Act, as part of the simplification agenda, will lead to a reduction of the administrative burden and reduction in costs for the Member States without any impact on the sector.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The delegated act in question would have provided significant relief for undertakings importing bioetanol. It would have removed the quarterly reporting obligation and most of the procedural obligations relating to ethyl alcohol import licences, under the cover of simplification. Consequently, there would be a huge increase in ethanol imports on the EU market, which would result in the ruins of Hungarian bioethanol producers. We must prevent this, since the production of bioetanol, on the one hand, provides a stable income for maize growers and, on the other hand, produces a significant amount of GMO-free and healthy feed, which is needed now more than ever in the EU and Hungary. This legislation would have benefited the most important bioetanol exporting countries over union producers. The EU is negotiating free trade with many of these countries today, I can only refer to TTIP. The dismantling of customs duties and market access should be negotiated in free trade negotiations and not decided in a Commission legislation. In addition to the above, I have also raised environmental concerns. The major ethanol exporter produces bioetanol from GMO crops in third countries. On the other hand, rainforests are cut down in these places and farmers are driven from the land in order to establish huge monoculture maize, rapeseed or palm plantations for bioetanol production. If we allowed in large quantities of foreign bioetanol, the EU would also contribute to the negative effects mentioned above. For these reasons, I voted in favour of challenging the delegated act.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it can limit imports of poor quality products at low prices, unfairly competing with French and European producers.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution refers to the objection of a delegated act concerning the amendment of the regulations relating to the obligation to submit an import licence for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, which lay down specific measures relating to the market for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and lay down certain implementing rules of Regulation (EC) No 670/2003. This objection has been raised in view of the view that the production of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin uses soil necessary for sustainable food production mainly in southern Europe, and that the large production of biofuels, much more profitable, could hinder and withdraw access to land for farmers and makes the fight against hunger much more difficult. Furthermore, it is necessary to record data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, ensuring both transparency and knowledge of market developments, which is still unstable and is faced with strong competition, in particular due to imports from third countries, and that allowances are made public, so that Member States and EU institutions are fully aware of the market situation, since Eurostat does not provide such precise information.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of Parliament's text that, unlike the Commission, the monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin must be maintained because it guarantees both transparency and knowledge of market developments.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the introduction of specific market measures in the field of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, since the text concerns the annulment of a Commission regulation which seeks to abolish the obligation to produce a certificate for ethyl alcohol, the production of which creates major problems especially in the countries of the South.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since I believe that the obligation to present a licence for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin would have a very positive outcome in a still unstable market, which faces strong competition.  Moreover, this obligation would be extremely useful when it comes to international agreement negotiations and anti-dumping investigations.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The delegated act in question would have provided substantial relief for undertakings importing bioetanol. It would have removed the quarterly reporting obligation and most of the procedural obligations relating to ethyl alcohol import licences, under the cover of simplification. Consequently, there would be a huge increase in ethanol imports on the EU market, which would result in the ruins of Hungarian bioethanol producers. We must prevent this, since the production of bioetanol, on the one hand, provides a stable income for maize growers and, on the other hand, produces a significant amount of GMO-free and healthy feed, which is needed now more than ever in the EU and Hungary. This legislation would have benefited the most important bioetanol exporting countries over union producers. The EU is negotiating free trade with many of these countries today, I can only refer to TTIP. The dismantling of customs duties and market access should be negotiated in free trade negotiations and not decided in a Commission legislation. In addition to the above, I have also raised environmental concerns. The major ethanol exporter produces bioet ethanol from GMO crops in third countries. On the other hand, rainforests are cut down in these places and farmers are driven from the land in order to establish huge monoculture maize, rapeseed or palm plantations for bioethanol production. If we allowed in large quantities of foreign bioetanol, the EU would also contribute to the negative effects mentioned above. For these reasons, I voted in favour of challenging the delegated act, a move that also complied with the direction of the European People's Party.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. It requests that a registration of import licences for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin be filed, so that such registration serves as a form of control over the use being given to agricultural parcels for crops intended for biodiesel inputs, with the detriment that this entails in the fight to combat hunger in the world. This type of policy helps to control the increase in food prices and verify the expansion of the biofuels market.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The following-up of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge as regards the evolution of the market, which is still unstable and faces strong competition.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution of 20 February 2015 Commission Delegated Regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 376/2008 as regards the requirement to present an import licence for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2336/2003 laying down certain detailed rules for the production of import licences for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin 670/2003 laying down specific measures for the market in ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin (C(2015)00861 – 2015/2580(DEA)), since information on data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin is not provided by Eurostat, which is relevant for the negotiation of an international agreement and anti-dumping studies, and ensures transparency.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. It requests that a registration of import licences for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin be filed, so that such registration serves as a form of control over the use being given to agricultural parcels for crops intended for biodiesel inputs, with the detriment that this entails in the fight to combat hunger in the world. This type of policy helps to control the increase in food prices and verify the expansion of the biofuels market.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the draft proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Commission's Delegated Regulation of 20 February 2015 amending Regulation (EC) No 2015. 376/2008 as regards the obligation to grant a licence for the importation of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the repeal of Commission Regulation (EC) No 376/2008. 2336/2003 on the introduction of certain detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 2336/2003. 670/2003 on specific measures for the market for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin on the basis that I disagree with many elements of the resolution.  I support the European Commission's political priority focused on simplification, which does not mean that surveillance and information gathering for the ethyl alcohol market will be suspended, but will be implemented through less burdensome means . On top of that, I voted no because it's also an ALDE group line.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Michel Dantin's resolution on the importation of ethyl alcohol into the Union. This resolution opposes the Committee's proposal to abolish the balance sheets of alcohol imports and the licensing requirement for third countries wishing to import products into the EU. The lack of data following the abolition of balance sheets would put the EU in a difficult position in future trade negotiations and the abolition of licences would favour importing countries without consideration for the EU. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of objection to the Commission's delegated act on the importation of ethyl alcohol into the European Union. This delegated act calls for the abolition, among other things, of the licensing requirement for third countries wishing to export products in the EU, which would undermine the transparency of the Union's trade relations with these countries.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the motion as it clearly identifies the problem of the production of ethyl alcohol from agricultural products. The change in crop patterns in cultivation, for example, has made it more difficult to combat hunger.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The delegated act in question would have provided significant relief for undertakings importing bioetanol. It would have removed the quarterly reporting obligation and most of the procedural obligations relating to ethyl alcohol import licences, under the cover of simplification. Consequently, there would be a huge increase in ethanol imports on the EU market, which would result in the ruins of Hungarian bioethanol producers. We must prevent this, since the production of bioetanol, on the one hand, provides a stable income for maize growers and, on the other hand, produces a significant amount of GMO-free and healthy feed, which is needed now more than ever in the EU and Hungary. This legislation would have benefited the most important bioetanol exporting countries over union producers. The EU is negotiating free trade with many of these countries today, I can only refer to TTIP. The dismantling of customs duties and market access should be negotiated in free trade negotiations and not decided in a Commission legislation. In addition to the above, I have also raised environmental concerns. The major ethanol exporter produces bioet ethanol from GMO crops in third countries. On the other hand, rainforests are cut down in these places and farmers are driven from the land in order to establish huge monoculture maize, rapeseed or palm plantations for bioetanol production. If we allowed in large quantities of foreign bioetanol, the EU would also contribute to the negative effects mentioned above. For these reasons, I voted in favour of challenging the delegated act, a move that also complied with the direction of the European People's Party.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Whereas the monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin guarantees both transparency and knowledge of market developments, which is still unstable and faces strong competition, in particular due to imports from third countries; That this information is also extremely useful in the context of the negotiations on international agreements and the anti-dumping investigations, and I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. This subject is intended to amend Regulation (EC) No. 376/2008 relating to the requirement to present an import certificate for ethyl spirits of agricultural origin and repealing Regulation (EC) No. 2336/2003. This resolution of the European Parliament calls on MEPs to reject the Commission's delegated regulation, since monitoring data on these alcohols provides a guarantee of transparency and allows the dissemination of information on the evolution of this volatile and highly competitive market due to imports from third countries, which are very useful in trade negotiations. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted for it. The Commission wants to remove the requirement to present an import certificate for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. I intervened in the Committee on Agriculture to reject this project, which goes against the opinion of professionals in the sector. They are logically concerned that it will encourage too much of imports and put them in difficulty. The proposal is to refuse the amendment to the regulations. That is in line with my request in committee.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against it because I believe that this Commission proposal exceptionally means less regulation and is more in favour of the freedom to conduct a business. I am not in a good place to introduce more ethanol-related bureaucracy.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The Commission adopted in 2003 a Regulation on specific measures for the market for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. For the purposes of simplifying and working programmes, the Commission shall determine whether the existing rules impose unnecessary bureaucratic procedures and administrative burdens, and this Regulation has been among them. In February this year, a Delegated Regulation was issued amending the existing one lifting the EU's obligation to establish and disclose a balance sheet for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and a quarterly commitment by Member States to provide information on production, availability and supplies. It also abolishes the obligation to provide import licences for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, including insurance deposits, into the EU.  I supported a resolution opposing the entry into force of the Commission Delegated Regulation, as this is how we lose useful information necessary for international negotiations in this market that has great competition from third countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's delegated regulation of 20 February 2015 amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be repealed. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. It is therefore necessary to amend Regulation (EC) No 670/2003 laying down specific measures relating to the market in ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, since, on the one hand, it objects to the Commission's delegated regulation and, on the other hand, it instructs the President of the European Parliament to forward this resolution to the Commission and to inform it that the delegated regulation cannot enter into force.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. The purpose of the motion for a resolution is to oppose the decision to remove the certificate of import of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. This certificate allows transparency on data tracking and giving it up means playing the game of pro-free-trade Eurocrats. We reject this approach and we refuse to withdraw this certificate. We therefore voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I had to abstain from voting on the amendment of the delegated regulation on the obligation to present an import licence for ethyl alcohol. The current licensing and accounting of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin is quite sufficient and is also consistently enforced and reviewed. Furthermore, a further expansion of biofuel areas would put the fight against hunger at great risk.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. A 2003 regulation establishes measures for the agricultural ethyl alcohol market. The Commission has proposed a delegated regulation removing certain obligations. Thus, the delegated act removes the obligation for the Union to establish and publish a European Union assessment for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the obligation for Member States to provide information on production, run-off and stocks. However, monitoring ethyl alcohol data ensures transparency and ensures the dissemination of information on market developments, which is subject to strong competition due to imports from third countries. This information is extremely useful in anti-dumping investigations, for example. In addition, the act removes the requirement to present a certificate for importation even though the EU imports more than one billion litres of ethyl alcohol per year. The resolution opposes this delegated act. I'm voting for the resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection to the delegated committee act amending Regulation (EC) No 376/2008 concerning the obligation to submit an import licence for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. I share the guidance followed in the European Parliament resolution when considering transparency and knowledge of product market developments, which is essential within close competition with imports into third countries.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution and object to the Commission’s delegated regulation as I support the conclusions of the Committee on Agricultural and Rural Development.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I approved the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No …/.. amending Regulation (EC) No 376/2008 as regards the obligation to present a licence for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2336/2003 introducing certain detailed rules for applying Council Regulation (EC) No 670/2003 laying down specific measures concerning the market in ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, as it is essential to ensure transparency and knowledge of the state and market developments in relation to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. It is a market that is unstable and with strong competition, particularly due to imports from third countries. Moreover, these data are advantageous when it comes to negotiations on international agreements and anti-dumping investigations.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This subject is intended to amend Regulation (EC) 376/2008 relating to the requirement to present an import certificate for ethyl spirits of agricultural origin and repealing Regulation (EC) No. 2336/2003. This resolution of the European Parliament calls on MEPs to reject the Commission's delegated regulation, since monitoring data on these alcohols provides a guarantee of transparency and allows the dissemination of information on the evolution of this volatile and highly competitive market due to imports from third countries, which are very useful in trade negotiations. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the proposal, as regards the obligation to present a licence for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2336/2003 introducing certain detailed rules for applying Council Regulation (EC) No 670/2003 laying down specific measures concerning the market in ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, but against all amendments.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the resolution on the Commission delegated regulation of 20 February 2015 amending the regulation on the obligation to present a licence for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, which raises objections to the Commission regulation.  Given that the European agricultural sector is an essential resource of our Union and must be promoted and supported as much as possible, its regulation must be managed very carefully.  In the specific case of imports of ethyl alcohol, it should be borne in mind that data monitoring ensures transparency and knowledge of the evolution of the EU market, which faces strong competition due to imports from third countries. The information is particularly useful in bilateral and multilateral trade negotiations and during anti-dumping investigations. As long as there is no Eurostat data on this subject, it will be important to maintain market control by means of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, without which it would not be possible to be informed of the market situation.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained because the proposal that has now been made cannot provide a sufficient answer to how the balancing act between food security in the growing regions – after all, the cultivation of plants for use in biofuels blocks the fields for re-use – and the EU's raw material autonomy can succeed.

name: Urmas PAET
text: book liult. \u2012 The responsibility of the wedding was when I stated the European Komisjoni ettepanekut.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not support the committee's proposal to oppose the delegated act.  In particular, existing bureaucratic obstacles need to be removed and unjustified administrative burdens should be prevented. It should be noted that the situation on the EU ethyl alcohol market has changed significantly. The EU has become a net importer of ethanol. This market development has been driven by EU biofuel policy.  It should be noted that the preparation of the EU ethanol balance of agricultural origin and the requirement to submit import licences are no longer targeted and necessary for the management of agricultural markets. The delegated regulation presented by the Commission will help to simplify and reduce the administrative burden on the Commission, Member State administrations and stakeholders.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for his work and hope to have made my contribution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this resolution objecting to the Delegated Regulation of the Commission by the European Parliament. I call on the Commission and the Member States to reflect once again on their positions, and to seek efforts to secure renewable energy sources on and not outside the EU. By importing energy from renewable sources, we do not work in favour of our energy independence. The production of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin is a source of employment and income for European farmers, and at the same time their contribution to Europe's energy independence. In some regions of Europe, rural areas are dying out, people are moving out, and fields are growing into thickets. I consider it wrong to have a policy that facilitates the placement of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin on the EU market from third countries until our fields are processed and our people have no business. Such a policy also enables additional production of ethyl alcohol in countries that irresponsibly relate to the joint efforts of our climate and energy policy, and the protection of areas under forests.  I consider it wrong to revoke import licences. These import licences are necessary to ensure traceability and to guarantee the origin of imported ethanol.  Updated statistics are needed to provide market information and transparency and policymaking. The market is volatile and we need the data to plan responsibly and manage the EU's energy and agricultural policy.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. At the last meeting of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, a change in the regulation on agricultural ethyl alcohol imports was proposed. It was requested that the import certificate be removed, which nevertheless allows for some transparency on the monitoring of the data. I note that industry professionals are opposed to this amendment and that my colleagues have intervened to oppose this project. The resolution proposed for vote is intended to reject the decision to remove the certificate. The aim is to reject the Commission's ever more liberal and free-trade policy and to combat the dumping of certain third countries which could permanently weaken the internal market of the EU and in particular France. That is why I am in favour of this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the Proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the Commission Delegated Regulation of 20 February 2015 amending Regulation (EC) No 2020/2016. 376/2008 as regards the obligation to grant a licence for the importation of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 100/2013. 2336/2003 on the introduction of certain detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 2336/2003. 670/2003 on specific measures for the agricultural ethyl alcohol market (C(2015)00861-2015/2580(DEA).  As monitoring of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge regarding the evolution of a market that remains volatile and in the face of strong competition, in particular due to imports from third countries, and that Eurostat does not provide such precise information, which means that there is no alternative way for operators, Member States and EU institutions to be fully aware of the market situation, I support objecting to the Delegated Commission Regulation.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - With the delegated act, the European Commission wishes to abolish the obligation to establish and disclose the EU's balance sheet for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the quarterly obligations of Member States to provide information on production, availability and supplies. It also wants to abolish the obligation to provide import licences for imports into the EU of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, including the deposit of insurance. While I support the Commission's political priority in terms of simplifying unnecessary administrative procedures, I do not consider this to be unnecessary bureaucratic rules. In this context, it should be noted that monitoring of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge regarding market evolution. The market itself remains volatile and faces strong competition, especially from imports from third countries. At the same time, this information, as stated in the proposal for a resolution, is of utmost benefit in terms of negotiations on international agreements and anti-dumping investigations. However, Eurostat does not provide such precise information, which means that operators, Member States and EU institutions have no alternative to be fully informed about the market situation. For the same reason, the European Parliament objected to the Delegated Regulation and told the Commission that it could not enter into force. As a result, I voted for this proposal.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree again that the delegated regulation should not enter into force as there are points that require more clarity. To date, the information provided by Eurostat is not very accurate, and as a result operators in the Member States have no alternative to being informed in detail about the market situation. The monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the information guarantee both transparency and the right knowledge on market developments, which is unstable and subject to competition due to imports from third countries. I hope that the Commission will do what is necessary as soon as possible.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. On Wednesday, the European Parliament rejected the proposal for a Commission's delegated regulation amending the regulation on the requirement to present a certificate for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. The aim of this text was to abolish market balance sheets for ethyl alcohol imported into the EU but also the licensing requirement for third countries wishing to import products into the EU. I voted against this text because I believe that the two previous points are important and should be maintained.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 As the Motion for A Resolution on the Regulation delegated to the Commission argues, there is still a lack of further knowledge of the market for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin before proceeding with import certification.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge regarding developments in a market that remains unstable and is subject to strong competition, especially in the face of imports from third countries. This information is also extremely useful for negotiating international agreements and anti-dumping investigations. Since Eurostat does not provide such precise information, so there is no alternative for economic operators, Member States and EU institutions to become fully aware of the market situation, I considered it necessary to vote in favour of objecting to this Commission Delegated Regulation.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the monitoring of the data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin that it introduces will ensure transparency and ensure the dissemination of information on the evolution of the market which remains unstable and which is subject to strong competition, particularly due to imports from third countries.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the delegated regulation presented by the Commission, as I believe it is necessary to update the legislation concerning ethanol of agricultural origin and its market. The delegated act will remove the union's obligation to draw up and publish an EU budget for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the quarterly obligation for Member States to provide information on production, disposal and stocks; the act in question will also remove the obligation to present an import licence for ethanol of agricultural origin in the Union. The proposed text is in line with the Commission's political priority: to determine whether the existing rules impose unnecessary bureaucratic and administrative burdens, or are obsolete or not in accordance with its priorities.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. It requests that a registration of import licences for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin be filed, so that such registration serves as a form of control over the use being given to agricultural parcels for crops intended for biodiesel inputs, with the detriment that this entails in the fight to combat hunger in the world. This type of policy helps to control the increase in food prices and verify the expansion of the biofuels market.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This was an objection to a delegated act concerning the importation of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the establishment of specific measures in relation to the market for this product. We have proposed three amendments to the text as we understand that it is important that the problem of access to land and its use for food purposes be reflected in it. However, I voted in favour of the objection to the delegated act, since the current monitoring of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and its commercialization ensures greater transparency and knowledge as to market developments than the commission's proposal that this data be collected by Eurostat. This would not give such accurate information and data on a controversial market against which I am highly critical would be lost.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The following-up of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge as regards the evolution of the market, which is still unstable and faces strong competition.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I believe that the Slovak Republic, as well as Europe itself, will be helped by maintaining a licence to import agricultural alcohol. A group of countries such as France, Hungary, Poland and slovakia would also be threatened by uncontrolled imports of agricultural alcohol from third countries.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin should comply with EUROPEAN Union standards within the framework of transparency, and it is therefore necessary to monitor the data related to the product being traded. This ensures transparency and knowledge regarding the evolution of the European market. I support this draft motion for a resolution, as it aims to improve conditions on the European market, to empower markets and increase transparency - these are the factors that are necessary for further market growth.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution regarding the market for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Commission's Delegated Regulation of 20 February 2015 amending Regulation (EC) No 2020/2016. 376/2008 as regards the obligation to grant a licence for the importation of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 100/2013. 2336/2003 on the introduction of certain detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 2336/2003. 670/2003 on specific measures for the market for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, as monitoring of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge regarding the evolution of a market that remains volatile and faces strong competition, in particular due to imports from third countries. The EU produces more than 6 billion litres of ethanol of agricultural origin for the domestic market with a demand of around 7.9 billion litres. Therefore, the EU has become a net importer of ethanol. This enlargement is the result of the EU's biofuels policy. In my view, import licences are necessary to ensure traceability and to ensure the origin of ethanol imports. Furthermore, updated statistics are needed to provide market information, transparency and policymaking, as Eurostat does not provide such precise information, meaning that there is no alternative way for operators, Member States and EU institutions to be fully aware of the market situation.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because I do not agree that the abolition of monitoring of ethyl alcohol-related data is a bad step. That step will lead to a reduction in the administrative burden for the operators concerned and to a reduction in costs on the part of the authorities processing those data, without substantial negative consequences.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The text concerns the annulment of a Commission regulation which seeks to abolish the obligation to produce a certificate for ethyl alcohol, the production of which poses major problems, particularly in the countries of the South.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the obligation to present licences for imports of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. I share the view that the monitoring of data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin ensures both transparency and knowledge of the development of a market that is still unstable, especially in the face of strong competition from imports from third countries. The motion for a resolution also states that this information is extremely useful in negotiations on international agreements and in anti-dumping investigations. At present, such precise information is not available, which means that market participants, Member States and EU institutions are unable to receive full information on the market situation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. This is a minor legislative adjustment, so I voted in favour of the Commission's (EU) Delegate Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No. 376/2008 with regard to the requirement to present a certificate for ethyl alcohol imports d agricultural origin and repealing Regulation (EC) 2336/2003 setting out certain modalities for the application of regulation (EC) 670/2003 of the Council establishing specific measures relating to the market for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. It requests that a registration of import licences for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin be filed, so that such registration serves as a form of control over the use being given to agricultural parcels for crops intended for biodiesel inputs, with the detriment that this entails in the fight to combat hunger in the world. This type of policy helps to control the increase in food prices and verify the expansion of the biofuels market.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. It requests that a registration of import licences for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin be filed, so that such registration serves as a form of control over the use being given to agricultural parcels for crops intended for biodiesel inputs, with the detriment that this entails in the fight to combat hunger in the world. This type of policy helps to control the increase in food prices and verify the expansion of the biofuels market.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This was an objection to a delegated act concerning the importation of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and the establishment of specific measures in relation to the market for this product. We have proposed three amendments to the text as we understand that it is important that the problem of access to land and its use for food purposes be reflected in it. However, I voted in favour of the objection to the delegated act, since the current monitoring of data relating to ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and its commercialization ensures greater transparency and knowledge as to market developments than the commission's proposal that this data be collected by Eurostat. This would not give such accurate information and data on a controversial market against which I am highly critical would be lost.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. A few months ago, the Commission sent the European Parliament a delegated act which should remove the requirement to present a certificate for the importation of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin into the Union. It also proposes to remove the quarterly obligation for Member States to provide information on alcohol production, run-down and stocks and to publish balance sheets. This is a huge setback in terms of traceability, transparency and guarantee of the provenance of consumer products such as ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. The availability and timeliness of statistics on this subject are also absolutely necessary to be in possession of all the information that allows you to conduct and adjust policies in this area. I therefore voted in favour of Parliament's resolution which opposes this delegated act and blocks its implementation.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution refers to the objection of a delegated act concerning the amendment of the regulations relating to the obligation to submit an import licence for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, which lay down specific measures relating to the market for ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin and lay down certain implementing rules of Regulation (EC) No 670/2003.  This objection has been raised in view of the view that the production of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin uses soil necessary for sustainable food production mainly in southern Europe, and that the large production of biofuels, much more profitable, could hinder and withdraw access to land for farmers and makes the fight against hunger much more difficult. Furthermore, it is necessary to record data on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin, ensuring both transparency and knowledge of market developments, which is still unstable and is faced with strong competition, in particular due to imports from third countries, and that allowances are made public so that MEMBER STATES and EU institutions are fully aware of the market situation, since Eurostat does not provide such precise information.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I had to abstain from voting on the amendment of the delegated regulation on the obligation to present an import licence for ethyl alcohol. The current licensing and accounting of ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin is quite sufficient and is also consistently enforced and reviewed. Furthermore, a further expansion of biofuel areas would put the fight against hunger at great risk.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote in favour the European Parliament's proposal on the market in ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin. I believe that the text takes into account every aspect of the issue and sets the conditions for further initiatives.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would like to explain why I abstained in the final vote and did not support the resulting resolution. I think that supporting mothers on maternity leave, creating the best possible conditions for the compatibility of the maternal and professional role is in the interest of the European Union, but it is primarily in the interests of the Member States. I could not agree that this resolution contained a proposal to introduce compulsory paternity leave within the range of ten days. I think that this is a matter that the Member States, the European Parliament and the European Commission must agree on. The motion for a resolution also called for a return to the old proposal for a directive, which has been under discussion here for more than seven years, and it turns out to be a blind path. I therefore prefer the new approach of the European Commission promised by Commissioner Věra Jourová.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I voted against the vote on the maternity directive. I am very much in favour of socially safeguarding young mothers in the world of work, for which there are also many rules in the Member States. However, the issue of maternity protection is regulated differently in Poland than in Malta, Germany or the United Kingdom. This also has something to do with social cultures and social responsibility of the Member States. The EU must not level these things up, we should not interfere responsibly in the social competence of the Member States. That is why I voted against.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I want to reference the issue of paternity leave. Fathers have got to step up and stay at home, and governments must help them to do that. Shared responsibility for new-born babies is the key to equality in the labour market, but the responsibility will always fall on women unless governments introduce better paternity leave circumstances. Women will always suffer in their careers if they are the ones to take the time off to mind children. Paternity leave is a real solution to equality in the workplace, but a huge culture shift has to be achieved and governments in the EU are going to have to drive that. I am conscious that employers, particularly in small businesses, would fear the cost of temporarily losing men as well as women to these family-friendly policies, but I urge them to change their views on family life and family time off.  Employees being absent is a cost to business; I recognise that, especially for small businesses. But I think we are going to have to accept that it is a cost to business just like rent, rates, holiday pay, electricity costs and other benefits. Populations need to be replaced and if people stop having children because their careers cannot bear a few months’ absence, then the cost to us all would be much greater in the long run.  We have to take a wider society view here and not think of rearing children as something that is best done in one’s spare time.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this motion for resolution because it is unacceptable that the Maternity Leave Directive is still blocked in the Council – and now there are rumours it might even be withdrawn as part of the Commission’s refit exercise to make EU law lighter. Yes, we need to have more efficient law-making that focuses on crucial things, but I find it difficult to understand why issues like the participation of women in the labour market and the fight against poverty, which is directly linked to this, would not be seen as key ones, on which the EU should tap the full potential of its ability to move things forward. It is unbelievable that for an issue as crucial as this one, which affects our entire society, we are still relying on a 1992 directive that has not been adapted to present-day needs. In the UK, more than half of mothers rely on grandparents when they go back to work, but not everyone is lucky enough to be able to rely on the help of others. That is why I urge the Commission to make sure that the Council finally breaks the deadlock on this crucial issue instead of taking the easy way out and referring it to the bin.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this because I think that is what the European Union was meant to be about. We had a European Union – or a European Community – that Ireland joined whereby we actually managed to gain some more rights, but it seems now the European Union is about pushing back on that. In particular, on paternity leave, my wife and I had a baby eight months ago and, because I decided I would do the right thing and stay at home and help her, I was pilloried in my national media for being lazy, for not trying and for being a bad politician, etc. So I think the first thing this institution could do, if it is serious about this, would be, if someone is missing on maternity leave or paternity leave, kindly not to mark them down as ‘absent, don’t care, lazy, couldn’t give a bloody damn’. Can you kindly have something put in place so that, if someone does care about their newborn and they want to stay at home and take care of them, it is recognised in here and you are not put down as a layabout for trying to do the right thing, and then your media attacks you, and in particular the female members of that media. Ironic or bloody what?

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, I regret that the maternity directive proposed in 2010 and has since been blocked by the Council has failed to reach an agreement.  Taking into account that national legislation in most Member States already has such or even better solutions secured than what the directive proposes, I abstained in this vote because I believe that some new solutions and new proposals need to be offered.  I note that member states are essential to ensuring the right of mothers of maternity and fathers, to be undisturbed by their children in their first months and years. Given the current demographic situation in Europe, we have a duty to ensure legislatively that employers provide women workers and at the same time married couples with quality conditions that will encourage and support childbearing and childbearing, which requires the presence of mothers and fathers especially in their first years of life.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to point out that this resolution absolutely must be reconnected with the fact that we have already decided in 1992 to create maternity leave at European level, so it makes no sense to say that this decision must remain solely with the Member States, because it is a question of increasing welfare, particularly with regard to mother, child, father and the conditions of motherhood and conciliation.  But we cannot stand still at the 14 weeks laid down in the 1992 directive still in force. We must also move forward to ensure greater protection not only of women's and children's health, but also to enable reconciliation, especially at times of great economic and employment crisis, when we see an increase in the poverty of women and children, the difficulties in entering and remaining in the labour market.  And so we have to understand that giving these opportunities today means, among other things, having higher productivity – for those who are concerned about costs – and this also makes it easier for many women to access work. Today we must say forcefully, as we said in the resolution, that the Commission must take back an initiative and, above all, we call on the next Luxembourg Presidency to resume a legislative initiative, and mediation by the Commission will be necessary. We cannot allow the possibility of finally making a directive that is finally adequate to fall after two legislatures.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the non-legislative and non-binding resolution on the situation of the maternity leave directive. This resolution was more to do with the EU procedural situation than the content of the legislation. UKIP totally opposes the EU creating laws over the UK – the only people that should make such legislation are elected national governments, accountable to voters at the ballot box, not unaccountable EU institutions. Once EU legislation has passed, the only people that can initiate new legislation, begin to repeal or start amendment of it is the EU Commission and they are not elected. However due to misrepresentation by the British press and other parties, UKIP abstained to show that we are not opposed to maternity leave. What we are opposed to is unelected Commissioners in Brussels creating the law.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the non-legislative and non-binding resolution on the situation of the maternity leave directive. This resolution was more to do with the EU procedural situation than the content of the legislation. UKIP totally opposes the EU creating laws over the UK – the only people that should make such legislation are elected national governments, accountable to voters at the ballot box, not unaccountable EU institutions. Once EU legislation has passed, the only people that can initiate new legislation, begin to repeal or start amendment of it is the EU Commission and they are not elected. However due to misrepresentation by the British press and other parties, UKIP abstained to show that we are not opposed to maternity leave. What we are opposed to is unelected Commissioners in Brussels creating the law.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on maternity leave because I believe that the rights of working mothers cannot be locked in a drawer.  The proposal to amend the existing directive extends the protection and safety of workers who are pregnant or have recently given birth, as well as mothers who have adopted a child under one year of age. I find it difficult to understand that the EU is able to agree on many economic measures, and when we talk about something as relevant as the rights of working mothers, the Council is unable to reach an agreement, and the Commission therefore raises the withdrawal of the proposal.  I also defend the need, in the resolution, for the Commission to submit a proposal for a directive on paternity leave and a revision of the parental leave directive, in order to achieve better reconciliation of family and work life for mothers and fathers. Finally, I also endorse the request made to the Commission to submit a new proposal as soon as possible if it finally decides to withdraw the proposal on the table.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted positively in the resolution tabled, as this is a blockade of more than four years in the Directive amending Directive 92/85/EEC on maternity leave. This is an extension and harmonisation of a right of workers across the EU, extending their right to maternity leave until 20 weeks, and at least 2 weeks for workers immediately after childbirth; at the same time, it also reaffirms Directive 2010/18/EU on paternal leave, which guarantees minimum leave to share leave up to four months.  This proposal had been approved at first reading by Parliament but has since been blocked by the Council, leading to increased labour costs and job security. First, we believe it is unfair for workers to pay the consequences of the financial crisis and for it to have a negative impact on their rights; on the other hand, withdrawing this legislative proposal from the Commission will not help break with the perpetuation of gender roles associated with women's reproductive capacity in the world of work.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report because I think the issue of parental leave is important. However, I am concerned that some of the proposals contained in the discussion on raising the minimum level of parental leave are poorly designed, and I am concerned that the EU will impose a bad system on the Member States. For example, there is a risk that discrimination against women in the labour market will worsen if, instead of applying a social security model, employers are determined to bear the cost. However, this report does not consist of creating proposals, but is primarily aimed at continuing the discussion.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Maternity leave has so far been regulated at EU level by a 1992 directive which imposes a minimum duration of 14 weeks. As part of a Commission proposal from 2010, the European Parliament decided at first reading to extend the current legislation from 14 to 20 weeks. The Council of Ministers has not been able to agree on this for four years, so the Commission has announced that it will withdraw its proposal. Against this background, I welcome Parliament's resolution today, which urges the Council to resume negotiations and calls on the Commission to help bring the positions of Parliament and the Council closer together. I also support the proposal to draw up a separate directive providing for paid paternity leave of at least 10 working days – as is already the case in Belgium.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. I supported the European Parliament's resolution on maternity leave because it is important to adopt real legislation in this area to carry out European harmonisation. Indeed, in 2010 the European Parliament voted to extend maternity leave from 14 to 20 weeks and to introduce two weeks of fully paid paternity leave. The aim is to balance work and private life by increasing women's participation in the labour market and supporting the birth rate. I voted for this resolution because we must take a stand and send a message to the Council to resume negotiations on this subject.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to encourage Member States to resume negotiations on extending minimum maternity leave.
