More women, especially older women, whose pension is on average 39% lower than men's pensions, and single mothers, than men live in poverty and exclusion. Women are more likely than men to work part-time, with fixed-term or temporary contracts and women's poverty to a large extent precarious work. The crisis has further reduced the birth rate in the EU, as unemployment and uncertainty about the future have led to couples delaying the decision to have children. Member States need to resume negotiations on the Maternity Leave Directive. I support the calls for the Commission to assume the role of fair mediator and to cooperate with the co-legislators in order to reconcile the positions of Parliament and the Council.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. We called for a relaunch of negotiations on the Maternity Leave Directive. This text has been blocked for four years in the Council! We call for extending maternity leave from 14 to 20 fully paid weeks and introducing two weeks of fully paid paternity leave. It is essential to guarantee this right to women and that fathers can be involved in this process without being discriminated against.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the maternity directive, which is currently blocked due to a lack of agreement between Member States. The aim of this text is to improve the protection of pregnant and young women delivered by proposing a more homogeneous and longer maternity leave by increasing it to 18 weeks (compared to 14 currently) as recommended by the ILO. In addition, paternity leave of at least 10 days will be offered. This proposal is a step in the right direction because it allows for gender equality and thus promotes women's work contrary to the ideas conveyed by some liberals (see for example Sweden). This text thus allows a balance in private and family life between men and women and promotes better protection of pregnant workers. It is vital for health and safety reasons for both mother and future child. Finally, this encouragement of motherhood is obviously a natalist argument, fighting against the ageing of Europe and avoiding the idea of immigration necessary to revive the birth rate in Europe. So I voted for this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the principle of equal treatment for women and men entails the absence of any discrimination, be it for motherhood or paternity, and the need to have equal family responsibilities.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution, which reminds the Council of its duties with regard to the directive on maternity leave and urges the Member States to resume the stalled negotiating phase.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I voted in favour of the Maternity Leave Directive. The decision today was about calling on the Council and the Commission to discuss the matter and make a proposal. When this final proposal is put forward for a decision in Parliament, I will evaluate how good or bad it is and then decide how To vote when it is sharp. It could be easy for me as a Swedish and an EU critic to dismiss a directive that is so bad compared to our Swedish system. However, when I meet my sisters in many EU countries, I also have to develop international feminism. Because as soon as someone proposes paid parental leave, access to childcare that doesn't cost the shirt, or a little job security for pregnant women, then it starts to scribble on the old man's benches. That is why I voted YES today.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on maternity leave because I believe that the rights of working mothers cannot be locked in a drawer.  The proposal to amend the existing directive extends the protection and safety of workers who are pregnant or have recently given birth, as well as mothers who have adopted a child under one year of age. I find it difficult to understand that the EU is able to agree on many economic measures, and when we talk about something as relevant as the rights of working mothers, the Council is unable to reach an agreement, and the Commission therefore raises the withdrawal of the proposal.  I also defend the need, in the resolution, for the Commission to submit a proposal for a directive on paternity leave and a revision of the parental leave directive, in order to achieve better reconciliation of family and work life for mothers and fathers. Finally, I also endorse the request made to the Commission to submit a new proposal as soon as possible if it finally decides to withdraw the proposal on the table.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it is necessary to unblock the maternity leave directive that is at an impasse. The Member States must resume the negotiations as soon as possible, as it has been five years since the European Parliament adopted its position on this directive, and it is certainly not acceptable that the Council is not taking action, the debate in the Council has stopped, thereby jeopardising the entire legislative procedure. The European Parliament is ready to help break the deadlock and calls on the Commission to assume the role of fair mediator and to cooperate constructively with the co-legislators in order to reconcile the positions of Parliament and the Council.  The Maternity Leave Directive is particularly important, especially when the crisis has further reduced the birth rate in the EU, leading to high unemployment, low-security conditions and uncertainty about the future. In addition, the economy has led to couples, especially younger women, delaying the decision to have children, and the trend towards demographic ageing continues to take hold across the EU. I therefore hope that more concrete action will be taken during the Luxembourg Presidency on the fate of this directive.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the FIDESZ-KDNP Group, I did not support the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, given that the definition of maternity leave allowance should remain the responsibility of the Member States.  In our view, this directive should primarily include measures to improve women's health and safety at work, as in the current directive, while better coordination of work and family life should be ensured through other directives and legislative instruments.  We need to develop legislation that respects the logic and differences of each member state's system.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Maternity leave is still managed in a very diverse way in Europe today, there are very different levels of protection. In the last parliamentary term, Parliament called for the minimum leave in each EU state to be increased from 14 to 20 weeks fully paid. We know that the debate on this extension has stalled in the Council and that the Commission will withse the proposal if the situation does not break away. With this resolution, which I support, we want to urge the Commission and the Council not to throw in the towel. Well-calibrated maternity leave can help to improve gender balance in the labour market, not forgetting the obvious demographic challenge that Europe is experiencing.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The Republic of Croatia has one of the best laws on maternity leave. Unfortunately, this is not the case for many EU member states. We need to work to improve the health and safety of pregnant women in the workplace and mothers. In this way, we can only tackle demographic challenges and reduce gender inequalities.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the Maternity Leave Directive. It is deplorable that the EU Commission has taken the regrettable decision to withdraw this directive which would have seen 20 weeks of paid maternity leave and paid paternity leave of 2 weeks. It is extremely disappointing, but unfortunately not unexpected from the new Commission, that they have made this decision which represents a serious step back for gender equality and the active participation of women in the labour market.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted yes to this resolution because increasing the duration of maternity leave and creating paternity leave are two necessary and fundamental measures both to combat gender inequalities and to encourage people to procreate and create families. In addition, I believe that it is up to the Union to harmonise as many rules as possible, starting with those relating to the rights of individuals.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased that this resolution by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality has been adopted. It is important to take this directive forward, on which this House adopted a position at first reading five years ago.  We will continue to focus on this issue so that women's right to maternity leave and reintegration into work is recognised and protected, without discrimination. With this resolution we reaffirm our desire to establish paid paternity leave of at least ten working days and to enable men, fathers, to exercise their right to achieve a balance between work and family. If this proposal for a review is withdrawn, our group will promote a legislative initiative to revise the current legislation, in order to improve the health and safety of pregnant or newly born or breastfeeding workers, thereby addressing demographic challenges and reducing inequalities between men and women.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This draft resolution deals with the maternity directive, which is currently blocked due to a lack of agreement between Member States. The aim is to improve the protection of pregnant women and young mothers when the child arrives, by harmonising the rules on maternity leave. As such, it should be noted that there is no correlation between the length of maternity leave and the employment rate of women. Indeed, the Member States of Northern Europe have the longest leave and the highest employment rate for women. I voted for the text in favour of all the policies that support the birth rate in France and Europe. Indeed, the best weapon against mass immigration remains a fertile birth among women in France and Europe.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The family is an important pillar in terms of the progress of society, and the sustainability of European society is impossible to achieve without a healthy demography, which implies protection for mothers and children. A new perspective and a new approach must be offered beyond the economic issues at stake. The European Commission's withdrawal of the proposal to revise this directive would lead to the deprivation of the rights of millions of women in the EU, as it is a means of protecting women and a guarantor of their rights. I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that this situation must be unblocked, and the Eu legislators must reach a common agreement that meets the needs and expectations of European families and the economy.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The principle of equal treatment for women and men means that there is no discrimination, including with regard to maternity, paternity and the fact that they have family responsibilities, but a quarter of the Member States do not provide for paternity leave; If we consider that the birth rate is falling in the European Union and that this trend is aggravated by the crisis, since unemployment, precariousness and the uncertainty of the future and the economy are forcing couples, and in particular younger women, to postpone the decision to have children, the trend towards an ageing population throughout the Union is further strengthened. The sharing of family and domestic responsibilities between men and women is a prerequisite for achieving gender equality. The resolution deplores the deadlock in the Council over the maternity leave directive and urges the Member States to relaunch negotiations.  It reiterates its willingness to draw up a separate directive establishing paid paternity leave of at least 10 working days and encouraging measures, legislative and other, enabling men, and in particular fathers, to exercise their right to achieve a work-family balance.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on maternity leave because I believe that the rights of working mothers cannot be locked in a drawer.  The proposal to amend the existing directive extends the protection and safety of workers who are pregnant or have recently given birth, as well as mothers who have adopted a child under one year of age. I find it difficult to understand that the EU is able to agree on many economic measures, and when we talk about something as relevant as the rights of working mothers, the Council is unable to reach an agreement, and the Commission therefore raises the withdrawal of the proposal.  I also defend the need, in the resolution, for the Commission to submit a proposal for a directive on paternity leave and a revision of the parental leave directive, in order to achieve better reconciliation of family and work life for mothers and fathers. Finally, I also endorse the request made to the Commission to submit a new proposal as soon as possible if it finally decides to withdraw the proposal on the table.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The right to maternity leave must exist and be respected in all EU Member States. I do not question that right in any way. However, I do not believe that it is up to the European Union to legislate in this area. We have an important principle in the treaties, that of subsidiarity. He must be respected. Family policy is the responsibility of the Member States. Each country has both cultural and social specificities that must be taken into account. In this case, it is the national level that is best able to legislate on maternity leave. I am therefore in for the right to maternity leave but also for respect for the principle of subsidiarity in this area. I therefore abstained on this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this resolution to ask the European Commission not to withdraw the proposal for a directive on maternity leave and to urge ministers to resume talks and agree on an official position. What Europe are we living in if those who create life are penalised? What kind of Europe are we living in if childbirth is synonymous with poverty? We cannot help mothers simply by deleting the proposal for a directive. Since 1992, when the directive on maternity leave was adopted, we have not made any progress. Women cannot wait, they deserve to be both women, mothers and workers without being discriminated against.  Paternity leave of at least 10 working days, in addition to maternity leave, should also be provided.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the non-legislative and non-binding resolution on the situation of the maternity leave directive. This resolution was more to do with the EU procedural situation than the content of the legislation. UKIP totally opposes the EU creating laws over the UK – the only people that should make such legislation are elected national governments, accountable to voters at the ballot box, not unaccountable EU institutions. Once EU legislation has passed, the only people that can initiate new legislation, begin to repeal or start amendment of it is the EU Commission and they are not elected. However due to misrepresentation by the British press and other parties, UKIP abstained to show that we are not opposed to maternity leave. What we are opposed to is unelected Commissioners in Brussels creating the law.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution to break the deadlock in the maternity leave directive. European legislation in this area is up to 1992 and should be updated; Many Member States have already introduced higher levels of protection.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ The question of maternity leave is a critical topic that must be discussed, however it is my view  that in this case the Member State level is best placed to be the most effective and efficient for taking into account the views of our citizens. With so many differences between the Member States and our national laws, it is inappropriate to attempt to apply a ‘one size fits all’ policy. We should instead be focusing our efforts into those areas where we can commonly create added European value. If this was a resolution on facilitating a better work-life balance for both men and women, it would have my full support. I regret that in this occasion I cannot support this as it stands.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I have been in favour of this motion for a resolution, which is intended to be a support initiative for the family and is part of a beneficial birth policy. The laudable objective of this resolution is indeed the protection of the pregnant woman and the young mother, today unfortunately too often victims of a situation of great precariousness to have given life. The resolution thus proposes guarantees of more homogeneous maternity leave in the Member States of the Union, as well as the possibility of paternity leave of at least ten days, which will allow fathers to help mothers in this period of great upheaval following the birth of a child. Maternity leave therefore goes beyond the purely liberal vision of women as production capital, allowing women to have a family life while ensuring that they have the opportunity to return to work, a reminder that women should never be punished for choosing to give life; Moreover, starting a family is not incompatible with having a job since the resolution reminds that countries like Sweden have the longest maternity leave while having the highest employment rate for women in Europe.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament wants fathers to have at least ten working days’ paternity leave, in addition to minimum 20 week maternity leave. The Commission has been signalling a worrisome eagerness to kill the proposal within a few months in the name of good legislative housekeeping, but Parliament has overwhelmingly objected today. If we must do it, let’s take the opportunity to restart the process rather than sweep our future under the carpet. Parliament and the Council are EU legislators on an equal footing, and the EU governments must not be allowed to ignore a majority of elected representatives who want to see a modicum of work-life balance at such a critical moment in family life. This is the kind of short-sighted, counterproductive penny-pinching that undermines the fabric of our societies to no tangible benefit. Fathers too have a right to experience and contribute to the earliest stages of development of their children across the Union. Paid paternity leave legislation is long overdue too. It’s interesting to see how conservative forces harp on about family values when they see fit, and yet show such little enthusiasm for a modest improvement in the conditions of working people’s family lives.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 As stated in the Europe 2020 strategy, smart, sustainable and inclusive growth cannot be pursued without focusing on achieving the right balance between work and family.  In another respect, it is an established fact that the increase in female employment is an important factor in GDP growth, and on the other hand the data show that the European countries with the most children today are also those where the employment rates for women are highest, confirming that it is perfectly possible to reconcile family and working life, provided that there are adequate protection mechanisms. The directive on maternity leave, which pursues precisely this objective, was approved by Parliament at first reading on 20 October 2010, and it is serious, and not in line with the principle of loyal cooperation under Article 4 TEU, that the Council has not yet adopted an official position. The question we have adopted urges the Council to assume its responsibilities and to adopt an official position on the directive, in order to break the deadlock and, if possible, to enter into negotiations with Parliament. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. In Denmark, fathers have been entitled to two weeks of paternity leave within the first 14 weeks of birth since 1984. The Danish members of the S&D Group are in favour of the EU being entitled to paid paternity leave of 10 working days, but at the same time considers that there is a need for a clear definition of what 'paid paternity leave' covers.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted against the maternity leave application because the EU has no regulatory competence in this area; this is the responsibility of the Member States. Basically, I am in favour of appropriate protection for expectant mothers. But there are already many rules for this in the Member States, and we already have Minimum European standards in this area. The social security systems in the 28 Member States are simply too different, so I think further harmonisation is wrong. We have a well-functioning system of maternity and parental leave in Germany – we must preserve this and not let ourselves be squeezed into a European corset that does not fit!

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ We seem to be focusing on this Directive merely in terms of giving women more weeks as maternity leave. This focus often makes us forget the socio-economic realities of Member States. We cannot allow ourselves to forget demographic data which clearly indicates that Europe is an ageing population, has difficulties in attracting women to employment, and retaining women in employment once they are of child-bearing age. We continuously state that we believe that women are equal partners and contributors in the political, social and economic sector and we are all in favour of gender equality. It is true that the Commission’s proposal to withdraw this dossier does not at first sound very attractive, but it is a pragmatic way of addressing a deadlock. Yet we cannot forget the principles we have declared to adhere to nor the socio-economic realities we face, and so the withdrawal of this dossier should be accompanied by other measures which have the same purpose or end. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the principle of equal treatment for women and men implies the absence of any discrimination, direct or indirect, including with regard to motherhood, paternity and the fact of having family responsibilities. I am voting in favour because I believe that there are still too many differences between the Member States and I firmly believe that the possibility for both parents to be able to live in the most serene and participatory way possible a fundamental moment in life, such as the birth of a child, must be guaranteed.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I voted positively in the resolution tabled, as this is a blockade of more than four years in the Directive amending Directive 92/85/EEC on maternity leave. This is an extension and harmonisation of a right of workers across the EU, extending their right to maternity leave until 20 weeks, and at least 2 weeks for workers immediately after childbirth; at the same time, it also reaffirms Directive 2010/18/EU on paternal leave, which guarantees minimum leave to share leave up to four months. This proposal had been approved at first reading by Parliament but has since been blocked by the Council, leading to increased labour costs and job security. First, we believe it is unfair for workers to pay the consequences of the financial crisis and for it to have a negative impact on their rights; on the other hand, withdrawing this legislative proposal from the Commission will not help break with the perpetuation of gender roles associated with women's reproductive capacity in the world of work.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of having better maternity and paternity leave. It was high time to call on the Commission to make a new legislative proposal in order to unblock the discussions on the maternity leave directive and to start negotiations under the Luxembourg Presidency. Now the European Commission must present a new legislative text on maternity leave if it decides to withdraw the current proposal on the table.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The purpose of this resolution is to discuss the state of negotiations of the proposal to harmonize maternity leave proposed in 2008, which aimed to extend compulsory maternity leave in Europe from 14 to 18 weeks. Adopted in 2010 by the European Parliament, the text has since been blocked in the Council of Ministers. This resolution criticises the European Commission's potential decision to withdraw the proposal in accord with its institutional prerogatives. Indeed, in accord with President Juncker's campaign promises, the European Commission announced when it adopted its 2015 work programme that it would withdraw the proposal if there was no tangible progress in the next six months. Considering, contrary to the substance of this resolution, that it is necessary, given the state of stalled negotiations and the lack of real progress in the negotiations, to break the institutional deadlock and for the European Commission to withdraw that text, even if it means proposing a new copy in its 2016 work programme, I abstained in the vote on this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I have always been very active in defending women's rights. Maternity leave is thus an instrument that allows women to find a good balance between private and professional life. It is therefore crucial that the European Union put an end to the deadlock that currently exists on this measure. I am also in favour of the introduction of paternity leave, which already exists in France. However, I did not wish to vote in favour of the paragraph calling for its implementation, as this resolution was to concern only the resumption of discussions on maternity leave. Legislative procedures must be respected and other debates should not be imported into a resolution with a clear and specific objective. The vote of this paragraph in plenary led me to abstain on this resolution.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Written. Although I support the resolution's intention, maternity leave is primarily a national competence. That is why I am not in favour of new European rules in this area and have abstained.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Maternity leave is an important guarantee for establishing a fair balance between family and career life. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe it is necessary to extend maternity leave to at least 18 weeks, 6 of which are compulsory after childbirth.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. It has been almost four years since the directive on the proposed extension of maternity leave was blocked in the Council. The Commission, which proposed in 2010 to harmonize the duration of maternity leave and its remuneration according to the recommendations of the International Labour Organization (ILO), namely an 18-week leave, must not give in to the reluctance of Member States. This is a strong gesture for European parents, women and men who will be helped to find a better balance between family and professional life. The Commission must not leave this appeal dead letter.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I abstained on the final vote of the resolution. I am afraid that the amended text will not break the current impasse and, on the contrary, only reinforce the blockages that we have been experiencing for the past five years on the proposed directive on improving the safety and health of pregnant, delivered or lactating workers at work. This new maximalist position of Parliament will only strengthen the European Commission in its proposal to withdraw the original draft directive and take new initiatives in this area, under the REFIT programme, when good things were present such as better sharing of parental responsibilities within the couple, an improvement in the employment rate of women and support for the birth rate.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the FIDESZ-KDNP Group, I did not support the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, given that the definition of maternity leave allowance should remain the responsibility of the Member States. In our view, this directive should primarily include measures to improve women's health and safety at work, as in the current directive, while better coordination of work and family life should be ensured through other directives and legislative instruments. We need to develop legislation that respects the logic and differences of each member state's system.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – In line with the position of the FIDESZ-KDNP Group, I did not support the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, given that the definition of maternity leave allowance should remain the responsibility of the Member States.  In our view, this directive should primarily include measures to improve women's health and safety at work, as in the current directive, while better coordination of work and family life should be ensured through other directives and legislative instruments.  We need to develop legislation that respects the logic and differences of each member state's system.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution on maternity leave. Parliament has decided to vote for a resolution which would prescribe 20 paid weeks of maternity leave (of which only 6 fully paid) and a call for a different proposal for fathers allowing them to take paid leave for 10 days.  It is hard for me to agree that such proposals would add value, stand for more equal rights for mothers and fathers and would progress gender equality, in particular in relation to working mothers. First, my question is why do we need to treat parents of one kid in two different pieces of legislation? Second, I find the standards set by both proposals very low and discriminatory towards parents of different sexes. In addition, they would create clear inequality between parents of the same sex. The Commission should have the right to withdraw this outdated  proposal and  revise the 2010 Parental Leave Directive to allow both parents,  irrespective of their sex, to take, on equal terms, paid leave and  to decide who stays at home.  If not, it should be left to the Member States to continue their own policies which, in most cases, are much more generous, dynamic and flexible.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ While I share the desire to see fair and comprehensive provision put in place to support both mothers and fathers as they get to grips with shouldering new parental responsibilities, I also believe that the EU should respect the principle of subsidiarity. It is not for the European Parliament to legislate in this area. Only a few weeks ago, the people of the United Kingdom, including those in my constituency, Northern Ireland, elected members to a new national Parliament at Westminster. It is there – not here in the corridors of Brussels and Strasbourg – that decisions around maternity and paternity leave provision should be taken and enforced. How often in recent times has this Parliament, through fascination with integration and harmonisation, forgotten that the greatest victories for our citizens come when local elected representatives recognise a local need and commit to bringing forward change to tackle it. That is a principle that is at the very core of the defence of national sovereignty – and is why I opposed this Motion.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the maternity leave regulation. It offers better protection for pregnant women as well as the possibility of paternity leave. I have also ensured that these measures are beneficial to businesses, which will be able to organize themselves optimally by providing for replacements, which they are struggling to achieve today.  However, we will have to pay special attention to the beneficiaries of this birth policy. Indeed, it must be ensured that it benefits European nationals and not the people who settle in our territories in order to enjoy our social policies.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed directive on the health and safety at work of pregnant workers and workers who have recently given birth or who are breastfeeding (Maternity Leave Directive) has been blocked in Council since 2010. There is a blocking minority of Member States who do not believe that it is within the EU’s legal competence to legislate on the specifics of maternity and paternity leave, notably regarding pay and duration. The ECR position remains consistent: we would like to see the Commission withdraw the proposal and we remain opposed to the EU legislating on the pay and conditions of maternity and paternity leave

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Maternity Leave Directive does not comply with the principles of subsidiarity and in this regard I cannot support this resolution calling for its revision. The Member States are competent in this field and their word must be last and have the right to regulate the legislation in this respect themselves.  In my country, maternity leave is paid for two years. Exchange of good practices is necessary, but not European legislation.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Council must respect the judgment of the European Court of Justice and provide sufficient justification as to why it is trying to withdraw the draft law extending maternity leave. We fully agree with this proposal and especially on the point where it emphasises the need to introduce paternity leave.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the FIDESZ-KDNP Group, I did not support the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, given that the definition of maternity leave allowance should remain the responsibility of the Member States. In my view, this Directive should primarily include measures to improve women's health and safety at work, as in the current directive, while better coordination of work and family life should be ensured through other directives and legislative instruments.  We need to develop legislation that respects the logic and differences of each member state's system.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. The principle of equal treatment between women and men implies the absence of discrimination, directly or indirectly, also with regard to maternity, paternity and the assumption of family obligations; the sharing of family and domestic obligations between men and women is important in relation to progress in gender equality and the assumption of rights. In this regard, there is a willingness to draw up a directive, always taking into account the principle of subsidiarity, which provides for the basis of maternity and paternity leave, and which, to the extent possible, favours reasonable measures to enable women and men to exercise their right to reconcile private life and professional life.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the European Commission not to withdraw draft EU legislation on maternity leave. The European Parliament has in the past voted to increase guaranteed maternity leave from 14 to 20 weeks fully paid and for the mandatory right to paternity leave for fathers. I strongly supported this.  I believe that the Parliament’s vote should be respected as the voice of citizens in Wales and Europe.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, the aim of which is to call for the release of the Maternity Leave Directive, which is stopped in the Council after being approved by Parliament in 2010. The main aim of this directive would be to establish the length of maternity leave (20 weeks is Parliament's proposal) and the amount of benefit to be paid, which Parliament proposes is equal to 100% of pay.  Given the many disparities that still exist between men and women, especially in the workplace even in normal situations – just think, for example, that women's pensions are on average 39% lower than those of their male colleagues – it is clear that, in the face of motherhood, women's natural duties risk restricting their rights as well. That is why harmonising the rules on maternity leave is certainly a fundamental step towards reducing gender discrimination. We therefore hope that the proposal for a directive (COM(2008)0637) can finally be unblocked before it is in danger of being withdrawn by the Commission in June under the REFIT programme.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. It is important to have ambitious parental insurance, but I do not believe that this is an issue that is best managed at European level. I therefore abstained from supporting this resolution.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Maternity leave is an essential tool for ensuring work-life balance. It is also particularly important in the face of the obvious ageing of the European population. However, its implementation varies between Member States and attempts to improve common standards in the EU have been blocked by governments since 2008. I regret that the Community executive can withdraw the proposal to revise the Directive. If this is indeed the case, it is important that you present a new legislative initiative during the Luxembourg Presidency of the Council. It is also proposed that a separate directive establishing paid paternity leave of at least ten working days be drawn up.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on maternity leave because I believe that the rights of working mothers cannot be locked in a drawer.  The proposal to amend the existing directive extends the protection and safety of workers who are pregnant or have recently given birth, as well as mothers who have adopted a child under one year of age. I find it difficult to understand that the EU is able to agree on many economic measures, and when we talk about something as relevant as the rights of working mothers, the Council is unable to reach an agreement, and the Commission therefore raises the withdrawal of the proposal.  I also defend the need, in the resolution, for the Commission to submit a proposal for a directive on paternity leave and a revision of the parental leave directive, in order to achieve better reconciliation of family and work life for mothers and fathers. Finally, I also endorse the request made to the Commission to submit a new proposal as soon as possible if it finally decides to withdraw the proposal on the table.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. We have played a decisive role in bringing this matter to this Parliament's attention and in demanding the condemnation of this resolution. That is why we welcome it. The case of the Maternity Directive leaves the state of this European Union and what its people can expect. An instrument and vehicle for imposing deep social setbacks – wage cuts, attacks on the social functions of the State in health, education, social security, the reduction of social and labor rights, privatizations, etc. – is at the same time a buffer to any small measure, which is to improve living conditions; a modest advance, that is, towards social progress. The Council, which so readily understands the setback, does not agree to increase the protection of working mothers and their children by guaranteeing them a minimum of 20 weeks fully paid for maternity leave. And in view of this, the European Commission (the one that it claimed to be the bearer of a new progressive impulse), decides to send its proposal to the dustbin and disguises the decision – deeply political – by taking it as a mere administrative act.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on maternity leave has long been the subject of a dispute between the European Parliament and the Council, which has blocked it in the past. It is very important that this deadlock can be resolved. This is a clear expression of opposition to women's rights and their conscious trampling. Women's working conditions need to improve, and that is where practical steps need to be taken and not just constantly discussed. In doing so, Europe is fighting the demographic crisis, and the solutions offered by the European Parliament are constantly rejected by some institutions. The European institutions must send out a positive signal and promote parenting and maternity protection in the European Union.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of greater equal treatment for women and men, which means that there is no discrimination, including with regard to motherhood, paternity and the fact that we have the same family responsibilities.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on maternity leave. The Council must respect the judgment of the European Court of Justice and provide sufficient justification as to why it is trying to withdraw the draft law extending maternity leave. I fully agree with this proposal and especially on the point that it emphasises the need to introduce paternity leave.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this Motion for a Resolution. I do not believe that it is within the EU’s legal competency to legislate on the specifics of maternity and paternity leave, notably pay and duration. This is a matter for Member States and I urge the Commission to withdraw the proposed Maternity Leave Directive.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Adopting an ambitious directive on maternity leave would have a number of positive results on the quality of European societies, such as increasing the employment rate of women and the birth-rate in Europe. I am concerned about the declared intention of the Commission to withdraw such an important proposal if the co-legislators do not find a way out of the deadlock within six months. It is about time for the Council to engage in dialogue and start negotiations with the European Parliament on the Maternity Leave Directive, taking responsibility for refusing the improvements in the safety and health at work of pregnant workers and workers who have recently given birth or are breastfeeding It is clear that if we want to tackle the issue of gender equality we must ensure that both men and women are entitled to the same rights and that women are allowed to balance their family and professional lives. If we believe that social rights are at the heart of European society we cannot overlook having high standards on Maternity Leave.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the FIDESZ-KDNP Group, I did not support the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, given that the definition of maternity leave allowance should remain the responsibility of the Member States.  In our view, this directive should primarily include measures to improve women's health and safety at work, as in the current directive, while better coordination of work and family life should be ensured through other directives and legislative instruments.  We need to develop legislation that respects the logic and differences of each member state's system.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the FIDESZ-KDNP Group, I did not support the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, given that the definition of maternity leave allowance should remain the responsibility of the Member States.  In our view, this directive should primarily include measures to improve women's health and safety at work, as in the current directive, while better coordination of work and family life should be ensured through other directives and legislative instruments. We need to develop legislation that respects the logic and differences of each member state's system.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. For the European Union, the principle of equal treatment between women and men is one of its main objectives, encompassed in the fight against any form of discrimination. Motherhood and paternity should not lead to discrimination against any parent. Both sexes must equally assume the obligations of family care and household chores, so from the European Union we must support family reconciliation measures, even considering the alarming decline in birth in the EU. We cannot allow European regulation on maternity and paternity leave to be blocked in the Council, and that is why I voted in favour of the Resolution.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on maternity leave because I believe that the rights of working mothers cannot be locked in a drawer. The proposal to amend the existing directive extends the protection and safety of workers who are pregnant or have recently given birth, as well as mothers who have adopted a child under one year of age. I find it difficult to understand that the EU is able to agree on many economic measures, and when we talk about something as relevant as the rights of working mothers, the Council is unable to reach an agreement, and the Commission therefore raises the withdrawal of the proposal. I also defend the need, in the resolution, for the Commission to submit a proposal for a directive on paternity leave and a revision of the parental leave directive, in order to achieve better reconciliation of family and work life for mothers and fathers. Finally, I also endorse the request made to the Commission to submit a new proposal as soon as possible if it finally decides to withdraw the proposal on the table.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. The proposal to amend the existing maternity directive extends the protection and safety of workers who are pregnant or have recently given birth, as well as mothers who have adopted a child under one year of age. I find it difficult to understand that the EU is able to agree on many economic measures, and when we talk about something as relevant as the rights of working mothers, the Council is unable to reach an agreement, and the Commission therefore raises the withdrawal of the proposal.  I voted in favour of the resolution on maternity leave because I believe that the rights of working mothers cannot be locked in a drawer.  I also defend the need, in the resolution, for the Commission to submit a proposal for a directive on paternity leave and a revision of the parental leave directive, in order to achieve better reconciliation of family and work life for mothers and fathers. Finally, I also endorse the request made to the Commission to submit a new proposal as soon as possible if it finally decides to withdraw the proposal on the table.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. As already enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, the dignity of the individual must be respected and protected, and today, even with the vote on this important report, we are fighting for a future capable of offering socially fairer and wider horizons, capable of promoting family policies and protecting people's rights. Unfortunately, the figures do not always comfort us with regard to the objectives of social and labour policies that Europe is trying to guarantee. This is therefore the huge gap that we still find between the economic treatment of women's and men's employment, part-time or precarious contracts for women and stable for men, and the consequent treatment of women's pensions, which even reaches peaks of 39% less than that of men. All the necessary action must be taken immediately to ensure that discrimination is definitively overcome, allowing men and women equal access to the world of work, equal economic treatment and equal conditions, and again, but not last but not, the possibility of reconciling private and professional life by guaranteeing adequate maternity leave, which would also mean the drive to enlarge families and have more children. , ensuring mothers and families have a future with less uncertainty.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this oral question on the grounds that this directive encroaches too far into Member States’ right of subsidiarity and would have a disproportionate cost for the UK. Parliament’s amendments also go beyond the Commission’s original proposal and the recommendations of the International Labour Organisation. Additionally there are no legal grounds for the EU to be legislating on paternity leave. The Conservative Party believes that women’s rights are fundamental but sees no benefit for maternity, paternity or parental leave to be legislated on at an EU wide level. The Conservatives have already made considerable and progressive changes in the UK to maternity and parental leave in addition to the provision of childcare to help both mothers and fathers return to work after the birth of a child.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the maternity leave directive, which is currently blocked due to a lack of agreement between Member States. The aim is to improve the protection of pregnant and young women delivered by offering more homogeneous maternity leave in EU countries, as well as paternity leave of at least ten days. Maternity leave is an organizational responsibility for the company. If it were longer, employers would see better the need for replacement. These replacement positions could therefore be an opportunity to return to work, especially for women who themselves return from educational leave. It should be noted that northern European countries, such as Sweden, have both the longest length of maternity leave and the highest employment rate for women. This encouragement of motherhood is obviously a dimension of family policy, which avoids the usual discourse on ageing Europe justifying immigration. A national preference coupled with improved maternity leave conditions would therefore be ideal.  On the other hand, I recall that I questioned the European Commission about the lack of maternity leave in the United States, considering that this is an additional obstacle to the signing of the free trade agreement being negotiated.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. Since the first reading in Parliament in October 2010, for the adoption of an EP and Council Directive amending a previous Directive on maternity leave, this legislative process is blocked in the Council because of the position of some Member States. This amendment included, inter alia, extending paid maternity leave to 20 weeks, 2 weeks of paid paternity leave and protecting women upon return to work.  Amendment that risks disappearing in the legislative screening process which, under the pretext of regulatory effectiveness, has been undertaken by the Commission under the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT).

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on maternity leave because I believe that the Council should return to the negotiating table as soon as possible. Instead of scaring the withdrawal of the proposal, the Commission should make every effort to break this deadlock and develop a common position between Parliament and the Council. In view of the ageing of our continent and the low growth in most European countries, the rules guaranteeing a better reconciliation of family and professional life are extremely important.  I also voted in favour of paragraph 5 on the establishment of paid paternity leave. Fathers, like mothers, should be guaranteed the right to reconcile private and professional life. Member States should realise that it is in the interest of creating a law that does not deter young people from starting a family, but encourages them to do so.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour colleagues I voted in favour of this resolution because it reiterates a willingness to draft a separate directive establishing paid paternity leave of at least 10 working days and encouraging measures, legislative and otherwise, which will enable men, and fathers in particular, to exercise their right to achieve work-life balance.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. While the sharing of family and domestic responsibilities is still largely unbalanced, to the detriment of women, and while only a quarter of Member States offer paternity leave, our responsibility as European elected representatives is to support the implementation of a directive on maternity leave.  In order to shake up the immobility of the Council, which has so far refused to take a position, I supported the vote on a resolution to reiterate our desire to unblock this situation and to prevent this text from disappearing into the oblivion of THE REFIT. If the Commission were to decide to withdraw this proposal, then we would ask it to introduce a new piece of legislation. Beyond cost issues, I believe that this text is essential to improve the health and safety of pregnant, delivered or lactating workers at work, which would also address demographic challenges while reducing gender inequalities.  Too many women are at risk of poverty if they do not receive full protection during maternity leave, this is not acceptable. In the same way, by giving ourselves paternity leave at European level, we defend the place that fathers must take in family life.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on maternity leave because it gives us the power to continue negotiations on the maternity leave directive, which is currently intolerably stalled. I support not only clearer EU measures to promote birth rates, to provide clearer conditions for maternity leave, but I also voted in favour of the amendment to reduce parental discrimination by including paternity leave.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on maternity leave because I believe that the rights of working mothers cannot be locked in a drawer.  The proposal to amend the existing directive extends the protection and safety of workers who are pregnant or have recently given birth, as well as mothers who have adopted a child under one year of age. I find it difficult to understand that the EU is able to agree on many economic measures, and when we talk about something as relevant as the rights of working mothers, the Council is unable to reach an agreement, and the Commission therefore raises the withdrawal of the proposal.  I also defend the need, in the resolution, for the Commission to submit a proposal for a directive on paternity leave and a revision of the parental leave directive, in order to achieve better reconciliation of family and work life for mothers and fathers. Finally, I also endorse the request made to the Commission to submit a new proposal as soon as possible if it finally decides to withdraw the proposal on the table.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the revision of the Maternity Leave Directive as it aims to improve the protection and employment rights of pregnant workers and those who have just given birth or are breastfeeding as well as contribute to a better reconciliation of professional, family and private life.  This resolution reiterates the European Parliament’s willingness to end the deadlock, and calls for the Commission to play its role and to engage in a constructive manner with the co-legislators with a view to reconciling the positions of Parliament and the Council.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Today, a motion on maternity leave is also to be put to the vote. To avoid any misunderstanding: Sure, the longer, the better. But what does this have to do with 'Europe'? Where is the added value of a European solution? I do not think it, i am voting against the motion for a resolution today.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the FIDESZ-KDNP Group, I did not support the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, given that the definition of maternity leave allowance should remain the responsibility of the Member States. In our view, this directive should primarily include measures to improve women's health and safety at work, as in the current directive, while better coordination of work and family life should be ensured through other directives and legislative instruments. We need to develop legislation that respects the logic and differences of each member state's system.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ In the past I have had some misgivings about this Houseʼs position on maternity leave and it is clear that compromises will have to be found if we are to achieve a satisfactory outcome. It is not appropriate however for legislation to be simply jammed in the system and I therefore voted in favour of this resolution and would like to see some sort of meaningful progress on the subject matter.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. Since the first reading in Parliament in October 2010, for the adoption of an EP and Council Directive amending a previous Directive on maternity leave, this legislative process is blocked in the Council because of the position of some Member States. This amendment included, inter alia, extending paid maternity leave to 20 weeks, 2 weeks of paid paternity leave and protecting women upon return to work. Amendment that risks disappearing in the legislative screening process which, under the pretext of regulatory effectiveness, has been undertaken by the Commission under the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT). This motion for a resolution calls for this situation to be unlocked in the Council and negotiations between Member States to resume. Europe cannot fail to make decisive progress on equality between men and women.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: In writing. I believe that the negotiations on the maternity leave directive, or rather the lack of negotiations, are an example not to be repeated.  It is a piece of legislation that was approved by this Parliament five years ago to better protect mothers and pregnant women in the workplace. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.  This text thus contributes to the achievement of the major objectives of the "Europe 2020" strategy and contributes to equality between women and men; it promotes the recovery of the economy in Europe by improving the integration of women into the labour market and reducing the inequalities they face. And yet, this text was slowly buried and almost finally removed.  Parliament has consistently demonstrated its willingness to negotiate, but cannot do so in the absence of the Council, the co-legislator, or without the help and political will of the European Commission.  We are told to reintroduce a new proposal in the event of failure. What direction will it show when no official position has been expressed? A favourable outcome is still possible, but for this the three institutions must play their full role.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 Vote in favour of the development of a specific directive establishing paid paternity leave of a minimum duration of ten working days and favouring measures, legislative and non-legislative, allowing men, and in particular parents, to exercise their right to reconcile private life and professional life, and requests a revision of that Directive, and requests a revision of that Directive , since it fails to achieve its objectives of reconciling private life and professional life, in order to achieve work-life balance for the two parents, especially for women affected by the women-male pay gap, the retirement pension gap and poverty.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. I voted for the proposal for a resolution on maternity leave because I believe that discrimination should in no way be present when it comes to family and taking on family responsibilities. Women are often very undervalued when it comes to the unemployment rate. Because of the uncertainty of their work, it is usually those who first experience poverty and social exclusion. I believe that measures should be implemented to improve gender equality, such as the introduction of paid maternity leave for fathers in a quarter of EU members who have not had this before, and that work is being done to increase europe's ageing birthrate, as many couples choose to postpone starting a family due to crisis and uncertainty in the near future.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. At present, the maternity leave directive is blocked because Member States have failed to reach a compromise. The aim of the resolution presented here is to improve the protection of pregnant women and young mothers by homogenising the duration of maternity leave in the Union. The resolution also provides for paternity leave for at least ten days. By extending the duration of maternity leave, companies are obliged to provide for replacements. This initiative, in the end, is a way to create jobs in the Union. These positions will also be an opportunity for women returning from maternity leave to find a job quickly. The Scandinavian states are examples here, as they are the countries with the longest maternity leave and the highest employment rate for women. Immigration is therefore not a necessity: women can work and have children. This resolution therefore defends a proactive family policy. For all these reasons, I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the motion for a resolution on maternity leave. Indeed, the proposal to amend the current directive on this subject is not sufficient in my view to guarantee gender equality, only a new directive can be able to put in place this gender equality in the face of maternity leave and a harmonisation of European rights on this subject.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I warmly welcome the achievement of maternity leave, but I believe that national rules work better here than an EU one-size-fits-all approach. To express my support for maternity leave, while rejecting a less effective regulation at EU level, I am abstaining.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the resolution. It follows four years of deadlock over the 2010 Maternity Leave Directive which aims to extend the minimum length of maternity leave and protect the health and safety of workers who have recently returned to work after giving birth. We strongly deplore the attitude of the Council and urge the Member States to resume negotiations. If women are to play their full part in our economic recovery, and if we are to boost employment, it is clear we need to provide flexibility for mothers returning to the labour market after pregnancy. We are also calling on the Commission to present a separate legislative proposal establishing a paid paternity leave. Fathers must also have the right to achieve a work-life balance.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is quite sad that the European Parliament has to remind the Commission and the Council once in a while what to do and that they should agree. This is precisely the de facto purpose of the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, which I supported. The European Parliament has already discussed the proposal to amend the Maternity Leave Directive at first reading on 20 October 2010, and since then this only directly elected institution of the European Union has been waiting in vain for the Council's opinion. The change was to determine the rules for so-called paternal parental leave. One of the many reasons for this change was that the sharing of responsibilities in the family and in the home between women and men is an essential condition for achieving gender equality, and given that a quarter of Member States do not allow any paternity leave, it seemed appropriate for the European Parliament to comment on the issue. However, the other institutions seem to refuse to discuss the subject. In the debate, which was less than a day before the vote on the motion for a resolution, Commissioner Jourová announced that she was withdrawing the proposal to amend the Maternity Leave Directive and made the present document a worthless piece of paper. Six months ago, she promised: "I will seek support for the Maternity and Parental (i.E. Paternity) Leave Directive, which has been proposed since 2008."

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the FIDESZ-KDNP Group, I abstained on the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, given that the definition of maternity leave allowance should remain the responsibility of the Member States.  In our view, this directive should primarily include measures to improve women's health and safety at work, as in the current directive, while better coordination of work and family life should be ensured through other directives and legislative instruments.  We need to develop legislation that respects the logic and differences of each member state's system.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – A human-centred European Union is a resolution designed to help children not lose their jobs and to reconcile their work more easily with their family and private lives. At last, the European Parliament has stood firmly in the interests of citizens, even taking on the role of confrontation with the Council. Conscious childbearing must be promoted by all means, because that is where the future of Europe lies.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 Today this House condemned the Council's inaction on an important issue such as maternity leave. The Commission must activate its role as an impartial mediator between Parliament and the Council so that we can break this deadlock in achieving this common objective. It is important to establish a separate directive allowing men to have guaranteed their right as fathers with paternity leave of at least 10 working days. Through this we not only guarantee a right to fathers, but also, and above all, restore the balance in our families. The reconciliation of private and professional life in order to achieve a balance between family and work is one of the objectives to be achieved for families and for our society.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on the motion for a resolution on maternity leave in order to respect the principle of subsidiarity, taking into account, therefore, the structural differences of the Member States and the different historical and cultural traditions in this area, which, in my opinion, have not been properly incorporated into this proposal.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I wished to abstain on the vote on the resolution on maternity leave, because the proposals she is advocating do not allow us to hope to break the current impasse. It must be noted that, for the past five years, because of the extreme and up-to-the-button positions adopted by the European Parliament at its first reading of the proposed directive, the situation of deadlock in the Council has been total. It has not found the conditions for a start-up in its discussions on Parliament's position, and, as a result, under the application of the REFIT programme, the European Commission is considering withdrawing the initial draft directive, which is completely state-of-the-art, and taking a new initiative. Proposing new legislation on parental or paternity leave in the resolution, as the left-wing parliamentary groups have hoped, will not break the political deadlock. We need an in-depth debate to assess how best to respond to the challenge of improving the European framework for protecting the health of mothers and pregnant women and their better integration into the labour market, and certainly no cookie-cutter statements, with no tangible results to be expected.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. Currently, maternity leave is governed by a 1992 directive that grants a minimum of 14 weeks, six of which are mandatory with compensation equal to the full salary. The Commission proposed a revision of the text in 2008 to a minimum of 18 weeks. In 2010, Parliament voted to extend the leave to 20 weeks. But at the government level, the issue has been stalled since then, despite repeated calls from Parliament to move the issue forward on the basis of a minimum of 20 weeks of leave for mothers and two for fathers. Upon taking office, the new Commission indicated that if Parliament and the Council did not reach an agreement by June, it would withdraw its proposal. That is why, of course, I have the adoption of this text which rejects this blackmail by the Commission and calls on European governments to finally unblock this dossier, which would represent a real step forward for many European women.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted for it. The aim of this resolution is the 'maternity' directive, which is blocked due to a lack of agreement between the Member States. The text proposes a more homogeneous maternity leave in the countries of the European Union with the aim of improving the protection of pregnant and young women who give birth as soon as the child arrives. Fathers are not forgotten because paternity leave of at least ten days is proposed, which is a rather uncommon and encouraging measure. Northern European countries such as Sweden have both long-term maternity leave and the largest employment rate for women in the European Union. There is therefore no incompatibility between the two measures. The extension of the duration of parental leave is therefore not a handicap for the company and instead allows to better manage absences. Moreover, this kind of measure promoting motherhood is part of a natalist policy that the National Front has always defended. It is time, in fact, to stop the discourse that deplores the ageing of the population and thus justify the call to immigration and to start a policy promoting births.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Resolution calls on the Council, as co-legislator, to adopt an official position on Parliament's first reading and to take responsibility for rejecting improvements in the safety and health at work of pregnant workers, who have given birth or are breastfeeding. It also requests the Commission to indicate the concrete measures taken so far to bring the positions of Parliament and the Council closer, and to consult Parliament before withdrawing the proposal for a revision of the Directive. Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In support of Parliament's resolution to amend the Maternity Leave Directive, I voted in favour of equal rights for women throughout the European Union to enjoy the same standards of maternity leave and to maintain decent pay for young women. The maternity leave regulation meets EU policies on reconciling private and professional life, tackling demographic change and protecting women's health. Furthermore, the recommendations contained in this regulation indirectly contribute to the implementation of the 2020 strategy and allow young mothers to live a dignified life while caring for young children. Given that this project aims to improve the living conditions of Union citizens and is in line with the International Labour Organisation's recommendations on maternity protection, it should not be withdrawn.  I would also point out that this proposal also strengthens the protection of women from dismissal after the end of the maternity period, which allows women to maintain greater stability in employment.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against it because the resolution calls for the introduction of the Maternity Leave Directive. This matter must remain solely within the competence of individual States, taking into account the domestic situation.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: Written. – The PVV today voted against the resolution to reopen negotiations by the Council on the Maternity Leave Directive. The PVV is not against extra days off for new fathers and extra rest from newly a given mothers. However, we believe that this debate should not be held in the European Parliament because social benefits are and should remain a national competence. It is therefore up to national governments to take decisions on this at their own country level.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. At the beginning of the year, the European Commission set a six-month deadline for parliament and the Council to agree on amendments to the Maternity Leave Directive. The deadline is coming to an end, but there are still no negotiations on a topic that is both the demographic and social challenges of today. I supported The Resolution of Marie Arena and Iratxa García Pérez, which regrets that since October 2010 the Council has not responded to Parliament's position on amendments to the Directive and calls for a debate on maternity leave, as this creates a picture that women's rights and equal treatment of women are not a sufficiently important topic.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am proud to have been among the 419 Members who voted in favour; 97 were against, 161 abstained. The European Union is increasingly approaching common standards for maternity leave, but Latvia looks very good on this background. The document will not only promote gender equality, but will also actually help to raise the birth rate in the EU a little bit. In principle, this document is a follow-up to the initiative launched by my S&D colleague, Marc Tarabella, to protect women's rights and to fight for women's rights.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The position of women in relation to their natural mission – motherhood – and the reconciliation of their private and professional life must be legislatively ensured and resolved. There is a very low birth rate in the EU Member States. Indigenous people will dwindling. The escalating unfavourable demographic developments in Europe urgently require the creation of appropriate legislative conditions for the protection of motherhood, its material security, measures to improve workplace conditions for pregnant women and also for postpartum workers, but also a sufficient number of nurseries and crèches. Best practices of those EU countries with higher birth rates need to be followed. This subject is, above all, a subject of human and social, not political, so it cannot be the subject of pointless and unnecessarily long-lasting debates and processes.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, because it is complete and adequate but also for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech of 19/05/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this motion for a resolution. A maternity directive was under consideration but was never successful because there was no agreement between the Member States, which is why we welcome this motion for a resolution. Its aim is to improve the protection of pregnant women and young mothers by offering more homogeneous parental leave between Member States. We believe that these measures, coupled with a national preference, would be a good thing for France.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I consider it shameful that a directive aimed at regulating something as fundamental as maternity and paternity leave should drag on for years because of the lack of will of the Member States. It cannot be repeated to exhaustion that Europe has a demographic problem, that the birth rate needs to be increased, without creating basic conditions so that those who are a mother and who wants to be a father can actually be.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. It is important that we seek agreement between all the INSTITUTIONS that make up the EU to unblock the negotiations on the maternity leave directive, a matter which is too stagnant and which we must resolve, since European citizenship demands it. My support, therefore, for the resolution in which we from the European Parliament call for the negotiations to be resumed and for a proposal to be adopted that responds to what European society expects of us.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. As I do not believe that this issue falls within the competence of the European Union, I abstained from voting on this closure.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Resolution which deplores the deadlock in the Council regarding the Maternity Leave Directive and urges the Member States to resume negotiations.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In October 2008, the Commission proposed a review of maternity leave legislation.  The Commission initially proposed, on the basis of the ILO, 18 weeks of maternity leave (compared to 14 currently). In 2010, Parliament established a 20-week maternity leave. Since then the procedure has been blocked by the Council, which opposes the proposed paternity leave and is concerned about the cost of this measure. In 2014, the Commission extended the deadline for Parliament and the Council to reach an agreement by six months.  The Committee on Gender Equality here calls on the Council to take a stand and thus "take responsibility for the refusal to improve the safety and health of pregnant, delivered or lactating workers at work".  I vote for this text and denounce the hypocrisy of the French government in this matter. He claims to defend equal rights between men and women, the right to balance work and family life and the fight against wage inequality and when he has the opportunity finds it too expensive.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The Council has been delaying legislation on this matter for five years. I think it is appropriate that we reopen this dose in order to reach an agreement that is advantageous to all parties.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it is important that the negotiations on the Maternity Leave Directive between Member States at Council are resumed.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Every family needs sufficient time together at the moment of birth, therefore finding a balance between family life and work is necessary to reach a satisfactory situation for every mother, father and child, as well as for workers and for employers. I therefore supported the Resolution calling on EU countries to resume negotiations on maternity leave in order to improve the working time arrangements for mothers across the EU.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the existence and general recognition of pregnancy and maternity related rights, women are still discriminated against because of their pregnancy.
