Following the period of maternity or parental leave, the professional situation of women very often deteriorates and sometimes leads to harassment or to dismissal. We cannot accept the current situation and the outdated Council Directive in force (92/85/EEC) does not leave room for improvements. The Council has still not responded officially to Parliament’s first-reading position of 20 October 2010. If the Commission withdraws the proposal, the only acceptable option is a new legislative initiative. Parliament is ready to undertake a constructive inter-institutional dialogue demonstrating that citizensʼ rights and womenʼs rights come first and we are determined to fight discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy, maternity and parenthood.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal on maternity leave, which reviews a 1992 Directive, was tabled by the European Commission in October 2008 and the European Parliament (EP) adopted its position at first reading. In the last five years, the Council of Ministers of the European Union, which legislates on an equal footing with the EP in this area, has not made progress with legislative work due to lack of political will, and the proposal is currently blocked. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's proposal, which regrets blocking the revision of maternity leave and advocating the creation of paternity leave in the European Union. I believe that the European Union needs to move quickly towards extending the period of maternity leave provided for in European legislation from the current 14 to 20 weeks paid to 100%, so that it is easier to reconcile family and working life. Today, the European Union is in the strong running of a very serious demographic problem and it is essential to create new economic and social conditions that enable parents to exercise their family responsibilities in the best possible way.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The purpose of this resolution is to make the protection of pregnant or just-delivered women more effective, while the maternity directive is suspended due to persistent disagreements between States. It proposes to extend the duration of maternity leave to 18 weeks and thereby to standardise its practice (in accordance with ILO recommendations), but also to provide paternity leave of at least 10 days.  If it is up to The Member States, in principle, to decide on social reforms, this is a compelling public policy to ensure gender equality, particularly in access to work, since this measure is likely to increase the participation rate of women. This proposal therefore ensures a balance between private and family life in the name of the best interests of the child and could promote the birth rate in an ageing Europe. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 As Vice-President of the Intergroup on Family Policies, I voted strongly in favour of this resolution calling for the negotiations on the maternity leave directive to be relaunched. Since 2010, this text has been in the EU Council and there has been no response to the European Parliament's rulings on this matter. Pope Francis recalled here in Strasbourg in November that the family is "a fundamental cell and a precious element of every society [that] brings with it the fundamental elements to give hope to the future". But how can parents fully assume their educational role if a fair integration of tasks between fathers and mothers is not allowed, including through the establishment of paid paternity leave, nor a proper work-life balance? We cannot applaud the Pope's words and then contradict them with inaction.  The time has come for the European legislator to assume his responsibilities, therefore, by recovering the directive on maternity leave. Parliament has done so by adopting this resolution. We call on the European Commission and the EU Council to do the same.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I abstained on the final vote of the resolution on maternity leave because I am convinced that the only possible outcome for the harmonisation of maternity leave at European level will only be through the withdrawal of this directive and the drafting of a new proposal. To defend France's position, I supported the possibility of 10 working days of paternity leave. I am also in favour of measures on gender equality, shared parenting and work-life balance; Finally, I am against gender inequality in pay and pensions.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 With this motion for a resolution that we are voting on today, the European Parliament has the opportunity to demonstrate, in practice, its desire not to lower attention on the issue of the protection not only of motherhood but of parenthood in a greater sense.  The proposal is blocked in the Council after Parliament raised the number of weeks of maternity leave to 20 weeks, with an allowance equal to all pay, and introduced two weeks of paternity leave. It is now in danger of being withdrawn because of this stalemate, and today's resolution is yet another attempt to prevent this from happening.  How can we talk about 'Union' when there are such disparities within it and, depending on the Member State, we are going to increase from 2 to 22 weeks of compulsory leave? We need European legislation in this area that raises the bar for everyone and introduces paternity leave for everyone: a cultural shock that helps to understand that the family, and its care, affects all its members, not just mothers.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ On the Oral Question and resolution on maternity leave, I voted in favour. The resolution condemns the Commission for suggesting it will withdraw a draft directive to amend legislation on maternity leave by granting 20 weeks paid maternity leave and paternity leave of two weeks.  The amended legislation was submitted by the European Parliament to the Council in 2010 based on implementing a 2000 ILO Convention on work-life balance. The Council has blocked it. This resolution was an important attempt to save the proposed amended legislation from being dumped. Adequate and fair maternity leave is something everyone should be entitled to. It plays a crucial role in ensuring women can fully participate in the labour force and live fulfilling lives without being discriminated against at work for having children. For these reasons I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I have argued for years that we need common European legislation on maternity leave. As the document adopted today states, the issue of maternity leave, the issue of obvious inequalities between women and men on several fronts are very big problems for all states, including Romania. In this respect, European legislation ensuring rights and equalities for both parents is imperative on the basis of the principle of giving equal opportunities to all European citizens.  In this respect, I regret the deadlock in which the negotiations are located, I totally disagree with the delay in the Council at this time and I support the position of the report calling for the unblocking and expediting of the negotiations.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. \u2012 Ensuring equal opportunities for women and men and increasing employment rates requires that we also do so at European level so that maternity leave is properly and properly regulated in all Member States.  In my view, such a common European regulation would help to find a balance between life and work. I welcome the initiative to allow paid paternity leave.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution as it offers a significant improvement in the position of mothers and can contribute to a better work-life balance.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This resolution follows the Commission's decision to withdraw its draft legislation on maternity leave in the EU, which would harmonize existing situations in Europe and be a step forward for women's rights, gender equality and better work-life balance.  The resolution calls on the Council to resume talks with Parliament after four years of blocking the file, strongly condemns the Commission's proposal for withdrawing its draft directive, and instead calls on it to act as a conciliator between the two co-legislators.  If the Commission confirms its withdrawal, the resolution indicates that a new legislative proposal should be proposed shortly. I voted in favour of this resolution, which also provides for paternity leave, and calls for measures to enable men and fathers to have the right to a good balance between work and family life.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. I supported the proposal. It is regrettable that negotiations on amending the Maternity Leave Directive have run into gridlock. This should be overcome and the subject should be moved forward.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution.  In particular, the negotiations on the Maternity Leave Directive should be resumed, as it is essential to ensure that men and women have the opportunity to properly share family and household responsibilities while actively participating in the labour market. This would ensure a high level of employment for women and men, improve people's quality of life and strengthen economic competitiveness.  Interinstitutional instability needs to be removed and a solution to the impasse is urgently needed. It is therefore essential that the Commission assumes the role of fair mediator and cooperates constructively with the co-legislators in order to reconcile the positions of Parliament and the Council.  I believe that it would be appropriate to draw up a separate directive laying down paid paternity leave of at least ten working days, which would enable men, in particular parents, to exercise their right to work-life balance properly.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's call for the relaunch of the maternity leave initiative, because it is time to put an end to the current institutional impasse. The deplorable silence of the Council of Ministers must not be used as an excuse to put this issue to one side, but on the contrary to push us to raise our voices. The European Parliament and the Group of the Party of European Socialists do not intend to abandon pregnant women, and we therefore call on the Commission to present a new legislative proposal aimed at protecting women's health and safeguarding the right to work. We want to act to help women find a work-life balance so that they are not put at a crossroads.  Better legislation on maternity leave is a key step in strengthening the presence of women in the world of work.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for his work. However, given that a quarter of the Member States do not offer paternity leave, and that the sharing of domestic responsibilities between men and women is essential for achieving gender equality, I support the direct call for Member States to resume negotiations and the direct oral question to the Council in order to understand how to revise the text of Directive 2010/18/EU, with the sole aim of adopting the most effective protection measures.  For these reasons, Therefore, I voted against.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the maternity directive, which is currently blocked due to a lack of agreement between Member States.  The aim is to improve the protection of pregnant and young women who give birth on the arrival of the child by offering more homogeneous maternity leave in EU countries, as well as paternity leave of at least ten days (almost a quarter of countries do not offer paternity leave). While this resolution is a good feeling, I nevertheless believe that the birth rate policy must remain a prerogative of the Member States and should not be forcibly harmonized. Nor is it acceptable to bypass negotiations between sovereign states with this kind of resolution. That is why I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. Given that the principle of equal treatment implies that there must be no discrimination, direct or indirect, in terms of motherhood, fatherhood and equal sharing of family responsibilities. In view of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, which aims, inter alia, to increase the percentage of employees to 75% and reduce by 20 million the number of socially disadvantaged by 2020.  It should be taken into account that more women, unlike men, live in poorer conditions, especially older women whose pension benefits are on average 39% lower than that of men, as well as single mothers, and the fact that women are more likely than men to work part-time or on a fixed-term employment contract. It should also be taken into account that the financial crisis has affected the decline in birthrates in the Member States of the European Union, as well as the issue that a quarter of member states do not regulate maternity leave for fathers. Given that the Council has not yet formally responded to the first reading in Parliament as of 20.10.2010, the proposal for the adoption of the Maternity Leave Directive is fully adopted by the European Parliament's Resolution on Maternity Leave.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the European Parliament, in its resolution today, called on the European Commission to unblock the new legislative proposal on the Maternity Leave Directive. The blockage was made by the European Council. Some EU Member States disagreed with the extension of minimum compulsory maternity leave to 20 weeks, including Parliament's recommendation to pay the full salary allowance throughout this period, which the Council refused to accept. The Council has rejected further debates on this subject, which Parliament considers unacceptable. The renegotiation may finally take place under the forthcoming Luxembourg Presidency. The European Commission has received a clear signal about our priorities: above all, we want to protect the health and safety of pregnant women in the working environment and in the period following the birth of a child. Many women are most economically at risk at the time of maternity leave, a lack of economic security leads them to postpone starting a family until an ever older age. At the same time, we called on the Commission to prepare proposals for paid leave for fathers, because, like mothers, they should be given the opportunity to better balance their working and family lives.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain, not because it is against maternity leave, which I certainly support, but because I believe that it would have been a more balanced choice to put an oral question to the Council.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. On Wednesday, MEPs reiterated their desire not to withdraw the draft EU directive on maternity leave. However, this text has been blocked in the Council for four years.  I abstained because I believe it would be more effective and useful to give this directive a second life by encouraging the Commission to make a new proposal.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the non-legislative and non-binding resolution on the situation of the maternity leave directive. This resolution was more to do with the EU procedural situation that the content of the legislation. UKIP totally opposes the EU creating laws over the UK – the only people that should make such legislation are elected national governments, accountable to voters at the ballot box, not unaccountable EU institutions. Once EU legislation has passed, the only people that can initiate new, begin to repeal or start amendment of it is the EU Commission and they are not elected. However due to misrepresentation by the British press and other parties UKIP abstained to show that we are not opposed to maternity leave. What we are opposed to is unelected Commissioners in Brussels creating the law.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Exasperated by five years of deadlock, the European Parliament has demanded that the Commission take the maternity leave directive out of the fridge! Voted in 2010, the text is frozen in the Council, which is totally divided on the issue. This is not a big surprise, it must be admitted: Parliament's desire to extend maternity leave to 20 weeks compensated 100% made any compromise impossible. Far from attempting to demining, or facilitating a rapprochement, the Commission proposed to proceed with vertical classification, no more and no less. There is no way for MePs who reiterate their desire to break the deadlock and ask the Commission to play its part! I have, of course, supported this request, while continuing to believe that parliament was shooting itself in the foot by dint of loading the boat. Setting the bar too high is the risk of creating real discrimination in hiring, as confirmed by the OECD, but also by middle-class experts. Beyond the length of leave, and the level of compensation, it is mainly a question of having a system that, by virtue, does not ultimately penalize women themselves. Sometimes the best is the enemy of the good.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has sent a clear signal to the Commission on the issue of maternity leave. As my colleague Maria Arena said, we only ask the Commission to "do not give up on pregnant women, because there are many reasons to support them" in an increasingly ageing Europe. In addition to maternity leave, we also urge the Commission to submit paid paternity leave.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on maternity leave because I believe that the rights of working mothers cannot be locked in a drawer.  The proposal to amend the existing directive extends the protection and safety of workers who are pregnant or have recently given birth, as well as mothers who have adopted a child under one year of age. I find it difficult to understand that the EU is able to agree on many economic measures, and when we talk about something as relevant as the rights of working mothers, the Council is unable to reach an agreement, and the Commission therefore raises the withdrawal of the proposal.  I also defend the need, in the resolution, for the Commission to submit a proposal for a directive on paternity leave and a revision of the parental leave directive, in order to achieve better reconciliation of family and work life for mothers and fathers. Finally, I also endorse the request made to the Commission to submit a new proposal as soon as possible if it finally decides to withdraw the proposal on the table.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of this motion for a resolution, which denounces the current blocking of the Maternity Leave Directive in the Council and urges Member States to resume negotiations. This vote is also an opportunity to deplore the fact that the proposal to revise the directive risks being withdrawn by the EU executive under REFIT. On the contrary, I believe that the Council's Directive 92/85/EEC should be revised to better ensure adequate EU-wide minimum standards for maternity rights and thereby improve the safety and health of pregnant, delivered or lactating workers at work.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 At the present time, and always taking into account the deadlock in the Council, the structural differences of the Member States – for example on paternity leave – as well as the different historical and cultural traditions in this area, I have chosen to abstain from voting on the motion for a resolution on maternity leave.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. Since the first reading in Parliament in October 2010, for the adoption of an EP and Council Directive amending a previous Directive on maternity leave, this legislative process is blocked in the Council because of the position of some Member States. This amendment included, inter alia, extending paid maternity leave to 20 weeks, 2 weeks of paid paternity leave and protecting women upon return to work. Amendment that risks disappearing in the legislative screening process which, under the pretext of regulatory effectiveness, has been undertaken by the Commission under the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT). This motion for a resolution calls for this situation to be unlocked in the Council and negotiations between Member States to resume. Europe cannot fail to make decisive progress on equality between men and women.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted for mothers in the European Union to have an insured maternity leave. The European Commission must come up with a new proposal for a directive on maternity leave if it has to withdraw the current proposal, but I hope that the European Executive will finally succeed in reconciling the positions of Parliament and the Council in favour of mothers. It is not fair for the EU to give up defending the rights of pregnant women, especially as a number of women abandon their professional plans to have children. Europe's population is ageing and we need to ensure that appropriate conditions are created to maintain demographic balance. I believe that a full-paid maternity leave of 20 weeks is not an absurd request, and I hope that the Member States will achieve this.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported a resolution that reiterates the European Parliament's determination to make a constructive contribution to unlocking the situation in the Council, which has been preventing the adoption of the Maternity Leave Directive for several years. The lack of interest of the Member States in making progress on this matter is indeed regrettable, but it should not be a reason for the Commission to resign and not to continue its efforts to find a way out.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted positively in the resolution tabled, as this is a blockade of more than four years in the Directive amending Directive 92/85/EEC on maternity leave. This is an extension and harmonisation of a right of workers across the EU, extending their right to maternity leave until 20 weeks, and at least 2 weeks for workers immediately after childbirth; at the same time, it also reaffirms Directive 2010/18/EU on paternal leave, which guarantees minimum leave to share leave up to four months.  This proposal had been approved at first reading by Parliament but has since been blocked by the Council, leading to increased labour costs and job security. First, we believe it is unfair for workers to pay the consequences of the financial crisis and for it to have a negative impact on their rights; on the other hand, withdrawing this legislative proposal from the Commission will not help break with the perpetuation of gender roles associated with women's reproductive capacity in the world of work.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 Maternity leave is part of a set of basic and essential conditions in contemporary and developed society. Women and men must have equal conditions of access to the labour market and, for this, the absence of women by motherhood must be part of the system. And not, on the contrary, to be the victim of ostracism by the system.  In the European Union, labour markets are increasingly integrated. It is necessary to humanize them and introduce measures that truly reward the commitment of workers, whose value is beyond mere monetary compensation. Fighting for common standards in the implementation of maternity leave is not just a question of gender equality. It is a choice for a society that is already aged but wants to rejuvenate itself, for a society that refuses to reproduce discrimination. It is a choice for a society that is beyond the immediate, which has the ability to listen to silent causes, but nevertheless meets them. It is a choice for a model of society with a future and with which I wish to commit myself.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs have today called on the Commission to present a new legislative proposal to protect pregnant workers and provide stronger maternity and paternity rights. The resolution – which Tory MEPs voted against – follows four years of deadlock over the 2010 maternity leave directive which aims to extend the minimum length of maternity leave and protect the health and safety of workers who have recently returned to work after giving birth. MEPs also called for legislation to establish paid paternity leave.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Parenting is a huge gift and deserves the attention and support of employers and the state. The adoption of the resolution aims to address the situation of women on maternity leave within the EU. Although this is a very important topic for both women and families, it should be stressed that family policy falls entirely within the competence of the Member States, which can also lay down rules for maternity leave. That is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal for a resolution on maternity leave, which would increase this period to a minimum of 20 weeks instead of the current minimum 14 weeks of maternity leave. In addition to mother's leave, the motion for a resolution also asks for two weeks of paid leave for fathers. This draft law is actually an updated version of the Maternity Leave Act of 1992 and has been under no progress for four years due to the Council not yet declaring this case.  The proposal also represents a change of attitude, in legal terms, regarding the postpartum period as "sick leave" and pregnant women as "patients" and I strongly welcome the same measure.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – At present, the whole EU is facing a demographic crisis, fewer children are born every year, the population is ageing. This threatens the labour market and the entire social and pension system for the future. Also from this point of view is the incomprehensible approach of the Council, which has blocked the directive since 2010. Although the social system is determined separately by each Member State, it should be taken into account throughout the EU that, even as a result of the crisis, women are the most vulnerable working group in the labour market, that women earn much less than men and that, after retirement, they have a pension on average 39% lower than men. Extending maternity leave to 20 months and protecting pregnant women and new mothers after returning to work must be a priority for each Member State, and therefore the Council should resume negotiations on a European directive on maternity leave as soon as possible. There are also no excuses for the economic crisis and the austerity measures involved, because there is a need to close the gender inequality gap in pay, employment, but above all, all the preconditions need to be created for more children to be born and for mothers to therefore have all possible facilitation conditions in place. I consider the disapproval and concern of employers to be justified, which is why every Member State should enter intensively in the policy of maternity leave, guarantees of benefits and payments.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \ amendment of the Maternity Leave Directive was made by the Commission in 2008 and was intended to increase the protection of pregnant workers and workers who have just given birth. The amended Directive should help to facilitate the reconciliation of private and professional life.  The amendment to the directive would extend the minimum duration of maternity leave from 14 to 18 weeks and recommend that workers receive 100% compensation. Protection against termination of employment contracts would also be increased and workers would have the right to return to the same or comparable post after maternity leave and could apply for flexible working hours.  Parliament approved this proposal in 2010, including an amendment to extend the length of maternity leave to 20 weeks. Unfortunately, the Council has neither accepted nor rejected the proposal, and as a result, the new Commission has announced the withdrawal of the proposal to amend the directive if the Council does not deliver an opinion within six months. As the motion for a resolution addresses the council's unresponsiveness, which threatens the whole legislative process, and calls for it to be defined on Parliament's proposal and for taking responsibility for improving the health and safety of workers, I voted to support it.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution calling on the European Commission not to withdraw the proposal for an EU directive on maternity leave presented in 2008, despite being blocked for four years in the COUNCIL of EU Ministers.  The resolution reaffirms Parliament's desire to break the current deadlock and calls on the Commission to play its role as mediator in order to reconcile the positions of Parliament and the Council on the blocked text or, should the Commission withdraw its proposal, to present a new legislative initiative by the end of the year.  This is an important text to protect the health and safety of pregnant women in the workplace, in order to avoid exposing them to forms of discrimination and removal after birth and to ensure their full protection during maternity leave (paid leave of 20 weeks is proposed). In addition, the text calls on the Commission to present a proposal on paid paternity leave, with the aim of improving the work-life balance of parents and reducing the gender gap.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'I am very pleased that the EP today decided to call on the Commission not to withdraw the revision of the proposal on maternity leave. It concerns the safety and health of pregnant women at work. The old maternity directive dates back to 1992 and no longer reflects the current social reality. Parliament took a clear position on this as early as 2010.  The possible withdrawal of this crucial reform would be a slap in the face to mothers and fathers whose health and well-being would be strengthened by the proposals. European rules would be extended to the level of the recommendations of the International Labour Organisation. The EP agreed to increase the guaranteed maternity leave from 14 to 20 weeks while maintaining full paid leave and compulsory right to paternity leave for fathers. If Vice-President Timmermans wants to put a stop to safety and health standards at work for pregnant women with 'better legislation', he will first have to pass the Greens through our Group. I'll fight tooth and nail. If the Commission were to withdraw the directive, I would examine the possibility of taking this decision before the European Court of Justice.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to increase the birth rate in the EU, we need to create better conditions for women on maternity leave. The area of social affairs remains the responsibility of the nation states. The EU should create conditions so that Member States have more scope to extend maternity leave and increase net income during maternity leave.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒  I am a strong supporter of strengthened maternity and paternity rights, and so I voted in favour of this resolution. In order for people to balance their work and family lives we need a modern maternity leave framework which provides flexibility for mothers returning to work after having a child. To boost employment and economic recovery this needs to be addressed as soon as possible and I call for the Commission to take immediate action.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because I do not agree that the European Union should centrally determine the conditions and financial compensation for maternity leave for all EU countries. I believe that, in this area, the European Union is well above its remit and that decision-making on maternity leave should remain the full competence of the Member States.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, I voted against it mainly for two reasons. The directive calling for the resolution to be renewed is already problematic at its core, mainly because of the non-respect of the principle of subsidiarity, since the regulation of certain specific rights falls, in my view, within the competence of the Member States. First of all, However, I do not agree that the Maternity Leave Directive should address issues that, in my opinion, are not directly related to this subject, e.g. bioethic or gender issues.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ The position of the UK Conservative Delegation on this matter remains consistent. We would like to see the Commission withdraw this proposal and we remain opposed to the EU legislating on pay and conditions of maternity and paternity leave.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Council must respect the judgment of the European Court of Justice and provide sufficient justification as to why it is trying to withdraw the draft law extending maternity leave. There is also a need to establish paternity leave.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on maternity leave, which proposes on the principle of equal treatment between women and men. I am in support of the fact that there is no direct or indirect discrimination between men and women in the European Union, even on the basis of the commitment of family responsibilities. I support the motion's initiative to develop a paternity leave scheme with at least 10 paid days off, within the framework of a separate directive, and to further encourage legislative and other measures to enable men, in particular fathers, to exercise their right to work-life balance. I consider these proposals to be of the utmost importance in order to ensure a healthy balance in the lives of families.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In view of the demographic challenges facing the European Union today, decisive action is needed to promote fertility, as the rapid ageing of European societies can lead to a collapse or a significant breach of pension systems.  Although Poland currently has one of the longest maternity leave in Europe, at a rate of 12 months, I believe that the competence to determine their length should remain in the hands of the Member States. Only then will it be possible for the legislator to take into account a number of national and national considerations relevant to this issue, such as tradition or the level of socio-economic development of individual countries. I therefore abstained from voting on a resolution calling for the resumption of work on the amendments to the Maternity Leave Directive.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to send a clear message: the EU Council must unblock negotiations for the revision of the Maternity Leave Directive, which has stalled since 2010. In fact, in that year, Parliament approved its ambitious position to establish harmonised leave at EU level for maternity set at twenty weeks and also paternity leave of at least ten days, both of which are 100% paid. There are still too many differences between the Member States, and I firmly believe that the possibility of both parents being able to live in the most serene and participatory way possible a fundamental moment in life, such as the birth of a child, must be guaranteed.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Equal opportunities is a sine qua non principle of European society. There can be no doubt that the protection of mothers' rights and the encouragement of birth rates are priorities to be followed in all public policies at European level and, by implication, at national level. Inter-institutional bottlenecks cannot stand in the way of common sense, natural principles, which provide clear rules of protection for mothers in Europe and, at the same time, which provide for equal opportunities for women and men, including on the issue of raising children. We cannot be deterred by the Council's attitude when we know that women in Europe are paid less than men for work of equal value and ignore the cold statistic that they also have pensions that are 39% lower. It is time to act and it is time for the European Council to make commitments to European citizens, which include ensuring the protection of mothers and their rights to maternity leave, either by amending existing directives or by initiating new legislation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I am a strong advocate for women's rights. We urge the Commission not to withdraw a draft European directive on maternity leave, even though it is the subject of a four-year deadlock in the Council of Ministers, in a resolution voted on Wednesday. Ministers were also urged to resume negotiations and agree on an official position.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Maternity leave is an essential tool for women in today’s society and that should be acknowledged. But it is not the responsibility of the EU to legislate on that issue. This is a purely national competence and I believe that the EU should not interfere in such matter. This is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Long years of struggle have not yet led to real equality between women and men. Whether it is unemployment, wages, job uncertainty, and women's social conditions are often more precarious, which also reduces the birth rate in member countries. However, for the past five years, the Council has blocked a draft directive that would, among other things, extend maternity leave from 14 to 20 weeks. I voted in favour of this resolution because there is an urgent need to put an end to this situation. It meets several of my commitments: to improve health and safety conditions during pregnancy for women and children, to enable women to balance work and personal life, to support the birth rate. The directive calls on the Council of Ministers to resume negotiations and make its position known. It is important to remember that despite the votes of the right-wing and far-right conservatives, the European Parliament has voted overwhelmingly in favour of raising awareness of the reality of the status of women and increasing their rights.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Maternity Leave Directive, i.e. the health and safety of pregnant women or women labourers who have recently given birth or are ingested, has been blocked since 2010 due to disagreements between a smaller number of Member States in the Council. In my view, this issue should not be within the competence of Union legislation, as we know that the past practice of European and non-EU countries is very different in terms of the exercise of maternity leave rights. In addition to the fact that this issue needs to be addressed within the legislative framework of a Member State, I consider this to be a matter for every woman's personal choice. I base this opinion on the need to look at all the advantages and weaknesses in the application of maternity protection provisions in practice. I believe that parental leave benefits for women are not too stimulating and result in early return to work, which cannot achieve the basic goal of leave, which is quality care for the child. Member States are obliged to ensure respect for fundamental rights, the thus finding a balance between employers' demands and vulnerable groups of workers, including pregnant women, women who have recently given birth or are having a baby in order to address the implementation of non-discriminatory measures contributing to economic growth and recovery.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. Since the first reading in Parliament in October 2010, for the adoption of an EP and Council Directive amending a previous Directive on maternity leave, this legislative process is blocked in the Council because of the position of some Member States. This amendment included, inter alia, extending paid maternity leave to 20 weeks, 2 weeks of paid paternity leave and protecting women upon return to work. Amendment that risks disappearing in the legislative screening process which, under the pretext of regulatory effectiveness, has been undertaken by the Commission under the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT). This motion for a resolution calls for this situation to be unlocked in the Council and negotiations between Member States to resume. Europe cannot fail to make decisive progress on equality between men and women.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The legislation has to adapt to social changes and after twenty years from the current wording of the directive on maternity leave should make it a day. The profile of the traditional family has evolved in many ways, for example, has increased the number of single-parent families, the role of women in society and in the workplace has also made many steps forward, fortunately. But we need a new law that guarantees gender equality, to facilitate work-life balance. I ask the Commission not to withdraw the proposed revision of this Directive. I encourage all institutions involved to make an effort for dialogue for the sake of all Europeans.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the maternity leave directive, which is currently blocked due to a lack of agreement between the Member States. The aim is to improve the protection of pregnant women and young people delivered by offering more homogeneous maternity leave in EU countries, as well as paternity leave of at least ten days. Maternity leave is an organizational responsibility for the company. With a longer duration, employers would see better the need for replacement. These replacement positions could therefore be an opportunity to return to work, especially for women who themselves return from educational leave. It should be noted that northern European countries such as Sweden have both the longest length of maternity leave and the highest employment rate for women. This encouragement of motherhood is obviously a dimension of family policy, avoiding the usual discourse on ageing Europe justifying immigration. A national preference coupled with an improvement in maternity leave conditions would therefore be ideal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – Since the first reading in Parliament in October 2010, for the adoption of an EP and Council Directive amending a previous Maternity Leave Directive, this legislative process is blocked in the Council due to the position of some Member States. This amendment included, inter alia, extending paid maternity leave to 20 weeks, 2 weeks of paid paternity leave and protecting women upon return to work. Amendment that risks disappearing in the legislative screening process which, under the pretext of regulatory effectiveness, has been undertaken by the Commission under the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT). This motion for a resolution calls for this situation to be unlocked in the Council and negotiations between Member States to resume. Europe cannot fail to make decisive progress on equality between men and women.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which precludes the European Commission from withdrawing the draft Maternity Leave Directive, which would ensure a common framework for economic protection and job security for persons using such leave.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation, concerning Maternity leave because the European Union should renew urgently its maternity leave policy. Our continent is facing dramatic changes in social, demographic and financial terms. Therefore a more up-to-date regulation for new mothers is needed, so we will be able to cover not only the needs of mothers and their families’ new-born members but also the needs of the financial market.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted positively in the resolution tabled, as this is a blockade of more than four years in the Directive amending Directive 92/85/EEC on maternity leave. This is an extension and harmonisation of a right of workers across the EU, extending their right to maternity leave until 20 weeks, and at least 2 weeks for workers immediately after childbirth; at the same time, it also reaffirms Directive 2010/18/EU on paternal leave, which guarantees minimum leave to share leave up to four months.  This proposal had been approved at first reading by Parliament but has since been blocked by the Council, leading to increased labour costs and job security. First, we believe it is unfair for workers to pay the consequences of the financial crisis and for it to have a negative impact on their rights; on the other hand, withdrawing this legislative proposal from the Commission will not help break with the perpetuation of gender roles associated with women's reproductive capacity in the world of work.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Written. The N-VA is a party that pays close attention to the well-being of the family. This resolution calls for a mandatory extension of maternity leave to 20 weeks. The N-VA delegation abstains because the principle of subsidiarity must be guaranteed. The determination of the duration of maternity leave must be addressed at Member State level.  The N-VA delegation also points to the very specific and rather complex Belgian context given the existence of the various systems such as time credits and thematic engagement (e.g. parental leave). These systems are integrated into a system of career account, which is a flexible and tailor-made form of career policy and ensures an effective and workable combination between work and care.  The recitals also draw attention to the position of women in the labour market and their low employment rate. The N-VA delegation warns of the risk that a mandatory unilateral extension of maternity leave could further weaken this position.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my EPLP colleagues I voted in favour of this resolution because it reiterates its willingness to draft a separate directive establishing paid paternity leave of at least 10 working days and encouraging measures, legislative and otherwise, which enable men, and fathers in particular, to exercise their right to achieve work-life balance.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the Council to resume talks with the European Parliament on maternity leave. It has been four years since the Council blocked any discussion and therefore refused to formalise not only its rejection of Parliament's proposal, but also the idea of any directive in this area. Faced with this institutional deadlock, the Commission is threatening to withdraw the draft directive if the Council and Parliament do not quickly find a compromise. The European Parliament wished to support a recommended period of maternity leave of 20 weeks, which is fully compensated. Today, 11 Member States of the European Union have maternity leave for more than this period, but fourteen provide only six weeks. France, on the other hand, grants 16 weeks, of which only two are compulsory before giving birth. I voted in favour of this resolution which urges the Council to move in the direction of improving the living and working conditions of women in the European Union. In voting on this resolution, I also voted in favour of the drafting of another directive on paternity leave, for greater equality of rights between women and men in order to truly reconcile work and family life.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This question casts the true nature of the EU in question. For cuts in wages and social and labor rights there is always agreement. If countries are held hostage by the usury of banks, through troika loans, there is no doubt too and everyone agrees. As for sending military forces to sovereign countries, we also see no difficulty in getting agreement. But when it comes to protecting the rights of working mothers by guaranteeing them a minimum of 20 weeks fully paid for maternity leave, we only see uncomfortable silence. The Commission does not have to withdraw this proposal. This is a political decision, not an administrative one. As for the (not) political decision, it will be the people who judge it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this resolution because, in my view, this issue does not fall within the competence of the European Union.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has today sent out a clear signal: the Commission must present a new legislative text on maternity leave if it really wants to withdraw the current proposal. The Commission cannot and must not abandon women but, at the same time, it must have the ambition to propose a clear and defined strategy to enable mothers and fathers to reconcile parenting commitments and work, thereby reducing the gender gap.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected this resolution because the European Parliament is not the appropriate institution to decide on these issues. Maternity protection is an elementary part of family policy. This is, in principle, a national task. However, the EU acquires competence by exercising the woman, following the Marxist maxim, only as a fully integrated worker in the labour market, but not in her natural role as a mother. In addition, the Commission added an anti-discrimination clause as the legal basis. However, it is not a disadvantage for men not to naturally have children and therefore cannot benefit from maternity leave. The EP itself is to blame for the deadlock in the negotiations. It must be recalled that the rapporteur, Edite Estrela (S&D), overcame Parliament's position so excessively that the Council of Ministers has since quite rightly refused any further negotiations. All national delegations defend their own national law, because maternity protection, as part of national family policy, is deeply rooted in the cultural consciousness of nations. That is why it is self-deception for the EP to act as an 'honest mediator' in this resolution. If each Member State were to regulate its maternity protection on its own responsibility, it would also be understandable how the state and society value mothers and families.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my EPLP colleagues I voted in favour of this resolution, deploring the institutional deadlock around the Directive, calling on the Council to resume negotiations, and the Commission to play its role as an honest broker.  If the proposed directive does go into REFIT, it must be replaced immediately with a legislative alternative.   The resolution also reiterates Parliament’s willingness to draft a separate directive establishing paid paternity leave of at least 10 working days and encouraging measures, legislative and otherwise, which enable men, and fathers in particular, to exercise their right to achieve work-life balance.  I am proud that my colleagues in the Socialist and Democrats Group have remained determined and undeterred on this, to hold Member State governments in the Council of Ministers to account. There must be a push towards strong maternity and paternity leave, empowering women economically across Europe.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for a resolution calls for the Commission to come forward with new proposals to unblock discussions on the maternity leave directive. After four years of deadlock, there had been fears that the Commission would withdraw the original proposal without presenting a replacement text. The original Maternity Leave Directive aimed to extend the minimum length of maternity leave and protect the health and safety of workers who have recently returned to work after giving birth. Labour MEPs voted in favour of this resolution because we want to protect the rights of working parents and enable mothers, and fathers, to balance their work and family lives.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the debate on maternity leave needs to be reopened at European level. However, this issue must be approached constructively and openly, especially in the context of finding a satisfactory solution for European citizens from all Member States. This is undoubtedly a politically complicated matter that interferes with the subsidiarity of states.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is true that Slovakia already guarantees women up to 34 weeks' maternity leave in some cases, which is 14 weeks more than the proposed wording of the directive. Nothing would therefore change for Slovakia in this respect. However, the directive contains a provision whereing a woman would have received 100% of her previous salary during 20 weeks of maternity leave. Although this idea sounds attractive at first hearing, many Member States have said that their national budgets would not attract such a change. If, in some countries, a parent employer pays, it could in turn be that such an arrangement would lead to even greater discrimination against women in recruitment, as it would thus fundamentally 'make' the female workforce more expensive. From my point of view, the provision on two weeks' paternity leave can be regarded as the most positive part of the proposal. There are currently eight EU countries, and Slovakia is one of them, where men are not entitled to a single day of paternity leave. So he and his partner and newborn can't enjoy some of the rarest moments in their family life. Efforts to adopt this directive have been ted for seven years. The European Parliament has not been able to reach agreement with the Council. The time has come to admit that this proposal is, even for the reasons I am stating, impassable.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The demographic crisis in Europe is no longer a question of the near future, but a real problem that is increasingly affecting our ageing European society. The European Union is, of course, not a remedy for all the problems involved. It is the role of the Member States that is at the fore, they should ensure that social policies are geared towards supporting families and that women who decide to suspend their working lives and have a child are appropriated. This line between the competences of the EU and the Member States is very clear and no one is questioning it.  However, we cannot ignore the potential of the Community to create a family-friendly and motherhood-friendly climate. We have the opportunity at European level to combat the trends of an ageing population and we should seize this opportunity. Women's support is extremely important here, as they bear the greatest cost of deciding to have a child. Creating solutions to better contribute to men's childcare will be a valuable incentive to decide on parenthood. I believe that it is worth supporting this resolution and encouraging the Council to work more actively for our future.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This Resolution on the Maternity Leave Directive condemns the blockade in the Council with regard to this process of revision of the Directive, calls on the Commission to play the role of mediator and to intervene constructively with the co-legislators in order to reconcile the positions of Parliament and the Council, calls on the Member States to resume negotiations and reaffirms Parliament's readiness to end this impasse through negotiations.  The adoption of this Resolution goes in the opposite direction to that of the European Commission's decision reaffirmed in the Plenary of the European Parliament to withdraw the proposal to revise the Directive in the framework of the REFIT exercise. If this decision is made, the lives of millions of working mothers will be affected, who will continue to be discriminated against because they have had children and will make it impossible to fulfill the dreams of many young families. This is a decision that contrasts with the official rhetoric of the European Union on the alleged defence of equal rights between men and women, the right to work-life balance and the fight against wage inequalities (16.4% in the EU; 15.7% in Portugal). We voted for it.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's motion for a resolution, which calls on the European Commission not to withdraw the proposal for a directive already approved by the European Parliament in 2010 and instead to call on the Council to resume negotiations. I am convinced that, in substance, it is important to have legislation that ensures that mothers combine their private and working lives when they want to have children and that workers cope with this situation. Parliament had increased the minimum weeks of maternity leave to 20, with 100% allowances, compared with the 18 initially proposed by the Commission. It is true that the European Parliament's expectations were high compared with the Commission's initial proposal, but the Council has never taken a position, given the disagreement between the States, and this behaviour risks losing the job of so many years.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: – Mr President, the job-taking, which has now been adopted by a huge majority, gives the UN concrete answers about the measures that the European Parliament has taken in recent times. I would like to highlight a few specific references. The first is that the Resolution calls on the three EU Member States, Finland, Ireland and the Netherlands, to ratify as soon as possible the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The other specific reference is that it urges the European Commission to involve the European Parliament in the dialogue with the UN Committee as soon as possible so that we can conduct this dialogue together. The third is to urge the Commission to present the European accessibility package as soon as possible. Fourthly, a specific budget should be foreseen for the EU framework for monitoring the implementation of the UN Convention in order to be able to carry out its work effectively. I would like to point out that, after the UN has examined the European Union and is making its recommendations, the three Commissions of the European Parliament, EMPL, LIBE and PETI, will prepare a joint report on the process. Finally, I would like to thank you, because I think it is symbolic that the factions were able to work together and such a cross-cutting cooperation was born.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would like to explain why I voted in favour of the resolution by which the European Parliament responds to united nations questions on the fulfilment of the rights of people with disabilities.  On equal employment opportunities for people with disabilities, the European Union should set an example. I also have great respect for my fellow Members who work with great commitment here in the European Parliament, after all, my speaker, Mr Kosa, is just one of these very active Members. The lack of action of the European Union is also evidenced by the fact that there is still a small percentage of employees with disabilities in the institutions and bodies of the European Union themselves. I know that criticism of the UN Committee on the Rights of People with Disabilities is not always pleasant, but it cannot be taken lightly and must be confronted and actively held.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I supported this motion because it is clear that much more needs to be done to make sure that people with disabilities – and their carers – are offered the same opportunities as any other person. In the UK there are currently 1.3 million disabled people who are available and want to work, but only half of them are employed. Less than a quarter of disabled people have qualifications. Their carers are in a situation that is no better: 81% of at-work parents indicate that finding suitable childcare for a disabled child or children is a major barrier to pursuing a career. In the UK, again, we have 700 000 such children, and across the EU 15 million children, and their families whose options are potentially restricted through the lack of an enforceable entitlement to customised childcare. That is why it is crucial that the EU institutions step up their game to implement the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. This House can be instrumental in making sure that this happens.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Mr President, there are 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union who, as citizens of the European Union, have the same rights as anyone else. However, practice is far from the case and people with disabilities face a number of obstacles that healthy people are not even aware of. Whether, for example, in access to education or work, in transport, in search of independent housing.  The European Parliament, in cooperation with the Commission and the Council, should work to remove these obstacles and on the specific objectives and basic tasks identified by the UN Committee. In this context, I would like to appeal to the European Commission to present as soon as possible the promised European Accessibility Act, which also highlights the recommendations of the UN Committee to the European Union. We should bear in mind that the Convention sets only minimum standards for the protection of persons with disabilities. The European Union should strive to promote them to a higher level. I therefore supported the European Parliament's resolution, of course.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, I am in favour of this because I believe recognising the rights of persons with disabilities is not only of benefit to people with disabilities, but is of benefit to us all because of all that can be offered.  In fact, if you look at the majority of people, they have some form of a disability, whether it be my colour blindness and not being able to use the tube map in London, or whether I have one leg shorter than the other. We all have disabilities one way or another and we all have something to offer. This is what the European Union should be about. I come from a country where 50 years ago people were put in institutes on the basis that you would hide them from your family in case someone thought that you were the source of evil that created this. It is wonderful, in what is a very flawed world, that this is something that seems to be continuously improving and does give hope.  I am 100% in favour of this, not only for people with disabilities, but because I think it is to the advantage of absolutely everyone.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I am very happy to support this motion today because it is important that the active inclusion of disabled people and their full participation in society be promoted, in line with the EU human rights approach to disability issues. It is an approach at the core of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and the Commission’s disability strategy builds on that convention. We must prioritise areas such as accessibility, make services and facilities accessible to people with disabilities, and promote the marketing of assistive devices. That is where the digital strategy that has been promoted now will certainly be of enormous benefit to people who have disabilities. In the area of employment, we need to raise significantly the share of persons with disabilities working in the open labour market. We must also promote inclusive education and lifelong learning for individuals with disabilities. I note that the Commission has welcomed or launched several education initiatives particularly for disabled people, including the European Agency for Development in Special Needs Education, as well as a study of disability and lifelong training. We in this House must welcome all this and promote them and support them.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, every man should be provided with fundamental human, civil, political and social rights and the protection of human dignity. Diversity must not be a cause for discrimination, nor should we allow anyone's disability to be a reason that prevents them from participating in society. That's exactly why I supported this resolution.  Given that there are around 80 million people with disabilities living in the European Union, that they continue to face discrimination and barriers in their daily lives, I believe that we should do everything in our power to remove these barriers. It is essential that all EU countries comply with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and implement the European Disability Strategy in their social policies.  Member States should protect and promote the human rights of persons with disabilities and provide them with equal opportunities to participate in civil, political, social, economic and cultural life.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is estimated that there are almost 80 million people living in the European Union with serious and average forms of disability.  The United Nations Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities, which, as has been mentioned, has been ratified by the European Union but not by all The Member States ( 3 are still missing), is, however, an absolute point of reference because it guarantees the recognition of the universality of human rights and the need to ensure the full active inclusion of persons with disabilities, without discrimination. However, there are still gaps in data and accessibility to goods and services and employment, as well as often to citizenship rights. I voted in favour because I believe that with this resolution we are making real progress, first of all by asking the Commission to approve the package for disabled people aimed at these policies in order to have a dedicated budget line. Above all, however, I am prepared, as chairman of the Committee on Culture and Education, to cooperate with the other committees, for example on the issue of the inclusion of quality, the integration of disabled people into schools and universities. Finally, we call for greater involvement of Parliament and the associations in the monitoring of the Convention.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Mr. President, there are 80 million people with disabilities living in the European Union who need to have the same rights as everyone else, work and education opportunities and quality everyday life. However, in everyday life they encounter a number of obstacles.  It is necessary to take a full look at the problems that people with disabilities face, from problems in health, education, employment to inclusion in society and everyday life in families or the lives of single people. For each of the areas, we need to set goals and activities that will make progress in quality of life. Social inclusion is one of the objectives at the level of the European Union strategy that cannot be achieved on its own. The work of all Member States and all institutions is needed.  There are 520,000 people with disabilities in Croatia. They have been hardest hit by the crisis, government savings, unemployment. A small step has only been taken recently with the introduction of compulsory employment quotas.  There is still a lot of work to be done to understand and tackle people with disabilities. This Parliament resolution calls on everyone to act actively and raise awareness of the vulnerability of disability problems and I am happy to support it today.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. The resolution adopted today on the revision of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities reiterates the obligations of the EU and its Member States for the effective implementation of the principle of accessibility and non-discrimination of persons with disabilities in a cross-cutting manner and not only with regard to access to employment , to achieve true autonomy and independence.  In this regard, the Spanish Socialists are very pleased to have obtained the support of the House (566 votes in favour, 84 against and 26 abstentions) to our proposals for a request to the Council to unlock the Anti-Discrimination Directive, which has been blocked since 2008.  We also welcome the fact that we have obtained the support of the House to request Member States to remove restrictions on the exercise of the right of active and passive suffrage of persons with disabilities currently in force in 21 of the 28 Member States, for a restrictive interpretation of their legal capacity and in contravention of Article 12 of the CDPD on equality before the law.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution as I share its content whose main claim is the best objective of the living conditions of persons with disabilities, through equal access to services and the labour market. I regret that it is not mentioned that this can only be done through a policy that strengthens public services and establishes concrete anti-discrimination policies for persons with disabilities, and although it urges States to cooperate with each other in these areas, it does not set a concrete priority or set minimums to be met within the Union.  However, I understand that the political will of this resolution is positive, hence my vote in favour, but there is a lack of concrete resources and commitments in ending discrimination (double discrimination in the case of women with disabilities) suffered by these people.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Four years ago, the EU and 25 of its Member States ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Nevertheless, there is still much to be done. The rights of people with disabilities must be taken into account at all levels in the EU: starting with legislative proposals, implementation and, ultimately, particularly monitoring. In particular, access to the labour market and education, transport and accessibility and social security need to be improved. I welcome the motion for a resolution and I am counting in particular on cooperation with the European Agency for Fundamental Rights and the European Disability Forum.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to implement the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. EUR 80 million | The people of the European Union have a disability. 2008 The Commission has proposed an EU anti-discrimination directive, but it is still blocked by the Council. Existing EU legislation on the rights of persons with disabilities should be better implemented and its implementation should be better ensured in order to increase access to these rights for all persons with disabilities throughout the EU. I support the calls set out above for the collection and dissemination of disability statistics, for people with disabilities to access goods and services, to promote the independent lives of persons with disabilities and to increase access to public sector bodies' websites. The implementation of EU legislation needs to be improved in order to ensure that people with disabilities can travel independently using all modes of transport, including public transport.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Strategy 2010-2020 for People with Disabilities is essentially aimed at empowering people with disabilities to enjoy their rights on an equal footing with other citizens and removing the barriers they face in their daily lives. It is also intended to contribute to the practical application of the provisions of the Convention, both at EU and national level. This strategy supports and complements the measures taken by Member States on disability, a competence that is theirs first.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Union currently has almost 80 million people with disabilities and it is clear that they are finding jobs more difficult than others despite all the measures taken in the various Member States. This resolution wants to draw up a list of statistics on disabled people in order to monitor their situation, it also calls on the three Member States that have not yet done so to ratify the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and it also encourages the adaptation of the means of communication for them such as the accessibility of websites or the ratification of the Treaty of Marrakech. If we generally agree with these measures which are in line with more rights for people with disabilities, I do not think that it is up to the EU to propose this convention to the states for signature, since they must remain sovereign in terms of international agreements and conventions that they pass. I therefore abstained on this motion for a resolution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution and strongly call on the Commission to take action to present a concrete and workable proposal for European legislation on accessibility for people with disabilities; I regret the lack of progress in the Council on this issue and hope that the Member States will take steps to adopt a common position without further delay.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The resolution adopted today on the revision of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities reiterates the obligations of the EU and its Member States for the effective implementation of the principle of accessibility and non-discrimination of persons with disabilities in a cross-cutting manner and not only with regard to access to employment , to achieve true autonomy and independence.  In this regard, the Spanish Socialists are very pleased to have obtained the support of the House (566 votes in favour, 84 against and 26 abstentions) to our proposals for a request to the Council to unlock the Anti-Discrimination Directive, which has been blocked since 2008.  We also welcome the fact that we have obtained the support of the House to request Member States to remove restrictions on the exercise of the right of active and passive suffrage of persons with disabilities currently in force in 21 of the 28 Member States, for a restrictive interpretation of their legal capacity and in contravention of Article 12 of the CDPD on equality before the law.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – It is a unique historical opportunity for the UN to examine whether the EU is properly implementing the UN Convention for the Protection of Persons with Disabilities. The European Parliament must not miss the opportunity to send a reply to the UN on its own behalf. This is what the resolution is about, which gives concrete answers to the UN on what the European Parliament is doing for people with disabilities. In the decision, we call on the three EU Member States – Finland, Ireland and the Netherlands – who have not yet ratified the Convention to do so as soon as possible, and those who have already ratified it, including the EU itself, to speed up the implementation of the Convention. We urge the European Commission to formally involve Parliament in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to establish the long-awaited European Accessibility Act. And for the EU Framework, of which the EP is a member, which monitors the implementation of the Convention, we need resources to be able to operate effectively. It is important that, following the final UN report, the European Parliament's EMPL, LIBE and PETI committees will also prepare a joint report on the subject, expected later this autumn. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion because it will facilitate the effective implementation of the UN Convention.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. It is estimated that over 80 million people with some form of disability live in the European Union. They, as full citizens, have equal rights and have the right to inaliething dignity, equal treatment, independent living and full participation in society.   We must take into account the fact that the provisions of the UN Convention are minimum standards that allow the European institutions to act further in protecting people with disabilities and combating discrimination. Existing legislation on the rights of persons with disabilities should be better applied to increase accessibility for all persons with disabilities throughout the Union.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Joint Motion for a Resolution, tabled by all parliamentary groups. The purpose of this resolution was to call, as MEPs, for the European Parliament to have a formal role in the process of monitoring and commenting on the progress of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities (UNCRPD). While the European Parliament is part of the EU Framework to promote, protect and monitor the UNCRPD across the EU, the Commission appears to be excluding Parliament from formally and meaningfully participating in the review process being carried out by the UNCRPD Committee. The most significant proposals in the Resolution are the statement that the Parliament will respond directly to the CRPD Committee in relation to all questions in the List of Issues that it has competence over. The Resolution lists these. It also calls on the Commission to take Parliament’s views into account when it sends its own response to the CRPD Committee.  More than 13% of the population across Ireland are living with a disability. I voted in favour of this report because it is crucial for political representatives,  as well as broader civil society and especially disability rights organisations, to be properly included in the review process.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to support this resolution with my vote, since I agree with the need to draw up European legislation on accessibility that will allow citizens with disabilities to enjoy their rights to the full.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 An estimated 80 million people in the European Union have some form of disability in 2014 and are therefore one of the largest and most vulnerable groups of people in our society. It is a non-homogeneous group, whose full integration into social and working life represents a major challenge for all of us. Today there is still no EU policy that is equal to the situation: the Commission proposed an EU anti-discrimination directive in 2008, but unfortunately it is still blocked by the Council. Nevertheless, we believe that full integration and equal participation of people with disabilities can be achieved.
