It is possible to create a truly free, welcoming and barrier-free society by promoting the implementation of human rights at all levels of the definition, from programming to monitoring EU policies, thus binding the Commission to take account of Parliament's proposals. Legislative proposals must involve the representations of disabled people in their drafting and must affirm the right to paid work and adequate training from primary school as essential elements to enable people with disabilities to lead independent lives and contribute to the society in which they live.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This proposal for a resolution with a declarative scope calls for the issue of disability to be better addressed by the various EU institutions. While this issue is paramount and needs to be better integrated into public policy, it is primarily within the sovereign competence of the Member States. The fight against disability should not be used as a pretext to strengthen the European Commission's interference in the public policies of each Member State. That is why I abstained on the vote of this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Whether we are talking about social integration or economic inclusion, people with disabilities need continuous support. Instruments such as the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities at international level or the Europe 2020 Disability Strategy at European level provide a concrete and comprehensive framework governing the situation of respect for the fundamental rights of persons with disabilities. In the context of economic and social integration, it is important to stress that around 80 million people are often unable to participate fully in social and economic life because of physical and behavioural barriers. People with disabilities are more prone to social and economic exclusion, so an integrated approach to the problem must be used for these people to enjoy the same rights. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because we must be aware that every citizen matters, and the inclusion issues of people with disabilities are a barometer for respect ing human rights in society.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. As part of the monitoring of the implementation of the CRPD, the UN dedicated committee sent a list of issues in reference to the EU's initial report. In addition to pointing out the answers and actions already taken by the EU in relation to this list of questions, Parliament ensures that the questions put directly to it are answered and calls on the Commission to answer the questions put to it. Of course, there is a call for the Commission to 'present an ambitious proposal for European accessibility legislation' (paragraph 8) and an emphasis on 'the need for enhanced political cooperation within the EU framework' (paragraph 12).

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. The resolution adopted today on the revision of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities reiterates the obligations of the EU and its Member States for the effective implementation of the principle of accessibility and non-discrimination of persons with disabilities in a cross-cutting manner and not only with regard to access to employment , to achieve true autonomy and independence.  In this regard, the Spanish Socialists are very pleased to have obtained the support of the House (566 votes in favour, 84 against and 26 abstentions) to our proposals for a request to the Council to unlock the Anti-Discrimination Directive, which has been blocked since 2008.  We also welcome the fact that we have obtained the support of the House to request Member States to remove restrictions on the exercise of the right of active and passive suffrage of persons with disabilities currently in force in 21 of the 28 Member States, for a restrictive interpretation of their legal capacity and in contravention of Article 12 of the CDPD on equality before the law.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the list of issues adopted by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities on the initial report of the European Union. There are more than 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union. All too often they are discriminated against and face considerable obstacles. It is our duty to facilitate the daily lives of these people. With this resolution, the European Parliament assures that it will answer all questions from the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Parliament also calls on the European Commission and Member States to work towards improving respect for the rights of people with disabilities.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the UNITED Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. People with disabilities have equal rights, including those inalienable to dignity, equal treatment, independent living and full participation in society. Unfortunately, even in Europe, they face discrimination and obstacles to the exercise of their rights on an equal footing with others. The resolution adopted by Parliament therefore called on the Commission to present an ambitious proposal with regard to European accessibility legislation, which fully involves disabled people throughout the legislative cycle. The resolution also highlighted that this proposal must cover a wide range of policy areas in relation to accessibility to goods and services for all EU citizens, promoting independent living and the full inclusion of people with disabilities.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This Joint Motion for Resolution aimed to wind up the debate on the statement by the Commission on the List of Issues adopted by the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in relation to the initial report of the European Union (2015/2684(RSP)). The purpose of this report is essentially to call for the Commission to formally and meaningfully include Parliament in the review process, as well as including responses from civil society. It is a Joint Motion for a Resolution by all the Groups.  The proposal for an EU anti-discrimination Directive aims to protect persons with disabilities against discrimination in social protection, health care and (re)habilitation, education, as well as access to and supply of goods and services, such as housing, transport and insurance; deplores the lack of progress within the Council on this proposal and urges Member States to work towards the adoption of a common position without any further delay. This is of fundamental importance in any democracy and it was for these reasons that I voted in favour of the Joint Motion for Resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I have always worked to ensure that people with disabilities are guaranteed equal opportunities, fundamental rights, equal access to services and the labour market, as well as the same rights and obligations with regard to access to social security as nationals of the Member State in whose social security system they fall, in line with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I firmly believe that the European Union and its Member States must honour their commitments as signatories to the Convention. For me as rapporteur on Web Accessibility, I would like to especially stress the need to ensure that persons with disabilities are fully included in the digital revolution and our European Digital Single Market.  As we move forward with e-government and e-commerce, all citizens must be able to take part and have full access to information. I hope the Commission will take this into account when drafting the concrete proposals listed in the DSM strategy action plan. I also look forward to the Council adopting its General Approach on Web Accessibility as soon as possible so we can finally make this EU law and make sure no one is left behind in Digital Europe.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Today, the European Parliament approved, with a resounding majority, this resolution on active inclusion and participation of disabled people in the EU. On foot of the adoption of the UN Convention on the Right of Persons with Disabilities, Member States should translate the obligations derived from Article 12 of the Convention into national laws, but more importantly ensure the right of all persons with disabilities to vote and to be elected.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution we voted on is an important step towards the full implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, moving in the direction of strengthening the role of the European Parliament in monitoring and implementing this Convention, in close cooperation with the UN Committee responsible for analysing progress in the implementation and implementation of the Convention. The resolution also calls for the rapid adoption of two legislative measures of great importance to people with disabilities: a European Accessibility Act and the Directive to protect persons at risk of discrimination. Furthermore, the resolution calls on the Member States to respect the obligation arising from Article 12 of the Convention to guarantee in their national legislation the right of persons with disabilities to the active and passive electorate.  More generally, the resolution also promotes the inclusion and full participation of people with disabilities in social life, including through their representative organisations. For these reasons, I voted in favour of

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 In the EU, 80 million people live with some form of disability. Unfortunately, as denounced by the many petitions submitted to the EP, these people often face discrimination and obstacles to the exercise of their rights. As far as employment is concerned, in the 20-64 age group, less than 50% of people with disabilities have jobs, compared with over 70% of non-disabled people, while for women with disabilities this figure falls to 44%, compared with 65% for non-disabled women.  The EU has formally ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD), which has been signed by all 28 EU Member States and ratified by 25 of them. This motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to officially consult all relevant institutions, agencies and organisations and to present an ambitious proposal on accessibility, including electronic accessibility, recommends that EU funds be used for this purpose and, finally, calls on those Member States that have not ratified the Convention to ratify it without delay. In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Persons with disabilities, as full citizens, enjoy the same rights and are entitled to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, autonomy and full participation in society. People with disabilities are one of the most vulnerable groups in our society and their integration into the labour market presents one of the greatest challenges facing social and labour market policies.  I support this resolution because I believe that better implementation of EU legislation is needed to increase accessibility for all people with disabilities in the EU. On the other hand, Member States which have not yet ratified the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities should ratify it as soon as possible. In order to ensure the full mobility of all citizens, it is imperative to ensure that people with disabilities can travel autonomously, using all means of transport, including public transport.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution tabled by Parliament following the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, appreciating, in particular, the European Parliament's increased attention to disability issues and its commitment to combating discrimination and the isolation of affected individuals.  Ensuring access to employment is essential to enable people with disabilities to lead independent and independent lives. I therefore support the call on the Member States to ensure that this is done.  I also believe that all relevant civil society organisations, agencies and institutions, primarily Parliament, as an expression of the will of the people, must be consulted and involved in order to find the most appropriate responses to the outstanding issues related to the issue of disability, in order to facilitate the implementation of the CRPD Convention and the monitoring of progress. Finally, I support the call for the Commission to present an ambitious proposal for European legislation on accessibility that will allow the use of quality goods and services for all EU citizens, promote independent living and the full inclusion of people with disabilities and establish a permanent, effective and independent mechanism to record their development.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. "Based on the circumstances of each Member State, it is important for us Moderates to underline that it is the individual countries that can best combat the discrimination that exists among citizens of different countries and can best ensure that the rights of all citizens are respected.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this resolution as I share its content whose main claim is the best objective of the living conditions of persons with disabilities, through equal access to services and the labour market. I regret that it is not mentioned that this can only be done through a policy that strengthens public services and establishes concrete anti-discrimination policies for persons with disabilities, and although it urges States to cooperate with each other in these areas, it does not set a concrete priority or set minimums to be met within the Union. However, I understand that the political will of this resolution is positive, hence my vote in favour, but there is a lack of concrete resources and commitments in ending discrimination (double discrimination in the case of women with disabilities) suffered by these people.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a historic opportunity for the UN to examine whether the EU is properly implementing the UN Convention for the Protection of Persons with Disabilities. On this occasion, the European Parliament will also send a reply to the UN in the form of an adopted resolution on its own behalf, detailing what the institution is doing for people with disabilities. The EP resolution calls on the three EU Member States that have not yet ratified the Convention to do so as soon as possible, and those who have already ratified it, including the EU itself, to speed up the implementation of the Convention. It also urges the European Commission to formally involve Parliament in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to establish the long-awaited European accessibility legislation. Resources are needed for eu framework cooperation monitoring the implementation of the Convention, of which the EP is a member, to function effectively. Following the final UN report, Parliament's EMPL, LIBE and PETI committees will shortly prepare a joint report.  For example, this institutional cooperation at international level for the rights of persons with disabilities could serve as an example of similar steps taken to protect the rights of other persons, who also require greater legal protection and attention than those of national minorities. I voted in favour of the adoption of this motion because it will facilitate the effective implementation of the UN Convention.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. We are an inclusive society which has the responsibility and duty to treat all its citizens equally and with dignity. Persons with different abilities deserve the same treatment and opportunities as anyone else. Empowering persons with disabilities in the field of access to employment can ensure an independent living module to all those who seek it. This combined with a move from institutionalisation to community-based care, a good educational basis for children with disabilities, both physical and intellectual, based on the concept of ʽdifferent abilitiesʼ rather than ʽdis-abilitiesʼ can help us fight the social stigma that persons with a disability still face in todayʼs day and age.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This proposal is part of the European Commission's consultation process with the European Commission in the framework of the work of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CDPH), which monitors the European Union's implementation of the Convention. In particular, this text calls on the European Commission to answer all the questions that would be put forward by that committee. Parliament is also calling on Member States that have not yet done so to ratify the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities as soon as possible. This resolution also recalls the work under way in Parliament on the EU's proposal for an anti-discrimination directive, which aims to protect disabled people from discrimination and deplores the lack of progress in the Council. Considering that it is necessary for the European Union and the Member States to respect their international obligations and make ambitious proposals to facilitate the accessibility and participation of disabled people in the life of the city, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. As the Member States have all signed and/or ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the European Union must have a clear policy on the rights of persons with disabilities. It is important that Parliament should take part in the monitoring of the European strategy for people with disabilities. He is the direct representative of the 500 million European citizens, 80 million of whom are disabled. As a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I am particularly invested in ensuring the fundamental rights of all citizens, including people with disabilities. We must ensure true equality of access to justice for women.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Written. – More than 75 million Europeans are disabled and cannot fully exercise their rights in our society. This is absolutely unacceptable to me and I hope that in the long term the European Commission will take its responsibility to meet the many questions of this population in Europe. I voted in favour of this report because I do not find the discrimination seen by many of them acceptable.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a unique historical opportunity for the UN to examine whether the EU is properly implementing the UN Convention for the Protection of Persons with Disabilities. The European Parliament must not miss the opportunity to send a reply to the UN on its own behalf. This is what the resolution is about and gives concrete answers to the UN about what the European Parliament is doing for people with disabilities. In the resolution, we call on the 3 EU Member States – Finland, Ireland and the Netherlands – who have not yet ratified the Convention to do so as soon as possible, and those who have already ratified it, including the EU itself, to speed up the implementation of the Convention. We urge the European Commission to formally involve Parliament in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to draft the long-awaited European accessibility legislation. And for the EU Framework, of which the EP is a member, which monitors the implementation of the Convention, we need resources to be able to operate effectively. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion because it will facilitate the effective implementation of the UN Convention.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is an important legislative document adopted by the UN Assembly on 13 December 2006 which sets out in detail what needs to be done by states so that disabled people can also be actively part of civil society without suffering any kind of discrimination.  The European Union signed the UN Convention on 30 March 2007. Despite the enormous results achieved in recent years, much remains to be done to give disabled people the opportunity to exercise their rights on an equal footing with other citizens. Removing all the obstacles that people with walking disabilities encounter in everyday life remains one of the European Union's priorities.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted a resolution expressing its support for the full implementation of the International Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (ICDPH). The Union must ensure that people with disabilities can fully exercise their rights on an equal footing with other citizens. All European legislative instruments, policies and programmes must respect the provisions of the Convention enshrining the rights of persons with disabilities, within the limits of the principle of subsidiarity and the own competences of the Member States and parties to the Convention.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – It is a unique historical opportunity for the UN to examine whether the EU is properly implementing the UN Convention for the Protection of Persons with Disabilities. The European Parliament must not miss the opportunity to send a reply to the UN on its own behalf. This is what the resolution is about and gives concrete answers to the UN about what the European Parliament is doing for people with disabilities. In the resolution, we call on the 3 EU Member States – Finland, Ireland and the Netherlands – which have not yet ratified the Convention to do so as soon as possible, and those that have already ratified it, including the EU itself, to speed up the implementation of the Convention. We urge the European Commission to formally involve Parliament in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to draft the long-awaited European accessibility legislation. And for the EU framework monitoring the implementation of the Convention, of which the EP is a member, resources are needed to make it work effectively. It is important that, following the final UN report, the European Parliament's EMPL, LIBE and PETI committees will also prepare a joint report on the subject, expected later this autumn. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion because it will facilitate the effective implementation of the UN Convention.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ Mr President, it is imperative that the European Union continue to fulfil the obligations of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which it ratified in 2011, and which seeks the full integration and enhancement of people living with physical and mental impairments into education, employment and society as a whole.  Today’s motion comes in response to a list of questions posed by the UN Committee in April of this year aimed at driving forward change in many areas where problems and obstacles exist. It is positive, I feel, that Parliament has recognised the need to improve independent travel opportunities for those living with disabilities, as well as to safeguard effective access to justice, services, the labour market and improved communication with advocacy groups in this sector.  As an MEP for Northern Ireland, I work closely with many local charities, including Something Special in Eglinton, who provide an outlet in terms of skills training and employment for those living with learning difficulties. These organisations deserve continued EU financial and networking support in order to maximise their transformative work with this section of our community.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ An estimated 80 million people in the European Union have a disability. The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is an international human rights treaty of the United Nations intended to protect the rights and dignity of persons with disabilities. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) entered into force on 21 of January 2011. This has been signed by all 28 EU Member States and ratified by 25 of them. Issues examined in the review include equal rights to vote and stand for elections, criteria for reasonableness and proportionality for accommodation measures, full EU website accessibility, and a proposal for a European Accessibility Act. On the basis of the Commission’s reply, the UNCRPD Committee will form its concluding observations by 4 September 2015.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem of people with settlements in the European Union is not to be underestimated.  Bulgaria stands in one of the last places in the union in the quality of services offered to people with such a functional deficit. According to data from the last census in 2011. they're half a million. Eurostat shows that twice as many bulgarians with disabilities have given up early learning compared to the EU average. Not to mention the social exclusion and poverty they have to contend with.  The 2011 Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is a positive step and its implementation must be monitored.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour because, indeed, people with disabilities are a particularly vulnerable social group, the standard of living of which today is far from desirable. We note, however, that this text, despite good intentions, does not go beyond the usual ideological approach and we almost certainly believe that it will offer little to achieve the expected objective.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution on the application of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I am pleased that the plenary of the European Parliament voted overwhelmingly in favour of the report by my fellow Member Adam Kósa. It is of the utmost importance that the EU is able to provide a full and credible report to its UN Expert Committee on how it transposes the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities into everyday life. We must send a strong call to Member States that have not yet transposed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities into their internal law. We also urge the Commission to formally involve Parliament and the members of the EU framework in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to draft the long-awaited European accessibility legislation.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It highlights the aim of an EU anti-discrimination directive to protect those with disabilities against discrimination in social protection, health care and (re)habilitation, education, as well as access to and supply of goods and services. It also criticises the lack of progress within the European Council, and urges Member States to work towards a common position without further delay. I am glad that in Wales we have a Commissioner who can take up such cases and promote positive action.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 I could only vote in favour of this motion for a resolution to consider the list of issues raised by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as a follow-up to the EU's initial report; Among other issues, the UN asks the EU what measures have been taken to raise awareness among citizens and to train them about the provisions of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD), as well as to ask the EU to explain what measures have been taken to ensure that people with disabilities have the right to full portability of their welfare rights in the event of movement within the Union.  However, this resolution lacks a reference to the right of people with disabilities to receive care in their family environment rather than in special facilities, and consequently the reference to policies in the Member States that recognise the figure of family caregiver as a guarantee of this right. It must be remembered that in too many European countries, including Italy, millions of people are giving up a dignified life in order to devote themselves full-time to caring for their disabled family members, even though they are not protected in any way by their own state.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. An estimated 80 million people in the EU are disabled and, as full citizens, enjoy the same rights and are entitled to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, autonomy and full participation in society. However, information provided by the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights consistently attests that people with disabilities face discrimination and barriers to exercising their rights on equal terms with others and their integration into the labour market represents one of the biggest challenges facing social and labour market policies. The employment rate of people aged 20-64 is over 70%, while the employment rate for people with disabilities is below 50% and the employment rate among women without disabilities is 65%, compared to 44% among women with disabilities. I therefore believe that access to employment and non-discrimination in the workplace are fundamental elements for an autonomous and independent life. It is essential for me that there should be an ambitious proposal for an EU legislative act on accessibility, with the full involvement of people with disabilities throughout the legislative cycle, promoting independence and the full inclusion of people with disabilities and establishing a mechanism for continuous, effective and independent monitoring and implementation.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. The resolution adopted today on the revision of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities reiterates the obligations of the EU and its Member States for the effective implementation of the principle of accessibility and non-discrimination of persons with disabilities in a cross-cutting manner and not only with regard to access to employment , to achieve true autonomy and independence.  In this regard, the Spanish Socialists are very pleased to have obtained the support of the House (566 votes in favour, 84 against and 26 abstentions) to our proposals for a request to the Council to unlock the Anti-Discrimination Directive, which has been blocked since 2008.  We also welcome the fact that we have obtained the support of the House to request Member States to remove restrictions on the exercise of the right of active and passive suffrage of persons with disabilities currently in force in 21 of the 28 Member States, for a restrictive interpretation of their legal capacity and in contravention of Article 12 of the CDPD on equality before the law.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. We have supported this resolution, although we cannot fail to point out some key aspects of this issue. It should be found that transparency of accountability, also derived from the obligations of signing the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, applies to the very functioning of the EU institutions and that this information needs to be accessible to all. To be consistent with this Convention would, for example, not encourage and support cuts in public education systems affecting people with disabilities. In Portugal, in the context of the troika and post-troika policy that are one and the same, the number of special education teachers has been brutally reduced and in many schools there is not even a teacher, a situation that has worsened in recent years. There are students who for lack of support in school are advised to stay at home, finding their parents completely desperate and without solutions. They are children and young people who have been removed from the right to education. Does this have anything to do with the Convention that is so defended here?

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union fully supports and promotes the active inclusion and full participation of persons with disabilities in society. It should not be forgotten that disability is a question of rights and not a matter of discretion. In 2010, the European Commission adopted a European Disability Strategy 2010-2020. The main objectives of this strategy include, inter alia, accessibility, participation, equality, employment, education and training, social protection, health and also external relations.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution encouraging greater efforts in the area of the rights of persons with disabilities.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on a United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, because indeed people with disabilities are a particularly vulnerable social group, the standard of living of which today is far from desirable. I note, however, that this text, despite good intentions, does not go beyond the usual ideological approach and I almost certainly think it will do little to achieve the expected objective.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the fact that the EU is based on the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, persons with disabilities must benefit from measures designed to ensure their independence, social and occupational integration and participation in the life of the community.  I truly hope that this resolution will lead to the adoption of the most appropriate and encompassing mechanism to ensure optimal application of the UN Convention on the Right of Persons with Disabilities. Empowering people with disabilities would allow them to fully enjoy their rights and participate in society and in the economy on an equal basis with others.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a unique historical opportunity for the UN to examine whether the EU is properly implementing the UN Convention for the Protection of Persons with Disabilities. The European Parliament must not miss the opportunity to send a reply to the UN on its own behalf. This is what the resolution is about and gives concrete answers to the UN about what the European Parliament is doing for people with disabilities. In the resolution, we call on the three EU Member States – Finland, Ireland and the Netherlands – who have not yet ratified the Convention to do so as soon as possible, and those who have already ratified it, including the EU itself, to speed up the implementation of the Convention. We urge the European Commission to formally involve Parliament in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to draft the long-awaited European accessibility legislation. And for the EU framework monitoring the implementation of the Convention, of which the EP is a member, resources are needed to make it work effectively. It is important that, following the final UN report, the European Parliament's EMPL, LIBE and PETI committees will also prepare a joint report on the subject, expected later this autumn. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion because it will facilitate the effective implementation of the UN Convention.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a unique historical opportunity for the UN to examine whether the EU is properly implementing the UN Convention for the Protection of Persons with Disabilities. The European Parliament must not miss the opportunity to send a reply to the UN on its own behalf. This is what the resolution is about and gives concrete answers to the UN about what the European Parliament is doing for people with disabilities. In the resolution, we call on the 3 EU Member States – Finland, Ireland and the Netherlands – who have not yet ratified the Convention to do so as soon as possible, and those who have already ratified it, including the EU itself, to speed up the implementation of the Convention. We urge the European Commission to formally involve Parliament in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to draft the long-awaited European accessibility legislation. And for the EU Framework, of which the EP is a member, which monitors the implementation of the Convention, we need resources to be able to operate effectively. It is important that, following the final UN report, the European Parliament's EMPL, LIBE and PETI committees will also prepare a joint report on the subject, expected later this autumn. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion because it will facilitate the effective implementation of the UN Convention.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities because all EU citizens must enjoy the same rights. From institutions we must work to ensure equal treatment, the right to independent living and full participation in the society of persons with disabilities. Especially important for the full integration of this collective is access to the labour market to allow people with disabilities to have an independent life, as well as to achieve a good educational basis from primary education.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the revision of the implementation of the UN Convention for the Rights of Persons with Disabilities because it reiterates the obligations of the EU and its Member States for the effective implementation of the principle of accessibility and non-discrimination of disabled persons in a cross-cutting manner and not only with regard to access to employment , to achieve true autonomy and independence.  The resolution calls on the Council to adopt without delay a position on the Anti-Discrimination Directive, which has been blocked since its adoption by Parliament at first reading in April 2009, a claim of paramount importance to the Socialists. In addition, the Socialists have secured the support of the House to call on Member States to remove restrictions on the exercise of the right of active and passive suffrage of persons with disabilities, currently in force in 21 of the 28 Member States, due to a restrictive interpretation of their legal capacity and in contravention of Article 12 of the CDPD on equality before the law.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 In the vote in question, we called on the Commission to involve the European Parliament more fully in this matter and called for the full implementation of the UNITED Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, calling on the three Member States that have not yet ratified it to ratify it as soon as possible. It is essential that on such an important issue we do not get lost in unnecessary bureaucratic discussions and take concrete action. Today's large majority vote demonstrates this Parliament's determination to remove the remaining odious obstacles that restrict the rights of people with disabilities.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I wholeheartedly supported the resolution on the rights of people with disabilities. For too long, the European Commission has been promising to present a proposal for European legislation on accessibility. There is an urgent need for a political act that guarantees the full participation of disabled people in the entire legislative cycle: this proposal must include a wide range of areas of action, in order to promote independent living and the full inclusion of people with disabilities and to establish a permanent and effective mechanism. In this context, I would like to stress the need to promote accessibility, including electronic accessibility for people with disabilities, which is an aspect that is little considered but which is becoming increasingly urgent.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the list of issues adopted by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in relation to the EU's initial report.  People with disabilities are one of the most vulnerable groups in our society and often face obstacles that prevent full equality of rights with other citizens.  Despite member states' policies and European strategies to ensure better access to the labour market, people with disabilities are still subject to strong discrimination. I therefore agree with the need to push the Member States to improve the effectiveness of these policies and to allow the full participation of disabled people in work and social activities in Europe.  I strongly believe in the importance of an ambitious proposal by the Commission on the accessibility of disabled people to goods and services for all EU citizens, so as to promote independence and full inclusion in society.  Finally, I would like to see stronger political cooperation between the Member States and the EU, and I welcome the European Parliament's initiative to draw up a regular joint report in the EMPL, LIBE and PETI Committees to monitor progress in this area.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. – There are eighty million people with disabilities in the European Union, and they are too often faced with discrimination and barriers in the exercise of their rights and in access to culture, education and employment. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities entered into force in January 2011 in the European Union, but three Member States (Sweden, the Netherlands and Ireland) have not yet ratified it. Parliament today calls for respect and implementation of this Convention so that persons with disabilities can enjoy their rights like any other European citizen. I support this text, because much remains to be done in order for real equality to exist.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, which states that the European Parliament must participate fully in the monitoring and implementation of human rights and all actions to correct inequality in their access. We find the adoption of two key pieces of legislation fundamental: the European Accessibility Act and the General Anti-Discrimination Directive, both being an essential part of the implementation of the UN Convention. The resolution also calls on Member States to reflect the obligations under article 12 of the UN Convention on National Laws and more specifically, as well as the right of all persons with disabilities to vote and be elected.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my S&D colleagues, voted in favour of this resolution because it calls on the Commission to present an ambitious proposal for a European Accessibility Act, with the full involvement of persons with disabilities throughout the legislative cycle.  It also stresses the need for this proposal to include a full range of policy areas with regard to the accessibility of goods and services for all EU citizens, fostering the independent living and full inclusion of people with disabilities and establishing an ongoing, effective and independent monitoring and enforcement mechanism.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. The resolution adopted today on the revision of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities reiterates the obligations of the EU and its Member States for the effective implementation of the principle of accessibility and non-discrimination of persons with disabilities in a cross-cutting manner and not only with regard to access to employment , to achieve true autonomy and independence.  In this regard, the Spanish Socialists are very pleased to have obtained the support of the House (566 votes in favour, 84 against and 26 abstentions) to our proposals for a request to the Council to unlock the Anti-Discrimination Directive, which has been blocked since 2008.  We also welcome the fact that we have obtained the support of the House to request Member States to remove restrictions on the exercise of the right of active and passive suffrage of persons with disabilities currently in force in 21 of the 28 Member States, for a restrictive interpretation of their legal capacity and in contravention of Article 12 of the CDPD on equality before the law.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. 80 million Europeans are now disabled. All too often, in their daily lives, these citizens cannot enjoy the same rights, equal treatment, autonomy and full participation in social life as able-bodied people. In the face of this situation, I voted in favour of a resolution addressed in particular to the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the Commission and the Council, in order to mark a new step in the progress to be made towards a real equality of rights for all. This includes: the Commission's proposal for an ambitious text on accessibility and full participation of people with disabilities throughout the legislative process; the rapid adoption of the Directive on the accessibility of the websites of public sector organizations; Increased deployment of means to increase access to employment for these people; Easier access to justice States' use of EU funds to strengthen services for people with disabilities; or the unblocking of the Anti-Discrimination Directive. In the wake of the United Nations, Europe must rise to these challenges.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the list of issues adopted by the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities concerning the original report of the European Union, because I share the position that, as fully-fledged citizens, persons with disabilities have equal rights and the right to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living and full participation in society. We therefore call on all EU institutions to work closely together to improve the conditions for the integration of persons with disabilities in the EU, including the call for the Commission to submit an ambitious proposal for a European Accessibility Act, with the full involvement of persons with disabilities throughout the legislative cycle, and to actively consult the European Parliament.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. The resolution adopted today on the revision of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities reiterates the obligations of the EU and its Member States for the effective implementation of the principle of accessibility and non-discrimination of persons with disabilities in a cross-cutting manner and not only with regard to access to employment , to achieve true autonomy and independence.  In this regard, the Spanish Socialists are very pleased to have obtained the support of the House (566 votes in favour, 84 against and 26 abstentions) to our proposals for a request to the Council to unlock the Anti-Discrimination Directive, which has been blocked since 2008.  We also welcome the fact that we have obtained the support of the House to request Member States to remove restrictions on the exercise of the right of active and passive suffrage of persons with disabilities currently in force in 21 of the 28 Member States, for a restrictive interpretation of their legal capacity and in contravention of Article 12 of the CDPD on equality before the law.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I shadowed this Resolution on behalf of my Group and was very pleased to support it. As the EU has ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD), its Institutions as well as the Member States have significant responsibilities to ensure that the rights of persons with disabilities are fully vindicated. This means that both the Commission and Member States must take a human-rights-based approach to disability at all levels of EU and national policymaking.  Unfortunately my own Member State, Ireland is one of the three countries in the EU which has signed but not yet ratified the Convention and I continue to urge the Irish Government to do so as soon as possible in the interest of our disabled citizens and their families. I was particularly pleased that the ALDE amendment calling on Member States to adopt the EU Anti-Discrimination Directive without further delay was carried. This would be a major step forward as the Directive seeks to protect persons with disabilities from discrimination in the areas of social protection, healthcare, education and the supply of goods and services such as housing, transport and insurance.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I think Parliament has a role in calling for improved rights for persons with disabilities all across the EU. We should recognise that full inclusion and equal participation of persons with disabilities can only be achieved by taking a human-rights-based approach to disability.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Written. "Based on the circumstances of each Member State, it is important for us Moderates to underline that it is the individual countries that can best combat the discrimination that exists among citizens of different countries and can best ensure that the rights of all citizens are respected.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a unique historical opportunity for the UN to examine whether the EU is properly implementing the UN Convention for the Protection of Persons with Disabilities. The European Parliament must not miss the opportunity to send a reply to the UN on its own behalf. The resolution gives concrete answers to the UN on what the European Parliament is doing for people with disabilities. In the resolution, we call on the three EU Member States – Finland, Ireland and the Netherlands – who have not yet ratified the Convention to do so as soon as possible. Those who have already ratified it, including the EU itself, should speed up the implementation of the Convention. We urge the European Commission to formally involve Parliament in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to draft the long-awaited European accessibility legislation. And for the "EU Framework" to monitor the implementation of the Convention, of which the EP is a member, resources are needed to make it work effectively. It is important that, following the final UN report, the European Parliament's EMPL, LIBE and PETI committees will also prepare a joint report on the subject, expected later this autumn. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion because it will facilitate the effective implementation of the UN Convention.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ The European Unionʼs signing and ratification of the UN Convention was a landmark step, but this resolution allows me to express regret that Parliament and disabled peopleʼs organisations were not consulted about the implementation report submitted by the Commission, and to call for them to be included now both in the preparation of answers to the List of Issues and in the European Union delegation to take part in the Constructive Dialogue in Geneva when they are debated. The Commission says that it supports the ʽNothing about us, without usʼ call, and I hope it will respect it, in this most important opportunity for the lives of disabled people.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament has today issued a strong call for progress to be made on an anti-discrimination directive and it is imperative that the Member States take full note of that call. Unfortunately many aspects of disability discrimination remain outwith the control of the Scottish Parliament and we now have a majority Tory government at Westminster who are unlikely to prioritise many of the most vulnerable people in society. The SNP in the Scottish, UK and European Parliaments will ensure that the needs of persons with disabilities are at all times fully recognised.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, which states that the European Parliament must participate fully in the monitoring and implementation of human rights and all actions to correct inequality in their access. We find the adoption of two key pieces of legislation fundamental: the European Accessibility Act and the General Anti-Discrimination Directive, both being an essential part of the implementation of the UN Convention. The resolution also calls on Member States to reflect the obligations under article 12 of the UN Convention on National Laws and more specifically, as well as the right of all persons with disabilities to vote and be elected.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted for a draft motion for a resolution on a list of issues adopted by the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in relation to the initial Report of the European Union, as it highlights the need for better political cooperation within the Union in order to improve the conditions for the dignified life of people with disabilities. There are around 80 million people with disabilities in the EU and some Member States have not yet ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. These people often encounter discrimination in employment, non-compliance with their rights in the workplace, in education and in many other areas of life important for their self-determination and independent living. Developing and implementing certain measures in the EU would improve rights and increase the social inclusion of such persons in society.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The UN Committee on the Disabled has drawn up a list of questions on this subject, which it will forward to the Commission for response. In this resolution, the European Parliament makes itself available to the Committee of the Disabled of the United Nations to answer these questions as well. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. These are only minimum standards and the Union must go beyond these standards in order to better protect people with disabilities and to combat discrimination.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The rights of people with disabilities are particularly close to my heart. The resolution aims at a barrier-free Europe that allows all people to participate in economic and social life. National efforts to achieve this objective will be supported. I am therefore voting in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. I am glad that EPP, my political group, initiated the resolution in question. It addresses shortcomings in providing support to people with disabilities.  One of the priorities is to better ensure that people with a disability will receive adequate state support without unnecessary bureaucratic obstacles. I am concerned about the current state of affairs, especially as there is no proper data on the situation across Europe. I call on the Commission to address the issue of data gathering and sharing. First, we have to map the needs and challenges, and then adequate answers can be provided both on European and national level. The underlying principle should be enabling every person with disability to lead as independent a life as possible. This means encouraging society as a whole to accept these people as equals, companies to adapt to the special situation of disabled persons and to integrate them better into the job market. Every human being deserves to live a dignified and independent life.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ The EU promotes the active inclusion and full participation of disabled people in society, in line with the EU human rights approach to disability issues. Disability is a rights issue and not a matter of discretion. This approach is also at the core of the UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities (UNCRPD), to which the EU is a signatory. I supported the resolution, as it is consensual and calls on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative proposal on the matter.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities entered into force on 21 January 2011. However, following the Commission staff working document, a full list of questions has emerged which has been adopted by the relevant UN committee and is now to be answered by the Commission. Given that Parliament is the only directly elected body of the European Union representing European citizens, it is somewhat sad that it has limited powers to monitor the UN Convention. The European Parliament therefore has nothing left but to assure the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities that the European Parliament will answer the questions addressed directly to it, while urging the Commission to take into account Parliament's positions when formulating its answers. I would consider it sensible for the European institutions to try to work in concert and thus not harm those who are already in an already difficult position. Despite existing programmes, initiatives and strategies at EU level, employment of persons with disabilities is less than 50% and employment of women with disabilities is at 44%. I believe that it is within our power to help people with disabilities if we work in concert. The goal is to help, not bicker. I therefore voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, which is written in a similar vein.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a unique historical opportunity for the UN to examine whether the EU is properly implementing the UN Convention for the Protection of Persons with Disabilities. The European Parliament must not miss the opportunity to send a reply to the UN on its own behalf. This is what the resolution is about, which gives concrete answers to the UN about what the European Parliament is doing for people with disabilities. In the resolution, we call on the three EU Member States – Finland, Ireland and the Netherlands – who have not yet ratified the Convention to do so as soon as possible, and those who have already ratified it, including the EU itself, to speed up the implementation of the Convention. We urge the European Commission to formally involve Parliament in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to draft the long-awaited European accessibility legislation. And for the EU framework monitoring the implementation of the Convention, of which the EP is a member, resources are needed to make it work effectively. It is important that, following the final UN report, the European Parliament's EMPL, LIBE and PETI committees will also prepare a joint report on the subject, expected later this autumn. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion because it will facilitate the effective implementation of the UN Convention.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, experience has shown that there are few results of resolutions of a similar nature that would be timely to change. A more effective approach, a renewed, more human-centred approach to the material is to be welcomed. I supported the recommendation, and I trust that, through a more efficient use of resources, there is a chance for better rights for people with disabilities. In fact, there is still plenty of work to be done in the EU.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. It is estimated that around 80 million people in the European Union have a form of disability and the information provided by the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights systematically demonstrates that people with disabilities face discrimination and obstacles to exercising their rights on an equal footing with others. I have chosen to vote in favour because I am convinced that we need enhanced political cooperation within the EU framework on this issue in order to adopt concrete proposals.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. National Front MEPs abstained on the resolution on the list of issues adopted by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities with regard to the initial report of the European Union. Of course, as recital A of the text points out, persons with disabilities, as full citizens, enjoy the same rights and can claim inalienable dignity, equal treatment, autonomy and full participation in social life.  However, it is up to the Member States to ensure that this principle is respected and put into practice. In particular, the text calls on "the Commission to formally consult all the institutions and agencies concerned with the list of issues, namely the European Parliament, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions, the European Ombudsman and the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights". The involvement of all this machinery in the European Union runs counter to the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Convention, signed by the 28 Member States, was ratified by the majority, as well as by the European Union in 2011. The United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities will review the implementation of the Convention in September this year, hence the interest in having a position by Parliament prior to this review. On the text of the Resolution: introduces classic collective requests such as asking the Commission to submit a proposal for a European Accessibility Law that includes accessibility to goods and services; requests the Council to speed up its work on the proposal for a directive on accessibility of public institutions' websites; calls for the use of European funds to promote accessibility and accessibility and lists the EP's actions to put the list of tasks of the Convention into operation. Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am aware of the problem addressed in the resolution, but I consider it more as empty talk of disability unemployment, a call for the collection of new statistics instead of real solutions that could help these people to feed themselves, e.g. to remove regulations for domestic production.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Disabled people in Latvia have already been abandoned and neglected. This resolution will strengthen the rights of people with disabilities, because the un-convention in the said country protects them very well. I voted in favour. It is now necessary to resort to a major EU anti-discrimination directive.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has become a Party to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities by ratification. It was signed by all 28 Member States and ratified by 25 states. The EU has thus made a commitment to build a Europe without barriers for 80 million people with different forms of disability by 2020. Although the Convention entered into force in 2011, its content is not being fulfilled as expected and persons with disabilities continue to be confronted with various forms of discrimination compared to others. It is therefore necessary, in cooperation with organisations bringing together disabled persons, to carry out analyses that will realistically evaluate the reality of the management of the rights of disabled citizens. I support the swift development and presentation of measures that will lead to the effective removal of barriers and the immediate fulfilment of the Convention's obligations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the list of issues adopted by the United Nations Commission on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in connection with the European Union's initial report because it is complete and adequate but also for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament of 19/05/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Resolution which rightly states that paid employment is essential to enable persons with disabilities to lead an independent life, and that the Member States should therefore strive for wider access to employment for people with disabilities so that they can contribute to the society they live in, and should, as a precondition, provide inclusive education for all children with disabilities, including those with learning difficulties, in order to help them acquire a good educational grounding from primary school on so that they can follow a curriculum appropriate to their learning abilities, thereby giving them the opportunity to gain a solid educational background that can help them develop a career or secure a good job which enables them to live an independent life later on.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of understanding that the EU still has a long way to go with regard to the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, not only in the field of combating discrimination but also with regard to the removal of barriers and increased accessibility and electronic accessibility, the development of high-quality health cities and the strengthening of the capacities and role of organisations of persons with disabilities.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My support for the european Parliament's request for greater cooperation from now on to defend the rights of persons with disabilities and to enable the UN Convention protecting this group to be clearly implemented in the EU. The European Parliament needs to be taken into account throughout this process, as we are actively working from here to be able to implement all the policies necessary to develop the rights and equal opportunities of these people with disabilities.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I could not support the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The concessions that the Union would have to make to people with disabilities would not lead to an improvement in the situation, but to positive discrimination. This, in turn, would make the situation of these people even worse in the long run. That is why I abstained.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In this report, a dialogue is taking place between the European Union and the United Nations on the issue of people with disabilities. The report is an answer to questions from the United Nations Committee on Disability following a previous parliamentary report on the subject.  This non-legislative text remains at the stage of good intentions and avoids certain issues such as access to employment and housing. In addition, he continues to talk about people with disabilities, even though they are people with disabilities.  Nevertheless, it calls on Member States that have not yet done so to ratify the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities as soon as possible. The convention, adopted in 2006, aims to "promote, protect and ensure" the dignity, equality before the law, human rights and fundamental freedoms of people with disabilities of all kinds. I vote for this text without any illusions as to its effects.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. Persons with disabilities, as full citizens, enjoy the same rights and are entitled to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, autonomy and full participation in society. There are 80 million people in the European Union who are disabled. Integration policies are needed to enable us to improve the quality of life of these fully fledged European citizens. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this joint resolution as I fully support the recommendation for EU funds to be used to promote accessibility and e-accessibility for persons with disabilities. I also support the importance the resolution gives to the need for the Commission to present an ambitious proposal for a European Accessibility Act. It is crucial that persons with disabilities are involved throughout the legislative cycle of any such act.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. As a strong defender of fundamental rights, I consider it essential to ensure that the 80 million fellow citizens of Europe with disabilities have full enjoyment of their rights. In fact, people with disabilities still too often suffer discrimination every day, which must be tackled with the utmost determination. Full answers must be provided to questions posed by the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. More broadly, I think it makes sense for the Commission to present as soon as possible an ambitious legislative act aimed at significantly improving the autonomy and integration of people with disabilities into our societies.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ It is estimated 80 million people in the European Union have a disability and yet persons with disabilities still face discrimination and barriers to exercising their rights on an equal basis with others.I fully support the rights of people with disabilities, who as full citizens, have equal rights and are entitled to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living and full participation in society. Therefore, I have co-signed and voted in favour of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Persons with disabilities, as full citizens, enjoy the same rights and are entitled to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, autonomy and full participation in society. An estimated 80 million people in the European Union are disabled and the information provided by the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights consistently attests that people with disabilities face discrimination and barriers to exercising their rights on an equal basis with others. According to the Fundamental Rights Agency, 21 of the 28 Member States still impose restrictions on the full exercise of legal capacity. The EU Anti-Discrimination Directive was proposed by the European Commission in 2008, but remains blocked in the Council and every year the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions receives petitions relating to cases of discrimination on grounds of disability in access to employment, independent work, public services and education. For these reasons, I vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution on the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities proposes to use statistics to monitor the situation of people with disabilities in the Member States, but also to ratify the Treaty of Marrakech or to make websites more accessible. Indeed, the 80 million people with disabilities living in the Union face many obstacles, notably in access to work or communications, despite the various national legislations going in the right direction. If I share the measures proposed by this motion for a resolution, I believe that it is up to the Member States to assess and ratify this UN convention, not the EU to propose its signature to the States. I therefore decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote is, of course, in favour of the joint resolution on the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It is estimated that 80 million people have disabilities in the European Union: people who are full citizens, who must be guaranteed the inalienable right to dignity and full participation in cultural, social and political life.  However, even today, also because of gaps in services, these people are victims of discrimination and barriers, which make it difficult for them to live an independent and self-determined life.  With this vote in favour, I would like to see a strengthening of that spirit of political cooperation aimed at promoting accessibility and e-accessibility for people with disabilities, developing quality social and health services (making full use of European funding) and strengthening cooperation through and with organisations for people with disabilities.  In addition, as a useful tool for monitoring and implementing appropriate policies, the collection and subsequent dissemination of statistical data on disability, from the employment sector to those specific to daily life, is relevant.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities has adopted a list of questions relating to the initial European Union report, to which the Commission must formally respond. The European Parliament, as a democratically elected institution representative of European citizens, could not miss this opportunity to answer questions from the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Today, in Europe, about 80 million people are disabled and more than half of them are out of work. EU legislation is not yet fully implemented and implementing it would improve the daily life and accessibility of the professional world for people with disabilities! Better cooperation between the European institutions is also needed to combat discrimination against people with disabilities.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the resolution on the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities because it is fully in line with the direction taken by the European Union, which has been fighting for years for the active inclusion and full participation of disabled people in public life. The approach outlined in the 2010 European Disability Strategy 2010-2020 is in line with the guidelines of the UN Convention, which identifies eight priority areas for action to combat inequalities caused by disability.  The areas identified – accessibility, participation, equality, work, education and teaching, social protection, health and external action – all require decisive action and strong monitoring.  Nevertheless, the Commission and the Council need to involve Parliament in the necessary adaptation of the EU regulatory framework. We are convinced that this resolution is significant in calling on the European Commission to present an ambitious legislative proposal as soon as possible that addresses the issue of disability as a whole, and that sees the active involvement of all the institutional actors concerned.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Joint Motion for a Resolution, tabled by all parliamentary groups. The purpose of this resolution was to call, as MEPs, for the European Parliament to have a formal role in the process of monitoring and commenting on the progress of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights for People with Disabilities (UNCRPD). While the European Parliament is part of the EU Framework to promote, protect and monitor the UNCRPD across the EU, the Commission appears to be excluding Parliament from formally and meaningfully participating in the Review process being carried out by the UNCRPD Committee. The most significant proposals in the Resolution are the statement that Parliament will respond directly to the CRPD Committee in relation to all questions in the list of issues that it has competence over. The Resolution lists these. It also calls on the Commission to take Parliament’s views into account when it sends its own response to the CRPD Committee.  More than 13% of the population across Ireland are living with a disability. I voted in favour of this report because it’s crucial for political representatives,  as well as broader civil society and especially disability rights organisations, to be properly included in the Review process.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report on the rights of people with disabilities in my vote today. People with disabilities have very serious problems in finding jobs and respecting equal rights, and unfortunately they are a very vulnerable group in our societies. There is a need for very close cooperation and cooperation between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission at EU level. However, it is regrettable that in this case the importance of the European Parliament has not been respected, thus depriving the debate of citizens' input. I believe that this report highlights many of the problems faced by people with disabilities, without trying to make an exhaustive list of them. In this respect, I have supported and support this position which seeks to bring the direct participation of citizens in the decisions taken on this issue back into the debate.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. \u2012 The 80 million Europeans with disabilities are equal citizens of the Union, yet, on the basis of the available data, they do not enjoy equal rights and opportunities in the majority of Member States. In my view, it is crucial that there is a broad dialogue between NGOs, EU institutions and Member States on the necessary measures, including the development of a strong accessibility package and improving educational and employment opportunities.  I find it extremely regrettable that a directive banning discrimination against people with disabilities has still not been reached, guaranteeing equal access to social protection, health care, education, housing and services. Accepting this should be one of the most important tasks of the European institutional system in the period ahead.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because the position of people with disabilities in the EU, as well as in many Member States, still needs to be improved and the UN Convention provides good approaches here.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution. I consider it important to ensure equal opportunities and rights for people with disabilities to participate in society, which requires all parties to contribute to this. The relevant legislation needs to be better implemented and interinstitutional dialogue intensified, but the involvement of third parties must also be increased.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. This year, the United Nations Commission on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities will review for the first time how the EU has complied with its obligations. We have asked the Commission to improve the collection of data and statistics, since without them it is impossible to assess, but also not to ensure adequate policies.
