In addition, we call on the Commission to present an ambitious proposal for a European Accessibility Law, which has the full participation of persons with disabilities throughout the legislative cycle, because otherwise it will be a huge mess.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because I firmly believe that much progress still needs to be made to ensure the full and effective social inclusion of people with disabilities. Equal opportunities and social inclusion for all are key principles to which each State is obliged to comply through the removal of causes that restrict, or even prevent, full access to the different areas of people's lives. The state must ensure adequate education for people with greater learning difficulties so as to pave the way for them to work and, consequently, to allow a dignified life. Counselling and support activities also for the families of people with disabilities are a key principle of the proper functioning of the State.  Statistics tell us that more than 80 million Europeans have disabilities. The protection of the most vulnerable sections of society has always been a primary objective; ratifying the CRPD Convention and giving answers equal to the recommendations of the CRPD Committee is a key step in the positive development of basic services that a State absolutely must guarantee.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012Considering that, like all citizens, people with disabilities have the right to live an independent life and full participation in social life; that the European Agency for Fundamental Rights has fully demonstrated that people with disabilities are victims of discrimination on a daily basis and must fight against barriers that restrict the free exercise of their rights;  I voted in favour.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Job availability coupled with non-discrimination in the workplace is a fundamental element for self-determination and independent living. Despite existing PROGRAMMES, initiatives and strategies at EU level, the employment rate of people between 20 and 64 is more than 70%, while the employment rate for people with disabilities is below 50%. The employment rate for women without disabilities is 65% compared to that for women with disabilities, which is 44%.  Paid work is essential to enable people with disabilities to live independently and whereas Member States should therefore strive for greater accessibility of employment for people with disabilities so that they can contribute to the society in which they live, as a precondition for this they should provide inclusive education for all children with disabilities, including those with learning disabilities that can help them develop a career or guarantee a good job that later allows them to live independently.  As Parliament is the only directly elected Body of the European Union representing European citizens and therefore fully respects the Parisian principles, it is of utmost importance that it is involved in the process of ensuring all rights and the full inclusion and equality of persons with disabilities.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The EU strongly promotes the active participation and inclusion of people with disabilities in society. There are around 80 million people with disabilities living in Europe and this issue is of uncrpd's highly relevant issue. People with disabilities are not a homogeneous group, so despite the progress achieved, further initiatives should be worked on to improve their rights, with a particular focus on the 8 priority areas of the European Disability Strategy.  The list of issues adopted by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in relation to the initial EU report stated that work needs to be done to improve conditions so that people with disabilities can travel independently by all means of transport. In this regard, I should note that in December 2014 I asked the Commission about the problems of people with disabilities when introducing a guide dog on board. What I would point out, as stated in the census, is the concern for unemployment of people with disabilities, which make up as much as 1/6 of the EU average working population, so of particular concern is the fact that their employment at EU level is below 50%.  In Croatia, where there are around half a million people with disabilities, but also in other Member States, the use of european social fund funds should be specifically focused with a view to their involvement in the labour market. Finally, I would like to point out that together with a number of colleagues, I am a member of the EP Intergroup on People with Disabilities.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I will not tire of repeating that people with disabilities are full citizens who must enjoy equal treatment and aspire to an independent life and participation in the life of the society in which they live. I regret to know, however, that even today, according to information provided by the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, people with disabilities face obstacles and difficulties in exercising their level playing field.  I welcome this resolution, which calls for action to be taken as a result of the list of issues in the UNITED Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It is important that there should be ever closer cooperation between the various institutions so that fundamental rights are accessible to all.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In the context of defending the rights of people with disabilities, and promoting their inalienable dignity, equal treatment, autonomy and participation in social life, the European Parliament voted in favour of the list of issues adopted by the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities with regard to the EU's initial report. I have spoken in favour of this text and I stress that Parliament should be more consulted on these issues. Parliament's point of view is indispensable on these issues and helps to ensure the defence of the Union's fundamental values and principles.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. At noon, Parliament called on the Commission to present an ambitious legislative proposal to promote the autonomy and full integration of people with disabilities. He also asked him to unblock his proposal for an "anti-discrimination" directive in 2008. Within the EU, 80 million people are disabled, or more than 15% of the population. One in four Europeans has a disabled person in their family. Six out of ten Europeans know a person with a disability in their immediate circle or in their relationships.  The European Union has formally ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which was signed by the 28 Member States and ratified by 25 of them. But we have to go further. People with disabilities are constantly discriminated against and face daily barriers. This limits their social life, particularly in terms of employment, transportation, education and training.  In its vote this afternoon, Parliament reaffirmed its commitment to end the obstacles faced by people with disabilities in the exercise of their rights in order to enable them to lead independent lives and participate in the society in which they live.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the list of issues adopted by the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities on the initial EU report. If the European Commission is responsible for answering questions, it must not forget to take parliament's comments into account; the only body directly elected by European citizens. People with disabilities enjoy the same rights and can claim inalienable dignity and equal treatment. We therefore urge Member States to take appropriate action by ratifying the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and by adopting, as soon as possible, a common position on the EU 'anti-discrimination' directive so that it can be implemented. It is essential that every institutional player mobilizes to support one of the most vulnerable groups in our society.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The difference cannot be seen as inequality, but as a great-great-great-all of human life. I believe that the current legislation of the European Union should be applied in order to respect the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and for fundamental rights to reach everyone.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The resolution adopted today on the revision of the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities reiterates the obligations of the EU and its Member States for the effective implementation of the principle of accessibility and non-discrimination of persons with disabilities in a cross-cutting manner and not only with regard to access to employment , to achieve true autonomy and independence.  In this regard, the Spanish Socialists are very pleased to have obtained the support of the House (566 votes in favour, 84 against and 26 abstentions) to our proposals for a request to the Council to unlock the Anti-Discrimination Directive, which has been blocked since 2008.  We also welcome the fact that we have obtained the support of the House to request Member States to remove restrictions on the exercise of the right of active and passive suffrage of persons with disabilities currently in force in 21 of the 28 Member States, for a restrictive interpretation of their legal capacity and in contravention of Article 12 of the CDPD on equality before the law.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I have, of course, voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on Member States that have not yet done so to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities as soon as possible. The text also calls on the Commission to present an ambitious proposal for the EU's legislation on accessibility and to involve people with disabilities fully throughout the legislative process. Finally, the resolution stresses that this proposal must include a wide range of policy areas on the accessibility of goods and services for all EU citizens, promote the autonomy and full integration of people with disabilities and establish a permanent, effective and independent mechanism for monitoring implementation. Let's keep it that way!

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the UNITED Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. In line with the position adopted by this Parliament, I find it unacceptable that the European Commission and the Council have not made Parliament – an institution representing European citizens and their interests – involved in the work on establishing the Code of Conduct. This code serves to ensure that the Member States that have ratified the Convention fully respect it. The lack of cooperation between the three European institutions meant that the EC was not aware of the problems that people with disabilities encounter every day in their lives, even within the institutions themselves. I agree with the text of the resolution, which proposes, on the one hand, greater investment in European funds to promote the accessibility of disabled people and, on the other hand, greater implementation of existing European legislation by the Member States.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this resolution, which states that the European Parliament must participate fully in the monitoring and implementation of human rights and all actions to correct inequality in their access. We find the adoption of two key pieces of legislation fundamental: the European Accessibility Act and the General Anti-Discrimination Directive, both being an essential part of the implementation of the UN Convention. The resolution also calls on Member States to reflect the obligations under article 12 of the UN Convention on National Laws and more specifically, as well as the right of all persons with disabilities to vote and be elected.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: Writing. \u2012 For the revision of the UNITED NATIONS Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD), the UN Committee shall draw up a report on the European Union, examining how the EU transposes the UN Convention into everyday life. The European Commission prepares the answers to the UN's questions in this area, but it is important that the European Parliament also emphasises the importance of this matter. The resolution urges the EU to take stronger action in the interests of people with disabilities. It also highlights the need to speed up the ratification of the CRPD Convention as an important objective. The resolution that has just been adopted also calls on the European Commission to take into account in its reply the position of the European Parliament and to involve it more strongly in the dialogue with the UN. Since I agree with the above objectives, I voted in favour of the adoption of this resolution.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution as I share its content whose main claim is the best objective of the living conditions of persons with disabilities, through equal access to services and the labour market. I regret that it is not mentioned that this can only be done through a policy that strengthens public services and establishes concrete anti-discrimination policies for persons with disabilities, and although it urges States to cooperate with each other in these areas, it does not set a concrete priority or set minimums to be met within the Union.  However, I understand that the political will of this resolution is positive, hence my vote in favour, but there is a lack of concrete resources and commitments in ending discrimination (double discrimination in the case of women with disabilities) suffered by these people.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ MEPs voted in favour of the report on the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, calling on the Commission to deliver the requested explanation as to how it can ensure in current and future legislation that persons with disabilities are guaranteed equal opportunities, fundamental rights, equal access to services and the employment market, and the same rights and obligations in accessing social security as nationals of the Member State in which they are covered, in line with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination, so that all persons with disabilities can enjoy the right to free movement held by all EU citizens.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained when voting on the resolution adopted by the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in relation to the initial report of the European Union. This resolution contains many important proposals, which I consider to be very beneficial. At the same time, however, it refers to the anti-discrimination directive not yet adopted, which, in its current form, carries the risk of jeopardising contractual freedom, as well as a dangerously vague and very broad interpretation, which could, as a result, lead to legal uncertainty and also to the restriction of civil rights and freedoms.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I strongly support the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Persons with disabilities must have equal rights, namely the right to dignity, equal treatment, independent living and full participation in society.  There are an estimated 80 million people with disabilities in the Union, and data from the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights constantly indicates that they face discrimination and barriers to exercising their rights. It is one of the most vulnerable groups in our society, and their involvement in the labour market poses one of the biggest challenges for social and labour market policy.  I therefore believe that full inclusion and equal participation of persons with disabilities can only be achieved through human rights-based access to disability at all levels of public policy.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – The principles of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities show the way for all persons with disabilities to enjoy human rights and aim to provide the necessary protection and assistance to families, which should contribute to making persons with disabilities fully and equally able to exercise their rights. Every year, the Committee on Petitions receives petitions highlighting discrimination on grounds of disability in access to employment, self-employment, public services and education. Therefore, EU funds should also be used to promote accessibility and e-accessibility for persons with disabilities, to support the transition from institutional care to community care, to develop quality social and health services and to invest in capacity building of organisations representing persons with disabilities. When developing future EU policies and legislation, it is necessary to ensure that persons with disabilities have the same rights and obligations in the labour market, in the use of services, in leisure activities and in their personal lives.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution in which the European Parliament expresses its strong support for the full implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. With this resolution, we are calling for two legislative measures of great importance to people with disabilities to be adopted as soon as possible, namely a European Accessibility Act and the cross-cutting directive to protect people at risk of discrimination. Furthermore, the resolution states that the European Parliament should be fully involved in the monitoring and implementation of the UN Convention as well as in the process of revising it, maintaining a constructive dialogue between the EU and the UN Committee responsible for analysing progress on the implementation of the Convention.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒There are around 80 million people with disabilities living in the European Union. As one of the most vulnerable groups in our society, they face many challenges and their involvement in the market poses one of the biggest challenges for social and labour market policy. It is important to take action to increase the employment of people with disabilities and to enable them to live a dignified and independent life without the discrimination and barriers to employment they currently face.  I support this draft proposal because it aims to improve conditions for people with disabilities and points to the need for a heterogeneous approach to the problem. I also express the need to monitor the situation of people with disabilities in everyday life, not just in the field of employment.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims to uphold the rights of persons with disabilities, tackle discrimination and promote equality, therefore I voted in favour.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ By voting, I supported the Commission's Declaration on the UN Convention on the Rights with Persons with Disabilities. More than 80 million people with disabilities face significant barriers to access to education, employment and goods and services in the EU, with greater social exclusion and poverty as a consequence. Valuable existing and potential contributions of persons with disabilities to the overall prosperity and diversity of their communities should be accepted, and the result of promoting the full enjoyment of human rights and fundamental freedoms by persons with disabilities and the full participation of persons with disabilities will be their greater sense of belonging and significant progress in the human, social and economic development of society and the eradication of poverty. The importance of personal autonomy and independence of persons with disabilities, including freedom of choice, should be highlighted and should be given the opportunity to be actively involved in policy and programme decision-making processes, including those directly related to them. Access to the physical, social, economic and cultural environment as well as education, information and communication is important, enabling full enjoyment of all human rights and fundamental freedoms for people with disabilities.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the rights of persons with disabilities. We have 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union, who should be guaranteed universal rights and enable full integration in society in the fields of education, employment, the labour market and quality leisure. Social inclusion is also one of the objectives of the European Union strategy. A lot has already been done, and we have more work to do. I also voted in favour of the resolution because I agree that the problems of people with disabilities must be addressed comprehensively and not in part.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We consider any effort to improve the living conditions of our fellow disabled people a positive step. The need to disappear any discrimination against these people is undeniable. The measures being promoted must be implemented in such a way that the people in need of support really benefit.  We must stress that there is still much that can and must be done. Unfortunately, the neoliberal measures of harsh austerity promoted by the EU restrict the welfare state and first of all affect vulnerable groups such as those with disabilities. Our position is that any measures must be accompanied by an integrated state social policy that really helps people with disabilities live a decent life.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 People with disabilities are indeed a particularly vulnerable social group, the standard of living of which today is far from desirable. We note, however, that this text, despite good intentions, does not go beyond the usual ideological approach and we almost certainly believe that it will offer little to achieve the expected objective.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a unique historical opportunity for the UN to examine whether the EU is properly implementing the UN Convention for the Protection of Persons with Disabilities. The European Parliament must not miss the opportunity to send a reply to the UN on its own behalf. This is what the resolution is about and gives concrete answers to the UN about what the European Parliament is doing for people with disabilities. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion because it will facilitate the effective implementation of the UN Convention.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, as I agree that the rights of persons with disabilities are equal to the rights of citizens without disabilities, that their dignity is inalienable and that they are entitled to equal treatment, independent living and full participation in society. I believe that people with disabilities are one of the most vulnerable groups in our society and that their integration into the labour market is one of the biggest challenges of social policy and labour market policy.  I support encouraging Those Member States that have not yet ratified the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities to do so without delay. I consider it important to draw up an ambitious proposal for a European accessibility package and to fully involve people with disabilities at all stages of the legislative cycle. I support accessibility not only in the physical sense, but also in the sense that public services are also made accessible. I believe that the motion gives a comprehensive picture of the existing problems, and that a comprehensive legislative work must be launched to resolve them.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. We urge the Commission to put forward an ambitious proposal for the EU's accessibility legislation and to involve people with disabilities fully throughout the legislative cycle, and stress that this proposal must include a wide range of policy areas on the accessibility of goods and services for all EU citizens, promote the autonomy and full integration of disabled people. , and establish a permanent, effective and independent monitoring and implementation mechanism.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Persons with disabilities have equal rights and are entitled to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living and full participation in society. An estimated 80 million people in the European Union have a disability, therefore it is key to act and keep this in mind in all policies to be taken in the EU. I call on those Member States which have not already done so to ratify the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities CRPD without delay.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this resolution, which states that the European Parliament must participate fully in the monitoring and implementation of human rights and all actions to correct inequality in their access. We find the adoption of two key pieces of legislation fundamental: the European Accessibility Act and the General Anti-Discrimination Directive, both being an essential part of the implementation of the UN Convention. The resolution also calls on Member States to reflect the obligations under article 12 of the UN Convention on National Laws and more specifically, as well as the right of all persons with disabilities to vote and be elected.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear colleagues, People with disabilities are among the most vulnerable groups in our society. Around 80 million people in the European Union have some form of disability and their integration, especially in the labour market, poses one of the biggest challenges. Despite all the existing programmes, initiatives and strategies at EU level, there is much more to be done in Europe towards equal treatment and the removal of still existing barriers to people with disabilities. The resolution adopted today is a guarantor of our commitment to underpin European policies, full compliance with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with a view to eliminating all forms of discrimination against them and fully participating in economic and public life.  This document reflects our desire for more engagement and participation in the development of targeted policies to improve the conditions for independent living, in line with the Convention, as its ratification by Member States does not amount to application. Its re-creation in cases is our common responsibility – of the European institutions and of the Member States. This can only be achieved through a harmonised approach and in continuous dialogue and close cooperation with organisations representing persons with disabilities.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities as it will bring significant changes to the lives of people with disabilities, but also immense responsibility for us, the EU. People with disabilities need to be able to enjoy their rights today. We have to guarantee and ensure that people with disabilities will have equal access and equal opportunities and will enjoy social protection and education. This Convention can and will be an important step forward for our continent.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution as I share its content whose main claim is the objective improvement of the living conditions of persons with disabilities, through equal access to services and the labour market. I regret that it is not mentioned that this can only be done through a policy that strengthens public services and establishes concrete anti-discrimination policies for persons with disabilities, and although it urges States to cooperate with each other in these areas, it does not set a concrete priority or set minimums to be met within the Union.  However, I understand that the political will of this resolution is positive, hence my vote in favour, but there is a lack of concrete resources and commitments in ending discrimination (double discrimination in the case of women with disabilities) suffered by these people.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ We voted with my socialist colleagues in favour of this resolution because it calls on the Commission to present an ambitious proposal for a European Accessibility Act, with the full involvement of persons with disabilities throughout the legislative cycle.  It also stresses the need for this proposal to include a full range of policy areas with regard to the accessibility of goods and services for all of the EU.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. More than 75 million Europeans are disabled and cannot fully exercise their rights in our society. This is absolutely unacceptable to me and I hope that in the long term the European Commission will take its responsibility to meet the many questions of this population in Europe. I voted in favour of this report because I do not find the discrimination seen by many of them acceptable.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities came into force in the European Union on 21 January 2011. There are 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union, many of them face discrimination and obstacles in the exercise of their rights. They are one of the most vulnerable groups in our society and their professional integration is a great political challenge. There is no doubt that they must have the same rights as all those living in the EU, but they must be effective. All necessary measures must therefore be taken in the areas of social protection, health care, adaptation and rehabilitation, education, access to goods and services, but also housing, transport and employment, so that they enjoy real equality of treatment, maximum autonomy and full participation in social life. This resolution is a step in the right direction, even if it is only symbolic in scope. So I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Transparency of accountability on the functioning of the European institutions themselves is now essential. This information must also be accessible to everyone. To be consistent with this Convention is also, for example, not to encourage and support cuts in public education systems affecting people with disabilities.  In Portugal, in the context of the troika and post-troika policy that are one and the same, the number of special education teachers has been brutally reduced and in many schools there is not even a teacher, a situation that has worsened in recent years. There are students who for lack of support in school are advised to stay at home, finding their parents completely desperate and without solutions. They are children and young people who have been removed from the right to education. That's the hypocrisy we're in.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I could not support the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The concessions that the Union would have to make to people with disabilities would not lead to an improvement in the situation, but to positive discrimination. This, in turn, would make the situation of these people even worse in the long run. That is why I abstained.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my socialist colleagues in favour of this resolution because it calls on the Commission to present an ambitious proposal for a European Accessibility Act, with the full involvement of persons with disabilities throughout the legislative cycle.  It also stresses the need for this proposal to include a full range of policy areas with regard to the accessibility of goods and services for all EU citizens, fostering independent living and full inclusion of people with disabilities and establishing an ongoing, effective and independent monitoring and enforcement mechanism.  This vote was of particular personal interest. Firstly, due to the need to take into account the diversity existing among persons with disabilities by adopting specific actions and strategies which address the perspective of children, women & girls and persons identifying as LGBTI with disabilities who might suffer from multiple forms of discrimination and have even more specific needs. That must include ensuring their contribution to the public debate and their participation in decision making, in order to respect the principle reflected in the parliamentary Disability Intergroup’s motto: ‘Nothing about us without us’. Secondly, it stresses the importance of taking disability into account in the EU development and Humanitarian Aid strategy. The EU must adopt a disability and development policy.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted for the resolution on the list of issues adopted by the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in connection with the initial report of the European Union. The Commission must come up with an ambitious proposal for a European Accessibility Act, through the full involvement of people with disabilities throughout the legislative cycle, and promote an independent life and their full inclusion. It also welcomes the recommendation on the use of EU funds to promote accessibility and e-accessibility for people with disabilities, the transition from institutional care to community care, the development of quality social and health services and to invest in capacity building of organisations representing people with disabilities.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported this initiative on the list of issues adopted by the United Nations Commission on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in connection with the initial report of the European Union. This resolution takes into account, inter alia, the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD), as well as the relevant official positions put in place by the EU.  It is another important step in defending the rights of people with disabilities, both in terms of civil liberties and justice but also in terms of employment and social affairs.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 It is estimated that 80 million people in the European Union have a form of disability and the information provided by the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights systematically demonstrates that they face discrimination and obstacles to exercising their rights on an equal footing with others.  It is inconceivable that, despite all existing programmes, initiatives and strategies at EU level, the employment rate of people aged 20-64 should be over 70%, while that of people with disabilities under 50%. Paid work is essential to enable people to lead independent lives, and member states should therefore work to increase access to employment for people with disabilities so that they can contribute to the society in which they live, while also providing inclusive education that allows them to follow a path appropriate to their learning skills by giving them the opportunity to achieve a solid level of training.  It is certainly necessary for the European Union to have a permanent structural dialogue with people with disabilities through their representative organisations in full compliance with Article 4.3 of the United Nations Convention, which is a central condition for the effective implementation of the Convention.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that it is absolutely necessary to remove any restrictions on the rights of persons with disabilities, especially in the areas of social protection, education and access to services such as transport or accommodation. Persons with disabilities must have equal rights and be fully involved in society.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 There are more than 80 million people with disabilities living in the European Union who, unlike healthy citizens, cannot take full advantage of the freedoms on which the European Union is built. Unfortunately, there is still a long time to go before we can say that the whole old continent can really take care of the most vulnerable. The Union should set an example in respecting the obligations arising from the Convention and promote barrier-freeness not only in individual Member States, but also across borders. Barriers should also not be in access to healthcare for disabled people. The moment we remove all these obstacles, we will be able to say that the right to freedom of movement is indeed a prerogative of all.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Transparency of accountability, also derived from the obligations of signing the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, on the functioning of the European institutions themselves is now essential. This information must be accessible to everyone. But consistent with this Convention would be, for example, not to encourage and support cuts in public education systems affecting people with disabilities. In my country, Portugal, within the framework of troika and post-troika politics which are one and the same, the number of special education teachers has been brutally reduced and in many schools there is not even a teacher, a situation that has worsened in recent years. There are students who for lack of support in school are advised to stay at home, finding their parents completely desperate and without solutions.  They are children and young people who have been removed from the right to education. Does this have anything to do with the Convention that this Parliament so claims to defend? However, in accordance with the principles advocated in the resolution, although we criticise the concrete policies that do not apply them, we voted in favour.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I must congratulate my colleagues on having just voted on a motion for a resolution which is practically in line with the Commission's implementing decision.  At this point I wonder what Parliament's real role is. Have we worked for days to reconfirm the same decisions as the Commission itself? Okay, we agree with the import control measures, which are in complete agreement on aid to farmers and research, but in this resolution there is no mention of the need for a cost-benefit analysis, in the medium and long term, of strategies for eradicating the pathogen. There is also no desire to reconsider the proposed measures in the light of the scientific evidence that has been presented on several sides so far, and this refers to the exclusion of the vine from potentially host plants in Xylella or to the damage to health and the environment caused by the use of large-scale pesticides. With the application of this decision it will be possible to eradicate healthy trees within a radius of one hundred meters from the infected tree and to prohibit the planting of all species only because they are potentially hosts, regardless of any controls and monitoring. We are talking about measures, therefore, which are myopic and which will certainly have European consequences because of the social, environmental and economic repercussions.  But my prediction is unfortunately all too easy. That is why, as the Chef de cabinet suggested to me at a recent meeting, we have decided to join forces and our voice with the main italian and European farmers' and environmental organisations: I am talking about Federbio, I am talking about Copagri, the CIA, PAN Europe. We have just finished presenting and drawing up a common and shared position paper, so we will present it to the Commission. These alternatives are supported, among other things, by Community directives and also approved by representatives of academia and science.  At this point I doubt whether the competent authorities will be able to look the other way and not assume their responsibilities.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our lands (Salento) and our farmers have been hard hit by an epidemic that European rules and controls have not been able to stem. Our farmers are victims, not culprits.  Olive trees are not only the main source of income, but also a strong identity trait. Puglia and Salento, without their great centuries-old olive trees, would be like Paris without its famous tower. It is therefore a good thing that the Plant Health Committee has taken a decision not to continue with the crazy idea of eradicating millions of olive trees in infected areas. But that is not enough: we need action, at least three. Firstly, resources under Horizon 2020 to develop scientific knowledge that will enable us to eradicate this still little-known disease. Secondly, urgent measures by the Commission to compensate for the serious damage suffered by farmers and operators. And thirdly, rational management of buffer zones.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I voted in favour of the resolution I tabled together with other Colleagues on measures to deal with the devastating effects of the Xylella fastidiosa bacterium. The resolution approves concrete measures and calls, firstly, for financial support for olive growers affected by Xylella; Xylella is a dangerous bacterium which, unless immediate action is taken, olive growers in Greece and the Mediterranean will suffer a huge economic disaster. We therefore welcome the adoption of our resolution on Xylella and call on the European Commission and the Member States to proceed with its immediate implementation.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, the problems faced by Italian olive growers cause fear for their neighbours, including Croatian olive growers. What worries them most is the lack of relevant and reliable information. I supported this resolution because it warns of the almost catastrophic situation faced by olive growers. I am grateful that my proposals concerning facilitating access to information and sharing experience and developing comprehensive guidelines for the application of preventive, anti-control and surveillance measures with a clearly indicated scope and duration of these measures have been accepted.  Measures to indemnce olive producers should not be ignored. Insufficient compensation for the resulting damages creates resistance to the implementation of measures, and their ineffective implementation can only be a trigger for the spread of the disease.  Croatian olive growers want clear answers, and communication on these issues must be quick and efficient, not only between the competent authorities, but also with olive producers.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution because it does not reflect the real damage that massive tree felling can cause to the inhabitants of Italy's Puglia Region. There is no guarantee that approved chemical treatments will eradicate this serious disease, while it will bring serious costs to farmers and does not stop imports from infected regions. Our parliamentary group on the European Left has proposed an alternative resolution with the Green Group and italy's Five Star Movement, which pointed to the environmental risks of the proposed treatments and the need to help affected farmers. In view of the significant risks this disease may pose to our country, we do not believe that this resolution proposes appropriate international import control measures to prevent spread and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. The bacterium Xyllela fastidiosa, responsible for the mortality of olive trees and likely to affect other plant species, is a real threat to the agricultural economy of the Mediterranean areas. I welcome the fact that, as a result of France's protection measures, the Union has followed suit. On 29 April, the Commission took steps to destroy infected trees, control and limit any movement of plant material from the affected areas, and ban all importation into the EU of plants from the third countries from which the bacteria appeared. But it would be wrong for us to stop there. This health event again raises the problem of controlling plants imported into Europe. A year ago, we had this debate about protecting plants from the importation of pests. Faced with the repeated failures of the current control system at the Union's external borders, I had proposed to change it. I had not been heard. Parliament's resolution urges the Commission to review this system of plant health control in order to better protect the territory of the Union. I will support this request as the one calling for support for the areas affected by Xyllella fastidiosa.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution on the spread of Xylella fastidiosa is one of the important texts that need to be voted on, implemented and supported to ensure their effectiveness. While it is difficult to effectively control this bacterium, the motion for a resolution stresses that grubbing seems to be an adequate solution. Targeted pesticides are to date too serious a source of concern. A policy of protectionism, limiting the importation of products from regions affected by Xylella, finds its meaning here. However, the European Union prefers to condemn The Member States that choose this route, accusing them of not respecting the rules of free trade. Despite these reservations, I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ It would be nonsensical for a British MEP to vote on this issue.  We have negligible olive trees in the United Kingdom. This is a matter which could, and should, be determined by the countries concerned. I do not know whether the proposed measures are good or bad, helpful or counterproductive to countries with olive trees. It is not for me to judge. I therefore abstained, and hope that other MEPs will extend the same courtesy to the United Kingdom. Better yet, we should stop taking action at EU level on issues which do not affect all of the countries within the European Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to call on the EU to take measures to prevent the spread of the bacteria Xylella fastidiosa in the Puglia region, Italy, and to avoid additional damage. The bacterium Xylella fastidiosa is very dangerous and poses a very serious direct threat to the cultivation of certain crops in southern Europe. A bacterium can cause disastrous losses with huge economic, ecological and social consequences. Until now, the focus has been on internal action to combat the outbreak and no measures have been envisaged to prevent the spread of the disease to the EU from third countries. I support the calls for the Commission to take targeted measures against Xylella fastidiosa to ensure that infected material does not enter the EU. I support the calls on the Commission and the Member States to compensate growers for the destruction measures and income foregone, i.e. income not only for agricultural production, but also for cultural heritage, history and tourism-related activities.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The bacterium Xyllella fastidiosa is currently decimating olive trees in southern Italy. It is estimated that 10% of the trees in the Lecce region- or several thousand hectares - are already infected. It is therefore urgent that the European Commission takes all necessary measures to prevent the spread of the bacteria to other parts of Italy and other Member States. Finally, the Commission must also take measures to financially support farmers affected by the epidemic.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. – Although the European Commission has tried to contain the Xylella outbreak affecting olive trees, the disease continues to spread, wreak havoc in southern Italy and increasing fears in countries where this sector is key. Through this resolution, we call, inter alia, for the sector to be compensated for losses and to restrict imports of plants from affected areas of third countries. We regret that, once again, the Commission is late in implementing preventive measures (it has already occurred with the black spot from South Africa that mainly affected Spain) and that it does not have determination when reviewing legislation on phytosanitary controls. In all this, we hope that the Commission will take into account what we have approved in this parliament.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Xylella fastidiosa has been imported from Central America and is currently destroying olive trees in the Puglia region of Italy. The danger is obviously the risk of spreading the bacterium to other European countries, but it is agreed that scientific control against it is difficult and that the preference is for grubbing up, which is not entirely satisfactory. France, in order to deal with this bacterium, has decided provisionally to ban imports of plants from infected regions. Imports should be supported and better controlled. I voted for this text because it encourages the control of these imports.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the nature of Xyella fastidiosa is not fully known and that there are several conflicting scientific opinions on the measures to be put in place to combat this bacterium, and also noting that EFSA itself has declared the likely ineffectiveness of eradication as a conflicting intervention, especially in cases of propagation that have already taken place, I have decided to abstain in the vote on this resolution.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the Commission to take more effective measures to prevent the spread of annoying Xylella in the EU. Xylella fastidiosa is a bacterium with enormous pathogenic potential over a large number of plants that can cause serious losses in European agriculture and the agri-food chain. Its emergence in Italy with 9 million olive trees affected, - apparently due to contagion of an infected ornamental plant that entered Rotterdam - highlights the malfunction of the EU's phytosanitary protection against imports from third countries and the Commission's slowness to react to a problem which, if not tackled in time , can be devastating for olive trees in southern Europe and whose spread also threatens citrus fruits and the vineyard. It is therefore necessary to review the official EU phytosanitary system applicable to imports, introduce a preventive system for import controls, implement the mandatory establishment of the olive phytosanitary passport and use as many funds and instruments as possible to contribute to the economic recovery of the affected areas.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the outbreak of the disease 'Xylella fastidiosa' affecting olive trees. The plant disease caused by this bacterium has already devastated large areas of the growing area in third countries, such as vineyards in California and citrus groves in Brazil, and is widespread in the USA and Latin America. Currently, there are no unhealthy plant treatments and damaged plants usually remain infected throughout their life cycle or quickly disappear. This disease can be infected with various plants, including wild plants without signs of disease, in the European Union. The Commission does not always respond quickly enough to the need to prevent the introduction of plant diseases from third countries into the EU, as the import control system is strictly based on a reactive approach that does not provide sufficient protection against harmful organisms such as the Xylella bacterium. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to verify the source of the contamination and to review the EU's official phytosanitary import system in order to protect EU territory. In addition, the Council and the Commission should resume discussions on the review of the EU's formal phytosanitary control system in order to protect EU territory.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. The bacterium Xylella fastidiosa poses a significant danger and poses a direct threat to the cultivation of certain crops in southern Europe, such as olives, almonds, peaches, citrus fruit, etc. This bacterium causes significant damage to olive groves in the southern Italian region of Puglia, which can cause significant environmental and economic damage to that country. However, the biggest problem is the unusually rapid spread of this disease to the remaining areas and plants grown in the countries of southern Europe. I believe that effective measures must be taken within the EU as soon as possible to prevent the spread of Xylella fastidiosa. These measures should primarily target the most deprived crops and ensure effective protection against the spread of the bacterium. However, controls at EU entry points, especially in ports, must also be tightened. However, in order to ensure effective control or prevention of spread, sufficient financial and human resources must be provided and farmers should be able to benefit from financial support to implement appropriate agricultural practices to combat this dangerous bacterium.  I voted in favour of the proposed resolution because, in my opinion, it requires the European Commission to take key measures to limit the spread of this bacterium. Otherwise, farmers in these areas are facing a major catastrophe.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The joint resolution of parliament's main groups was not convincing: while noting the Commission's shortcomings in the delay and superficiality with which it handled the Xylella emergency (pointed out in good time by Italy), it did not call on the Commission to revise the current eradication plan put in place, on whose reliability EFSA itself is now sceptical. I therefore abstained on the final vote, instead supporting only Resolution B8-0450/2015, which called on the Commission to review its plan to contain the disease.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Last year 2014 will be remembered as one of the worst in terms of olive growing or olive yield. In addition to the lack of rainfall, EU Member States where olive growing is a significant part of agricultural production have faced an infestation of pests that damages and reuses the fruit. For example, Croatia recorded its worst crop in 40 years.  Furthermore, the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) issued a scientific opinion in January warning against the spread of Xylella fastidiosa, which attacks not only olives but also cultures such as citrus and vines. I hope that the Commission, in line with its powers, will take decisive action to stop its expansion.  In addition to the obvious economic damage and endangered livelihoods of European olive growers, the lack of oil on the market and the consequent increase can have an impact on the public health of European citizens. Olive oil is a healthier alternative to common types of edible oil and as such has a more beneficial effect on the cardiovascular system of the human body.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this resolution because I believe that the Commission should put in place more effective prophylaxis measures against infected products from third countries and that it should seriously consider indening producers for the uprooting measures and loss of income that the Xylella fastidiosa epidemic has caused so far and is still causing.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The lavish Xylella is not an Italian problem, but a European one. Unfortunately, this was not a foregone conclusion, given the first decisions taken by France with the decree of 2 April 2015 that blocked all imports of plants from Italy, with damage to production even hundreds of kilometers away from the area affected by the epidemic. Unjustified measures of this kind, which in fact pursue protectionist aims, add damage to the damage and require coordination by the European institutions. On the other hand, thanks to the work of the European Parliament on this resolution, great strides have been made in clarifying the problems we have raised.  As a first response, the ban on the import of infected plants (they have also been found in France and other countries) solves the root of the problem. Similarly, avoiding the total eradication of plants in the infected area by implementing less radical measures is of fundamental importance from a social, economic and environmental point of view. Finally, the most important aspects are linked to increased investment in scientific research and economic compensation measures for farmers and nurseries to compensate for the losses incurred.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Imported from Central America, Xylella bacteria is currently destroying many olive fields in the Puglia region of Italy. The risk of spread is greatest and solutions to combat this scourge are not without side effects. The most effective being the restriction of imports from areas affected by the bacterium, the European Union has nevertheless accused France of not respecting the rules of free movement of goods on the common market. That is why any proposal for a resolution to limit imports and strengthen controls must be supported to combat the spread of this bacterium. I voted for the text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The spread of the xylella fastidiosa bacterium which has now affected olive crops in northern Italy but which in the future risks extending to vines, peaches, citrus fruits and ornamental plants raises a serious alarm about the measures to stop the spread and prevent its spread. Unfortunately, there is currently no treatment for infected plants, and a significant number of wild plants carrying bacteria show no visible symptoms, which creates difficulties in identifying and stopping the spread of the bacterium. In order to prevent new outbreaks, imports from areas where the bacterium has been identified should be prohibited and strict control and monitoring of plants from suspect areas should be imposed. We have co-signed the resolution on the spread of Xylella fastidiosa because I am convinced that we must react firmly and make every effort at our disposal to create a quarantine procedure to stop the spread of the disease, because its effects can be disastrous for the entire European agricultural sector.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained. To date, the nature of the weed bacterium is not fully known and, as a result, there are several conflicting scientific opinions on the phytosanitary protection measures to be put in place. These include the eradication of infected and potentially infected plants.  The Lega Nord has clearly spoken out against this measure, which is a key element of the Commission's proposal. Although eradication has, in the past, been a useful measure for similar, if not equal, phenomena that have attacked other plant species (the vine, for example, against which a plant eradication plan was carried out), efsa's recent positions recognise the substantial ineffectiveness of the intervention, especially in view of the spread of the disease. Since these are centuries-old trees and, in any case, which come into production after many years (decades, compared to the production levels of a historic plant), which are also a fundamental element of the rural landscape of those lands and therefore represent a not insignificant economic, tourist and social value, our precautionary position is amply justified.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Xylella fastidiosa is a bacterium that directly threatens the production of certain plants, especially olive trees. The bacteria has already caused a lot of damage in Puglia in Italy. In some areas, the spread of this bacterium has considerable economic and social consequences. With this resolution, we call on the Commission and the Member States to act as quickly as possible to stop the contamination of plants and to compensate the producers concerned. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this resolution to urge the Commission and the Member States to compensate farmers, particularly in Puglia, for eradication measures and loss of income, including from tourism-related activities. I also call on the Commission to use all possible funds and instruments to help the economic recovery of the affected areas and to encourage farmers to take preventive measures. At the moment there is no treatment available for sick plants. The Commission should therefore promote and intensify its research efforts, increasing international cooperation and dealing with this issue as a matter of urgency.  I welcome the EU's decision to restrict imports of plants from affected areas of third countries, such as imports of coffee plants from Costa Rica and Honduras, but I would also stress that the Commission's reaction times are often not fast enough to prevent plant diseases from spreading within the EU. In order to safeguard the territory, the eu's official phytosanitary control system should be reviewed and, if necessary, the Commission should introduce more restrictive import measures.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ Xylella fastidiosa is a plant pathogenic bacterium that was detected in olive trees in Apulia province in Italy in October 2013. The bacteria-affected olive trees in the region could have a potential impact on 8 000 workers in the olive culture sector risk who are at risk of losing their livelihoods. Olive production is one of the Apulia region’s most important agricultural sectors, accounting for 11.6% (or EUR 522 million) of the total value of agricultural production in the region and 30% of the value of Italian olive production in 2013. The EU Commission proposed to remove and destroy infested plants, and all host plants within a radius of 100m, irrespective of their health status. This could lead to desertification and destruction of agricultural heritage, without clear scientific evidence of its effectiveness in preventing the spread of the pathogen. There is another solution, different to the removal or destruction of all affected plants. My Group tabled an alternative resolution calling on the Commission to consider alternative solutions that will also safeguard the agro-food sector and the environment in the region. It was for these reasons that I voted against this Joint Motion for Resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Xylella fastidiosa bacterium is a plague that is seriously affecting olive growers in the south of our country. I voted against the proposed resolution in this regard because it provides for the eradication of all plants potentially susceptible to cation, even if healthy, within a radius of up to 100 metres from the affected areas, so as to create 'buffer zones'. This is an exaggerated prevention measure, without clear scientific support, which will bring the economy of the entire region to its knees, hitting a flagship of Italian production in the area.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution, which addresses the serious problem of the Xylella bacterium, which poses a considerable danger to olive farms, particularly in Italy. This bacterium, imported from Central America, poses a real risk of the spread and destruction of all olive plants on the European continent; the joint motion for a resolution proposes to limit imports in this area, which seems to be the most realistic and effective solution, as the grubbing solution has presented its limits and the use of pesticides raising many food and environmental security issues. Note the positive attitude of the French authorities, which very quickly decided to ban imports of plants from infected regions, a public health measure that may justify an exception to the free trade regime that governs the European internal market.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. (u2012 In exceptional cases where, for example, a disease such as xylella fastidiosa causes serious economic damage to European agricultural production, it may be appropriate to allow financial compensation from the EU. However, such compensation shall not cover losses in cultural heritage, history and tourism-related activities.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 Xylella fastidiosa poses a highly dangerous immediate threat to the production of certain crops in southern Europe and the epidemic affecting olive trees in Puglia has already caused serious damage not only to producers but to the entire olive production chain. Puglia's olive sector represents 11.6%, or EUR 522 million, of the total value of agricultural production in the region and 30% of the value of Italian olive production. The first outbreak was notified to the Italian authorities in October 2013, but the situation has since deteriorated dramatically. EFSA, given the difficulty in combating Xylella once it has spread to a production area, stressed the need for prevention initiatives.  The Commission is therefore called on to prevent the import of infected material, to compensate producers for uprooting measures and loss of income, to carry out information campaigns, to set up an open database, with a list of competent authorities in the Member States and at EU level, and to inform the EP periodically, or when deemed necessary, of the threat posed by Xylella or other bodies.  In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Italian case of Xylella fastidiosa. I agree with the criticism leveled at the European Commission regarding delays in the management of the problem, as well as the inadequacy of the measures taken until April 2015, aimed only at combating the epidemic and not at preventing the import of infected material from non-EU countries. I share the wish to introduce measures to prevent or restrict the import of infected plants, such as those already adopted for infected Coffea plants from Honduras and Costa Rica, and any other useful action.  The central point remains the request to the Commission and the Member States to provide compensation for plant producers who will be eradicated not only in terms of damage to agricultural production, but also to cultural, historical and tourist heritage. I think it is right to use all the funds and instruments at our disposal to find financial resources and to allow the economic recovery of the affected areas to take place as quickly as possible. Efforts must also be stepped up to improve research in order to increase scientific knowledge and identify appropriate treatments for eradicating these diseases, as well as to create an open database for the exchange of information and best practices.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Xylella fastidiosa is a highly dangerous bacterium of immediate threat to production, especially in southern Europe. The spread of Xylella fastidiosa bacteria in Italy has caused severe damage to olive trees. Xylella has many hosts and could attack other plants, including almond, peach and citrus trees, ornamental plants and vineyards. The resolution calls for effective measures to prevent the spread of Xylella fastidiosa bacteria beyond Italy and compensate growers, and suggests stepping up and promoting increased international networking. I have thus voted in favour as further spread of Xylella fastidiosa could lead to unprecedented and devastating losses, with dramatic economic, environmental and social consequences.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. I voted in favour of the resolution on emergency measures to curb the outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa which has knocked out large parts of olive production in southern Italy and parts of Spain. I believe that measures need to be taken, because this is of great importance for Europe's consumers to feel safe.  Xylella is highly contagious and is in danger of spreading further. Nevertheless, I believe that controls on imports from third countries must be risk-based and proportionate. That must not mean closing our trade limits.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution because it does not reflect the real damage that massive tree felling can bring to the inhabitants of Italy's Puglia Region. There is no guarantee that approved chemical treatments will eradicate this serious disease, while it will bring serious costs to farmers and does not stop imports from infected regions. Our parliamentary group on the European Left has proposed an alternative resolution with the Green Group and italy's Five Star Movement, which pointed to the environmental risks of the proposed treatments and the need to help affected farmers. In view of the significant risks this disease may pose to our country, we do not believe that this resolution proposes appropriate international import control measures to prevent spread and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The xylella epidemic affects one of the most important agricultural sectors, in particular for Puglia, a region that has always had an agricultural vocation. Not only that, but the risk is that, in addition to the agricultural sector, the entire production chain, including processing and marketing, will also be put to its knees. Unfortunately, there are no remedies at the moment and the simple eradication of infected plants would not, on its own, be sufficient to eradicate the disease, so efforts must be concentrated on prevention and research.  On the one hand, therefore, it is necessary to activate all the phytosanitary protection procedures that make it possible to contain the epidemic, avoiding the risk of its further spread. On the other hand, efforts in the field of research must be stepped up, simplifying the use of funds and funding available to institutions, to identify pathogens and vectors that cause the spread of the disease. In the meantime, the Commission and the Member States must take all initiatives to ensure compensation for producers and territories, which are suffering losses not only in terms of future agricultural production but also in terms of cultural and historical heritage.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of having more means to ensure the detection of harmful organisms at points of entry in the EU and for the Commission to take targeted measures against Xylella fastidiosa. I am in favour of the Commission taking effective measures to avoid the spread within the EU, in particular by targeting the crops most at risk. We need preventive measures and real help should be given to those who are most affected.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Xylella fastidiosa epidemic affecting olive trees.  Xylella fastidiosa is seriously damaging not only Italian olive producers, but more generally tourism and marketing activities related to this sector and is in danger of spreading to other COUNTRIES of the Union. Immediate measures must be put in place to combat the epidemic, but the prevention strategy must also be important: with this resolution, Parliament is calling on the Commission to review the official European system of plant health controls, in order to prevent this and new epidemics from coming from third countries from hitting European territories. We need a strong response from the European Union, which only with strong and coherent policies will be able to respond to the challenges that the globalised world of interconnected markets poses to us and will not fail to pose to us in the future.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This epidemic illustrates the major risks of unchecked opening of our European borders to agricultural products and plants from abroad. The risk to plant and animal health is now obvious. The solution lies firstly in strengthening product controls at the Union's borders, it is a necessity. In addition, compensation procedures should be initiated for farmers affected by this epidemic. Funding for research is also an imperative. Our scientists must very quickly find solutions to eradicate the bacteria and preserve the remaining crops. As these various points are present in the resolution, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Since 2013, the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa has been wreaking havoc in the Italian olive sector. This Parliament's resolution intervenes to prevent the spread of a plant health crisis in several parts of European agriculture and horticulture. Measures have already been taken to control the bacteria at the local level in the Puglia region, however a more comprehensive action plan is needed. This resolution calls for increased vigilance at customs upon entry into the Union for imported goods and travellers. The bacterium is transmitted both by the infected plants themselves and by insects. Finally, I am pleased that Parliament is taking into account the threats to the livelihoods of people in the affected areas by providing them with compensation.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Xylella fastidiosa epidemic, in addition to having dramatic economic, environmental and social consequences, puts Apulian olive growing at serious risk. The European Union must take every action to tackle the problem and thus prevent its spread to other regions. The European Commission will also need to invest more in research to study and analyse this bacterium in order to find ways of eradicating it.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The Puglia region of southern Italy has been the victim of an outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa, a bacterium that affects olive trees, since 2013. Already 10% of olive groves in Lecce province have been infected. Carried by insect vectors, this bacterium is already spreading to neighbouring regions. A suspicious case has even been reported near Nice. The lack of treatment for contaminated plants, the large number of species likely to be infected, and the likelihood of its spread in the European Union make this bacterium a very serious threat to agriculture. This is why the European Parliament is asking the Commission, in order to avoid further damage, to take targeted measures such as the removal and destruction of listed host plants (citrus, olive, vines, plums, almond trees, tobaccos, pink laurels, oaks, brambles...) within a hundred metres of any plant reached by Xylella fastidiosa.  At the same time, aid will have to be allocated to farmers for the replenishment of olive and other affected tree crops.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which urges the European Commission to fight with determination the spread of Xylella fastidiosa on European territory. A range of actions are needed, including strengthening measures to prevent and control the spread of this disease, the development of effective control measures, compensation for producers, but also strict control of imports of plant products. The fight against Xylella will illustrate the European Union's determination to protect its territory and agriculture from the growing health risks caused by increased trade and insufficient plant protection resources.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the spread of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, which infects olive trees. It is a scourge that threatens olive groves around the Mediterranean.  It has spread widely throughout Puglia and there are serious concerns about the Corsica region in particular. We must be responsible and careful in doing everything we can to stop the bacteria. On the one hand, the olive tree epidemic is an environmental concern, especially for France and Italy. On the other hand, it is a significant economic risk that weighs on many olive growers. In order to limit the spread and eradicate the bacteria, imports should be controlled and those from affected areas should be banned. Indeed, optimal management of the flow of goods is the only viable and sensible solution.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 It is absolutely necessary to support, since this harmful disease already causes catastrophic damage. We must actively protect our regions, which are under direct threat. I am personally very worried about this disease and its possible spread in Bulgaria. Our regional products are of excellent quality, so we need to keep this situation and avoid any influx of bacteria from third countries; it has already caused sufficient damage.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Positive because there are solutions to fight the disease without consequences for the environment.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of parliament's resolution calling for strengthening joint action against Xylella fastidiosa and increasing efficiency. On the one hand, the Commission must ensure that sufficient financial and human resources are available to implement these pest control strategies. Producers should receive adequate financial support for the application of best agricultural practices which are crucial in the fight against Xylella fastidiosa. Furthermore, EU compensation should be granted to farmers who have been harmed by the felling of olive trees. Finally, appropriate resources should be allocated to research into Xylella fastidiosa and other dangerous plant pests. The resources of Horizon 2020 should be allocated, inter alia, to such cases.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the outbreak of Xylella Fastidiosa. It is currently having a disastrous effect on thousands of square miles of olive trees, mainly in southern Italy, but has been seen recently in other Member States and in other plants too. It is vital that we protect our agriculture in Wales by taking early and preventative action.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 Xylella fastidiosa is a bacterium that is affecting olive growing in southern Italy, especially Puglia. The resolution provides for the lifting of all plants within a radius of 100 metres from areas affected by the bacterium; this is considered to be an excessive precautionary measure which, moreover, is not supported by concrete scientific evidence. I voted against because the final version approved by Parliament does not incorporate some of the key amendments we have proposed. Consequently, the final version of the resolution risks putting local businesses, large and small, in serious difficulty, undermining one of Italy's excellences.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Xylella fastidiosa is a very serious direct threat to the production of certain crops in Southern Europe, namely olive, almond, peach and ornamental plants.
