The strain that is infecting olive trees in the Apulia region of southern Italy is different from the disease-causing strain on vines or citrus fruits in other parts of the world. Olive production in the Apulia region is one of the most important agricultural sectors, accounting for 11.6 % (i.e. EUR 522 million) of the total value of agricultural production in the region and 30 % of the value of olive production in Italy in 2013; I agree with the need for the European Commission to take effective measures to prevent the spread of Xylella fastidiosa in the European Union and to compensate producers for eradication measures and loss of income, which entail losses not only in terms of agricultural production but also in historical terms, cultural heritage and tourism-related activities.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is a first awareness of the necessary fight against this bacterium causing serious havoc in olive plantations, even if it does not go far enough with regard to restrictive import measures.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. In 2013, the Italian authorities were first notified of the occurrence of xyllela fastidiosa infection. It is a bacterial infection that mainly affects olive trees. The lack of effective treatments to cure plants infected by this microorganism, the broad spectrum of infection of susceptible plant species, as well as the high probability of contamination, make this bacterium a serious threat. This resolution calls on the Commission to take measures not only to stop this outbreak, but also to protect the sector from future outbreaks through preventive measures. It calls for support from targeted farmers who see their crops destroyed and incentives for farmers to take effective action to prevent infection, and for those who have appropriate farming practices to deal with this problem. It also asks research institutes for funds to increase scientific knowledge about Xyllela fastidiosa and to identify the nature of the link between pathogen, symptoms and the development of the disease. Although we consider that the resolution presented by our group contained a more correct and complete approach to this problem, we consider that the resolution adopted contains a minimum set of measures necessary in this phase of emergency.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Xylella fastidiosa is a bacterium that reached Europe from the United States in 2013. This disease has mainly affected olive trees in southern Europe, especially in the Puglia region of southern Italy, and has the potential to endanger other regions and crops in the future, which could have very dramatic economic, environmental and social impacts. We must do everything we can to stop the further spread of this disease to neighbouring regions.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the reports in their entirety on the Xylella fastidiosa epidemic, a bacterium that affects olive trees. The EU must take measures and the solutions that will be provided must not be temporary and superficial but help the affected areas. There are solutions to fight the disease without consequences for the environment.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The phytosanitary emergency affecting olive groves in Southern Europe, especially in the Apulia region of Southern Italy, potentially threatening other crops and regions, has assumed unprecedented and serious proportions, with dramatic economic, environmental and social consequences. On 28 April the standing Committee for Plant Health of the European Commission adopted a new decision aiming to stop the disease spreading to other regions. Also imports of plants from regions known to be susceptible will be subject to strict conditions. Member State experts also backed a ban on imports of coffee plants from Honduras and Costa Rica due to the risk from the pest. As a result France has since lifted its ban on plant imports from areas hit by the bacteria in light of the reinforced EU action.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. Xylella fastidiosa poses an immediate and very dangerous threat to the production of certain crops in southern Europe, including olive trees, almond trees, peaches and ornamental plants. There is currently no treatment available to cure diseased plants on site, and affected plants tend to remain infected throughout their lives or die quickly. Considering how difficult it is to stop the spread of Xylella fastidiosa once it affects a production area, priority should be given to import-focused prevention measures and outbreak containment, while intensifying trade in the field of research. That's why I voted for it.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Xylella fastidiosa emergency clearly showed the limitations of the European Union's border management system. For this reason, faced with the misfortune that we are experiencing in the Puglia Region, we wanted to send a strong signal of support to the thousands of farmers involved – the first victims of this dramatic situation – by proposing compensation for eradication measures and the resulting loss of income. In order for this tragedy not to happen again in the EU, we have also called for the EU's official phytosanitary control system to be reviewed and for more restrictive measures to be introduced for imports at risk.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. Xylella fastidiosa poses a serious threat to the production of certain crops in southern Europe, including olive trees. It is already causing significant damage in Puglia, Italy, and could lead to economic, environmental and social consequences, far beyond. No treatment is currently available to treat contaminated plants that remain infected throughout their lives or wither quickly. Given the difficulty in stemming the spread of Xylella fastidiosa once it has infested a production area, it is necessary to prioritize preventive measures targeting imports.  Unfortunately, the Commission is mainly focusing on internal measures to combat the epidemic, without taking into account the need to take measures to prevent the introduction of the disease into the European Union from third countries That is why I agree with this resolution which calls on the Commission to take swift all necessary measures to limit the spread of the disease and for Member States to compensate producers for eradication measures and the loss of income related to these measures.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Today, among other things, the "Massive infestation of olive trees with Xylella fastidiosa" is to be voted on. Admittedly, I did not know that olive trees in southern Europe are dying from this plant disease, threatening the livelihoods of many olive growers. But why should an MEP from Berlin deal with this problem? Since neither oaks, beech nor spruce are threatened by this disease, so a cross-border danger is by definition excluded, I have had to vote against this motion for a resolution. We cannot constantly preach subsidiarity and then open the door to centralism.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. The current epidemic of olive trees in Italy is a phenomenon little known to French citizens. It is no less dangerous as it now threatens vines and 300,000 other plant species. Given the risk, there is an urgent need to respond by imposing drastic controls on European ports to minimise contagion. The problem with this epidemic, if not contained, is that it can spread to animal species and may even pose a risk to humans. To date, scientists have not been able to develop a device to eradicate the bacteria. Only plant slaughter measures have helped to limit the spread, but this solution has a strong impact on the activities of producers and farmers. In the face of this phenomenon, we must put in place strict controls on imports of plant products and make research as easy as possible. Otherwise, it is all European agriculture that is at risk.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ The outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa is already serious in parts of Italy and has the potential to be devastating across the Mediterranean area and southern Europe. This is a major threat to rural industry and culture in the areas affected as well as to consumers across the EU. My Group has called for strict quarantine measures to be implemented and it is disappointing that the majority in this House have not opted to follow that call.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this resolution as we consider that the measures that are being taken are not only insufficient, but also undermine the future of the agricultural sector of olive groves. The escalation in the focus of infection is a reality that can be seen in the face of this alarming situation, the proposal made since the committee is eradication as an urgent solution. It is unworkable for us to raise such a scenario as the only way to curb mass contagion. These measures do not reflect the compensation for losses or the age of the olive trees, as well as the particularities involved in the production of each of them.  This decision does not at any time deny the possibility of reclassifying agricultural land for uses other than that of origin in the face of the removal of infested shrubs. Nor is emphasis placed on the importance of land sustainability and the protection of the sectors living on it.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the Xylelle fastidiose epidemic, which attacks olive trees, as I am well familiar with the problem and have been actively involved and supported other previous initiatives on this topic, such as a written question and oral question in the European Parliament, and have participated in the preparation of the Resolution as coordinator of a group of ALDE Members. The problem of this bacteria is especially important and worrying for me given the great development that olive growing has achieved in Istria. As I have participated partly personally in this process through my previous political actions, I am particularly interested in countering the expansion of Xilelle fastidiosa. Any expansion to other areas of the Mediterranean at the scale occurring in the Puglia region would have catastrophic consequences.  I am in favour of swift measures aimed at combating Xilelle fastidiosa, but also to take into account the graduality of measures if possible so that removal measures do not achieve irreversible effects on plantations. The EU must also adequately assist olive growers in the affected areas.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution on the spread of Xylella fastidiosa is one of the important texts that need to be voted on, implemented and supported to ensure their effectiveness. While it is difficult to effectively control this bacterium, the motion for a resolution stresses that grubbing seems to be an adequate solution. Targeted pesticides are to date too serious a source of concern. On the other hand, it is important to point out here that a policy of protectionism, limiting the importation of products from regions affected by Xylella, makes perfect sense. However, the European Union prefers to condemn The Member States that choose this route, accusing them of not respecting the rules of free trade. For all these reasons, I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the bacterium Xylella. This bacterium that ravages olive trees in southern Italy, and more precisely in the region of Puglia, must absolutely be stopped. Parliament the group the following is the case for the Committee to act as quickly as possible against this scourge for our agriculture and to do everything possible to prevent its spread to the rest of the European Union. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "One of the goals of our work in the AGRI Committee is to provide consumers with the highest quality food. We cannot predict all adversity, but we have the capacity to prevent and respond appropriately to food diseases and pollution.  So it should be this time. Having already been taught many times (ASF disease in Poland, "cucumber crisis" in Germany) we should create the right tools so that such a problem, which erupts in a certain area, does not condemn consumers to health risks, and producers to industry gridlock and huge losses in their own companies, and above all the loss of thousands of jobs.  We should treat each case in particular, because the different areas have their own characteristics and will react differently to the crisis.  Olives have been cultivated in Puglia for several thousand years, so the tools used here should take a special approach to the epidemic occurring here. First of all, a financial instrument should be launched to support farmers during the crisis and to deal with the problem quickly and return to the market. I would like to stress that such an instrument should be constantly available so that it can be activated immediately if necessary.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The bacterium Xylella fastidiosa wreaks hastitarian destruction, so it must be prevented from spreading at all costs. The call for better research is just as important as avoiding the fight against environmentally-friendly measures such as grubbing-up. I am therefore voting in favour of this resolution and supporting the proposals it makes.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ The outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa demonstrates the inadequacies of the EU phytosanitary control system, combined in this case, as it seems, with the weak response from the Italian authorities. Nevertheless, since the outbreak is highly contagious and might pose threat to other species of plants across Europe, a sign of solidarity and swift action is needed.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – It is now up to the olive trees and the recommendation offers an effective package of solutions to support it. For the future, however, it is necessary to think about the roots of similar and from time to time legal problems, the wider context of the problem. The EU agricultural model is monoculture in nature, which greatly threatens the stability of agro-ecosystems due to its adverse impact on biodiversity. The global free trade in goods, which is the basis for the spread of pathogens.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Unfortunately, we are all aware of the considerable damage caused by the bacterium "Xylella fastidiosa" for the Puglia region, whose farmers, owners of farms and nurseries have been grappling with this phenomenon for two years now, which has led to decimation of production, market blockades, embargoes from Algeria, Morocco and France, and above all now see a new axe fall on their already difficult situation : a new plan to stem the risks that will provide for a preventive culling of about 296 thousand plants currently under seals as they are considered hosts of the bacterium. A precautionary quarantine that will result, for farmers, in a real economic ruin and for the territory in a difficult undertaking to regain the traditional environmental appeal of olive groves and the international fame of Salento oils, known and loved worldwide. In the face of this difficult emergency, I therefore fully support the call for action as an EU as soon as possible with compensation and support in the face of the serious losses suffered by farmers and landowners, also promoting the exchange of good practices and giving concrete testimony to a European Union ready to intervene in national emergencies not only with measures of difficult application but also with interventions that translate into support , understanding and sharing the evils, risks and the common search for overcoming them, for a return to the enhancement of the great excellences that characterize the Member States and the Union itself.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the Xylella fastidiosa epidemic affecting olive trees, which was adopted following the debate on 30 April. Xylella is seriously threatening agriculture in Europe and especially in southern Europe because of its unstoppable spread, the lack of treatment of plants of proven effectiveness and the number of plant species susceptible to infection. The EU must strengthen prevention measures, given the origin of the bacterium from plants imported from Costa Rica. I therefore supported Parliament's call to strengthen EU legislation on plant health controls and to provide states with the necessary resources to control and prevent the entry into the EU of phytopathies from third countries, by suspending imports of plants from infected countries. I approved the request made to the Commission to compensate producers for the grubbing-up measures and loss of income incurred, using European resources for the economic recovery of the affected areas.  I think we need further reflection on the need to retrain our agriculture by redirecting it towards less invasive practices.  I could not, therefore, but share the concerns about the intensive use of pesticides and the request for financial support for farmers who adopt agronomic practices to combat the bacterium and its vectors.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒  I urge the Commission to act swiftly on the outbreak of Xyllella fastidiosa in the Southern Italian region of Apulia, and, in particular, to verify the source of the infection and to review the EU official phytosanitary control system, to take all necessary measures against the importation of plants affected by Xylella by controlling imports into the European Union and ensure the traceability of susceptible plants imported.  I also encourage the Commission to analyse the best means of compensating producers for the destruction of their crops.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ With the free movement of goods being a vital component of the Common Market, it is absolutely necessary for Italy, as well as the EU collectively, to take the prescribed action to prevent the spread of Xylella Fastidiosa to the rest of the market. Import controls are one of the EU’s most effective tools for preventing undesirable substances and diseases from entering the market and a risk-based approach is of course the most logical way to determine which products are safe for importing. Although the eradication of infected plants will negatively impact the important olive growing regions of southern Italy in the short term, to allow this disease to spread further would not be in the interest of growers. The Conservative Party believes that coordinated measures by EU Member States are needed to preserve the wellbeing of the Common Market, which benefits the economies of the UK and EU as a whole, so I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this resolution as we consider that the measures that are being taken are not only insufficient, but also undermine the future of the agricultural sector of olive groves. The escalation in the focus of infection is a reality that can be seen in the face of this alarming situation, the proposal made since the committee is eradication as an urgent solution. It is unworkable for us to raise such a scenario as the only way to curb mass contagion. These measures do not reflect the compensation for losses or the age of the olive trees, as well as the particularities involved in the production of each of them.  This decision does not at any time deny the possibility of reclassifying agricultural land for uses other than that of origin in the face of the removal of infested shrubs. Nor is emphasis placed on the importance of land sustainability and the protection of the sectors living on it.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission should ensure that sufficient financial and human resources are available to implement the relevant strategies, including financial support for farmers to apply appropriate agricultural practices for the management of Xylella fastidiosa and its vectors. This resolution urges the Commission to promote intensified research efforts without delay, with a view to increasing scientific knowledge of Xylella fastidiosa and positively identifying the nature of the link between the pathogen, the symptoms and the development of disease.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. On Wednesday, May 20, I voted in favour of new measures to prevent the spread of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, which infects olive trees. In particular, they provide that Member States will have to notify any outbreak of the bacteria and delineate the affected area. In the event of a new outbreak, they will have to destroy within a radius of 100m all plants that are likely to host the bacteria. I welcome the introduction of such European measures, the implementation of which will improve the effectiveness of the fight against this olive-killing bacterium. Research funding is key to enabling our scientists to find quick solutions to contamination and preserve existing crops. More than 300,000 plant species are threatened, including citrus fruits and vines. We must therefore act quickly and use all our means at European level to contain the epidemic.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the outbreak of the disease 'Xylella Fastidiosa' affecting olive trees, as the consequences of this disease have crossed continents, there are no unhealthy plant treatments, there is a lack of preventive measures to stop the development of contamination, and the regulation of imports from third countries is a complex and lengthy process. It is therefore necessary to ensure the protection of the EU's territory as soon as possible by verifying the source of the contamination and to resume interinstitutional work on this problem.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I supported the EP resolution with my vote because it urges the Commission to review the EU's official phytosanitary control system and calls for financial compensation for producers affected by the eradication measures recently agreed by the Commission, which it also approves. The Spanish Socialist delegation has long questioned the Commission about the serious threat posed by the Xylella outbreak to the Spanish olive grove and other productions, such as citrus and vines, which could be affected. We stressed the need for the plenary debate to be accompanied by a motion for a resolution to reflect the position of the European Parliament. While it is true that the adopted text lowers our expectations - it does not include socialist amendments: the introduction of the phytosanitary passport for olive trees and the requirement that a "positive list" system be implemented (only plant material on the list) for plant imports into the EU - the Resolution highlights the seriousness of the situation for southern agriculture and calls for increased inspections by Member States to prevent spread of the bacteria.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the Xylella fastidiosa epidemic affecting olive trees in Puglia, causing serious economic, environmental and social consequences. Our aim must be to prevent the spread of the parasite, but it is essential to provide for an adequate aid and subsidy plan for farmers, to compensate them for the serious damage suffered as a result of the Xylella emergency. At the same time, border controls must be strengthened and funding for scientific research increased.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution calling for a strengthening of measures at EU level to combat the outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa, a bacterium that particularly affects olive trees in southern Europe. With this resolution, adopted by an overwhelming majority of MEPs, we have called on the European Commission and the Member States to compensate producers for the measures they have had to put in place to try to eradicate this bacterium and for the loss of income generated, including losses from tourism activities.  We also stressed the need to act quickly and to implement all available means at European level to contain the epidemic which mainly affects agricultural crops in southern Europe, particularly in France.  Finally, this resolution calls on the European Commission to promote increased research, including enhanced international collaboration, including by making more funds available to research institutes, to improve our scientific knowledge of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa and thus to combat its devastating effects on plant and animal health more effectively.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution relates to the spread of Xylella fastidiosa, which infects olive trees. It is a bacterium from Central America that is currently rampant in southern Italy. This text increases import controls and, in particular, allows for a temporary ban on imports of plant products from contaminated areas, in order to avoid contagion to other EU countries, as it is currently very difficult to combat it. I therefore voted in favour of the measures envisaged by this text.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted for it. The bacterium Xylella fastidiosa wreaks havoc on olive plantations in the Puglia region of Italy. It is a bacterium that was imported from Central America. Given the seriousness of the economic situation in the Puglia region caused by this bacterium, it is indeed urgent to make decisions.  It seems difficult to control the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa in a scientific way. The removal of infected plants was decided with the use of pesticides, which is always tricky. But it is essential to prevent the spread of the disease. The focus of this is the limitation and increase in imports. This motion for a resolution, even if it does not give enough room for the possibilities of action by States, has the merit of calling for the limitation of plant imports and increased controls on what enters the territory of the Member States of the European Union. Having said that, the Commission should also consider the possibilities of supporting the genetic diversity of plants, such as animals, which could be a guarantee of safety against epidemics.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the problem of olive trees does not concern the Czech Republic, whose citizens I represent, I have let my colleagues decide on the matter.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Xylella fastidiosa pathogenic bacteria is extremely dangerous for olives. We should also pay attention to the fact that the bacteria attacks the vines and citrus fruits. The bacteria was imported from third countries, namely Central and South America, and the consequences of its action are most felt by olive growers in the south of Italy.  In the Republic of Croatia, all three species are of great importance for the agriculture sector. Olive groves and vineyards in 2013 occupied an area of more than 45 thousand hectares and annually produced 50 thousand hectolitres of olive oil and more than 1200 thousand hectolitres of wine. I support a resolution calling on the Commission to engage and react more swiftly to stop the further spread of the bacteria, otherwise we will feel the effects in the economy, the environment and society.  According to an estimate by the European Food Safety Agency, as many as eleven million trees are at direct risk of falling in the south of Italy, while the whole of Croatia has six million trees. Given that since 2013, when Italy reported the infection, no adequate solution has been found, we should take this situation as an example that the problem should not be solved when it arises but prevent it, so we need a strong preventive system. Prevention should also include raising awareness of the consequences that are catastrophic today, as infected olive trees will no longer be able to be used.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, which attacks olive trees, poses a serious threat to the southern territories of the European Union. It has effects on the rapid decline in the production of olive trees and causes them to be eumitage. The use of pesticides appears to be low-effective, and it also has other negative effects. It is necessary for the Commission, in cooperation with the eu institutions and Member States, to review the measures taken so far without delay and to present procedures to prevent the further spread of this bacterium.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ The EU model of agriculture is increasingly based on unhealthy agricultural systems which are not resilient, with very limited attention to biodiversity and crop rotation in the case of non-perma-crop monocultures, a lack of beneficial organisms, and biodiversity declining in general, thus making it relatively easy for exotic plants and animals to establish themselves; resistance to pesticides used as insecticides is accelerated by the excessive and uncontrolled use of these products, thereby jeopardising any phytosanitary successes achieved.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Xylella fastidiosa is a bacterium accidentally imported from Central America that is currently destroying olive trees in the Puglia region of Italy. Few measures seem possible to prevent the spread: grubbing is unacceptable and pesticide treatment is frowned on. The temporary solution adopted by France is to limit imports of products from infected areas. This motion for a resolution proposes, at European level, a limit on imports and the establishment of protection of European territory, which we support. So I voted for it.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the understanding that it is essential for the Commission to consider açlternativas solutions to the eradication programme, taking into account the risks of desertification and destruction of agricultural heritage, which preserve the agri-food sector and the environment of the Apulia region.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. U2012 The 'Xylella fastidiosa' has become a real threat to the olive grove in some parts of southern Europe and we have to put the necessary measures so that this bacterium does not spread to other territories and other crops. I therefore support the resolution calling on the Commission to take all necessary measures to prevent this bacterium from being further spread, as well as to try to ensure that there are more stringent controls on the ins and outs of third-country plants, so that in the future these pests which are so harmful to our agriculture will not be reintroduced.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The mass infestation of olive trees with Xylella fastidiosa not only threatens the destruction of agricultural heritage, but also that around 8000 people will lose their jobs in the affected regions. The affected areas in Italy must be 'cleansed' in order to prevent the spread of the bacterium in Europe, especially in view of the fact that large areas have already been destroyed in California and Costa Rica as a result of the spread of this bacterium. I also believe that the call for research into the bacterium strain and the creation of additional, less environmentally friendly measures is useful. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Xylella fastidiosa arrived in Europe from a major infectious outbreak in California in 2013. Today widespread in southern Italy, it poses an immediate threat very dangerous to many crops in southern Europe: olive trees, almond trees, peaches and plants. It is also a potential threat to vines and citrus fruits. To limit contamination the resolution proposes import restrictions from the bacteria's outbreaks. But it leaves the Commission to draw up "detailed guidelines for the implementation of disease prevention and control measures, clearly specifying their scope and duration, to which the competent authorities and services of the Member States can refer". As the European Commission is totally under pressure from lobbies and especially from plant protection products, its solution will surely be full of pesticides. On the contrary, it is a model of peasant agriculture, reduced exploitation and polyculture that will fight these bacteria by strengthening the resilience of plants. I vote against this text

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution on the spread of Xylella fastidiosa is one of the important texts that need to be voted on, implemented and supported to ensure their effectiveness. While it is difficult to effectively control this bacterium, the motion for a resolution stresses that grubbing seems to be an adequate solution. Targeted pesticides are to date too serious a source of concern. On the other hand, it is important to point out here that a policy of protectionism, limiting the importation of products from regions affected by Xylella, makes perfect sense. However, the European Union prefers to condemn The Member States that choose this route, accusing them of not respecting the rules of free trade. For all these reasons, I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The bacterium Xylella fastidiosa is a bacterium that infects more than 300 plant species (including olive, almond, vines and citrus fruits) whose treatment is not always effective, since it lodges inside the tree, making it difficult to fight, and which is transmitted mainly through contaminated plants. A plague has arisen in the Apulia region of Italy, and more than half a million olive trees have already been infected. This is not a problem of Italy, Portugal or Spain. Unfortunately, and as the January report by the European Food Safety Authority shows, it is a European problem that has all the conditions to get worse. It is very likely that the disease will spread to other countries of the European Union. Portugal is, as we know, the fourth largest producer of olive oil in the world. That is why, and as an effective member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, this is a very concern to me. Hence my sense of vote.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this joint motion for a resolution as it urges the Commission to also implement strong measures to prevent Xylella fastidiosa from entering the EU from third countries. The resolution also stresses the need for greater screening and scanning methods to be utilised to detect harmful organisms at points of entry into the Union.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The pathogen Xylella fastidiosa, also called olive tree plague, has taken on serious proportions. This plant disease causes a very heavy economic loss for the entire production chain of the olive industry in Italy. More than 1 million trees have been affected since the disease was first deformed in Italy in 2013. It is feared that this bacterial infection, transmitted by insects, now threatens more than 11 million olive trees and that by extension several Southern crops are at risk of contamination.  For the time being, Xylella fastidiosa itself is not yet combatable and the main focus must be on combating further spread in the EU. To this end, it is recommended to take drastic plant health measures. For example, specific controls on the import of plants that may be carriers of this disease should be streamlined and stepped up, and it is recommended to transport only plants from production zones that are bacteria-free.  It is also necessary to carefully monitor the use of pesticides in the fight against crickets, the main spreader. In any case, the Commission must intensify scientific research into efficient and sustainable pesticides and the Commission and the Member States must take the best approach to a rapid economic and landscape recovery of the affected regions.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I welcomed the Resolution on measures to prevent the spread of the Xylella fastidiosa bacterium damaging olive trees. The Resolution is calling for EU import restrictions on plants from affected areas in third countries, agrees that growers be compensated for their losses, and suggests stepping up funding for research to combat the bacterium, which may attack other plants.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Food Safety Authority, in a recent scientific opinion on the risk assessment posed by Xylella fastidiosa, demonstrated that "the intensive use of insecticide treatments to limit the transmission of the disease and control the insect vector can have direct and indirect repercussions on the environment by altering entire trophic networks, with chain consequences, thereby affecting different trophic levels".  Nevertheless, in this case, the agri-food sector in Puglia is one of the most important industries in the region and trade unions estimate the number of oil sector workers at risk of losing their jobs at 8,000.  I am voting in favour of this resolution by asising the Commission for a cost-benefit analysis of the eradication strategy, the call for consideration to be given to the application of alternative measures, depending on the extent of the spread of the bacterium, the affected plants and the strain of the bacterium, and by urging the Commission to limit the large-scale use of pesticides and to implement Directive 2009/128/EC establishing a framework for action at Community level for the sustainable use of pesticides.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution relates to the spread of Xylella fastidiosa, which infects olive trees. It is a bacterium from Central America that is currently rampant in southern Italy. This text increases import controls and, in particular, allows for a temporary ban on imports of plant products from contaminated areas, in order to avoid contagion to other EU countries as it is currently very difficult to combat it. I therefore voted in favour of the measures envisaged by this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa demonstrates the inadequacies of the EU phytosanitary control system, combined in this case, as it seems, with the weak response from the Italian authorities. Nevertheless, since the outbreak is highly contagious and might pose a threat to other species of plants across Europe, a sign of solidarity and swift action is clearly needed.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of the phytosanitary emergency that has been affecting olive groves in southern Italy for some months, but which could potentially expand to other crops and regions of Europe, we intend to urge the Council and the Commission to resume the debate on the review of the system of official plant health controls on EU imports in order to protect and safeguard European territory, while avoiding a negative impact on global trade.  We believe it is necessary not only to provide adequate compensation for producers for the economic losses they have suffered, but also to step up research efforts by promoting greater cooperation at international level and by making funding available to all national research institutes. It is necessary, in fact, to deepen scientific knowledge about Xylella fastidiosa and to identify with certainty the pathogens and vectors that cause the spread of the disease, potentially dangerous for all European crops and areas.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the application because the bacterial infestation is seriously endangering the stock of olive trees in Italy. In California and Costa Rica, massive damage has already been caused by the bacterium. The motion to be voted on therefore deals not only with the fight against the bacterium, but also with research, and to contribute to the protection of the workplace as well as to the environment.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. Xylella fastidiosa is a particularly dangerous bacterium that attacks olive trees and trees in general. It is highly contagious and there is currently no effective means of control. The joint resolution calls on the Commission to take strong action against the epidemic, aimed at limiting its contagion in the EU, such as stopping the importation of trees from the affected areas. Parliament is asking for compensation for the affected producers and is proposing additional funding to the affected areas for a rapid recovery. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution. The outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa has already damaged large areas of Italy, is highly contagious to different plants and, in this context, capable of causing major economic, environmental and also social damage. It is therefore necessary to develop a strategy to combat infection, including preventive measures and effective control of imported plants.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. Although the European Commission has tried to contain the Xylella outbreak affecting olive trees, the disease continues to spread, wreaking havoc in southern Italy and increasing fears in countries where this sector is key. Through this resolution, we call, inter alia, for the sector to be compensated for losses and to restrict imports of plants from affected areas of third countries. We regret that, once again, the Commission is late in implementing preventive measures (it has already occurred with the black spot from South Africa that mainly affected Spain) and that it does not have determination when reviewing legislation on phytosanitary controls. In all this, we hope that the Commission will take into account what we have approved in this parliament.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. The outbreak of the xylella Fastidiosa bacterium, which is damaging olive trees, poses a huge threat to an important sector of European agriculture.  Action is needed at EU level to prevent the spread of this bacterium, as the scale of the epidemic is very large. In particular, measures should be put in place to prevent the spread of the disease to the EU from third countries. The precautionary principle should be used to respond to this outbreak. In order to protect the EU's territory from the Xylella fastidiosa, the Commission should carry out a cost-benefit analysis of the eradication strategy in the short and long term.  I believe that demarcated areas should be established. In addition, it is essential that the use of pesticides is restricted to a large extent, as it poses a risk to human and animal health and the environment.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As a southerner and politician from a territory dramatically affected by the problem, I can only vote in favour of the work done by my colleagues on the issue of Xylella fastidiosa, which represents an immediate and highly dangerous threat. The problem cannot and must not be foreseen in the production of certain crops in southern Europe, including olive, mandoland and peach (as well as ornamental plants), but it must be seen as a threat that could lead to devastating and unprecedented losses, with huge economic, environmental and social consequences for thousands of European citizens.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Xylella fastidiosa has been imported from Central America and is currently destroying olive trees in the Puglia region of Italy. There is, of course, a risk of spread. Action must be taken at European level. Fighting its devastation is scientifically difficult; the solution chosen was grubbing up, which does not seem to be the most satisfactory. The use of targeted pesticide products is more effective but has concerns about their effects. The French government has pre-emptively decided to ban imports of plants from infected regions, which has provoked criticism, as France has been accused of not respecting the rules of free trade. Any proposal to limit imports and protect European territory and strengthen controls should therefore be supported. As the resolution proposes such measures, I vote for it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The bacterium Xylelle fastidiosa is an extremely dangerous bacterium that has already caused significant losses in the olive growing sector in southern Italy where a total of 11 million infected trees will be cut down. The presence of Xylelle fastidiose causes serious economic damage not only to olive producers, but to the entire production chain, tourism and marketing activities, as olive growing is much more than just an agricultural branch. It is the foundation of millennial cultures in the Mediterranean. Since the disease is transmitted by insects, olive groves and other Mediterranean countries are at risk. In parallel with the spread of the Xylelle fastidiose outbreak in the south of Italy, last year's olive yield was as much as 90% lower than the average due to the occurrence of olive leaf disease. Yield expectations this year are just as bad.  In a discussion on this topic at the plenary session in April, the Commission representative said that the Commission would find a way to help olive growers financially, through rural development programmes or Horizon 2020. Following the Commission's statement and the adoption of this European Parliament resolution, I hope the Commission will take concrete action. In order to prevent the spread of the Xylelle fastidiosa outbreak, the Commission has allocated additional resources to the malina sector across Europe, which was severely affected by the epidemic of the aforementioned bacteria last year, but also by other diseases such as olive milk and peacock eye.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a resolution on the Xylella fastidiosa outbreak that attacks olives because the epidemic has already caused unprecedented consequences in southern Europe, especially in southern Italy with dramatic economic, social and environmental consequences. By a worrying fact, I find fastidiosa to have a wide range of hosts, including many species in the EU such as olive, lemon, vine, almond, peaches, plums and many others. Due to the great difficulties of stopping the spread of the epidemic, the EU must take all necessary measures to prevent its spread to other Member States as soon as possible. I welcome the EU measures that require Member States to notify if there is an epidemic and that stopping the spread of infection must be by eradicating plants immediately in place and within a 100m radius, regardless of the health status of the plant.  In my view, the implementation of strict measures focusing on imports in particular from epidemic-infected countries and third world countries must be a priority, as preventing the movement of infected plants and insects can only help prevent pests from spreading to other EU countries and territories. Due to its geographical location and connection with Italy, there is also a danger for Croatia, to which this epidemic would bring irreparable damage especially from data showing that there are between 2.5 - 3.5 million trees in Croatia.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution that we approved by a large majority in plenary on Xyella fastidiosa is extremely important given the catastrophic situation that the bacterium is creating in Puglia and especially in Salento. The Commission will have to take account of what is indicated in the resolution, especially when it comes to the eradication of olive trees already infected and healthy ones, but only if within a hundred metres of new outbreaks. It was also very important that the resolution called for compensation for farmers suffering from the epidemic, who are currently in a very difficult economic and financial situation. It is necessary, as indicated, to push for studies and scientific research on the contrast of the most incisive bacterium; we could also think of specific funds for this emergency, given the seriousness of the situation. Greater border control is also a necessary measure, through more restrictive import measures to protect our crops.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Since 2013, the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa has ravaged olive trees in southern Italy and is threatening to spread to the Mediterranean. This bacterium poses a major risk to the European territory. It is therefore essential to implement emergency measures at European level to curb this phenomenon.  MePs have adopted a joint motion for a resolution on the UNION's measures. I voted in favour of this text and I stress the urgency of the situation. But we need to go further. I particularly stress the need to strengthen prevention and decontamination measures and to amend the plant disease regulation to strengthen border controls for imported products.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Xylella fastidiosa, a barbaric name for a bacterium recently discovered in southern Italy, in the province of Lecce, and which has already caused considerable damage to olive groves in this region. The European Parliament has taken this threat very seriously by adopting a resolution this afternoon on this pathogen which worries the authorities and the agricultural world. The latter follows the decision taken on 28 April by experts from the 28 countries of the European Union to strengthen preventive measures and in particular to ban the import of coffee trees from Honduras and Costa Rica, since three coffee plants were analysed as contaminated with Xylella on 15 April. Noting that Xylella fastidiosa poses an immediate and very dangerous threat to the production of other crops, such as almond, peach and ornamental plants, MEPs call on the Commission to cooperate in the best possible way with the Member States concerned, drawing on the expertise of the European Food Safety Authority. EFSA has already expressed in a communication the importance of targeting imports of host plants in order to prevent 2015 from being the year of the spread of this bacterium in Europe.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the spread of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa. This bacterium poses a serious threat to the production of certain crops in southern Europe such as olive trees, almond trees but also vines or citrus fruits. This has serious environmental, social and economic consequences with losses in agricultural production as well as on heritage or cultural activities. We must take effective measures to prevent the spread of this bacterium but also to help producers. Targeting the most exposed crops, compensating producers, using available funds to contribute to economic recovery in affected areas, or implementing preventive measures. While spread is difficult to contain once an area is infested, prevention and awareness are essential in areas of the EU that may be affected. We wish to be continuously informed by the European Commission of any developments in the situation in order to remain attentive to the dangers of Xylella fastidiosa.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. This is a joint motion for a resolution on the outbreak of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, which mainly affects olive, almond, peach trees, vineyards and citrus orchards. The directives expressed in the proposal should be taken into account in order to prevent their spread, without, however, forgetting the economic recovery of the affected areas.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the Commission to take more effective measures to prevent the spread of annoying Xylella in the EU. Xylella fastidiosa is a bacterium with enormous pathogenic potential over a large number of plants that can cause serious losses in European agriculture and the agri-food chain. Its emergence in Italy, with 9 million olive trees affected - apparently due to contagion from an infected ornamental plant that entered Rotterdam - highlights the malfunction of the EU's phytosanitary protection against imports from third countries and the Commission's slowness to react to a problem that, if not tackled in time , can be devastating for olive trees in southern Europe and whose spread also threatens citrus fruits and the vineyard. It is therefore necessary to review the official EU phytosanitary system applicable to imports, to introduce a preventive system for import controls, to implement the mandatory establishment of the phytosanitary passport of olive trees and to use as many funds and instruments as possible to contribute to the economic recovery of the affected areas.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted a resolution calling for further measures to prevent the spread of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, which infects olive trees in Puglia, Italy. It should be noted that Xylella fastidiosa poses an immediate and very dangerous threat to the production of certain crops in southern Europe, including olive, almond and peach trees, as well as vines and citrus fruits. The bacteria could also lead to unprecedented colossal losses and serious economic, environmental and social consequences. Parliament has therefore called on the Commission to take targeted measures to prevent the spread of Xylella fastidiosa in the EU. It was asked to compensate producers as a result of eradication measures and loss of income, and to use all possible funds and instruments to contribute to the economic recovery of the affected areas. Parliament has also called for the release of more important resources to ensure the detection of pests at points of entry into the Union. Finally, Parliament called for the creation of a public database to exchange information and develop detailed guidelines for the implementation of disease prevention and control measures.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. Xylella bacteria are responsible for the current epidemic, which particularly affects olive trees in southern Europe. In order to combat this epidemic, it is necessary to strengthen product controls at the Union's borders, because without it, we risk having to cut down contaminated plants and jeopardise European farmers. In parallel with these actions, it is necessary to strengthen research funding in order to find solutions as soon as possible to eradicate the bacterium and preserve the crops in place. More than 300,000 plant species are currently threatened, hence the urgency and need to act as soon as possible; it is in this sense that I supported this resolution.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Xylella fastidiosa epidemic affecting olive trees. It is time for Europe to take action to solve a problem that has seriously damaged a crop and a derivative product that has made us famous all over the world.  The bacterium in question, which arrived in Italy with the import of ornamental coffee plants from Central America, affected the expanses of olive groves of which Puglia is rich, forcing growers to eradicate and burn plants because they are infected and dangerous even for fauna. I agree that the Commission can increase import controls, compensate for damage and allocate adequate resources, for example under the Horizon 2020 programme, to carry out research and analysis on Xylella fastidiosa and its carriers and to identify remedies.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution as we consider that the measures being taken are not only insufficient, but also undermine the future of the olive grove agricultural sector. The escalation in the focus of infection is a reality that can be seen in the face of this alarming situation, the proposal made since the committee is eradication as an urgent solution. It is unworkable for us to raise such a scenario as the only way to curb mass contagion. These measures do not reflect the compensation for losses or the age of the olive trees, as well as the particularities involved in the production of each of them.  This decision does not at any time deny the possibility of reclassifying agricultural land for uses other than that of origin in the face of the removal of infested shrubs. Nor is emphasis placed on the importance of land sustainability and the protection of the sectors living on it.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution because it does not reflect the real damage that massive tree felling can cause to the inhabitants of Italy's Puglia Region. There is no guarantee that approved chemical treatments will eradicate this serious disease, while it will bring serious costs to farmers and does not stop imports from infected regions. Our parliamentary group on the European Left has proposed an alternative resolution with the Green Group and italy's Five Star Movement, which pointed to the environmental risks of the proposed treatments and the need to help affected farmers. In view of the significant risks this disease may pose to our country, we do not believe that this resolution proposes appropriate international import control measures to prevent spread and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The epidemic of Xylella fastidiosa that is spreading in southern Italy has caused serious damage to the agricultural sector, in particular to the olive groves of Puglia. In these circumstances, greater coordination and synergy between the emergency measures ordered by the Union and national and regional interventions is desirable in order to prevent, control and eradicate the bacterium. It is important that the means put in place to combat the pathogen are proportionate to the objectives, so as to preserve the territory and the environment as much as possible. I also hope that due consideration will be given to the sacrifices made by farmers by preparing appropriate and appropriate forms of compensation.  I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this resolution in the hope that it will contribute to a better understanding and solution of the problem at European level.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 We live in a globalized market context, where our borders are more open, but in which permeability is obviously controlled. This control comprises a type of inspection which must be guided by reciprocity in relation to the practices of our trading partners and the risk associated with the origin of the products. Diseases of animals and plants can have devastating economic and environmental effects and the risk of dissemination is, in this context, high. Border surveillance must be carried out effectively, but this effectiveness is hardly absolute. It is a competence which, by its nature, is up to the european union to implement, naturally relying on the capacities of the Member States. In the event of an outbreak of animal and plant diseases, all means are required to contain the spread and, for this, European solidarity is required.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission should ensure that sufficient financial and human resources are available to implement the relevant strategies, including financial support for farmers to apply appropriate agricultural practices for the management of Xylella fastidiosa and its vectors. This resolution urges the Commission to promote intensified research efforts without delay, with a view to increasing scientific knowledge of Xylella fastidiosa and positively identifying the nature of the link between the pathogen, the symptoms and the development of disease.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I believe that the epidemic of Xylella fastidiosa bacteria attacking olive trees poses a great danger and that it is necessary to react quickly to the appropriate bodies in suppressing it. The bacteria has emerged in the Puglia region of southern Italy and has taken on unprecedented serious proportions with dramatic economic, environmental and social consequences as a potential threat to plantations in other regions. The eradication method proposed by the Commission to prevent the spread of the infection should be proportionate to the level of disasters with a view to promoting good agronomic management and plant health, including in selecting the most appropriate method of monitoring the gear. A balanced and biologically diverse agronomic ecosystem that is more resistant to invasive pests is one way to prevent susceptibility to plant diseases and the spread of these diseases. I also express my extreme concern in the context of the Republic of Croatia, which is located in the immediate vicinity of the infected area.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In 2013, olive decay occurred in southern Italy, in Puglia. The rapid spread and devastating effects of Xylella fastidos are of great concern. The bacterium causes damage to various plants, and olive trees are at the most at risk in Europe at this time. In 2013, 8,000 hectares of plantations were infected, and in 2014 the infected area increased further. This phenomenon poses a major threat to olive groves and olive growers in Europe, and action must therefore be taken and the disease spread as quickly as possible.  The total cut of olive groves and the use of toxins on huge surfaces are certainly not acceptable and are ecologically inappropriate. In addition, it is likely that the felling will not eradicate the disease and, after the destruction of the first million olive trees, a new million infected will be found. Other measures should be considered, such as the treatment of olive trees by injecting a 'medicine' against xylella fastidiosa. The problem is very serious if we do not address it in a thoughtful and fast way. I do not agree with the measures proposed in the resolution, and even as a member of the Greens, I am in favour of environmentally friendly gripes that will not place an additional burden on nature and vegetation. I therefore voted against that resolution.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the epidemic caused by the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, which is decimating olive trees in large areas of the Puglia region and threatens to spread to other areas.  In the text we call on the European Commission to take two urgent measures: to compensate rapidly producers who have suffered losses as a result of the eradication of olive trees carried out to stem the infection of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa beyond italy's borders; stepping up efforts in research and prevention, allocating more funding and international collaboration.  The text also supports the EU's decision to restrict imports of plants from affected areas of third countries, in particular imports of coffee plants from Costa Rica and Honduras; However, in order to prevent such epidemics from spreading further within the Territory of the Union, it is also necessary to review the EU plant health control system, introducing, if necessary, further restrictions on imports.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Xylella fastidiosa is a dangerous bacteria that can cause major losses in agriculture. Prompted by cases in Brazil and California, it is necessary to react quickly and prevent further spread of the infection that can affect many agricultural crops such as olive trees, almonds, peaches, and ornamental plants. It is also a potential threat to other cultures such as vines and citrus fruits. I support this motion for a resolution, as in addition to the rapid reaction to prevent further infection of Xylellaom fastidiosaom, activities aimed at preventing new infections with other types of bacteria and diseases, such as research and greater control of imports of infected goods into the European Union, are also needed.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution on the outbreak of outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa affecting olive trees. This outbreak is highly contagious and could pose a serious threat to other species of plants across the European Member States, therefore swift action is needed.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒By voting, I supported the proposal for a resolution on the Xylella fastidiosa outbreak that attacks olive trees. Xylella is a very dangerous imminent threat to the production of individual crops in southern Europe, including olive, almond, peach and ornamental plant trees and a potential threat to other crops, such as vineyards and citrus trees, and can lead to unsuspected and devastating losses, with dramatic economic, environmental and social consequences. The bacteria is already causing severe damage to olive groves in the Puglia region of southern Italy, potentially threatening other crops and regions. Xylella has already ravaged, destroyed and ruined large areas of production in third countries, such as vineyards in California and citrus groves in Brazil. I welcome the decision taken by the European Commission in April 2015 to stop imports of infected coffee seedlings from Costa Rica and Honduras. Enhanced research efforts should be promoted without delay, including the labelling of funds available for research institutes, to improve our scientific knowledge of Xylella and positively identify pathogens - the cause of olive death. The European Commission and the Member States should compensate producers for eradication measures and loss of revenues – including loss not only in the form of agricultural production, but also in the form of cultural heritage, history and tourism-related activities.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ because I agree with the measures to combat Xylella fastidiosa. In view of the possible spread of the disease within the EU, this is a problem that really affects the whole of the European Union and therefore a problem that is within the competence of the EU.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the outbreak of Xyella fastidiosa, which attacks olive trees, as it represents the adoption of measures to combat the severe consequences of the bacterium. In Slovenia, in Slovenian Istria, to a lesser extent in the area of Goriška brd, olivery has a very long tradition. In Slovenia there are about 1,900 hectares of olive trees. While slovenian olive oil production is negligible compared to other Member States, olive oil productions are of high quality. I supported this resolution, which draws attention to the catastrophic situation faced by olive growers. I also support the development of appropriate guidelines for measures to combat the spread of this disease.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 There are solutions to fight the disease without consequences for the environment.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa infection in olive trees, as it calls for a solution to an extremely dangerous infection that poses a direct threat. I think it is important to note that in addition to the olive trees in the title, the pathogen also poses a danger to almond and peach trees and ornamental plants. The motion draws attention to the potential threat to grapes, citrus fruits and other crops, depending on the type of bacteria, and can cause unprecedented and devastating damage with dramatic economic, environmental and social consequences. This means that this is not only dangerous for production regions in southern Europe.  I agree that such an infection causes serious economic damage, not only to producers, but also to the entire production chain (including cooperative and privately owned plants), tourism and distributors. One of the elements of resolving the threat is to prevent imports of contaminated products into the Union through targeted measures and, if necessary, by introducing more stringent measures. I trust that the EU will find a solution to stop the infection, but I believe that we need to respond more quickly to this type of infection. In this connection, I agree with the proposal in the motion to review the implementation of the EU's official phytary control system.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The joint resolution was too weak, and in my opinion more harmful than useful to Mediterranean biodiversity. The problem is certainly not in the quantity or quality of pesticides that will be used to break down the pathogen, not least because it is not yet scientifically clear whether the disease developed for the reasons that led to the first eradications. On the agent that causes the rapid drying of olive trees, further studies are needed and there is a well-founded suspicion that at the origin of the epidemic there is instead the neglect with which olive trees are kept. The common agricultural policy penalises small producers, and this is a fact: hence the lack of care for olive groves, the weakening of plants and the easy success of pathogens.  The resolution presented by the 5 Star Movement was intended to highlight the risks of desertification and destruction of the agricultural heritage that the current eradication programme brings with it. It would have been much more useful, at least to ask the Italian and European authorities some doubts, at least in order to ask the right questions. Once again, long live Europe.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The EU must take strong, targeted and effective measures to prevent the spread of Xylella fastidiosa bacteria beyond Italy, where it severely damages olive trees, according to a resolution adopted by Parliament on Wednesday. MEPs welcome EU restrictions on the importation of plants from affected areas in third countries and demand that producers be compensated for their losses.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution calling for further measures to prevent the spread of the Xylella fastidiosa bacterium destroying olive trees in Italy. Xylella fastidiosa is a dangerous threat to the production of certain crops and urgent measures are needed. Indeed it is urgent to take initiatives to avoid the spread of Xylella fastidiosa within the EU, in particular by targeting the crops most at risk, while not neglecting other crops that could also be seriously affected by the disease. We should also bring support to the producers affected by this bacterium.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Xylella fastidiosa is a bacterium that threatens agricultural production in Europe. It has recently entered Italy, and endangers more than 150 species of plants. It already has dramatic consequences in Puglia where millions of olive trees have been torn off, with no guarantee of avoiding the epidemic.  In the face of this danger, we have formed a majority of MEPs to urge the Commission to take the necessary measures to stop the spread of the bacteria. Thus, the current system of import control of plants, which is very failing, will be revised to prevent the spread of diseases. This must result in the issuance of plant health passports, for example. I regret and am concerned, however, that some tightening of regulations, such as the quarantine of products that may have been infected with Xyllela fastidiosa, have not convinced a majority of MEPs. Finally, I hope that the European Commission will react quickly to our request to raise funds to help areas affected by this bacterium.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I supported the motion for a resolution because I believe that the emergence of Xylella fastidiosa, which attacks olive trees in Italy, poses a serious danger to European olive growers. Croatia as a neighbouring country and a country with a long and rich tradition of growing and processing olives is at great risk of the onset of this disease. Since there is no cure for this bacterium, it is necessary to take all possible preventive measures and measures to control imported products. This could stop its spread and rehoming in other areas, which could result in severe consequences such as reduced yields and major damages, which would eventually require even more costly control measures.  I therefore support the adoption of provisions that will help contain and possibly eradicate this disease. In order to combat this problem, it is necessary to provide olive growers with adequate compensation for the loss of trees, as well as additional resources and information in order to be able to deal with the occurrence of this disease in a fair way.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this resolution as we consider that the measures that are being taken are not only insufficient, but also undermine the future of the agricultural sector of olive groves. The escalation in the focus of infection is a reality that can be seen in the face of this alarming situation, the proposal made since the committee is eradication as an urgent solution. It is unworkable for us to raise such a scenario as the only way to curb mass contagion. These measures do not reflect the compensation for losses or the age of the olive trees, as well as the particularities involved in the production of each of them.  This decision does not at any time deny the possibility of reclassifying agricultural land for uses other than that of origin in the face of the removal of infested shrubs. Nor is emphasis placed on the importance of land sustainability and the protection of the sectors living on it.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ This is an important resolution as it tackles several issues affecting our agriculture sector. Making sure that imported food products do not bring any infections that may spread to Europe has relevance in safeguarding our own agriculture.  This is an important resolution for the olive tree sector, but it is also very important for the whole of the agriculture sector. It creates a precedent to encourage the Commission to be proactive and faster in tackling these situations. Hence, I welcome this resolution to mitigate the big problem of the outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa but I also welcome it because it raises awareness in the EU institutions that more needs to be done, and faster sometimes, to safeguard EU producers and consumers.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution as we consider that the measures being taken are not only insufficient, but also undermine the future of the olive grove agricultural sector. The escalation in the focus of infection is a reality that can be seen in the face of this alarming situation, the proposal made since the committee is eradication as an urgent solution. It is unworkable for us to raise such a scenario as the only way to curb mass contagion. These measures do not reflect the compensation for losses or the age of the olive trees, as well as the particularities involved in the production of each of them.  This decision does not at any time deny the possibility of reclassifying agricultural land for uses other than that of origin in the face of the removal of infested shrubs. Nor is emphasis placed on the importance of land sustainability and the protection of the sectors living on it.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution because it does not address the problem of the rapid spread and devastating effects of the Xylella annoying bacteria infestation. It is currently affecting Italy but poses a potential threat to all meditatives, especially smallholder farmers and olive and citrus growers. The European response should therefore live up to the task, as the massive use of pesticides, in addition to severely weakening biodiversity, leaves the areas where they have been used without any natural resistance to subsequent pests.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution concerning the ‘Outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa affecting olive trees’ in Southern Europe, as we should act immediately and secure the EU’s olive oil production but also the main source of income of thousands Southern Europeans. It is our mission to find solutions and take effective measures, so we should prevent the further spread of this bacterium. The European Parliament should safeguard not only EU olive oil and olive production but should also take all the necessary measures so that Xylella fastidiosa will not attack other plants. I believe that this resolution is extremely significant since Xyllela fastidiosa is an enemy of Europe’s agriculture, its tourism and therefore its economy and demands an immediate solution and action.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. The Xylella contagion is seriously endangering millions of olive trees and the economy of entire territories. The bacterium from Latin America is destroying, in fact, a heritage of centuries-old plants. The current large-scale eradication programme adopted by the Commission is worrying, given the potential risks of desertification and destruction of agricultural heritage accompanied by a lack of clear scientific evidence of the real effectiveness of the strategy adopted to prevent the spread of the pathogen. In this respect, I therefore believe it is essential to consider alternative solutions that also safeguard the agri-food sector and the environment of the regions concerned. It is also important to ensure concrete support for the farmers involved so that appropriate agricultural practices can be adopted to combat Xylella and its carriers, while also ensuring appropriate compensation for the sources of subsistence and income lost in the event of the eradication of olive trees and other plants potentially host the bacterium. For the above reasons, I have therefore supported motion for a resolution B8-0450/2015.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution because it does not reflect the real damage that massive tree felling can cause to the inhabitants of Italy's Puglia Region. There is no guarantee that approved chemical treatments will eradicate this serious disease, while it will bring serious costs to farmers and does not stop imports from infected regions. Our parliamentary group on the European Left has proposed an alternative resolution with the Green Group and italy's Five Star Movement, which pointed to the environmental risks of the proposed treatments and the need to help affected farmers. In view of the significant risks this disease may pose to our country, we do not believe that this resolution proposes appropriate international import control measures to prevent spread and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The cultivation of olive trees is a building block of culture and agriculture in the Mediterranean. The olive tree is part of the heritage, history and, of course, the economy of the entire Mediterranean, especially in the South of France and Corsica. The spread of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa is a danger that affects all of Europe.
