The European Union can act to promote coordination in the fight against this threat, but the measures taken to "strict eradication in infected areas" leads to the destruction of many host plants: olive trees but also citrus fruits, vines, plum trees, almond trees, tobacco, pink laurels, oaks, brambles... within a 100-metre radius of the contaminated plant. Moreover, the massive and unreasonable use of pesticides is a danger to biodiversity, human and animal health. Each proposed solution should be subject to a short- and long-term cost-benefit analysis. Monitoring and containment measures such as appropriate agricultural practices are better suited to preserve and protect territories and biodiversity and thus to provide a sustainable environmental response. So I voted against this resolution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution calls on the Commission to take measures not only to stop this outbreak, but also to protect the sector from future outbreaks through preventive measures. It calls for support from targeted farmers who see their crops destroyed and incentives for farmers to take effective action to prevent infection, and for those who have appropriate farming practices to deal with this problem. It also asks for funds from research institutes in order to increase the scientific knowledge of Xyllela fastidiosa, and to identify the nature of the link between pathogen, symptoms and the development of the disease. We welcome you.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The mass infestation of olive trees with Xylella fastidiosa not only threatens the destruction of agricultural heritage, but also that around 8000 people will lose their jobs in the affected regions. The affected areas in Italy must be 'cleansed' in order to prevent the spread of the bacterium in Europe, especially in view of the fact that large areas have already been destroyed in California and Costa Rica as a result of the spread of this bacterium. I also believe that the call for research into the bacterium strain and the creation of additional, less environmentally friendly measures is useful. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that we need a commitment from the European Union to support farmers who are facing the Xylella epidemic. The Commission will have to put in place prevention and control instruments but, at the same time, help those who, as a result of this disease, are at great risk in economic and social terms.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I and my group voted in favour of the resolution on the infestation of olive trees in Italy by a bacterium. Olive trees in Italy are attacked by the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa. The presence of the bacterium in Italy was first discovered in 2013. Since then, it has been spread by insects in the Puglia region. Recently, the presence of the bacterium has also been established in the province of Lecce. At the end of April, the Commission proposed measures for strict control and containment in Italy. Experts from EU Member States agreed that stronger measures are needed to prevent further spread. A risk-based approach has been agreed on imports; the import of coffee plants from Honduras and Costa Rica has been stopped. The ECR Group wants to see the immediate introduction of mitigation and control measures. Free trade is a very high commodity, but it finds its limits when the import of the products causes injury to third parties.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. The infestation of olive trees by the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa has taken on epidemic proportions in the region of Apolylia, which poses serious risks to olive production in Southern Europe but also other crops such as almond trees, peaches and ornamental plants. In other manifestations, the bacterium is a danger to both vines and citrus fruits. This initiative lays down the conditions for measures to support producers and strengthen crop protection mechanisms.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Thousands of olive trees erased or cut and reduced to dead logs. This is the sad scenario that is expected in Salento, Puglia, where the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa has affected the cultivation of olive trees creating a real collective psychosis.  This resolution calls for more money to be allocated to research and areas affected by this bacterium and to increased border controls as well as compensation to all farmers damaged by the spread of the bacterium. The attempt was to stop imports of infected coffee plants from Honduras and Costa Rica and called for greater control at the borders and within the Member States themselves in order to prevent the spread of the bacterium, which affects not only olive trees, but also many other types of plants. In addition, the Commission has been invited to draw up comprehensive guidelines for the implementation of preventive and disease control measures, which can also be used as a support tool by the competent authorities and services of the Member States.  However, this text lacks a cost-benefit analysis of the strategies for eradicating the pathogen, which could only eradicate healthy trees because they are potentially hosts regardless of any controls.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the outbreak of the Xylella fastidiosa epidemic. The resolution calls on the Commission to take targeted measures against the spread of Xylella, in order, among others, to prevent the importation of infected material into the EU. I think it is particularly appropriate to call on the Commission to apply stricter measures, such as the authorisation of imports from production sites alone that are not affected by the epidemic. I will conclude by renewing my call on the Commission to review the implementation of the European plant health control system in order to protect and safeguard our territory from the epidemic.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2013, it was first reported by the Italian authorities of the occurrence of the infection by the bacterium Xyllela fastidiosa, which infected the entire province of Apulia in southern Italy. In the audit carried out on the region, the audit committee found that, at the time of the audit, no action had been taken by the Italian authorities to stop infection and contamination in the region, and there were already several affected areas. It is a bacterial infection that affects, in Europe, mainly olive trees, and can infect several other fruit trees. In February 2014, emergency measures were adopted that were detailed in July of the same year. Concrete measures are proposed to stop this outbreak, such as a ban on imports of plants without a plant health certificate excluding xyllela fastidiosa infection, the prohibition of the movement of plants for planting, with the exception of seeds and plants in the list of annexes to the Directive. Other recommendations concern the suspension of passport stake of host plants, the immediate destruction of the entire infected plant, the mandatory disposal and cleaning of surrounding herbs and the mandatory treatment with insecticides from nurseries to control the vectors of the infection. We voted for it.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the 2014 Progress Report on Turkey (2014/2953 (RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank Parliament for giving me the opportunity to address you on the important issue of EU-Turkey relations.  Let me begin by emphasising that Turkey is very significant partner for the EU. Its dynamic economy provides a valuable contribution to the prosperity of the European continent. I would like to underline, in this regard, the important regional role of Turkey and its active involvement in its wider neighbourhood. The European Union has repeatedly re-affirmed the importance it attaches to our relations. Two days ago the EU-Turkey Association Council held its 53rd meeting in Brussels. It was a valuable meeting for relations between the EU and Turkey, despite diverging positions on certain issues. I want to start today with positive developments in our relations.  There have been a number of important positive signals in our relations over the last year. First, we welcome the dialogue and cooperation on foreign policy issues, in particular, active counterterrorism dialogue between the EU and Turkey and exchange of best practices on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment to terrorism. The attacks in Paris, Belgium and Denmark prove how important such steps are. We should develop closer cooperation against ISIL/Da’esh and its funding networks, and enhance our efforts to stem the flow of foreign fighters.  Secondly, we acknowledge the important regional role Turkey plays. Here I would like to praise the considerable efforts made by Turkey in hosting around two million refugees fleeing the violence in Syria and Iraq. The EU will continue to support Turkey so it can deal effectively with the increasing flow of refugees, including through financial assistance.  Thirdly, we have seen the ratification of the EU readmission agreement and the ongoing dialogue on visa liberalisation. In this regard, we expect a full and effective implementation of the agreement by Turkey in respect of all EU Member States. This applies equally to the visa roadmap.   Now let me turn to the accession negotiations with Turkey. Further progress in the accession negotiations requires political will and courage and is in the interests of us all. In this context, we welcome the strong commitment to EU accession displayed by the Turkish Government in its EU strategy and look forward to its concrete follow-up. Progress under Chapter 17 on economic and monetary policy would in due course further support economic dialogue between Turkey and the EU and encourage alignment with the aquis.  Mentioning Chapter 17 brings me to reiterate that active and credible accession negotiations, which respect the EU’s commitments and establish conditionality, will enable our relations to achieve their full potential. In line with the negotiating framework, the EU continues to encourage Turkey to develop its foreign policy, in coordination with the EU, and to progressively align with the EUʼs common foreign and security policy.  I would also like to remind you that Turkey needs to commit itself fully to good neighbourly relations and to the peaceful settlement of disputes, in line with the negotiating framework and previous European Council conclusions. I would recall that on 24 October 2014 the European Council expressed serious concern about the tension in the eastern Mediterranean. It urged Turkey to respect the sovereignty of Cyprus over its territorial sea and the sovereign rights of Cyprus in its exclusive economic zone.  Under those circumstances, the European Council considers it more important than ever to ensure a positive climate so that negotiations for a comprehensive Cyprus settlement can resume. Turkey’s commitment and contribution in concrete terms to such a comprehensive settlement is crucial and we certainly welcome the resumption of talks, which took place on 15 May 2015.  The opening of further negotiation chapters continues to deepen our fulfilment of the requirements of the negotiating framework and accession partnership. Turkey’s full and non-discriminatory implementation of the additional protocol to the Association Agreement in respect of all Member States could also provide a significant boost to the negotiation process.  Let me reiterate that the EU is determined to continue to help Turkey in its reform efforts with a view to advancing the negotiations as soon as the respective conditions are met. The pace of negotiations can be accelerated by Turkey advancing in the fulfilment of benchmarks, by meeting the requirements of the negotiation framework and by respecting its contractual obligations towards the EU.  This brings me to my next point, which concerns domestic developments in Turkey. The EU extends its strongest political support to the renewed efforts for a peaceful settlement of the Kurdish issue. We encourage further engagement by all parties to move the process forward.  Concerning the ongoing reforms, we welcome the continued implementation of reforms adopted in previous years and, in particular, measures announced in the democratisation package. We are, however, concerned about undue interference by the executive in the judiciary, frequent changes to key legislation without the due consultation of stakeholders, and restrictions on access to information.  The Council, in its conclusions of December 2014, addressed the issue of the rule of law and respect for human rights – including the rights of women, children and persons belonging to minorities – freedom of religion and property rights. Freedoms and reforms should also enhance the implementation of all the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights.  Last year we also expressed regret at the continued response by the Government to the alleged cases of corruption. These actions have cast serious doubts over the independence and impartiality of the judiciary and demonstrated an increasing intolerance of political opposition, public protest and critical media. The police raids and the detention of a number of journalists and media representatives in Turkey in December 2014, on which this House also issued a resolution expressing its concerns, call into question respect for media freedom, which is a core principle of democracy. Let me underline that legislation on the right of association and the right of assembly should be brought into line with European standards. In this regard, we emphasise the important role of the constitutional court and we note positively the growing engagement of civil society in Turkey. It should be further supported and encouraged as a legitimate stakeholder. We consider that stepping up cooperation with the EU and strengthening common activities in the area of the rule of law and fundamental rights will bring Turkey closer to the EU and speed up work on possible future discussions in these key areas.  To conclude, we firmly believe that the EU should remain the anchor of political and economic reforms in Turkey and we continue to encourage work on the implementation of reforms.  Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Kati Piri, for the tremendous work she has put into the resolution. The number of amendments is impressive and testifies to the great importance Parliament attaches to the EU’s relations with Turkey. Thank you all for a well-balanced and comprehensive end product.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am here today to deliver the following statement on behalf of Commissioner Hahn, who is responsible for neighbourhood policy but unfortunately could not be here today due to the Riga Summit. First, I would like to thank the rapporteur on Turkey, Mrs Kati Piri, for delivering a high-quality report and for her endless efforts in procuring compromises. The report is balanced and addresses the key elements of EU—Turkey relations both in terms of achievements and challenges.  In order to tackle the serious global and regional challenges that we share, we need to engage Turkey even more. The human tragedies in the Mediterranean, the threat posed by terrorist groups, the severe conflicts in our neighbourhood, the economy and climate change are all issues we cannot effectively face alone. Concerning migration and border management: as you know from the European Council meeting in April, there is more generally a pressing need to reinforce our cooperation with Turkey on managing these issues, including the fight against the smuggling of migrants. At a working dinner last Sunday, Frederica Mogherini, Johannes Hahn and Turkey’s ministers Çavuşoğlu and Bozkir agreed to work together to prepare a plan on reinforced cooperation. This also underlines the high level of importance we attach to the visa liberalisation dialogue.  The situation in Syria and Iraq has called for the reinforcement of our cooperation on foreign policy issues and counter-terrorism. Turkey has made remarkable efforts to host about 2 million Syrian and Iraqi refugees and deserves our full support in coping with this immense burden. Turning to the Cyprus issue, the Commission believes that the time has come for all involved to embrace the current opportunity to solve the problem. The Commission stands firmly behind the UN envoy Espen Eide in his efforts to get the communities in Cyprus to successfully continue the settlement talks. The Commission strongly encourages all the relevant stakeholders, including Turkey, to contribute to a positive climate. Turkey has marked a renewed commitment to the accession process, notably through a new EU strategy and corresponding action plans. It is in the interest of both the EU and Turkey that the EU remains the anchor for Turkey’s political and economic reforms. We are, in particular, determined to fully tap into the huge potential of our economic relations. The Commission is also actively working towards developing a high-level economic dialogue and making progress towards the opening of Chapter 17 on economic and monetary policy, for which technical preparations are underway. Last week, Commissioner Malmstrom and the Turkish Minister for the Economy, Zeybekçi, building on important preparatory work, have endorsed the process of enhancing and deepening EU-Turkey trade relations and of upgrading the customs union agreement to improve its structure and function. The Commission will now be launching internal procedures, including a comprehensive impact assessment, in order to seek negotiating directives from the Council. The Commission intends to keep the relevant committees of this Parliament regularly informed on this important process.  Regarding energy security: in March, Vice President Maroš Šefčovič launched a high-level energy dialogue and attended the start of works on the TANAP Trans-Anatolian Gas Pipeline which, once completed, will contribute to Europe’s energy security. Regarding developments in Turkey, we share most of the views and concerns raised in your report on the rule of law and the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms. These are key areas where Turkey needs to prove its commitment to the accession process. We hope to see Turkey re—engage in reforms, in line with European standards and values, and actively consult all stakeholders. Providing a clear roadmap for reforms and defining the opening benchmarks for Chapters 23 and 24 will be in the interest of both Turkey and the EU. The Commission is ready to help, including through pre-accession assistance. Our assistance is to be based on sector reform strategies and will be result-oriented with the aim of increasing its impact and visibility.  To conclude, the Commission has high expectations for our cooperation with Turkey. After the election, I hope to see the new government and parliament re-energise the EU agenda in Turkey. It will also be an excellent opportunity for Members of the European Parliament to engage with their Turkish counterparts in a constructive manner on both positive achievements and challenges.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, my thanks to the Council and Commission for their contributions to this debate. The EU and Turkey are important strategic partners and it is in the interests of both to have close and effective cooperation. We encourage Turkey to accelerate the pace of negotiations by clearly committing itself to respecting democratic values and principles. Parliament continues to support the EU accession process of Turkey as the cornerstone of our relations. However, in the report which will be voted on tomorrow we asked the Commission to reassess the way in which the negotiations with Turkey have been conducted so far, and how things can be further improved and intensified.  At a time when we ourselves are having intensive discussions in the EU – and indeed this morning in this Chamber – about how adequate protection can be given to refugees, we commend and praise all the efforts made by the Turkish Government in hosting more refugees than any other country in the world today. If we want to make sure that those in need of protection can find a safe haven in the region, we need to step up our efforts actively to assist Turkey in providing adequate shelter, healthcare and education for refugees and their children. Another area in which we strongly support and encourage efforts by the Turkish Government and all other stakeholders is the drive to achieve a comprehensive and sustainable conclusion to the peace process with the Kurdish community. But there is also clear concern in this Parliament about certain developments in Turkey. These are issues at the core of the negotiation process, such as the independence of the judiciary, freedom of expression and the freedom of the press. The pressure put on media outlets and journalists, which often results in the intimidation, dismissal or even arrest of journalists and widespread self-censorship, is of great concern to all of us. The recently adopted security package is, in our view, very wide in scope and bypasses the judiciary. Most investigations into the events that occurred in Gezi Park in May and June 2013 are still pending, and too little progress has been made in identifying the alleged perpetrators. We believe that the EU should remain a benchmark for reforms in the country. That means that we do not want to shut the door to Turkey, but we are calling for more dialogue and intensified engagement. The European Parliament report provides several proposals in areas where we believe it is of mutual benefit to increase cooperation. These are foreign and security policy, anti-terrorism, energy security and also, of course, specifically, the field of fundamental rights. Delivering the official opening benchmarks and a subsequent opening of Chapters 23 and 24, which has just been referred to by the Commission representative here, is the best way to promote truly effective reforms. We are ready to support Turkey in developing solid democratic institutions and effective legislation based on respect for human rights, the rule of law and defence of the interests of all sectors of Turkish society. Finally, Parliament also reiterates its strong support for the reunification of Cyprus on the basis of a fair, comprehensive and viable settlement for both communities there. We very much welcome the fact that the leaders of both communities have officially resumed negotiations under the auspices of the UN, and we believe that there is a unique window of opportunity now for a shared solution to the benefit of all Cypriots. We expect that Turkey and all relevant stakeholders will play a positive and constructive role in this delicate process. Let me mention here my gratitude and my thanks to all the shadow rapporteurs on the Turkey report, because if this had not been a joint exercise it would have been very difficult for me to stand here. I am happy that we have a united position on this here in Parliament.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, allow me to express my thanks to Parliament's rapporteur, Kati Piri: we have been negotiating with each other for many weeks and months. At the same time, I would like to thank the rapporteurs from the other groups. These were difficult talks that we had and we reached very good agreements – and everyone in this House knows how difficult this is on the subject of Turkey. So you really have to appreciate and acknowledge that. And something very special must also be acknowledged. This year we are in an anniversary year. October marks the tenth anniversary of the opening of accession negotiations with Turkey. But it was precisely with the start of these negotiations that the will to reform in this country faded, and now, on the contrary, there have been almost only regressions for years. Turkey is moving step by step further away from the European Union. It is not just a question of this country still not fulfilling the Copenhagen pre-accession criteria on any single point. We are talking about massive interference with fundamental rights and freedoms, and of course we are addressing this in our resolution. To trample democratic principles and the rule of law underfoot in this way is outrageous for a country that has been a candidate country for more than fifteen years. Nor has the policy towards the Republic of Cyprus changed. I do not have to go into this, enough other Members will do that. Dramatic developments, we hope for improvement. And in this situation, I really must say that I think it is wrong to call for the opening of new negotiating chapters. After all, that would also support the AK Party in the current election campaign. They would sell it as a reward for their anti-democratic policies. I am much more likely to think that we need a reassessment of the negotiation process. The Commission and the Council of Ministers should reflect on this in the same way as we did in our discussions in the run-up to this resolution. Yes, Turkey is important to us – as a trusting neighbour, as a trading partner with regard to security of energy supply and, of course, the fight against terrorism. And yes, Turkey is doing so much for the refugees it has taken in, and it deserves our recognition and support. Finally, allow me to say a final sentence: but no, Turkey has unfortunately not moved closer to the fundamental values of the European Union – the opposite is the case. And this is a sad situation. We in the European Parliament must make this clear, that is our task.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, it is some 50 years, I think, since Turkey first put forward its application to join the European Community. I must say I welcome the Commissioner’s undertaking to re-energise the relationship with Turkey but, in spite of lip service to Turkish accession, there is a fundamental dishonesty about whether or not Turkey will ever join the sort of EU that we have today. I have to say that many – not just in my own country but across Europe – would like to see a fundamentally different sort of European Union: a less tightly knit community of sovereign nations, with overlapping circles of engagement, an end to ever closer union, and a primary focus on making a success of the single market. I would suggest that this is the sort of European Union that would be far more hospitable to Turkey. The resolution reflects the ambivalence on the European Union side, recognising on the one hand the importance of Turkey’s position as a strategic partner, and particularly its significance in economic and energy relations, while on the other hand there is so much about Turkey itself which is subject to criticism. We cannot go on offering insults and expecting progress in return. Energy cooperation is a crucial issue. We should oppose the Turkish Stream project, which would bring Russian gas across the Black Sea to Turkey, and work towards the opening of Chapter 15 in order to encourage Turkey to continue to engage with the European Union instead. May I ask the Commission what other specific barriers there are to opening the energy chapter with Turkey? For many, the continued division of Cyprus is a useful obstacle to progress in relations with Turkey, and if the EU really wanted to do something useful it would devote much political effort to helping to resolve the Cyprus issue. Such a resolution would even be helpful in boosting economic and political confidence in Greece, may I add. Instead, the European Union continues to make lame, one-sided demands about, for example, the additional protocol, or fails to fulfil its own promises with regard to Northern Cyprus. The new president of Northern Cyprus, Mr Akıncı, has shown a great willingness to reach an accommodation. What more will the EU do to help? We need to make sure that Turkey continues to play its vital role as a strong ally in NATO and a partner of the European Union: part of the alliance confronting terrorism and instability in the Middle East and across the Black Sea, with a prosperous economy and anchored firmly in the democratic family of nations. We need to do more to help Turkey in this direction.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ten years ago, accession negotiations with Turkey began. On the recommendation of the Commission, this was decided by the Council. Even then, this decision was deeply dishonest and therefore unwise. There are a number of countries that do not remotely think of ever letting Turkey into the European Union. Our friends in Ankara know this, our friends in Istanbul know that, our friends in Turkey know that. When the Council says here at noon this afternoon that the European Union is still the anchor of political reforms in Turkey, I wonder: what planet are you actually living on? Turkey is reforming itself in the direction it wants to go, in the direction in which the democratically elected government wants to lead the country. Unfortunately, this is a direction that has little to do with the first Copenhagen criterion, the political criterion. We have heard it from you, Madam President-in-Office of the Council. Freedom of the press is in flagrant danger, the independence of the judiciary is not guaranteed, freedom of assembly is not guaranteed – these are essential criteria for a country's accession to the European Union. But that is precisely why we are asking for a reassessment of this whole process, and that is a constructive reassessment. No one in this House disputes that Turkey must be an important strategic ally of the European Union. There is so much good we could do with each other – in energy policy, in people-to-people contacts, in visa facilitation. There is so much – research, universities, culture. But everything is overshadowed by an accession process that has led to the poisoning of relations because it is so deeply dishonest. That is why I believe that it is really crucial to carry out this reassessment constructively together, so that the European Union and Turkey are still partners and friends in the centenary of the Republic of Turkey in 2023, and this process has not led us to turn away from each other.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Ladies and gentlemen, the report, for us debating, has quite positive elements, but unfortunately also some negative ones. I'll talk about them later. Personally, I will focus mainly on the new effort to resolve the Cyprus issue, which is also of great concern to this report because there are real possibilities for resolving it. I believe that the European Union, through its representatives, should closely monitor this new process. I therefore call on the President of the European Parliament, the representatives of the Commission and, in particular, Mr Younger, to be present at the negotiations, in order to ensure that the proposals submitted are in line with the acquis communautaire and that the final solution is run through the basic principles and values of the European Union. So if the two leaders – I welcome here the appointment of Mustafa Akinji to the leadership of the Turkish Cypriots – reach an agreement on the internal aspect of the Cyprus issue, then pressure should be increased on Turkey on issues that, above all, concern it and which are guarantees and the military. A Member State does not need guarantees and invasive rights; The report has positive references to Cyprus, Kurdish, human rights in Turkey. However, we do not agree with the opening of the chapters mentioned. I thank Mrs Piri for the high political culture she has shown during all the discussions of the representatives of the political groups with her. The solution will send a brilliant signal both within the European Union and outside the European Union. And that message, I think the old continent needs it.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, who has been extremely patient in trying to get through the compromises that all the groups would support, especially in view of the way in which perceptions are sprawling between different groups, and it is also sprawling between different countries. I myself come from Sweden, where there is very strong political support for Turkish membership. It is therefore very strange that some groups here could not accept wordings relating to accession, but that we have to end up with wordings on negotiations instead. I and my group, the Green Group, would have liked us to have continued to talk about accession and not just about negotiations. Although we are in favour of accession to the Union, we also feel that it is our responsibility to criticise when things are moving in the wrong direction. It has obviously been doing so for some years, for example, in terms of media freedom and the possibility of the opposition to act freely. Just yesterday, we received new information about attempts to stop critical media voices from using government infrastructure for communication. That is, of course, not acceptable and another in a series of restrictions on freedom of expression and the media.  Elections are about to take over in Turkey. The hope of us, and not least of the people of Turkey, is that the elections will be free, transparent and fair, but unfortunately this does not look like that, which we must be able to criticise. Another issue That I would like to take this opportunity to highlight is peace with the Kurds – that it is time. It is also important that aid shipments to the Kurdish part of Syria, to Rojava, arrive. We continue to receive information that aid shipments are being returned, and we cannot accept that either. In the situation where we stand today, where the Middle East is in flames, also on Turkey's border, neither Turkey nor the Kurds have anything to gain from a continuing conflict between them. A solution to the Kurdish question is crucial for the peaceful development of the whole region. Turkey has a key role to play there. I would also like to take this opportunity to ask for support for our Amendment No 9, which deals with the great construction boom that Turkey is in. It has been largely at the expense of environmental and natural interests. We would like Parliament's support to call on Turkey, in future projects, to carry out impact assessments in the same way as we do for projects here in the European Union.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we know that Turkey is a strategic partner for the European Union in economic, geopolitical and energy security terms, but we also know that Ankara is not adopting the necessary reforms and lacks an adequate legal framework, based on democracy and the rule of law.  How should we look at a government that still does not want to grant full social and political rights to citizens of Kurdish origin? How should we interpret the failure to implement the provisions of the EC-Turkey Association Agreement for the third year in a row? How can we accept in Europe a state that is not in line with the fundamental values on which the European Union is based, without an independent judicial system, in which the most basic rights of justice, freedom and security are still denied, a state in which workers do not have the right to protest or strike? In the light of all this, we wonder whether Turkey really intends to do everything possible to meet the criteria for accession or whether it is not necessary to start a moment of reflection on the accession process itself.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Madam President, as we all know, since 2000, when discussions on Turkey's accession to the European Union began, little to little progress has been made. The Turkish Government is well aware that the country does not meet the Copenhagen criteria to become a full member of the European Union. However, instead of trying to make some progress, it accuses the European Union of being responsible for the delays in integration procedures which it is calling for to be speeded up. Turkey, too, is doing very well and is pursuing this policy which serves its interests. My question is why in the European Parliament, but also in the other institutions of the European Union, there are officials who, instead of demanding that Turkey be consistent with its obligations, are pressuring those who ask for the obvious to accept Turkey's behaviour and consent to the opening of other chapters, such as Chapter 15 on energy. , so that Turkey can supposedly make the necessary reforms. This policy is also utopian and reinforces Turkey's provocation. As long as Turkey threatens Greece with war, and as long as it denies the entity of Cyprus, of which it illegally owns a part, the Greek nationalists will be guards at the back door of the European Union so as not to allow Turkey to grind down this international organisation as well.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Madam President, I would first of all like to say that I am not speaking today as the EPP foreign policy coordinator because our group is very divided on the issue of Turkey. I just want to evoke what I said when, in February, together with other colleagues from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I was in Turkey and had meetings with the country's highest officials: with the President, with the Prime Minister, with the Minister for European Affairs. I told, for example, to our interlocutors that we are about to discuss, debate and vote on a resolution on the genocide against Armenians, and, as you know, we have done so. We also told our interlocutors that we would discuss the report by Mrs Kati Piri, who was with us there, and that some of us, at the very least, are in favour of opening new negotiating chapters with Turkey. And I think we need to keep our word. That is why tomorrow I will vote in favour of all those amendments that call for the opening of new chapters: that it is justice and the rule of law, that it is about energy. I think it is important for us to deepen the dialogue with Turkey; on the other hand, of course we cannot forget domestic political developments and we have been looking forward to the elections in Turkey for over a few weeks. It is a very sensitive issue related, moreover, to the People's Democratic Party, the pro-Kurdish party. (The speaker agreed to answer three questions put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Urmas PAET
text: blue card issue. – Good colleague. For years, the European Union has been talking about how much cooperation with Turkey on security and foreign policy would be needed, given everything that is happening in the wider Middle East. However, there is no special cooperation, unfortunately, and so does energy policy. What do you think these are concrete steps that the European Union should take in the near future to confirm what it said, in order to actually coordinate and harmonise more foreign policy with Turkey, and also to link more with each other in energy policy?

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Honourable Member, you said in your speech that your group is quite divided on Turkey or on its issue. Can you tell me this, which is the one or two most important questions where you see a fault line? What are they?

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" question. – I would like to ask Mr Preda whether I would have asked for any capital to be opened at a time when ships were patrolling his country, threatening with casus belli its living space, if his country had recently received a note issued by the Turkish Ministry of Foreign Affairs and bound its islands, as they did in our country, if they would have held half his country, would he be talking about capital openings at the moment?

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Answer to three questions asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure – Madam President, the issue of energy, of course, we all know that this is a very sensitive issue in our relations, not only with Turkey, but also with other partners, and the PPE Group is just preparing to define a very clear position, including on the external dimension of energy security. Turkey, for its part, must choose: I do not believe that it can also partner with the Union and its strategic opponents. With regard to the division of the EPP, I will disappoint my colleague, but I am just saying this: we have a shadow rapporteur who has spoken and we will see tomorrow - there is no place here for a seminar on this subject, but I think it is right to assume that we are not in agreement on this. Finally, on the last issue of opening chapters, my view is that by blocking the opening of new chapters with Turkey, we have pushed it to move away from our positions on issues that are essential, and look at the situation in the field of foreign policy. Unfortunately, if a few years ago there was a quasi-similarity in terms of the foreign policy position, today they overlap to an extent, which is why I think we must help Turkey intelligently and give up the oppositions that sometimes come from nationalist and populist passions, I would add.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Madam President, firstly I warmly congratulate my colleague Kati Piri on this first report and recognize the very broad support she has in our Group, even if other Groups are not able to say the same in theirs.  As for myself, let me be clear that I am someone who has argued over a long period for constitutional reform in Turkey, as reflected in paragraph 6 of the report. That does not mean a super-presidency, as proposed by some. Three weeks ahead of the parliamentary elections it highlights the danger of any one party obtaining a majority, which could threaten the need to win a cross-party consensus for any constitutional change. I note the recent survey showed 60% of the Turkish public is against adoption of the presidential system. Next, the Kurdish issue. The message for the European Parliament today for all parties is that the peace talks with the PKK must continue in good faith. Any question against this would be deeply ironic, given the importance of the Kurdish population in bringing security to the region.  To those on the opposite side of this House who have argued against the opening of Chapters, let us address the unrest in the region, because surely this supports the case in the resolution for opening Chapter 31 on foreign policy. There is no strategy for promoting conflict resolution, counter terrorism, non-sectarianism and non-proliferation across the whole of the Middle East and North Africa that does not seriously include Turkey within its process.  To those who are concerned about the new Gazprom deal announced between Russia and Turkey, which is by no means their first energy deal, I would say that this is an argument for opening the energy Chapter to secure Europe’s interest, and not to fight shy of it. Above all, any Member who is genuine in expressing concern about human rights and democracy in the country should join with us in calling for the opening of Chapters 23 and 24 on fundamental rights. If Europe really is open to Turkish accession it is these Chapters which should be open most.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Poland was the first European country to establish diplomatic relations with Turkey more than 600 years ago. These relations worked well in the most difficult times for us, when Poland torn apart by its neighbors did not exist on the maps of the world. At a time of great geopolitical challenges, the threat of terrorism, a hybrid war that is not known when it starts, how it proceeds and when it ends, we should remember that Turkey is our ally.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for her huge efforts on the preparation of the draft motion for a resolution and the intention to provide a suitable framework for EU-Turkey relations. Unfortunately, the last version has been modified and the whole philosophy of the motion has been changed.  There is a disproportionate emphasis on the negative elements, without referring to the positive steps undertaken by the Turkish Government. Such an approach could increase the Euroscepticism within Turkish society and threaten the positive trend of public approval for EU membership. Instead of tolerating positive attitudes towards the EU within society, we could achieve a negative effect.  Analysis of the official visit of the delegation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) to Ankara has not been taken into consideration. There is no clearly stated position on opening chapters, especially chapters 23 and 24, which could provide the Turkish Government with impetus for implementation of reforms.  Noting that Turkey plays a key role in the region, in regard to the refugees from the Middle East it should be stressed that sustainment of almost two million Syrian refugees costs nearly USD 6 billion, while financial and political support from the international community is very limited.  Turkey has a strategic role as a partner of the EU and a member of NATO and its geopolitical importance in addressing security and stability in the region is crucial. The cooperation between the EU and Turkey is of mutual interest, so we need each other in order to overcome the security challenges more than ever.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). – What we are discussing today is wrongly referred to as the 'Turkey Progress Report' as a candidate country. "Regression report" should be called because this is actually the case.  A government such as turkey, which responds to accusations of corruption by firing the relevant judges and prosecutors and temporarily banning YouTube and Twitter, obviously respects neither the rule of law nor freedom of expression. A society such as Turkey, where underage girls are forced by their relatives into marriage against their will, obviously does not respect gender equality. A country such as Turkey, which militarily holds part of the territory of another State, namely Cyprus, and conducts illegal searches on its continental shelf and even challenges existing international treaties and Greek sovereignty over a number of Aegean islands, obviously does not respect international law. The Turkish candidacy for membership of the Union is a farce.

name: Ska KELLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Much is going wrong in Turkey. The problems have already been mentioned: minority rights, women's rights, the freedom to express themselves, whether online or offline, freedom of the media, freedom of the press. There are many problems. The new law, which criminalizes demonstrators and activists, has also been mentioned. It is precisely because of all these problems that we should take the accession process more seriously right now, because an accession process is our best way of supporting the actors for change in Turkey. If we tear down the bridges, it will not help anyone. Fundamental rights and justice should always be at the beginning and in the middle, at the heart of an accession process. These chapters must finally be opened. They should have been opened from the beginning. It is very, very late. We should do it now rather than later. These are our core values, because Europe is more than just an internal market. It is not enough to look at market opportunities. We must strengthen the rule of law, democracy and the rights of the people on the ground. That is what this is all about, but that is precisely what we can achieve with a serious and credible accession process.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: –  Mr President, this afternoon part of the town of Palmyra in Syria fell to Islamic State. Palmyra is around the same distance from the border of Turkey as Strasbourg is from Frankfurt. Should Turkey become a Member State, all the EU Member States – and especially the UK, which I represent – would all have borders with Iran, Iraq, and Syria. Let us be clear.  The British Liberal Democrats, the British Labour Party, and especially the British Conservatives, who should all be ashamed of themselves, are all cheerleaders for Turkey to become a Member State of the European Union.  I urge these parties, and people over there, in their own national interest, and in the interest of all Member States, to consider that, whatever their rationalisation may have been to have this pro-Turkish policy when it was formulated, the facts on the ground have changed.   Turkey is no longer a credible candidate to be a Member State of the European Union. Further – and this is a separate point, because our security would be at risk – Turkey is a persistent and systematic violator of the human rights of its own people.  If the European Convention on human rights means anything, and I have to say I think it does not, there is no way that Turkey can be a Member State. I urge Members, therefore, to support my amendment tomorrow.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), blue card question. – I would like to ask this, because he has spoken of timing, in order to pave Turkey's way to the European Union. If he really wants to, it would not be better to open a "avenue" for Turkey, to ask Erdogan to withdraw Turkish occupying troops from the European territory of the Republic of Cyprus, to support a solution based on the principles and values of the acquis communautaire. That is why we are in the European Union. This will show that we have political differences but that, above all, it is the rules of European Union law. What do you think of that? (The speaker wishes to put a blue card question to Ska Keller)

name: Ska KELLER
text: blue-card answer. – If I understood correctly, you are asking about the Cyprus question. As the Commissioner mentioned, I think we now have a unique window of opportunity that we need to use. I think the European Union should do its utmost to support the resolution process in Cyprus. It is absolutely right that we have a big problem there and that the Turkish army should not be in Cyprus. But let us use that opportunity. In the past, opportunities have unfortunately not been used, but we should go ahead now because we really should not have this unresolved problem and crisis in the middle of the European Union. I also think that the accession process in Turkey could be a vital tool to, let us say, give a little push towards a solution.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Madam President, I had planned a slightly more conventional intervention, but I would like to respond this evening to Mrs Keller and Mr Ali. I would like to solemnly denounce Turkey's ambiguous role in both the Middle East and Europe! For the past ten years, in the European Parliament, you have wanted to force us to enter Europe! I say no, no and no! I will oppose Turkey's entry into Europe because it does not represent the fundamental rules of the European Union! It illegally occupies territory in Cyprus and has not denounced the genocide of Armenians! And you persist today in making us believe that Turkey is now a democratic country! Check out what's happening at Gezi Park, see what's happening in Christian minorities! What you want, in fact, is a Turkish Europe! I denounce precisely the fact that Turkey imposes on Europe its choices of civilization. We must defend here, today, the civilizational acquis of a Christian Europe.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, the European Union's relations with Turkey are very important. The European Union has old and numerous links with Turkey, including a customs union. And it is also a candidate country for accession with which, as we all know, the corresponding negotiations are taking place. Accession requires major reforms in Turkey. European standards for the rule of law, independence of the judiciary and respect for human rights are the ones that must guide these reforms, which have to move forward. But on the other hand, Turkey is experiencing a difficult situation because of its neighborhood with Syria and Iraq and the consequent wave of refugees. We must continue to provide them with humanitarian aid. Moreover, Turkey and several Member States of the European Union have as neighbouring southern Mediterranean countries that face serious security and stability challenges. Cooperation between the European Union and Turkey on security and counter-terrorism is therefore necessary, as is migration cooperation. I therefore welcome the recent entry into force of the Agreement on readmission. We must also cooperate on energy. Turkey is much needed to diversify Europe's energy supply routes. And it is also appropriate to keep Turkey informed of the negotiations we are conducting with the United States on the trade and investment agreement. Turkey is an important regional player and has a strategic location. Dialogue and cooperation with Turkey on foreign and security policy is becoming increasingly necessary in a very difficult regional context. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card question. – Thank you very much for taking the question. You mentioned – as almost nobody else has, that I am aware of – that Turkey is already a member of the EU customs union. As Turkey is already a member of the EU customs union – as you correctly, and perceptively, mentioned – why is it necessary for Turkey to become a full Member State, which means we have free movement of people, massive cohesion fund payments and the rest?

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: "blue card" response. – The customs union. We do not have the other components, which are very numerous, of the European Union. Of course, I understand that it is lawful for Turkey to want to aspire to full integration. The customs union is a part, but only part of what is political union and full accession to the European Union. It's just a part, not the whole.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, I begin by reiterated the support of the Group of Socialists and Democrats for Turkey's integration into the European Union. I congratulate the rapporteur on her excellent report, for the extraordinary work she has done to achieve the compromises that will enable this report to be adopted. We have a choice between isolating Turkey, which some suggest, and engaging in dialogue with it, however difficult. We know that this is the only way we can influence developments in Turkey. We have a choice between pushing Turkey into Russia's arms or keeping Turkey in institutionalised cooperation with the Euro-Atlantic world. From this perspective, I suggest three important directions: 1) humanitarian cooperation, where Turkey is already contributing significantly to taking in the largest number of refugees from Syria; 2) cooperation in the field of foreign policy in the fight against terrorism, in stopping funding for terrorist groups as well as in stopping arms trafficking, identifying and isolating foreign combatants; 3) Conclude by supporting the importance of opening Chapter XV in the field of energy, the only one that will allow us to reduce dependence on gas imports from a single supplier, namely Russia.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Almost as a ritual, the European Union is evaluating progress in relations with Turkey. With each step forward, the country puts two back.  This year too, we need a magnifying glass to see structural progress. After ten years of accession negotiations, Turkey still has major difficulties with fundamental freedoms, such as freedom of the press, freedom of expression and freedom of religion.  The commission strongly condemns ankara's handling of a major corruption scandal. We must not close our eyes to this. Year after year, the republic's leadership is taking on more authoritarian tendencies, a trend that coincides with the rise of Erdoğan, first as prime minister and since last year as president. I hold my heart for the consequences of the parliamentary elections in June.  With even more power for Erdoğan, Turkey could be slipping into an authoritarian state for good. Two reservations about this report. One, where does the EU want to go with a country that is increasingly turning away from European values? And two: do the acclaimed Turkish efforts in the field of visa liberalisation and as a trading partner further outweigh the ever-increasing degradation of the rule of law?

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, the annual progress report has sadly become a regress report. The concerns we have on the rule of law, separation of powers, human rights and fundamental freedoms are now even more substantial than in previous years as a result of the passing of security laws, restrictions on press and internet freedom, and an acknowledgment that evidence in a mass trial was actually doctored. That leads to key questions about fair trial and due process.  I have always fought for the accession process as I believed it would lead to a win-win situation for the people in the EU and Turkey alike, and I am sad to share how sombre I am about where things stand.  Now, are we only highlighting concerns? No. We also clearly stressed the importance of updating the customs union and of a common coordinated approach to foreign policy and humanitarian matters, but it must be crystal clear that an effective and credible EU—Turkey partnership can only be based on solidly shared values and a common understanding of democratic principles, such as are laid down in the Copenhagen criteria.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). – Ladies and gentlemen, this House a few months ago condemned Turkey's violations of the Cypriot EEZ. How is the rapporteur's request to open the energy chapter justified today? In order to open the chapter, Turkey must first sign and ratify the Convention on the Law of the Sea, recognise the Republic of Cyprus and respect its sovereign rights. The resolution critically mentions developments in Turkey, but the European Union must insist on the need to implement all the Copenhagen criteria and Turkey's contractual obligations, first and foremost, for the benefit of the Turkish people themselves. We welcome the calls on Turkey to start withdrawing the occupying army from Cyprus, to support the work of the CMR, to implement UN Security Council Resolution 550 on Famagusta and the Supplementary Protocol and, in particular, to contribute constructively to the solution of the Cyprus problem, on the basis of the bi-social bi-community federation with one sovereignty, one nationality and one international personality. But we also insist on the need to end settlement immediately and to demilitarize Cyprus.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Madam President, thank you, Mrs Piri, for your ability to reach agreements and, even more, for your patience in the face of various intransigences. The report contains, first of all, as harsh as it is necessary criticism of the Turkish Government's action in the field of democratic quality and respect for the basic rights of its citizens. Secondly, an explicit recognition of the European Union's lack of leadership over the past period and a positive assessment of Turkey's strategic role in the economic and geopolitical sphere. Third, the need to give new impetus to talks on all pending chapters—especially, of course, chapters 23 and 24, but also chapters 15. The opposite, by the way, would be precisely to justify the attitudes of victimistic nationalism that the majority party wants to make an electoral argument. Fourthly, the hope recovered in a possible agreement with Cyprus, for which Europe must show serenity without interference and make all its contribution, discreetly but positively, to the success of the talks. And finally, a certain expectation that the Kurds will be able to play a central role in the Turkish democratic system in the next period. That is why, if the balance achieved is not altered, we will support this Resolution. Let us work to ensure that Turkey the day after the election is once again the positive interlocutor friend, consistent with the Copenhagen criteria, which Europe wanted to have when, ten years ago, we started the talks.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to take this opportunity to warmly thank my fellow Members who have supported my candidacy today and the principle of pluralism in this house. I would like to thank Mrs Piri for her work on this report. You rightly pointed out that accession can potentially be a valuable opportunity for Turkish democratisation. The real question we must ask ourselves, however, is: does Turkey really want to take advantage of this opportunity?  It does not seem to me that it has so far taken the right path in the right direction. Of course, we are well aware of the persistent shortcomings in respect for EU values and the principles of freedom of expression, and we are also very familiar with the reforms, or rather the counter-reforms, which have been constitutionally existing with regard to the rights of political opposition, and it is perhaps superfluous to recall that 48 000 sites between 2007 and 2014 were blocked by the Turkish authorities. , unfortunately following some anti-democratic tendencies of closure to the opposition forces.  As long as there is no just solution to the Cyprus question, recognition of the Armenian genocide and fairness to the Kurdish people as well, I believe that turkey will not support this will and I hope that the Turkish people will, on the other hand, mark a break from this point of view in the June elections.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Madam President, the 'progress report' on Turkey is a link in the accession process to the European Union which is a painful choice for the Turkish people, which will mean new gains for The European Union and Turkish monopolies. The report paves the way for new negotiating chapters that are literally a reward for the continued occupation of Cyprus, increased aggression and violations of Turkey, both in the Cypriot EEZ and in Greek airspace and sea. That is why the European Commission's recent credit to Turkey, citing the CFSP criteria, reveal how dangerous European Union policy and the CFSP are to the people; But peoples have other criteria and interests, and by fighting against the European Union, their monopolies and their plans and their competition can impose their own interests.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE). Madam President, in the Committee on Foreign Affairs I voted for the report on Turkey. But now I am having second thoughts, and that is because of the attempt to open specific chapters. I wonder why Chapter 23 and 24 on justice and civil rights should be opened when we have the events in Gezi Park and the flagrant arrests of journalists and the violation of individual rights? Why should Chapter 15 on energy be opened by a country that does not respect and ratify the law of the sea, the UNCLOS Treaty and illegally adopts Navtex directives on the EEZ of neighbouring Member States of the European Union? Why should Chapter 31 on foreign and defence and security policy be opened when Turkey still retains the casus belli, that is to say the threat of war in a Member State of the European Union, and indeed in force? I think that, three weeks before the elections, we are making a very big gift to the current Government of Turkey. Rather, we should open up the Council's benchmarks, the so-called 'Benchmarks', and not open new chapters. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: blue-card question. – Just one short question, Mr Kefalogiannis. We were in negotiations together in which you participated in your capacity as the Chair of the EP/TGNA Joint Parliamentary Committee. Your statements now indicate that you have serious problems accepting vast swathes of Turkish policy—making.  Do you think you should continue in your function as Chair of the JPC, because apparently you have really serious problems with Turkey?

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE), "blue card" answer. – Looking at your democratic systems, I understand that your question is at least unfortunate because you know very well that in this position I am not appointed but I am elected;

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Kati Piri, for the work she has done: a great job, hard, arduous and with very complex negotiations to reach an agreement and have the report that we have today. The report does two things. It makes an adequate and necessary criticism of the deterioration of the rule of law, democratic quality, the right to freedom of expression and independent justice that has occurred in recent years in Turkey, deep concerns which have also been expressed on different occasions in this Parliament. It also expresses the recognition, also necessary, of Turkey's solidarity with refugees, of its role in the area in strategic terms or, also, with regard to relations with Europe in the energy field. But what we need to be clear about is that Turkey's accession process must be the necessary lever — and regulation has to go in this direction — for progress to be made on democratic reforms, taking into account the Copenhagen criteria and the values that have underpinned the European Union for its construction.

name: Bas BELDER
text: I actually wanted to raise one case with the European Commission. A very serious matter. On 18 April 2007, a triple murder of Christians took place in Malatya, Turkey, in a gruesome murder. A torture murder that was even filmed with their phones by the suspects and the perpetrators. They were also arrested at the scene.  Now we're eight years on and what does it show? These defendants are at large, to the horror and dismay of the next of kin whom they even threatened during the hearings. Also to the dismay and dismay of the members of the small Turkish Protestant community, who feel unsafe in view of the intimidation by the perpetrators during the trial. They ask themselves: what is the law for Christians in Turkey? I called them again this afternoon to ask if there's any progress in this case. There have already been 101 hearings.  My urgent question is for the Commission to ask the Turkish judicial authorities: what is going on with this murder case? After all, the perpetrators are at large under so-called house arrest.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). – ... Ten years have passed since the start of negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union. Ten years in which Turkey continues to hold European territory with an army - half of Cyprus - and systematically violate the sovereign rights of its neighbours, disregard international treaties and decisions, as in the case of the Cypriot EEZ and investigations, and also violate European airspace. In the last eighteen months alone, there have been about two thousand seven hundred violations. Ladies and gentlemen, if the occupying army does not withdraw from Cyprus, if the Additional Protocol is not implemented and the Republic of Cyprus is not recognised, if the casus belli is not lifted vis-à-vis Greece, a member of the European Union, and violations of European air and water borders do not stop, no enlargement can happen, no chapter can be opened, and no deepening can be decided in the customs union. Ladies and gentlemen, if we really want to develop our relations with Turkey, we must remain adamant about these conditions.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: – Turkey has made all the progress since Atatürk broke down. Christians, Kurd political opposition, journalists, judges, women are systematically oppressed by violence. The beast of Ankara has given IS free rein in the battle for Kobani, revealing its true agenda.  Turkey is on its way to an Islamophobic dictatorship led by the dangerous Islamist Erdoğan. And what does the EU do? It rewards this misconduct. It feeds the beast that's going to bite our throats. It gives no less, but more money to dictator Erdoğan, who has just spent 300 million on a megalomaniac palace, fifty times bigger than the White House, in which he hangs out the sultan.  Mr President, this country must never become a member of the EU. I demand that this Commission immediately end all funding for this Islamic dictatorship, detailed accountability for the use of the billions it has received from and through corrupt Turkey and an immediate cessation of the negotiation process.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Madam President, I am deeply convinced that the European Union must continue to actively support anyone in Turkey who wants democracy and the country's pro-European integration. It is strategically important for us to have a reliable ally, neighbor and partner in the face of the Republic of Turkey. Regional and global challenges underline the clear need to strengthen cooperation on priority topics such as energy security and diversification of supply, stability in the Middle East and countering irregular migration, which is particularly relevant in the context of the discussion of a new solidarity migration policy of the EU.  The process of negotiating Turkey's accession to the EU has been open-ended from the outset, but it represents a strong incentive to carry out reforms and democratic processes in the country and an opportunity to realise the full potential of our strategic partnership. I welcome the resumption of active dialogue in recent months, which is vital for strengthening mutual trust and I hope it will reinvigorate reforms in the country. Overcoming critical points in key areas such as respect for fundamental rights, the rule of law, solutions to problems with neighbours, which are the value foundation of the European Union, are conditions without which the process of European integration cannot continue.  Ratification and entry into force of the Readmission Agreement is a step in the right direction, but it is important to ensure its full and effective implementation.  Bulgaria and Turkey share a land border, which is also an external border of the European Union. We attach particular importance to full cooperation with the Turkish authorities towards strengthening border security, combating trafficking in human beings and goods, energy infrastructure and the economy.  (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear Colleague, how will you comment on the increasingly authoritarian attitude and behaviour of Prime Minister Davutoglu and President Erdogan, who are going in a very Islamist direction, and in this sense do you not think that with their policy they are taking Turkey away from the European Union and Turkey is going its own way, especially in the context of both Turkish Stream and the flooding of Bulgaria with illegal immigrants?

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – That is why I said at the beginning that it is in our interest to actively support those environments in Turkey that want pro-European integration and want democracy. What we are seeing, unfortunately, is the undemocratic development of the country and of course moving the country away from, so let's say, the European corridor, because let alone full membership of the European Union. The negotiations themselves have been conducted with an open end since the beginning of the negotiation process, when it was decided in Luxembourg to open negotiations with the Republic of Turkey, they are open-ended. At the end of this negotiation process, if it comes to that, then it will be decided at all what it is about - full membership, some kind of partnership or what is the current status quo with the customs union. So our desire, in my opinion, and my desire is to motivate these forces in Turkey who want democracy, they want respect for human rights, for all minorities, religious, ethnic, etc. and that is in the interest of the European Union.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D). Madam President, Relations between the European Union and Turkey are at a key point where it must really be seen whether the Turkish Government wants to become a member of the European family. Lies, tactics and purpose must end and the message from the European Union must be clear. Turkey must demonstrate in practice that it respects human rights, the sovereignty of neighbouring states and international law. The withdrawal of Turkish occupying troops from Cyprus, the recognition of the Republic of Cyprus, respect for the freedoms and rights of Turkey's own citizens, the resolution of the Kurdish problem, harmonisation with the principles and values of the European Union must be a one-way street for Turkey. We want Turkey in the European Union as a force for peace and stability and not as a factor of instability and anomaly that creates problems in the region.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Madam President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur for her hard work and balanced approach in dealing with this delicate matter. Regardless of the opinions held across this House, I think that we can all agree that it is in everyone’s interest for Turkey to be a safe, democratic and prosperous country. While I take on board some of the concerns expressed by colleagues, I am afraid that the default negative position adopted by some keeps pushing Turkey further away instead of drawing it into the fold. Though this may be exactly what some want, we should not be surprised to see that constantly boxing Turkey out has frustrated Turkish moderates and fostered the isolationist sentiment the many in this House are so quick to condemn. Let us adopt a more cohesive approach that rewards positive developments. It is the only way that we will be able to genuinely evaluate whether or not the EU can take its relationship with Turkey to the next level.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let us put it this way: Turkey is a great regional power that has no intention, and perhaps no interest, of containing its enormous military, geopolitical and expansionist aspirations: the case of Cyprus shows this. Cyprus is also one of the members of the European Union, but it is not defence. I would remind you not only of the opposition's complaints, which are manifold and detailed, about the connivance (there has been talk of Turkey's ambiguity on the issue of terrorism, of 50 000 terrorists accepted, according to an opposition spokesman), but also of the complaints of international bodies which already indicate in 2014 the discovery of Turkish-made weapons dated that year in conflict zones. So there's evidence. This issue has been the subject of my question, and Mrs Mogherini says that there will be action to ensure that Turkey tracks these weapons. But when will they give us an answer? The reality is that Erdoğan's Turkey makes fun of us. The reality is that it is led by a leader who responds in a threatening and mafia-like manner to the moderate words of peace of the Pope, guilty only of using the term 'genocide', because genocide scares this Turkey. Remembering genocide is our duty – the genocide of the Armenians! – and you, the cowardly Europe, do not have the courage to interrupt these ... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: PPE). – The report on Turkey is unacceptable because it sets the Republic of Cyprus on the sidelines and exposes it to serious risks, disconnects the Cypriot from the accession process, promotes the opening of chapters without Turkey having fulfilled its obligations to the Republic of Cyprus and to the Union, promotes the deepening of the customs union without Turkey having implemented the Additional Protocol and refuses to include in the paragraph on the Cyprus issue the counter-declaration of 21 September which is an integral part of the acquis communautaire which expressly states that the European Union recognises on the island a State, the Republic of Cyprus, which has joined the Union as a single State under Protocol 10. It also allows Turkey to participate in the Foreign and Defence Councils and promotes the opening of the security chapter while the Turkish army continues to hold Cyprus and the Turkish fleet violates our sea daily. If the European Parliament votes on the report, it exposes the Republic of Cyprus to an immediate risk of its dissolution and transformation into a protectorate of Turkey and makes this protectorate Trojan Horse to flood the European Union with fanatical Islamists. The European Parliament has no competence to determine the state form of the solution to the Cyprus problem and, therefore, the promotion of a concrete solution, which legitimises Turkey's ongoing war crime against Cyprus, also exposes the European Union to serious risks. The European Parliament has a moral obligation to ensure that the solution is governed by the principles and values of the European Union and safeguards the human rights of the Cypriot people. With regard to the refugees that Turkey protects, let us consider how many millions of refugees the Turkish army and the Turkish state itself are responsible for. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – This may be food for thought for my Greek Cypriot friends and colleagues, whom I appreciate very much. Ms Theocharous, do you not think that issues with Turkey could be settled more easily within the process of Turkey’s accession to the European Union? If Turkey is kept outside the European Union, things will become more difficult. This situation has to be used by all of us.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: PPE), "blue card" answer. – I have said many times that we would like a democratic neighbour, progressive and modern, to protect – as long as Turkey has as much power as it has – all the small peoples around. Unfortunately, however, Turkey wants to join the European Union on its own terms and to take care of the European Union itself. That is why it does not go through democratic processes and changes that allow us to feel safe. If you feel safe with this Turkey which does not even respect its own people and violates basic human rights, then what can I say? I have nothing more to say.
