Yes! we would like a democratic Turkey in the European Union so that we too feel better and safer.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If there is a difficult report, it is certainly true of the progress report with Turkey – that is precisely why I would like to thank Kati Piri for doing so well. It is no secret that many interests clash here: the interest of those who never want to see Turkey in the EU, the endless conflict with Cyprus and with Greece, the 'Western' NATO member on the one hand – and I say this by quotation mark – on the one hand, and turkey, which is increasingly moving away from these very Western fundamental values. In this context, I mention only the shameful treatment of journalists, or how the Internet is misused for political purposes. And then there is Turkey, which plays an important role in the Middle East conflict and has taken in almost four times as many refugees as the whole of Europe combined. So opposites wherever you look. In the interests of Europe and Turkey, I hope that the number of contradictions will have decreased in the next report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, Turkey continues its provocative attitude towards Cyprus and Greece. A few hours ago, Turkish fighter jets once again violated Greek airspace between Chios and Samos. And while Turkey continues to illegally hold 37% of the territory of Cyprus – a Member State of the European Union – the European Union itself continues to silence Ankara. In fact, the report we are debating proposes to open new chapters of the European Union-Turkey pre-accession dialogue. At a time when Turkey does not even recognise Cyprus, while Turkey maintains the casus belli against Greece in case my country extends its territorial waters to twelve miles, while Turkey questions the sovereign rights of Greece and Cyprus, the report attempts to upgrade Turkey's position in the political dialogue with the Union. The report we are debating is therefore unacceptable. Finally, I would like to point out once again that I am opposed to any future accession of Turkey to the European Union.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is truly regrettable that there are so few Members in the Chamber today in this important debate. It is all the more pleasing for me that the gallery is full of young listeners. I warmly welcome my compatriots, the corps students of the Montanuniversität Leoben from Austria. When we talk today about Turkey's progress report, it would be appropriate to talk about a backstep report. As the Commission confirmed to me only this week, it is currently being examined whether pre-accession aid, namely around 700 to 750 million a year, should not be suspended, as I have asked for many times. It's interesting that after years, you're obviously thinking about actually doing it. This is an overdue step in view of Turkey's serious continuing violations of freedom of expression, democracy and the rule of law. The situation in Cyprus remains tense. After all, the country under Sultan Erdogan has long since detached itself from its secular heritage, and public life is increasingly placed under the dictates of Islam. This, of course, raises the question: who is still in favour of Turkey's accession? 72% of my Austrian compatriots are clearly against it. It would be more honest to break off the negotiations and consider other solutions.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Madam President, Turkey is determined to join the Union and is willing to introduce effective reforms, develop good neighbourhood relations and adopt the necessary international standards. Nevertheless, the country still fails to ensure freedom of speech and the press, there is a lack of a legal framework to fight corruption, the separation of powers and the independence of the judiciary leave serious things to be wished for, and relations with the Turkish neighbourhood are very strained. Turkey has a strategic role to play in relation to the Eastern and Southern European Neighbourhood Policies, especially in the fight against terrorism in Syria and Iraq. It also plays an important role in European energy security. With this in mind, cooperation with it should be continued.  Nevertheless, the European-Turkish dialogue must be maintained on the basis of values. We can rightly expect Turkey to fulfil its own commitments in terms of ensuring fundamental human rights, to refrain from any action that has a detrimental impact on neighbourhood relations, to normalise its relations with Greece and Cyprus and to normalise its relations with Armenia. A century after the Armenian genocide, this step will no longer be delayed.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D). – We all understand that Turkey is an important partner of the European Union. But progress and the smooth continuation of accession negotiations now depend solely on it. As noted in the European Parliament's resolution, it must proceed with the necessary reforms and fully comply with the Copenhagen criteria. Ensuring the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and freedom of the press are at the core of the European values and principles that it must respect. At the same time, Turkey must normalise bilateral relations. Practices such as continuous violations of Greek airspace, illegal underwater searches in the Aegean and Eastern Mediterranean, as well as its refusal to remove the casus belli against Greece and to recognise the Republic of Cyprus, must be terminated. We want a Turkey that is a source of stability for the region and respects European values and the social acquis. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Mr Andrulakis, I come from the Balkans and the only way not to provoke old layerings left over from the history of the Balkans is for countries to get their European perspective. In this regard, do you not think it necessary that Cyprus and the Republic of Turkey could solve their problems as part of the European Union?

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), "blue card" answer. – It is obvious that the Balkans is a region that has experienced very difficult times in recent decades. However, the conclusion of all processes in our region is respect for European rules. So as long as Turkey does not proceed with such a standard practice, it is obvious that there will be no normalisation in relations and the attempt to move the accession process forward will be constantly undermined by its extreme strategy.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Madam President! As time goes on, it is increasingly clear that it was a mistake to open accession negotiations with Turkey. Turkey is an incredibly important player in the region, it is a member of NATO and it should be a democratic society with which we can have natural cooperation in the European Union.  But membership of the European Union has proved to be the wrong way for Turkey. We see today that fundamental rights, such as freedom of expression, freedom of the press and freedom to gather and demonstrate, are being trampled underfoot by what until a few years ago was a Turkey that was heading in a Western direction, a Turkey that was moving towards a genuine democracy in the understanding we have of the concept of the Western world.  That is why I think it is quite clear that the EU membership, which has been envisaged, has had the opposite effect of what had been hoped. We have moved away from Atatürk and towards Islamism, and if that trend continues, Then I hope that we will stop the accession negotiations, rather than tomorrow.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the good work on this progress report. I think we should see the EU integration process as a vehicle to enhance reforms in the country. We need to stay focused on the reformsʼ processes such as strengthening the rule of law, independence of the judiciary and unconditional respect for fundamental freedoms, including freedom of association, expression and freedom of the media. Turkey should be encouraged to intensify its dialogue with the EU and the Venice Commission in order to converge to the EU aquis.  I would also like to stress the importance of Turkey as a major regional and international player. In the security context, Turkey remains a key NATO ally which can play an increasingly positive and constructive role in all regional constellations. This includes relations with the EU Member States, EU candidate countries in the western Balkans and Turkeyʼs troubled neighbourhood in the south-east. We need to see an increased complementarity in the EU’s and Turkey’s foreign and security policy issues. In the current security environment a closer relation between Turkey and the European Union is to the benefit of both.  (The speaker accepted to take a blue-card question under Rule162(8))

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), "blue card" question. Mr Kukan, I wanted to ask you this: in view of turkey's behaviour so far, what makes you think that Turkey is really interested in joining the European Union, is interested in making the reforms that need to be made, and which you quite rightly mentioned, and what makes you think again that, if that country joins the European Union on the terms it wants and not on the terms that it needs to. , it will be - as you said - a good support for security and all those nice and pleasant things that we are trying to say and accept that will happen if Turkey becomes a member of the European Union.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: blue-card answer. – First of all I do not believe that Turkey will become an EU member on its own terms. You are underestimating the European Union if you say that. And I did not say that I believe that; I said that Turkey – whether you like it or not – is a candidate country which is going through the accession negotiations.  Whatever you say, this is the truth, and I repeat that the European Commission is the body which defines with whom we are going to start accession negotiations. It is a process – nobody wants to accept Turkey now. It is a matter of years. I do not know how this process is going to end.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, Turkey has changed in the last 12 years in a way that has not changed in the decades before. I am afraid that we have not been able to reflect these changes sufficiently. Of course, we do not like some of these changes, but I think we should take note of them and respect them.  Turkey has changed its paradigm in the perception of the European Union, changed its internal policy, changed its foreign policy, which is far more assertive. In any case, Turkey remains an important player in the region, remaining a key geopolitical player in terms of ensuring the security as well as the energy security of the European Union. Turkey also deserves high credit for its access to refugees, because if it had not captured refugees from Syria and Iraq, they would have been in Europe long ago. Regardless of its accession to the European Union, we are doomed to cooperate with Turkey. I don't think we should corner him, and certainly, if pre-election aid were cut off now, in the crucial period before the election, I would consider it a very bad signal. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: blue-card question. – I do appreciate your constructive approach towards Turkey’s involvement in the reform process and, indeed, we should follow this line. Would you envisage any new instruments for Turkey? And, especially, what should the Commission provide in order to speed up these reforms and make them irreversible?

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: blue-card answer. – I do not see the necessity of introducing any new measures or any new instruments. I think, and I can only repeat what my predecessor Mr Kukan has said, that we are in the course of a negotiation process. I think that the trustworthiness of any international organisation, and the European Union first and foremost, should be measured also according to whether it is able to fulfil its promises. Once we have started the negotiation process we have to go on with that and we have to make a final evaluation at the end of this process, not stop it in the meantime or change the conditions in the meantime.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, the European Parliament is sending mixed messages to Turkey. We call for the acceleration of reforms but we slow down on the prospects for membership. Why should we have a say in Turkey’s internal policies if we then tell them that Europe will never be their home? Accession negotiation is the highway to change. I share concerns regarding censorship, freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary, but I think that opening the chapters on justice and fundamental freedom is the best way to promote democratic reforms. We should also move forward on visa liberalisation. This is not about rewarding the current government: it is about engaging long-term to build trust with the people of Turkey. We must look beyond the rhetoric and actions coming from Ankara now. Yes, more needs to be done, but we do see some progress in the peace process with the Kurdish community, dialogue with Cyprus, the readmission agreement and the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women. Being punitive does not lead anywhere. Let us be pragmatic. Turkey is strategic for the EU. We share major challenges: migration, human trafficking, terrorism and jihadism, energy and trade. Let us be clear, Turkey is not ready to become a member yet, but let us give them the same chance as other candidate countries, without double standards. Our uncertainty has a price, which is the undermining of pro-European consensus and policies in Turkey. Is it really the case that Turkey is turning its back on Europe? Or are we turning our backs on the people of Turkey? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: PPE), "blue card" question. – Mrs Bildt, how do you judge Turkey's attitude to implement the readmission agreement with the 27 Member States but not with the Republic of Cyprus which it describes as offensive, which I prefer not to translate from Turkish, and how do you judge the fact that Cypriot citizens are not allowed to issue visas unless they admit that they come from this "Greek Cypriot administration of the South" – as the Republic of Cyprus is described? And you know that the European Union recognises the Republic of Cyprus.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much. I would like to say that there has been, just in the past week, progress in confidence-building measures on resolving the conflict in Cyprus. I do not think that using the fact that you are a Member of the European Parliament constantly just to harass and attack Turkey is constructive for a long-term, fair, win-win solution for all the people of Cyprus.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, despite the Turkish Government’s declaration that its priority is EU membership, today’s progress report shows this wanting. Humanist civil rights, particularly for journalists, continue to be undermined and corruption is widespread.  The opportunity for reopening talks in Cyprus following the welcome election of Mustafa Akıncı in occupied northern Cyprus has been undermined by Ankara’s attitude to Cyprus’s oil exploration rights. Meanwhile, Turkey, in spite of its NATO membership, remains at best ambivalent towards ISIS terrorism and hostile to Israel. It is also regrettable, on the centenary of the Armenian genocide, that Turkey refuses to open the border with Armenia or recognise this historic crime. Meanwhile, President Erdoğan continues to aggrandise his office into that reminiscent of an Ottoman sultan whilst boosting his ties with Putin’s Russia. Turkey has great geopolitical potential, as has been said by many, as a strategic country with huge economic and energy security roles and a vibrant and rich culture. Let us hope that the muted tone of the period report will be the beginning of a rapprochement rather than a harbinger of a deteriorating relationship between Turkey and the European Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Madam President, it has been ten since Turkey opened negotiations together with my country, or ours, the homeland of Croatia. Here we have been a full member for two years, and when it comes to Turkey, the situation is not so good.  We all acknowledge that Turkey is important to us for strategic reasons and this fact is irrefutable, and it is important to improve dialogue and talks between the European Union and Turkey. But at the same time, we must acknowledge and be aware that the human rights situation in Turkey is not at an enviable level. Likewise, we must be aware that the executive branch is interfering with the judiciary. We also know that the state of the media and freedom of speech is not at an enviable level. We also know that gender equality is not being respected in Turkey. I also know that the Copenhasian criteria are also not respected. These are all facts that do not support advocates of Turkey's approach as early as possible.  The Cyprus issue has not been resolved. From here, I call on the United Nations representative to continue this process of possible reconciliation, the rapprochement between the two sides.  Anyway, I'm not in the way of new chapters being opened because of election rhetoric or election campaigning. Thus, it is necessary to look calmly, taking into account turkey's importance to the European Union, but at the same time taking care to accept European values.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, I categorically do not share the enthusiasm in some of the representatives in this Chamber with regard to the so-called ' progress of Turkey. Today's Turkish power can be characterized as authoritarian, totalitarian and undemocratic, and all this is too far from the so-called " european values, which are much talked about in the Hall. In foreign policy terms, this undemocraticity is expressed in the continued support for Islamic State – financial, military and logistical; the ongoing occupation of Cyprus; continuing provocations to the State of Israel; (c) the continuing trafficking of migrants against Greece and Bulgaria, jeopardising their economy and national security. The unacceptable intervention of the Government of Turkey in the internal affairs of a sovereign member state of the European Union, such as Bulgaria, continues. Internally, we are increasingly lacking in freedom of speech, trampling on journalists' rights, lack of justice and a judicial system; we also have a fraught deed of religious freedoms. Just to remind everyone in the hall, who are otherwise democratic and tolerant, that in Turkey can not ring a bell. This Turkey, today's Turkey is not a European country and who did not understand this will pay for it later.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – A great deal has already been said in this debate. On the one hand, the rapporteur, who has done a great deal of work on this report, criticises. This is right, because in recent years and months there has been a lot going on in Turkey, which is not in line with European values. The examples have already been mentioned.  On the other hand, However, I also note that this rapporteur and that this report wants to open new chapters in the negotiations with Turkey more than ever. Let us not ignore it, ladies and gentlemen, that will be seen in Ankara as a reward and encouragement, whereas as far as I am concerned there is no cause for joy and this is not the signal we want to send. Will I slam the door on Turkey? No, definitely not. We need to keep talking to this important neighbor. We must continue to monitor progress on key benchmarks and, of course, continue to support the development of the rule of law from the bottom up.  But we may also have to look each other in the eye in this Parliament and towards the European Commission. Because we have all gone into a process that is aimed - as we had blinkers on - at membership and membership alone. Perhaps we can also come to the conclusion from both sides that it is better to invest - from a critical spirit - in an alternative partnership. It takes political courage to sometimes deviate from the beaten path and the pre-established standard course. In any case, the EPP is prepared to look at these alternatives from that constructive spirit, and I hope that this realism will also permeate other colleagues.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As we meet every year here to assess whether and what changes have taken place for the better on Turkey's path to accession to the European Union. Today, as always, I would like to focus on one very important aspect, which is also addressed in this report. I am talking about freedom of the press and the judicial processes of journalists who are arrested on various pretexts for allegedly disseminating the views and propaganda of terrorist organisations because of uncomfortable topics for the authorities in Ankara. In 2014, Reporters Without Borders classified Turkey as one of the countries where journalists were the subject of the highest number of arrests, threats, trials and physical attacks. Arrests are a fact and we must, as the European Parliament, insist that ongoing judicial proceedings against journalists be conducted in a transparent manner, in compliance with the law and under appropriate conditions.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Madam President! Turkey is an important strategic partner for the EU. This is political, economic, and that is perhaps why the European Parliament is compromising the Copenhagen criteria of 1993. The Copenhagen criteria have both an economic and a political aspect. The economic criterion of a functioning market economy will probably not cause any problems. But what about the political criteria which require the country to have stable institutions that ensure democracy, the rule of law, respect for human rights and the protection of minorities? It was agreed in 1993 that when accession negotiations begin, it is a prerequisite that the candidate country meets the political criterion.  Turkey lacks European values. Freedom of expression suffers, journalists and union leaders are persecuted, and religious minorities are stalked. In other words, the basic conditions are not working at all. Now colleagues in the Chamber are talking about the opening of new chapters. If Turkey had been a small country, the door would have been closed. I very much agree that an alternative partnership needs to be looked at instead.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). – Ladies and gentlemen, if we really wanted to be honest, objective and reliable today, we would all say with one voice that Turkey is taking 'unpredictable' and is not passing the tests in terms of its assessment of the European Union. Because I believe that there is no progress here, and I call on anyone to point out to me even a small step that has been taken on the key issues. Turkey continues to disrespect and implement the Ankara Protocol, which is a direct insult and provocation to all the Member States of the European Union. Turkey continues to disrespect international law and the law of the sea; it continues to violate rights both inside Turkey and outside Turkey; it continues to hold European territory and create 200,000 European citizens in Cyprus. I believe that the possibility of opening funds for Turkey is a challenge but, at the same time, it is also a reward for Turkey and any incentive to improve in turkey today will be lost. I must point out, however, that there is now a truly essential dialogue to resolve the Cyprus problem and I call on the European Union, the European Parliament and everyone to contribute so that a fair and sustainable solution to the Cyprus problem can really be found, as determined by the positive element of the report on the reunification of Cyprus, the immediate return of the city of Famagusta. , implementation of human rights, implementation of the principles and values of the European Union which Turkey has not adopted and respected to date as it should respect.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, I welcome the fact that the motion tabled by the Committee on Foreign Affairs specifically emphasises the importance of reconciliation with the Kurdish community, while also calling for the Turkish Government to strengthen the cultural and political rights of the Kurds and their equal treatment. In joining the committee on foreign affairs, I also believe that it is important for the European Commission to allocate funds under the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance to programmes to promote socio-economic reintegration of people living in south-east Turkey in order to strengthen the Kurdish resettlement process. Turkey needs to make progress in many areas during the accession process, and one of the key things is the enforcement of the rights of national minorities, including, in particular, improving the situation of the Kurdish community. I hope that this area will be given due prominence during the accession process.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Turkey is a strategic partner for the European Union. Since accession negotiations began in 2005, much progress has been made, but many issues remain on the table.  I am thinking of the incidents that have on several occasions raised doubts about the independence, impartiality and efficiency of the judicial system, the separation of powers and respect for the principle of the rule of law, which are at the heart of the Copenhagen political criteria. I am thinking of the problem of corruption, which is also recorded in the Transparency international report, which places Turkey in 64th place. But critical issues are also recorded in the relationship with the press and the media: "Reporters Without Borders" classified Turkey in 2014 as one of the countries where journalists were most exposed to physical threats and aggression. In short, Turkey is called upon to do much more to meet the Copenhagen criteria. The time has come to align itself with the parameters of the European Union, which necessarily involves the implementation of appropriate and effective reforms. Turkey will have to make these efforts to strengthen its institutions and the process of democratisation, which are essential if it is to be seen as an advanced and mature country.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, we often speak in this Parliament, every time, at every session about the problems of migration, refugees, the energy problems of the European Union.  Turkey is our ally. Turkey is our ally when we talk about 2 million refugees and when we talk about what the possibility of different energy supply means. And because he is our ally, we have the right to talk about the problems that exist for Turkey to advance towards the European Union and joining the European Union. Because these problems exist, because we are allies, we must make it clear that until there are appropriate democratic changes and reforms in Turkey, it cannot become part of the European Union. But that is why I think that the process of negotiation and openness to partners in Turkey, taking everything into account, is a very important moment in order to create regional peace in that part of Europe, that is, the world.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). – The main issue that I think should concern us all is one: there is a decision by the United Nations and the Security Council calling on Turkey to withdraw the invading and occupying troops of Cyprus. That's where we have to start! Why does Turkey not implement the decisions of the United Nations? And not only that: he has carried out ethnic cleansing of the division he conquered in Northern Cyprus. 200,000 Turkish Cypriots have been forced to flee because it has carried out ethnic cleansing. Who has spoken on this issue so far? Everyone talks and says he's the big strategic partner. I challenge all those who claim to undo it because I complain to them, on purpose, that they are paid agents in Turkey and I say so that they can sue me so that the matter can go to court to launch an investigation everywhere around the matter.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Turkey has been a candidate country for 15 years, and accession negotiations were opened ten years ago. Since then, unfortunately, there has been not only any progress, but no: there have been setbacks. Turkey has moved further and further away from the EU's values: freedom of religion, freedom of expression, freedom of the press, freedom of assembly, etc. You have to articulate that, you have to point that out. This does not mean, however, that Turkey is not an important partner of the EU in many respects. We must therefore pause for a moment, reassess the EU's relationship with Turkey and Turkey with the EU and put it on a new footing.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D). Madam President, first of all I would like to express my thanks to my colleague, Mrs Kati Piri, for the work she has done which has been far from easy. However, I will summarise, because I am probably one of the last speakers, the common finding of almost everyone, starting from my right to the other point of the half-circle. The point is one: that in this progress report by Turkey, there is virtually no progress! And the question, ladies and gentlemen, to which we all have to answer, is this: this process which has brought us here, and I am also addressing my dear colleague, Mr Van Orden, is the process that began ten years ago, when the Republic of Cyprus did something that many would never do: with a third of its territory, occupied by Turkey , decided to give a date for the opening of accession negotiations in Turkey, agreeing with all the Member States in our family in the European Union. And we got to this point today. I wonder, then, is there no other method other than the continuous opening of funds to push Turkey in the right direction? That is the question, Mr Van Orden, and please do not call the occupied ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, yes, Turkey still faces issues in relation to freedom of the press, freedom of justice, internet freedom, the construction of the Ilısu dam and the Akkuyu nuclear plant. But, at the same time, Turkey is a strategic partner of the European Union on security and defence issues, on energy security, on economic issues and on foreign policy as well. It is of outstanding strategic importance to the EU in addressing challenges and threats in Europe’s eastern and southern neighbourhood. Turkey is a bridge between Europe, the Middle East and Asia: a country strong both economically and militarily, and the sole NATO member close to the Middle East, Central Asia and the Caucasus. The European Union needs Turkey and Turkey needs the European Union. All the issues with Turkey can be settled in the process of negotiating Turkey’s accession to the European Union.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Madam President, I would like to influence three points on which this Parliament could — and, in my opinion, should — be much more resounding and effective. Firstly, to remove the PKK from the list of terrorist organisations in the European Union and to demand the immediate release of Abdullah Ocalan, which is evident to many of us and to us and, of course, to the Kurdish people, but which is also the only way forward to negotiate a just and lasting peace. Secondly, we must urge Turkey to open the border in Kobane for humanitarian and reconstruction aid. Finally, in these days leading up to the crucial elections of 7 June, there have been dozens of attacks on militants and headquarters of the political partisan HDP. We must demand that Ankara stop instiling or tolerating these attacks and be fully involved in the peace process.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all Members of this House who expressed their support for the Commission’s comprehensive agenda on Turkey. This includes work in crucial areas such as energy, migration, the economy and modernisation of the customs union. This recognises the importance of the shared challenges in EU-Turkey relations. The Commission is committed to developing these relations further. I also share many of your concerns, of course. The rule of law and fundamental freedoms – such as freedom of assembly, freedom of expression, freedom of the media – and the independence of the judiciary are all core principles of democratic societies. It is up to Turkey to ensure that both the legal framework and its implementation in these areas are in line with European standards. The Commission is prepared to work with the new Turkish Parliament and Government on these issues. Regarding the issue of Cyprus, I would like to echo the comments made here today that there is now a window of opportunity to find a lasting solution to this very crucial issue. The Commission would like to encourage all involved to make decisive progress in the settlement talks with the support of the UN. Such progress could also add new momentum to Turkey’s accession process.  To conclude, the Commission underlines that we must be prepared to step up our efforts in further engaging with Turkey after the upcoming elections. The enlargement process provides the most suitable framework for cooperation and performance.  Thank you very much for your attention and for this very rich discussion.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the debate today clearly shows that we need to continue to encourage political and economic reforms in Turkey. This is the best way forward and we should continue down this road. Answering the question by Mr Lambsdorff on whether the EU is the anchor of reforms in Turkey, the Council’s answer is clear: both sides, including Turkey, have much to gain from the process of political and economic reforms.  During the debate, many of you also mentioned energy issues. Let me assure you that the Council fully supports the strengthening of EU-Turkey energy cooperation with the aim of facilitating and integrating energy markets. Here, I would like to refer also to the proposal by the Commission on energy union, which points to Turkey as an important strategic energy partner. The EU is committed to developing energy and climate diplomacy where it can use all its foreign policy instruments. In this debate we also heard several Members calling for the opening of further negotiation chapters, for example Chapters 23 and 24. Let me remind you that negotiating chapters may only be opened in compliance with the rules of the Intergovernmental Conference, according to the established procedures and in line with the negotiation framework. Unanimity in Council is required for this process. As a Presidency, we are committed to continuing the process. Together with the Member States and the Commission we are doing what we can to move things forward.  I shall not take more time and will conclude by recalling that, ultimately, it is Turkey’s own ability and willingness to move forward which will determine the pace of the negotiations. Turkey’s own progress in addressing benchmarks, as well as the requirements of the negotiating framework and accession partnership, continue to be the primary determining factors. Advancing the negotiations will not only require further general reform efforts, but also a great deal of political courage from Turkey. We join the Commission in expressing hope that the EU agenda will be re-energised in Turkey after the elections. I thank you very much for this debate and thank you once again for your attention.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: A motion for a resolution was submitted to me in accordance with Article 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, May 21, 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This proposal relates to the 2014 follow-up report on Turkey and details the country's multiple developments in terms of its status as a candidate country for membership of the European Union. Although this report contains criticisms of Turkey and the Erdogan administration, including respect for fundamental rights, freedom of expression, human rights or justice, we cannot deny that the EU and the report remain in favour of Turkey's enlargement and the arrival of Turkey in the Union. To this end, I have already tabled a motion for a resolution against Turkey's entry into the EU and the cessation of negotiations, especially since Turkey still refuses to recognise the Cypriot state. Turkey, by its history, culture or regime, cannot fundamentally join the EU. Finally, the funding, already important for its pre-accession, risks becoming unsustainable if we have to allocate an effective part of the budget to Turkey if it were to join the EU.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Commissioner for European Neighbourhood Policy and Enlargement Negotiations has acknowledged that he wants to place Turkey among the priority countries during this Parliament, and 14 out of 35 chapters have already been opened as part of the accession process. On 29 May 2005, during the referendum on the draft European Constitution, the French voted overwhelmingly against it, in part because they did not want Turkey to join the European Union. Ten years later, under American pressure, EU leaders are still ready to accept everything and turn a blind eye to many areas of darkness: the situation of minorities, freedom of expression, respect for fundamental rights, official recognition of the legal existence of the Cypriot Republic, Turkey's financial capacity...  Moreover, by constantly advocating enlargement, the European Union is no longer functioning, this is a reality. If there were to be further enlargement, then the European peoples should be consulted. It is the very foundation of democracy. There is no doubt then that under these conditions Turkey would not enter the European Union.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Ethiopia (2015/2703 (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, I welcome the opportunity to discuss the situation in Ethiopia just four days before elections take place there. It is indeed important that we can exchange views on this very important country. To start with, the Commission wishes to recognise Ethiopia’s active role in regional and international efforts to build a more secure and peaceful Horn of Africa region. Ethiopia is notably leading Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) mediation efforts in South Sudan. It has contributed a significant number of troops to the African Union mission to Somalia, in particular, fighting al-Shabaab with considerable success. This illustrates Ethiopia’s importance as a partner for the European Union in terms of regional peace and stability. We have common interests and similar positions on a number of global issues – on migration and displacement, for instance. Ethiopia is a key country of origin and transit, as well as a destination. It is host to more than 680 000 refugees, with all the difficulties this entails. It is actively involved in the Khartoum Process.  The recent killing of Ethiopian Christian migrants by ISIS in Libya has brought the issue of migration, as well as terrorism, to the top of the agenda in Ethiopia, and the government has expressed an interest in expanding cooperation on these matters with the European Union. On climate change, Ethiopia’s policy in global discussion is in line with the European Union position. The European Union intends to sign the Lima Declaration on cooperation with Ethiopia, as several EU Member States have already done.  In terms of economic development and poverty reduction, Ethiopia is considered in many ways a success story for Africa. The assistance that the EU and its Member States have been providing is bearing fruit in terms of progress towards the Millennium Development Goals for social and economic growth. The IMF estimate for economic growth in the current year, 2015, is 7.5-8.5%, which is rather impressive for the region. Moreover, according to a recent report by the World Bank, poverty in Ethiopia fell by one third between 2000 and 2011. These are remarkable achievements and I am glad that our support contributed to them. But we all know there is another side to the coin: as in many post-conflict situations, democratic transition in Ethiopia is taking time and does not always go smoothly. The Commission is well aware that the political environment is not conducive to transparent, credible and inclusive elections – and this is a concern which we have raised with the government during our Article 8 political dialogues and bilateral meetings, including at the highest level. We have repeatedly highlighted the need for genuine political dialogue with the opposition, and for full respect for freedom of speech, freedom of association and freedom of the press, as provided for by the Ethiopian Constitution. The government’s line is that their primary concern is stability and security for their people, and that they cannot permit destabilisation of the country which would jeopardise social and economic progress. Thus, we cannot say that we agree on everything, but we have an ongoing open dialogue on these issues, sometimes with constructive results. We are, for example, discussing the possibility of cooperating on improving the quality of the Ethiopian media, both public and private, as an outcome of a recent Article 8 dialogue on the media. Turning to the elections, you are all aware that progress in following up implementation of the recommendations of previous election observation missions has been lacking. The reports of 2005 and 2010 have unfortunately been rejected. We have not received an invitation for the elections that will take place next Sunday, and therefore the European Union will not send an election observation mission. Similarly, we have decided against financially supporting the UNDP electoral programme. The situation of journalists, bloggers, members of the opposition and other individuals is a major cause for concern. They have been imprisoned for having expressed their opinions publicly. The space for the media and political parties has been gradually reduced since just before the start of the electoral period in 2014. The EU delegation, together with Member States present in Addis Ababa, is closely following the situation and monitors all the relevant trials. We also discuss these issues, including the use of the anti-terrorism proclamation to stifle dissent, with the Ethiopian authorities, and the authorities are fully aware of our concerns and positions. Our global partnership with Ethiopia therefore does not mean that the European Union is indifferent to the difficulties that the Ethiopian population continues to face, as discussed in the Human Rights Subcommittee meetings in January this year and in September 2014, when the EU issued a statement on the political and human rights situation in Ethiopia. We will certainly continue to follow the situation closely and to react publicly when necessary. I will be happy to hear your views on EU engagement with Ethiopia.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, with a population of 94 million, Ethiopia is the second most posse country in Africa and one of the key countries for the stability and development of a continent that certainly has strategic importance for our European security precisely for all the reasons that you, Commissioner, have mentioned before.  That is why we look with concern at the narrowing of democratic freedoms, and this is evidenced by the imprisonment of opposition politicians and journalists critical of the ruling People's Revolutionary Democratic Front. As in other African countries, Ethiopia has a visible link between lack of freedom, good governance and poverty. It is therefore important that this weekend's elections are fair, free, that the government is currently and unconditionally free political prisoners and journalists. Affirmation of the legal state and the initiation of an inclusive reconciliation process are indeed a key precondition for sustainable development in Ethiopia. Our development cooperation must therefore be geared towards these objectives, to support Ethiopia and as an important partner in the region. Why? Because it is important for us that Ethiopia continues with constructive regional cooperation. Although a poor state, today it accepts more than 680,000 refugees, and it is also important to us that Ethiopia remains a reliable partner in the fight against radical and terrorist organisations such as Al Shabaab. But that is why, because we want Ethiopia as a strong partner we must stand up for respect for human rights in Ethiopia, promote good governance and the rule of law. We expect the government to initiate a serious credible dialogue process with the opposition in order to achieve national reconciliation and deepen the democratisation process.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ethiopia is a key player in peace in the Horn of Africa region, Somalia, Eritrea and South Sudan, but in order to play its international role, peace must also be achieved internally.  There can be no development aid without progress in the democratisation process in the country. Ethiopia is preparing to vote on Sunday, as we have just heard. However, we are already aware of the outcome of this vote. The Union has chosen not to send observers for this election. Mr President, we are the main providers of aid to this country. There are still too many, too many, abuses in the country today. Urgessa Danana, Obsa Abdissa, Tadesse Sime (young students), Birehanu Diriba (teacher): these are just some of the names of people arrested by the Government of Italy, identified in recent days by the League for Human Rights of the Horn of Africa. 50 were arrested at a student demonstration, 20 injured – this in April alone – in a country where the media is gagged. Bloggers, such as the one belonging to the group "Zone 9", who have been in prison for a year without trial, and journalists are intimidated and arrested on a daily basis. Not even an EU passport stops the government's abuse of information: swedish journalists Martin Schibbye and Joan Person, arrested in 2011 and released after 14 months in prison, have discovered this.  Ethiopia has been experiencing an economic boom in recent years. The time has come for the regime to also make progress towards a fairer society that is respectful of the rights of the individual.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Elections will be held soon in Ethiopia. Although there has long been a restriction on civil liberties, media freedom, and many irregularities have been reported in previous elections – as the Commissioner has just said – the European Union continues to provide assistance to Ethiopia through the m.in. European Development Fund. We must therefore at least ensure effective control of the spending of these funds, since there are problems with the external observation of elections. Ethiopia is an important country for the European Union, if only from the point of view of the problem of migration. Recently, some 30 Ethiopian refugees, Christians, were brutally murdered by Islamic terrorists in Libya, causing social unrest in Ethiopia. It is therefore absolutely necessary to send an observation mission there – although we know that the European Union has not been invited there – because social unrest can destabilise one of africa's most populous countries and, consequently, increase the number of illegal refugees in Europe.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I have just returned from a mission in Addis Ababa where I spoke with the Prime Minister about the context of the upcoming elections, the situation in the country but also the regional situation. The image and opinion I have of Hailemariam Desalegn are those of a prime minister above the fray. The great interest is that he is foreign to ethnic quarrels but also to religious quarrels. He is a Muslim, Meles Zenawi was a Christian and yet they got along very well. In the context of this country, this is obviously an undeniable quality.  With 5,328 kilometres of borders, Ethiopia faces the fragility of its neighbours. This is all the more risky because Ethiopia is, without a doubt, in the crosshairs of the Islamist movement linked to Al-Qaeda. In January 2014, it agreed to include its troops in the African Union response force in Somalia. I firmly believe that it is essential for the European Union to have an intense political dialogue with this key country in the region. I would remind you that the country has 90 million people. That is not nothing. It is a giant in the Horn of Africa and it obviously plays an important role for stability. The United States, for that matter, has long understood the importance of supporting this country. I believe that we must help Ethiopia in its leadership role in the fight against terrorism in the Horn of Africa. The country was pulled up, albeit some think, by the visionary dimension of the late Prime Minister Meles Zenawi. His successor seems to be part of this continuity, emphasizing modernity, youth and accountability. But it is true that there is a black spot, it is obviously the work that remains to be done on the aspect of human rights. We must help them in this regard by intensifying the political nature of a preferential dialogue with the authorities of that country.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I wonder how Ethiopia can be proposed or said to be a model of poverty eradication in the area, when we are talking about a Government which has made more than ten million hectares of land available to foreign companies, of a government that is launching dam projects, such as Gibe III or Renaissance, built by an Italian multinational, and is also launching large plantations, such as Kuraz, that threaten the Omo River and Lake Turkana, which are the livelihoods of thousands and thousands of people and people living on the river and lake, who are also suffering from intimidation and repression so that they do not resist. This, Commissioner, will cause more hunger, more poverty and more deaths in a country where 80% of the population already lives on less than two dollars a day. I believe that this is a model for the interests of the great transnationals of the European Union, but not for the interests of people living in the country. Please convey to Mrs Mogherini, on behalf of our group, that it will put an end to Western greed. Severing these projects is the most useful thing we can do to fight terror and save lives.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Mr Representative of the Commission, you have left me quite perplexed. You're telling me about an Ethiopia that has nothing to do with the one I know. Everyone knows that elections in Ethiopia are a sham. Ethiopia is the fourth country to receive the most development aid from the European Union and is also the country where election observers sent by this Parliament are not allowed entry; the country where Swedish journalists are imprisoned on the mere charge of having entered the Ogadén area. Independent organizations denounce the systematic persecution of political opponents, independent journalists and bloggers who criticize the government and ethnic groups such as oromo, ogadén, or sidama. The Ethiopian Government does not allow observers or journalists to enter the Ogadén area, where an estimated 30% of women have been raped, many of them by government agents. I wonder what the European Union expects to condemn the Ethiopian Government and to demand immediate respect for human rights. What are we waiting for to condition our aid on the creation of a mission that investigates human rights violations, persecution and torture? The peoples of Ethiopia do not deserve the punishment they suffer at the hands of this government tolerated and aided by the European Union. Can we ensure that no part of the European Union's aid is being used for repression? We have an important responsibility for the suffering of thousands of people and cannot look the other way. Otherwise, we'll be complicit. It's time to act now.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, there are concerns in this Chamber about human rights in Ethiopia. It is only right that Ethiopia should be encouraged to respect the rights of its citizens, but it would be foolish to take a holier-than-thou approach to diplomacy. Take, for example, the issue of villagisation, which revolves around the removal of people to villages in new areas often far from their tribal lands, all in the name of commercialising agriculture. Before emitting the usual gasps of horror, the EU and the Member States need to look in the mirror and genuinely consider whether the foreign aid they have provided is being used to support this policy.  Ethiopia fulfils many humanitarian obligations, as we have heard from the Commissioner: not least, accommodating more than 650 000 refugees, the largest number in Africa, including populations from South Sudan, Eritrea and Somalia. Ethiopia enjoys good relations with the West, and it is essential that this regional power, in a deeply troubled part of the world, is allowed to continue developing its economy alongside regional stability, including that of its promising neighbour Somaliland, which craves and deserves international recognition. Instead of a reactionary response to the crisis in the Mediterranean, and in an attempt to stop further migration, we should pursue instead the proactive development of the country through trade – an area in which the European Union has, of course, been destructive. Ethiopia’s top export (accounting for 28%) is coffee, which can face third-country tariffs of up to 9%. If Africa is truly to be allowed to develop, then the EU must lift its protectionist tariffs and stop mumbling into its own, cheaper coffee.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr President, prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn is likely to be re-elected in Sunday's general election without prejudging the sovereign choice of Ethiopian voters. I hope that the Member States of the European Union will support the Ethiopian government, one of the few islands of stability and development in East Africa. To this day, Europeans are the great absentees of Ethiopian development and let China act supreme in Ethiopia. In addition to increased support for development, through the establishment of European enterprises, more active cooperation, particularly militarily, should be cooperationd with Ethiopia in its fight against radical Islamism, both inside and outside its borders. In return, Ethiopia should be asked to be more effective in combating the emigration of its living forces, particularly via Libya. This illegal emigration puts at risk of death migrants who, in addition to the risk of shipwreck in the Mediterranean, find themselves, as Christians, under threat of massacres committed by the so-called Islamic State in Syria.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Ethiopian citizens will go to the polls on 24 May this year to vote in the general election. However, there is a great concern that elections may not meet basic international standards and their results may prove unreliable due to the repressive political system.  The basis of democracy, modern society and the source of legitimacy of the political system is political pluralism. The holding of elections requires a free and fair procedure and a level playing field for all candidates. The Ethiopian Government should therefore ensure democratic political debate and compliance with the Electoral Code. The fight against corruption and freedom of expression are fundamental foundations for transparent and fair elections.  However, the Ethiopian authorities are taking action to eliminate political opposition through persecution and human rights violations. Known cases of arbitrary arrests of independent journalists and bloggers, detention of political prisoners, displacement of ethnic minorities, discrimination against Christians, as well as extrajudicial executions or torture and sexual violence are crimes committed in large part by ethiopian troops. Union action should affect the Ethiopian authorities in order to ensure that they comply with the Cotonou Agreement on human rights, including freedom of expression, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and to investigate without delay serious allegations of torture and rape of minors in Ogadenie by the Ethiopian armed forces.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Horn of Africa obviously plays a very important role in our security, and Ethiopia is a key element in this. His government gives the impression that it can guarantee this security, and we reward it for it. The current elections, the so-called elections, serve to continue this role. And we, ladies and gentlemen, should not believe that security can be equated with calm. Sustainable security means the rule of law, human rights and that all stakeholders have a say. I and many others are particularly concerned about the situation in Ogaden. And if we do not respond to these concerns, if we do not try to initiate a different development here, then we are really preparing the ground for extremism. Only with the illusion of apparent security will we not be able to combat extremism in this region.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 24 May there will be new elections in Ethiopia, africa's second most populous country. It will be another farce and sad election, because at most the polls will tell us whether the now ruling party, the EPRDF, will have 99%, 99.5% or 100% of the seats.  Unfortunately, this country has the record of journalists imprisoned throughout the continent. I personally participated as an observer for the European Union in the elections in Tunisia and Nigeria on the African continent. I have seen in the eyes of those peoples what hope for true democracy means and I say to you, ladies and gentlemen, that double-digit economic growth and a few contingents of soldiers are not enough to forget what the rule of law and civil and political freedoms in Ethiopia are being violated on a daily basis. We must ask ourselves this, we must also ask China, which is colonising it in a savage manner. We can no longer close our eyes and we must always be consistent with our values, whatever the cost.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Mr President, Ethiopia has become a great regional power and a real pole of stability in the Horn of Africa. With a growth rate of 10.5% for 2013, it is reaping the benefits of a development model based on a strong and structured state-led economy. In an African continent hit by numerous civil wars and attempted putschs, Ethiopia is a model for political stability, given its very strong ethnic and religious diversity. Sunday's parliamentary elections are the first since the death in 2012 of the popular Prime Minister Zenawi. They should therefore not be used as a pretext for any moral interference by the European Union and Western countries in the internal affairs of a government that is certainly authoritarian, but which has achieved spectacular results in terms of poverty reduction. The occurrence of disorders could lead to a cycle of destabilization that no one can predict the outcome of. Finally, I regret that the Member States of the Union are paying limited attention to the economic potential of Ethiopia, with whom we would benefit from strengthening our cooperation links with a view to fair economic exchanges.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, any effort by Ethiopia to promote economic growth and poverty reduction, to support the development and well-being that we recognise and applaud can, however, be seriously undermined if, at the same time, there is no effort to ensure sustainable democratic development. And there can be no such development if we restrict freedom of expression and information, which is a necessary condition and, nevertheless, it is one of the fundamental values on which we have built our collective life.  That is why we cannot remain silent as the European Union about what is happening in Ethiopia in general and in particular in view of the forthcoming parliamentary elections. The economic situation cannot be judged independently and does not justify any action to suppress civil and human rights.  Europe has a duty not to leave its citizens and information workers alone, because that is also how we help sustainable development in that country.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Josef Weidenholzer and many other colleagues for speaking on this issue, which sadly does not reach mainstream Western media. I have been working with civil society groups from Ogaden in Ethiopia, and it was important for me to speak out on the situation as there has been no level playing field for opposition voices. Ethiopia will have its elections next week without an EU election observation mission, and this is happening while the government cracks down on journalists and civil society and persecutes the Ogaden Oromo and other ethnic groups, targeting women and children. Rape and torture have been systematically used to spread fear, and the Ogaden region is effectively under government embargo.  Meanwhile, Ethiopia is the fourth largest recipient of EU aid and receives 45% of its budget through foreign aid. The EU must make a clear public statement, outlining its concerns about the upcoming elections before 24 May and making clear its commitment to human rights and democracy in solidarity with the people of Ethiopia. It must also ensure the EU aid money is not being used or implicated in ethnic persecution and human rights violations. A more secure and peaceful Ethiopia must not come at the price of human rights abuses or sham elections with no healthy opposition. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for taking my blue card, Mrs Ward. Do you not accept why everybody in this Chamber is concerned about allegations of human rights abuse? The greatest threat to the Horn of Africa is the rise of Islamic fundamentalism. Do you not agree with me that Ethiopia should actually be given credit for the huge work she is doing to combat extremism in that area, and for actually being able to have a far better approach to women’s rights and children’s rights than that which is being offered by Islamic fundamentalists?

name: Julie WARD
text: blue-card answer. – I spend a lot of my time working with civil society groups and I work with unrepresented people who have no voice. I speak here, I use my position to give power and voice to those people who do not have a voice. The organisations that I have worked for have brought forward huge abuses of human rights in respect of violence against women and girls in Ethiopia by the government there. So yes, I stand up for human rights, and I think one of the worst threats against our security and democracy is the fact that we are not represented equally in the world. Women and men do not have equal representation. I see that as a massive problem for us in society.  (Interjection from the questioner) I have answered the question. The biggest threat, Mr Carver, is the threat that men hold the balance of power.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, the elections in Ethiopia, scheduled for 24 May, will not be fair or free. The recommendations of the European and other election observation missions of 2005 and 2010 were neither received nor followed by the government. This is the real reason why there will be no European election observation mission this year and not, as the government says in its propaganda, for financial reasons.  The High Representative followed the recommendations of this Parliament.  Opposition parties say the eprdf in power has undermined their efforts to register candidates. Since last year, more members of opposition parties have again been arrested and persecuted. The only member of the opposition in Parliament will not run for re-election due to state interference in his party. Political pluralism and freedoms of expression, association and the press are much more restricted today than ten years ago, when I was Head of the Election Observation Mission in Ethiopia. No other African country has so many journalists and so many bloggers arrested, falsely accused of terrorism, such as Eskinder Nega and Reeyot Alemu and many others.  Ethiopia is africa's largest beneficiary of development aid by the European Union and is a key ally of the European Union and the United States on security in the region, which explains the unresothing about the serious human rights violations, the undemocratic laws in Ethiopia and the fierce repression of its Oromo majority and its minorities , in particular in Ogaden.  The European Union must be audible, requiring the Ethiopian government to release all journalists and political opponents, including Andargachew Tsige, an Ethiopian and British citizen, an opposition leader in exile, who was kidnapped in July 2014 in Yemen and extradited to Ethiopia. By not promoting voices for democracy in Ethiopia, the European Union is betraying its values and promoting interreligious tensions, anti-Western extremism in the country, a counterproductive sentiment against Ethiopia's interests and against our interests. This is a strategic country in the region. We can't keep our mouths shut. We have to demand a change of strategy, of policy for Ethiopia, which is, in fact, where we have immense influence and that effectively makes a difference. I'm counting on you, Mr. Stylianides!

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, the situation in Ethiopia is alarming and calls for alarm in several respects. There will be parliamentary elections in Ethiopia on Sunday, with pluralism of the party system only declaratively present and repression being carried out against opposition parties.  Media freedom as one of the founding principles of democracy is not only limited, but journalists are put in a position to choose between self-censorship or arrest, and many are forced to flee their own country. Although mostly Christian, Ethiopia is today the 22nd country in the world to persecute Christians.  Christians are persecuted by extreme groups advocating the creation of the Islamic State, which in Islam cannot have a foothold or justify violence by invoking God. We must fight them more vigorously together. It also deeply disturbs the violent programme of resettlement of populations from rural areas under the guise of improving their living conditions.  Agricultural is important for the local population, it provides them with life, therefore it is necessary to oppose and urgently stop the violent snatching of agricultural land from the hands of the local population.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, too little is still being done for Ethiopia, one of africa's countries with the greatest economic and social difficulties.  The most worrying thing in this country is one of the lowest life expectancies in the world, which is no more than 49 years. The main reason for high mortality is the lack of the main good for the human being - water. Even today, women have to walk several kilometres to reach the very few wells present, and it is estimated that in Ethiopia every 20 seconds a person dies from water shortages and the consequences of poor hygiene conditions. The country is also facing a very high rate of emigration, which forces even educated young people to escape unemployment by looking for work elsewhere. Another issue of concern is the difficult coexistence between Christians and Muslims.  The local government has in recent days put in place a major investment plan for industrial development. This is certainly a good thing, but it is useless if the emergencies preventing the population from living in acceptable conditions are not resolved first.  Europe should be able to take more concrete action to relieve the country of this serious situation and to guarantee conditions of liveability.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, on 19 April ISIS released a video of the beheading in Libya of thirty Christians from Ethiopia with the aim of terrorizing the population of Ethiopia, a country in which two thirds of its 100 million inhabitants are Christians. The aim of the Jihadists is to use religion and poverty in Ethiopia to promote their dark interests. But today, hundreds of thousands of Ethiopian men and women are forced to flee their poverty-hit country, unemployment, political instability, and the arrests of dissidents. The conditions for democratic elections, freedom of the press and the rights of the opposition must therefore be guaranteed. We are therefore seriously concerned about the situation of this populous Christian country and the European Union must contribute to the stability of the region, to the economic development of Ethiopia, to the functioning of the rule of law and to the protection of democratic rights. Ethiopia must, at last, cease to be a vine for large Chinese and Italian multinational companies.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, in this Parliament I feel that sometimes we debate exclusively. This discussion looks a bit like that discussion we had when we talked about Turkey. Let's just say to ourses those things that are positive and good for Ethiopia, those things that are useful for the European Union, for Europe. If it were in Europe, Ethiopia would be the largest country by population. Ethiopia today is a factor of stability in a very restless part of the world and in a way it is about protecting our interests in that world. And that is why I am in charge of continuing to help Ethiopia, but of course I am also in charge of it, which is what colleagues speak for and point to the undemocratic actions of the current government.  However, I ask everyone here to take into account and try to balance values when we talk about Ethiopia, Turkey or whenever we talk about a country for which we have a special interest.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have heard the debate: here, depending on who speaks, someone says that Ethiopia is a disaster, someone else says that GDP is 10 % – Europe had 10 % GDP! – some say that every x second an Ethiopic dies and someone else says that they are finally coming out of poverty. Get along! However, in my opinion, over and above Ethiopia, perhaps we should talk more about Europe. Do we want to talk about our elders? Do we want to talk about our young people out of work? Or do we want to talk about Libya? Where the Europeans, the people who speak here, these hypocrites who are here, bombed Libya and Gaddafi, and now we suck, in Libya. We have the crap and illegal immigrants arrive with terrorists, with boats, as happened today in Italy. And we have a government of farabutti in Italy that says that's not true. So this is Africa that Europe means?  Wake up!!

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, Ethiopia is certainly a very important partner of the European Union. It is a key state with an important strategic position in the area, although I am deeply concerned that elections in Ethiopia will not meet international or African Union standards for fairness or credibility due to a repressive political environment and efforts by the Ethiopian Government to limit political pluralism and the independent media. Ethiopia now has the second largest number of journalists in exile in the world, and the highest number of imprisoned journalists in Africa. Opposition parties have routinely been denied access to state media and prevented from holding public campaign events. The ruling party has used its control over municipal governments to deny permission for opposition rallies and, on several occasions, police have forcibly disbanded and arrested peaceful protesters. These kinds of violations of human rights and the right to freedom are not acceptable and must be formally condemned.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this debate at such a timely moment. I agree with most of the concerns you have raised on our partnership, but this partnership has many aspects and facets, some more controversial than others. We should bear in mind the substantial positive developments that this country and its people have seen, as well as the constructive and critical role in the region and beyond that Ethiopia plays.  Our aim is to continue to engage with Ethiopia while strengthening our messages on democratisation, on human rights, on fundamental freedoms. After the heat of the elections we will certainly further deepen our engagement with the authorities on the long-term democratisation of the country. If Ethiopia wants to maintain stability and to achieve middle income status by 2025, it is essential that the population is provided with the opportunity to openly express its views.  Federica Mogherini, the High Representative, intends to visit Ethiopia some time soon to see the situation for herself and to personally discuss issues of concern with the country’s leadership. This is the situation. Thank you for your attention and for this very rich debate.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (2015/2704 (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to make a statement on behalf of Vice-President Federica Mogherini on the situation in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which is very fluid.  You are all familiar with the tragic events in Kumanovo in the north of the country close to Kosovo and Serbia. We have expressed our condolences to the families and friends of those killed and injured. We understand that these events were predominantly criminally and not inter-ethnically motivated. The Commission therefore welcomes the fact that all parties, exceptionally, came together in a multi-ethnic way to condemn the activities. One of the parties also played an important role in helping to negotiate a solution without further bloodshed. Let me now turn to the long-term political crisis from which those events cannot be a distraction. In response to the EU’s and others’ calls for political accountability for what is being revealed in the wiretaps, which the opposition are making public, we note the resignation last week of two ministers and the head of state security. We have already said that this is a concrete step towards political accountability and that we hope that this development will contribute to restoring faith in state institutions.  In this context we have also followed the two sets of demonstrations that were held in Skopje on Sunday and Monday. It is important that people were able to freely express their views on both occasions. This was done in a peaceful manner. A calm and appropriate handling from all sides will remain important. From the outset of the political crisis, the European Union has called for the restoration of normal political dialogue between the main government and opposition parties. I welcome that three of your colleagues responded to my colleague Johannes Hahn’s proposal to facilitate dialogue between these two parties. As you will be aware, three distinguished Members of this Parliament, Mr Vajgl, Mr Howitt and Mr Kukan, together with Commissioner Hahn, met here in Strasbourg yesterday and in the early morning hours of today with the Prime Minister of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Mr Gruevski and the leader of the opposition, Mr Zaev. This was an important meeting. It is clear that both sides are taking these facilitation efforts very seriously. In-depth discussions on divergent viewpoints took place and further dialogue will be needed.  The Commission commends the confirmation of the commitment of the parties to the EU integration process and democratic principles as well as their agreement to put the interests of the country first. We urge all sides to continue their engagement in this spirit; we welcome in this respect their readiness to meet again under the umbrella of this facilitation effort. Also, we welcome the fact that the four main party leaders met in Skopje on 14 and 18 May and that they have agreed to meet again on 26 May in an attempt to find a way forward, because the citizens of this country deserve better than a political stalemate. A stalemate that drags on simply does not respond to the aspirations of the population.  We call on the leaders of the country to take their responsibilities seriously and put the interests of the state above those of their parties. In parallel, the European Union has been calling on the relevant authorities to investigate all allegations of potential wrongdoing, including those being made public in the wiretaps, in a transparent and independent manner. The Commission has also sent a team of senior legal experts to look into some of the systemic issues on which the Commission had previously expressed concern. Arising from the wiretaps, these systemic issues need to be addressed to get this candidate country back on the right track as it deserves.  In conclusion: our collective approach to this crisis is a good example of how various EU institutions and services can work together using our various tools to deliver a clear European message. In all of this, we are also working very closely with our international partners on the ground to improve the situation.

name: Eduard KUKAN
