text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the Commissioner for giving a very excellent speech, a very good analysis. He was speaking directly to the point, which was very helpful. First of all, let me express my hope that this discussion here and now will reflect our support to Macedonia, to its people and their European ambitions. I believe that the country is at a turning point. In this difficult situation we should be clear and decisive in carrying our message of support. Macedonia is facing a really difficult political crisis, doubled with the extreme security challenges that would shake the basis of any political system in Europe. After last week’s event in Kumanovo we know how serious the situation can get. The deep political crisis in the country needs to get more of our attention as well.  There are serious revelations coming from the wire-tapping scandal which have to be addressed by the relevant authorities. At the same time, politicians need to address the question of political accountability. In this situation we have to see reflection, political responsibility and more political dialogue. This needs to come from all sides of the political spectrum and across ethnic lines.  In a country with such severe challenges, it is important that the democratic institutions and mechanism work. This concerns especially the parliament, which is the platform for a political dialogue and mechanism for political oversight. It is important that all politicians show responsibility and openness. I mean the politicians in Macedonia, but also the politicians in this very House. Please, let us keep in mind that the European integration processes are in this situation one of the few tools which could help to overcome this crisis. We need to get Macedonia back on track. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" question. – I would like to ask my colleague if he knows when the current inhabitants of this region came to this place. When exactly did they come, in what date?

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: blue-card answer. – I do not know, please explain to me.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we meet on the day after the latest cross-party mediation talks – the contents of which must remain confidential – in a process in which I am proud to take part on behalf of my group. The meeting last night, which was prolonged, dealt with the contentious issues, including commitment to the European perspective agreed by all parties, in a process which is continuing. To my fellow members of the European Parliament, I wish to make some comments of my own, not about the talks, but about the country. Firstly, the one-sided call to end the parliamentary boycott, without taking decisive measures to address the failings of the political institutions, is a partisan, not a cross-party, answer and it is therefore not an answer. Secondly, my group has never actively supported any parliamentary boycott or even the publication of wiretap tapes, and, if jointly we are to succeed, then members of the EPP Group – not Mr Kukan – should show the same discipline by not blaming the opposition, or indeed my own Group. Thirdly, no-one suggests that the leaked surveillance tapes which prompted this crisis are entirely fabricated, and this Parliament should support the demarche from the EU ambassadors that there must be accountability for the wrongdoing identified. Fourthly, the reforms in the very areas which have caused concern – the judiciary, the media, electoral practices, civil society – have already been part of progress reports, action plans and the high-level accession dialogue, so that any fresh commitment to address them must demonstrate why this time it will be different. Fifthly, no-one is above the law but, if an opposition leader is put in jail, our solidarity would be not simply with him but with the very notion of democracy in the country, which itself will be called into question by such a step. Last weekend I stood at the site of the terror attacks in Kumanovo amidst burnt-out houses whose walls were pockmarked with bullet holes and where the view through shattered windows revealed interiors buried in rubble. The families I talked to had hidden for their lives from a 30—hour firefight and suffered the trauma of witnessing 18 people dead. We all hoped that this was a one-off event with no repercussions for inter-ethnic relations, but the families told me they believe the event to be linked to the breakdown of political stability. This lack of trust is, in itself, dangerous. I have repeatedly warned that Europe’s failure to start accession talks risks a return to conflict, and this deadly attack is a tragic and urgent reminder that this warning is crying out to be heard. What happened in Kumanovo, and in the country, may not be the direct responsibility of Europe, but if we expect the political parties of the country to exercise their responsibilities – and we do expect that – then they can reasonably expect Europe to exercise ours.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all, I express my deepest condolences to the families of all the officers who died at the Ministry of The Interior during the police operation. Secondly, I declare my unequivocal support for the territorial integrity and independence and sovereignty of our brotherly state.  There is no doubt that this country is currently in one of its worst political crises. The government in Skopje owes an awful lot of answers, responds to accusations of corruption, responds to recordings that leak into the public domain and shows an undemocratic way of government. Therefore, the local authority owes an explanation to its constituents, to its citizens. On the other hand, I fully support the integration of the state into the European Union and into THE EU, but this is done only through a good neighbourly treaty, this is done only through the outright denial of hate speech, the theft of the common history, the abuse of it, the recognition of all rights and legitimate interests of more than at least 90,000 Macedonian citizens with Bulgarian national consciousness. Strong support on the basis of friendship and on the basis of good neighbourliness.  (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Dzhambazki, I listened carefully to you and I wonder if you really honestly think that FYROM or the Republic of Macedonia - as we say in Croatia should become a member of the European Union, NATO for the stability in the Balkans, and that it would be good if your country, your government and Bulgaria, neighbours and Greece help Macedonia along the way, or FYROM, so that no one is offended here? You know why I say The Republic of Macedonia, because I come from Croatia.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear Colleague, as far as I understand it, yes, I believe that, in meeting the European criteria and preserving the rights and legitimate interests of all its citizens, this is the only option for that country to maintain its territorial integrity – respecting European criteria and preserving the rights and legitimate interests of all its citizens and achieving a neighbourhood treaty with all its neighbours.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, – Honourable President-in-Office, Honourable Commissioner, I, too, would like to thank you for your excellent words and the very precise introduction you have given us in this debate. We have recently supported Macedonia by a large majority in this House as the country we want in the Membership of the European Union, stressing that it has been fulfilling most of the conditions for starting membership negotiations for many years. That this has not happened before, and at a time when we have opened the door to candidates who are far behind Macedonia in many ways, the only reason is the absurd dispute over the name of the country. Unfortunately, the trigger for today's debate is not only the desire to repeat the positive view of Macedonia's progress as a candidate, but a serious political crisis with the tragic events in Kumanov, which have reminded us that there are still known interstate and inter-ethnic problems in this part of South-Eastern Europe, and that there are new threats of aggressive Islamic chauvinism and already transparent attempts to instigate Macedonia into Russia's geostratetic plans. The situation in Macedonia requires more understanding of the European Union for this potential member. It is time to find a compromise for the name or to start negotiations with Macedonia and remove this problem until their conclusion. Macedonia must be supported in the context of the comprehensive concept of collective security in Europe in an effort to become a member of NATO. The opposition of neighbouring Greece, a country that expects and enjoys aid and solidarity from us, must be rejected and called upon to take into account common interests. There are some bizarre things going on these days. Today, the Albanian prime minister threatened to block Macedonia's entry into NATO. Macedonian politicians, who are responsible for the escalation of the internal crisis, must take responsibility for the euro-Atlantic future of the country. Just yesterday, in Parliament, after more than ten hours of collusion with the leaders of the two largest Macedonian parties, we adopted a platform to overcome the crisis through dialogue. Let the consensus come to an end to the political crisis and a serious effort to stabilise the country! (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), "blue card" question. Mr President, I listened very carefully to your position and found that you have just committed an impropriety: you have described Greece's dispute with Skopje over the name issue as foolish. And I ask you: If this were to happen in your own country, if Skopje had expansionary aspirations in your own country, if in any way they affected your own country, would you be so comfortable to say what you said?

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: blue-card answer. – I would just like to say that I think that, in these times when we are facing far more important issues in this world, this problem looks like an artificial conflict, and I would say stop it. It makes no sense anymore.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, just two months ago, in the debate on the annual progress report on FYROM, I stressed that the policy of rewarding all those negatives that make up the current situation of the country could only act as a factor in its progress. Unfortunately, the events in Kumanovo confirmed me in the most tragic way. In our neighbouring country there are serious problems in the functioning of the rule of law, respect for human rights, the implementation of the transnational agreement in Ahrid, respect for the principle of good neighbourliness and the lack of democracy in the country. It is precisely this that we, as the European Union, must focus our attention on. All the other complaints about external responsibilities do nothing but embellish reality, to ally this tragic situation and, of course, deepen the crisis. The continuation of this tactic and policy, above all else, is a direct undermining of the principles of the European Union – let us not forget this – and prevents any possibility of progress and development of the country called FYROM.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we in the Green Group, are in full agreement with all our colleagues who say that the situation in Macedonia is serious and even fraught with further danger. While the crisis is obviously regional in its origin and it is fundamentally an internal Macedonian political crisis, it is not entirely surprising that a country waiting for 10 years for the start of the accession negotiations may lose its political balance. Actually, Macedonia has become the Prince of Wales of European accession: it has been waiting for the start for a decade by now. Although we generally support the new Greek Government in breaking with the policies of its predecessors and we welcome its anti-austerity programmes, we think that there is now a very important opportunity for this new Greek Government to break with the past and revise their policies vis-à-vis Macedonia. I commend the efforts of our three colleagues in bringing the Macedonian political leaders to the negotiating table. However, we believe that the promise to continue the talks is not enough now. The government of Macedonia should immediately initiate fully transparent and impartial investigations both into the Kumanovo tragedy and the allegations in the wire-tapping crisis. If they feel unable to do that, they should step down and someone else should do it. We believe there is much to be built upon in Macedonian politics, but this building needs to be done right now. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" question. I will remind you, Mr President, of something that the ambassadors for the F.B.I. government said after their meeting with Mr Gruevski: we have expressed, they say, our concerns to the Prime Minister that the government has not made progress on the publicized allegations of abuse of power. This raises serious doubts as to whether the country's government is committed to the democratic principles and values of the Euro-Atlantic community. The continued failure will damage its progress in the European Union. I would like to make it clear, once again, that Greece supports the European perspective of YROM provided that the Copenhagen criteria are respected and progress is made in good neighbourly relations. Do you not think that this farce should stop, that we should start negotiations on countries that violate international law and their governments show no interest in complying with the principles and values of the European Union?

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: blue-card answer. –  Yes, we are in full agreement, except that there are no negotiations going on for the accession of Macedonia for the time being, precisely because Greece is blocking them.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Stylianides has usefully described the situation in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. He described the violence and killings in the north and he referred to the long-running political crisis in the country. I am sure he understates the seriousness of the nature of the problem, but never mind, because he tells us that the EU is sending legal experts to sort out the systematic problems there. The Commissioner is confident that FYROM can soon be brought back on track in its candidate process in joining the European Union.  Indeed, as recently as 11 March this Parliament voted in favour of the progress report on FYROM’s entry into the EU. Like so many countries before it, it does not matter how corrupt or unsuitable FYROM is. From the European Union’s point of view, what is important is that it brings another entry country into its great empire. Good luck to your legal experts in sorting out its problems. I sincerely wish them luck.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). – Dangerous developments in the FYLOM and the wider region are not surprising. It is a consequence and continuation of the intervention of the United States, NATO and the European Union in the region. The cultivation of state big-mindedness and altruism, taking advantage of Kosovo's protectorate, ethnic and religious conflicts, the change of borders, the rotation of urban governments by tapping into popular dissatisfaction with the anti-labour policy pursued, are becoming tools for the redistribution of wealth, the control of transport networks in the region – especially energy – by business groups. Their own interests and their competition with Russian and American monopolies serve and reflect the European Union's progress reports. The peoples of YROM, the Balkans, lived peacefully in Socialism. In capitalism they tasted barbarism, war, poverty, exploitation. They must be vigilant to cancel the continuation of imperialist interventions, the new ills that the accession of the FYLOM and other countries to the European Union and NATO entails.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – First of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Stylianidis for his clear words. Macedonia - the former Yugoslav Republic, as a candidate country, is facing an internal political crisis and a multi-year blockade of the opening of accession negotiations. Following the tragic incident in Kumanov, the political stabilisation of this country is even more important for it and for the wider region than before. In this context, I welcome and support the launch of a political dialogue between the opposition and the opposition, including the parties of the Macedonian Albanians, which is supposed to lead to the normal functioning of the Macedonian Parliament and to transfer political debate on key issues of the state. I am grateful to Commissioner Hahn and my colleagues Kukan, Howitt and Vajgel for all efforts to support this dialogue.  I also welcome the political culture at the political rallies a few days ago. However, I call for such a dynamic of collusion so that, after a long period of time, the full functioning of the Joint Parliamentary Committee, which is a necessary element in the candidate's accession process, can be fully functioning. I believe that, in the interests of political stability, a better neighbourhood and a credible European perspective, all useful progress in the accession process must be made without anyone losing their face.  We must do everything to ensure that internal, not external causes do not lead to a new conflict hotspot on European soil. Let us not underestimate the political, inter-ing, inter-believe, and post-ottoitarian aspects of the Western Balkans, which so far have not eliminated all sources of instability. The stability, security and European perspective of Macedonia - the former Yugoslav Republic - is not only in its interest, it is also not just its responsibility. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), "blue card" question. Mr President, I wanted to ask my colleague – who calls them Macedonians – where I come from and was born and raised in Kastoria, a prefecture of Macedonia, Greece, what would the honourable Member call me? A Skopje?

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – So if you were born in Greek Macedonia, then it is hard to imagine what you would call yourself someone from Skopje, as you said.  But I don't see much of a problem with that. Everyone has their own identity and can live according to it, whether they live here or there.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has all been I would also like to thank our colleagues Vajgl, Kukan and Howitt and also Commissioner Hahn for their mediation efforts. This is a difficult task, and this difficult task is to reconcile a new beginning without throwing the whole country into chaos or causing peaceful protest to turn into violence. I was in Skopje at the weekend and saw tens of thousands of people demonstrating for a shift towards more democracy, towards more freedom of justice and the media and more activities against corruption and crime. It was not so important that social democrats also spoke. What was much more important was that there were a wide range of NGOs, that there were people of different ethnic backgrounds and that it was peaceful. Peaceful because the demonstrators were peaceful and because the police and the authorities behaved wisely. This attitude brings the country closer to the EU, and that is why we should support it. Our condolences go out to the families and friends of those who died in Kumanovo. But I am quite sure that this is not an ethnic conflict, but a crime. That is why we should be careful in our words that we do not talk about ethnic conflict. I wish our mediators luck and success. This also includes a willingness to compromise, not just on one side, but on all sides. But let us not deceive ourselves: no head of government in the European Union – except for one – would survive if such news about him and the work of his government were revealed, as has happened in recent days about this eavesdropping story.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – Mr President, as representative of the Republic of Bulgaria, I am very concerned about attempts to portray fragile ethnic peace in the region as a hostage to narrow-minded interests. Even Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov today stepped in and talked about how Bulgaria and Albania want to share Macedonia. This is complete nonsense and speculation, of course. The deliberate shift of attention from the severe internal problems in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia with ethnic opposition on a regional basis can shift the focus and have severe long-lasting consequences in the Balkan region. FYROM's only route is to respect the European Union Roadmap, with minority rights one of the chapters.  The rights of the Bulgarian minority in Macedonia are not respected, unlike the rights of other minorities. Condolences for the murdered Macedonian police officers, but the lives and assets of 100,000 Bulgarian citizens and European citizens are at risk in a candidate for membership of the European Union. How can Macedonia enter the European Union when the country does not respect the rights of European citizens? (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), "blue card" question. Thank you, Mr President, for accepting my question. You said earlier that political purposes are holding fyrom country hostage. I wanted you to clarify to me whether this remark is addressed to the leadership of the country which not only does not meet the Copenhagen criteria but also does nothing in this direction, or do you have anything else on your mind?

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Thanks for the question, I only mean Macedonia's negotiations with the European Union. I am a Bulgarian citizen and a European parliamentarian, but three-quarters of my relatives were also born in Macedonia – both Greek and Bulgarian and Macedonian Macedonia. Let's not put our personal biases and our personal past on the fate of a country that must be preserved in its entirety. I just want to say that Macedonia has a duty to respect the rights of all citizens, including the Bulgarian minority in Macedonia.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: – Mr. President, colleagues and colleagues, it is important to note that after the tragic events in Kumanovo, there was no interethnic conflict. It is equally important to note that the protests in a very tense political atmosphere passed without conflict, which speaks to the maturity of Macedonian society and the chances of exiting the crisis. Of course the authorities are most responsible for the events in Macedonia, because of the abuse of power, but it certainly contributed to the loss of the European perspective that the country has had for 10 years. That is why I call on the European institutions to open up a European perspective to Macedonia, and to the colleagues who help in this, Mr. Vajgl, Kukan and Howitt, I congratulate and thank you.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: – Mr President, I think every one of us was shocked by this brutal attack and the killing of Albanians in Kumanovo a couple of days ago.  The situation is very sensitive and of concern. It is like reviving ghosts of the past, and this has to be investigated, including the allegations that it might have been instigated also even by the Gruevski Government, or even with Russian influence. If the Gruevski Government cannot answer this themselves, including the allegations – or the fact – of wiretapping, then they really do have to step down.  Let me take two things that are clear: this attack in Kumanovo, according to my information, was not an Islamist attack, it was mere terrorist criminals. It is also not an ethnic conflict, which is important to say, and I was very glad to see last Sunday Albanian and Slavic Macedonians demonstrating together peacefully in Skopje, even uniting their flags. So this is an important signal that should take us further. One last thing: I would like to call on the European People’s Party to stop defending politicians of their own political family who simply have drifted away from the democratic path and from the rule of law.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Karol KARSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to ask President Lunacek, because you come from a country in such a place in Europe – far enough, but also close enough to the Balkans. What is your view on the name of this country? I have the impression that it is hard to live in a country – it is difficult for it to be a stable state that citizens do not even know what their country should be called. However, I have a question about what this problem looks like from your point of view.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you Mr Karski for this question. It gives me the chance to talk about the part that I did not manage to mention in my first one minute.  I would support very strongly all of those in this House who call on the Greek Government – on the Tsipras government which I personally, and my political group, have lots of sympathies with, in their fight against austerity and to get the social situation back on track – to really be a government that can help people, with the support of the European Union.  But I think the Tsipras government could also take the chance of making something new in the European Union, paving the way for an agreement on the name of Macedonia, and let Macedonia start accession negotiations with the European Union.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Gruevski, on the one hand, and Zaev, on the other, met here yesterday. We have sought mediation, difficult mediation between two parties that are in a fairly fiery political debate situation. Meanwhile, we see people in Macedonia parading through the streets, in a climate that is becoming increasingly incandescent. I believe that this is also, in part, the result of 10 years or more waiting in the process of accession to the European Union, which has meant that, instead of making progress for that people in moving towards the rule of law, steps have been taken backwards.  So I believe that here we, ladies and gentlemen, must ask ourselves whether we have any responsibility, as the European Union, for having wasted so much time, and especially whether some States have had responsibilities. I would like to take up the appeal made by Mrs Lunacek, especially to the Greek Government, which has just taken office, to make some important progress in this respect.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, in December 2012, the European Council unanimously decided that, in order to have a European perspective, the FYLOM must promote and respect good neighbourly relations, implement the necessary reforms and contribute to resolving the naming issue under the auspices of the UN. Does anyone in this Chamber believe that the Greeks will surrender two and a half thousand years of history, culture and heritage to agree to the unconditional signing of the FYROM baptism certificate? Does anyone really believe that if you call them Macedonians, Thracians, Spartans, Athenians, then does this state formation really have a place in the European Union? YROM has open fronts on the outside but mainly on the inside. Simply refer to the progress reports of the Commission or the OSCE, ask yourself why the FYLOM is in conflict with Greece, Bulgaria - for historical reasons - and Albania - for racial minority reasons. Consider whether Kumanovo today, or Tetovo in the past, are minor events. Travel to Perlepe, Ahrid and the Monastery and talk about Macedonianism. You'll be surprised by the answers. It is difficult for Greece to stoically accept the constant insults, even from representatives of Member States of the European Union, and their constant reference to the 'bad Greeks' who deny the European perspective of THEROM. Intransigence and ambiguity have certain limits. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: blue-card question. – Indeed, this should not be a philosophical discussion: what name? what region? what to call citizens born in Greek Macedonia and in the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia? By the way, some countries have recognised Macedonia under the name of Macedonia because the question came up for them even later.  But my question is: this is very much about regional cooperation, about engagement and really practical things that might be changed because of bilateral and multilateral relations. I ask you, what are the practical steps you might recall from the Greek side, recently, taken in order to involve Macedonia in the regional cooperation and to help this country to undertake some of the reforms it so needs?

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), "blue card" answer. – The country of Skopje should not express alytic and expansive aspirations against other countries, such as neighbouring countries: Bulgaria, Albania and Greece.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, two months ago, when we discussed Macedonia, I was saying that even though it was a progress report on Macedonia, it was difficult to use that word and that it was more stagnation than progress. Right now, we are all wondering if this is really something worse, that is, a regression in the face of the ongoing political crisis. In fact, Macedonia's big problem comes from this lack of a culture of compromise, of genuine dialogue. On the one hand, I welcome, like the other colleagues, the fact that a troika of the European Parliament (Kukan, Vajgl, Howitt) is trying to unblock the situation and, on the other hand, I still wonder what is the strategy of the Socialists who, at the same time, with important figures, are on the streets to challenge the government. This is not an easy attitude to read, both in negotiation and on the street. I am glad that Mrs Lunacek is interested in the relationship between the EPP and the rule of law, on the major issues, but I would also like to see the same attitude developed towards socialist prime ministers in Europe and governments that have condemned ministers in their ranks, for example in Romania. You may not have heard of it, but I think we have to be fair and not use the street to demolish institutions, and that is not the epp issue, it is a very serious political crisis. I would like to add, unlike what the Socialists, Liberals and Greens are saying, that there is an ethnic dimension to this political crisis, and it is very dangerous. It is not enough to hear the Socialists, Liberals and Greens say that this is not an ethnic problem. As you well know, the region can explode at any time. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: blue-card question. – Mr Preda, this is one thing that as Greens we criticise – be it EPP, Social Democrats and even sometimes our own people where they are in government – so do not worry, that is not our problem here. But what I meant was what we have seen – and I do not refer to the debate yesterday we had with Mr Orbán, but am now referring to Mr Gruevski – that some of your political family have still been on his side even though he has been going a very sort of authoritarian way recently – for more than just months. That is something I think you should not keep defending.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: "blue card" answer to Ulrike Lunacek. "Madam, what do you say to all this?" I do not want to turn this debate, which deals with a very serious political crisis in a country that is very important to us, into a debate on the EPP group. I do not believe that the right attitude to unblock political crises is to find scapegoats because you are now politically weaker and you want to occupy the political agenda, you Greens.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Mr President, do you not understand that this is not a dispute between the EPP, between the Greens, the left and the like? Here the question is about the territorial integrity and security of a country in the Balkans, and those who are from the Balkans know what that means. This is about ethnic opposition, possible and dangerous, this is about human rights violations, this is about corruption. In my opinion, the dispute is not about the relationship between the left and the right, but about the security of the whole region.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: "blue card" answer. "Absolutely agree, sir, we need to focus on Macedonia. Nevertheless, we must never forget that we can also do harm by encouraging solutions in the Balkans, in different countries, that are more a matter of ideological improvisation. Unfortunately, we have had many examples of this in the recent past.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, I believe that the blue card institution between Mr Preda and Mrs Lunacek has been abused. I did not hear any questions from Mrs Lunacek, but they were just having a political debate.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: – Mr President, there used to be times when Macedonia was among the forerunners for EU accession in the Western Balkans. However, today we are facing a very deep political crisis and we should be aware that it is not just a momentous situation; it is about very fundamental issues which are enshrined in the European idea. We should ask ourselves how we got here and how the European Union underestimated what was going on in the Republic of Macedonia for such a long time as a way of government, establishing quite an authoritarian regime which is subduing the media and the economy and putting pressure on the judiciary. This is a very serious problem.  I was there on Sunday at the civil rally which gathered in Skopje. I was not there to teach or preach; I was there to listen, and I saw people of different ethnic origins, of different political affiliations and people from NGOs and from the media. They were standing together for democratic values. As one of the speakers from the students’ movement said, it is not about power, but about how the state will be functioning, and this should not be repeated. This is what we have to take into consideration in our attitude towards the situation in Macedonia, because the crisis is deep and the EU has responsibility.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: – Mr President, honourable members, the leader of the Bulgarian Liberal Party Movement for Rights and Freedoms, Mr Lyuthvi Meston, wrote at the beginning of the year a letter to all liberal leaders in Europe that it was time for the European Union to open its doors to the Western Balkans. The situation in Macedonia proves the insight of this thesis and provokes us to insist on a proactive Union policy for its faster integration as a guarantee to preserve its territorial integrity and peace therein. The leadership of the state must make efforts to resolve the political crisis and Macedonia must quickly move towards European values and standards, towards guaranteeing rights and freedoms, including the Bulgarian community. A good example is the Bulgarian ethnic model, which has ensured a peaceful transition from totalitarianism to democracy in our country.  I hope that Macedonia and the European Union will meet on the field of democracy and respect for the rights of all citizens.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first I wanted to greet the audience present: you who are here watching, look at how many Members are busy. Do you know how much this game costs? €250 million per year. This is the Europe of squandering. As far as FYROM is concerned – because it is called FYROM and not Macedonia – none of you spoke of a very, very particular interest that the United States has, namely not to let the gas pipeline through. And perhaps it is not really the United States that is fomenting the movements that are taking place at FYROM, precisely because this is not the case and because FYROM, so to speak, is moving towards Russian issues, because FYROM, by the way, is looking at different solutions? Do you not think that perhaps the Americans, as they do all over the world, want to put their beaks in it and when they fail to foment revolutions, they foment groups to rebel perhaps on something else? Think about it a little better instead of sleeping all day.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Mr. Buonanno, thank you for accepting my blue card. I just can't sit here without reacting anymore. I came in at 9:00 and I'm sitting here so far. Your President Salvini came in this morning and talked about migration, came in and the first thing he said was, "This place is an empty, yet so important topic. Why is there no one here?" When he finished speaking, he came out and never showed up again. Do you find that a hypocritical speech, as this speech of yours is hypocritical?

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: That wasn't the question.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: blue-card question. – My question is really simple and short. Do you stay here in the plenary session all the time?

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: answer to a "blue card" question. You should first educate yourself on my history: I am also the mayor, in Italy, voted for 21 years in a row. Be that as it may, I'm here, look at my data and my voting percentages and what I do. I think I am in the top 50 of all 751 Members from Strasbourg and Brussels. And since I'm someone who says things in my face, I say what I think; I am a man of the people, sometimes I also say bad words, but I prefer to say sometimes the swear words than to be a hypocrite like so many of you – I am not dealing with everyone but with a little yes – who perhaps make salamelecchi, laugh and joke and then care about the European people. Clear?

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr President, Macedonia's political elite must do its utmost to address the current crisis and not seek opposition and conflict, both internally and externally. Unfortunately, over the past 9 years, Prime Minister Gruevski has distanced the country from its European path, which we here have always supported and will continue to support. However, we have not seen a will to improve democratic practices and ensure equality for all citizens, regardless of their national identity. On the contrary – the country's relations with the neighbors deteriorated as a result of the reluctance to accept the outstretched hand and to put aside the vicious practices of the totalitarian Communist Yugoslav past as manipulation of historical facts at the expense of the aggressive imposition of a newly formed Macedonian identity.  The European Union has an interest in a stable and democratic Macedonia in which media freedom and separation of powers are guaranteed and the personal and collective rights and freedoms of Macedonian citizens are respected. The question marks remain over the country's geopolitical choices. Macedonia does not support sanctions against the Russian Federation, Lavrov just allowed himself to say that Macedonia is a victim of the West and Bulgaria and Albania want to share it, macedonia's attitude to the crisis in Ukraine remains unclear.  Macedonian citizens deserve transparent and responsible governance to ensure rapid acceptance into the European Union and it is unacceptable to become hostages to the political survival of one party leader or another who is trying to personified the country!  (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. "Although I agree with many things, Congressman, what you have said, I do have a serious problem here. Do you think it is appropriate, I am asking whether you really think it is appropriate to unilaterally push responsibility to Macedonia, while the European institutions have completely unsked the enlargement prospects of this country – and other countries – or their belief in it. I think there should be at least two parties responsible here. The Balkans have always been powder kegs, and Europe can't say, "Oh, my God, you're the bad guys and we're good!" No, no, no.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Of course, dear Colleague, that responsibility is always a two-way street, as well as solidarity – the outstretched hand must be accepted by the other side. But since it has been an independent country for more than 25 years Macedonia has failed to create such a climate with its neighbours, and to prove now on a European stage that it really wants good neighbourliness, because the imposition, I said in my statement, of an identity that does not correspond to the historical truth – there is no evidence in the story of one – there can be no conflict in the present. The present and future, dependent on the assessments of the past, is not good, which is why we have made to Macedonia many times in our progress reports these recommendations, which are selectively read in Skopje.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. Commissioner, Macedonia is a geographically small country, but it is plagued by serious internal ruins in a turbulent geopolitical environment. While the majority in the Union perceives Macedonia through the prism of the name dispute with Greece, the general situation is deteriorating year after year. Accusations of illegal wiretapping of thousands of citizens, threats against journalists, accusations of manipulation of terrorism, but also the events of terrorism, widespread corruption, often unrecognizable differentiation between party and state activities - are just some of the problems. The consequence is a profound giveaway in society without the will for elementary political dialogue. This is a realistic picture of a country that started its Euro-immigration journey before Croatia.  Maintaining the status quo will only multiply the problems facing the country, but the real danger is that they become chronic or spill over its borders. This requires taking responsibility on all sides and an urgent political solution. Such a solution can be contributed by the European Union, for example, if, for example, the members - Macedonia's neighbours finally give Skopje a sincere opportunity to continue on a path that has been blocked for too long.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Macedonia has been waiting 10 years for accession negotiations. The European Union is also to blame for escalating tensions following last year's elections. Although electoral observers did not find significant shortcomings, incomprehensible statements from both the Commission and some Member States were a welcome pretext for the second largest party to question the results of the elections and not to take up seats. For example, the Dutch Ambassador identified as a major problem, and I quote: 'The lack of distinguish between party and state activities during the election campaign'. According to such a criterion, we can call into question all the results of the elections in half of the Member States. I'm a friend of Macedonia. I last visited him just a few weeks ago. Despite the deep internal crisis, Macedonia is still a democratic state belonging to the European Union. I appeal to the Commission to urgently start negotiations on Macedonia's accession with an open end. At the same time, I am appealing to the politicians and citizens of Greece to be accommodating on the name of the young republic. Because stability in the Balkans is in the interests of all of us.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Mr. Vice President Czarnecki, Commissioner Stilianides, thank you for your presentation. First of all, I want to express my support for Macedonia on its European path and as a relatively neighbouring country, since I come from Croatia, but also a country that passed with Macedonia in parallel, and I am sorry that those who initialled the Stabilisation and Association Agreement back in 2000 at the Zagreb summit, 15 years later are unable to open accession negotiations.  I think it's bad and it's not good and that frustration is part of what we've been seeing over the last few weeks. I believe that the Macedonian opposition, therefore the Socialist Party should not boycott Parliament but participate in it, that the ruling coalition should also accept political responsibilities for what is not good in this situation, and that by joint efforts of both Commissioner Hahn and our fellow deputies we should find a package that would stabilise the country, not to repeat such terrorist attacks as it was in Kumanovo and it is good that albanian ethnic parties did not react at all to provocations. In this sense, there is a great political responsibility on the European Union, for macedonia's quality European future.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – A country that has developed so successfully over the last decade is under difficult trials. There are at least two reasons for the destabilisation of Macedonia. The first is political. After a heavy election defeat, the opposition Socialists boycotted, demonstrated, even eavesdropped on the government after a heavy election defeat, accusing the government of eavesdropping. Given the sharpness of the socialists' moves, we can see that we have already seen a similar story in the case of Bulgaria and Slovenia, as well as Hungary. The terrorist attack in Kuman is another reason for destabilizing. You could even start inter-heat fighting. Over the past decade, inter-interic relations have been successfully rescued in Macedonia on the basis of all-round inclusion. However, macedonian Albanians demanded faster European integration at the cost of a constructive posture. I think that if European integration were to run faster, the situation in Macedonia and the region would be more stable. I fear that vulnerable Macedonia will become a victim of various interests if we do not help it in time.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Mr President, Commissioner, the fact that the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is vulnerable to incidents such as those in Kumanovo shows that there is a serious deficit in the functioning of democracy in the country. The government of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia does not respect the Ohrid Agreement and therefore the rights of the very strong Albanian minority in relation to the local population. But that's not all. The opposition has not sat on the benches of the Parliament in Skopje since the elections; the government has not convinced that an independent investigation is under way into the phone intercepts in which, incidentally, Prime Minister Gruevski's cousin, who is also here in Strasbourg, is also starring – he is accompanying the prime minister, according to the press. Prime Minister Gruevski speaks of a foreign finger in the political life of the country, while Russia, through Sergei Lavrov, sees behind the turmoil caused by the eavesdropping, an attempt to prevent Skopje from participating in the 'Turkish Stream' pipeline. These are all conspiracy scenarios, and it is clear that there is no respect for the rights, not only of Albanians but also of the Roma, and press freedoms are being violated. We have a responsibility to make recommendations to the candidate countries in the region, first of all the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, so that the tension can drop. And, indeed, after all this, does anyone here believe that the only obstacle to the start of the negotiations between the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and the European Union is their difference with Greece? Do we really want to open the door of the Union to a country that circumvents basic principles in the functioning of democracy?

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, first of all, I extend my deepest condolences to the families of the fallen Macedonian police officers who were brutally killed in the kumanovo terrorist attack. I hope that the sponsors of this vandal act will be discovered, the perpetrators punished and that all security measures will be taken so that the same situation does not happen again.  If Macedonia had been admitted to NATO instead of leaving itself in the waiting room, I believe such a merciless event would not have happened. It grieves me that the overall situation has not prompted the Macedonian opposition to return to Parliament, which is the right place to seek the best solutions for the well-being of the Macedonian people and Macedonia's European path.   But the culprit for the dramatic situation in Macedonia should first and foremost be sought in the auspices of the EU, namely the Council, which despite all the European Parliament resolutions still puts obstacles to Macedonia opening negotiations.  If Macedonia had started negotiations with the EU, they would certainly not have attempted to come to power without elections and to attack its sovereignty.  I will repeat once again: Macedonia has met all the necessary conditions and deserved to have negotiations opened for it. The bilateral name problem should be resolved during the negotiations, according to the Model Croatia and Slovenia, as it has proved successful.  Stability in Macedonia is important for the stability of the entire region but also for the EU. Macedonia must no longer be in the waiting room for membership in the European Union and NATO ither for the Macedonian people nor for the credibility of the EU.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: PPE). Mr President, there are four basic conditions for the European Union to develop its cooperation with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and to pave the way for future accession. Firstly, the political system, which has authoritarian characteristics, must be democratised. Secondly, the dominance of organised crime and para-state groups must be stopped. Thirdly, there must be respect for the country's Albanian-speaking minority in order to prevent a repeat of the civil war. Fourthly, the name issue must be resolved with an honest compromise that satisfies both Skopje and Athens. Since I am Greek, and you may think that I give exclusive importance to the fourth point, I call on those who exercise power in Skopje to start their long European course by improving the situation on the first three issues.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, the current situation in Macedonia is very alarming. Government is unstable, interethnic tensions have not been at a higher level for a long time, there is no rule of law, and so is the precondition for normal economic development, and the growing dissatisfaction of citizens has spilled over into the streets.  Adding to this the stalemate in the Euro-Atlantic integration process becomes quite clear that Macedonians have little reason to be optimistic. Turning the current hopelessness into a permanent state could drag the country into ruin and we must prevent that, as Macedonian security services also seem to be backing down, making this combustible situation even more dangerous for the security of the whole of Southeast Europe. And it's up to all of us whether we put out this flame or wait until it blows up into a big fire.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, the problem in Macedonia is not just a problem of the State of Macedonia. This is a problem in the Balkans, not least the European Union itself.  Macedonia's long-standing forced isolation is one of the main causes of its current crisis. We should not absolate the criterion that the parties have decided all their bilateral issues in advance. Absolation means telling all Balkan countries that their membership of the European Union is impossible. Therefore, Mr President, I would like to say that there are themes in the Balkans that can be solved not before, but with the membership of the European Union itself. The integration of the Western Balkans is not because of their political elites, it is not even because of their prime ministers, but because of the civil societies of these young democracies. The European Union must not let the Western Balkans stand in the seemingly neutral field between East and West. Completing, but not least, the integration of the Western Balkans is the most reliable prevention against radicalisation of these young societies. That is why we Bulgarian liberals will prepare a meeting in September to discuss a new integration strategy of all countries in the region.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). – Many MEPs referred to the issue of the name of YROM and its dispute with Greece. I must tell you that the Greek governments over time have shown readiness, compromise on this issue – and they have said so. The problem comes from the other side: it comes from what the MEP of the European People's Party said, Mr Preda, that there is no culture of compromise on the part of the Political System of Skopje and, in particular, on the part of the Gruevski government which, in this way, i.e. by disorienting its people on obsolete issues, such as territorial claims which are essentially hidden under the name issue, wants to draw the attention of the citizens from the current problems in which it displays a completely authoritarian attitude. Therefore, the issue lies on that side and not on greece's side.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr. President, I didn't ask for a blue card. I wanted to point out to you procedurally this: too many blue cards have been given. We are waiting here for the 'Catch-the-Eye' process – I was one of the first to ask to intervene with the 'Catch-the-Eye' process – and it would be wrong if this tactic continued. I would therefore like to suggest that those who are speakers do not use a blue card because that is how they speak twice, and those who use a blue card cannot participate in the 'Catch-the-Eye' process. That's how we can all talk. That's what I've indicated to you informally. I don't want to ask my colleague a question.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Macedonia has found itself in a very difficult situation, and if we spoke about Macedonia a few months ago, its path to European integration and the fulfilment of the conditions for doing so, we have now been able to convince ourselves that, of course, peace is an extremely fragile category. What or where is stuck in the case of Macedonia, of course, before this will show the real time, how much it has influenced external factors, how much conspiracy theories there, how much of course it wants to influence macedonia's geostratetic position from one side or the other... The fact is, however, that Macedonia has, of course, become a barrel of meslace that can explode and can seriously threaten the region, and that is why, of course, parliament is also required, and that is why I would like to thank Mr Vajgel, Kukan and Mr Howitt in particular for the work to be done so far and, above all, wished parliament a great deal of courage, wisdom and impartiality. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Urmas PAET
text: blue card issue. – Almost 10 years ago, Macedonia was one of the western Balkans that had moved towards the European Union and NATO, but then every year it received a 'no' to start, for example, accession talks with the European Union. It is clear that the motivation in this country has decreased enormously over these years, as the European Union has not wanted to start substantive talks.  How do you estimate how much macedonia has received a 'no' for years from both the European Union and NATO, actually affecting the situation that Macedonia tends to reach again today?

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – I think this issue is very much in place and we have also heard some answers in today's debates. It is true, this journey of Macedonia to the European Union has long been dragging on, and it is clear that this has its consequences.  And I would also like to draw attention to this: Macedonia is one of the countries in this area where peace is fragile, and I would, of course, draw attention to Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is also in this process for some time, not so much, but also there, to point out that some activities must start on time, so that there are also problems that we are witnessing in Macedonia.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I have not spoken already; I came in here to the debate and I must say I found it extremely frustrating, like my Greek friend. You allowed one blue card, two blue cards; a lot of them were not even questions. You allowed blue cards under ‘catch the eye’ which I heard previous Presidents saying was not allowed.  I think it has disrupted the debate, and if this is going to continue, nobody would want to come in here. I came in here, like my colleague over there, in good faith. I wanted to listen to the debate; I put up my hand for ‘catch the eye’ and, under the conditions which you have called out, I qualified and you did not call me. What is going on?

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, our political initiative, both Commission and European Parliament, as all of us have already mentioned, is ongoing. It is important to safeguard a constructive approach from all sides so that this initiative achieves its mission. This is very important for me. Vice-President Federica Mogherini and Commissioner Hahn will continue to be closely involved and will be happy to keep you informed of further developments. I think they have the opportunity to inform you of any further developments on this very critical issue.  This has been a very controversial debate, but at the same time a very rich debate. I think now all of us have expressed our wish to have a very concrete outcome of this ongoing initiative by Commissioner Hahn and the Members of the European Parliament.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). Why don't you let me talk? You previously gave the floor to the other colleague, why are you not allowing me to take the floor? Finally, respect me, I'm 93 years old and I've been here since this morning! I want to talk, say why you've violated and won't let me express myself.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I would like to recall Article 162 of our Rules of Procedure, which, in paragraph 12, states: 'Members who have not spoken in a given debate may, not more than once in a part-session, make a written declaration not exceeding 200 words, which is annexed to the full debate report'. Please use this point. I myself use this as an MEP and I also propose that other people who I have not been able to give a voice to benefit from this. Once again, I apologise to all those to whom I have not given a voice. The debate has been closed.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, we need to clarify the rules of operation a little. There are a number of colleagues: I, Mr Jakovčić and others, who often wish to use the 'Catch-the-Eye' procedure. To do this, there must be sufficient time after the end of the speakers. Because you were also present in the debate, if those who are speakers and who are written and know that they will certainly talk about a subject, also exercise the right of the blue card, they deprive, de facto, time from those who are in 'Catch-the-Eye'. Secondly, you in the Bureau can see how many Members have asked to speak in accordance with the 'Catch-the-Eye' procedure and, if they do not exist, use the blue card. However, if there are many speakers, then the person who has asked to speak under the Catch-the-Eye procedure should have priority. So I tell you that, on the subject of Skopje, I first asked to speak in this process [......] and I checked it ... (The President interrupts the speaker) 10 seconds please. Ok, now count 10 seconds. (The President cut off the speaker) (continuation of the previous intervention of Noti Maria) ... So I first asked for the floor for Catch-the-Eye. I checked with the Bureau and I was first. I am not complaining because I was not given the reason but because of the way in which the procedure was carried out. We might as well have all spoken to Catch-the-Eye and not abused the blue card. So I should like to know, and I should like to ask ten questions with the blue card in the next debate. Please very much, organize the discussion .... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Let me simply explain to you. I was here during the debate, I listened to the debate, and then I was waiting for Mr Czarnecki to finish. It is the prerogative of the President to decide how many catch-the-eyes and how many blue cards he or she gives. In the agenda we had five minutes for catch-the-eye, which usually means  one person per group. We also have a practice whereby, when we give catch-the-eye, we look to see who has not yet spoken. Those who have had blue cards are not called in catch-the-eye and those who have not spoken can speak. I am not going to discuss how my colleague was doing that; there is a rule that it is up to the President to decide how many catch-the-eye speeches he or she gives, so this is all I can say. We now have a different debate and I will switch to German. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. – During today's meeting in Strasbourg with my Colleagues in the European Parliament, we discussed the situation in the Republic of Macedonia. The protests and unrest that erupted there a few days ago are also an occasion for the presence in the European Parliament of Macedonian Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski and the leader of the opposition – Zoran Saev.  It is extremely important and positive news that when there is a crisis in Macedonia, the European Union is the intermediary. Moreover, it is also very important that, despite their differences, both politicians categorically prioritise the country's membership of the EU.  The conclusions of this and previous meetings are that this problem is not new and is quite serious. In order not to continue the deepening of the crisis in the country, faster integration of Macedonia is needed. Without the start of negotiations on EU membership, democracy in the country will be in danger.  Attention should also be paid to the fact that the most irritated of the whole situation is Russia. Once again, it tries to interfere in the politics of a country in the Balkans that shares the values of a United Europe, wants to be a member of the European Union and strives to develop democratically.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Eastern Partnership Summit (21-22 May) (2015/2610(RSP)).

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, can you tell us what your policy is going to be during this debate on the blue cards? Will you take one, will you take two, will you take them under catch-the-eye and how many catch-the-eyes are there going to be? I think it is reasonable to ask that because, as you can see, Members are getting totally frustrated with the way things are being done.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Kelly, I understood your question. As you have seen, I have just arrived. I have not seen the whole list. I am going to look at it and I am going to look at the time to see where we stand right now, and then I will decide whether I will take blue cards or not, whether I take one or two or whether I just take them for the first speakers of the Groups, and I will let you know.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, allow me to start by thanking the European Parliament for the opportunity to debate the Eastern Partnership just before the Riga Summit, which will gather the Heads of State from the European Union and the Eastern Partnership partner countries from 21 to 22 May in Riga. Almost six years ago in Prague, we set out our vision of bringing the relationship between the EU and its Eastern European partners to a new level by deepening our bilateral engagement and building a multilateral framework for cooperation and dialogue.  Since then, we have achieved good progress in our partnership. We have a better understanding of the different interests, needs and ambitions of our partner countries within the Eastern Partnership. In Riga, we will take stock of the considerable achievements we have witnessed since Vilnius and chart a positive agenda for the future.  Since the last Eastern Partnership Summit in Vilnius, the signing of Association Agreements and Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) agreements brought to a new level our cooperation with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine.  The Association Agreements, including DCFTAs, with Georgia and the Republic of Moldova are already provisionally applied and the initial indications are very promising. Trade is already increasing between the EU and the partners concerned.  As regards Ukraine, the recent EU Summit with Ukraine reconfirmed that the provisional application of the Ukrainian DCFTA will start on 1 January 2016. As you are aware, Commissioner Cecilia Malmström, is holding trilateral talks with her Ukrainian and Russian counterparts to ensure that provisional application on 1 January takes place in the best possible environment.  The Riga Summit will be an opportunity to review the early stages of the implementation of Association Agreements and DCFTAs and to demonstrate the EU’s strong commitment to deepening our cooperation. The summit will reaffirm the importance of reforms which consolidate the rule of law and a competitive market economy as the best prospect for guaranteeing a European future for our partners.  We will highlight the EU’s commitment to supporting efforts devoted to advance cooperation in institution-building, mobility and people-to-people contacts, market opportunities and interconnections.   Therefore, I would like to stress that, on the margins of the Riga Summit, three large-scale side events will take place: the media conference on the role of the media in the Eastern Partnership, the civil society conference and the business forum. These events will emphasise the increasing role of civil society and business contacts as an integral part of the Eastern Partnership policy. Let me stress that the EU values our relationship with all six of our Eastern partners and we are ready to work for more tailor-made arrangements with them. For partners with Association Agreements, the path ahead is laid out in those agreements. For the other partners, there is work to be done.  We have reached an understanding with Armenia on the scope of our future relationship and we hope that the Council allows negotiations to begin on a new contractual agreement with Armenia. The relevant negotiating mandate is being prepared.  We currently await Azerbaijan’s ideas on how it sees its future relations with the European Union. Once we have received these, we will give serious consideration as to the kind of relationship that both sides need and expect.  We are also exploring ways to further deepen our critical engagement with Belarus.  We are convinced that developing bilateral relations in this differentiated way is the best way to ensure that all six partners have a stake in the Eastern Partnership and therefore remain committed to this unique framework. We have moved forward in the area of mobility. Since April last year, Moldova has enjoyed a visa-free regime with the Schengen area. Nearly half a million people have been able to take advantage of it.  Both Georgia and Ukraine have made good progress in implementing the benchmarks of their Visa Liberalisation Action Plans. Fulfilling the actions required in the recent Commission progress reports would allow these countries to complete their respective implementation of all the Visa Liberalisation Action Plans’ second-phase benchmarks. The Commission will continue to monitor and to do its utmost to support them and will report on progress by the end of 2015. The finalisation of the negotiations with Belarus on the visa facilitation agreement and readmission agreement and the launch of the Mobility Partnership in June is foreseen.  Let me stress that the Eastern Partnership Riga Summit is taking place in a new geopolitical environment where borders have been changed by force and where partners (and indeed Member States) have been subjected to considerable pressure. Let me stress once again that we do not share the zero-sum thinking based on rival spheres of influence or the use of coercion.  Let me be absolutely clear: neither the Eastern Partnership nor the bilateral relations between the EU and any of its partners have ever, nor will they ever, be directed against anyone. But let me be equally clear, the EU will continue to stand up for our partners as they make free, sovereign choices about their foreign and trade policies.  In addition to being a major opportunity to reconfirm our commitment to the Eastern Partnership, the summit in Riga will also be a valuable occasion to get our partners’ views on the future of the European Neighbourhood Policy. We want to make sure that in redesigning our policy for the future we have listened to our partners and taken their views fully into account. Let me re-state that we offer our Eastern European partners a genuine partnership. We do not impose choices on our partners. Differentiation in our bilateral relations will need to be further enhanced, taking account of each partner`s ambitions and needs. The full engagement of partners’ governments is crucial in bringing about the necessary reforms.  Nevertheless, no government is able to succeed in such an endeavour without the broad support of the people. Successful transformation is only possible if it emerges as a result of joint efforts of society as a whole.  The nurturing of constituencies for reform able to influence national decision-making is imperative. Local authorities, parliamentarians  (including this House), the business community and civil society have a very important role to play in the Eastern Partnership. We therefore count on this House to help us stand with our partners in delivering the chance their citizens desire.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: I now have an answer for Mr Kelly and also for all the others who wanted to know. I will allow at the end one catch—the—eye per political group, and I will take blue cards according to how the debate is going. I will also retain the privilege not to allow blue cards, and I will not take a blue card from anybody who is on the list of speakers for this item.

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, my first two sentences do not count in my speaking time because they are informal. I think it is deplorable that the Commission chair is empty at such an important debate. If this is a signal of the importance which the Commission attaches to the Eastern Partnership programme, then I am sorry for Riga. Now, please start my time. The Eastern Partnership is a well-designed policy of strategic importance and it is very much needed by the EU because it impacts on economics, prosperity and security and because the primary mission of the Union is peace. And it is very much needed by our neighbours because they want to transform themselves in line with the European model. The Eastern Partnership is a work in progress and it will continue, with necessary modifications and reinforcements. There was an attempt by Russia to derail the Eastern Partnership by pressing for Ukraine to refuse to sign it in Vilnius. Euromaidan gave a clear answer and stood up to the Russian pressure, and the people of Ukraine said: we want European values. Then Russia waged a war against their choice, but Russia will fail in trying to stop the Eastern Partnership and the free choices of free peoples. An old rule says ‘When a bear charges, do not retreat’. In Riga, the EU will stick to its plan and will stay on course. When somebody tries to stop you, you have two choices: either to backtrack or to progress further with redoubled energy. The second is our choice because, firstly, it is the strong will of our partners and, secondly, it is in the fundamental interest of the EU and it reflects our values. Thirdly, if we do not defend freedom and democracy in our neighbourhood, then our own freedom, democracy and prosperity will be in danger.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Eastern Partnership has a clear objective. It provides the EU's neighbours with a framework for political and economic cooperation, enabling intensive trade relations and greater social exchanges. The Eastern Partnership is an offer of cooperation as closely as possible to neighbours who do not want to be or want to become members of the EU. So there is nothing to stand in the way of good cooperation with Armenia and Azerbaijan from this point of view, simply because they have rejected the offer of an association agreement and an extended free trade agreement. However, foreign trade and external relations must also be able to orientate themselves there in line with our values. It is useful that the Commission has initiated a review of the Neighbourhood Policy. And, in view of the enormous security challenges in the neighbourhood, which Mr Saryusz-Wolski also addressed – now in Ukraine – it is probably not the right time to completely change the current policy. But the Riga Summit must send a clear signal that the EU wants to make its cooperation with its eastern partners not only better, but also more efficient. More solidarity, yes, but also more efficiency and effectiveness in concrete terms with the individual partners. It is time to remember the strengths of the Eastern Partnership, the concrete offers of cooperation and support for the strengthening of state institutions, for democratic reforms, for improved regional cooperation. Finally, the Georgian President said the other day in the Committee on Foreign Affairs that good cooperation between countries and the West and East is important for the Eastern Neighbourhood. And we should also take this into account in our thoughts, at least in the medium term.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The draft text for the Riga Summit on the future of the Eastern Neighbourhood, as adopted by the Member States, is disappointing. For of all the previous major statements on European solidarity and the defence of our principles, I find only a faint decoction. No real ambition, no clear strategy, when they are just as much needed. The pressure Russia has exerted on the three associated partner countries of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine in recent years is enormous. This presents us with new geopolitical challenges.  I do not condemn the build-up of Russian troops on our Eastern European borders or their presence in Ukraine. Contrary. Russia is invited to determine the terms of the free trade agreement with Ukraine.   Last week I was here in Kiev and in eastern Ukraine with some of my colleagues. We saw the disastrous consequences of the aggression supported by Russia. Very direct for the many families that were under attack: this here is a scrape, a shrapnel from a Russian Grad projectile that destroyed the home of a family in Marioepol. Consequences for the whole country as well.  I want to warn you here. The conflict sucks the blood out of the country, not only financially, but also psychologically. The population is becoming tired and disillusioned. Reforms demand sacrifices from the people. They must nevertheless feel that Europe will reward their efforts. There is an atmosphere of defeatism. We must not lose these people. They expect a clear and positive signal from Riga. Clearer and more positive than is now the case in the draft text. That is why I ask that the Union be consistent and bold. Give a European perspective! Offer Ukraine and Georgia a clear deadline for visa liberalization!

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the Eastern Partnership launched five years ago is an example of the European Union in real action. Despite all the difficulties – and even open attacks – the Eastern Partnership is something we should be proud of today. The ALDE Group fully supports the Eastern Partnership policy, as it represents a highly effective stimulus for furthering democratic change and the process of reform in the partner countries in Eastern Europe. As a result, we have today three associated partners of the EU on the map of Europe: Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. We all know the price they are paying for their European choice: the one of unprecedented military, political and economic pressures and propaganda. We initiated an open letter to the EU heads of state and their governments concerning the declaration of the Riga Summit. This letter has been signed by 98 Members of this House. We believe that the Riga Summit should act in an ambitious way and in the spirit of solidarity with our associated partners. Firstly, we call on the EU leaders in Riga to recognise the future membership perspective of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. Clarity on this, along with the criteria and requirements, will be the right step and is needed today, not tomorrow. Secondly, we urge in Riga to commit to extending the visa-free regime to the citizens of Georgia and Ukraine by setting definite deadlines, hopefully by the end of this year, for the completion of their visa liberalisation plans. It is EU policy vis-à-vis Russia which has failed, to everybody’s regret, and it is the Eastern Partnership which proved to bring positive results.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group.
