Madam President, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has  The Eastern Partnership Summit, which begins tomorrow in Riga, will be a summit of contradictions. This is already demonstrated by the announcements of the summit, in which we talk about differentiated relations, but at the same time announce the continuation of the EU's previous policy, regardless of the expectations of the partners. Obviously, Mr Saryusz-Wolski, you are right to refer to the Commission's absence here in the Chamber. Contradictions also characterise the main points of the summit: strengthening the rule of law – yes. But we have to ask what the EU is actually doing to ensure that corrupt oligarchs in Moldova do not overturn a prime minister, that Ukraine cannot, contrary to our fundamental values, ban parties as we see fit. According to a recent survey by the Gorzhenin Institute of the government in Kiev, just over three quarters of the population of Ukraine certify that there are no real, profound reforms that have been long awaited since the Majdan protests. These are the realities against which the summit must be measured. Another reality for Riga is that it is difficult to leave out social rights and social justice issues from the outset: unemployment rates of just under 20% in Armenia and Georgia – which are much higher among young people – and an almost halved female employment rate, as in Moldova, signals profound socio-economic transformation processes that require more than the "development of market opportunities". We must address these questions – we, the Council and the Commission – because the Eastern Partnership is more than geopolitics, it is above all a policy and development that is jointly designed.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, if there is one policy amongst our common external policies that is in desperate need of a review, it is our neighbourhood policy and more specifically, the Eastern Partnership. Compared to its original aims and admissions, it is far from an unqualified success. Therefore our Group has welcomed the review process initiated by Commissioner Hahn and the work on its broad conclusions as well – so far. Differentiation, which is the core word of this review, is reasonable and probably unavoidable in the Eastern Partnership. Nevertheless, we should not forget that three of the partnership countries signed an Association Agreement with us and under the DCFTAs, they are aligning their economies with that of the European Union. They should be offered primarily a credible European perspective, and we should help them in the short and the medium term to offset the social costs which are associated with that economic alignment.  The more-for-more principle of neighbourhood policies in general makes sense only if it also implies a less-for-less policy. We believe it would be right and proper to increase the more-for-more financial allocations which are currently at 20 % and direct them towards the associated countries. In order to be credible, the European neighbourhood policy requires proper financial support. The EUR 2 billion allocated yearly both to southern and eastern neighbours allows neither a credible commitment nor an ambitious policy. We think we should certainly revisit that number in the forthcoming mid-term review. So in short, we need a credible commitment to our partners, both in the south and in the east.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are approaching this very important conference that we will have very soon on the Eastern Neighbourhood Policy. I have to agree with those who have said that it is very sad to find the Commission seat empty: you can see that it is not a priority, even if it seems absurd to think so. How, however, are we approaching this summit? For our part, I repeat that it is right for any country that fulfils the Copenhagen criteria to cultivate European ambitions and prospects. Unfortunately, however, it is clear that in many of our partner countries corruption, state architecture and the independence of the judicial system are enormous problems, stumbling blocks to be tackled. For our part, I think that it is absolutely necessary to direct in this respect the funding and aid for cooperation that we allocate annually to the partner countries and not, precisely, to follow crazy races towards polarisation and armaments that are certainly not the priority of the populations involved.  We hope that this summit will be an opportunity to reiterate this.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, when you are going to open a discussion with somebody, you should know the truth. In some cases you may be shocked by your opponent. So everybody knows that Boris Nemtsov has been killed in Russia, but nobody knows that it is much safer to be an opposition politician or an independent journalist in Moscow than in Kiev.  In Ukraine over the last few weeks, Oles Buzina, Oleh Kalashnikov, Oleksandr Puklushenko, Olga Moroz, Serhiy Sukhobok, Stanislav Melnik, and plenty of Hungarians, Moldovans, Jews, Gagauz and Russians, have been killed by the Ukrainian nationalists. I understand that the fascists, who are growing in influence in the European Union, look on in sympathy at the nationalists in Ukraine, but it is the truth that will make us free.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Madam President, there is something strange about the Eastern Partnership because, before the Vilnius Summit in November 2013, there was already talk of the failure of this summit. We may have the same attitude now, a few hours before the opening, because some people are talking about a failure. But, basically, and we now know this, the Vilnius summit was not a failure, if we take into account, as some colleagues have already said, the balance sheet that can be drawn up since 2013. The signing of association agreements, progress in visa facilitation and a series of advances were recalled.  Of course, we are all aware that the societies to which this Eastern Partnership policy applies expect not only a review of the recent past but also a promise, a message, a commitment for the future. I think that is our strong point. I think we need to talk about the future. We must define a political ideal and a political commitment of Europe towards these eastern partnership countries. Otherwise, with our pessimism and self-stigmatization, we will not resist Russian propaganda which has only one message and only one definition of the Eastern Partnership, namely a company against Moscow. That's what it says.  I think that in the face of that, we need courage. It takes the courage of commitment and we must be very clear about the European future of the Eastern Partnership countries. It would indeed be a pity today if we were, in our proposals, more modest than two or four years ago in Warsaw. That's my proposal.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Madam President, the importance of the upcoming Eastern Partnership summit in Riga must not be underestimated due to the changed geopolitical circumstances following russia's annexation of Crimea and aggression in eastern Ukraine. The draft declaration sent to eastern partnership countries is not encouraging. It contains a much weaker text than the Vilnius Declaration in 2013, although Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia have since signed an Association Agreement. If we don't want to give false hopes, which I agree with, is the blurred perspective and doubts about visa liberalization all we have left? Our partners can't be left alone under pressure, and we're just bystanders. This summit can and should be a unique opportunity for the Union to demonstrate its unquestionable commitment to the Eastern Partnership. He needs to give a thoughtful answer to the question of the extent to which Russia and the EU can be partners on the same premises today, and to which they remain rivals. They would have to send an unequivocal message that the EU will continue to actively and unitedly support its eastern partners in their reforms and foreign policy commitments.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Firstly, I would like to say that we are dealing with a situation which is absolutely embarrassing, that there is no Representative of the Commission in the section on the High Representative's statement on the Eastern Partnership Summit. At the same time, we are aware that this summit is extremely important, perhaps even the most important in the history of the Eastern Partnership, because, on the one hand, we are dealing with partnership countries that have concluded association agreements with the Union and are now in a difficult situation, and on the other hand we are dealing with a Union itself that is trying to reconcile various opposing interests.  The text to be adopted at the summit should be hard and decisive. We should reaffirm the European perspective of Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova, and we should also declare the creation of visa-free travel for Ukrainians and Georgians as early as 2016. In this text, we should also strongly call Russia's action by name: Russian aggression against Ukraine, annexation of Crimea. If we go back, if this text is weaker, it will be taken away by Russia as an agreement to act. We cannot allow this to happen.

name: Urmas PAET
text: - Of course, the Eastern Partnership policy is a very important policy, but unfortunately I must be critical of the summit that begins tomorrow.  It would be expected that this summit will take a concrete step towards supporting its eastern partners, in particular Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia, but unfortunately all the signs are that there will be a speech party where there will be no important decisions. And it is very sad that the European Union is not making a decision on the visa-free movement of Ukrainian citizens, even though this strong positive message is urgently needed by Ukrainian society in the current situation. It is also embarrassing that the European Union cannot unequivocally and clearly confirm that Ukraine has a clear European perspective. The lack of enthusiasm for supporting Ukraine in some Member States of the European Union also shows that eight Member States have not yet been able to ratify the Association and Free Trade Agreement with Ukraine during the year. I very much hope that, however, in the coming weeks, after the summit, the European Union will be able to bring itself together and make decisions about these decisions.

name: Miloslav RANSDORF
text: – Madam President, the Eastern Partnership was a good, indeed excellent, idea, but the Commission helped to destroy it by complying entirely with the US policy of hostility towards Russia. Ukraine has been devastated. There is currently inflation of 60%, the technical default of the national bank. It must be said that since the Maidan, 46 banks in Ukraine have actually failed. The average monthly income is currently €40.  Meanwhile, the Americans are currently withdrawing, as shown by the Sochi meeting between Kerry, Lavrov and Putin and Victoria Nuland's visit to Moscow. I think it's the best time for us to stop playing fools and do the same to back off.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Today, Russia makes it clear that what is happening in Ukraine may recur in other eastern neighbourhood countries. In the context of such an economic and security threat, the European Union must be even more united and strong in showing its support for the Eastern Partnership countries. Today, we need to talk about real support that is tangible and can bring mutual benefits. We need to ensure that the Eastern Partnership countries are better informed about the work of Parliament, the Commission and the Council and future legislation. This requires funding for the work of journalists from eastern partnership countries here in Strasbourg and Brussels. We need to promote regional cooperation, to intensify support for projects related to the sharing of experience, the development of skills and knowledge. Today, we are talking a lot about the necessary reforms in the Eastern Partnership countries, but they must not only become a tool to become members of the European Union, but also to the aspiration of georgia, Ukraine and Moldova themselves, which will help them to secure their own prosperity. I therefore call on everyone to invest in the people of the Eastern Partnership countries by conveying the strength of Europe's fundamental ideas.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, I look on with interest at this. I see the summit is tomorrow, and you spoke about the achievements which have already been achieved, including the dealings with Ukraine. It is a peculiar definition of achievement if you look at the sorry state of affairs in that country at the moment, and my thoughts – and I am sure all of our thoughts – go to the people who are suffering there. The constant drive by this place to expand its influence and authority, to take in more countries, does not seem to know any bounds or limits – even when you know that you are heading out into the sphere of influence of where Russia is, you know the situation there, and you know that it is putting peace at further risk. This seems a reckless method. It is almost like the enemy on Star Trek called The Borg, who just cannot help but assimilate. They take individuality and make everyone the same; everyone is under their sphere of control and it is their sole purpose for existence.  The more I am in this place, the more I feel that this is a very serious version of that. You cannot help but seek to expand constantly, grow, influence, and it needs to stop. You need to stop. Take a breath, and just think about what is going on. So, once again, I despair when I hear these things, and I truly hope that nothing bad will come of this summit.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Madam President, the Eastern Partnership could be an appropriate framework for the EU to develop good political and economic relations with six former Soviet republics. However, the level of cooperation cannot be raised by force. If a country has a government committed to the EU, that does not mean that it is capable of an association agreement. The case of Ukraine proves this. Among their first actions, the US-backed political forces wanted to limit the use of language by minorities. Rampant corruption, the rule of oligarchs, the state legalisation of extremist armed groups are all contrary to what we regard as European values. We must also accept that there are countries that do not wish to give up their relations with Russia as we approach the EU. Let's not force them to choose.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: – Madam Vice-President Lunacek, tonight's debate on the 4th Eastern Partnership Summit to be held in Riga this week is politically important for the credibility of EU foreign policy. The messages we gave to the 6 countries, first of all these 5 that were more engaged, I don't mean Belarus, which has a specific status for some time, are now in a fundamentally different position than they were during the Vilnius summit.  What is important in Riga is that we note progress on the European path of certain countries, especially those three countries whose authorities are determined to continue on the European path: ukraine, Moldova and Georgia and it is up to us to follow their aspirations and wishes with the instruments and policies at our disposal. In this regard, strong implementation of the Association Agreement, financial assistance, institution building, reform assistance, in particular strengthening the rule of law and fighting corruption must be priorities for both our policies and our financial instruments.  Signals to the peoples of these countries, in particular in terms of visa facilitation and liberalisation, are essential for the public perception of the Union of those Member States. After our messages in recent years it is important that there is no disappointment and it is important that all others, namely the neighbors of these countries, know that these countries have the right to independently and sovereignly decide their future, and we need to give them a hand in this European future.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, since the last summit on the Eastern Partnership in Vilnius many things have changed with our Eastern partners and in particular those that signed Association Agreements with the EU and which are confronted with dramatically increasing external pressure. In Ukraine, in fact, this external pressure is a war, with no insignia and Russian troops spending their ʽholidaysʼ in eastern Ukraine in armoured vehicles. The EU is seen as, and should concretely represent for the Eastern Partnership countries, a reliable partner which stands by them, helps them in their effort for reforms but also acknowledges their progress when this has been made. Low ambition in Riga will mean a dramatic impact – a negative one – on Europe and on our eastern side. I call on both sides, the Commission and the Member States, to make sure that the Riga Summit sends the positive message our Eastern partners need. The EU cannot and must not suffocate the expectations and aspirations of our partners and their people, but must rather encourage and compensate their efforts, show them that the European integration path is even more open than before and offer them messages and opportunities that can also counter the heavy pressure from Russian propaganda. From this point, I see a clear and important step that should be taken, namely the free visa regime for Georgia and Ukraine. Let us not give something else, but something we can do and which should be done according to the efforts those countries have made. It is the first and the most important sign that their future lies with Europe and we should continuously fight for this.  Finally, I unconditionally back, and I proudly join, the letter initiated by our colleague, Mr Auštrevičius.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Tomorrow's Eastern Partnership Summit is another opportunity for the European Union to stop simulating an active policy towards its eastern neighbours and really start to pursue it. If what is happening in Ukraine at the moment, if Russian armaments and threats are not sufficient motivation to draw up a concrete plan to support our partners in eastern Europe, then I think nothing will be able to force us to do so.  Ukraine is now a first-class topic: deepening chaos, the threat of bankruptcy and another Russian offensive are destroying the country and destroying the security architecture in our immediate neighbourhood. Can we really afford just more generalities? The real conditions and prospects for membership of the Union, economic support and effective assistance in modernising public institutions and the creation of a friendly visa programme must be included in the conclusions of the Summit. Not only the people of Ukraine, but also Moldova and Georgia are waiting for this. Russia's strength, ladies and gentlemen, is our powerlessness and indecision. The Riga Summit can show that we can afford firmness and we should use it, but the Commissioner is not here.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – I think you will take my word at the end, because it is difficult to say a complicated thing very quickly and briefly. Both the Eastern Partnership and the Union for the Mediterranean were some innovations in European politics that did not work out for a long time, and that is why we have come to talk today about the need for a thorough review. Both organisations have become captives of open bilateral issues and geostrategic interests. However, I think that we need to look for a purpose for both of us, not in spreading political influence, but in expanding the space of freedom, the space of values that we share and which we want to be in this part of the world as well. I remain convinced that if we had understood the role of partnerships in this way, then even a war in Ukraine would not be inevitable.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Madam President, we do not like the Eastern Partnership, as it is being raised in Riga. Their association treaties, their areas of free trade, are actually weapons of political control in a deeply unequal economic relationship. The countries of the south know very well what this means: more debt, more deind industrialization and the path to subalternity.  In this context, instead of calming and integrating, we have supported an illegal displacement of power, destabilization and war. And we continue to shake the board, with a NATO that creates tools and capabilities in an aggressive direction. For more inri, we invented a fetish word, "hybrid warfare," which serves both to qualify or disqualify Greece's relations with Russia and to attack the media. All this for the greater glory of the wishes of the United States, the number one partner, and in the opposite direction to a justly integrated and truly independent Europe.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Mrs Kalniņa-Lukaševica, I do not share your optimism, as the Eastern Partnership in its actual form is a trigger for conflict. The only way for the EU to stop this trend is to prevent any further deterioration of the increasingly fractured relationship with Russia and to stop the pressure on the people of the countries of the Eastern Partnership. The fatal mistake made by the EU is in its interpretation of the partnership, which was assumed to be a character of genuine imperial expansion of the European Union in the East. The civil war in Ukraine is a poisonous fruit of this fatal distortion.  Today, 40 years after the Helsinki Final Act was adopted, there is an urgent need to convene a new conference on common security in Europe and just this appeal might be made at the Riga Summit. If the participants will not do it, then civil society will. The role of the EU must be to unite, not divide.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini's representative, on the eve of the Riga summit, an assessment of the eastern partnership policy is needed: none of the post-Cold War promises have been kept. We could have created an area of prosperity, the first step in an independent Europe, united between East and West. Instead, whenever a country represented a bridge between East and West, the Union's policy pitted people against each other, ordered to choose their membership in the West and NATO, whether Serbia, Georgia or Ukraine, to name the countries in conflict. We have certainly exceeded 10,000 victims in Ukraine. For what record? Further confrontations will take place as long as we support a bellicose and extended POLICY of NATO against the interests of Europe and europeans. We are at a favourable time thanks to Mr Kerry and to a realistic policy also sought by the High Representative. So let's get out of Manichaeism, let's not double standards for a great united Europe. That is what it is like to be European today.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, the Riga Summit should not become a summit of little political commitment, as some forecast. It is said that some Member States are reluctant to commit themselves to any new agreements or promises. Some others see it as a last chance to save the partnership, but what we need is the opposite. The EU must demonstrate its unwavering political commitment toward our eastern neighbours on the very difficult road towards democracy.  I very much like the declaration by the Latvian Presidency that we need genuine partnership, and I hope that the Latvian Presidency could implement it in Riga’s decisions also. I am one of the signatories of MEPs’ letters to the Riga Summit, so let me repeat the appeal: for next year, a visa-free regime for two countries, Ukraine and Georgia, and a clear European perspective for the three countries which are clearly willing to have this perspective. Our duty is also to guarantee that these countries could freely choose their paths, and the EU approach should be better tailored to each participant. But our message today should be that we cannot let these countries down by loosening our commitment. These nations are welcome to the European family – and better sooner than later.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. The most important task of the Riga Eastern Partnership Summit is to answer the question of whether there will be a reform of the Eastern Partnership programme in form and, above all, in content, whether fragmentation and gradual death await this project. Unfortunately, the signs of the disease are already evident. The first is that virtually no important decision that our partners expect from us is taken at this summit. For example, it is not clear why visa-free travel with Georgia, which has already fulfilled all the conditions, has not been introduced. I know that the Commission intends to take a positive decision in the near future, but I am not clear why this was not done.  It is a matter of attitude. We don't even notice that we act arrogantly. The problem is that the European Union is trying to play the role of big brother in this relationship, but that is a big mistake. Our partners are allergic to this from previous times. They want to participate in the programme as an e-mail partner. If this equality is not achieved, we cannot expect positive results. We must definitely start with the reform of the Eastern Partnership programme. Thank you!

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Let us always remember that strengthening the independence of the states that originated in the East after the collapse of the Soviet Union defines the very meaning of our cooperation. Bill Etheridge spoke - before he left the chamber - about the fact that realism dictates respect for russia's zone of influence. Well, if we speak such language, we will strike out not only the political but the moral meaning of Europe in general.  But let us remember one more thing: we very often hear in this House: our values, our values. Maybe it is time for us to think that the nations we are talking to in eastern Europe – Ukrainians, Georgians – want to bring us their values, which we can benefit from as well. Europe should thank every day that Christian life has endured years of Soviet persecution, but do we write about it in our resolutions, or have we adopted the 'March of the Family' in Tbilisi? Let us remember this.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, riga's forthcoming Council of the European Union summit will be an opportunity to differentiate the European Union's relations with each individual country of the Six Eastern Partnerships. The other side of the coin, on the other hand, will be the search for a unified common position between the European Union and the Eastern Partnership countries. What is the common denominator for six countries? Three Eastern Partnership countries are at war, Armenia is at war with Azerbaijan, Ukraine is in a hybrid war with the Russian Federation. Three countries have part of their territory occupied, Georgia Abkhatia and South Ossetia, Moldova left bank dniester, Ukraine Crimea and part of Donbas. The sixth country is Belarus, a country that makes no secret of its concerns about external security risks. In all cases, the imperial and violent policy of the Russian Federation is the common denominator for the European Union's policy towards the Eastern Partnership countries. I would like to ask Commissioner Hahn to find the courage to call things by their real names. Russia has launched a hybrid war against Europe. Russia is waging a hybrid war against eastern partnership countries whose nations are trying to break free of the autocratic Kremlin regime and subscribe to European democratic values. The president of my country, Václav Havel, once said that we would help Russia by telling the truth about it. Russia once again became the Reagan empire of evil. Especially for the Six Eastern Partnerships.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Madam President, what has been said by the Commission and the Council Representative, who is also acting on behalf of the High Representative, is encouraging in terms of what must be one of the most important achievements of the Riga Summit, namely that the European Union should take back its proactive and managing role in our most important and insecure neighbourhood. In all this, however, notice the elephant in the room! Our largest Eastern Partnership partner, Ukraine, has been subjected to external aggression, war is underway in the country, and several other countries in the region are vulnerable to similar aggressive Russian power efforts. It is in this situation that the EU must therefore be offered a credible and attractive democratic European alternative.  It is precisely for the sake of credibility that in the future the Union cannot face a politically unprepared crisis along its borders or that some large Member States take over the role of the Community in solving critical situations. I therefore call on and encourage the High Representative and the Commission to take on this responsibility in the full unity of the EU.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The clear political signal from this Riga Summit should be that the European Union is continuing its close cooperation with the partners of the Eastern Neighbourhood consistently and with commitment. In view of some of the strange speeches I have heard in this debate today – from representatives of both the far left and the far right – I would like to stress once again that the Eastern Partnership does not mean that the partner countries have to choose between the EU and Russia. It is not a question of 'either - or' rather the question 'both - and'. The Eastern Partnership is not directed against anyone, not even Russia. On the contrary, it is up to the countries of the Eastern Partnership themselves to decide to what extent they want to cooperate with the European Union. Not all countries can and do not want to move closer to the European Union at the same speed and in the same policy areas. That is why it will also be a question of developing tailor-made approaches for each of the six countries when working with the partner countries. At the same time, however, the European Union must not tire of stressing the importance of our European values, such as democracy, the rule of law and human rights. That, too, should be a topic of the forthcoming riga summit.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, the current situation to the east of our borders resembles a return to the old politics of influence between the West and the East. The concept of the Eastern Partnership in this situation is an important framework for engagement. Our ultimate goal is for the EU to have more democratic, more prosperous and more integrated neighbours. We need to get back to these basics. To be successful we have to clearly demonstrate that we are prepared to fully engage our political capital for our neighbours. We have to be all-in. We can do that by sending strong, united and encouraging messages through this summit.  I repeat: our neighbourhood policy needs to be more politically driven. This means to propose a clear and courageous vision for our neighbours and to match our words with deeds. It concerns especially those who have clearly voiced their European ambitions. They need this signal from us now more than ever.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: –  Madam President, as we speak history is being written and age-defining changes are under way. In the coming years, we should be able to look back to now with the conviction that we did the right thing and provided the right response to the critical challenges facing Eastern Europe. I will focus on the element of ambitions and membership perspective: we need to do more for those who have real and tangible European ambitions, for those who have decided on the European path.  Of course, much needs to be done, and words are less credible than concrete and tangible actions, but the EU should send a clear signal to Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine that their future is with the 28 Member States as long as they genuinely fulfil their obligations and show real commitment to the Association Agreements’ reform agenda. We cannot ask them to implement harsh reforms without having light at the end of the tunnel. If they deliver, they should be considered serious candidates on the road to the EU.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – First of all, I would like to point out that the policy towards our Eastern partners has always been characterted by a certain inconsistency, naivety, instability and all these elements that have made us ineffective, in short. I have the impression that we have made some progress in this area for five years. We are still, perhaps, not consistent enough, still, perhaps, we are not always able to make a good offer, but in general, I want to stress that we have progress in this matter. What I would like to draw particular attention to at the moment is that, within the framework of the Eastern Partnership, however, these partners should be treated very individually in order to build up offers against them, taking into account the differences that undoubtedly exist in terms of these individual countries, are very strong and very often culturally determined.  Using the end of this time, I would like to address a few of the allegations made against the High Commissioner. Well, I would like to point out that the High Commissioner has, quite often, however, been a guest in this House, and I want to justify it at least in part.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: –  Madam President, Ms Kalniņa-Lukaševica said that we, the European Union, are offering a genuine partnership to these three countries. Unfortunately, we are offering less than expected. We are making a step back in comparison with the last Eastern Partnership in Vilnius. These countries need a real European perspective. This is what they are looking for and, unfortunately, at this summit that is going to start tomorrow, we are transforming these three countries into kind of buffer states. It is a step back; like a concession offered to Russia. Also, I agree with the Council in supporting the earliest possible ratification by all Member States of the Association Agreements and the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. These agreements are fundamental in order to strengthen political association and economic integration.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Madam President, the fact is that we have been in a whole new geopolitical situation since the last summit in 2013, the fact is that borders are changing by force, that some of our Member States are subject to pressure, that these 6 countries we are talking about are in completely different situations and the situation can be compared perhaps in three countries. In any case, the situation is different than in 2013.  I believe that the Union must continue on its path, we must listen to our partners, we must (as the Council representative said) give them a full serious partnership, because this is the only way we will resist Russia. The fact is that Russia has failed to divert us from the path we have charted and that is what we must insist on. We don't necessarily consider them enemies, but in this case they are our rivals. The fact is that the citizens of these countries expect change. And that is why we must persevere on this path, we must offer them a European perspective. The association agreement was signed - that's the difference, after all. In any case, our primary goal is peace and therefore we must persevere with this basic principle of ours. So not just solidarity, but solid support.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to see a summit outcome that our Eastern partners can feel encouraged by, encouraged in terms of a European perspective, as far as they seek. My impression is that some people want to choose this perspective – and it is not a must on our part – because only such a perspective will anchor democracy, freedom and the rule of law in this part of Europe. We all know what the Russian perspective is in this regard. In concrete terms, this means that we must not fall behind the Vilnius Declaration in 2013 and that, in view of the Russian aggression that has taken place since then, we make it clear that, in addition to the multi-billion-dollar aid, particularly towards Ukraine, we are also delivering something very concrete to the people, but what our commitment and sympathy with them makes clear. : And in my view, this is a concrete and short-term visa waiver. This is also stated in the letter, which has already been mentioned by other Members. I think that, on the occasion of this summit, we must give a very precise outlook, so that people also feel for themselves that they are part of this free Europe.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Madam President, in the wake of the annexation of Crimea and the Russian-Ukrainian war crisis, a whole new geopolitical situation has emerged in relation to the eastern partnership countries. The Riga Summit of the Eastern Partner Countries is now held in this challenging and extremely complex set of relations. For this reason, the meeting should send a radically changed, unfavourable message of encouragement and affirmative note to our partners, which are also shared among themselves, and in particular to Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia, which signed the European Association Agreement last year. In order to avoid war and ensure security in the region, the EU must, above all, find a political solution to the Russian-Ukrainian, Russian-European crisis. However, it must assure its Eastern partners of its continued committed support, offering them a reliable road map and vision for their continued accession to Europe.

name: Michał BONI
text: – Madam President, there are many expectations related to the Riga Summit; because of the aggressive stance of Russia, we would like to have stronger achievements. If the Riga Summit could be a game changer in that area, I see small progress.  We are talking about the accession process of three countries. We are working on new measures in the redefined Neighbourhood Policy for economic growth and energy cooperation, for civic society development and the rule of law, as a foundation. We are supporting reforms, which are crucial. We are on the road with all countries, including Armenia and Azerbaijan. I am not sure if it concerns Belarus. What is needed the most? To give a positive signal to the societies. Under the present threats from Russia, they should feel that they are beneficiaries in many areas. Examples: concrete visa liberalisation offers should be clearly presented to Georgia and Ukraine; a promising description of the EU membership perspective is needed.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Before the Partnership Summit, we are wondering what we have achieved, because it has achieved good results, albeit incomplete ones. We would probably have achieved better results if there had been more determination, including in the High House, to confirm the aspirations of the Member States of the Partnership. This initiative was not directed against anyone, particularly against Russia, and it is often attempted here to emphasise that this was the case.  The partnership is differentiated because it is built in relation to six members who have different expectations, different aspirations and ambitions, and this requires a flexible and differentiated approach. It has undeniable achievements, which include m.in of the Association Agreement with Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia; projects that have been financed by the Neighbourhood Fund. Reforms are needed in the Partner Member States, but due to the diversity of ambitions they should be adapted to the expectations of the partners. I welcome the declaration that speaks of aspirations and the European choice of Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia and other Partnership countries.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, firstly I want to thank your predecessor in the chair for clarifying the position regarding blue-cards and, as a result, we have had a very structured debate. So I thank you for that. Secondly, I have been here in Parliament for six years now. I think it is the first time I have seen the Council here – sometimes they have been criticised for not being here, sometimes unfairly – but a debate of this nature without the Commission is unbelievable. The only thing we can do is to show that their inertia will be replaced by our determination to ensure there is a successful outcome in Riga.  And above all, these countries, I think, have shown very bravely that they have declared ‘East is beast, West is best’. But we must respond equally courageously by having a successful outcome in Riga and, above all, having visa-free travel for them by 2016, if at all possible. This will give encouragement to the citizens and therefore proceed in the path which they have taken independently. We should encourage and respect that.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The forthcoming Eastern Partnership Summit will undoubtedly be a major test for this whole initiative, which is why the expectations for it are huge. One of the particularly important points to be addressed is, in my opinion, cooperation on energy security and interconnections. The European Commission's stress tests in 2014 examining the potential effects of the suspension of gas supplies from Russia have clearly indicated that increased coordination and cooperation between Member States can significantly mitigate the potential effects of non-supply. In the current fragile international situation, Europe must pay particular attention to energy security, which is why I very much look forward to concrete proposals to strengthen energy security, including the development of interconnections in the Eastern Partnership countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity in the debate on the Eastern Partnership, to address a serious issue concerning the Greek populations residing in Georgia, in a region where, traditionally, several decades ago, more than 150,000 Greeks lived, most of whom, after the collapse of the Soviet Union, came to Greece; The problem is that, after leaving Georgia, where they were also citizens of Georgia, they left their homes, which were theirs, owned by them. However, after they left, their own homes were illegally occupied. Despite the efforts we have made, this illegal occupation of the homes of Greek citizens continues and the Georgian authorities are not taking measures to restore legitimacy and protect the property rights of Greek citizens. We therefore call for this matter to be taken seriously today by the Presidency of the Council.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, I wish success to the Riga summit because I am convinced that the citizens of all these six countries and that they want a European perspective or at least see the European Union as something very positive.  I remember what it was like in earlier decades when we and many here who were colleagues entering the European Union. That is why I wish success to this summit in Riga because I believe that our priorities must be peacekeeping and economic cooperation with countries concerning the Eastern Partnership. But our condition must be European values, especially human rights, media freedom and all that we can succinctly say that they make up our society and make up this European Union.  So, I want to make it clear, we are not making enemies, this is not a move against Russia, but we are forming a partnership in the desire that everyone, after all, will be our partners.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, first of all, please allow me to underline that today, and for this particular debate, I am talking on behalf of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy/Vice-President Ms Mogherini, so we should take that into account.  At the same time, as a Presidency I can only underline that several Commissioners are already in Riga today because, as I mentioned, several side events – for example the first Eastern Partnership Media Conference, have started already. So we do appreciate also, as a Presidency, the very good cooperation with the Commission on preparation of this Eastern Partnership Summit and it is very important to have several Commissioners in Riga today already. Coming back to our debate, please allow me, once again on behalf of the High Representative, to underline that we have listened carefully to all that has been said here today during the debate. Please rest assured that we will be taking into consideration all the comments and proposals made by Members. Let me reiterate that the Riga Summit will demonstrate that the Eastern Partnership remains our priority and will send a clear political signal that, firstly, the EU is strongly committed to its Eastern Partnership and determined to pursue closer tailor-made relations with its independent and sovereign Eastern European partners. We will therefore continue to give every support to those partners which have taken on mobilisation on the most ambitious reform commitments through all the association agreements.  The summit marks a new level in our relations with our partners, the most ambitious: our bilateral association agreements with the three partners.  Secondly, our partnership involves six partner countries. I cannot stress enough the importance of maintaining the inclusivity of the partnership. The EU will therefore continue to engage strongly with all partners whatever their individual level of relations with the EU.  Thirdly, we will step up our strategic communication efforts to explain what the relations with our partners are about and what they are not about, and we will certainly argue that they are not directed against any third party. We will therefore continue our dialogue with those who challenge this.  Several Members also raised the question of the European perspective for Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine and the strength of the reflections in the Riga Declaration. Let me first of all stress that the drafting process of the joint declaration of the Eastern Partnership Summit is still ongoing.  Negotiations are of an inclusive nature between both our Member States and partners. Negotiations are still ongoing and therefore, at this stage, we still await the final outcome of these negotiations. The agreed consensus will have to reflect each country’s specific needs, priorities and aspirations and the common interests they share with the EU, as well as the EUʼs interests, while making a realistic assessment of what can be achieved within the next few years. In this context, Riga should highlight first and furthermost that we have moved to a new level in our relations with the three partners with whom we have signed the most ambitious ever bilateral association agreements, but it should also signal our readiness to work for more tailor-made agreements with others to ensure that the Partnership remains an inclusive framework.  I believe we share the opinion that preparation for the Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga is of such utmost importance that we could take much more time to discuss several topics and more details. But respecting your agenda, I will save time and, in concluding, I will just mention that I highly appreciate your commitment and support for the Eastern Partnership, and that relations with national parliaments and the role of Euronest in promoting and consolidating the Eastern Partnership are highly important. Together we must help partners realise their full potential. I thank you very much for all your contributions and your support for the Eastern Partnership policy and I thank you very much that you do care about the need for us to have a successful Riga Summit.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – I consider the Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga on 21 and 22 May to be one of the most important events in recent times, affecting the EU's eastern neighbours, where the main focus of the parties is on promoting state building and upholding the rule of law, exploring new market opportunities, energy security, and negotiating mobility and strengthening relations between civilians.  As Vice-President of Euronest, in the message to the summit participants, I asked for important issues concerning ukraine, the eastern partnership country that has suffered the most in the last year. I called for the swift implementation of reforms in Ukraine, in particular with regard to decentralisation and minority rights, and for Ukraine to guarantee and respect fundamental and egalitized human and political rights for all nationalities in the country.  I believe that discussing these issues and resolving them as soon as possible will help Ukraine to emerge from a deep economic and social crisis. In addition, I have drawn attention to the importance of cross-border and cross-border cooperation and joint projects to help for closer relations between the European Union and its eastern partners.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Gradual visa liberalisation with a view to visa-free travel is one of the main tools for bringing the societies of the European Union and the Eastern Partnership countries closer. Since the first Prague Summit in 2009, most partners have made significant progress in implementing the reforms required by the European Union. Moldova managed to abolish visas as early as April 2014. The Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga raises hopes for decisions on the prospect of visa waiver with the next countries, Georgia and Ukraine, and the introduction of visa facilitation with Belarus. The issue of visa liberalisation is of political, social and economic importance and therefore its acceleration is a key element in shaping relations between them. Visa-free travel is an opportunity to strengthen cooperation between the EU and the Eastern Partnership countries; during the first year of application, half a million Moldovan citizens benefited from it. Open borders are of great importance not only for trade, culture and society, but also stimulate the democratic aspirations and libertarian aspirations on which the idea of a common Europe is based. The difficult reforms that our Eastern partners face are awaited by both the people of the Eastern Partnership countries and the EU, as they have an impact on increasing security in the region. We hope that from 2016 the citizens of Georgia and Ukraine will benefit from the visa-free travel law.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. A year and a half ago, with the Eastern Partnership slide, the protests in Majdan Square began, during which Ukraine made it clear that it would belong to Europe instead of the east, choosing western civic development over an authoritarian past. Since then, Russia has annexed Crimea with military force, constantly seeking to destabilize eastern Ukraine. At the current riga summit, Europe must give a punchy response to the Russian threat. The entry into force of the new financial assistance to Ukraine, the Association and Free Trade Agreement, point in this direction.  The EU must equip eastern partnership policy with adequate political and economic resources to counterbalance partner countries against Russian punitive measures. Preventing further violence and the political and economic stability of Ukraine is in the EU's top interest. We cannot let Ukraine down after we have pulled away from the honeybee of EU accession. However, the EU cannot give in to its principles to Ukraine either: the independence of the Ukrainian judiciary, the sound rule of law, democratic principles and the suppression of corruption are non-negotiable. However, it is important that if the EU cannot assert respect for values 'inward', how can we expect it to be 'outward', requiring the eastern partnership countries to do so? That is why what is happening in its own Member States, such as Hungary, is important for the Union.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Writing. – An important area of multilateral cooperation under the Eastern Partnership is the promotion of state building and the consolidation of the rule of law for partner countries. This is of particular importance in the light of the situation in Ukraine, because, while enforcing our security policy aspects, it is in the interest of all of us to get Ukraine out of the crisis stronger. It is necessary not only from an economic point of view for the renewal of the country, but also for the stability of the institutional system, the suppression of corruption and the real rule of law.  In this context, and as time progresses, we need to talk more and more about the part of the Minsk agreement on constitutional reform, decentralisation and guaranteeing the rights of national minorities. I believe that these issues cannot be avoided by the parties at the Eastern Partnership Summit.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the statement of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the EU-CELAC summit (10-11 June) (2015/2637 (RSP)).

name: n/a
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. Madam President, honourable Members, we have the next topic on our agenda. I am glad to participate in this discussion on the next summit between the EU and the Community of Latin America and Caribbean States (CELAC), which will take place on 10 and 11 June 2015 in Brussels for the first time.  It will be the second summit held with CELAC as a counterpart, but the eighth ever, since our partnership with the region was launched in Rio back in 1999. As Members are well aware, events all around Europe’s neighbourhood keep a good deal of attention focused there. But the EU, as a global player, does not lower its guard in its relations with other regions of the world. In some areas, we find regions which are luckily more stable, sometimes giving the false impression that the international community is less in demand.  Latin America and the Caribbean is such a region, and the upcoming Summit of Heads of State and Government in June will be a critical moment to infuse new dynamism into our relations. We want to create a real partnership for the next generation. Under the general heading ‘Shaping our common future: working for prosperous, cohesive and sustainable societies for our citizens,’ we intend to highlight the many dimensions of our relations.  Features such as a common cultural heritage, common values, a strong belief in regionalism and in an effective multilateralism – if combined well – have the capacity to unlock opportunities through our cooperation with the region.  The strategic bi-regional partnership that unites the EU and the region has been active for over 15 years. In this time, we have strengthened our relations, making the EU the main investor and a key trading partner, with 26 association or free trade agreements out of 33 countries. However, on the political front, we can still do more to tackle effectively global issues together. This is why part of the summit’s discussion will focus on exploring possible areas of convergence as regards key international processes.  Negotiations around climate change, the post-2015 development agenda or the international debate on drugs issues, in view of the Special Session of the United Nations General Assembly in 2016, will be the object of one of the three working sessions.  In order to materialise our common priorities, we also intend to adopt a reviewed and expanded EU-CELAC Action Plan, which will include new areas of cooperation such as higher education and citizen security. This shows how much we are linked.  Citizen security in Latin America and the Caribbean affects stability in our neighbourhood, through organised crime along the ‘cocaine route’, right into Europe. Our scientific communities on both sides of the Atlantic are working together on similar projects; they will link up more easily through a fibre-optic cable connection which the EU will promote.  The summit will also serve to highlight some historical developments taking place in the region. We will manifest our support to the ongoing reforms in Cuba. The summit will encourage the peace talks in Colombia and confirm the willingness to support peace implementation, including through an EU trust fund.  As a reflection of the change that the region has experienced in the last 10 to 15 years, the summit will also present new, innovative modalities of cooperation, for instance by means of triangular cooperation schemes. These will enable us to join forces with the more developed countries of the region in support of the less developed ones.  We must recognise that the region is diverse, and that while CELAC is certainly an inclusive political dialogue framework for our bi-regional relations, we need also to engage with the sub-regions and bilaterally. This is why, in the afternoon of the 11 June, we will hold two high-level political dialogue meetings, specifically with the Caribbean and with Central American countries. As was said before, the EU and CELAC share a strategic bi-regional partnership. Allow me to highlight the concept of ‘strategic’. I started out pointing out the challenges of instability very close to our borders. Through our relations with third countries and regions, it is also our intention to reinforce alliances around the fundamental principles of the international order which are currently under attack. Basic principles such as the rule of law, territorial integrity and sovereignty affect us all equally, beyond any particular geographical location.  Finally, I would like to highlight that the EU’s relations with the region are not limited to governmental relations. In fact, it is our aim that relations become ever-stronger between citizens, and their representatives. In this sense, I welcome very much the work being done by the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly (EuroLat), which will hold its Plenary Session just a few days before the Summit.  The EuroLat conclusions will be presented to the summit alongside other preparatory events, and will certainly enrich its outcome, precisely as a reflection of the multiple layers that we find in the relations with the region.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: PPE Group. – Madam President. In the light of the forthcoming EU-CELAC Summit, Mrs Kalnya-Luka-evica. It is true, as Mrs Kalnya-Luka-evica has said, that it is the second already under this format, which is a good sign of the dynamism of this regional integration body, which we have certainly supported since its inception. In a world, ladies and gentlemen, increasingly economically integrated, but more politically fragmented, where crises are unfortunately no exception, but a constant one, it is of paramount importance to strengthen the vitality of our bi-regional relationship. Particular interest also arouses deepening our economic and trade relations. In this regard, we hope from this Parliament that the agreements with Mexico and Chile will be reviewed. We are confident of an early revival of negotiations with Mercosur. And we hope that the process for the approval of the agreement with Ecuador will develop as quickly as possible, and the country can be integrated in the successful Multiparts Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru.  Madam President, we hope that the European Commission will speed up the visa waiver process for the citizens of Colombia and Peru, as it no longer makes any sense for this matter to take longer.  We also welcome the changes taking place in Cuba and the progress of our negotiations with Havana. We may attend a historic milestone if everyone live up to the circumstances. As friends, we hope that lasting peace can be achieved in Colombia.  Nothing would be more rewarding if bullets were exchanged for votes in that beloved country, as we once heard President Santos say here in this very House.  But also, ladies and gentlemen, since respect for the Venezuelan people, we must condemn without mitigation the unacceptable drift of President Maduro's government. We hope that, on the occasion of the Summit, Venezuela will not be the protagonist for its outings of tone but for its positive participation. And, at this point, you will find sure understanding and solidarity. Ladies and gentlemen, Latin America is the region of the world with the most elements in common with Europe. Europe must look to Latin America for its own value and for being an essential part of Atlantic relations.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Madam Minister, I believe that in recent years we have wasted precious time maintaining the relationship that Latin America deserves with the European Union. I think we are taking a serious risk that Latin America's most dynamic countries will start looking more towards the Pacific than the Atlantic. Indeed, the Pacific Alliance is one of the most dynamic economic alliances at the moment in Latin America, largely as a result of a set of investments and trade agreements, not only with Korea or Japan, but also and especially with China.  I believe that in recent years, Madam Minister, the Council and the European Union in general have not been close enough to Latin America. We have wasted precious time even though, as you said, we are a fundamental strategic bi-regional alliance because we have a lot of common elements — such as a common history, common languages and beliefs in values, in democracy, in human rights that are common — to do much and good in the whole world: Latin America and the European Union.  It is this set of reflections that we will set out from Eurolat to the Summit of Heads of State, very happyly accepting the invitation they offer us in this direction. But the fundamental message is that we must intensify our work with Latin America; that we must indeed help to conclude new and better agreements with the countries with which we already have political and trade agreements; that Colombia and Peru must be relieved of the visa requirement, as has been said; to be helped in Cuba; to be helped in Colombia; that democracy in Venezuela must also be helped. We must help, that is, dialogue, and therefore make it easier not to destroy democracy in that country, and we will probably have to send some concrete messages for democracy in Venezuela to be saved and secured. These are the messages we're going to send, Madam Minister.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Madam Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the second EU-CELAC Summit on the theme will be held in Brussels next June: building our common future, working to create prosperous, cohesive and sustainable societies for our citizens. This is a unique opportunity to deepen the political dialogue on innovation for sustainable growth, education, security and climate change. It will also be a decisive moment to correct some successes in relations between the regions of Latin America and Europe. The deadlock in the free trade agreement between the European Union and Mercosur has caused some of these countries to focus on preferential trade agreements with Japan and the United States.  The European Union, as its largest investor in celac countries, cannot be left behind. I believe, therefore, that we will have to strengthen our bilateral relations with some Latin American countries, such as Brazil, a true regional power. I would like to cite, as an example, the need to speed up the construction of a digital submarine cable, which will connect Latin America to Europe via Brazil-Portugal. Another example will be the strengthening of the aeronautical sector on both sides of the Atlantic through cooperation with companies such as Brazil's Embraer, whose large investments in my country have been a success story. To finish, I hope that the affirmation of our common future will necessarily involve strengthening support for peace negotiations in Colombia, opening dialogue with Cuba and uncompromisingly defending the values of democracy in Venezuela, a country which the Representative of the Council has forgotten to mention.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the forthcoming European Union-Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC) summit allows us to compare two radically different models of regional integration, that of this Maastricht European Union, NATO, of the troika, a European Union where inequalities increase, where unemployment grows, where poverty grows and where repression and the cut of freedoms also increase, and another model, that of Latin America, that of Hugo Chavez's Venezuelan-driven ALBA, which emphasizes solidarity, justice and cooperation, that of CELAC, which sets as objectives the fight against poverty, the promotion of education and the fight against climate change. So, abstain from giving lessons to Latin America. We have little to teach and much to learn. That is why we hope that the next Summit will be in a framework of equality, symmetrical relations and respect for the sovereignty of Latin American countries. Overcome the colonialist stances of this Europe that is believed to be the navel of the world. May the Summit finally give the European Union's common position on Cuba. To serve as a clear support to the peace process in Colombia. Provide justice and reparation for victims, solve the problem of access to land, and eliminate their interference policies forever.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the Foreign Service, I believe that the Summit can be two things, and it would be a failed summit: it may be one more photo, of which practically nothing comes out, or it may be another festival of neoliberal free trade, which is what we have seen in recent years and what we are used to.  Or it could be something else. It can be a new impetus for a new agenda that addresses certain global challenges of interest to both Latin Americans and us: whether it's debt issues, what we can and must learn from Latin America, or the issues of climate change, which I hope will be a central element. I too believe that rethinking in a certain way the trade relations between the two blocs, not least because I am convinced that the account of free trade — which has been a bit the one that has articulated relations between the two blocs in recent years — is absolutely exhausted and, therefore, either the European Union has something new to offer Latin America, or the dialogue will obviously be channeled and that would obviously not benefit anyone.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, some people rightly complained that we are in danger of being overtaken in the reports by the Pacific Alliance. And I am not at all surprised, moreover, because unfortunately we still have the arrogance, the illusion of being the point of reference, but above all we have this desire to concentrate our relations with South America exclusively on the economic and commercial side. And that is why it is lost: Europe loses every time it renounces to put political relations first, relations based also on the fight against corruption, money laundering, climate change, every time it becomes a renunciation and thinks simply of cowardly pecunia, as some would have said. Instead, we must put development at the heart of our relationship with South America, as I said more harmoniously and at 360 degrees. We must win over our South American partners first with our brains and hearts and perhaps later with our pockets, but unfortunately many of us have not yet understood this.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, I hope that the forthcoming European Union-CELAC Summit will mark the beginning of a strengthening of relations between the European Union and Latin America and the Caribbean. Since taking office, Mrs Mogherini has shown her commitment to strengthening this very important relationship. Because the difficult challenges we are experiencing in the Eastern Neighbourhood or the Arab world cannot be a pretext for the European Union to forget, or marginalize, or postpone Latin America. The historical, economic, cultural links that link it with Europe are very close. Moreover, this part of the Americas is also, I would say, a natural ally of the European Union to meet global challenges. I think about climate change, energy, security, development, disarmament and much more. We share with these countries, as has already been said, the same vision of the human being and I would also say that of the world. The European Union and Latin America also share a commitment to integration processes. In addition, let me say that, given the numerous economic and trade agreements that unsothe many Latin American countries with the European Union and also with the United States, the conclusion of the TIC negotiations would open up the prospects for a large triangular economic space, in which many Latin American countries, as well as Canada, could also be present. I'm going back to the Summit. Many challenges of bi-regional interest should be present at this forthcoming Summit, as well as significant global challenges. The modernization of the agreements with Mexico and Chile, the impetus for negotiation with Mercosur, security challenges in Central America and the Caribbean, cooperation in education and technology, and the setting – and I finish – of a specific date, at last, for the abolition of visas to the citizens of Colombia and Peru have already been cited. Finally, I hope that the Summit will be crowned with great success and a boost, which we need, to Latin America's relationship with the European Union.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, Madam Minister, in the current geostrategic context all summits are very important, especially if the European Union can participate in these summits with a clear vision of its priorities, with a clear vision to consolidate a sustainable, peaceful and people-centred globalisation. In fact, strengthening relations between the European Union and CELAC is a great opportunity to rebalance relations between the major economic and political blocs on a global scale, bringing together territorial spaces that are linked by a common history and values with very strong humanist roots. It is important, however, that this summit does not just have good intentions. There is ample scope here for joint work in consolidating the processes of democratic stabilisation and openness and in deepening and developing free trade agreements containing the social and environmental standards which constitute a European reference for new globalisation.  Our expectation of the progress that can be made at this summit is very high. We expect a concerted response to the challenges posed by the instability in Venezuela and the opportunity for economic and political openness in Cuba. We expect a new impetus for free trade processes, in particular with Mercosur, we expect an articulated vision for the Paris Climate Summit and clear signs of willingness to cooperate in the energy transition process. We hope for a convergent vision of regulating the new digital economy so that access to knowledge, business opportunities, privacy protection, Net neutrality are common marks of a new cycle of globalization that will emerge with the new technological framework.  We live in a European Union tobessed by its ghosts and internal incongruities. But I have to admit that the action of the High Commissioner for Foreign Policy has been courageous and clarifying. That is why we hope and hope that this summit will be a factor of hope. It can not be to meet schedule, can not serve only to meet schedule.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). – Ladies and gentlemen, in today's critical circumstances, where cold war voices are intensifying, the effort to further develop relations with this region is a response to those who continue to propose deadlocked policies of intervention, blockades and embargoes. It is a response to these voices who have in the past supported the destabilisation of the region, by orchestrating coups, by imposing doctoral regimes and by economic and commercial exclusion. The voices that today support external attempts to destabilise democratically elected governments - such as that of Venezuela - and turn a blind eye to persecution and violations of the fundamental rights of indigenous peoples and human rights defenders, ignoring the colonial attitudes of multinational corporations. In the face of all this, ladies and gentlemen, we must fight to ensure that our relations are based on equality, mutual respect, the sovereignty of each state, the principle of non-interference in internal affairs and respect for the principles of human rights and the principles of international law and peace.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: – Madam President, Madam Minister, the June Summit will give us a new opportunity to strengthen ties with Latin America, which for Europe must be of strategic importance. One of the crucial issues is sustainable development in this region, where most countries are middle-income countries, but with the Union's correct policies and support for the implementation of these policies, they could finally cross that threshold that still separates them from the developed world.  Several times in the past Latin America seemed to be well on track, approaching that threshold, but then institutions would crumbled and go back to zero. Political and institutional development is therefore the outstanding subject in several Latin American countries. Caudillism or the temptation to reform constitutions to allow presidential re-elections are symptoms of the institutional fragility that impedes development.  To be sure, as has been said, the sharpest situation at the moment is Venezuela's, but it is not the only one. That is why it is important that Europe's focus on cooperation programmes focuses on strengthening democratic institutions in Latin America.

name: Constanze KREHL
text: Madam President, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The European Union has been successfully linked to Chile for twelve years through an association agreement. Much has been achieved: Chile is now one of the most stable countries in Latin America. Economic development has been very positive, and we have now reached a time when it must simply be said that, after twelve years, such an association agreement must be modernised. We in the European Union have a great interest in continuing the political dialogue, in ensuring greater cooperation, particularly in areas such as social cohesion, energy policy, education policy, cooperation – including with research institutions in Europe and Chile – and, of course, trade. Chilean President Bachelet has also proposed that a new association agreement between the EU and Chile should include gender policies and that LGBTI rights should take their place there. We very much welcome this and expect the EU-CELAC Summit to support this commitment to modernise this agreement and to take a real boost. I believe that we need this not only in relations with Chile, but also in cooperation with the Latin American countries as a whole.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: – Madam President, at the second CELAC Summit in 2014, the Latin American governments unanimously adopted a proclamation declaring Latin America and the Caribbean an area of peace and free of colonialism. It is with respect for this proclamation that we hope that the Eu-CELAC Summit and the eurolat assembly, which precedes it, will take place. On the basis, moreover, of the principles which CELAC itself proclaimed for itself and which do not allow any other kind of relations, as proved at the last Summit of the Americas held in Panama: multilateralism, dialogue, peaceful solutions, unconditional respect for the Charter of the United Nations and international law and the inalienable right of each country to choose its form of political and economic organization. And we also hope, for example, that they will learn from some policies, for example fao-awarded policies by the Venezuelan government to combat poverty, poverty and hunger.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Madam President, Madam President, in an increasingly globalised and at the same time fragmented world it is important to promote ever closer cooperation between the various regions of the globe and the European Union has to make choices and the choice of a more intense relationship with Latin America is almost a natural option, which stems precisely from the great cultural proximity between these two regions. We've wasted too much time in the past. It's time to make up for that lost time. We are negotiating today, the European Union is negotiating a major transatlantic agreement with the United States. This is a very important step in creating, in fact, a large Euro-Atlantic area. But we cannot ignore the importance of relations with Latin America, nor can we run the risk of these relations being devalued, and so we must make a great effort to strengthen existing cooperation at various levels.  Many South American countries have recently had successful democratic experiences, which have had economic growth, promoted the creation of consistent middle classes, which have come to give more strength to their political choices. There are now increased reasons for trying to enhance this relationship.  I would like to refer specifically to an issue which I think is of the utmost importance, the question of the trade agreement between the European Union and Mercosur. We must definitely overcome the obstacles that have prevented the implementation of this agreement and the European Union must also overcome these same difficulties within itself. It is time to overcome national selfishness that jeopardises a common will to move towards an agreement of the utmost importance for all these countries.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, I welcome the summit to be held in Brussels between the European Union and the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States.
