There are a billion people and the potential for cooperation between the two large communities is enormous. The ideas and proposals resulting from this summit will inform the policies and heads of state and government in order to increase and strengthen investment and cooperation. I would therefore like to recall the fundamental role that this summit plays in promoting greater scientific cooperation between Europe and Latin America and the Caribbean.  From the last summit, an action plan was given priority to scientific cooperation with the aim of creating an EU-CELAC area of knowledge. This initiative seems very important and I call for continued promotion and for steps to be taken in this direction at this next summit. Access to finance must be ensured, for example, by ensuring that programmes such as Horizon 2020 remain robust.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the second Summit of the European Union-Latin American and Caribbean Countries (CELAC) could, under certain conditions, be a historic meeting. To do this, however, it should focus on "follow up", then to be given to the implementation of the decision taken by the UN General Assembly in September 2014 on procedures for the write-off of government debt, as both latin American and European region countries that have been placed in memoranda are facing a huge sovereign debt crisis. Because, without the write-off of the shameful debt, there can be no growth in the European Union and Latin America which have been overwhelmed by armies of the unemployed and millions of poor because of austerity policies. In addition, the Joint Initiative on Research and Innovation should target the social inclusion of millions of unemployed young scientists in both Europe and Latin America. The dialogue on migration could contribute to the exchange of good practices.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, I wish success to this 8th EU-CELAC summit to be held in Brussels because there are many reasons why we want such success. There are those human reasons, there are those cultural, economic, political reasons. Indeed, human connection and everything that binds us to Latin America to Europe is so important, and that's why I want success for this summit.  What I want to emphasize in particular are certainly good developments in Cuba, in Venezuela, and we believe that such a thing will be soon in Colombia. We want Venezuela to reach far better values than it has today.  But what I want to warn about is something else: it is the problem of the arrival of cocaine and the countries that will be present at CELAC, at this summit, and therefore I ask that this be seriously discussed as well as one detail – xylelli fastidiosi – that we talked about here, which came to Iż Costa Rica in Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, the EU-CELAC summit is fundamental in order to strengthen relations between European, Latin-American and Caribbean countries. This will be a useful platform to discuss regional and global issues with our partners. Hopefully this year we will have the chance to talk about EU-Cuba relations, about the Venezuela situation and about the Colombian peace process, as well as about the trade agreement with Mexico and the revitalisation of trade agreements with Mercosur. I completely agree with Ms Mogherini when she states that we share cultural and historical roots and a wish for peace and prosperity. I would also like to underline the importance of the EuroLat Parliamentary Assembly to strengthening the monitoring of democracy and legitimisation as part of cooperation between countries.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/on behalf of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, in just a few weeks’ time we will have 61 heads of state and government in Brussels – about one third of the United Nations membership, representing around a billion citizens.  But, as the saying goes, we are much more than the sum of our parts. Over the last few years, the EU and CELAC have accumulated a considerable stock of political and economic capital, which is the reflection of a modern relationship developing in terms of equality and mutual respect. Today’s debate has put forward ideas and perceptions which show that, while the region is indeed diverse, there is no one-size-fits-all approach. It also presents itself as a constructive partner with whom we can work and achieve things.  Several of you mentioned development cooperation with Latin America. The EU continues to provide aid to the poorest Latin American countries at bilateral level with development cooperation, and it increased regional cooperation to foster integration. The overall budget for 2014-2020 under the Development Cooperation Instrument is about EUR 2.4 billion. You also asked about trade negotiations. Commissioner Malmström is planning a meeting with Mercosur ministers in the margins of the summit to try to relaunch negotiations on trade agreements.  Moments such as the upcoming summit will serve to reaffirm this relationship of equals and explore the modalities in which, together, we can address common challenges. But summits, whichever they may be, are just another stepping stone in the process. What is essential is to ensure a proper follow-up of what is discussed by leaders. This is why we will also propose at the summit to reinstall ministerial meetings in the year between the summits so as to strengthen our relations and ensure continuity.  Thank you very much for this debate.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. (The meeting is suspended for a few moments) Written statements (Article 162)

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. –  Now is the time to infuse new vibrancy into our relations with Latin America and the Caribbean. I truly hope that the upcoming EU-CELAC Summit will mark the start of a renewed focus on many important areas of cooperation. The Summit provides the perfect opportunity to send a clear message on how to strengthen our trade ties with the region. I expect a clear political push for the upgrade of our trade relations with Mexico, as well as new momentum to our longstanding negotiations with Mercosur. Both sides must begin taking steps now to move forward.  While highlighting trade relations with the region, Europe must also be active in supporting civil society in Latin America. A strong civil society is vital to the democratic process. We must give additional support to countries such as Cuba during its transition to ensure that fundamental rights are respected throughout the process. The human rights situation in Venezuela is worsening. Supporting civil society there is key to ensuring a peaceful and democratic solution to the current crisis. As a first step, all political prisoners must be freed.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the oral issue in the Council on the Youth Employment Initiative - the need for rapid implementation at Member State level, by Marita Ulvskog, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000051/2015 - B8-0551/2015) (2015/2679 (RSP)).

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: author. – Madam President, the crisis has caused youth unemployment to reach alarming levels in many Member States and regions. Many young people are deprived of taking on a first job and are thus obstructed from assuming independent adult lives. In 2013, to urgently help address the situation, the Youth Employment Initiative was adopted. The purpose of this initiative is to provide funding to promote youth employment in the most affected regions of the European Union, including by establishing youth guarantee schemes.  With a view to ensuring swift implementation, the Youth Employment Initiative was front-loaded and expenditure was made eligible as of 1 September 2013. Yet well over one year into the programme, the results on the ground do not meet initial expectations. Measures designed to allow for a quick uptake of funds have not led to a quick and efficient mobilisation of the Youth Employment Initiative, and opportunities to urgently address youth unemployment have been left unused. The initiative was initially proposed by the European Council, yet at present – over one-and-a-half years after expenditure was made eligible – Member States’ use of its resources falls far short of expectations, and progress is uneven. Besides a lack of liquidity to launch the Youth Employment Initiative, an issue now addressed by the proposed substantial increase in pre-financing, what is holding Member States back? How does the Council intend to urgently encourage swift and efficient implementation? The Member States faced with the highest youth unemployment rates and hardest hit by the crisis are, on average, lagging behind in using Youth Employment Initiative resources and implementing Youth Guarantee schemes, while long-term policies are needed to address this issue.  What specific hurdles do they face? What improvements can the Council promise? Can the Council ensure sound funding for the Youth Employment Initiative once the frontloading funds have been used? Parliament is expecting a quick, efficient and result-oriented use of the additional pre-financing within 12 months after the entry into force of the amending regulation. What measures does the Council envisage in order to assure the young unemployed, and Parliament, of this swift use of funds? How does it intend to report on progress to the young unemployed, to Parliament, and to other stakeholders involved? Can the Council promise an assessment of progress six months after the entry into force of the amending regulation? How does the Council intend to proceed where those results do not meet expectations, even after the current increased pre-financing?

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I am grateful for this opportunity to discuss with you the youth labour market situation in the European Union. The Presidency attached great importance to improving the conditions of groups facing the biggest challenges to accessing or remaining in employment. These groups include, in particular, young people, and among them especially those without proper education and skills.  Fighting youth unemployment and ensuring sustainable labour market integration remains a top priority for the EU. Indeed, the Europe 2020 strategy has put a special focus on implementing effective measures to address youth unemployment.  The reality is that youth unemployment is still at a very high level in several Member States, leading to underutilised talents, the loss of human resources and, in some cases, leaving damaging consequences for the rest of the working life.  In this context, the Youth Guarantee, together with the financial provisions of the Youth Employment Initiative, are highly relevant: both measures seek to support the fight against youth unemployment in the most affected regions, namely those with youth unemployment rates above 25%.  As a positive example, I would like to underscore the experience of Latvia. Latvia is one of the countries which started the implementation of the Youth Guarantee as of January 2014. We can already see the first results: the youth unemployment rate decreased by 3.8% in 2014. A lot depends on the programmes implemented by the Member States. Nevertheless, it is already clear that more needs to be done.  Despite the promising stimulus, the Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee are not a panacea to solve Europe’s youth unemployment problems. They are part of a range of tools to address the issue. As we all know, the shorter implementation period of the Youth Employment Initiative compared to the Multiannual Financial Framework cycle means that concrete progress in the first years will be crucial for the overall success of the Initiative. This can help to tackle the problem faced by the millions of young Europeans who are without a job and who do not have adequate access to education or training.  Therefore, I am convinced that the honourable Members of the European Parliament share my view that any further delay in the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative is likely to weaken the impact of actions undertaken by Member States to combat youth unemployment. One of the main obstacles in the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative is the lack of sufficient cash flow to provide advance payments to beneficiaries. The Presidency wants to highlight the importance and timeliness of the current legislative proposal to accelerate the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative. I therefore fully agree with the European Parliament that making funding available to Member States earlier in the implementation process is a key condition for improving the performance and generating tangible results soon. Sufficient liquidity at the beginning of the implementation process will allow for faster delivery of the relevant policy measures set out in the national Youth Guarantee Implementation Plans. We can be proud that the current amending legislative proposal has been finalised in record time. The Council adopted the draft proposal yesterday. Today, immediately after your vote, we, together with President Schulz, co—signed the text already. After the publication, which will occur in the coming week, Member States will be able to receive pre-financing.  In total, the initial pre-financing made available from the specific allocation for the Youth Employment Initiative will be increased to about EUR 1 billion in 2015.  I would like to take this opportunity to reaffirm that the Council will continue to actively monitor developments concerning the youth employment situation and the implementation by the Member States of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative. At the same time, we need to keep in mind that the causes behind youth unemployment are complex. The increase in funding is complementary to other measures and reforms that Member States have to make in order to tackle the different crisis-related and structural problems behind the youth employment situation. All in all, to significantly reduce unemployment, we need to do more to create new jobs.  Last but not least, let me also underscore the important role the Social Partners play in this context.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, I would like to say this evening to our representative of the Council that the Member States wanted this initiative for youth employment. It's their invention. They have made cheap communication about the youth employment initiative. Sometimes, I must say, they have created confusion between the youth guarantee and the youth employment initiative. But this initiative for youth employment corresponds to a real need of citizens; you were talking about the importance of the number of unemployed young people that calls for a very strong reaction.  However, in the first year of operation of this youth employment initiative, there was a real weakness in the Implementation of the Member States. There are some good examples — you're quoting them right now — but that's not the case everywhere. Was it a lack of funding? We reacted immediately to the quarter turn. On this subject, for once, the reaction of the European Union has been of exceptional speed.  And in three months, we increase pre-financing from 1% to 3%. Thank you to all the political groups who helped us react. Thank you to the Council and thank you to the Commission. But we will not let go of anything because what we want is for this device to be used. I have seen many ministers who still confuse youth guarantee with youth employment initiative. I saw a lot of people who needed information, communication.  We really want this initiative to be implemented, so help us and put pressure on the Member States.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear representative of the Council, I am pleased to have the opportunity once again to address the serious issue of youth unemployment just a few weeks after the adoption of the measure to increase the amount of pre-financing for the youth employment initiative.  Today, the European Parliament is calling on the Member States to show seriousness in tackling the scourge of unemployment among young Europeans. We need assurances that the Council is prepared to fight for its young people, whatever the cost: 'ready to do whatever it takes', to use a terminology that we are all well aware of.  We have said this before, I repeat today: Parliament has played a team game with the Commission and the Council in approving the amendment to the ESF regulation, thus allowing the release of resources for the Member States in record time. However, the time has now come to produce results, to launch programmes and to overcome obstacles once and for all.  This is not just a financial problem, though. Firstly, major problems linked to excessive bureaucracy in the registration of programmes for both young people and companies, the partners who would like to join, will have to be resolved. It will also be essential to strengthen the communication aspect of these programmes, which is totally inadequate to date. Many young people, especially those who need it most, do not even know the existence of the youth guarantee and the youth employment initiative. This is frankly absurd.  We need to change gears quickly. Efforts must be stepped up so that young people receive quality offers, preventing the risk of these instruments becoming an antechamber to precariousness or even an instrument of exploitation. All this must be pursued by the Member States, with the help of the Commission and with the supervision of Parliament. They must rise to a challenge that can define or cost the fortunes of an entire generation. The youth employment initiative alone is not capable of creating new jobs. There are no magic wands: alongside the rapid and efficient use of all the resources offered by the Union, we need to combine a policy of economic growth that depends on investments in strategic sectors. In essence, therefore, we need a European industrial policy, the ability to distribute income in a Union that is still too marked by inequalities to leave a better future for future generations. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Yes, I also think what you think is the need for quality jobs, but do you see a monitoring and evaluation system that can really guarantee that, when using money, governments not only provide some kind of 'alibi' jobs, not just spend money in general, not only improve statistics, but also help young people in a real, verifiable way?

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I believe that we need a mixture of actions: on the one hand, an ability to grow the economy so that the jobs, the jobs that are created are real and so that these projects, these European funds, do not become subsidies, therefore subsidy policies, but really are labour activists; on the other hand, we need the Commission, with clear indications, and Parliament to watch over the Member States. So, you need both.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, unemployment in my country and in my own region of the West Midlands has in fact been declining significantly over the last few years. Unemployment amongst the 16-24 year olds has been falling rapidly over the last year. Yet it edged down only slightly in the 3 months to March and, as a result, youth unemployment now stands at 15.9%, and the most recent figures from the CBI show that unemployment actually rose last month in the West Midlands.  So whatever the statistics tell us, what I know is that we still have six and a half thousand 16-24 year olds unemployed in the city of Birmingham. So we need to take a very good look at what is, and what is not, successful.  The Youth Employment Initiative has fallen very short of expectations. I find the Court of Auditors report very worrying and I particularly welcome the opportunity of an exchange of views with Iliana Ivanova, in the Employment Committee next week, on the ECA’s special report. If the Youth Employment Initiative is not having a positive impact, we should be looking carefully at why this is the case and, in a week when we see the better regulation package announced by Vice President Timmermans, let us make sure that we help SMEs, because that is where growth comes, and that is where jobs for young people will come.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the reason we are here this evening is to ask searching questions about the Youth Employment Initiative. Some of those questions have been put already. They include: why has the uptake been so slow, what is the delay, what improvements can we expect, and when? I do not need to quote the youth unemployment figures. All of us in this House know that they are unacceptably high. The EU institutions have put forward the Youth Employment Initiative as their response to youth unemployment. We are supposed to be adding value at European level and yet, so far, unfortunately, there seems to be little European added value. If we are to be successful, the Council must play its role (and it is a hugely important role) in implementing the Youth Employment Initiative. There is plenty of flexibility within the Youth Employment Initiative: the possibility to provide traineeships and apprenticeships, the provision of first job experience, targeted and well-designed wage and recruitment subsidies, job and training mobility measures and start-up support for young entrepreneurs.  The Council has already told us that the Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee are not a panacea. We know that, but they are substantial and the reason we are pushing the Council is because we are genuinely concerned about the delay regarding this issue of youth unemployment. As our question says, we are expecting a quick, efficient and result-oriented use of the additional pre-financing. My colleague, Anthea McIntyre, has spoken about the issues raised by the Court of Auditors in regard to the Youth Guarantee. We have already had an exchange of views with the Court of Auditors and some of these issues need to be addressed: the fact that there was no proper ex-ante assessment carried out and that Member States did not provide accurate and complete information in regard to the source of funding used to support their Youth Guarantee implementation plans. These issues need to be addressed but, crucially, we are expecting Member States to take on their full responsibility and immediately implement the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, beyond the reasonable doubts raised in Marita Ulvskog's question there is a structural problem, which is that social cuts policies are leading countries that implement them towards a change of model in which precariousness and poverty become the norm, a model in which it is normal to work and not reach the end of the month. In order to implement expansion and job creation policies, we must, inter alia, find a reasonable and dialogued solution to the debt problem in southern Europe, democratise the European Central Bank and address in our countries progressive tax reform that increases taxes on the richest. Meanwhile, measures such as the Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee function rather as an excuse to transfer public funds to businesses, lowering the temporary recruitment of children under the age of 26 and on the basis of an erroneous premise: the lack of employability of young people.  Young people need no more training, but a new economic policy that injects public money into the economy and creates quality and socially useful jobs. Youth self-employment currently involves, in many cases, the indebtedness and bankruptcy of a business that has no market or consumers. If we continue to impoverish the population and cut into public funds, the demand for goods and services that private companies, cooperatives and self-employed companies can provide will continue to contract and limit their possibilities. We reiterate our commitment to a new economic course that places useful and quality job creation at the centre.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we are having this debate today because the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has posed an oral question to the Council under the title ‘Youth Employment Initiative – need for swift implementation at Member State level’. As important as this question is, I would assume that at least 99% of EU citizens do not have a clue what an oral question actually is and what this debate is about. So I thought I should explain. It is stated in the question that the financial and economic crisis ʽhas caused youth unemployment to reach alarming levels in many Member States’. Let me translate this statement briefly and bluntly.  Neo-liberal policies, following a deregulation agenda, have messed up European economies and created massive levels of youth unemployment in recent years. The group most affected by this are young people who had no opportunity to influence the policies that led to this situation. Now, as a reaction to this, we see a common pattern – youth is blamed, the EU reacts, the EU allocates money. For me, it is still far too little, but, well, the EU allocated money to fight youth unemployment that is now supposed to be spent by the Member States in the regions most affected by youth unemployment. The oral question reads: ‘results on the ground do not meet initial expectations’. Wow! This sentence is almost too diplomatic to even be translated, but I will try. Many Members of this Parliament, including me, are simply outraged by the fact that the money allocated to the Member States for the Youth Employment Initiative has still, after 22 months, not been properly taken up. We, as parliamentarians, thus use this tool of an oral question to tell the Member States very clearly that we need to see action now. I hope that many citizens will follow this example and go out on the streets, write letters and pose questions to their governments, urging them to take action.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the Council's representation; I have asked myself on several occasions why an initiative which was so obvious is so obvious that it should have had the specific aim, alas, of solving the problem of unemployment and not of increasing employment. Because, unfortunately, we are currently working in the emergency of a very serious problem, such as unemployment, which obviously does not allow us to make long-term projects, which does not allow us to think about the future, create jobs and innovate. Mrs Morin-Chartier made one point: she said that very often the youth employment initiative is confused with the youth guarantee, and this is a problem that ministers and Heads of Government very often have. Very often, unfortunately, I have to say that many people probably do not even know what the youth employment initiative is, and they also do not know what the guarantee is for young people, and not to make a difference between the two and to determine which is one and which is the other. This is even more serious, because if we knew what the opportunities were, if specific programmes were made that really take into account the needs of our young people, well, perhaps we could make policies that are much more effective, which is unfortunately not the case in my country. We missed all the goals.  I can ask one thing, because I continue to be ashamed of the way in which the opportunities provided by the European Union are wasted: monitor closely how these resources are used by the countries and Member States, supervise, monitor the programmes, monitor the way in which the money is implemented, because I can assure you that the young people who have benefited from these resources in Italy are counting on the fingers of one hand – let me pass the comparison , which doesn't hold up that much, but that's the reality. That is the reality and we must take note of it.  I call for monitoring, for careful and continuous monitoring of how this money is used.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: – Madam President, we must recognise that the results achieved do not yet meet expectations and we must therefore work together to make the Initiative a useful and effective instrument. One of the main obstacles to implementation seems solved. Increasing pre-financing will allow Member States that were unable to advance funds due to liquidity problems to implement the actions necessary for young people to join the labour market. Therefore, we must be able to identify and solve other obstacles that may exist. But I am optimistic, and let me therefore set an example for my own country. Spain is one of the countries with the highest rates of youth unemployment. It has a decentralized model that slows down its implementation in some cases, but despite these difficulties, it is one of the first to have put in place the necessary measures. We already have more than forty-eight thousand registrations, 43% of women, who, thanks to increased pre-financing and on-the-fly advertising campaigns, will be exponentially multiplied. Cooperation with chambers of commerce, increased business involvement and improved job-seeking advice to achieve the objectives can also help a great part.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is sad how long this takes and how the opportunities of many young Europeans are wasted, even destroyed, by lack of initiative. But we here in the European Parliament will not let up in the fight against youth unemployment. That is why it was important for us to put this question to the Council today for oral answers. After all, we are still light years away from the goal of reducing youth unemployment in Europe or even going to zero. For years there have been effective summits, public conferences, fine words, many promises – but nothing has happened. And time and again reasons and problems were pointed out for the failure. At first there was no money, then money was made available. Then there was money, but it was not retrieved. Then co-financing or pre-financing was the problem, and we have now solved that. But now there must finally be no more excuses. Now the Member States must finally act and show really visible initiatives. Help the youth, please!

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: – We know that the Commission's proposal to increase the pre-financing of the Youth Initiative has been met with significant support here in Parliament. However, this support is not a blank cheque. Above all, there will be no more excuses for which the programme does not work as it should. If, despite the increase, we are unable to offer young people the skills and work we have promised them, this will show, above all, the doubt of such schemes. In fact, if the activation of the unemployed has worked well in Finland, for example, and is now failing in the states where it is most needed, it shows that the problem of unemployment is more complicated and requires other solutions. The European Union can help, but only really ready. That is why I am really most interested in the Council's answer to the last question today, namely: if, despite the time has passed, the increase in resources and professional assistance, the Member States are not able to help the young effectively, are we still sure that we do not know better ways of helping?

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: – Madam President, in addition to labour market reforms, the Youth Employment Initiative is one of the important tools to increase young people's activity in the labour market. I therefore consider the report that the European Council increased pre-financing by almost EUR 1 billion in 2015 to be very important. I am all the more pleased that the approval in the European Commission, Parliament and the Council has taken place in a record short period of time. Effective and meaningful cooperation is the only way that can lead to a better future for young people. We are all aware that the unemployment gap between Member States is abysmal. In some countries, there are even higher numbers of young people out of work than those employed. Other countries, on the other hand, are so good at employment for young people that they will not reach the funds of the initiative at all. I believe that now that pre-financing has been approved by the European Council, the whole implementation process will be accelerated. It is worrying that, more than a year after the launch of the initiative, we do not see real results and the opportunities available remain untapped. Are administrative obstacles causing this situation? Or vague definitions like "quality employment" that set hard-to-define and evaluatable goals?  I would like to personally call on the Member States to take this great opportunity to change the plight of the labour market responsibly and to make real effective use of the hand shake. How do you, representatives of the Council, want to motivate the Member States?

name: Karima DELLI
text: Madam President, Madam Representative of the Council, I have a very simple message to convey. Tell the Heads of State or Government: "Stop the blah blah blah. Be bold. Be really brave. Make sure that the priority of your policy choices is youth employment!" To date, according to the Court of Auditors, no jobs have been created as a result of the European Youth Initiative. The delay in ignition, which the Member States have committed, is no longer justifiable since it has been said that the envelope has been increased. Of course, administrative arrangements need to be improved to actively support young people and protect them from poverty and exclusion, but the future must be built. Heads of state or government need to understand that we know the areas of the future. What are they? Renewable energy, thermal insulation. We also know digital. That's where you really need to invest. What for? Because all of these opportunities are strong, sustainable and non-relocable opportunities. Ladies and gentlemen, heads of state or government, you no longer have the right to make communication. Youth is no longer a variable of adjustment.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, well who could possibly have guessed that we would end up here – a headline EU policy involving taxpayers’ money that just has not worked out. It kind of sums up the European Union really, does it not? A big idea, splashing about taxpayers’ money like cologne, and the results are ineffective and disappointing. And when countries realise that this EU state intervention is not right for their countries, what does this Parliament seek to do but try to force them to do it the EU way anyway! There is such a simple alternative: British taxpayers funding British projects with British knowledge to get British young people into work; German taxpayers funding German projects; Latvian taxpayers funding Latvian projects. It is so simple and straightforward. It does not have to be the EU way. Stop interfering and leave countries to spend their own money to support their own young people.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Madam President, Madam Chair of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has done very well to ask her last question. What if the increase in pre-financing does not work within 12 months? No doubt it is struck by the grace of lucidity because, with the same causes producing the same effects, the inconsistent use of European funds, in this case the ESF, will continue to reinforce youth unemployment rather than reduce it. Indeed, more unemployment equals more payroll taxes, equals fewer hires: a vicious circle that all Member States are familiar with. It is therefore urgent to move away from the sphere of words and jargon used for more than 30 years in this institution and to take action: let us reduce European constraints on states and businesses, especially SMEs and SMEs; free up normative constraints on vocational training and employment; let's put the brakes on entrepreneurship and energy. Stop the colossal sums poured into bottomless and uncontrolled wells! See you in a year. Alas, barring any surprises, the negative results are known in advance.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – It is almost summer and it is almost eight years after the great financial crisis hit Europe. Banks faltered, businesses went upside down and unemployment skyrocketed. Six school leavers entered the labour market without the best prospects. Unemployment among young people is sky-high across Europe. The European Parliament has been working for a new perspective for young people from the regions most affected. Partly because of this commitment, money is now available for pre-financing. Programmes to guide young people into the labour market no longer have to wait for governments in their countries to complete co-financing. They don't have to waste time. But noblesse oblige, nobility obliged. In six months' time, we want to know whether we are on the right track, because we do not want an eighth rate of school leavers without prospects in the labour market.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: – Madam President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, if there is one thing to play in Europe's credibility, if anything is played, in the face of our voters and in the face of European citizenship, the possibility of the European project is to end the scourge of massive and brutal unemployment. It is fundamental to the future of our young people in particular.  If the Council has decided to take charge of this, I think that is very good. For life should be severed, but that it makes the Member States work, that they do not come with absolutely useless excuses in the face of the drama that is being lived: that if administrative decentralised;  that if they do not have administrative capabilities; that if the money is late for them. Look at you: we're not kidding! The last thing I've heard is that, moreover, talking about quality jobs means that certain projects cannot be picked up. It's absurd. We want to include young people and they have to do it now!

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, what we are clear about is that you have not just launched the Youth Employment Initiative. Even though it had made an effort to pre-finance States, knowing that deficit targets were drowning out funding for some States, it has not just worked.  We have five million young people standing still — five million young people under the age of 25 — and it turns out that the Eurobarometer recently reminded us that only eight out of ten have heard of this Initiative—only eight out of ten—and talks about how effective we are. But let's take some example: the example of Spain has been set. Spain is important, not only because it has a lot of youth unemployment, but above all because it is the first country in resources. It turns out that out of the 800,000 young people, only 48,000 have registered, and I say 'registered' because they have only been registered; that's not to say they've found a job, or that they're forming. And it also turns out that the resources are going to be devoted to tax deductions, that is, they're going to fire your father to hire you for half the European Union's subsidized price. That's a scandal!

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Madam President, I would like to raise some concerns regarding the measurement of the efficiency of the Youth Guarantee in some Member States. For impact assessment we need certain criteria and the youth unemployment rate is only one of them. In Eastern and Southern Europe, we can observe rapid changes to young populations due to emigration. For example, in Estonia the youth unemployment rate went down from about 17% at the beginning to about 12 % at the end of 2014: what a success story! But if unemployment rates fall basically due to a youth exodus, these figures cannot prove the efficiency of the program. The Commission shall also consider the unemployment rates of key social groups. In my country, the annual unemployment rate for ethnic Estonians is 1.6 times lower than for Russian speakers. Russian speakers made up 27% in this age group, but their unemployment rate was almost 21%. This aggregated statistical data is crucial for the adequate analysis of any measures, including the Youth Guarantee.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: – Madam President, I would like to start by welcoming the decision to supplement the pre-financing funds on the Youth Employment Initiative. For the greatest impact, I encourage the Commission to allocate even more resources to programmes aimed at combating unemployment, with a focus on encouraging entrepreneurship among young people and women and to work with Member States, the European Investment Fund, the European Investment Bank to create an advisory group to develop financing mechanisms for new businesses for young people and women ,in each Member State. This will facilitate their development. Only then will we be able to preserve their creative ideas in the European Union. As far as the education system is concerned, in my opinion, it must be anchored in reality and as practical as possible. In order to achieve this, we must insist that the Member States improve and intensify relations between the main actors involved, namely governments, employers, public or private educational institutions and, last but not least, civil society organisations in each Member State. As a representative of youth, I believe that the school must provide real debugging to graduates and ensure them a smooth transition to the field.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Madam President, this scheme had been running for a year before – in March 2014 – the Tory Government of the UK even presented any programmes to draw down any money whatsoever. They then only proposed to draw down a minimum amount. There were EUR 206 million available to the UK, tens of millions of euros available to help put young people in my region of the West Midlands back into work. The United Kingdom Government, led by these Conservatives has now put in a minimal proposition to draw it down a year late. And, of course, they refuse to accept the basic rules that apply to everybody else in the Union, that govern this scheme, to enable the money to be drawn down. They will not in fact draw it down unless it is done in their own special different way. The result is that young people in the West Midlands, tens of thousands of them, remain unemployed.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Madam President, the question being discussed is actually one: what is the Council's attitude to the implementation of the youth guarantee so noisily advertised for several years now? In the questions that were asked to the Council and did not receive a response in the opening statement, I draw attention to two. Will the Council commit itself to an assessment of the progress of the implementation of this guarantee, six months after it enters into force under the revised Regulation and what will the Council do if this guarantee clearly does not work? These are the questions we want answered, it is the duty of the Council, in every meeting of Labour and Social Affairs ministers, to put first and for all how the guarantee is implemented.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her 153 billion a year – this sum is probably known to everyone in this House – is the cost of youth unemployment in Europe. Nevertheless, in many countries there are still problems with the submission of projects and the collection of funds. I would like to point out that the young people themselves are already criticising this programme, precisely because the resources do not reach young people at all. I would like to draw your attention, representatives of the Council, to a campaign by the European Trade Union Confederation and its youth associations: Back to our Future. This campaign clearly shows the image of European policy among young people. Unimaginable sums have been made available for bank bailouts within a very short period of time. But when it comes to young people, far too little money arrives far too late. I don't think that this feeling of young people is deceptive. I hope that all Member States will soon be able to say the same thing as the European Parliament, namely to have done its job.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As you can all feel, we are concerned with 5 million young people who are without education, without work, without prospects. We do not want to console us with fine words, we want concrete measures, that is to say the European Youth Guarantee plus the Youth Employment Initiative. Only if the EUR 6 billion – and there are more – are not called up if the regional institutions do not agree on competences, if cofinancing in problem regions and crisis states is not enough, does that only mean that we are preventing the impediments to effective trade. I therefore ask you, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, whether the Youth Guarantee will be better implemented if the advance amount rises from 1% to 30%? Will you put the issue on the agenda at the Council summits all the time? Do you involve the social partners? Do you ensure that small and medium-sized enterprises are naturally involved? We in the European Parliament never want to leave those affected alone. I believe that this message has arrived. I hope that you can convince the Member States of this.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, Representative of the Council, the Youth Unemployment Initiative was welcomed with gratitude when it was adopted in 2013. In the run-up to the elections, there was talk to young people by a great many parties that this is also your continent, Europe is also working for you. Where is the credibility of the Union if young people are promised in large letters, but this money, which is also available, does not materialis all the way to them? The treatment of youth unemployment must not be tired at any level. We must constantly struggle to find new ways and practices. All means and tools must be used, and society as a whole, the public sector, businesses, small businesses and NGOs must be involved, projects must be found and good ideas shared, not forgetting softer sectors either. There is a lot of work to be done in Europe. I refuse to talk about the lost generation. Young people and generations of the Depression must also be able to provide the keys to independent living, experience and education so that they can take Europe forward.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Madam President, two years after the launch of the Youth Employment Initiative, this is not yet being implemented throughout the Union as expected, to the detriment of young Europeans. The youth unemployment rate remains at absurdly high levels at a time when all the conditions for its full implementation are made available, and I therefore urge the Council to quickly help to resolve this situation. In order to motivate the Member States that have not yet implemented this initiative, I would like to leave here the example of my country, Portugal, which, after a very tough programme of financial assistance, has implemented the Youth Initiative and despite maintaining unacceptable numbers of youth unemployment, begins to check the effects of the implementation of this programme, namely: in the various measures of the Youth Guarantee, in the last two years , about 246,000 young people are involved; in the last year alone, we have seen unemployment falling by 2.2% to around 15,000 young people aged 15-24, but if we extend this range from 15 to 34, as proposed by this Parliament, then we have 50,000 fewer young people involved unemployed.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, seven million unemployed young people, seven million people whose future is being called into question – a project such as the Youth Employment Initiative should have generated new jobs, especially in disadvantaged areas. By contrast, projects are missing, even though the pre-financing rate for them has increased. We can no longer afford to wait for the Member States to wake up. Therefore, if States are not up to it, I propose that these funds be converted into programmes directly managed by the European Union and into grants and de minimis aid for young people, schools or the employing company. We need to realise that unemployed young people can no longer wait for national bureaucracies to move and need measures that are easy to understand, use and access. Each passing day is more than a procedural stage and a day in the lives of seven million young Europeans, who have lost hope that they can live a normal life. Because some of the Member States don't care!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). – Austerity has filled the European Union with armies of unemployed people. We have over five million unemployed young people. In Greece, in November 2014, the unemployment rate was 50.5%.  In January 2015, in Italy the youth unemployment rate reached 41.5%, in Spain 50.9%. If we really want youth unemployment to be stopped, we need to change policy, we need to stop the policy of austerity, we need to write off the shameful debt . Secondly, how much is the amount available to support youth employment? EUR 6 billion for the employment initiative, EUR 10 billion for the youth guarantee. But Mr. Draghi has 1.1 trillion euros for quantitative easing. And finally, do you know why these measures don't work? Because it needs state co-financing. Member States do not have these funds. In Greece, in order to co-finance the initiative, the Greek state will have to allocate 160 million euros so that the European Union can allocate another 160 million euros.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Madam President, my 60 seconds today I will use, not to point out problems, but to propose solutions. If we are going to deal with youth problems, then we better do it with a youth approach and in the language of young people. Experience has taught us that no matter how much money we spend on employment, what counts in the end is how many young people have found work. Let's take a step forward, let's move from subsidiary employment to promoting youth entrepreneurship, let's wake up the entrepreneur in every young person outside, let employees in the labour offices not just clerks, let them remove their ties and go on the field to those who need them. Let's use smartphones to combat youth unemployment, let the employment services have an app so that they are close to young people. Last but not least, young people hate queues, they hate to line up at the overs, they hate bureaucracy and a lot of paperwork. Let's eliminate this bureaucracy, let's give the young a chance and they will overturn Europe.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, colleagues, efforts to address the alarmingly high levels of youth unemployment must be common, targeted, effective action-oriented. I appreciate the actions taken so far aimed at increasing youth employment, especially the Youth Employment Initiative, but despite the efforts made in this direction, as of February 2015, nearly 5 million euro had been young people were out of work in the European Union. Aware of the serious difficulties that Member States are experiencing in launching operational programmes, support under the Youth Employment Initiative, I was among those Members of the European Parliament who supported the European Commission's proposal to increase their pre-financing. I know that the allocation of additional funds alone will not solve the problem. I would therefore like to ask the Council: what action do you intend to take with regard to the applications of the so-called and how do you think to adequately take into account the results achieved?

name: Soraya POST
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We must bear in mind that unemployment is not only due to a lack of work or a lack of education. For a large group of people in the EU, unemployment is primarily about racism and discrimination. The Roma have always been among the most marginalised groups in the EU. In the bad times that have been, it is, of course, much harder. Unemployment among Roma is three times higher than among the majority population. Roma young people are over-represented in the group of young people not working or studying in the EU. That is why Member States must make special efforts on Roma youth in their youth guarantees, and the EU Youth Initiative must also be targeted specifically at Roma. This is a crucial issue in order for Europe's young Roma to have a chance at a better life than their parents and for us to put an end to the anti-Gypsyism that prevails. I hope you take it with you.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Madam President, a respected colleague, I am pleased that you have asked a question about the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative. You concluded well that Member States facing the highest rates of youth unemployment and most affected by the crisis are largely lagging behind in the use of youth employment initiative funds and the implementation of the Youth Guarantee scheme. Croatia is suffering a recession for the sixth year, the youth unemployment rate has approached 40%, which according to Eurostat data is the second highest youth unemployment rate in Europe, young people are leaving looking for work in other Member States, and the Government has not used a single euro from this Initiative until February 2015.  You also asked: How does the Council intend to encourage swift and effective implementation in the short term? I am of the opinion that the Council can hardly encourage the work of incompetent governments. This change can only be made by voters in the Member States.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Dear Madam President, although it has been more than a year since the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative, the results at local level are far from expected. I am of the opinion that we need to make effective use not only of the financial instruments available, but also of the much-needed educational reforms. The lasting solution to this problem goes through educational changes that offer a variety of forms of non-formal learning, focus on practical experience and stimulate the entrepreneurial spirit and innovative thinking of young people. Last but not least, I believe that youth employment schemes need to adapt to the specific problems of the Member States. In Bulgaria, for example, one of the most serious challenges continues to be the difficult transition from school to employment. Furthermore, in the context of the demographic crisis, in my country the emigration of highly qualified professionals continues to increase. The Council must not only monitor the rapid and efficient implementation of the programme, but also be well aware of the problems and difficulties faced by Member States and act.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me use this opportunity to signal once again the high political importance of the Youth Employment Initiative and to thank Parliament for the very fruitful cooperation that allowed us to react promptly to the challenge of youth unemployment. Members have asked what is holding Member States back. At this point in time, it is still difficult to fully assess the actual progress on the ground, as the reporting cycle at EU level has not yet started. Aside from the financial liquidity issue, which is the most pressing one, I could refer to three other challenges to the sufficiently speedy mobilisation and uptake of Youth Employment Initiative measures: firstly, some Member States lack the implementing structures; secondly, there is the matter of finalising the designation of competent authorities, which has also been emphasised by some Member States; and, thirdly, there are a number of issues related to the administrative capacity of the national, regional and local structures implementing Youth Employment Initiative measures.  So how does the Council intend to urgently encourage swift and efficient implementation? The Council considers, in line with the European Parliament, that sufficient liquidity will also allow for a faster implementation of the relevant policy measures set out in the national Youth Guarantee implementation plans. The new proposal to increase pre-financing should contribute to a quicker mobilisation of resources and thus to increasing the capacity of national authorities to launch calls for projects and to process applications more speedily. The additional pre-financing will be paid to Member States immediately after the entry into force of the amending regulation. A positive impact could be expected soon. On the other hand, the implementation of the Youth Guarantee requires both structural reforms and measures targeting individuals. Member States are currently implementing a mix of national youth employment policies on the basis of their individual needs and priorities, with the Youth Guarantee Scheme representing one of these measures. All relevant Member States have submitted their Youth Guarantee implementation plans and the implementation at national level is being regularly monitored by the Council, based on contributions from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs in a multilateral and indicator-based process. Exchange of experience between Member States is also important, as well as impact evaluation of the measures carried out.  To conclude, I would like to underline that Member States are currently in the process of submitting structured data reports on the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative. These reports will provide an overview, also limited, of the progress made by Member States in the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative, which will feed into the Commission’s analysis of further measures and into the regular monitoring by the Council.  Effective monitoring is thus one of the preconditions of successful implementation and continuity of sound funding. In this respect the Council, on the basis of the work of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, is pursuing a multilateral surveillance on implementation and undertaking a peer review on the progress in the implementation of the reforms addressed in the country-specific recommendations.  Last but not least, based on the experience of 2014 and with little improvement of the youth employment figures in some of the hardest-hit Member States, it can be expected that this issue will be addressed in the framework of the 2015 European Semester debate. In any case, the Council will discuss this issue in more detail at the June session in conjunction with a special report of the Court of Auditors. Member States will also have to further strengthen their efforts, focus on implementing relevant structural reforms and deliver quality measures to enable young people to participate in the labour market, training or education. These will also be very important measures. To sum up, the Council shares the view that more needs to be done to fight youth unemployment. I have just mentioned a few examples of measures underway in the Council and the Commission with the aim to make the system more effective. I cannot promise Members a miracle solution tomorrow, but I can firmly say that hard work is being done to find a solution as soon as possible.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The European Youth Employment Initiative was created in 2013. At the time, youth unemployment in the Europe of 28 was around 23%. Almost two years later, in October 2014, the average youth unemployment in the Eurozone was also around 23%. In other words, an initiative in which, by 2020, we will give EUR 6 billion, has so far brought poor, if not minimal, results. Youth unemployment continues to gallop. In the countries of the European south, more than 40% of young people, and in Greece in particular, about 50% are unemployed. This tragic phenomenon was further exacerbated during the years of crisis and austerity. This clearly shows that the measures imposed by the dominant political and social forces in the European Union not only do not break the deadlock, but plunge us deeper into it. Finally, what do we think is the future of an ever-ageing Europe where its educated and capable youth are left untapped? We need to create the conditions for growth by strengthening the real economy, which in turn will create employment opportunities.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I believe that, in her question, Mrs Ulvskog raised an important issue. I would like to point out that the problem of under-util use of funds, or not very quickly enough, concerns not only the Youth Guarantee instrument, but also cohesion policy resources in general. We should therefore consider what the cause is and how we can remedy it. I believe that increasing and accelerating the absorption of resources can be ensured by simplifying procedures as much as possible. In addition, it is worth considering additional support from the Commission, both information and technical, which could make it easier for Member States and beneficiaries to raise and use funds. Let us bear in mind that the Youth Guarantee is a unique aid measure designed to rapidly improve the dramatic situation on the labour market. I therefore call on the Commission, above all, to be flexible and proactive.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Parliament approved the decision to increase the pre-financing of the European Social Fund in order to support Member States in their fight against youth unemployment. While one can only admire this decision, and this desire for rapid implementation does not solve the pre-existing problems: EU rules on budget deficits still prevent states from advancing funds, no impact assessment has been made and the overall cost of this implementation is still not known, the Commission's monitoring of the scheme is still wobbly and there is still no guarantee that the funds promised will be guaranteed. will be unlocked by the EU. The real weakness of the Union is not a lack of pre-financing or speed, it is the absence of a real employment policy, support for the Member States, it is the socio-economic failure of European policies. The only solution, we cannot repeat enough, is to protect our productions from social dumping, to practice wise protectionism at the level of each Member State and to enable them to take the necessary measures to create jobs and get out of the crisis. Only then can we help young people.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. The case of the youth employment initiative is, unfortunately, an exemplary demonstration that, unless there is a clear and effective plan for how to structure a public policy, its funding, even a large one, is not enough. Work is not only created by putting liquidity into the system, but also by completely rethinking our employment system, especially in the part of access to work but also in training and vocational guidance. This is too important to be left to the individual States: there should be guidelines that are the same for everyone, at European level, that will allow the most effective use of the funding that the Union provides under the IOG. Every policy, but above all those relating to employment, should be followed by an assessment which will make it possible to identify their strengths and weaknesses, so that they can act on them. All the more so on such a central policy, such as the policy on combating youth unemployment, we must begin to do so.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – We era see Europe as the project of working people. Because only real employment can lead to the other things we aspire to – social inclusion, political engagement and professional activity. However, the future of Europe as a project of workers is highly threatened, given the statistics that 15.4% of young people in Europe between the ages of 15 and 29 are out of employment or education. In the face of the danger that in some countries we may have a lost future generation that may fall out of the social network, the EC and the EP have approved funding under the Youth Employment Initiative of EUR 1 billion for 2015 alone. I would therefore like to point out that this decision is particularly important and it unties the hands of national governments to use this fund. I hope that they will all spend these funds wisely, with a clear plan and look for a real effect. In a year's time, we all have to take into account what we have achieved. To make sure that in 20 years there will be someone to run Europe's economy.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Europe is facing social problems, on the one hand, related to ageing populations, as well as difficulties in the context of young people taking up work. This situation is recognised by The Member States, which are taking individual action in this area. In addition to national support for youth employment, Member States can also benefit from the European Social Fund (ESF) and the funds allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative in the context of the 2014-2020 financial framework. The problem of youth unemployment is very complex and its causes are different in different Member States. In view of the different severity of the problem from country to country and the significant differences in efficiency with which actions are implemented, particular attention should be paid to the cases where support is most needed and to those where it is least effective. Young people are the future of the EU, so as many actors as possible , both public and private, should be involved in efforts to enable them to get off to a good start in their working lives.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Both as a Romanian MEP and as a representative of the young Social Democrats in Romania, I know that young Europeans have remained in a period of crisis. If Europe has largely overcome the period of unjustified austerity and the economic and financial crisis, young Europeans are today in an identity crisis. Unemployment, although it has started to be reduced within certain Member States, is still high enough to ask ourselves serious questions about the future of Europe. The European Youth Initiative, built on the framework of the European Youth Guarantee, proposed by S&D and PES, needs shock measures to deliver better results. Emergency funding for assistance measures for young people in Member States where unemployment is high among this category is very important. We want, within four months of the end of the last form of education or the unemployment of any young European, to have the necessary tools to offer him a job, a specialisation and training programme, an internship or an apprenticeship programme. If we want to push the accelerator, it is good to do so now, through pre-financing funds allocated by the Commission under the European Youth Initiative.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Council's statement on Japanese whaling in Antarctica (2015/2702 (RSP)).

name: n/a
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, the last point in today’s agenda: Japanese whaling activities in the Antarctic. The issue of Japanese whaling activities in the Antarctic is not new, but it gained new prominence in 2010 when Australia filed an application with the International Court of Justice against Japanʼs programme called JARPA II.  In its application, Australia contested the legality of JARPA II as being incompatible with the International Convention on the Regulation of Whaling. The International Court delivered its judgment on 31 March 2014 and found against Japan on a number of counts. We read this judgment with great interest, as we consider it offers a definitive interpretation of the Convention and its Schedule, and clarifies the legal framework for scientific whaling. It is an important milestone for all contracting governments to the International Whaling Commission (IWC), certainly when it comes to assessing the necessity of having recourse to lethal methods of sampling where non-lethal alternatives exist. The Presidency, at that time, on behalf of the EU and its Member States, expressed this view at the meeting of the International Whaling Commission held in September 2014, in Portorož, in Slovenia. We supported the adoption of Resolution 2014-5, called ‘Whaling under Special Permit’, which offers, among other elements, directions for the Scientific Committee to consider when assessing new and existing special permit research programmes. Yesterday, the IWC Scientific Committee began its meeting in San Diego. Japan has submitted a proposal for a new special permit research programme in the Antarctic Ocean, which is currently being reviewed under what is known as the ʽAnnex P processʼ. The findings of the Expert Panel set up by the Scientific Committee will be reviewed and the Scientific Committee should make a recommendation to the IWC. The European Union and its Member States have always favoured an approach that would preserve both the independence of the Scientific Committee, as a scientific forum, and the policy prerogatives of the IWC as the ultimate decision-making authority under the International Convention. Under this approach, policy matters should not be discussed in San Diego.  We remain ready to engage politically with Japan at the appropriate level and in the appropriate forum, once the Scientific Committee has issued its recommendations to the International Whaling Commission.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – A year ago, we voted here without a vote against the resolution concerning the negotiations for the conclusion of the Strategic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Japan. It is used to identify a number of areas of strategic cooperation, including in the fields of science, the environment, climate change and fish stock management.  It seems to me right to place the issue of kitolyl, following a clear judgment of the International Court of Justice and japan's response to it, also as part of efforts to conclude this agreement, in which one of the fundamental starting points is respect and enforcement of the principles of international law. I assume that the European Union and Japan share an opinion on the importance of biodiversity in a global context.  I expect Japan, like other countries whose fishermen are still fishing for whales, will not only follow the decision of the International Court of Justice, but will regulate its scientific interest in whales in accordance with international rules, the growing awareness of whale threats and the attention to the 2012 European Parliament resolution in which we advocated the end of whales for scientific purposes.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I come from a geographical area known for the Cetaceans Sanctuary, an international marine area characterised by a significant ecological presence of these mammals. I shall not dwell further on the importance of their protection recognised by the European Union, which prohibits their capture. But that's not the case everywhere. Japan has announced that it will resume its programme of killing whales in Antarctica for scientific reasons, despite a ruling by the International Court of Justice in The Hague which just a year ago considered it necessary to suspend this practice because it lacked scientific purposes, not least because – let us face it – the so-called scientific evidence often ended up on the shelves of Japanese supermarkets. Yes, let us not hide behind a finger: behind scientific research we want to disguise a purely commercial activity.  Japan's intention, therefore, is clearly at odds with the international moratorium on commercial hunting of sea giants imposed in 1986 by the International Whaling Commission, a body set up to protect cetaceans at risk of extinction. We cannot stand by and allow this slaughter to take place again with the complicit silence of the institutions. Europe is opposed without ifs and buts. Trade agreements between the EU and Japan are now being discussed. Well, I believe that, even in that agreement, Europe must be more ambitious and must impose as a condition the cessation of practices that can be counted as illegal fishing.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, in 1986 the International Whaling Commission adopted a ban on commercial whaling for very good reasons: whales are endangered. However, since then over 30 000 whales have been killed and Japan has contributed to this massacre, because it is one of only three countries continuing to hunt whales.  It justifies this under scientific research, but the rest of the world has always seen this as an excuse to continue whale hunting for food. The ICJ ruled this March that there was a lack of scientific merit in Japan’s whale hunting programs, yet, since the court’s ruling, Japan has announced another 12-year whaling program. It is truly horrifying that Japan continues such practices with no sign of scientific reports; there are just no excuses for the killing of whales. If it must study, Japan should carry out non-lethal research and stop killing highly endangered species. It is possible and rewarding and much more productive. Japan has plenty of other meat to eat, and as the Japanese have become better informed the demand for whale meat has plummeted, but still Japan continues to subsidise this killing. We and the international community must discourage these barbaric acts. I thank the Council for its actions to get Japan to stop these barbaric practices. The EU trades with Japan and has ties with Japan. What next, then, does the Council plan to say to Japan? Stop now or suffer the consequences?

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Whales have been protected for 50 years and an international ban on commercial whaling has been in place since the 1980s. And now, almost 30 years later, there are still countries that have failed to comply with that ban, such as Iceland, Norway and Japan. They hunt under false pretenses, killing 1 500 whales every year. And what has Europe done to prevent these crimes? Nothing.  It is time for Europe to act. Many cetaceans are threatened and will die out if we do nothing now. Moreover, whale hunting is nothing short of gruesome. Japanese whalers chase the animals into the icy waters of the Southern Ocean and then shoot a harpoon into their bodies. A long and gruesome death struggle ensues. Then there is another point. In Taiji, Japan, many thousands of dolphins are chased into a bay every year, driven together and killed. A great massacre is the result! I would welcome the Council's clear position, as the Netherlands has already done in the fight against whaling, for example. Whaling must stop, and it can, if Europe exerts pressure on Japan through its trade policy. And then you are not going to continue negotiating a trade treaty, because countries that are leaving animals to die out to make money, they do not deserve support.  I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is important that nations such as Japan respect the judgments of the International Court of Justice, especially on matters involving the management of common goods. The Court's ruling was clear: Japan's whaling in Antarctica has no scientific purpose and is in fact illegal.  Japan's proposal to resume whalery is no different from the previous programme and is therefore contrary in form and spirit to the court's judgment. Experts from the International Whaling Commission have also stated that the new request submitted by Japan is not scientifically justified. This Parliament must urge the Commission and all the Member States to make it clear to the Japanese Government that we expect it to comply fully with the court's rulings and the decisions of the International Whaling Commission and, of course, there must be no resumption of whaling in Antarctica next season. With a view to Japan's candidacy for the Security Council, Japan itself should set a good example and desist from any action contrary to the international order.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, Japan is in violation of international law which has prohibited commercial whaling since 1986. He continues to practice this hunt by claiming that it is a scientific hunt. Its objective would be to study the age of whales to discover their reproductive rate. This is not credible, because you do not have to kill whales to study them, you can simply observe them by satellite or with underwater cameras. In reality, Japan is laughing at us. It is indeed a commercial hunt that he practices. He killed 11,000 whales between 1987 and 2013 to eat them. The International Court of Justice ordered Japan on 31 March 2014 to stop whaling in Antarctica. Japan has obeyed for a year, but has just announced that it will kill 333 whales in Antarctica in 2015. There is an urgent need to put pressure on Japan to comply with international law. We must protect the whales that, according to the Cuban writer Enrique Serpa, embody the strength in the protean world of the sea.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I think we are all outraged that these protections for whales have been in place for 30 years and that Japan simply does not comply with them. This is a very, very bad example of trust and also of solidarity for the protection of species and natural capital, and I wonder what more needs to happen to stop Japan. The question, of course, goes to the Council and the Commission: what are we doing now? Keep watching, continuing to listen, or are we intervening? With the political and economic pressure that the European Union can exert, we would certainly find other partners in the world.  The scientific programme is clearly a pretext. Most whales end up in the supermarket and not in the laboratories. We know that, and yet we are always comforted – from programme 1, from programme 2. Now we are in programme 3, and the cynical thing is that 81 more whales are killed in programme 3 than in programme 2. So obviously the need for "science" has increased considerably, although one has other methods.  We are running out of patience and we are calling on the EU to take more drastic action against Japan now!

name: Stefan ECK
