text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The later the evening, the more interested the listeners. The hall is almost empty, but it is all about animals! But on the subject: Japan is supposedly hunting whales for scientific purposes. In 2014, the International Court of Justice ruled that Japan must stop whaling because it is not for scientific purposes. The Japanese want to resume whale hunting in Antarctica this year. The catch quota is even to be increased: from 252 to 333 minkwale. Most hunted whale species are now threatened in their population. It is a disgrace that, in view of this fact, Japan and two other states are simply continuing stubbornly. Because when these majestic marine mammals disappear from the world stage, the earth has miraculously become poorer. I would like to quote my friend, Captain Paul Watson, of Sea Shepherd: 'First the sea dies, then man dies'. The European Council has a duty to make every effort to ensure that Japan gives up whaling, and does so completely.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, the matter of whaling activities in Japan is absolutely not of subsidiary importance and cannot be left out in our talks with Japan. Our reason is that the protection of biodiversity and of the environment is at the core of our European principles and values and, if we do not want to be called irresponsible, incoherent and weak, we must always take this into consideration in our relationship with other countries.  This is a matter of having the holistic ambitious and far-sighted view that we owe to European citizens and to the entire world population. Moreover, I believe we must think twice before skipping talks on important matters and before engaging with a partner that does not respect international law. Japan must comply with the spirit and the letter of the International Court of Justice ruling and refrain from further whaling activities in the Antarctic until such time as the International Whaling Commission gives a contrary opinion – all the more so given our shared interest in the rules—based international order and effective multilateralism. I do not understand nor support the exclusion of an environmental interest in our talks with Japan. We should honestly represent our citizens’ concerns, make their voices heard and solve this issue once and for all. I therefore strongly invite Vice—President Mogherini to raise this issue at the upcoming EU-Japan Summit on 29 May.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, as a scientist, as a Member and a citizen, I accept hunting and fishing even in cases contrary to my culture, but Japanese whaling, made under scientific pseudo-research, is not permissible. There are opinions of reputable scientists, issued under the aegis of the International Whaling Commission, which point to the lack of scientific basis for Japanese hunting. At the same time, the southernmost area of our planet should be a place of peace and scientific research, as stated in the Antarctic Treaty.  I would also like to point out that what happens every year with marine mammals in Taiji City, Japan, is unacceptable. The use of animals for human consumption will never justify their torture, neither in Japan nor anywhere. For this reason, Japan was expelled from the World Association of Zoos and Aquariums. In the Azores, Portugal, whaling has long been abandoned and replaced by a lucrative cetacean watching activity in the wild. This is the way and the only way forward in relation to the great cetaceans.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Madam President, respect for the decision of the international court is a matter of lawful conduct in international relations. Non-compliance with the decisions of international authorities is the exact opposite of that. Although the international court banned whaling for commercial purposes, it left the possibility of harvesting for scientific purposes. It is a crack that allows Japan, but also Norway and Iceland, to continue "controlled whale hunting under the guise of science". This crack has grown over the years into a legal loophole through which not only one whale can get through, but more than 10,000 can pass because that's exactly how many have been found. The question is whether Japan, like Norway and Iceland, will find a way not to abuse the good faith of the rest of the international community like its international partners, who have enabled it to continue the so-called "controlled catch".  Our problem, the Problem of the European Union, is how we will react to the violation of the decision of the international court. Ignoring the problem will not help either whales, Japan or international law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, although commercial whaling has been banned internationally since 1986, Japanese whaling has continued to exterminate 1000 whales each year, using the loopholes in international whaling law for "alleged" scientific purposes. A year ago, the International Court of Justice in The Hague, in a leading ruling, banned whaling, ruling that the JARPA II scientific programme was a showcase for Japan to continue commercial whaling. Now Japan is trying to get an exemption for the coming fishing season from the International Whaling Commission, to continue under the cloak of "supposedly" scientific research for whaling purposes, while, in practice, what it is doing is to proceed to whaling for commercial purposes in Antarctica. And that is something that the international community should not allow. For this reason, the European Union must take decisive measures to stop Japanese whaling in Antarctica.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the EU and its Member States are strongly committed to the protection of whales. As I mentioned in my introductory remarks, the International Court of Justice (ICJ) Judgment of March 2014 has, in our opinion, offered the definitive interpretation of the Convention and the schedule when it comes to scientific whaling. It is expected that the Scientific Committee, following Resolution 2014-5, will also put forward a proposal to the International Whaling Commission (IWC) on the update of the Annex P procedure in order to fully take into account the findings of the ICJ in its judgment. We are following these developments closely and remain ready to engage with all other IWC parties in discussing how best to enhance the conservation status of whales worldwide and how to bring all whaling operations within the IWC.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – I am strongly opposed to the hunting of cetaceans (whales, dolphins, and porpoises). I believe the hunting of these creatures involves unacceptable cruelty and that well-managed, responsible tourism is the only truly sustainable use of these animals. I therefore strongly support the maintenance of the International Whaling Commission’s global moratorium on commercial whaling. Japan is legally bound by the IWC moratorium yet carries out large-scale whaling for so called ‘scientific research’. There is no valid scientific or other reason for these hunts and I urge Japan to cease its activities immediately. Japan does great harm to its reputation by carrying on these hunts and is undermining the global moratorium on commercial whaling.
